He was ever dusting his old lexicons and grammars, with a queer"][[0 30 3] "handkerchief, mockingly embellished with all the gay flags of all"][[0 30 4] "the known nations of the world. He loved to dust his old grammars; it"][[0 30 5] "somehow mildly reminded him of his mortality."][[0 31 1] "\"While you take in hand to school others, and to teach them by what"][[0 31 2] "name a whale-fish is to be called in our tongue leaving out, through"][[0 31 3] "ignorance, the letter H, which almost alone maketh the signification of"][[0 31 4] "the word, you deliver that which is not true.\" --HACKLUYT"][[0 32 1] "\"WHALE.... Therefore you must not, in every case at least, take the"][[0 39 6] "higgledy-piggledy whale statements, however authentic, in these"][[0 39 7] "extracts, for veritable gospel cetology. Far from it. As touching the"][[0 39 8] "ancient authors generally, as well as the poets here appearing, these"][[0 39 9] "extracts are solely valuable or entertaining, as affording a glancing"][[0 39 10] "bird's eye view of what has been promiscuously said, thought, fancied,"][[0 39 11] "and sung of Leviathan, by many nations and generations, including our"][[0 39 12] "own."][[0 40 1] "So fare thee well, poor devil of a Sub-Sub, whose commentator I am. Thou"][[0 40 2] "belongest to that hopeless, sallow tribe which no wine of this world"][[0 40 3] "will ever warm; and for whom even Pale Sherry would be too rosy-strong;"][[0 40 4] "but with whom one sometimes loves to sit, and feel poor-devilish, too;"][[0 40 5] "and grow convivial upon tears; and say to them bluntly, with full eyes"][[0 40 6] "and empty glasses, and in not altogether unpleasant sadness--Give it up,"][[0 40 7] "Sub-Subs! For by how much the more pains ye take to please the world,"][[0 40 8] "by so much the more shall ye for ever go thankless! Would that I could"][[0 40 9] "clear out Hampton Court and the Tuileries for ye! But gulp down your"][[0 40 10] "tears and hie aloft to the royal-mast with your hearts; for your friends"][[0 40 11] "who have gone before are clearing out the seven-storied heavens, and"][[0 40 12] "making refugees of long-pampered Gabriel, Michael, and Raphael, against"][[0 40 13] "your coming. Here ye strike but splintered hearts together--there, ye"][[0 40 14] "shall strike unsplinterable glasses!"][[0 41 1] "EXTRACTS."][[0 42 1] "\"And God created great whales.\" --GENESIS."][[0 43 1] "\"Leviathan maketh a path to shine after him; One would think the deep to"][[0 43 2] "be hoary.\" --JOB."][[0 44 1] "\"Now the Lord had prepared a great fish to swallow up Jonah.\" --JONAH."][[0 45 1] "\"There go the ships; there is that Leviathan whom thou hast made to play"][[0 45 2] "therein.\" --PSALMS."][[0 46 1] "\"In that day, the Lord with his sore, and great, and strong sword,"][[0 46 2] "shall punish Leviathan the piercing serpent, even Leviathan that crooked"][[0 46 3] "serpent; and he shall slay the dragon that is in the sea.\" --ISAIAH"][[0 47 1] "\"And what thing soever besides cometh within the chaos of this monster's"][[0 47 2] "mouth, be it beast, boat, or stone, down it goes all incontinently that"][[0 47 3] "foul great swallow of his, and perisheth in the bottomless gulf of his"][[0 47 4] "paunch.\" --HOLLAND'S PLUTARCH'S MORALS."][[0 48 1] "\"The Indian Sea breedeth the most and the biggest fishes that are: among"][[0 48 2] "which the Whales and Whirlpooles called Balaene, take up as much in"][[0 48 3] "length as four acres or arpens of land.\" --HOLLAND'S PLINY."][[0 49 1] "\"Scarcely had we proceeded two days on the sea, when about sunrise a"][[0 49 2] "great many Whales and other monsters of the sea, appeared. Loomings."][[1 2 1] "Call me Ishmael. Some years ago--never mind how long precisely--having"][[1 2 2] "little or no money in my purse, and nothing particular to interest me on"][[1 2 3] "shore, I thought I would sail about a little and see the watery part of"][[1 2 4] "the world. It is a way I have of driving off the spleen and regulating"][[1 2 5] "the circulation. Whenever I find myself growing grim about the mouth;"][[1 2 6] "whenever it is a damp, drizzly November in my soul; whenever I find"][[1 2 7] "myself involuntarily pausing before coffin warehouses, and bringing up"][[1 2 8] "the rear of every funeral I meet; and especially whenever my hypos get"][[1 2 9] "such an upper hand of me, that it requires a strong moral principle to"][[1 2 10] "prevent me from deliberately stepping into the street, and methodically"][[1 2 11] "knocking people's hats off--then, I account it high time to get to sea"][[1 2 12] "as soon as I can. This is my substitute for pistol and ball. With a"][[1 2 13] "philosophical flourish Cato throws himself upon his sword; I quietly"][[1 2 14] "take to the ship. There is nothing surprising in this. If they but knew"][[1 2 15] "it, almost all men in their degree, some time or other, cherish very"][[1 2 16] "nearly the same feelings towards the ocean with me."][[1 3 1] "There now is your insular city of the Manhattoes, belted round by"][[1 3 2] "wharves as Indian isles by coral reefs--commerce surrounds it with"][[1 3 3] "her surf. Right and left, the streets take you waterward. Its extreme"][[1 3 4] "downtown is the battery, where that noble mole is washed by waves, and"][[1 3 5] "cooled by breezes, which a few hours previous were out of sight of land."][[1 3 6] "Look at the crowds of water-gazers there."][[1 4 1] "Circumambulate the city of a dreamy Sabbath afternoon. Go from Corlears"][[1 4 2] "Hook to Coenties Slip, and from thence, by Whitehall, northward. What"][[1 4 3] "do you see?--Posted like silent sentinels all around the town, stand"][[1 4 4] "thousands upon thousands of mortal men fixed in ocean reveries. Some"][[1 4 5] "leaning against the spiles; some seated upon the pier-heads; some"][[1 4 6] "looking over the bulwarks of ships from China; some high aloft in the"][[1 4 7] "rigging, as if striving to get a still better seaward peep. But these"][[1 4 8] "are all landsmen; of week days pent up in lath and plaster--tied to"][[1 4 9] "counters, nailed to benches, clinched to desks. How then is this? Are"][[1 4 10] "the green fields gone? What do they here?"][[1 5 1] "But look! here come more crowds, pacing straight for the water, and"][[1 5 2] "seemingly bound for a dive. Strange! Nothing will content them but the"][[1 5 3] "extremest limit of the land; loitering under the shady lee of yonder"][[1 5 4] "warehouses will not suffice. No. They must get just as nigh the water"][[1 5 5] "as they possibly can without falling in. And there they stand--miles of"][[1 5 6] "them--leagues. Inlanders all, they come from lanes and alleys, streets"][[1 5 7] "and avenues--north, east, south, and west. Yet here they all unite."][[1 5 8] "Tell me, does the magnetic virtue of the needles of the compasses of all"][[1 5 9] "those ships attract them thither?"][[1 6 1] "Once more. Say you are in the country; in some high land of lakes. Take"][[1 6 2] "almost any path you please, and ten to one it carries you down in a"][[1 6 3] "dale, and leaves you there by a pool in the stream. There is magic"][[1 6 4] "in it. Let the most absent-minded of men be plunged in his deepest"][[1 6 5] "reveries--stand that man on his legs, set his feet a-going, and he will"][[1 6 6] "infallibly lead you to water, if water there be in all that region."][[1 6 7] "Should you ever be athirst in the great American desert, try this"][[1 6 8] "experiment, if your caravan happen to be supplied with a metaphysical"][[1 6 9] "professor. Yes, as every one knows, meditation and water are wedded for"][[1 6 10] "ever."][[1 7 1] "But here is an artist. He desires to paint you the dreamiest, shadiest,"][[1 7 2] "quietest, most enchanting bit of romantic landscape in all the valley of"][[1 7 3] "the Saco. What is the chief element he employs? There stand his trees,"][[1 7 4] "each with a hollow trunk, as if a hermit and a crucifix were within; and"][[1 7 5] "here sleeps his meadow, and there sleep his cattle; and up from yonder"][[1 7 6] "cottage goes a sleepy smoke. Deep into distant woodlands winds a"][[1 7 7] "mazy way, reaching to overlapping spurs of mountains bathed in their"][[1 7 8] "hill-side blue. But though the picture lies thus tranced, and though"][[1 7 9] "this pine-tree shakes down its sighs like leaves upon this shepherd's"][[1 7 10] "head, yet all were vain, unless the shepherd's eye were fixed upon the"][[1 7 11] "magic stream before him. Go visit the Prairies in June, when for scores"][[1 7 12] "on scores of miles you wade knee-deep among Tiger-lilies--what is the"][[1 7 13] "one charm wanting?--Water--there is not a drop of water there! Were"][[1 7 14] "Niagara but a cataract of sand, would you travel your thousand miles to"][[1 7 15] "see it? Why did the poor poet of Tennessee, upon suddenly receiving two"][[1 7 16] "handfuls of silver, deliberate whether to buy him a coat, which he sadly"][[1 7 17] "needed, or invest his money in a pedestrian trip to Rockaway Beach? Why"][[1 7 18] "is almost every robust healthy boy with a robust healthy soul in him, at"][[1 7 19] "some time or other crazy to go to sea? Why upon your first voyage as a"][[1 7 20] "passenger, did you yourself feel such a mystical vibration, when first"][[1 7 21] "told that you and your ship were now out of sight of land? Why did the"][[1 7 22] "old Persians hold the sea holy? Why did the Greeks give it a separate"][[1 7 23] "deity, and own brother of Jove? Surely all this is not without meaning."][[1 7 24] "And still deeper the meaning of that story of Narcissus, who because"][[1 7 25] "he could not grasp the tormenting, mild image he saw in the fountain,"][[1 7 26] "plunged into it and was drowned. But that same image, we ourselves see"][[1 7 27] "in all rivers and oceans. It is the image of the ungraspable phantom of"][[1 7 28] "life; and this is the key to it all."][[1 8 1] "Now, when I say that I am in the habit of going to sea whenever I begin"][[1 8 2] "to grow hazy about the eyes, and begin to be over conscious of my lungs,"][[1 8 3] "I do not mean to have it inferred that I ever go to sea as a passenger."][[1 8 4] "For to go as a passenger you must needs have a purse, and a purse is"][[1 8 5] "but a rag unless you have something in it. Besides, passengers get"][[1 8 6] "sea-sick--grow quarrelsome--don't sleep of nights--do not enjoy"][[1 8 7] "themselves much, as a general thing;--no, I never go as a passenger;"][[1 8 8] "nor, though I am something of a salt, do I ever go to sea as a"][[1 8 9] "Commodore, or a Captain, or a Cook. I abandon the glory and distinction"][[1 8 10] "of such offices to those who like them. For my part, I abominate all"][[1 8 11] "honourable respectable toils, trials, and tribulations of every kind"][[1 8 12] "whatsoever. It is quite as much as I can do to take care of myself,"][[1 8 13] "without taking care of ships, barques, brigs, schooners, and what not."][[1 8 14] "And as for going as cook,--though I confess there is considerable glory"][[1 8 15] "in that, a cook being a sort of officer on ship-board--yet, somehow,"][[1 8 16] "I never fancied broiling fowls;--though once broiled, judiciously"][[1 8 17] "buttered, and judgmatically salted and peppered, there is no one who"][[1 8 18] "will speak more respectfully, not to say reverentially, of a broiled"][[1 8 19] "fowl than I will. It is out of the idolatrous dotings of the old"][[1 8 20] "Egyptians upon broiled ibis and roasted river horse, that you see the"][[1 8 21] "mummies of those creatures in their huge bake-houses the pyramids."][[1 9 1] "No, when I go to sea, I go as a simple sailor, right before the mast,"][[1 9 2] "plumb down into the forecastle, aloft there to the royal mast-head."][[1 9 3] "True, they rather order me about some, and make me jump from spar to"][[1 9 4] "spar, like a grasshopper in a May meadow. And at first, this sort"][[1 9 5] "of thing is unpleasant enough. It touches one's sense of honour,"][[1 9 6] "particularly if you come of an old established family in the land, the"][[1 9 7] "Van Rensselaers, or Randolphs, or Hardicanutes. And more than all,"][[1 9 8] "if just previous to putting your hand into the tar-pot, you have been"][[1 9 9] "lording it as a country schoolmaster, making the tallest boys stand"][[1 9 10] "in awe of you. The transition is a keen one, I assure you, from a"][[1 9 11] "schoolmaster to a sailor, and requires a strong decoction of Seneca and"][[1 9 12] "the Stoics to enable you to grin and bear it. But even this wears off in"][[1 9 13] "time."][[1 10 1] "What of it, if some old hunks of a sea-captain orders me to get a broom"][[1 10 2] "and sweep down the decks? What does that indignity amount to, weighed,"][[1 10 3] "I mean, in the scales of the New Testament? Do you think the archangel"][[1 10 4] "Gabriel thinks anything the less of me, because I promptly and"][[1 10 5] "respectfully obey that old hunks in that particular instance? Who ain't"][[1 10 6] "a slave? Tell me that. Well, then, however the old sea-captains may"][[1 10 7] "order me about--however they may thump and punch me about, I have the"][[1 10 8] "satisfaction of knowing that it is all right; that everybody else is"][[1 10 9] "one way or other served in much the same way--either in a physical"][[1 10 10] "or metaphysical point of view, that is; and so the universal thump is"][[1 10 11] "passed round, and all hands should rub each other's shoulder-blades, and"][[1 10 12] "be content."][[1 11 1] "Again, I always go to sea as a sailor, because they make a point of"][[1 11 2] "paying me for my trouble, whereas they never pay passengers a single"][[1 11 3] "penny that I ever heard of. On the contrary, passengers themselves must"][[1 11 4] "pay. And there is all the difference in the world between paying"][[1 11 5] "and being paid. The act of paying is perhaps the most uncomfortable"][[1 11 6] "infliction that the two orchard thieves entailed upon us. But BEING"][[1 11 7] "PAID,--what will compare with it? The urbane activity with which a man"][[1 11 8] "receives money is really marvellous, considering that we so earnestly"][[1 11 9] "believe money to be the root of all earthly ills, and that on no account"][[1 11 10] "can a monied man enter heaven. Ah! how cheerfully we consign ourselves"][[1 11 11] "to perdition!"][[1 12 1] "Finally, I always go to sea as a sailor, because of the wholesome"][[1 12 2] "exercise and pure air of the fore-castle deck. For as in this world,"][[1 12 3] "head winds are far more prevalent than winds from astern (that is,"][[1 12 4] "if you never violate the Pythagorean maxim), so for the most part the"][[1 12 5] "Commodore on the quarter-deck gets his atmosphere at second hand from"][[1 12 6] "the sailors on the forecastle. He thinks he breathes it first; but not"][[1 12 7] "so. In much the same way do the commonalty lead their leaders in many"][[1 12 8] "other things, at the same time that the leaders little suspect it."][[1 12 9] "But wherefore it was that after having repeatedly smelt the sea as a"][[1 12 10] "merchant sailor, I should now take it into my head to go on a whaling"][[1 12 11] "voyage; this the invisible police officer of the Fates, who has the"][[1 12 12] "constant surveillance of me, and secretly dogs me, and influences me"][[1 12 13] "in some unaccountable way--he can better answer than any one else. And,"][[1 12 14] "doubtless, my going on this whaling voyage, formed part of the grand"][[1 12 15] "programme of Providence that was drawn up a long time ago. It came in as"][[1 12 16] "a sort of brief interlude and solo between more extensive performances."][[1 12 17] "I take it that this part of the bill must have run something like this:"][[1 14 1] "\"GRAND CONTESTED ELECTION FOR THE PRESIDENCY OF THE UNITED STATES."][[1 15 1] "\"WHALING VOYAGE BY ONE ISHMAEL."][[1 16 1] "\"BLOODY BATTLE IN AFFGHANISTAN.\""][[1 18 1] "Though I cannot tell why it was exactly that those stage managers, the"][[1 18 2] "Fates, put me down for this shabby part of a whaling voyage, when others"][[1 18 3] "were set down for magnificent parts in high tragedies, and short and"][[1 18 4] "easy parts in genteel comedies, and jolly parts in farces--though"][[1 18 5] "I cannot tell why this was exactly; yet, now that I recall all the"][[1 18 6] "circumstances, I think I can see a little into the springs and motives"][[1 18 7] "which being cunningly presented to me under various disguises, induced"][[1 18 8] "me to set about performing the part I did, besides cajoling me into the"][[1 18 9] "delusion that it was a choice resulting from my own unbiased freewill"][[1 18 10] "and discriminating judgment."][[1 19 1] "Chief among these motives was the overwhelming idea of the great"][[1 19 2] "whale himself. Such a portentous and mysterious monster roused all my"][[1 19 3] "curiosity. Then the wild and distant seas where he rolled his island"][[1 19 4] "bulk; the undeliverable, nameless perils of the whale; these, with all"][[1 19 5] "the attending marvels of a thousand Patagonian sights and sounds, helped"][[1 19 6] "to sway me to my wish. With other men, perhaps, such things would not"][[1 19 7] "have been inducements; but as for me, I am tormented with an everlasting"][[1 19 8] "itch for things remote. I love to sail forbidden seas, and land on"][[1 19 9] "barbarous coasts. Not ignoring what is good, I am quick to perceive a"][[1 19 10] "horror, and could still be social with it--would they let me--since it"][[1 19 11] "is but well to be on friendly terms with all the inmates of the place"][[1 19 12] "one lodges in."][[1 20 1] "By reason of these things, then, the whaling voyage was welcome; the"][[1 20 2] "great flood-gates of the wonder-world swung open, and in the wild"][[1 20 3] "conceits that swayed me to my purpose, two and two there floated into"][[1 20 4] "my inmost soul, endless processions of the whale, and, mid most of them"][[1 20 5] "all, one grand hooded phantom, like a snow hill in the air."][[2 0 0] "CHAPTER 2. The Carpet-Bag."][[2 2 1] "I stuffed a shirt or two into my old carpet-bag, tucked it under my arm,"][[2 2 2] "and started for Cape Horn and the Pacific. Quitting the good city of"][[2 2 3] "old Manhatto, I duly arrived in New Bedford. It was a Saturday night in"][[2 2 4] "December. Much was I disappointed upon learning that the little packet"][[2 2 5] "for Nantucket had already sailed, and that no way of reaching that place"][[2 2 6] "would offer, till the following Monday."][[2 3 1] "As most young candidates for the pains and penalties of whaling stop at"][[2 3 2] "this same New Bedford, thence to embark on their voyage, it may as well"][[2 3 3] "be related that I, for one, had no idea of so doing. For my mind was"][[2 3 4] "made up to sail in no other than a Nantucket craft, because there was a"][[2 3 5] "fine, boisterous something about everything connected with that famous"][[2 3 6] "old island, which amazingly pleased me. Besides though New Bedford has"][[2 3 7] "of late been gradually monopolising the business of whaling, and though"][[2 3 8] "in this matter poor old Nantucket is now much behind her, yet Nantucket"][[2 3 9] "was her great original--the Tyre of this Carthage;--the place where the"][[2 3 10] "first dead American whale was stranded. Where else but from Nantucket"][[2 3 11] "did those aboriginal whalemen, the Red-Men, first sally out in canoes to"][[2 3 12] "give chase to the Leviathan? And where but from Nantucket, too, did that"][[2 3 13] "first adventurous little sloop put forth, partly laden with imported"][[2 3 14] "cobblestones--so goes the story--to throw at the whales, in order to"][[2 3 15] "discover when they were nigh enough to risk a harpoon from the bowsprit?"][[2 4 1] "Now having a night, a day, and still another night following before me"][[2 4 2] "in New Bedford, ere I could embark for my destined port, it became a"][[2 4 3] "matter of concernment where I was to eat and sleep meanwhile. It was a"][[2 4 4] "very dubious-looking, nay, a very dark and dismal night, bitingly cold"][[2 4 5] "and cheerless. I knew no one in the place. With anxious grapnels I had"][[2 4 6] "sounded my pocket, and only brought up a few pieces of silver,--So,"][[2 4 7] "wherever you go, Ishmael, said I to myself, as I stood in the middle of"][[2 4 8] "a dreary street shouldering my bag, and comparing the gloom towards the"][[2 4 9] "north with the darkness towards the south--wherever in your wisdom you"][[2 4 10] "may conclude to lodge for the night, my dear Ishmael, be sure to inquire"][[2 4 11] "the price, and don't be too particular."][[2 5 1] "With halting steps I paced the streets, and passed the sign of \"The"][[2 5 2] "Crossed Harpoons\"--but it looked too expensive and jolly there. Further"][[2 5 3] "on, from the bright red windows of the \"Sword-Fish Inn,\" there came such"][[2 5 4] "fervent rays, that it seemed to have melted the packed snow and ice from"][[2 5 5] "before the house, for everywhere else the congealed frost lay ten inches"][[2 5 6] "thick in a hard, asphaltic pavement,--rather weary for me, when I struck"][[2 5 7] "my foot against the flinty projections, because from hard, remorseless"][[2 5 8] "service the soles of my boots were in a most miserable plight. Too"][[2 5 9] "expensive and jolly, again thought I, pausing one moment to watch the"][[2 5 10] "broad glare in the street, and hear the sounds of the tinkling glasses"][[2 5 11] "within. But go on, Ishmael, said I at last; don't you hear? get away"][[2 5 12] "from before the door; your patched boots are stopping the way. So on I"][[2 5 13] "went. I now by instinct followed the streets that took me waterward, for"][[2 5 14] "there, doubtless, were the cheapest, if not the cheeriest inns."][[2 6 1] "Such dreary streets! blocks of blackness, not houses, on either hand,"][[2 6 2] "and here and there a candle, like a candle moving about in a tomb. At"][[2 6 3] "this hour of the night, of the last day of the week, that quarter of"][[2 6 4] "the town proved all but deserted. But presently I came to a smoky light"][[2 6 5] "proceeding from a low, wide building, the door of which stood invitingly"][[2 6 6] "open. It had a careless look, as if it were meant for the uses of the"][[2 6 7] "public; so, entering, the first thing I did was to stumble over an"][[2 6 8] "ash-box in the porch. Ha! thought I, ha, as the flying particles almost"][[2 6 9] "choked me, are these ashes from that destroyed city, Gomorrah? But \"The"][[2 6 10] "Crossed Harpoons,\" and \"The Sword-Fish?\"--this, then must needs be the"][[2 6 11] "sign of \"The Trap.\" However, I picked myself up and hearing a loud voice"][[2 6 12] "within, pushed on and opened a second, interior door."][[2 7 1] "It seemed the great Black Parliament sitting in Tophet. A hundred black"][[2 7 2] "faces turned round in their rows to peer; and beyond, a black Angel"][[2 7 3] "of Doom was beating a book in a pulpit. It was a negro church; and the"][[2 7 4] "preacher's text was about the blackness of darkness, and the weeping and"][[2 7 5] "wailing and teeth-gnashing there. Ha, Ishmael, muttered I, backing out,"][[2 7 6] "Wretched entertainment at the sign of 'The Trap!'"][[2 8 1] "Moving on, I at last came to a dim sort of light not far from the docks,"][[2 8 2] "and heard a forlorn creaking in the air; and looking up, saw a swinging"][[2 8 3] "sign over the door with a white painting upon it, faintly representing"][[2 8 4] "a tall straight jet of misty spray, and these words underneath--\"The"][[2 8 5] "Spouter Inn:--Peter Coffin.\""][[2 9 1] "Coffin?--Spouter?--Rather ominous in that particular connexion, thought"][[2 9 2] "I. But it is a common name in Nantucket, they say, and I suppose this"][[2 9 3] "Peter here is an emigrant from there. As the light looked so dim, and"][[2 9 4] "the place, for the time, looked quiet enough, and the dilapidated little"][[2 9 5] "wooden house itself looked as if it might have been carted here from"][[2 9 6] "the ruins of some burnt district, and as the swinging sign had a"][[2 9 7] "poverty-stricken sort of creak to it, I thought that here was the very"][[2 9 8] "spot for cheap lodgings, and the best of pea coffee."][[2 10 1] "It was a queer sort of place--a gable-ended old house, one side palsied"][[2 10 2] "as it were, and leaning over sadly. It stood on a sharp bleak corner,"][[2 10 3] "where that tempestuous wind Euroclydon kept up a worse howling than ever"][[2 10 4] "it did about poor Paul's tossed craft. Euroclydon, nevertheless, is a"][[2 10 5] "mighty pleasant zephyr to any one in-doors, with his feet on the hob"][[2 10 6] "quietly toasting for bed. \"In judging of that tempestuous wind called"][[2 10 7] "Euroclydon,\" says an old writer--of whose works I possess the only copy"][[2 10 8] "extant--\"it maketh a marvellous difference, whether thou lookest out at"][[2 10 9] "it from a glass window where the frost is all on the outside, or whether"][[2 10 10] "thou observest it from that sashless window, where the frost is on both"][[2 10 11] "sides, and of which the wight Death is the only glazier.\" True enough,"][[2 10 12] "thought I, as this passage occurred to my mind--old black-letter, thou"][[2 10 13] "reasonest well. Yes, these eyes are windows, and this body of mine is"][[2 10 14] "the house. What a pity they didn't stop up the chinks and the crannies"][[2 10 15] "though, and thrust in a little lint here and there. But it's too late"][[2 10 16] "to make any improvements now. The universe is finished; the copestone"][[2 10 17] "is on, and the chips were carted off a million years ago. Poor Lazarus"][[2 10 18] "there, chattering his teeth against the curbstone for his pillow, and"][[2 10 19] "shaking off his tatters with his shiverings, he might plug up both ears"][[2 10 20] "with rags, and put a corn-cob into his mouth, and yet that would not"][[2 10 21] "keep out the tempestuous Euroclydon. Euroclydon! says old Dives, in his"][[2 10 22] "red silken wrapper--(he had a redder one afterwards) pooh, pooh! What"][[2 10 23] "a fine frosty night; how Orion glitters; what northern lights! Let them"][[2 10 24] "talk of their oriental summer climes of everlasting conservatories; give"][[2 10 25] "me the privilege of making my own summer with my own coals."][[2 11 1] "But what thinks Lazarus? Can he warm his blue hands by holding them up"][[2 11 2] "to the grand northern lights? Would not Lazarus rather be in Sumatra"][[2 11 3] "than here? Would he not far rather lay him down lengthwise along the"][[2 11 4] "line of the equator; yea, ye gods! go down to the fiery pit itself, in"][[2 11 5] "order to keep out this frost?"][[2 12 1] "Now, that Lazarus should lie stranded there on the curbstone before the"][[2 12 2] "door of Dives, this is more wonderful than that an iceberg should be"][[2 12 3] "moored to one of the Moluccas. Yet Dives himself, he too lives like a"][[2 12 4] "Czar in an ice palace made of frozen sighs, and being a president of a"][[2 12 5] "temperance society, he only drinks the tepid tears of orphans."][[2 13 1] "But no more of this blubbering now, we are going a-whaling, and there is"][[2 13 2] "plenty of that yet to come. Let us scrape the ice from our frosted feet,"][[2 13 3] "and see what sort of a place this \"Spouter\" may be."][[3 0 0] "CHAPTER 3. The Spouter-Inn."][[3 2 1] "Entering that gable-ended Spouter-Inn, you found yourself in a wide,"][[3 2 2] "low, straggling entry with old-fashioned wainscots, reminding one of"][[3 2 3] "the bulwarks of some condemned old craft. On one side hung a very large"][[3 2 4] "oilpainting so thoroughly besmoked, and every way defaced, that in the"][[3 2 5] "unequal crosslights by which you viewed it, it was only by diligent"][[3 2 6] "study and a series of systematic visits to it, and careful inquiry of"][[3 2 7] "the neighbors, that you could any way arrive at an understanding of its"][[3 2 8] "purpose. Such unaccountable masses of shades and shadows, that at first"][[3 2 9] "you almost thought some ambitious young artist, in the time of the New"][[3 2 10] "England hags, had endeavored to delineate chaos bewitched. But by dint"][[3 2 11] "of much and earnest contemplation, and oft repeated ponderings, and"][[3 2 12] "especially by throwing open the little window towards the back of the"][[3 2 13] "entry, you at last come to the conclusion that such an idea, however"][[3 2 14] "wild, might not be altogether unwarranted."][[3 3 1] "But what most puzzled and confounded you was a long, limber, portentous,"][[3 3 2] "black mass of something hovering in the centre of the picture over three"][[3 3 3] "blue, dim, perpendicular lines floating in a nameless yeast. A boggy,"][[3 3 4] "soggy, squitchy picture truly, enough to drive a nervous man distracted."][[3 3 5] "Yet was there a sort of indefinite, half-attained, unimaginable"][[3 3 6] "sublimity about it that fairly froze you to it, till you involuntarily"][[3 3 7] "took an oath with yourself to find out what that marvellous painting"][[3 3 8] "meant. Ever and anon a bright, but, alas, deceptive idea would dart you"][[3 3 9] "through.--It's the Black Sea in a midnight gale.--It's the unnatural"][[3 3 10] "combat of the four primal elements.--It's a blasted heath.--It's a"][[3 3 11] "Hyperborean winter scene.--It's the breaking-up of the icebound stream"][[3 3 12] "of Time. But at last all these fancies yielded to that one portentous"][[3 3 13] "something in the picture's midst. THAT once found out, and all the rest"][[3 3 14] "were plain. But stop; does it not bear a faint resemblance to a gigantic"][[3 3 15] "fish? even the great leviathan himself?"][[3 4 1] "In fact, the artist's design seemed this: a final theory of my own,"][[3 4 2] "partly based upon the aggregated opinions of many aged persons with whom"][[3 4 3] "I conversed upon the subject. The picture represents a Cape-Horner in a"][[3 4 4] "great hurricane; the half-foundered ship weltering there with its three"][[3 4 5] "dismantled masts alone visible; and an exasperated whale, purposing to"][[3 4 6] "spring clean over the craft, is in the enormous act of impaling himself"][[3 4 7] "upon the three mast-heads."][[3 5 1] "The opposite wall of this entry was hung all over with a heathenish"][[3 5 2] "array of monstrous clubs and spears. Some were thickly set with"][[3 5 3] "glittering teeth resembling ivory saws; others were tufted with knots of"][[3 5 4] "human hair; and one was sickle-shaped, with a vast handle sweeping round"][[3 5 5] "like the segment made in the new-mown grass by a long-armed mower. You"][[3 5 6] "shuddered as you gazed, and wondered what monstrous cannibal and savage"][[3 5 7] "could ever have gone a death-harvesting with such a hacking, horrifying"][[3 5 8] "implement. Mixed with these were rusty old whaling lances and harpoons"][[3 5 9] "all broken and deformed. Some were storied weapons. With this once long"][[3 5 10] "lance, now wildly elbowed, fifty years ago did Nathan Swain kill fifteen"][[3 5 11] "whales between a sunrise and a sunset. And that harpoon--so like a"][[3 5 12] "corkscrew now--was flung in Javan seas, and run away with by a whale,"][[3 5 13] "years afterwards slain off the Cape of Blanco. The original iron entered"][[3 5 14] "nigh the tail, and, like a restless needle sojourning in the body of a"][[3 5 15] "man, travelled full forty feet, and at last was found imbedded in the"][[3 5 16] "hump."][[3 6 1] "Crossing this dusky entry, and on through yon low-arched way--cut"][[3 6 2] "through what in old times must have been a great central chimney with"][[3 6 3] "fireplaces all round--you enter the public room. A still duskier place"][[3 6 4] "is this, with such low ponderous beams above, and such old wrinkled"][[3 6 5] "planks beneath, that you would almost fancy you trod some old craft's"][[3 6 6] "cockpits, especially of such a howling night, when this corner-anchored"][[3 6 7] "old ark rocked so furiously. On one side stood a long, low, shelf-like"][[3 6 8] "table covered with cracked glass cases, filled with dusty rarities"][[3 6 9] "gathered from this wide world's remotest nooks. Projecting from the"][[3 6 10] "further angle of the room stands a dark-looking den--the bar--a rude"][[3 6 11] "attempt at a right whale's head. Be that how it may, there stands the"][[3 6 12] "vast arched bone of the whale's jaw, so wide, a coach might almost drive"][[3 6 13] "beneath it. Within are shabby shelves, ranged round with old decanters,"][[3 6 14] "bottles, flasks; and in those jaws of swift destruction, like another"][[3 6 15] "cursed Jonah (by which name indeed they called him), bustles a little"][[3 6 16] "withered old man, who, for their money, dearly sells the sailors"][[3 6 17] "deliriums and death."][[3 7 1] "Abominable are the tumblers into which he pours his poison. Though"][[3 7 2] "true cylinders without--within, the villanous green goggling glasses"][[3 7 3] "deceitfully tapered downwards to a cheating bottom. Parallel meridians"][[3 7 4] "rudely pecked into the glass, surround these footpads' goblets. Fill to"][[3 7 5] "THIS mark, and your charge is but a penny; to THIS a penny more; and so"][[3 7 6] "on to the full glass--the Cape Horn measure, which you may gulp down for"][[3 7 7] "a shilling."][[3 8 1] "Upon entering the place I found a number of young seamen gathered about"][[3 8 2] "a table, examining by a dim light divers specimens of SKRIMSHANDER. I"][[3 8 3] "sought the landlord, and telling him I desired to be accommodated with a"][[3 8 4] "room, received for answer that his house was full--not a bed unoccupied."][[3 8 5] "\"But avast,\" he added, tapping his forehead, \"you haint no objections"][[3 8 6] "to sharing a harpooneer's blanket, have ye? I s'pose you are goin'"][[3 8 7] "a-whalin', so you'd better get used to that sort of thing.\""][[3 9 1] "I told him that I never liked to sleep two in a bed; that if I should"][[3 9 2] "ever do so, it would depend upon who the harpooneer might be, and"][[3 9 3] "that if he (the landlord) really had no other place for me, and the"][[3 9 4] "harpooneer was not decidedly objectionable, why rather than wander"][[3 9 5] "further about a strange town on so bitter a night, I would put up with"][[3 9 6] "the half of any decent man's blanket."][[3 10 1] "\"I thought so. All right; take a seat. Supper?--you want supper?"][[3 10 2] "Supper'll be ready directly.\""][[3 11 1] "I sat down on an old wooden settle, carved all over like a bench on the"][[3 11 2] "Battery. At one end a ruminating tar was still further adorning it with"][[3 11 3] "his jack-knife, stooping over and diligently working away at the space"][[3 11 4] "between his legs. He was trying his hand at a ship under full sail, but"][[3 11 5] "he didn't make much headway, I thought."][[3 12 1] "At last some four or five of us were summoned to our meal in an"][[3 12 2] "adjoining room. It was cold as Iceland--no fire at all--the landlord"][[3 12 3] "said he couldn't afford it. Nothing but two dismal tallow candles, each"][[3 12 4] "in a winding sheet. We were fain to button up our monkey jackets, and"][[3 12 5] "hold to our lips cups of scalding tea with our half frozen fingers. But"][[3 12 6] "the fare was of the most substantial kind--not only meat and potatoes,"][[3 12 7] "but dumplings; good heavens! dumplings for supper! One young fellow in"][[3 12 8] "a green box coat, addressed himself to these dumplings in a most direful"][[3 12 9] "manner."][[3 13 1] "\"My boy,\" said the landlord, \"you'll have the nightmare to a dead"][[3 13 2] "sartainty.\""][[3 14 1] "\"Landlord,\" I whispered, \"that aint the harpooneer is it?\""][[3 15 1] "\"Oh, no,\" said he, looking a sort of diabolically funny, \"the harpooneer"][[3 15 2] "is a dark complexioned chap. He never eats dumplings, he don't--he eats"][[3 15 3] "nothing but steaks, and he likes 'em rare.\""][[3 16 1] "\"The devil he does,\" says I. \"Where is that harpooneer? Is he here?\""][[3 17 1] "\"He'll be here afore long,\" was the answer."][[3 18 1] "I could not help it, but I began to feel suspicious of this \"dark"][[3 18 2] "complexioned\" harpooneer. At any rate, I made up my mind that if it so"][[3 18 3] "turned out that we should sleep together, he must undress and get into"][[3 18 4] "bed before I did."][[3 19 1] "Supper over, the company went back to the bar-room, when, knowing not"][[3 19 2] "what else to do with myself, I resolved to spend the rest of the evening"][[3 19 3] "as a looker on."][[3 20 1] "Presently a rioting noise was heard without. Starting up, the landlord"][[3 20 2] "cried, \"That's the Grampus's crew. I seed her reported in the offing"][[3 20 3] "this morning; a three years' voyage, and a full ship. Hurrah, boys; now"][[3 20 4] "we'll have the latest news from the Feegees.\""][[3 21 1] "A tramping of sea boots was heard in the entry; the door was flung open,"][[3 21 2] "and in rolled a wild set of mariners enough. Enveloped in their shaggy"][[3 21 3] "watch coats, and with their heads muffled in woollen comforters, all"][[3 21 4] "bedarned and ragged, and their beards stiff with icicles, they seemed an"][[3 21 5] "eruption of bears from Labrador. They had just landed from their boat,"][[3 21 6] "and this was the first house they entered. No wonder, then, that they"][[3 21 7] "made a straight wake for the whale's mouth--the bar--when the wrinkled"][[3 21 8] "little old Jonah, there officiating, soon poured them out brimmers all"][[3 21 9] "round. One complained of a bad cold in his head, upon which Jonah"][[3 21 10] "mixed him a pitch-like potion of gin and molasses, which he swore was a"][[3 21 11] "sovereign cure for all colds and catarrhs whatsoever, never mind of how"][[3 21 12] "long standing, or whether caught off the coast of Labrador, or on the"][[3 21 13] "weather side of an ice-island."][[3 22 1] "The liquor soon mounted into their heads, as it generally does even"][[3 22 2] "with the arrantest topers newly landed from sea, and they began capering"][[3 22 3] "about most obstreperously."][[3 23 1] "I observed, however, that one of them held somewhat aloof, and though"][[3 23 2] "he seemed desirous not to spoil the hilarity of his shipmates by his own"][[3 23 3] "sober face, yet upon the whole he refrained from making as much noise"][[3 23 4] "as the rest. This man interested me at once; and since the sea-gods"][[3 23 5] "had ordained that he should soon become my shipmate (though but a"][[3 23 6] "sleeping-partner one, so far as this narrative is concerned), I will"][[3 23 7] "here venture upon a little description of him. He stood full six feet"][[3 23 8] "in height, with noble shoulders, and a chest like a coffer-dam. I have"][[3 23 9] "seldom seen such brawn in a man. His face was deeply brown and burnt,"][[3 23 10] "making his white teeth dazzling by the contrast; while in the deep"][[3 23 11] "shadows of his eyes floated some reminiscences that did not seem to give"][[3 23 12] "him much joy. His voice at once announced that he was a Southerner,"][[3 23 13] "and from his fine stature, I thought he must be one of those tall"][[3 23 14] "mountaineers from the Alleghanian Ridge in Virginia. When the revelry"][[3 23 15] "of his companions had mounted to its height, this man slipped away"][[3 23 16] "unobserved, and I saw no more of him till he became my comrade on the"][[3 23 17] "sea. In a few minutes, however, he was missed by his shipmates, and"][[3 23 18] "being, it seems, for some reason a huge favourite with them, they raised"][[3 23 19] "a cry of \"Bulkington! Bulkington! where's Bulkington?\" and darted out of"][[3 23 20] "the house in pursuit of him."][[3 24 1] "It was now about nine o'clock, and the room seeming almost"][[3 24 2] "supernaturally quiet after these orgies, I began to congratulate myself"][[3 24 3] "upon a little plan that had occurred to me just previous to the entrance"][[3 24 4] "of the seamen."][[3 25 1] "No man prefers to sleep two in a bed. In fact, you would a good deal"][[3 25 2] "rather not sleep with your own brother. I don't know how it is, but"][[3 25 3] "people like to be private when they are sleeping. And when it comes to"][[3 25 4] "sleeping with an unknown stranger, in a strange inn, in a strange"][[3 25 5] "town, and that stranger a harpooneer, then your objections indefinitely"][[3 25 6] "multiply. Nor was there any earthly reason why I as a sailor should"][[3 25 7] "sleep two in a bed, more than anybody else; for sailors no more sleep"][[3 25 8] "two in a bed at sea, than bachelor Kings do ashore. To be sure they"][[3 25 9] "all sleep together in one apartment, but you have your own hammock, and"][[3 25 10] "cover yourself with your own blanket, and sleep in your own skin."][[3 26 1] "The more I pondered over this harpooneer, the more I abominated the"][[3 26 2] "thought of sleeping with him. It was fair to presume that being a"][[3 26 3] "harpooneer, his linen or woollen, as the case might be, would not be of"][[3 26 4] "the tidiest, certainly none of the finest. I began to twitch all over."][[3 26 5] "Besides, it was getting late, and my decent harpooneer ought to be"][[3 26 6] "home and going bedwards. Suppose now, he should tumble in upon me at"][[3 26 7] "midnight--how could I tell from what vile hole he had been coming?"][[3 27 1] "\"Landlord! I've changed my mind about that harpooneer.--I shan't sleep"][[3 27 2] "with him. I'll try the bench here.\""][[3 28 1] "\"Just as you please; I'm sorry I cant spare ye a tablecloth for a"][[3 28 2] "mattress, and it's a plaguy rough board here\"--feeling of the knots and"][[3 28 3] "notches. \"But wait a bit, Skrimshander; I've got a carpenter's plane"][[3 28 4] "there in the bar--wait, I say, and I'll make ye snug enough.\" So saying"][[3 28 5] "he procured the plane; and with his old silk handkerchief first dusting"][[3 28 6] "the bench, vigorously set to planing away at my bed, the while grinning"][[3 28 7] "like an ape. The shavings flew right and left; till at last the"][[3 28 8] "plane-iron came bump against an indestructible knot. The landlord was"][[3 28 9] "near spraining his wrist, and I told him for heaven's sake to quit--the"][[3 28 10] "bed was soft enough to suit me, and I did not know how all the planing"][[3 28 11] "in the world could make eider down of a pine plank. So gathering up the"][[3 28 12] "shavings with another grin, and throwing them into the great stove in"][[3 28 13] "the middle of the room, he went about his business, and left me in a"][[3 28 14] "brown study."][[3 29 1] "I now took the measure of the bench, and found that it was a foot too"][[3 29 2] "short; but that could be mended with a chair. But it was a foot too"][[3 29 3] "narrow, and the other bench in the room was about four inches higher"][[3 29 4] "than the planed one--so there was no yoking them. I then placed the"][[3 29 5] "first bench lengthwise along the only clear space against the wall,"][[3 29 6] "leaving a little interval between, for my back to settle down in. But I"][[3 29 7] "soon found that there came such a draught of cold air over me from under"][[3 29 8] "the sill of the window, that this plan would never do at all, especially"][[3 29 9] "as another current from the rickety door met the one from the window,"][[3 29 10] "and both together formed a series of small whirlwinds in the immediate"][[3 29 11] "vicinity of the spot where I had thought to spend the night."][[3 30 1] "The devil fetch that harpooneer, thought I, but stop, couldn't I steal"][[3 30 2] "a march on him--bolt his door inside, and jump into his bed, not to be"][[3 30 3] "wakened by the most violent knockings? It seemed no bad idea; but upon"][[3 30 4] "second thoughts I dismissed it. For who could tell but what the next"][[3 30 5] "morning, so soon as I popped out of the room, the harpooneer might be"][[3 30 6] "standing in the entry, all ready to knock me down!"][[3 31 1] "Still, looking round me again, and seeing no possible chance of spending"][[3 31 2] "a sufferable night unless in some other person's bed, I began to think"][[3 31 3] "that after all I might be cherishing unwarrantable prejudices against"][[3 31 4] "this unknown harpooneer. Thinks I, I'll wait awhile; he must be dropping"][[3 31 5] "in before long. I'll have a good look at him then, and perhaps we may"][[3 31 6] "become jolly good bedfellows after all--there's no telling."][[3 32 1] "But though the other boarders kept coming in by ones, twos, and threes,"][[3 32 2] "and going to bed, yet no sign of my harpooneer."][[3 33 1] "\"Landlord!\" said I, \"what sort of a chap is he--does he always keep such"][[3 33 2] "late hours?\" It was now hard upon twelve o'clock."][[3 34 1] "The landlord chuckled again with his lean chuckle, and seemed to"][[3 34 2] "be mightily tickled at something beyond my comprehension. \"No,\" he"][[3 34 3] "answered, \"generally he's an early bird--airley to bed and airley to"][[3 34 4] "rise--yes, he's the bird what catches the worm. But to-night he went out"][[3 34 5] "a peddling, you see, and I don't see what on airth keeps him so late,"][[3 34 6] "unless, may be, he can't sell his head.\""][[3 35 1] "\"Can't sell his head?--What sort of a bamboozingly story is this you"][[3 35 2] "are telling me?\" getting into a towering rage. \"Do you pretend to say,"][[3 35 3] "landlord, that this harpooneer is actually engaged this blessed Saturday"][[3 35 4] "night, or rather Sunday morning, in peddling his head around this town?\""][[3 36 1] "\"That's precisely it,\" said the landlord, \"and I told him he couldn't"][[3 36 2] "sell it here, the market's overstocked.\""][[3 37 1] "\"With what?\" shouted I."][[3 38 1] "\"With heads to be sure; ain't there too many heads in the world?\""][[3 39 1] "\"I tell you what it is, landlord,\" said I quite calmly, \"you'd better"][[3 39 2] "stop spinning that yarn to me--I'm not green.\""][[3 40 1] "\"May be not,\" taking out a stick and whittling a toothpick, \"but I"][[3 40 2] "rayther guess you'll be done BROWN if that ere harpooneer hears you a"][[3 40 3] "slanderin' his head.\""][[3 41 1] "\"I'll break it for him,\" said I, now flying into a passion again at this"][[3 41 2] "unaccountable farrago of the landlord's."][[3 42 1] "\"It's broke a'ready,\" said he."][[3 43 1] "\"Broke,\" said I--\"BROKE, do you mean?\""][[3 44 1] "\"Sartain, and that's the very reason he can't sell it, I guess.\""][[3 45 1] "\"Landlord,\" said I, going up to him as cool as Mt. I come to your house and want a"][[3 45 4] "bed; you tell me you can only give me half a one; that the other half"][[3 45 5] "belongs to a certain harpooneer. And about this harpooneer, whom I"][[3 45 6] "have not yet seen, you persist in telling me the most mystifying and"][[3 45 7] "exasperating stories tending to beget in me an uncomfortable feeling"][[3 45 8] "towards the man whom you design for my bedfellow--a sort of connexion,"][[3 45 9] "landlord, which is an intimate and confidential one in the highest"][[3 45 10] "degree. And in the first place, you will be so good as to unsay"][[3 45 13] "that story about selling his head, which if true I take to be good"][[3 45 14] "evidence that this harpooneer is stark mad, and I've no idea of sleeping"][[3 45 15] "with a madman; and you, sir, YOU I mean, landlord, YOU, sir, by trying"][[3 45 16] "to induce me to do so knowingly, would thereby render yourself liable to"][[3 45 17] "a criminal prosecution.\""][[3 46 1] "\"Wall,\" said the landlord, fetching a long breath, \"that's a purty long"][[3 46 2] "sarmon for a chap that rips a little now and then. But be easy, be easy,"][[3 46 3] "this here harpooneer I have been tellin' you of has just arrived from"][[3 46 4] "the south seas, where he bought up a lot of 'balmed New Zealand heads"][[3 46 5] "(great curios, you know), and he's sold all on 'em but one, and that one"][[3 46 6] "he's trying to sell to-night, cause to-morrow's Sunday, and it would not"][[3 46 7] "do to be sellin' human heads about the streets when folks is goin' to"][[3 46 8] "churches. He wanted to, last Sunday, but I stopped him just as he was"][[3 46 9] "goin' out of the door with four heads strung on a string, for all the"][[3 46 10] "airth like a string of inions.\""][[3 47 1] "This account cleared up the otherwise unaccountable mystery, and showed"][[3 47 2] "that the landlord, after all, had had no idea of fooling me--but at"][[3 47 3] "the same time what could I think of a harpooneer who stayed out of a"][[3 47 4] "Saturday night clean into the holy Sabbath, engaged in such a cannibal"][[3 47 5] "business as selling the heads of dead idolators?"][[3 48 1] "\"Depend upon it, landlord, that harpooneer is a dangerous man.\""][[3 49 1] "\"He pays reg'lar,\" was the rejoinder. \"But come, it's getting dreadful"][[3 49 2] "late, you had better be turning flukes--it's a nice bed; Sal and me"][[3 49 3] "slept in that ere bed the night we were spliced. There's plenty of room"][[3 49 4] "for two to kick about in that bed; it's an almighty big bed that. Why,"][[3 49 5] "afore we give it up, Sal used to put our Sam and little Johnny in the"][[3 49 6] "foot of it. But I got a dreaming and sprawling about one night, and"][[3 49 7] "somehow, Sam got pitched on the floor, and came near breaking his arm."][[3 49 8] "Arter that, Sal said it wouldn't do. But I stood irresolute; when looking at a"][[3 49 11] "clock in the corner, he exclaimed \"I vum it's Sunday--you won't see that"][[3 49 12] "harpooneer to-night; he's come to anchor somewhere--come along then; DO"][[3 49 13] "come; WON'T ye come?\""][[3 50 1] "I considered the matter a moment, and then up stairs we went, and I was"][[3 50 2] "ushered into a small room, cold as a clam, and furnished, sure enough,"][[3 50 3] "with a prodigious bed, almost big enough indeed for any four harpooneers"][[3 50 4] "to sleep abreast."][[3 51 1] "\"There,\" said the landlord, placing the candle on a crazy old sea chest"][[3 51 2] "that did double duty as a wash-stand and centre table; \"there, make"][[3 51 3] "yourself comfortable now, and good night to ye.\" I turned round from"][[3 51 4] "eyeing the bed, but he had disappeared."][[3 52 1] "Folding back the counterpane, I stooped over the bed. Though none of the"][[3 52 2] "most elegant, it yet stood the scrutiny tolerably well. I then glanced"][[3 52 3] "round the room; and besides the bedstead and centre table, could see"][[3 52 4] "no other furniture belonging to the place, but a rude shelf, the four"][[3 52 5] "walls, and a papered fireboard representing a man striking a whale. Of"][[3 52 6] "things not properly belonging to the room, there was a hammock lashed"][[3 52 7] "up, and thrown upon the floor in one corner; also a large seaman's bag,"][[3 52 8] "containing the harpooneer's wardrobe, no doubt in lieu of a land trunk."][[3 52 9] "Likewise, there was a parcel of outlandish bone fish hooks on the shelf"][[3 52 10] "over the fire-place, and a tall harpoon standing at the head of the bed."][[3 53 1] "But what is this on the chest? I took it up, and held it close to the"][[3 53 2] "light, and felt it, and smelt it, and tried every way possible to arrive"][[3 53 3] "at some satisfactory conclusion concerning it. I can compare it to"][[3 53 4] "nothing but a large door mat, ornamented at the edges with little"][[3 53 5] "tinkling tags something like the stained porcupine quills round an"][[3 53 6] "Indian moccasin. There was a hole or slit in the middle of this mat,"][[3 53 7] "as you see the same in South American ponchos. But could it be possible"][[3 53 8] "that any sober harpooneer would get into a door mat, and parade the"][[3 53 9] "streets of any Christian town in that sort of guise? I put it on, to try"][[3 53 10] "it, and it weighed me down like a hamper, being uncommonly shaggy and"][[3 53 11] "thick, and I thought a little damp, as though this mysterious harpooneer"][[3 53 12] "had been wearing it of a rainy day. I went up in it to a bit of glass"][[3 53 13] "stuck against the wall, and I never saw such a sight in my life. I tore"][[3 53 14] "myself out of it in such a hurry that I gave myself a kink in the neck."][[3 54 1] "I sat down on the side of the bed, and commenced thinking about this"][[3 54 2] "head-peddling harpooneer, and his door mat. After thinking some time on"][[3 54 3] "the bed-side, I got up and took off my monkey jacket, and then stood in"][[3 54 4] "the middle of the room thinking. I then took off my coat, and thought"][[3 54 5] "a little more in my shirt sleeves. But beginning to feel very cold now,"][[3 54 6] "half undressed as I was, and remembering what the landlord said about"][[3 54 7] "the harpooneer's not coming home at all that night, it being so very"][[3 54 8] "late, I made no more ado, but jumped out of my pantaloons and boots, and"][[3 54 9] "then blowing out the light tumbled into bed, and commended myself to the"][[3 54 10] "care of heaven."][[3 55 1] "Whether that mattress was stuffed with corn-cobs or broken crockery,"][[3 55 2] "there is no telling, but I rolled about a good deal, and could not sleep"][[3 55 3] "for a long time. At last I slid off into a light doze, and had pretty"][[3 55 4] "nearly made a good offing towards the land of Nod, when I heard a heavy"][[3 55 5] "footfall in the passage, and saw a glimmer of light come into the room"][[3 55 6] "from under the door."][[3 56 1] "Lord save me, thinks I, that must be the harpooneer, the infernal"][[3 56 2] "head-peddler. But I lay perfectly still, and resolved not to say a word"][[3 56 3] "till spoken to. Holding a light in one hand, and that identical New"][[3 56 4] "Zealand head in the other, the stranger entered the room, and without"][[3 56 5] "looking towards the bed, placed his candle a good way off from me on the"][[3 56 6] "floor in one corner, and then began working away at the knotted cords"][[3 56 7] "of the large bag I before spoke of as being in the room. I was all"][[3 56 8] "eagerness to see his face, but he kept it averted for some time while"][[3 56 9] "employed in unlacing the bag's mouth. This accomplished, however, he"][[3 56 10] "turned round--when, good heavens! what a sight! Such a face! It was of"][[3 56 11] "a dark, purplish, yellow colour, here and there stuck over with large"][[3 56 12] "blackish looking squares. Yes, it's just as I thought, he's a terrible"][[3 56 13] "bedfellow; he's been in a fight, got dreadfully cut, and here he is,"][[3 56 14] "just from the surgeon. But at that moment he chanced to turn his face"][[3 56 15] "so towards the light, that I plainly saw they could not be"][[3 56 16] "sticking-plasters at all, those black squares on his cheeks. They were"][[3 56 17] "stains of some sort or other. At first I knew not what to make of this;"][[3 56 18] "but soon an inkling of the truth occurred to me. I remembered a story of"][[3 56 19] "a white man--a whaleman too--who, falling among the cannibals, had been"][[3 56 20] "tattooed by them. I concluded that this harpooneer, in the course of his"][[3 56 21] "distant voyages, must have met with a similar adventure. And what is it,"][[3 56 22] "thought I, after all! It's only his outside; a man can be honest in any"][[3 56 23] "sort of skin. But then, what to make of his unearthly complexion, that"][[3 56 24] "part of it, I mean, lying round about, and completely independent of the"][[3 56 25] "squares of tattooing. To be sure, it might be nothing but a good coat of"][[3 56 26] "tropical tanning; but I never heard of a hot sun's tanning a white man"][[3 56 27] "into a purplish yellow one. However, I had never been in the South Seas;"][[3 56 28] "and perhaps the sun there produced these extraordinary effects upon the"][[3 56 29] "skin. Now, while all these ideas were passing through me like lightning,"][[3 56 30] "this harpooneer never noticed me at all. But, after some difficulty"][[3 56 31] "having opened his bag, he commenced fumbling in it, and presently pulled"][[3 56 32] "out a sort of tomahawk, and a seal-skin wallet with the hair on. Placing"][[3 56 33] "these on the old chest in the middle of the room, he then took the New"][[3 56 34] "Zealand head--a ghastly thing enough--and crammed it down into the bag."][[3 56 35] "He now took off his hat--a new beaver hat--when I came nigh singing out"][[3 56 36] "with fresh surprise. There was no hair on his head--none to speak of at"][[3 56 37] "least--nothing but a small scalp-knot twisted up on his forehead. His"][[3 56 38] "bald purplish head now looked for all the world like a mildewed skull."][[3 56 39] "Had not the stranger stood between me and the door, I would have bolted"][[3 56 40] "out of it quicker than ever I bolted a dinner."][[3 57 1] "Even as it was, I thought something of slipping out of the window, but"][[3 57 2] "it was the second floor back. I am no coward, but what to make of"][[3 57 3] "this head-peddling purple rascal altogether passed my comprehension."][[3 57 4] "Ignorance is the parent of fear, and being completely nonplussed and"][[3 57 5] "confounded about the stranger, I confess I was now as much afraid of him"][[3 57 6] "as if it was the devil himself who had thus broken into my room at"][[3 57 7] "the dead of night. In fact, I was so afraid of him that I was not"][[3 57 8] "game enough just then to address him, and demand a satisfactory answer"][[3 57 9] "concerning what seemed inexplicable in him."][[3 58 1] "Meanwhile, he continued the business of undressing, and at last showed"][[3 58 2] "his chest and arms. As I live, these covered parts of him were checkered"][[3 58 3] "with the same squares as his face; his back, too, was all over the same"][[3 58 4] "dark squares; he seemed to have been in a Thirty Years' War, and just"][[3 58 5] "escaped from it with a sticking-plaster shirt. Still more, his very"][[3 58 6] "legs were marked, as if a parcel of dark green frogs were running up"][[3 58 7] "the trunks of young palms. It was now quite plain that he must be some"][[3 58 8] "abominable savage or other shipped aboard of a whaleman in the South"][[3 58 9] "Seas, and so landed in this Christian country. I quaked to think of it."][[3 58 10] "A peddler of heads too--perhaps the heads of his own brothers. He might"][[3 58 11] "take a fancy to mine--heavens! look at that tomahawk!"][[3 59 1] "But there was no time for shuddering, for now the savage went about"][[3 59 2] "something that completely fascinated my attention, and convinced me that"][[3 59 3] "he must indeed be a heathen. Going to his heavy grego, or wrapall, or"][[3 59 4] "dreadnaught, which he had previously hung on a chair, he fumbled in the"][[3 59 5] "pockets, and produced at length a curious little deformed image with"][[3 59 6] "a hunch on its back, and exactly the colour of a three days' old Congo"][[3 59 7] "baby. Remembering the embalmed head, at first I almost thought that"][[3 59 8] "this black manikin was a real baby preserved in some similar manner. But"][[3 59 9] "seeing that it was not at all limber, and that it glistened a good deal"][[3 59 10] "like polished ebony, I concluded that it must be nothing but a wooden"][[3 59 11] "idol, which indeed it proved to be. For now the savage goes up to the"][[3 59 12] "empty fire-place, and removing the papered fire-board, sets up this"][[3 59 13] "little hunch-backed image, like a tenpin, between the andirons. The"][[3 59 14] "chimney jambs and all the bricks inside were very sooty, so that I"][[3 59 15] "thought this fire-place made a very appropriate little shrine or chapel"][[3 59 16] "for his Congo idol."][[3 60 1] "I now screwed my eyes hard towards the half hidden image, feeling but"][[3 60 2] "ill at ease meantime--to see what was next to follow. First he takes"][[3 60 3] "about a double handful of shavings out of his grego pocket, and places"][[3 60 4] "them carefully before the idol; then laying a bit of ship biscuit on"][[3 60 5] "top and applying the flame from the lamp, he kindled the shavings into"][[3 60 6] "a sacrificial blaze. Presently, after many hasty snatches into the fire,"][[3 60 7] "and still hastier withdrawals of his fingers (whereby he seemed to be"][[3 60 8] "scorching them badly), he at last succeeded in drawing out the biscuit;"][[3 60 9] "then blowing off the heat and ashes a little, he made a polite offer of"][[3 60 10] "it to the little negro. But the little devil did not seem to fancy such"][[3 60 11] "dry sort of fare at all; he never moved his lips. All these strange"][[3 60 12] "antics were accompanied by still stranger guttural noises from the"][[3 60 13] "devotee, who seemed to be praying in a sing-song or else singing some"][[3 60 14] "pagan psalmody or other, during which his face twitched about in the"][[3 60 15] "most unnatural manner. At last extinguishing the fire, he took the idol"][[3 60 16] "up very unceremoniously, and bagged it again in his grego pocket as"][[3 60 17] "carelessly as if he were a sportsman bagging a dead woodcock."][[3 61 1] "All these queer proceedings increased my uncomfortableness, and"][[3 61 2] "seeing him now exhibiting strong symptoms of concluding his business"][[3 61 3] "operations, and jumping into bed with me, I thought it was high time,"][[3 61 4] "now or never, before the light was put out, to break the spell in which"][[3 61 5] "I had so long been bound."][[3 62 1] "But the interval I spent in deliberating what to say, was a fatal one."][[3 62 2] "Taking up his tomahawk from the table, he examined the head of it for an"][[3 62 3] "instant, and then holding it to the light, with his mouth at the handle,"][[3 62 4] "he puffed out great clouds of tobacco smoke. The next moment the light"][[3 62 5] "was extinguished, and this wild cannibal, tomahawk between his teeth,"][[3 62 6] "sprang into bed with me. I sang out, I could not help it now; and giving"][[3 62 7] "a sudden grunt of astonishment he began feeling me."][[3 63 1] "Stammering out something, I knew not what, I rolled away from him"][[3 63 2] "against the wall, and then conjured him, whoever or whatever he might"][[3 63 3] "be, to keep quiet, and let me get up and light the lamp again. But his"][[3 63 4] "guttural responses satisfied me at once that he but ill comprehended my"][[3 63 5] "meaning."][[3 64 1] "\"Who-e debel you?\"--he at last said--\"you no speak-e, dam-me, I kill-e.\""][[3 64 2] "And so saying the lighted tomahawk began flourishing about me in the"][[3 64 3] "dark."][[3 65 1] "\"Landlord, for God's sake, Peter Coffin!\" shouted I. \"Landlord! Watch!"][[3 65 2] "Coffin! Angels! save me!\""][[3 66 1] "\"Speak-e! tell-ee me who-ee be, or dam-me, I kill-e!\" again growled the"][[3 66 2] "cannibal, while his horrid flourishings of the tomahawk scattered the"][[3 66 3] "hot tobacco ashes about me till I thought my linen would get on fire."][[3 66 4] "But thank heaven, at that moment the landlord came into the room light"][[3 66 5] "in hand, and leaping from the bed I ran up to him."][[3 67 1] "\"Don't be afraid now,\" said he, grinning again, \"Queequeg here wouldn't"][[3 67 2] "harm a hair of your head.\""][[3 68 1] "\"Stop your grinning,\" shouted I, \"and why didn't you tell me that that"][[3 68 2] "infernal harpooneer was a cannibal?\""][[3 69 1] "\"I thought ye know'd it;--didn't I tell ye, he was a peddlin' heads"][[3 69 2] "around town?--but turn flukes again and go to sleep. Queequeg, look"][[3 69 3] "here--you sabbee me, I sabbee--you this man sleepe you--you sabbee?\""][[3 70 1] "\"Me sabbee plenty\"--grunted Queequeg, puffing away at his pipe and"][[3 70 2] "sitting up in bed."][[3 71 1] "\"You gettee in,\" he added, motioning to me with his tomahawk, and"][[3 71 2] "throwing the clothes to one side. He really did this in not only a civil"][[3 71 3] "but a really kind and charitable way. I stood looking at him a moment."][[3 71 4] "For all his tattooings he was on the whole a clean, comely looking"][[3 71 5] "cannibal. What's all this fuss I have been making about, thought I to"][[3 71 6] "myself--the man's a human being just as I am: he has just as much reason"][[3 71 7] "to fear me, as I have to be afraid of him. Better sleep with a sober"][[3 71 8] "cannibal than a drunken Christian."][[3 72 1] "\"Landlord,\" said I, \"tell him to stash his tomahawk there, or pipe, or"][[3 72 2] "whatever you call it; tell him to stop smoking, in short, and I will"][[3 72 3] "turn in with him. But I don't fancy having a man smoking in bed with me."][[3 72 4] "It's dangerous. Besides, I ain't insured.\""][[3 73 1] "This being told to Queequeg, he at once complied, and again politely"][[3 73 2] "motioned me to get into bed--rolling over to one side as much as to"][[3 73 3] "say--\"I won't touch a leg of ye.\""][[3 74 1] "\"Good night, landlord,\" said I, \"you may go.\""][[3 75 1] "I turned in, and never slept better in my life."][[4 0 0] "CHAPTER 4. The Counterpane."][[4 2 1] "Upon waking next morning about daylight, I found Queequeg's arm thrown"][[4 2 2] "over me in the most loving and affectionate manner. You had almost"][[4 2 3] "thought I had been his wife. The counterpane was of patchwork, full of"][[4 2 4] "odd little parti-coloured squares and triangles; and this arm of his"][[4 2 5] "tattooed all over with an interminable Cretan labyrinth of a figure,"][[4 2 6] "no two parts of which were of one precise shade--owing I suppose to"][[4 2 7] "his keeping his arm at sea unmethodically in sun and shade, his shirt"][[4 2 8] "sleeves irregularly rolled up at various times--this same arm of his, I"][[4 2 9] "say, looked for all the world like a strip of that same patchwork quilt."][[4 2 10] "Indeed, partly lying on it as the arm did when I first awoke, I could"][[4 2 11] "hardly tell it from the quilt, they so blended their hues together; and"][[4 2 12] "it was only by the sense of weight and pressure that I could tell that"][[4 2 13] "Queequeg was hugging me."][[4 3 1] "My sensations were strange. Let me try to explain them. When I was a"][[4 3 2] "child, I well remember a somewhat similar circumstance that befell me;"][[4 3 3] "whether it was a reality or a dream, I never could entirely settle."][[4 3 4] "The circumstance was this. I had been cutting up some caper or other--I"][[4 3 5] "think it was trying to crawl up the chimney, as I had seen a little"][[4 3 6] "sweep do a few days previous; and my stepmother who, somehow or other,"][[4 3 7] "was all the time whipping me, or sending me to bed supperless,--my"][[4 3 8] "mother dragged me by the legs out of the chimney and packed me off to"][[4 3 9] "bed, though it was only two o'clock in the afternoon of the st June,"][[4 3 10] "the longest day in the year in our hemisphere. I felt dreadfully. But"][[4 3 11] "there was no help for it, so up stairs I went to my little room in the"][[4 3 12] "third floor, undressed myself as slowly as possible so as to kill time,"][[4 3 13] "and with a bitter sigh got between the sheets."][[4 4 1] "I lay there dismally calculating that sixteen entire hours must elapse"][[4 4 2] "before I could hope for a resurrection. Sixteen hours in bed! the"][[4 4 3] "small of my back ached to think of it. And it was so light too; the"][[4 4 4] "sun shining in at the window, and a great rattling of coaches in the"][[4 4 5] "streets, and the sound of gay voices all over the house. I felt worse"][[4 4 6] "and worse--at last I got up, dressed, and softly going down in my"][[4 4 7] "stockinged feet, sought out my stepmother, and suddenly threw myself"][[4 4 8] "at her feet, beseeching her as a particular favour to give me a good"][[4 4 9] "slippering for my misbehaviour; anything indeed but condemning me to lie"][[4 4 10] "abed such an unendurable length of time. But she was the best and most"][[4 4 11] "conscientious of stepmothers, and back I had to go to my room. For"][[4 4 12] "several hours I lay there broad awake, feeling a great deal worse than I"][[4 4 13] "have ever done since, even from the greatest subsequent misfortunes. At"][[4 4 14] "last I must have fallen into a troubled nightmare of a doze; and slowly"][[4 4 15] "waking from it--half steeped in dreams--I opened my eyes, and the before"][[4 4 16] "sun-lit room was now wrapped in outer darkness. Instantly I felt a shock"][[4 4 17] "running through all my frame; nothing was to be seen, and nothing was"][[4 4 18] "to be heard; but a supernatural hand seemed placed in mine. My arm hung"][[4 4 19] "over the counterpane, and the nameless, unimaginable, silent form"][[4 4 20] "or phantom, to which the hand belonged, seemed closely seated by my"][[4 4 21] "bed-side. For what seemed ages piled on ages, I lay there, frozen with"][[4 4 22] "the most awful fears, not daring to drag away my hand; yet ever thinking"][[4 4 23] "that if I could but stir it one single inch, the horrid spell would be"][[4 4 24] "broken. I knew not how this consciousness at last glided away from me;"][[4 4 25] "but waking in the morning, I shudderingly remembered it all, and for"][[4 4 26] "days and weeks and months afterwards I lost myself in confounding"][[4 4 27] "attempts to explain the mystery. Nay, to this very hour, I often puzzle"][[4 4 28] "myself with it."][[4 5 1] "Now, take away the awful fear, and my sensations at feeling the"][[4 5 2] "supernatural hand in mine were very similar, in their strangeness, to"][[4 5 3] "those which I experienced on waking up and seeing Queequeg's pagan"][[4 5 4] "arm thrown round me. But at length all the past night's events soberly"][[4 5 5] "recurred, one by one, in fixed reality, and then I lay only alive to"][[4 5 6] "the comical predicament. For though I tried to move his arm--unlock his"][[4 5 7] "bridegroom clasp--yet, sleeping as he was, he still hugged me tightly,"][[4 5 8] "as though naught but death should part us twain. I now strove to rouse"][[4 5 9] "him--\"Queequeg!\"--but his only answer was a snore. I then rolled over,"][[4 5 10] "my neck feeling as if it were in a horse-collar; and suddenly felt a"][[4 5 11] "slight scratch. Throwing aside the counterpane, there lay the tomahawk"][[4 5 12] "sleeping by the savage's side, as if it were a hatchet-faced baby. A"][[4 5 13] "pretty pickle, truly, thought I; abed here in a strange house in the"][[4 5 14] "broad day, with a cannibal and a tomahawk! \"Queequeg!--in the name of"][[4 5 15] "goodness, Queequeg, wake!\" At length, by dint of much wriggling, and"][[4 5 16] "loud and incessant expostulations upon the unbecomingness of his"][[4 5 17] "hugging a fellow male in that matrimonial sort of style, I succeeded in"][[4 5 18] "extracting a grunt; and presently, he drew back his arm, shook himself"][[4 5 19] "all over like a Newfoundland dog just from the water, and sat up in bed,"][[4 5 20] "stiff as a pike-staff, looking at me, and rubbing his eyes as if he"][[4 5 21] "did not altogether remember how I came to be there, though a dim"][[4 5 22] "consciousness of knowing something about me seemed slowly dawning over"][[4 5 23] "him. Meanwhile, I lay quietly eyeing him, having no serious misgivings"][[4 5 24] "now, and bent upon narrowly observing so curious a creature. When, at"][[4 5 25] "last, his mind seemed made up touching the character of his bedfellow,"][[4 5 26] "and he became, as it were, reconciled to the fact; he jumped out upon"][[4 5 27] "the floor, and by certain signs and sounds gave me to understand that,"][[4 5 28] "if it pleased me, he would dress first and then leave me to dress"][[4 5 29] "afterwards, leaving the whole apartment to myself. Thinks I, Queequeg,"][[4 5 30] "under the circumstances, this is a very civilized overture; but, the"][[4 5 31] "truth is, these savages have an innate sense of delicacy, say what"][[4 5 32] "you will; it is marvellous how essentially polite they are. I pay this"][[4 5 33] "particular compliment to Queequeg, because he treated me with so much"][[4 5 34] "civility and consideration, while I was guilty of great rudeness;"][[4 5 35] "staring at him from the bed, and watching all his toilette motions; for"][[4 5 36] "the time my curiosity getting the better of my breeding. Nevertheless,"][[4 5 37] "a man like Queequeg you don't see every day, he and his ways were well"][[4 5 38] "worth unusual regarding."][[4 6 1] "He commenced dressing at top by donning his beaver hat, a very tall one,"][[4 6 2] "by the by, and then--still minus his trowsers--he hunted up his boots."][[4 6 3] "What under the heavens he did it for, I cannot tell, but his next"][[4 6 4] "movement was to crush himself--boots in hand, and hat on--under the bed;"][[4 6 5] "when, from sundry violent gaspings and strainings, I inferred he was"][[4 6 6] "hard at work booting himself; though by no law of propriety that I ever"][[4 6 7] "heard of, is any man required to be private when putting on his"][[4 6 8] "boots. But Queequeg, do you see, was a creature in the transition"][[4 6 9] "stage--neither caterpillar nor butterfly. He was just enough civilized"][[4 6 10] "to show off his outlandishness in the strangest possible manners. His"][[4 6 11] "education was not yet completed. He was an undergraduate. If he had not"][[4 6 12] "been a small degree civilized, he very probably would not have troubled"][[4 6 13] "himself with boots at all; but then, if he had not been still a savage,"][[4 6 14] "he never would have dreamt of getting under the bed to put them on. At"][[4 6 15] "last, he emerged with his hat very much dented and crushed down over his"][[4 6 16] "eyes, and began creaking and limping about the room, as if, not"][[4 6 17] "being much accustomed to boots, his pair of damp, wrinkled cowhide"][[4 6 18] "ones--probably not made to order either--rather pinched and tormented"][[4 6 19] "him at the first go off of a bitter cold morning."][[4 7 1] "Seeing, now, that there were no curtains to the window, and that the"][[4 7 2] "street being very narrow, the house opposite commanded a plain view"][[4 7 3] "into the room, and observing more and more the indecorous figure that"][[4 7 4] "Queequeg made, staving about with little else but his hat and boots on;"][[4 7 5] "I begged him as well as I could, to accelerate his toilet somewhat,"][[4 7 6] "and particularly to get into his pantaloons as soon as possible. He"][[4 7 7] "complied, and then proceeded to wash himself. At that time in the"][[4 7 8] "morning any Christian would have washed his face; but Queequeg, to"][[4 7 9] "my amazement, contented himself with restricting his ablutions to his"][[4 7 10] "chest, arms, and hands. He then donned his waistcoat, and taking up a"][[4 7 11] "piece of hard soap on the wash-stand centre table, dipped it into water"][[4 7 12] "and commenced lathering his face. I was watching to see where he kept"][[4 7 13] "his razor, when lo and behold, he takes the harpoon from the bed corner,"][[4 7 14] "slips out the long wooden stock, unsheathes the head, whets it a little"][[4 7 15] "on his boot, and striding up to the bit of mirror against the wall,"][[4 7 16] "begins a vigorous scraping, or rather harpooning of his cheeks. Thinks"][[4 7 17] "I, Queequeg, this is using Rogers's best cutlery with a vengeance."][[4 7 18] "Afterwards I wondered the less at this operation when I came to know of"][[4 7 19] "what fine steel the head of a harpoon is made, and how exceedingly sharp"][[4 7 20] "the long straight edges are always kept."][[4 8 1] "The rest of his toilet was soon achieved, and he proudly marched out of"][[4 8 2] "the room, wrapped up in his great pilot monkey jacket, and sporting his"][[4 8 3] "harpoon like a marshal's baton."][[5 0 0] "CHAPTER 5. Breakfast."][[5 2 1] "I quickly followed suit, and descending into the bar-room accosted the"][[5 2 2] "grinning landlord very pleasantly. I cherished no malice towards him,"][[5 2 3] "though he had been skylarking with me not a little in the matter of my"][[5 2 4] "bedfellow."][[5 3 1] "However, a good laugh is a mighty good thing, and rather too scarce a"][[5 3 2] "good thing; the more's the pity. So, if any one man, in his own"][[5 3 3] "proper person, afford stuff for a good joke to anybody, let him not be"][[5 3 4] "backward, but let him cheerfully allow himself to spend and be spent in"][[5 3 5] "that way. And the man that has anything bountifully laughable about him,"][[5 3 6] "be sure there is more in that man than you perhaps think for."][[5 4 1] "The bar-room was now full of the boarders who had been dropping in the"][[5 4 2] "night previous, and whom I had not as yet had a good look at. They were"][[5 4 3] "nearly all whalemen; chief mates, and second mates, and third mates, and"][[5 4 4] "sea carpenters, and sea coopers, and sea blacksmiths, and harpooneers,"][[5 4 5] "and ship keepers; a brown and brawny company, with bosky beards; an"][[5 4 6] "unshorn, shaggy set, all wearing monkey jackets for morning gowns."][[5 5 1] "You could pretty plainly tell how long each one had been ashore. This"][[5 5 2] "young fellow's healthy cheek is like a sun-toasted pear in hue, and"][[5 5 3] "would seem to smell almost as musky; he cannot have been three days"][[5 5 4] "landed from his Indian voyage. That man next him looks a few shades"][[5 5 5] "lighter; you might say a touch of satin wood is in him. In the"][[5 5 6] "complexion of a third still lingers a tropic tawn, but slightly bleached"][[5 5 7] "withal; HE doubtless has tarried whole weeks ashore. But who could show"][[5 5 8] "a cheek like Queequeg? which, barred with various tints, seemed like the"][[5 5 9] "Andes' western slope, to show forth in one array, contrasting climates,"][[5 5 10] "zone by zone."][[5 6 1] "\"Grub, ho!\" now cried the landlord, flinging open a door, and in we went"][[5 6 2] "to breakfast."][[5 7 1] "They say that men who have seen the world, thereby become quite at ease"][[5 7 2] "in manner, quite self-possessed in company. Not always, though: Ledyard,"][[5 7 3] "the great New England traveller, and Mungo Park, the Scotch one; of all"][[5 7 4] "men, they possessed the least assurance in the parlor. But perhaps the"][[5 7 5] "mere crossing of Siberia in a sledge drawn by dogs as Ledyard did, or"][[5 7 6] "the taking a long solitary walk on an empty stomach, in the negro heart"][[5 7 7] "of Africa, which was the sum of poor Mungo's performances--this kind of"][[5 7 8] "travel, I say, may not be the very best mode of attaining a high social"][[5 7 9] "polish. Still, for the most part, that sort of thing is to be had"][[5 7 10] "anywhere."][[5 8 1] "These reflections just here are occasioned by the circumstance that"][[5 8 2] "after we were all seated at the table, and I was preparing to hear some"][[5 8 3] "good stories about whaling; to my no small surprise, nearly every"][[5 8 4] "man maintained a profound silence. And not only that, but they looked"][[5 8 5] "embarrassed. Yes, here were a set of sea-dogs, many of whom without the"][[5 8 6] "slightest bashfulness had boarded great whales on the high seas--entire"][[5 8 7] "strangers to them--and duelled them dead without winking; and yet, here"][[5 8 8] "they sat at a social breakfast table--all of the same calling, all of"][[5 8 9] "kindred tastes--looking round as sheepishly at each other as though they"][[5 8 10] "had never been out of sight of some sheepfold among the Green Mountains."][[5 8 11] "A curious sight; these bashful bears, these timid warrior whalemen!"][[5 9 1] "But as for Queequeg--why, Queequeg sat there among them--at the head of"][[5 9 2] "the table, too, it so chanced; as cool as an icicle. To be sure I cannot"][[5 9 3] "say much for his breeding. His greatest admirer could not have cordially"][[5 9 4] "justified his bringing his harpoon into breakfast with him, and using it"][[5 9 5] "there without ceremony; reaching over the table with it, to the imminent"][[5 9 6] "jeopardy of many heads, and grappling the beefsteaks towards him.
