But"][[5 9 7] "THAT was certainly very coolly done by him, and every one knows that in"][[5 9 8] "most people's estimation, to do anything coolly is to do it genteelly."][[5 10 1] "We will not speak of all Queequeg's peculiarities here; how he eschewed"][[5 10 2] "coffee and hot rolls, and applied his undivided attention to beefsteaks,"][[5 10 3] "done rare. Enough, that when breakfast was over he withdrew like the"][[5 10 4] "rest into the public room, lighted his tomahawk-pipe, and was sitting"][[5 10 5] "there quietly digesting and smoking with his inseparable hat on, when I"][[5 10 6] "sallied out for a stroll."][[6 0 0] "CHAPTER 6. The Street."][[6 2 1] "If I had been astonished at first catching a glimpse of so outlandish"][[6 2 2] "an individual as Queequeg circulating among the polite society of a"][[6 2 3] "civilized town, that astonishment soon departed upon taking my first"][[6 2 4] "daylight stroll through the streets of New Bedford."][[6 3 1] "In thoroughfares nigh the docks, any considerable seaport will"][[6 3 2] "frequently offer to view the queerest looking nondescripts from foreign"][[6 3 3] "parts. Even in Broadway and Chestnut streets, Mediterranean mariners"][[6 3 4] "will sometimes jostle the affrighted ladies. Regent Street is not"][[6 3 5] "unknown to Lascars and Malays; and at Bombay, in the Apollo Green, live"][[6 3 6] "Yankees have often scared the natives. But New Bedford beats all Water"][[6 3 7] "Street and Wapping. In these last-mentioned haunts you see only sailors;"][[6 3 8] "but in New Bedford, actual cannibals stand chatting at street corners;"][[6 3 9] "savages outright; many of whom yet carry on their bones unholy flesh. It"][[6 3 10] "makes a stranger stare."][[6 4 1] "But, besides the Feegeeans, Tongatobooarrs, Erromanggoans, Pannangians,"][[6 4 2] "and Brighggians, and, besides the wild specimens of the whaling-craft"][[6 4 3] "which unheeded reel about the streets, you will see other sights still"][[6 4 4] "more curious, certainly more comical. There weekly arrive in this town"][[6 4 5] "scores of green Vermonters and New Hampshire men, all athirst for gain"][[6 4 6] "and glory in the fishery. They are mostly young, of stalwart frames;"][[6 4 7] "fellows who have felled forests, and now seek to drop the axe and snatch"][[6 4 8] "the whale-lance. Many are as green as the Green Mountains whence they"][[6 4 9] "came. In some things you would think them but a few hours old. Look"][[6 4 10] "there! that chap strutting round the corner. He wears a beaver hat and"][[6 4 11] "swallow-tailed coat, girdled with a sailor-belt and sheath-knife. Here"][[6 4 12] "comes another with a sou'-wester and a bombazine cloak."][[6 5 1] "No town-bred dandy will compare with a country-bred one--I mean a"][[6 5 2] "downright bumpkin dandy--a fellow that, in the dog-days, will mow his"][[6 5 3] "two acres in buckskin gloves for fear of tanning his hands. Now when a"][[6 5 4] "country dandy like this takes it into his head to make a distinguished"][[6 5 5] "reputation, and joins the great whale-fishery, you should see the"][[6 5 6] "comical things he does upon reaching the seaport. In bespeaking his"][[6 5 7] "sea-outfit, he orders bell-buttons to his waistcoats; straps to his"][[6 5 8] "canvas trowsers. Ah, poor Hay-Seed! how bitterly will burst those straps"][[6 5 9] "in the first howling gale, when thou art driven, straps, buttons, and"][[6 5 10] "all, down the throat of the tempest."][[6 6 1] "But think not that this famous town has only harpooneers, cannibals, and"][[6 6 2] "bumpkins to show her visitors. Not at all. Still New Bedford is a queer"][[6 6 3] "place. Had it not been for us whalemen, that tract of land would this"][[6 6 4] "day perhaps have been in as howling condition as the coast of Labrador."][[6 6 5] "As it is, parts of her back country are enough to frighten one, they"][[6 6 6] "look so bony. The town itself is perhaps the dearest place to live"][[6 6 7] "in, in all New England. It is a land of oil, true enough: but not like"][[6 6 8] "Canaan; a land, also, of corn and wine. The streets do not run with"][[6 6 9] "milk; nor in the spring-time do they pave them with fresh eggs. Yet, in"][[6 6 10] "spite of this, nowhere in all America will you find more patrician-like"][[6 6 11] "houses; parks and gardens more opulent, than in New Bedford. Whence came"][[6 6 12] "they? how planted upon this once scraggy scoria of a country?"][[6 7 1] "Go and gaze upon the iron emblematical harpoons round yonder lofty"][[6 7 2] "mansion, and your question will be answered. Yes; all these brave houses"][[6 7 3] "and flowery gardens came from the Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian oceans."][[6 7 4] "One and all, they were harpooned and dragged up hither from the bottom"][[6 7 5] "of the sea. Can Herr Alexander perform a feat like that?"][[6 8 1] "In New Bedford, fathers, they say, give whales for dowers to their"][[6 8 2] "daughters, and portion off their nieces with a few porpoises a-piece."][[6 8 3] "You must go to New Bedford to see a brilliant wedding; for, they say,"][[6 8 4] "they have reservoirs of oil in every house, and every night recklessly"][[6 8 5] "burn their lengths in spermaceti candles."][[6 9 1] "In summer time, the town is sweet to see; full of fine maples--long"][[6 9 2] "avenues of green and gold. And in August, high in air, the beautiful and"][[6 9 3] "bountiful horse-chestnuts, candelabra-wise, proffer the passer-by their"][[6 9 4] "tapering upright cones of congregated blossoms. So omnipotent is art;"][[6 9 5] "which in many a district of New Bedford has superinduced bright terraces"][[6 9 6] "of flowers upon the barren refuse rocks thrown aside at creation's final"][[6 9 7] "day."][[6 10 1] "And the women of New Bedford, they bloom like their own red roses. But"][[6 10 2] "roses only bloom in summer; whereas the fine carnation of their cheeks"][[6 10 3] "is perennial as sunlight in the seventh heavens. Elsewhere match that"][[6 10 4] "bloom of theirs, ye cannot, save in Salem, where they tell me the young"][[6 10 5] "girls breathe such musk, their sailor sweethearts smell them miles off"][[6 10 6] "shore, as though they were drawing nigh the odorous Moluccas instead of"][[6 10 7] "the Puritanic sands."][[7 0 0] "CHAPTER 7. The Chapel."][[7 2 1] "In this same New Bedford there stands a Whaleman's Chapel, and few are"][[7 2 2] "the moody fishermen, shortly bound for the Indian Ocean or Pacific, who"][[7 2 3] "fail to make a Sunday visit to the spot. I am sure that I did not."][[7 3 1] "Returning from my first morning stroll, I again sallied out upon this"][[7 3 2] "special errand. The sky had changed from clear, sunny cold, to driving"][[7 3 3] "sleet and mist. Wrapping myself in my shaggy jacket of the cloth called"][[7 3 4] "bearskin, I fought my way against the stubborn storm. Entering, I"][[7 3 5] "found a small scattered congregation of sailors, and sailors' wives and"][[7 3 6] "widows. A muffled silence reigned, only broken at times by the shrieks"][[7 3 7] "of the storm. Each silent worshipper seemed purposely sitting apart from"][[7 3 8] "the other, as if each silent grief were insular and incommunicable. The"][[7 3 9] "chaplain had not yet arrived; and there these silent islands of men and"][[7 3 10] "women sat steadfastly eyeing several marble tablets, with black borders,"][[7 3 11] "masoned into the wall on either side the pulpit. Three of them ran"][[7 3 12] "something like the following, but I do not pretend to quote:--"][[7 4 1] "SACRED TO THE MEMORY OF JOHN TALBOT, Who, at the age of eighteen, was"][[7 4 2] "lost overboard, Near the Isle of Desolation, off Patagonia, November"][[7 4 3] "st, . THIS TABLET Is erected to his Memory BY HIS SISTER."][[7 5 1] "SACRED TO THE MEMORY OF ROBERT LONG, WILLIS ELLERY, NATHAN COLEMAN,"][[7 5 2] "WALTER CANNY, SETH MACY, AND SAMUEL GLEIG, Forming one of the boats'"][[7 5 3] "crews OF THE SHIP ELIZA Who were towed out of sight by a Whale, On the"][[7 5 4] "Off-shore Ground in the PACIFIC, December st, . THIS MARBLE Is"][[7 5 5] "here placed by their surviving SHIPMATES."][[7 6 1] "SACRED TO THE MEMORY OF The late CAPTAIN EZEKIEL HARDY, Who in the bows"][[7 6 2] "of his boat was killed by a Sperm Whale on the coast of Japan, AUGUST"][[7 6 3] "d, . THIS TABLET Is erected to his Memory BY HIS WIDOW."][[7 7 1] "Shaking off the sleet from my ice-glazed hat and jacket, I seated myself"][[7 7 2] "near the door, and turning sideways was surprised to see Queequeg near"][[7 7 3] "me. Affected by the solemnity of the scene, there was a wondering gaze"][[7 7 4] "of incredulous curiosity in his countenance. This savage was the only"][[7 7 5] "person present who seemed to notice my entrance; because he was the only"][[7 7 6] "one who could not read, and, therefore, was not reading those frigid"][[7 7 7] "inscriptions on the wall. Whether any of the relatives of the seamen"][[7 7 8] "whose names appeared there were now among the congregation, I knew not;"][[7 7 9] "but so many are the unrecorded accidents in the fishery, and so plainly"][[7 7 10] "did several women present wear the countenance if not the trappings"][[7 7 11] "of some unceasing grief, that I feel sure that here before me were"][[7 7 12] "assembled those, in whose unhealing hearts the sight of those bleak"][[7 7 13] "tablets sympathetically caused the old wounds to bleed afresh."][[7 8 1] "Oh! ye whose dead lie buried beneath the green grass; who standing among"][[7 8 2] "flowers can say--here, HERE lies my beloved; ye know not the desolation"][[7 8 3] "that broods in bosoms like these. What bitter blanks in those"][[7 8 4] "black-bordered marbles which cover no ashes! What despair in those"][[7 8 5] "immovable inscriptions! What deadly voids and unbidden infidelities in"][[7 8 6] "the lines that seem to gnaw upon all Faith, and refuse resurrections to"][[7 8 7] "the beings who have placelessly perished without a grave. As well might"][[7 8 8] "those tablets stand in the cave of Elephanta as here."][[7 9 1] "In what census of living creatures, the dead of mankind are included;"][[7 9 2] "why it is that a universal proverb says of them, that they tell no"][[7 9 3] "tales, though containing more secrets than the Goodwin Sands; how it is"][[7 9 4] "that to his name who yesterday departed for the other world, we prefix"][[7 9 5] "so significant and infidel a word, and yet do not thus entitle him, if"][[7 9 6] "he but embarks for the remotest Indies of this living earth; why the"][[7 9 7] "Life Insurance Companies pay death-forfeitures upon immortals; in what"][[7 9 8] "eternal, unstirring paralysis, and deadly, hopeless trance, yet lies"][[7 9 9] "antique Adam who died sixty round centuries ago; how it is that we"][[7 9 10] "still refuse to be comforted for those who we nevertheless maintain are"][[7 9 11] "dwelling in unspeakable bliss; why all the living so strive to hush all"][[7 9 12] "the dead; wherefore but the rumor of a knocking in a tomb will terrify a"][[7 9 13] "whole city. All these things are not without their meanings."][[7 10 1] "But Faith, like a jackal, feeds among the tombs, and even from these"][[7 10 2] "dead doubts she gathers her most vital hope."][[7 11 1] "It needs scarcely to be told, with what feelings, on the eve of a"][[7 11 2] "Nantucket voyage, I regarded those marble tablets, and by the murky"][[7 11 3] "light of that darkened, doleful day read the fate of the whalemen"][[7 11 4] "who had gone before me. Yes, Ishmael, the same fate may be thine. But"][[7 11 5] "somehow I grew merry again. Delightful inducements to embark, fine"][[7 11 6] "chance for promotion, it seems--aye, a stove boat will make me an"][[7 11 7] "immortal by brevet. Yes, there is death in this business of whaling--a"][[7 11 8] "speechlessly quick chaotic bundling of a man into Eternity. But what"][[7 11 9] "then? Methinks we have hugely mistaken this matter of Life and Death."][[7 11 10] "Methinks that what they call my shadow here on earth is my true"][[7 11 11] "substance. Methinks that in looking at things spiritual, we are too"][[7 11 12] "much like oysters observing the sun through the water, and thinking that"][[7 11 13] "thick water the thinnest of air. Methinks my body is but the lees of my"][[7 11 14] "better being. In fact take my body who will, take it I say, it is not"][[7 11 15] "me. And therefore three cheers for Nantucket; and come a stove boat and"][[7 11 16] "stove body when they will, for stave my soul, Jove himself cannot."][[8 0 0] "CHAPTER 8. The Pulpit."][[8 2 1] "I had not been seated very long ere a man of a certain venerable"][[8 2 2] "robustness entered; immediately as the storm-pelted door flew back upon"][[8 2 3] "admitting him, a quick regardful eyeing of him by all the congregation,"][[8 2 4] "sufficiently attested that this fine old man was the chaplain. Yes, it"][[8 2 5] "was the famous Father Mapple, so called by the whalemen, among whom he"][[8 2 6] "was a very great favourite. He had been a sailor and a harpooneer in his"][[8 2 7] "youth, but for many years past had dedicated his life to the ministry."][[8 2 8] "At the time I now write of, Father Mapple was in the hardy winter of a"][[8 2 9] "healthy old age; that sort of old age which seems merging into a second"][[8 2 10] "flowering youth, for among all the fissures of his wrinkles, there shone"][[8 2 11] "certain mild gleams of a newly developing bloom--the spring verdure"][[8 2 12] "peeping forth even beneath February's snow. No one having previously"][[8 2 13] "heard his history, could for the first time behold Father Mapple without"][[8 2 14] "the utmost interest, because there were certain engrafted clerical"][[8 2 15] "peculiarities about him, imputable to that adventurous maritime life"][[8 2 16] "he had led. When he entered I observed that he carried no umbrella, and"][[8 2 17] "certainly had not come in his carriage, for his tarpaulin hat ran down"][[8 2 18] "with melting sleet, and his great pilot cloth jacket seemed almost to"][[8 2 19] "drag him to the floor with the weight of the water it had absorbed."][[8 2 20] "However, hat and coat and overshoes were one by one removed, and hung up"][[8 2 21] "in a little space in an adjacent corner; when, arrayed in a decent suit,"][[8 2 22] "he quietly approached the pulpit."][[8 3 1] "Like most old fashioned pulpits, it was a very lofty one, and since a"][[8 3 2] "regular stairs to such a height would, by its long angle with the floor,"][[8 3 3] "seriously contract the already small area of the chapel, the architect,"][[8 3 4] "it seemed, had acted upon the hint of Father Mapple, and finished the"][[8 3 5] "pulpit without a stairs, substituting a perpendicular side ladder, like"][[8 3 6] "those used in mounting a ship from a boat at sea. The wife of a whaling"][[8 3 7] "captain had provided the chapel with a handsome pair of red worsted"][[8 3 8] "man-ropes for this ladder, which, being itself nicely headed, and"][[8 3 9] "stained with a mahogany colour, the whole contrivance, considering what"][[8 3 10] "manner of chapel it was, seemed by no means in bad taste. Halting for"][[8 3 11] "an instant at the foot of the ladder, and with both hands grasping the"][[8 3 12] "ornamental knobs of the man-ropes, Father Mapple cast a look upwards,"][[8 3 13] "and then with a truly sailor-like but still reverential dexterity, hand"][[8 3 14] "over hand, mounted the steps as if ascending the main-top of his vessel."][[8 4 1] "The perpendicular parts of this side ladder, as is usually the case with"][[8 4 2] "swinging ones, were of cloth-covered rope, only the rounds were of wood,"][[8 4 3] "so that at every step there was a joint. At my first glimpse of the"][[8 4 4] "pulpit, it had not escaped me that however convenient for a ship,"][[8 4 5] "these joints in the present instance seemed unnecessary. For I was not"][[8 4 6] "prepared to see Father Mapple after gaining the height, slowly turn"][[8 4 7] "round, and stooping over the pulpit, deliberately drag up the ladder"][[8 4 8] "step by step, till the whole was deposited within, leaving him"][[8 4 9] "impregnable in his little Quebec."][[8 5 1] "I pondered some time without fully comprehending the reason for this."][[8 5 2] "Father Mapple enjoyed such a wide reputation for sincerity and sanctity,"][[8 5 3] "that I could not suspect him of courting notoriety by any mere tricks"][[8 5 4] "of the stage. No, thought I, there must be some sober reason for this"][[8 5 5] "thing; furthermore, it must symbolize something unseen. Can it be,"][[8 5 6] "then, that by that act of physical isolation, he signifies his spiritual"][[8 5 7] "withdrawal for the time, from all outward worldly ties and connexions?"][[8 5 8] "Yes, for replenished with the meat and wine of the word, to the faithful"][[8 5 9] "man of God, this pulpit, I see, is a self-containing stronghold--a lofty"][[8 5 10] "Ehrenbreitstein, with a perennial well of water within the walls."][[8 6 1] "But the side ladder was not the only strange feature of the place,"][[8 6 2] "borrowed from the chaplain's former sea-farings. Between the marble"][[8 6 3] "cenotaphs on either hand of the pulpit, the wall which formed its back"][[8 6 4] "was adorned with a large painting representing a gallant ship beating"][[8 6 5] "against a terrible storm off a lee coast of black rocks and snowy"][[8 6 6] "breakers. But high above the flying scud and dark-rolling clouds, there"][[8 6 7] "floated a little isle of sunlight, from which beamed forth an angel's"][[8 6 8] "face; and this bright face shed a distinct spot of radiance upon the"][[8 6 9] "ship's tossed deck, something like that silver plate now inserted into"][[8 6 10] "the Victory's plank where Nelson fell. \"Ah, noble ship,\" the angel"][[8 6 11] "seemed to say, \"beat on, beat on, thou noble ship, and bear a hardy"][[8 6 12] "helm; for lo! the sun is breaking through; the clouds are rolling"][[8 6 13] "off--serenest azure is at hand.\""][[8 7 1] "Nor was the pulpit itself without a trace of the same sea-taste that"][[8 7 2] "had achieved the ladder and the picture. Its panelled front was in"][[8 7 3] "the likeness of a ship's bluff bows, and the Holy Bible rested on a"][[8 7 4] "projecting piece of scroll work, fashioned after a ship's fiddle-headed"][[8 7 5] "beak."][[8 8 1] "What could be more full of meaning?--for the pulpit is ever this earth's"][[8 8 2] "foremost part; all the rest comes in its rear; the pulpit leads the"][[8 8 3] "world. From thence it is the storm of God's quick wrath is first"][[8 8 4] "descried, and the bow must bear the earliest brunt. From thence it is"][[8 8 5] "the God of breezes fair or foul is first invoked for favourable winds."][[8 8 6] "Yes, the world's a ship on its passage out, and not a voyage complete;"][[8 8 7] "and the pulpit is its prow."][[9 0 0] "CHAPTER 9. The Sermon."][[9 2 1] "Father Mapple rose, and in a mild voice of unassuming authority ordered"][[9 2 2] "the scattered people to condense. \"Starboard gangway, there! side away"][[9 2 3] "to larboard--larboard gangway to starboard! Midships! midships!\""][[9 3 1] "There was a low rumbling of heavy sea-boots among the benches, and a"][[9 3 2] "still slighter shuffling of women's shoes, and all was quiet again, and"][[9 3 3] "every eye on the preacher."][[9 4 1] "He paused a little; then kneeling in the pulpit's bows, folded his large"][[9 4 2] "brown hands across his chest, uplifted his closed eyes, and offered"][[9 4 3] "a prayer so deeply devout that he seemed kneeling and praying at the"][[9 4 4] "bottom of the sea."][[9 5 1] "This ended, in prolonged solemn tones, like the continual tolling of"][[9 5 2] "a bell in a ship that is foundering at sea in a fog--in such tones he"][[9 5 3] "commenced reading the following hymn; but changing his manner towards"][[9 5 4] "the concluding stanzas, burst forth with a pealing exultation and joy--"][[9 6 1] "\"The ribs and terrors in the whale,"][[9 6 2] "Arched over me a dismal gloom,"][[9 6 3] "While all God's sun-lit waves rolled by,"][[9 6 4] "And lift me deepening down to doom."][[9 7 1] "\"I saw the opening maw of hell,"][[9 7 2] "With endless pains and sorrows there;"][[9 7 3] "Which none but they that feel can tell--"][[9 7 4] "Oh, I was plunging to despair."][[9 8 1] "\"In black distress, I called my God,"][[9 8 2] "When I could scarce believe him mine,"][[9 8 3] "He bowed his ear to my complaints--"][[9 8 4] "No more the whale did me confine."][[9 9 1] "\"With speed he flew to my relief,"][[9 9 2] "As on a radiant dolphin borne;"][[9 9 3] "Awful, yet bright, as lightning shone"][[9 9 4] "The face of my Deliverer God."][[9 10 1] "\"My song for ever shall record"][[9 10 2] "That terrible, that joyful hour;"][[9 10 3] "I give the glory to my God,"][[9 10 4] "His all the mercy and the power.\""][[9 12 1] "Nearly all joined in singing this hymn, which swelled high above the"][[9 12 2] "howling of the storm. A brief pause ensued; the preacher slowly turned"][[9 12 3] "over the leaves of the Bible, and at last, folding his hand down upon"][[9 12 4] "the proper page, said: \"Beloved shipmates, clinch the last verse of the"][[9 12 5] "first chapter of Jonah--'And God had prepared a great fish to swallow up"][[9 12 6] "Jonah.'\""][[9 13 1] "\"Shipmates, this book, containing only four chapters--four yarns--is one"][[9 13 2] "of the smallest strands in the mighty cable of the Scriptures. Yet what"][[9 13 3] "depths of the soul does Jonah's deep sealine sound! what a pregnant"][[9 13 4] "lesson to us is this prophet! What a noble thing is that canticle in the"][[9 13 5] "fish's belly! How billow-like and boisterously grand! We feel the floods"][[9 13 6] "surging over us; we sound with him to the kelpy bottom of the waters;"][[9 13 7] "sea-weed and all the slime of the sea is about us! But WHAT is this"][[9 13 8] "lesson that the book of Jonah teaches? Shipmates, it is a two-stranded"][[9 13 9] "lesson; a lesson to us all as sinful men, and a lesson to me as a pilot"][[9 13 10] "of the living God. As sinful men, it is a lesson to us all, because it"][[9 13 11] "is a story of the sin, hard-heartedness, suddenly awakened fears, the"][[9 13 12] "swift punishment, repentance, prayers, and finally the deliverance and"][[9 13 13] "joy of Jonah. As with all sinners among men, the sin of this son of"][[9 13 14] "Amittai was in his wilful disobedience of the command of God--never"][[9 13 15] "mind now what that command was, or how conveyed--which he found a hard"][[9 13 16] "command. But all the things that God would have us do are hard for us to"][[9 13 17] "do--remember that--and hence, he oftener commands us than endeavors to"][[9 13 18] "persuade. And if we obey God, we must disobey ourselves; and it is in"][[9 13 19] "this disobeying ourselves, wherein the hardness of obeying God consists."][[9 14 1] "\"With this sin of disobedience in him, Jonah still further flouts at"][[9 14 2] "God, by seeking to flee from Him. He thinks that a ship made by men will"][[9 14 3] "carry him into countries where God does not reign, but only the Captains"][[9 14 4] "of this earth. He skulks about the wharves of Joppa, and seeks a ship"][[9 14 5] "that's bound for Tarshish. There lurks, perhaps, a hitherto unheeded"][[9 14 6] "meaning here. By all accounts Tarshish could have been no other city"][[9 14 7] "than the modern Cadiz. That's the opinion of learned men. And where is"][[9 14 8] "Cadiz, shipmates? Cadiz is in Spain; as far by water, from Joppa,"][[9 14 9] "as Jonah could possibly have sailed in those ancient days, when the"][[9 14 10] "Atlantic was an almost unknown sea. Because Joppa, the modern Jaffa,"][[9 14 11] "shipmates, is on the most easterly coast of the Mediterranean, the"][[9 14 12] "Syrian; and Tarshish or Cadiz more than two thousand miles to the"][[9 14 13] "westward from that, just outside the Straits of Gibraltar. See ye"][[9 14 14] "not then, shipmates, that Jonah sought to flee world-wide from God?"][[9 14 15] "Miserable man! Oh! most contemptible and worthy of all scorn; with"][[9 14 16] "slouched hat and guilty eye, skulking from his God; prowling among the"][[9 14 17] "shipping like a vile burglar hastening to cross the seas. So disordered,"][[9 14 18] "self-condemning is his look, that had there been policemen in those"][[9 14 19] "days, Jonah, on the mere suspicion of something wrong, had been arrested"][[9 14 20] "ere he touched a deck. How plainly he's a fugitive! no baggage, not a"][[9 14 21] "hat-box, valise, or carpet-bag,--no friends accompany him to the wharf"][[9 14 22] "with their adieux. At last, after much dodging search, he finds the"][[9 14 23] "Tarshish ship receiving the last items of her cargo; and as he steps on"][[9 14 24] "board to see its Captain in the cabin, all the sailors for the moment"][[9 14 25] "desist from hoisting in the goods, to mark the stranger's evil eye."][[9 14 26] "Jonah sees this; but in vain he tries to look all ease and confidence;"][[9 14 27] "in vain essays his wretched smile. Strong intuitions of the man assure"][[9 14 28] "the mariners he can be no innocent. In their gamesome but still serious"][[9 14 29] "way, one whispers to the other--\"Jack, he's robbed a widow;\" or, \"Joe,"][[9 14 30] "do you mark him; he's a bigamist;\" or, \"Harry lad, I guess he's the"][[9 14 31] "adulterer that broke jail in old Gomorrah, or belike, one of the missing"][[9 14 32] "murderers from Sodom.\" Another runs to read the bill that's stuck"][[9 14 33] "against the spile upon the wharf to which the ship is moored, offering"][[9 14 34] "five hundred gold coins for the apprehension of a parricide, and"][[9 14 35] "containing a description of his person. He reads, and looks from Jonah"][[9 14 36] "to the bill; while all his sympathetic shipmates now crowd round Jonah,"][[9 14 37] "prepared to lay their hands upon him. Frighted Jonah trembles, and"][[9 14 38] "summoning all his boldness to his face, only looks so much the more a"][[9 14 39] "coward. He will not confess himself suspected; but that itself is strong"][[9 14 40] "suspicion. So he makes the best of it; and when the sailors find him"][[9 14 41] "not to be the man that is advertised, they let him pass, and he descends"][[9 14 42] "into the cabin."][[9 15 1] "\"'Who's there?' cries the Captain at his busy desk, hurriedly making"][[9 15 2] "out his papers for the Customs--'Who's there?' Oh! how that harmless"][[9 15 3] "question mangles Jonah! For the instant he almost turns to flee again."][[9 15 4] "But he rallies. 'I seek a passage in this ship to Tarshish; how soon"][[9 15 5] "sail ye, sir?' Thus far the busy Captain had not looked up to Jonah,"][[9 15 6] "though the man now stands before him; but no sooner does he hear that"][[9 15 7] "hollow voice, than he darts a scrutinizing glance. 'We sail with the"][[9 15 8] "next coming tide,' at last he slowly answered, still intently eyeing"][[9 15 9] "him. 'No sooner, sir?'--'Soon enough for any honest man that goes a"][[9 15 10] "passenger.' Ha! Jonah, that's another stab. But he swiftly calls away"][[9 15 11] "the Captain from that scent. 'I'll sail with ye,'--he says,--'the"][[9 15 12] "passage money how much is that?--I'll pay now.' For it is particularly"][[9 15 13] "written, shipmates, as if it were a thing not to be overlooked in this"][[9 15 14] "history, 'that he paid the fare thereof' ere the craft did sail. And"][[9 15 15] "taken with the context, this is full of meaning."][[9 16 1] "\"Now Jonah's Captain, shipmates, was one whose discernment detects crime"][[9 16 2] "in any, but whose cupidity exposes it only in the penniless. In this"][[9 16 3] "world, shipmates, sin that pays its way can travel freely, and without"][[9 16 4] "a passport; whereas Virtue, if a pauper, is stopped at all frontiers."][[9 16 5] "So Jonah's Captain prepares to test the length of Jonah's purse, ere he"][[9 16 6] "judge him openly. He charges him thrice the usual sum; and it's assented"][[9 16 7] "to. Then the Captain knows that Jonah is a fugitive; but at the same"][[9 16 8] "time resolves to help a flight that paves its rear with gold. Yet when"][[9 16 9] "Jonah fairly takes out his purse, prudent suspicions still molest the"][[9 16 10] "Captain. He rings every coin to find a counterfeit. Not a forger, any"][[9 16 11] "way, he mutters; and Jonah is put down for his passage. 'Point out my"][[9 16 12] "state-room, Sir,' says Jonah now, 'I'm travel-weary; I need sleep.'"][[9 16 13] "'Thou lookest like it,' says the Captain, 'there's thy room.' Jonah"][[9 16 14] "enters, and would lock the door, but the lock contains no key. Hearing"][[9 16 15] "him foolishly fumbling there, the Captain laughs lowly to himself, and"][[9 16 16] "mutters something about the doors of convicts' cells being never allowed"][[9 16 17] "to be locked within. All dressed and dusty as he is, Jonah throws"][[9 16 18] "himself into his berth, and finds the little state-room ceiling almost"][[9 16 19] "resting on his forehead. The air is close, and Jonah gasps. Then, in"][[9 16 20] "that contracted hole, sunk, too, beneath the ship's water-line, Jonah"][[9 16 21] "feels the heralding presentiment of that stifling hour, when the whale"][[9 16 22] "shall hold him in the smallest of his bowels' wards."][[9 17 1] "\"Screwed at its axis against the side, a swinging lamp slightly"][[9 17 2] "oscillates in Jonah's room; and the ship, heeling over towards the wharf"][[9 17 3] "with the weight of the last bales received, the lamp, flame and all,"][[9 17 4] "though in slight motion, still maintains a permanent obliquity with"][[9 17 5] "reference to the room; though, in truth, infallibly straight itself, it"][[9 17 6] "but made obvious the false, lying levels among which it hung. The lamp"][[9 17 7] "alarms and frightens Jonah; as lying in his berth his tormented eyes"][[9 17 8] "roll round the place, and this thus far successful fugitive finds no"][[9 17 9] "refuge for his restless glance. But that contradiction in the lamp more"][[9 17 10] "and more appals him. The floor, the ceiling, and the side, are all awry."][[9 17 11] "'Oh! so my conscience hangs in me!' he groans, 'straight upwards, so it"][[9 17 12] "burns; but the chambers of my soul are all in crookedness!'"][[9 18 1] "\"Like one who after a night of drunken revelry hies to his bed, still"][[9 18 2] "reeling, but with conscience yet pricking him, as the plungings of the"][[9 18 3] "Roman race-horse but so much the more strike his steel tags into him; as"][[9 18 4] "one who in that miserable plight still turns and turns in giddy anguish,"][[9 18 5] "praying God for annihilation until the fit be passed; and at last amid"][[9 18 6] "the whirl of woe he feels, a deep stupor steals over him, as over the"][[9 18 7] "man who bleeds to death, for conscience is the wound, and there's naught"][[9 18 8] "to staunch it; so, after sore wrestlings in his berth, Jonah's prodigy"][[9 18 9] "of ponderous misery drags him drowning down to sleep."][[9 19 1] "\"And now the time of tide has come; the ship casts off her cables; and"][[9 19 2] "from the deserted wharf the uncheered ship for Tarshish, all careening,"][[9 19 3] "glides to sea. That ship, my friends, was the first of recorded"][[9 19 4] "smugglers! the contraband was Jonah. But the sea rebels; he will not"][[9 19 5] "bear the wicked burden. A dreadful storm comes on, the ship is like to"][[9 19 6] "break. But now when the boatswain calls all hands to lighten her;"][[9 19 7] "when boxes, bales, and jars are clattering overboard; when the wind"][[9 19 8] "is shrieking, and the men are yelling, and every plank thunders with"][[9 19 9] "trampling feet right over Jonah's head; in all this raging tumult, Jonah"][[9 19 10] "sleeps his hideous sleep. He sees no black sky and raging sea, feels not"][[9 19 11] "the reeling timbers, and little hears he or heeds he the far rush of the"][[9 19 12] "mighty whale, which even now with open mouth is cleaving the seas after"][[9 19 13] "him. Aye, shipmates, Jonah was gone down into the sides of the ship--a"][[9 19 14] "berth in the cabin as I have taken it, and was fast asleep. But the"][[9 19 15] "frightened master comes to him, and shrieks in his dead ear, 'What"][[9 19 16] "meanest thou, O, sleeper! arise!' Startled from his lethargy by that"][[9 19 17] "direful cry, Jonah staggers to his feet, and stumbling to the deck,"][[9 19 18] "grasps a shroud, to look out upon the sea. But at that moment he is"][[9 19 19] "sprung upon by a panther billow leaping over the bulwarks. Wave after"][[9 19 20] "wave thus leaps into the ship, and finding no speedy vent runs roaring"][[9 19 21] "fore and aft, till the mariners come nigh to drowning while yet afloat."][[9 19 22] "And ever, as the white moon shows her affrighted face from the steep"][[9 19 23] "gullies in the blackness overhead, aghast Jonah sees the rearing"][[9 19 24] "bowsprit pointing high upward, but soon beat downward again towards the"][[9 19 25] "tormented deep."][[9 20 1] "\"Terrors upon terrors run shouting through his soul. In all his cringing"][[9 20 2] "attitudes, the God-fugitive is now too plainly known. The sailors mark"][[9 20 3] "him; more and more certain grow their suspicions of him, and at last,"][[9 20 4] "fully to test the truth, by referring the whole matter to high Heaven,"][[9 20 5] "they fall to casting lots, to see for whose cause this great tempest was"][[9 20 6] "upon them. The lot is Jonah's; that discovered, then how furiously they"][[9 20 7] "mob him with their questions. 'What is thine occupation? Whence comest"][[9 20 8] "thou? Thy country? What people? But mark now, my shipmates, the behavior"][[9 20 9] "of poor Jonah. The eager mariners but ask him who he is, and where"][[9 20 10] "from; whereas, they not only receive an answer to those questions,"][[9 20 11] "but likewise another answer to a question not put by them, but the"][[9 20 12] "unsolicited answer is forced from Jonah by the hard hand of God that is"][[9 20 13] "upon him."][[9 21 1] "\"'I am a Hebrew,' he cries--and then--'I fear the Lord the God of Heaven"][[9 21 2] "who hath made the sea and the dry land!' Fear him, O Jonah? Aye, well"][[9 21 3] "mightest thou fear the Lord God THEN! Straightway, he now goes on to"][[9 21 4] "make a full confession; whereupon the mariners became more and more"][[9 21 5] "appalled, but still are pitiful. For when Jonah, not yet supplicating"][[9 21 6] "God for mercy, since he but too well knew the darkness of his"][[9 21 7] "deserts,--when wretched Jonah cries out to them to take him and cast him"][[9 21 8] "forth into the sea, for he knew that for HIS sake this great tempest"][[9 21 9] "was upon them; they mercifully turn from him, and seek by other means to"][[9 21 10] "save the ship. But all in vain; the indignant gale howls louder;"][[9 21 11] "then, with one hand raised invokingly to God, with the other they not"][[9 21 12] "unreluctantly lay hold of Jonah."][[9 22 1] "\"And now behold Jonah taken up as an anchor and dropped into the sea;"][[9 22 2] "when instantly an oily calmness floats out from the east, and the sea"][[9 22 3] "is still, as Jonah carries down the gale with him, leaving smooth"][[9 22 4] "water behind. He goes down in the whirling heart of such a masterless"][[9 22 5] "commotion that he scarce heeds the moment when he drops seething into"][[9 22 6] "the yawning jaws awaiting him; and the whale shoots-to all his ivory"][[9 22 7] "teeth, like so many white bolts, upon his prison. Then Jonah prayed unto"][[9 22 8] "the Lord out of the fish's belly. But observe his prayer, and learn a"][[9 22 9] "weighty lesson. For sinful as he is, Jonah does not weep and wail for"][[9 22 10] "direct deliverance. He feels that his dreadful punishment is just. He"][[9 22 11] "leaves all his deliverance to God, contenting himself with this, that"][[9 22 12] "spite of all his pains and pangs, he will still look towards His holy"][[9 22 13] "temple. And here, shipmates, is true and faithful repentance; not"][[9 22 14] "clamorous for pardon, but grateful for punishment. And how pleasing to"][[9 22 15] "God was this conduct in Jonah, is shown in the eventual deliverance of"][[9 22 16] "him from the sea and the whale. Shipmates, I do not place Jonah before"][[9 22 17] "you to be copied for his sin but I do place him before you as a model"][[9 22 18] "for repentance. Sin not; but if you do, take heed to repent of it like"][[9 22 19] "Jonah.\""][[9 23 1] "While he was speaking these words, the howling of the shrieking,"][[9 23 2] "slanting storm without seemed to add new power to the preacher, who,"][[9 23 3] "when describing Jonah's sea-storm, seemed tossed by a storm himself."][[9 23 4] "His deep chest heaved as with a ground-swell; his tossed arms seemed the"][[9 23 5] "warring elements at work; and the thunders that rolled away from off his"][[9 23 6] "swarthy brow, and the light leaping from his eye, made all his simple"][[9 23 7] "hearers look on him with a quick fear that was strange to them."][[9 24 1] "There now came a lull in his look, as he silently turned over the leaves"][[9 24 2] "of the Book once more; and, at last, standing motionless, with closed"][[9 24 3] "eyes, for the moment, seemed communing with God and himself."][[9 25 1] "But again he leaned over towards the people, and bowing his head lowly,"][[9 25 2] "with an aspect of the deepest yet manliest humility, he spake these"][[9 25 3] "words:"][[9 26 1] "\"Shipmates, God has laid but one hand upon you; both his hands press"][[9 26 2] "upon me. I have read ye by what murky light may be mine the lesson that"][[9 26 3] "Jonah teaches to all sinners; and therefore to ye, and still more to me,"][[9 26 4] "for I am a greater sinner than ye. And now how gladly would I come down"][[9 26 5] "from this mast-head and sit on the hatches there where you sit, and"][[9 26 6] "listen as you listen, while some one of you reads ME that other and more"][[9 26 7] "awful lesson which Jonah teaches to ME, as a pilot of the living God."][[9 26 8] "How being an anointed pilot-prophet, or speaker of true things, and"][[9 26 9] "bidden by the Lord to sound those unwelcome truths in the ears of a"][[9 26 10] "wicked Nineveh, Jonah, appalled at the hostility he should raise, fled"][[9 26 11] "from his mission, and sought to escape his duty and his God by taking"][[9 26 12] "ship at Joppa. But God is everywhere; Tarshish he never reached. As we"][[9 26 13] "have seen, God came upon him in the whale, and swallowed him down to"][[9 26 14] "living gulfs of doom, and with swift slantings tore him along 'into the"][[9 26 15] "midst of the seas,' where the eddying depths sucked him ten thousand"][[9 26 16] "fathoms down, and 'the weeds were wrapped about his head,' and all the"][[9 26 17] "watery world of woe bowled over him. Yet even then beyond the reach of"][[9 26 18] "any plummet--'out of the belly of hell'--when the whale grounded upon"][[9 26 19] "the ocean's utmost bones, even then, God heard the engulphed, repenting"][[9 26 20] "prophet when he cried. Then God spake unto the fish; and from the"][[9 26 21] "shuddering cold and blackness of the sea, the whale came breeching"][[9 26 22] "up towards the warm and pleasant sun, and all the delights of air and"][[9 26 23] "earth; and 'vomited out Jonah upon the dry land;' when the word of the"][[9 26 24] "Lord came a second time; and Jonah, bruised and beaten--his ears, like"][[9 26 25] "two sea-shells, still multitudinously murmuring of the ocean--Jonah"][[9 26 26] "did the Almighty's bidding. And what was that, shipmates? To preach the"][[9 26 27] "Truth to the face of Falsehood! That was it!"][[9 27 1] "\"This, shipmates, this is that other lesson; and woe to that pilot of"][[9 27 2] "the living God who slights it. Woe to him whom this world charms from"][[9 27 3] "Gospel duty! Woe to him who seeks to pour oil upon the waters when God"][[9 27 4] "has brewed them into a gale! Woe to him who seeks to please rather than"][[9 27 5] "to appal! Woe to him whose good name is more to him than goodness! Woe"][[9 27 6] "to him who, in this world, courts not dishonour! Woe to him who would"][[9 27 7] "not be true, even though to be false were salvation! Yea, woe to him"][[9 27 8] "who, as the great Pilot Paul has it, while preaching to others is"][[9 27 9] "himself a castaway!\""][[9 28 1] "He dropped and fell away from himself for a moment; then lifting his"][[9 28 2] "face to them again, showed a deep joy in his eyes, as he cried out with"][[9 28 3] "a heavenly enthusiasm,--\"But oh! shipmates! on the starboard hand of"][[9 28 4] "every woe, there is a sure delight; and higher the top of that delight,"][[9 28 5] "than the bottom of the woe is deep. Is not the main-truck higher than"][[9 28 6] "the kelson is low? Delight is to him--a far, far upward, and inward"][[9 28 7] "delight--who against the proud gods and commodores of this earth, ever"][[9 28 8] "stands forth his own inexorable self. Delight is to him whose strong"][[9 28 9] "arms yet support him, when the ship of this base treacherous world has"][[9 28 10] "gone down beneath him. Delight is to him, who gives no quarter in the"][[9 28 11] "truth, and kills, burns, and destroys all sin though he pluck it out"][[9 28 12] "from under the robes of Senators and Judges. Delight,--top-gallant"][[9 28 13] "delight is to him, who acknowledges no law or lord, but the Lord his"][[9 28 14] "God, and is only a patriot to heaven. Delight is to him, whom all the"][[9 28 15] "waves of the billows of the seas of the boisterous mob can never shake"][[9 28 16] "from this sure Keel of the Ages. And eternal delight and deliciousness"][[9 28 17] "will be his, who coming to lay him down, can say with his final"][[9 28 18] "breath--O Father!--chiefly known to me by Thy rod--mortal or immortal,"][[9 28 19] "here I die. I have striven to be Thine, more than to be this world's, or"][[9 28 20] "mine own. Yet this is nothing: I leave eternity to Thee; for what is man"][[9 28 21] "that he should live out the lifetime of his God?\""][[9 29 1] "He said no more, but slowly waving a benediction, covered his face with"][[9 29 2] "his hands, and so remained kneeling, till all the people had departed,"][[9 29 3] "and he was left alone in the place."][[10 0 0] "CHAPTER 10. A Bosom Friend."][[10 2 1] "Returning to the Spouter-Inn from the Chapel, I found Queequeg there"][[10 2 2] "quite alone; he having left the Chapel before the benediction some time."][[10 2 3] "He was sitting on a bench before the fire, with his feet on the stove"][[10 2 4] "hearth, and in one hand was holding close up to his face that little"][[10 2 5] "negro idol of his; peering hard into its face, and with a jack-knife"][[10 2 6] "gently whittling away at its nose, meanwhile humming to himself in his"][[10 2 7] "heathenish way."][[10 3 1] "But being now interrupted, he put up the image; and pretty soon, going"][[10 3 2] "to the table, took up a large book there, and placing it on his lap"][[10 3 3] "began counting the pages with deliberate regularity; at every fiftieth"][[10 3 4] "page--as I fancied--stopping a moment, looking vacantly around him, and"][[10 3 5] "giving utterance to a long-drawn gurgling whistle of astonishment. He"][[10 3 6] "would then begin again at the next fifty; seeming to commence at number"][[10 3 7] "one each time, as though he could not count more than fifty, and it was"][[10 3 8] "only by such a large number of fifties being found together, that his"][[10 3 9] "astonishment at the multitude of pages was excited."][[10 4 1] "With much interest I sat watching him. Savage though he was, and"][[10 4 2] "hideously marred about the face--at least to my taste--his countenance"][[10 4 3] "yet had a something in it which was by no means disagreeable. You cannot"][[10 4 4] "hide the soul. Through all his unearthly tattooings, I thought I saw"][[10 4 5] "the traces of a simple honest heart; and in his large, deep eyes,"][[10 4 6] "fiery black and bold, there seemed tokens of a spirit that would dare a"][[10 4 7] "thousand devils. And besides all this, there was a certain lofty bearing"][[10 4 8] "about the Pagan, which even his uncouthness could not altogether maim."][[10 4 9] "He looked like a man who had never cringed and never had had a creditor."][[10 4 10] "Whether it was, too, that his head being shaved, his forehead was drawn"][[10 4 11] "out in freer and brighter relief, and looked more expansive than it"][[10 4 12] "otherwise would, this I will not venture to decide; but certain it was"][[10 4 13] "his head was phrenologically an excellent one. It may seem ridiculous,"][[10 4 14] "but it reminded me of General Washington's head, as seen in the popular"][[10 4 15] "busts of him. It had the same long regularly graded retreating slope"][[10 4 16] "from above the brows, which were likewise very projecting, like two"][[10 4 17] "long promontories thickly wooded on top. Queequeg was George Washington"][[10 4 18] "cannibalistically developed."][[10 5 1] "Whilst I was thus closely scanning him, half-pretending meanwhile to be"][[10 5 2] "looking out at the storm from the casement, he never heeded my presence,"][[10 5 3] "never troubled himself with so much as a single glance; but appeared"][[10 5 4] "wholly occupied with counting the pages of the marvellous book."][[10 5 5] "Considering how sociably we had been sleeping together the night"][[10 5 6] "previous, and especially considering the affectionate arm I had found"][[10 5 7] "thrown over me upon waking in the morning, I thought this indifference"][[10 5 8] "of his very strange. But savages are strange beings; at times you do not"][[10 5 9] "know exactly how to take them. At first they are overawing; their calm"][[10 5 10] "self-collectedness of simplicity seems a Socratic wisdom. I had noticed"][[10 5 11] "also that Queequeg never consorted at all, or but very little, with the"][[10 5 12] "other seamen in the inn. He made no advances whatever; appeared to have"][[10 5 13] "no desire to enlarge the circle of his acquaintances. All this struck"][[10 5 14] "me as mighty singular; yet, upon second thoughts, there was something"][[10 5 15] "almost sublime in it. Here was a man some twenty thousand miles from"][[10 5 16] "home, by the way of Cape Horn, that is--which was the only way he could"][[10 5 17] "get there--thrown among people as strange to him as though he were in"][[10 5 18] "the planet Jupiter; and yet he seemed entirely at his ease; preserving"][[10 5 19] "the utmost serenity; content with his own companionship; always equal to"][[10 5 20] "himself. Surely this was a touch of fine philosophy; though no doubt he"][[10 5 21] "had never heard there was such a thing as that. But, perhaps, to be"][[10 5 22] "true philosophers, we mortals should not be conscious of so living or"][[10 5 23] "so striving. So soon as I hear that such or such a man gives himself"][[10 5 24] "out for a philosopher, I conclude that, like the dyspeptic old woman, he"][[10 5 25] "must have \"broken his digester.\""][[10 6 1] "As I sat there in that now lonely room; the fire burning low, in that"][[10 6 2] "mild stage when, after its first intensity has warmed the air, it then"][[10 6 3] "only glows to be looked at; the evening shades and phantoms gathering"][[10 6 4] "round the casements, and peering in upon us silent, solitary twain;"][[10 6 5] "the storm booming without in solemn swells; I began to be sensible of"][[10 6 6] "strange feelings. I felt a melting in me. No more my splintered heart"][[10 6 7] "and maddened hand were turned against the wolfish world. This soothing"][[10 6 8] "savage had redeemed it. There he sat, his very indifference speaking a"][[10 6 9] "nature in which there lurked no civilized hypocrisies and bland deceits."][[10 6 10] "Wild he was; a very sight of sights to see; yet I began to feel myself"][[10 6 11] "mysteriously drawn towards him. And those same things that would have"][[10 6 12] "repelled most others, they were the very magnets that thus drew me. I'll"][[10 6 13] "try a pagan friend, thought I, since Christian kindness has proved but"][[10 6 14] "hollow courtesy. I drew my bench near him, and made some friendly signs"][[10 6 15] "and hints, doing my best to talk with him meanwhile. At first he little"][[10 6 16] "noticed these advances; but presently, upon my referring to his last"][[10 6 17] "night's hospitalities, he made out to ask me whether we were again to be"][[10 6 18] "bedfellows. I told him yes; whereat I thought he looked pleased, perhaps"][[10 6 19] "a little complimented."][[10 7 1] "We then turned over the book together, and I endeavored to explain to"][[10 7 2] "him the purpose of the printing, and the meaning of the few pictures"][[10 7 3] "that were in it. Thus I soon engaged his interest; and from that we went"][[10 7 4] "to jabbering the best we could about the various outer sights to be seen"][[10 7 5] "in this famous town. Soon I proposed a social smoke; and, producing"][[10 7 6] "his pouch and tomahawk, he quietly offered me a puff. And then we sat"][[10 7 7] "exchanging puffs from that wild pipe of his, and keeping it regularly"][[10 7 8] "passing between us."][[10 8 1] "If there yet lurked any ice of indifference towards me in the Pagan's"][[10 8 2] "breast, this pleasant, genial smoke we had, soon thawed it out, and left"][[10 8 3] "us cronies. He seemed to take to me quite as naturally and unbiddenly as"][[10 8 4] "I to him; and when our smoke was over, he pressed his forehead against"][[10 8 5] "mine, clasped me round the waist, and said that henceforth we were"][[10 8 6] "married; meaning, in his country's phrase, that we were bosom friends;"][[10 8 7] "he would gladly die for me, if need should be. In a countryman, this"][[10 8 8] "sudden flame of friendship would have seemed far too premature, a thing"][[10 8 9] "to be much distrusted; but in this simple savage those old rules would"][[10 8 10] "not apply."][[10 9 1] "After supper, and another social chat and smoke, we went to our room"][[10 9 2] "together. He made me a present of his embalmed head; took out his"][[10 9 3] "enormous tobacco wallet, and groping under the tobacco, drew out"][[10 9 4] "some thirty dollars in silver; then spreading them on the table, and"][[10 9 5] "mechanically dividing them into two equal portions, pushed one of them"][[10 9 6] "towards me, and said it was mine. I was going to remonstrate; but he"][[10 9 7] "silenced me by pouring them into my trowsers' pockets. I let them stay."][[10 9 8] "He then went about his evening prayers, took out his idol, and removed"][[10 9 9] "the paper fireboard. By certain signs and symptoms, I thought he seemed"][[10 9 10] "anxious for me to join him; but well knowing what was to follow, I"][[10 9 11] "deliberated a moment whether, in case he invited me, I would comply or"][[10 9 12] "otherwise."][[10 10 1] "I was a good Christian; born and bred in the bosom of the infallible"][[10 10 2] "Presbyterian Church. How then could I unite with this wild idolator in"][[10 10 3] "worshipping his piece of wood? But what is worship? thought I. Do"][[10 10 4] "you suppose now, Ishmael, that the magnanimous God of heaven and"][[10 10 5] "earth--pagans and all included--can possibly be jealous of an"][[10 10 6] "insignificant bit of black wood? Impossible! But what is worship?--to do"][[10 10 7] "the will of God--THAT is worship. And what is the will of God?--to do to"][[10 10 8] "my fellow man what I would have my fellow man to do to me--THAT is the"][[10 10 9] "will of God. Now, Queequeg is my fellow man. And what do I wish that"][[10 10 10] "this Queequeg would do to me? Why, unite with me in my particular"][[10 10 11] "Presbyterian form of worship. Consequently, I must then unite with him"][[10 10 12] "in his; ergo, I must turn idolator. So I kindled the shavings; helped"][[10 10 13] "prop up the innocent little idol; offered him burnt biscuit with"][[10 10 14] "Queequeg; salamed before him twice or thrice; kissed his nose; and that"][[10 10 15] "done, we undressed and went to bed, at peace with our own consciences"][[10 10 16] "and all the world. But we did not go to sleep without some little chat."][[10 11 1] "How it is I know not; but there is no place like a bed for confidential"][[10 11 2] "disclosures between friends. Man and wife, they say, there open the very"][[10 11 3] "bottom of their souls to each other; and some old couples often lie"][[10 11 4] "and chat over old times till nearly morning. Thus, then, in our hearts'"][[10 11 5] "honeymoon, lay I and Queequeg--a cosy, loving pair."][[11 0 0] "CHAPTER 11. Nightgown."][[11 2 1] "We had lain thus in bed, chatting and napping at short intervals, and"][[11 2 2] "Queequeg now and then affectionately throwing his brown tattooed legs"][[11 2 3] "over mine, and then drawing them back; so entirely sociable and free"][[11 2 4] "and easy were we; when, at last, by reason of our confabulations, what"][[11 2 5] "little nappishness remained in us altogether departed, and we felt like"][[11 2 6] "getting up again, though day-break was yet some way down the future."][[11 3 1] "Yes, we became very wakeful; so much so that our recumbent position"][[11 3 2] "began to grow wearisome, and by little and little we found ourselves"][[11 3 3] "sitting up; the clothes well tucked around us, leaning against the"][[11 3 4] "head-board with our four knees drawn up close together, and our two"][[11 3 5] "noses bending over them, as if our kneepans were warming-pans. We felt"][[11 3 6] "very nice and snug, the more so since it was so chilly out of doors;"][[11 3 7] "indeed out of bed-clothes too, seeing that there was no fire in the"][[11 3 8] "room. The more so, I say, because truly to enjoy bodily warmth, some"][[11 3 9] "small part of you must be cold, for there is no quality in this world"][[11 3 10] "that is not what it is merely by contrast. Nothing exists in itself. If"][[11 3 11] "you flatter yourself that you are all over comfortable, and have been so"][[11 3 12] "a long time, then you cannot be said to be comfortable any more. But if,"][[11 3 13] "like Queequeg and me in the bed, the tip of your nose or the crown"][[11 3 14] "of your head be slightly chilled, why then, indeed, in the general"][[11 3 15] "consciousness you feel most delightfully and unmistakably warm. For this"][[11 3 16] "reason a sleeping apartment should never be furnished with a fire, which"][[11 3 17] "is one of the luxurious discomforts of the rich. For the height of this"][[11 3 18] "sort of deliciousness is to have nothing but the blanket between you and"][[11 3 19] "your snugness and the cold of the outer air. Then there you lie like the"][[11 3 20] "one warm spark in the heart of an arctic crystal."][[11 4 1] "We had been sitting in this crouching manner for some time, when all at"][[11 4 2] "once I thought I would open my eyes; for when between sheets, whether"][[11 4 3] "by day or by night, and whether asleep or awake, I have a way of always"][[11 4 4] "keeping my eyes shut, in order the more to concentrate the snugness"][[11 4 5] "of being in bed. Because no man can ever feel his own identity aright"][[11 4 6] "except his eyes be closed; as if darkness were indeed the proper element"][[11 4 7] "of our essences, though light be more congenial to our clayey part. Upon"][[11 4 8] "opening my eyes then, and coming out of my own pleasant and self-created"][[11 4 9] "darkness into the imposed and coarse outer gloom of the unilluminated"][[11 4 10] "twelve-o'clock-at-night, I experienced a disagreeable revulsion. Nor did"][[11 4 11] "I at all object to the hint from Queequeg that perhaps it were best to"][[11 4 12] "strike a light, seeing that we were so wide awake; and besides he felt"][[11 4 13] "a strong desire to have a few quiet puffs from his Tomahawk. Be it said,"][[11 4 14] "that though I had felt such a strong repugnance to his smoking in the"][[11 4 15] "bed the night before, yet see how elastic our stiff prejudices grow when"][[11 4 16] "love once comes to bend them. For now I liked nothing better than to"][[11 4 17] "have Queequeg smoking by me, even in bed, because he seemed to be full"][[11 4 18] "of such serene household joy then. I no more felt unduly concerned for"][[11 4 19] "the landlord's policy of insurance. I was only alive to the condensed"][[11 4 20] "confidential comfortableness of sharing a pipe and a blanket with a real"][[11 4 21] "friend. With our shaggy jackets drawn about our shoulders, we now passed"][[11 4 22] "the Tomahawk from one to the other, till slowly there grew over us a"][[11 4 23] "blue hanging tester of smoke, illuminated by the flame of the new-lit"][[11 4 24] "lamp."][[11 5 1] "Whether it was that this undulating tester rolled the savage away to far"][[11 5 2] "distant scenes, I know not, but he now spoke of his native island; and,"][[11 5 3] "eager to hear his history, I begged him to go on and tell it. He gladly"][[11 5 4] "complied. Though at the time I but ill comprehended not a few of his"][[11 5 5] "words, yet subsequent disclosures, when I had become more familiar with"][[11 5 6] "his broken phraseology, now enable me to present the whole story such as"][[11 5 7] "it may prove in the mere skeleton I give."][[12 0 0] "CHAPTER 12. Biographical."][[12 2 1] "Queequeg was a native of Rokovoko, an island far away to the West and"][[12 2 2] "South. It is not down in any map; true places never are."][[12 3 1] "When a new-hatched savage running wild about his native woodlands in"][[12 3 2] "a grass clout, followed by the nibbling goats, as if he were a green"][[12 3 3] "sapling; even then, in Queequeg's ambitious soul, lurked a strong desire"][[12 3 4] "to see something more of Christendom than a specimen whaler or two. His"][[12 3 5] "father was a High Chief, a King; his uncle a High Priest; and on the"][[12 3 6] "maternal side he boasted aunts who were the wives of unconquerable"][[12 3 7] "warriors. There was excellent blood in his veins--royal stuff; though"][[12 3 8] "sadly vitiated, I fear, by the cannibal propensity he nourished in his"][[12 3 9] "untutored youth."][[12 4 1] "A Sag Harbor ship visited his father's bay, and Queequeg sought a"][[12 4 2] "passage to Christian lands. But the ship, having her full complement of"][[12 4 3] "seamen, spurned his suit; and not all the King his father's influence"][[12 4 4] "could prevail. But Queequeg vowed a vow. Alone in his canoe, he paddled"][[12 4 5] "off to a distant strait, which he knew the ship must pass through when"][[12 4 6] "she quitted the island. On one side was a coral reef; on the other a low"][[12 4 7] "tongue of land, covered with mangrove thickets that grew out into the"][[12 4 8] "water. Hiding his canoe, still afloat, among these thickets, with its"][[12 4 9] "prow seaward, he sat down in the stern, paddle low in hand; and when the"][[12 4 10] "ship was gliding by, like a flash he darted out; gained her side; with"][[12 4 11] "one backward dash of his foot capsized and sank his canoe; climbed up"][[12 4 12] "the chains; and throwing himself at full length upon the deck, grappled"][[12 4 13] "a ring-bolt there, and swore not to let it go, though hacked in pieces."][[12 5 1] "In vain the captain threatened to throw him overboard; suspended a"][[12 5 2] "cutlass over his naked wrists; Queequeg was the son of a King, and"][[12 5 3] "Queequeg budged not. Struck by his desperate dauntlessness, and his wild"][[12 5 4] "desire to visit Christendom, the captain at last relented, and told"][[12 5 5] "him he might make himself at home. But this fine young savage--this sea"][[12 5 6] "Prince of Wales, never saw the Captain's cabin. They put him down among"][[12 5 7] "the sailors, and made a whaleman of him. But like Czar Peter content to"][[12 5 8] "toil in the shipyards of foreign cities, Queequeg disdained no seeming"][[12 5 9] "ignominy, if thereby he might happily gain the power of enlightening his"][[12 5 10] "untutored countrymen. For at bottom--so he told me--he was actuated by a"][[12 5 11] "profound desire to learn among the Christians, the arts whereby to"][[12 5 12] "make his people still happier than they were; and more than that,"][[12 5 13] "still better than they were. But, alas! the practices of whalemen soon"][[12 5 14] "convinced him that even Christians could be both miserable and wicked;"][[12 5 15] "infinitely more so, than all his father's heathens. Arrived at last in"][[12 5 16] "old Sag Harbor; and seeing what the sailors did there; and then going on"][[12 5 17] "to Nantucket, and seeing how they spent their wages in that place also,"][[12 5 18] "poor Queequeg gave it up for lost. Thought he, it's a wicked world in"][[12 5 19] "all meridians; I'll die a pagan."][[12 6 1] "And thus an old idolator at heart, he yet lived among these Christians,"][[12 6 2] "wore their clothes, and tried to talk their gibberish. Hence the queer"][[12 6 3] "ways about him, though now some time from home."][[12 7 1] "By hints, I asked him whether he did not propose going back, and having"][[12 7 2] "a coronation; since he might now consider his father dead and gone, he"][[12 7 3] "being very old and feeble at the last accounts. He answered no, not yet;"][[12 7 4] "and added that he was fearful Christianity, or rather Christians, had"][[12 7 5] "unfitted him for ascending the pure and undefiled throne of thirty pagan"][[12 7 6] "Kings before him. But by and by, he said, he would return,--as soon as"][[12 7 7] "he felt himself baptized again. For the nonce, however, he proposed to"][[12 7 8] "sail about, and sow his wild oats in all four oceans. They had made a"][[12 7 9] "harpooneer of him, and that barbed iron was in lieu of a sceptre now."][[12 8 1] "I asked him what might be his immediate purpose, touching his future"][[12 8 2] "movements. He answered, to go to sea again, in his old vocation. Upon"][[12 8 3] "this, I told him that whaling was my own design, and informed him of my"][[12 8 4] "intention to sail out of Nantucket, as being the most promising port for"][[12 8 5] "an adventurous whaleman to embark from. He at once resolved to accompany"][[12 8 6] "me to that island, ship aboard the same vessel, get into the same watch,"][[12 8 7] "the same boat, the same mess with me, in short to share my every hap;"][[12 8 8] "with both my hands in his, boldly dip into the Potluck of both worlds."][[12 8 9] "To all this I joyously assented; for besides the affection I now felt"][[12 8 10] "for Queequeg, he was an experienced harpooneer, and as such, could not"][[12 8 11] "fail to be of great usefulness to one, who, like me, was wholly ignorant"][[12 8 12] "of the mysteries of whaling, though well acquainted with the sea, as"][[12 8 13] "known to merchant seamen."][[12 9 1] "His story being ended with his pipe's last dying puff, Queequeg embraced"][[12 9 2] "me, pressed his forehead against mine, and blowing out the light, we"][[12 9 3] "rolled over from each other, this way and that, and very soon were"][[12 9 4] "sleeping."][[13 0 0] "CHAPTER 13. Wheelbarrow."][[13 2 1] "Next morning, Monday, after disposing of the embalmed head to a barber,"][[13 2 2] "for a block, I settled my own and comrade's bill; using, however, my"][[13 2 3] "comrade's money. The grinning landlord, as well as the boarders, seemed"][[13 2 4] "amazingly tickled at the sudden friendship which had sprung up between"][[13 2 5] "me and Queequeg--especially as Peter Coffin's cock and bull stories"][[13 2 6] "about him had previously so much alarmed me concerning the very person"][[13 2 7] "whom I now companied with."][[13 3 1] "We borrowed a wheelbarrow, and embarking our things, including my own"][[13 3 2] "poor carpet-bag, and Queequeg's canvas sack and hammock, away we went"][[13 3 3] "down to \"the Moss,\" the little Nantucket packet schooner moored at the"][[13 3 4] "wharf. As we were going along the people stared; not at Queequeg"][[13 3 5] "so much--for they were used to seeing cannibals like him in their"][[13 3 6] "streets,--but at seeing him and me upon such confidential terms. But we"][[13 3 7] "heeded them not, going along wheeling the barrow by turns, and Queequeg"][[13 3 8] "now and then stopping to adjust the sheath on his harpoon barbs. I asked"][[13 3 9] "him why he carried such a troublesome thing with him ashore, and"][[13 3 10] "whether all whaling ships did not find their own harpoons. To this, in"][[13 3 11] "substance, he replied, that though what I hinted was true enough, yet"][[13 3 12] "he had a particular affection for his own harpoon, because it was of"][[13 3 13] "assured stuff, well tried in many a mortal combat, and deeply intimate"][[13 3 14] "with the hearts of whales. In short, like many inland reapers"][[13 3 15] "and mowers, who go into the farmers' meadows armed with their own"][[13 3 16] "scythes--though in no wise obliged to furnish them--even so, Queequeg,"][[13 3 17] "for his own private reasons, preferred his own harpoon."][[13 4 1] "Shifting the barrow from my hand to his, he told me a funny story about"][[13 4 2] "the first wheelbarrow he had ever seen. It was in Sag Harbor. The owners"][[13 4 3] "of his ship, it seems, had lent him one, in which to carry his"][[13 4 4] "heavy chest to his boarding house. Not to seem ignorant about the"][[13 4 5] "thing--though in truth he was entirely so, concerning the precise way in"][[13 4 6] "which to manage the barrow--Queequeg puts his chest upon it; lashes it"][[13 4 7] "fast; and then shoulders the barrow and marches up the wharf. \"Why,\""][[13 4 8] "said I, \"Queequeg, you might have known better than that, one would"][[13 4 9] "think. Didn't the people laugh?\""][[13 5 1] "Upon this, he told me another story. The people of his island of"][[13 5 2] "Rokovoko, it seems, at their wedding feasts express the fragrant water"][[13 5 3] "of young cocoanuts into a large stained calabash like a punchbowl; and"][[13 5 4] "this punchbowl always forms the great central ornament on the braided"][[13 5 5] "mat where the feast is held. Now a certain grand merchant ship once"][[13 5 6] "touched at Rokovoko, and its commander--from all accounts, a very"][[13 5 7] "stately punctilious gentleman, at least for a sea captain--this"][[13 5 8] "commander was invited to the wedding feast of Queequeg's sister, a"][[13 5 9] "pretty young princess just turned of ten. Well; when all the wedding"][[13 5 10] "guests were assembled at the bride's bamboo cottage, this Captain"][[13 5 11] "marches in, and being assigned the post of honour, placed himself over"][[13 5 12] "against the punchbowl, and between the High Priest and his majesty the"][[13 5 13] "King, Queequeg's father. Grace being said,--for those people have their"][[13 5 14] "grace as well as we--though Queequeg told me that unlike us, who at such"][[13 5 15] "times look downwards to our platters, they, on the contrary, copying the"][[13 5 16] "ducks, glance upwards to the great Giver of all feasts--Grace, I say,"][[13 5 17] "being said, the High Priest opens the banquet by the immemorial ceremony"][[13 5 18] "of the island; that is, dipping his consecrated and consecrating fingers"][[13 5 19] "into the bowl before the blessed beverage circulates. Seeing himself"][[13 5 20] "placed next the Priest, and noting the ceremony, and thinking"][[13 5 21] "himself--being Captain of a ship--as having plain precedence over a"][[13 5 22] "mere island King, especially in the King's own house--the Captain coolly"][[13 5 23] "proceeds to wash his hands in the punchbowl;--taking it I suppose for a"][[13 5 24] "huge finger-glass. \"Now,\" said Queequeg, \"what you tink now?--Didn't our"][[13 5 25] "people laugh?\""][[13 6 1] "At last, passage paid, and luggage safe, we stood on board the schooner."][[13 6 2] "Hoisting sail, it glided down the Acushnet river. On one side, New"][[13 6 3] "Bedford rose in terraces of streets, their ice-covered trees all"][[13 6 4] "glittering in the clear, cold air. Huge hills and mountains of casks on"][[13 6 5] "casks were piled upon her wharves, and side by side the world-wandering"][[13 6 6] "whale ships lay silent and safely moored at last; while from others"][[13 6 7] "came a sound of carpenters and coopers, with blended noises of fires and"][[13 6 8] "forges to melt the pitch, all betokening that new cruises were on the"][[13 6 9] "start; that one most perilous and long voyage ended, only begins a"][[13 6 10] "second; and a second ended, only begins a third, and so on, for ever"][[13 6 11] "and for aye. Such is the endlessness, yea, the intolerableness of all"][[13 6 12] "earthly effort."][[13 7 1] "Gaining the more open water, the bracing breeze waxed fresh; the little"][[13 7 2] "Moss tossed the quick foam from her bows, as a young colt his snortings."][[13 7 3] "How I snuffed that Tartar air!--how I spurned that turnpike earth!--that"][[13 7 4] "common highway all over dented with the marks of slavish heels and"][[13 7 5] "hoofs; and turned me to admire the magnanimity of the sea which will"][[13 7 6] "permit no records."][[13 8 1] "At the same foam-fountain, Queequeg seemed to drink and reel with me."][[13 8 2] "His dusky nostrils swelled apart; he showed his filed and pointed teeth."][[13 8 3] "On, on we flew; and our offing gained, the Moss did homage to the"][[13 8 4] "blast; ducked and dived her bows as a slave before the Sultan. Sideways"][[13 8 5] "leaning, we sideways darted; every ropeyarn tingling like a wire; the"][[13 8 6] "two tall masts buckling like Indian canes in land tornadoes. So full of"][[13 8 7] "this reeling scene were we, as we stood by the plunging bowsprit, that"][[13 8 8] "for some time we did not notice the jeering glances of the passengers, a"][[13 8 9] "lubber-like assembly, who marvelled that two fellow beings should be so"][[13 8 10] "companionable; as though a white man were anything more dignified than a"][[13 8 11] "whitewashed negro. But there were some boobies and bumpkins there, who,"][[13 8 12] "by their intense greenness, must have come from the heart and centre of"][[13 8 13] "all verdure. Queequeg caught one of these young saplings mimicking him"][[13 8 14] "behind his back. I thought the bumpkin's hour of doom was come. Dropping"][[13 8 15] "his harpoon, the brawny savage caught him in his arms, and by an almost"][[13 8 16] "miraculous dexterity and strength, sent him high up bodily into the air;"][[13 8 17] "then slightly tapping his stern in mid-somerset, the fellow landed with"][[13 8 18] "bursting lungs upon his feet, while Queequeg, turning his back upon him,"][[13 8 19] "lighted his tomahawk pipe and passed it to me for a puff."][[13 9 1] "\"Capting! Capting!\" yelled the bumpkin, running towards that officer;"][[13 9 2] "\"Capting, Capting, here's the devil.\""][[13 10 1] "\"Hallo, _you_ sir,\" cried the Captain, a gaunt rib of the sea, stalking"][[13 10 2] "up to Queequeg, \"what in thunder do you mean by that? Don't you know you"][[13 10 3] "might have killed that chap?\""][[13 11 1] "\"What him say?\" said Queequeg, as he mildly turned to me."][[13 12 1] "\"He say,\" said I, \"that you came near kill-e that man there,\" pointing"][[13 12 2] "to the still shivering greenhorn."][[13 13 1] "\"Kill-e,\" cried Queequeg, twisting his tattooed face into an unearthly"][[13 13 2] "expression of disdain, \"ah! him bevy small-e fish-e; Queequeg no kill-e"][[13 13 3] "so small-e fish-e; Queequeg kill-e big whale!\""][[13 14 1] "\"Look you,\" roared the Captain, \"I'll kill-e YOU, you cannibal, if you"][[13 14 2] "try any more of your tricks aboard here; so mind your eye.\""][[13 15 1] "But it so happened just then, that it was high time for the Captain to"][[13 15 2] "mind his own eye. The prodigious strain upon the main-sail had parted"][[13 15 3] "the weather-sheet, and the tremendous boom was now flying from side to"][[13 15 4] "side, completely sweeping the entire after part of the deck. The poor"][[13 15 5] "fellow whom Queequeg had handled so roughly, was swept overboard; all"][[13 15 6] "hands were in a panic; and to attempt snatching at the boom to stay it,"][[13 15 7] "seemed madness. It flew from right to left, and back again, almost"][[13 15 8] "in one ticking of a watch, and every instant seemed on the point of"][[13 15 9] "snapping into splinters. Nothing was done, and nothing seemed capable of"][[13 15 10] "being done; those on deck rushed towards the bows, and stood eyeing the"][[13 15 11] "boom as if it were the lower jaw of an exasperated whale. In the"][[13 15 12] "midst of this consternation, Queequeg dropped deftly to his knees, and"][[13 15 13] "crawling under the path of the boom, whipped hold of a rope, secured one"][[13 15 14] "end to the bulwarks, and then flinging the other like a lasso, caught it"][[13 15 15] "round the boom as it swept over his head, and at the next jerk, the spar"][[13 15 16] "was that way trapped, and all was safe. The schooner was run into the"][[13 15 17] "wind, and while the hands were clearing away the stern boat, Queequeg,"][[13 15 18] "stripped to the waist, darted from the side with a long living arc of"][[13 15 19] "a leap. For three minutes or more he was seen swimming like a dog,"][[13 15 20] "throwing his long arms straight out before him, and by turns revealing"][[13 15 21] "his brawny shoulders through the freezing foam. I looked at the grand"][[13 15 22] "and glorious fellow, but saw no one to be saved. The greenhorn had gone"][[13 15 23] "down. Shooting himself perpendicularly from the water, Queequeg, now"][[13 15 24] "took an instant's glance around him, and seeming to see just how matters"][[13 15 25] "were, dived down and disappeared. A few minutes more, and he rose again,"][[13 15 26] "one arm still striking out, and with the other dragging a lifeless form."][[13 15 27] "The boat soon picked them up. The poor bumpkin was restored. All hands"][[13 15 28] "voted Queequeg a noble trump; the captain begged his pardon. From that"][[13 15 29] "hour I clove to Queequeg like a barnacle; yea, till poor Queequeg took"][[13 15 30] "his last long dive."][[13 16 1] "Was there ever such unconsciousness? He did not seem to think that he at"][[13 16 2] "all deserved a medal from the Humane and Magnanimous Societies. He only"][[13 16 3] "asked for water--fresh water--something to wipe the brine off; that"][[13 16 4] "done, he put on dry clothes, lighted his pipe, and leaning against the"][[13 16 5] "bulwarks, and mildly eyeing those around him, seemed to be saying"][[13 16 6] "to himself--\"It's a mutual, joint-stock world, in all meridians. We"][[13 16 7] "cannibals must help these Christians.\""][[14 0 0] "CHAPTER 14. Nantucket."][[14 2 1] "Nothing more happened on the passage worthy the mentioning; so, after a"][[14 2 2] "fine run, we safely arrived in Nantucket."][[14 3 1] "Nantucket! Take out your map and look at it. See what a real corner of"][[14 3 2] "the world it occupies; how it stands there, away off shore, more lonely"][[14 3 3] "than the Eddystone lighthouse. Look at it--a mere hillock, and elbow of"][[14 3 4] "sand; all beach, without a background. There is more sand there than"][[14 3 5] "you would use in twenty years as a substitute for blotting paper. Some"][[14 3 6] "gamesome wights will tell you that they have to plant weeds there, they"][[14 3 7] "don't grow naturally; that they import Canada thistles; that they have"][[14 3 8] "to send beyond seas for a spile to stop a leak in an oil cask; that"][[14 3 9] "pieces of wood in Nantucket are carried about like bits of the true"][[14 3 10] "cross in Rome; that people there plant toadstools before their houses,"][[14 3 11] "to get under the shade in summer time; that one blade of grass makes an"][[14 3 12] "oasis, three blades in a day's walk a prairie; that they wear quicksand"][[14 3 13] "shoes, something like Laplander snow-shoes; that they are so shut up,"][[14 3 14] "belted about, every way inclosed, surrounded, and made an utter island"][[14 3 15] "of by the ocean, that to their very chairs and tables small clams will"][[14 3 16] "sometimes be found adhering, as to the backs of sea turtles. But these"][[14 3 17] "extravaganzas only show that Nantucket is no Illinois."][[14 4 1] "Look now at the wondrous traditional story of how this island was"][[14 4 2] "settled by the red-men. Thus goes the legend. In olden times an eagle"][[14 4 3] "swooped down upon the New England coast, and carried off an infant"][[14 4 4] "Indian in his talons. With loud lament the parents saw their child borne"][[14 4 5] "out of sight over the wide waters. They resolved to follow in the same"][[14 4 6] "direction. Setting out in their canoes, after a perilous passage they"][[14 4 7] "discovered the island, and there they found an empty ivory casket,--the"][[14 4 8] "poor little Indian's skeleton."][[14 5 1] "What wonder, then, that these Nantucketers, born on a beach, should take"][[14 5 2] "to the sea for a livelihood! They first caught crabs and quohogs in"][[14 5 3] "the sand; grown bolder, they waded out with nets for mackerel; more"][[14 5 4] "experienced, they pushed off in boats and captured cod; and at last,"][[14 5 5] "launching a navy of great ships on the sea, explored this watery world;"][[14 5 6] "put an incessant belt of circumnavigations round it; peeped in"][[14 5 7] "at Behring's Straits; and in all seasons and all oceans declared"][[14 5 8] "everlasting war with the mightiest animated mass that has survived the"][[14 5 9] "flood; most monstrous and most mountainous! That Himmalehan, salt-sea"][[14 5 10] "Mastodon, clothed with such portentousness of unconscious power, that"][[14 5 11] "his very panics are more to be dreaded than his most fearless and"][[14 5 12] "malicious assaults!"][[14 6 1] "And thus have these naked Nantucketers, these sea hermits, issuing from"][[14 6 2] "their ant-hill in the sea, overrun and conquered the watery world like"][[14 6 3] "so many Alexanders; parcelling out among them the Atlantic, Pacific, and"][[14 6 4] "Indian oceans, as the three pirate powers did Poland. Let America add"][[14 6 5] "Mexico to Texas, and pile Cuba upon Canada; let the English overswarm"][[14 6 6] "all India, and hang out their blazing banner from the sun; two thirds"][[14 6 7] "of this terraqueous globe are the Nantucketer's. For the sea is his; he"][[14 6 8] "owns it, as Emperors own empires; other seamen having but a right of"][[14 6 9] "way through it. Merchant ships are but extension bridges; armed ones but"][[14 6 10] "floating forts; even pirates and privateers, though following the sea"][[14 6 11] "as highwaymen the road, they but plunder other ships, other fragments of"][[14 6 12] "the land like themselves, without seeking to draw their living from the"][[14 6 13] "bottomless deep itself. The Nantucketer, he alone resides and riots on"][[14 6 14] "the sea; he alone, in Bible language, goes down to it in ships; to and"][[14 6 15] "fro ploughing it as his own special plantation. THERE is his home; THERE"][[14 6 16] "lies his business, which a Noah's flood would not interrupt, though it"][[14 6 17] "overwhelmed all the millions in China. He lives on the sea, as prairie"][[14 6 18] "cocks in the prairie; he hides among the waves, he climbs them as"][[14 6 19] "chamois hunters climb the Alps. For years he knows not the land; so"][[14 6 20] "that when he comes to it at last, it smells like another world, more"][[14 6 21] "strangely than the moon would to an Earthsman. With the landless gull,"][[14 6 22] "that at sunset folds her wings and is rocked to sleep between billows;"][[14 6 23] "so at nightfall, the Nantucketer, out of sight of land, furls his sails,"][[14 6 24] "and lays him to his rest, while under his very pillow rush herds of"][[14 6 25] "walruses and whales."][[15 0 0] "CHAPTER 15.
