Chowder."][[15 2 1] "It was quite late in the evening when the little Moss came snugly"][[15 2 2] "to anchor, and Queequeg and I went ashore; so we could attend to no"][[15 2 3] "business that day, at least none but a supper and a bed. The landlord of"][[15 2 4] "the Spouter-Inn had recommended us to his cousin Hosea Hussey of the"][[15 2 5] "Try Pots, whom he asserted to be the proprietor of one of the best kept"][[15 2 6] "hotels in all Nantucket, and moreover he had assured us that Cousin"][[15 2 7] "Hosea, as he called him, was famous for his chowders. In short, he"][[15 2 8] "plainly hinted that we could not possibly do better than try pot-luck at"][[15 2 9] "the Try Pots. But the directions he had given us about keeping a yellow"][[15 2 10] "warehouse on our starboard hand till we opened a white church to the"][[15 2 11] "larboard, and then keeping that on the larboard hand till we made a"][[15 2 12] "corner three points to the starboard, and that done, then ask the first"][[15 2 13] "man we met where the place was: these crooked directions of his very"][[15 2 14] "much puzzled us at first, especially as, at the outset, Queequeg"][[15 2 15] "insisted that the yellow warehouse--our first point of departure--must"][[15 2 16] "be left on the larboard hand, whereas I had understood Peter Coffin to"][[15 2 17] "say it was on the starboard. However, by dint of beating about a little"][[15 2 18] "in the dark, and now and then knocking up a peaceable inhabitant"][[15 2 19] "to inquire the way, we at last came to something which there was no"][[15 2 20] "mistaking."][[15 3 1] "Two enormous wooden pots painted black, and suspended by asses' ears,"][[15 3 2] "swung from the cross-trees of an old top-mast, planted in front of an"][[15 3 3] "old doorway. The horns of the cross-trees were sawed off on the other"][[15 3 4] "side, so that this old top-mast looked not a little like a gallows."][[15 3 5] "Perhaps I was over sensitive to such impressions at the time, but I"][[15 3 6] "could not help staring at this gallows with a vague misgiving. A sort of"][[15 3 7] "crick was in my neck as I gazed up to the two remaining horns; yes, TWO"][[15 3 8] "of them, one for Queequeg, and one for me. It's ominous, thinks I. A"][[15 3 9] "Coffin my Innkeeper upon landing in my first whaling port; tombstones"][[15 3 10] "staring at me in the whalemen's chapel; and here a gallows! and a pair"][[15 3 11] "of prodigious black pots too! Are these last throwing out oblique hints"][[15 3 12] "touching Tophet?"][[15 4 1] "I was called from these reflections by the sight of a freckled woman"][[15 4 2] "with yellow hair and a yellow gown, standing in the porch of the inn,"][[15 4 3] "under a dull red lamp swinging there, that looked much like an injured"][[15 4 4] "eye, and carrying on a brisk scolding with a man in a purple woollen"][[15 4 5] "shirt."][[15 5 1] "\"Get along with ye,\" said she to the man, \"or I'll be combing ye!\""][[15 6 1] "\"Come on, Queequeg,\" said I, \"all right. There's Mrs. Hussey.\""][[15 7 1] "And so it turned out; Mr. Hosea Hussey being from home, but leaving"][[15 7 2] "Mrs. Hussey entirely competent to attend to all his affairs. Upon"][[15 7 3] "making known our desires for a supper and a bed, Mrs. Hussey, postponing"][[15 7 4] "further scolding for the present, ushered us into a little room, and"][[15 7 5] "seating us at a table spread with the relics of a recently concluded"][[15 7 6] "repast, turned round to us and said--\"Clam or Cod?\""][[15 8 1] "\"What's that about Cods, ma'am?\" said I, with much politeness."][[15 9 1] "\"Clam or Cod?\" she repeated."][[15 10 1] "\"A clam for supper? a cold clam; is THAT what you mean, Mrs. Hussey?\""][[15 10 2] "says I, \"but that's a rather cold and clammy reception in the winter"][[15 10 3] "time, ain't it, Mrs. Hussey?\""][[15 11 1] "But being in a great hurry to resume scolding the man in the purple"][[15 11 2] "Shirt, who was waiting for it in the entry, and seeming to hear nothing"][[15 11 3] "but the word \"clam,\" Mrs. Hussey hurried towards an open door leading to"][[15 11 4] "the kitchen, and bawling out \"clam for two,\" disappeared."][[15 12 1] "\"Queequeg,\" said I, \"do you think that we can make out a supper for us"][[15 12 2] "both on one clam?\""][[15 13 1] "However, a warm savory steam from the kitchen served to belie the"][[15 13 2] "apparently cheerless prospect before us. But when that smoking chowder"][[15 13 3] "came in, the mystery was delightfully explained. Oh, sweet friends!"][[15 13 4] "hearken to me. It was made of small juicy clams, scarcely bigger than"][[15 13 5] "hazel nuts, mixed with pounded ship biscuit, and salted pork cut up into"][[15 13 6] "little flakes; the whole enriched with butter, and plentifully seasoned"][[15 13 7] "with pepper and salt. Our appetites being sharpened by the frosty"][[15 13 8] "voyage, and in particular, Queequeg seeing his favourite fishing food"][[15 13 9] "before him, and the chowder being surpassingly excellent, we despatched"][[15 13 10] "it with great expedition: when leaning back a moment and bethinking"][[15 13 11] "me of Mrs. Hussey's clam and cod announcement, I thought I would try"][[15 13 12] "a little experiment. Stepping to the kitchen door, I uttered the word"][[15 13 13] "\"cod\" with great emphasis, and resumed my seat. In a few moments the"][[15 13 14] "savoury steam came forth again, but with a different flavor, and in good"][[15 13 15] "time a fine cod-chowder was placed before us."][[15 14 1] "We resumed business; and while plying our spoons in the bowl, thinks I"][[15 14 2] "to myself, I wonder now if this here has any effect on the head?"][[15 14 3] "What's that stultifying saying about chowder-headed people? \"But look,"][[15 14 4] "Queequeg, ain't that a live eel in your bowl? Where's your harpoon?\""][[15 15 1] "Fishiest of all fishy places was the Try Pots, which well deserved"][[15 15 2] "its name; for the pots there were always boiling chowders. Chowder for"][[15 15 3] "breakfast, and chowder for dinner, and chowder for supper, till you"][[15 15 4] "began to look for fish-bones coming through your clothes. The area"][[15 15 5] "before the house was paved with clam-shells. Mrs. Hussey wore a polished"][[15 15 6] "necklace of codfish vertebra; and Hosea Hussey had his account books"][[15 15 7] "bound in superior old shark-skin. There was a fishy flavor to the milk,"][[15 15 8] "too, which I could not at all account for, till one morning happening"][[15 15 9] "to take a stroll along the beach among some fishermen's boats, I saw"][[15 15 10] "Hosea's brindled cow feeding on fish remnants, and marching along the"][[15 15 11] "sand with each foot in a cod's decapitated head, looking very slip-shod,"][[15 15 12] "I assure ye."][[15 16 1] "Supper concluded, we received a lamp, and directions from Mrs. Hussey"][[15 16 2] "concerning the nearest way to bed; but, as Queequeg was about to precede"][[15 16 3] "me up the stairs, the lady reached forth her arm, and demanded his"][[15 16 4] "harpoon; she allowed no harpoon in her chambers. \"Why not?\" said I;"][[15 16 5] "\"every true whaleman sleeps with his harpoon--but why not?\" \"Because"][[15 16 6] "it's dangerous,\" says she. \"Ever since young Stiggs coming from that"][[15 16 7] "unfort'nt v'y'ge of his, when he was gone four years and a half, with"][[15 16 8] "only three barrels of _ile_, was found dead in my first floor back, with"][[15 16 9] "his harpoon in his side; ever since then I allow no boarders to take"][[15 16 10] "sich dangerous weepons in their rooms at night. So, Mr. Queequeg\" (for"][[15 16 11] "she had learned his name), \"I will just take this here iron, and keep"][[15 16 12] "it for you till morning. But the chowder; clam or cod to-morrow for"][[15 16 13] "breakfast, men?\""][[15 17 1] "\"Both,\" says I; \"and let's have a couple of smoked herring by way of"][[15 17 2] "variety.\""][[16 0 0] "CHAPTER 16. The Ship."][[16 2 1] "In bed we concocted our plans for the morrow. But to my surprise and"][[16 2 2] "no small concern, Queequeg now gave me to understand, that he had been"][[16 2 3] "diligently consulting Yojo--the name of his black little god--and Yojo"][[16 2 4] "had told him two or three times over, and strongly insisted upon it"][[16 2 5] "everyway, that instead of our going together among the whaling-fleet in"][[16 2 6] "harbor, and in concert selecting our craft; instead of this, I say, Yojo"][[16 2 7] "earnestly enjoined that the selection of the ship should rest wholly"][[16 2 8] "with me, inasmuch as Yojo purposed befriending us; and, in order to"][[16 2 9] "do so, had already pitched upon a vessel, which, if left to myself, I,"][[16 2 10] "Ishmael, should infallibly light upon, for all the world as though it"][[16 2 11] "had turned out by chance; and in that vessel I must immediately ship"][[16 2 12] "myself, for the present irrespective of Queequeg."][[16 3 1] "I have forgotten to mention that, in many things, Queequeg placed great"][[16 3 2] "confidence in the excellence of Yojo's judgment and surprising forecast"][[16 3 3] "of things; and cherished Yojo with considerable esteem, as a rather good"][[16 3 4] "sort of god, who perhaps meant well enough upon the whole, but in all"][[16 3 5] "cases did not succeed in his benevolent designs."][[16 4 1] "Now, this plan of Queequeg's, or rather Yojo's, touching the selection"][[16 4 2] "of our craft; I did not like that plan at all. I had not a little relied"][[16 4 3] "upon Queequeg's sagacity to point out the whaler best fitted to carry"][[16 4 4] "us and our fortunes securely. But as all my remonstrances produced"][[16 4 5] "no effect upon Queequeg, I was obliged to acquiesce; and accordingly"][[16 4 6] "prepared to set about this business with a determined rushing sort"][[16 4 7] "of energy and vigor, that should quickly settle that trifling little"][[16 4 8] "affair. Next morning early, leaving Queequeg shut up with Yojo in our"][[16 4 9] "little bedroom--for it seemed that it was some sort of Lent or Ramadan,"][[16 4 10] "or day of fasting, humiliation, and prayer with Queequeg and Yojo that"][[16 4 11] "day; HOW it was I never could find out, for, though I applied myself"][[16 4 12] "to it several times, I never could master his liturgies and XXXIX"][[16 4 13] "Articles--leaving Queequeg, then, fasting on his tomahawk pipe, and Yojo"][[16 4 14] "warming himself at his sacrificial fire of shavings, I sallied out among"][[16 4 15] "the shipping. After much prolonged sauntering and many random inquiries,"][[16 4 16] "I learnt that there were three ships up for three-years' voyages--The"][[16 4 17] "Devil-dam, the Tit-bit, and the Pequod. DEVIL-DAM, I do not know the"][[16 4 18] "origin of; TIT-BIT is obvious; PEQUOD, you will no doubt remember, was"][[16 4 19] "the name of a celebrated tribe of Massachusetts Indians; now extinct"][[16 4 20] "as the ancient Medes. I peered and pryed about the Devil-dam; from her,"][[16 4 21] "hopped over to the Tit-bit; and finally, going on board the Pequod,"][[16 4 22] "looked around her for a moment, and then decided that this was the very"][[16 4 23] "ship for us."][[16 5 1] "You may have seen many a quaint craft in your day, for aught I"][[16 5 2] "know;--square-toed luggers; mountainous Japanese junks; butter-box"][[16 5 3] "galliots, and what not; but take my word for it, you never saw such a"][[16 5 4] "rare old craft as this same rare old Pequod. She was a ship of the old"][[16 5 5] "school, rather small if anything; with an old-fashioned claw-footed look"][[16 5 6] "about her. Long seasoned and weather-stained in the typhoons and calms"][[16 5 7] "of all four oceans, her old hull's complexion was darkened like a French"][[16 5 8] "grenadier's, who has alike fought in Egypt and Siberia. Her venerable"][[16 5 9] "bows looked bearded. Her masts--cut somewhere on the coast of Japan,"][[16 5 10] "where her original ones were lost overboard in a gale--her masts stood"][[16 5 11] "stiffly up like the spines of the three old kings of Cologne. Her"][[16 5 12] "ancient decks were worn and wrinkled, like the pilgrim-worshipped"][[16 5 13] "flag-stone in Canterbury Cathedral where Becket bled. But to all these"][[16 5 14] "her old antiquities, were added new and marvellous features, pertaining"][[16 5 15] "to the wild business that for more than half a century she had followed."][[16 5 16] "Old Captain Peleg, many years her chief-mate, before he commanded"][[16 5 17] "another vessel of his own, and now a retired seaman, and one of the"][[16 5 18] "principal owners of the Pequod,--this old Peleg, during the term of his"][[16 5 19] "chief-mateship, had built upon her original grotesqueness, and inlaid"][[16 5 20] "it, all over, with a quaintness both of material and device, unmatched"][[16 5 21] "by anything except it be Thorkill-Hake's carved buckler or bedstead. She"][[16 5 22] "was apparelled like any barbaric Ethiopian emperor, his neck heavy with"][[16 5 23] "pendants of polished ivory. She was a thing of trophies. A cannibal of"][[16 5 24] "a craft, tricking herself forth in the chased bones of her enemies. All"][[16 5 25] "round, her unpanelled, open bulwarks were garnished like one continuous"][[16 5 26] "jaw, with the long sharp teeth of the sperm whale, inserted there for"][[16 5 27] "pins, to fasten her old hempen thews and tendons to. Those thews ran not"][[16 5 28] "through base blocks of land wood, but deftly travelled over sheaves of"][[16 5 29] "sea-ivory. Scorning a turnstile wheel at her reverend helm, she sported"][[16 5 30] "there a tiller; and that tiller was in one mass, curiously carved"][[16 5 31] "from the long narrow lower jaw of her hereditary foe. The helmsman who"][[16 5 32] "steered by that tiller in a tempest, felt like the Tartar, when he holds"][[16 5 33] "back his fiery steed by clutching its jaw. A noble craft, but somehow a"][[16 5 34] "most melancholy! All noble things are touched with that."][[16 6 1] "Now when I looked about the quarter-deck, for some one having authority,"][[16 6 2] "in order to propose myself as a candidate for the voyage, at first I saw"][[16 6 3] "nobody; but I could not well overlook a strange sort of tent, or"][[16 6 4] "rather wigwam, pitched a little behind the main-mast. It seemed only"][[16 6 5] "a temporary erection used in port. It was of a conical shape, some ten"][[16 6 6] "feet high; consisting of the long, huge slabs of limber black bone taken"][[16 6 7] "from the middle and highest part of the jaws of the right-whale."][[16 6 8] "Planted with their broad ends on the deck, a circle of these slabs laced"][[16 6 9] "together, mutually sloped towards each other, and at the apex united in"][[16 6 10] "a tufted point, where the loose hairy fibres waved to and fro like the"][[16 6 11] "top-knot on some old Pottowottamie Sachem's head. A triangular opening"][[16 6 12] "faced towards the bows of the ship, so that the insider commanded a"][[16 6 13] "complete view forward."][[16 7 1] "And half concealed in this queer tenement, I at length found one who"][[16 7 2] "by his aspect seemed to have authority; and who, it being noon, and"][[16 7 3] "the ship's work suspended, was now enjoying respite from the burden of"][[16 7 4] "command. He was seated on an old-fashioned oaken chair, wriggling all"][[16 7 5] "over with curious carving; and the bottom of which was formed of a"][[16 7 6] "stout interlacing of the same elastic stuff of which the wigwam was"][[16 7 7] "constructed."][[16 8 1] "There was nothing so very particular, perhaps, about the appearance of"][[16 8 2] "the elderly man I saw; he was brown and brawny, like most old seamen,"][[16 8 3] "and heavily rolled up in blue pilot-cloth, cut in the Quaker style;"][[16 8 4] "only there was a fine and almost microscopic net-work of the minutest"][[16 8 5] "wrinkles interlacing round his eyes, which must have arisen from"][[16 8 6] "his continual sailings in many hard gales, and always looking to"][[16 8 7] "windward;--for this causes the muscles about the eyes to become pursed"][[16 8 8] "together. Such eye-wrinkles are very effectual in a scowl."][[16 9 1] "\"Is this the Captain of the Pequod?\" said I, advancing to the door of"][[16 9 2] "the tent."][[16 10 1] "\"Supposing it be the captain of the Pequod, what dost thou want of him?\""][[16 10 2] "he demanded."][[16 11 1] "\"I was thinking of shipping.\""][[16 12 1] "\"Thou wast, wast thou? I see thou art no Nantucketer--ever been in a"][[16 12 2] "stove boat?\""][[16 13 1] "\"No, Sir, I never have.\""][[16 14 1] "\"Dost know nothing at all about whaling, I dare say--eh?"][[16 15 1] "\"Nothing, Sir; but I have no doubt I shall soon learn. I've been several"][[16 15 2] "voyages in the merchant service, and I think that--\""][[16 16 1] "\"Merchant service be damned. Talk not that lingo to me. Dost see that"][[16 16 2] "leg?--I'll take that leg away from thy stern, if ever thou talkest of"][[16 16 3] "the marchant service to me again. Marchant service indeed! I suppose now"][[16 16 4] "ye feel considerable proud of having served in those marchant ships."][[16 16 5] "But flukes! man, what makes thee want to go a whaling, eh?--it looks"][[16 16 6] "a little suspicious, don't it, eh?--Hast not been a pirate, hast"][[16 16 7] "thou?--Didst not rob thy last Captain, didst thou?--Dost not think of"][[16 16 8] "murdering the officers when thou gettest to sea?\""][[16 17 1] "I protested my innocence of these things. I saw that under the mask"][[16 17 2] "of these half humorous innuendoes, this old seaman, as an insulated"][[16 17 3] "Quakerish Nantucketer, was full of his insular prejudices, and rather"][[16 17 4] "distrustful of all aliens, unless they hailed from Cape Cod or the"][[16 17 5] "Vineyard."][[16 18 1] "\"But what takes thee a-whaling? I want to know that before I think of"][[16 18 2] "shipping ye.\""][[16 19 1] "\"Well, sir, I want to see what whaling is. I want to see the world.\""][[16 20 1] "\"Want to see what whaling is, eh? Have ye clapped eye on Captain Ahab?\""][[16 21 1] "\"Who is Captain Ahab, sir?\""][[16 22 1] "\"Aye, aye, I thought so. Captain Ahab is the Captain of this ship.\""][[16 23 1] "\"I am mistaken then. I thought I was speaking to the Captain himself.\""][[16 24 1] "\"Thou art speaking to Captain Peleg--that's who ye are speaking to,"][[16 24 2] "young man. It belongs to me and Captain Bildad to see the Pequod fitted"][[16 24 3] "out for the voyage, and supplied with all her needs, including crew. We"][[16 24 4] "are part owners and agents. But as I was going to say, if thou wantest"][[16 24 5] "to know what whaling is, as thou tellest ye do, I can put ye in a way of"][[16 24 6] "finding it out before ye bind yourself to it, past backing out. Clap"][[16 24 7] "eye on Captain Ahab, young man, and thou wilt find that he has only one"][[16 24 8] "leg.\""][[16 25 1] "\"What do you mean, sir? Was the other one lost by a whale?\""][[16 26 1] "\"Lost by a whale! Young man, come nearer to me: it was devoured,"][[16 26 2] "chewed up, crunched by the monstrousest parmacetty that ever chipped a"][[16 26 3] "boat!--ah, ah!\""][[16 27 1] "I was a little alarmed by his energy, perhaps also a little touched at"][[16 27 2] "the hearty grief in his concluding exclamation, but said as calmly as I"][[16 27 3] "could, \"What you say is no doubt true enough, sir; but how could I know"][[16 27 4] "there was any peculiar ferocity in that particular whale, though indeed"][[16 27 5] "I might have inferred as much from the simple fact of the accident.\""][[16 28 1] "\"Look ye now, young man, thy lungs are a sort of soft, d'ye see; thou"][[16 28 2] "dost not talk shark a bit. SURE, ye've been to sea before now; sure of"][[16 28 3] "that?\""][[16 29 1] "\"Sir,\" said I, \"I thought I told you that I had been four voyages in the"][[16 29 2] "merchant--\""][[16 30 1] "\"Hard down out of that! Mind what I said about the marchant"][[16 30 2] "service--don't aggravate me--I won't have it. But let us understand each"][[16 30 3] "other. I have given thee a hint about what whaling is; do ye yet feel"][[16 30 4] "inclined for it?\""][[16 31 1] "\"I do, sir.\""][[16 32 1] "\"Very good. Now, art thou the man to pitch a harpoon down a live whale's"][[16 32 2] "throat, and then jump after it? Answer, quick!\""][[16 33 1] "\"I am, sir, if it should be positively indispensable to do so; not to be"][[16 33 2] "got rid of, that is; which I don't take to be the fact.\""][[16 34 1] "\"Good again. Now then, thou not only wantest to go a-whaling, to find"][[16 34 2] "out by experience what whaling is, but ye also want to go in order to"][[16 34 3] "see the world? Was not that what ye said? I thought so. Well then, just"][[16 34 4] "step forward there, and take a peep over the weather-bow, and then back"][[16 34 5] "to me and tell me what ye see there.\""][[16 35 1] "For a moment I stood a little puzzled by this curious request, not"][[16 35 2] "knowing exactly how to take it, whether humorously or in earnest. But"][[16 35 3] "concentrating all his crow's feet into one scowl, Captain Peleg started"][[16 35 4] "me on the errand."][[16 36 1] "Going forward and glancing over the weather bow, I perceived that the"][[16 36 2] "ship swinging to her anchor with the flood-tide, was now obliquely"][[16 36 3] "pointing towards the open ocean. The prospect was unlimited, but"][[16 36 4] "exceedingly monotonous and forbidding; not the slightest variety that I"][[16 36 5] "could see."][[16 37 1] "\"Well, what's the report?\" said Peleg when I came back; \"what did ye"][[16 37 2] "see?\""][[16 38 1] "\"Not much,\" I replied--\"nothing but water; considerable horizon though,"][[16 38 2] "and there's a squall coming up, I think.\""][[16 39 1] "\"Well, what does thou think then of seeing the world? Do ye wish to go"][[16 39 2] "round Cape Horn to see any more of it, eh? Can't ye see the world where"][[16 39 3] "you stand?\""][[16 40 1] "I was a little staggered, but go a-whaling I must, and I would; and the"][[16 40 2] "Pequod was as good a ship as any--I thought the best--and all this I now"][[16 40 3] "repeated to Peleg. Seeing me so determined, he expressed his willingness"][[16 40 4] "to ship me."][[16 41 1] "\"And thou mayest as well sign the papers right off,\" he added--\"come"][[16 41 2] "along with ye.\" And so saying, he led the way below deck into the cabin."][[16 42 1] "Seated on the transom was what seemed to me a most uncommon and"][[16 42 2] "surprising figure. It turned out to be Captain Bildad, who along with"][[16 42 3] "Captain Peleg was one of the largest owners of the vessel; the other"][[16 42 4] "shares, as is sometimes the case in these ports, being held by a crowd"][[16 42 5] "of old annuitants; widows, fatherless children, and chancery wards; each"][[16 42 6] "owning about the value of a timber head, or a foot of plank, or a nail"][[16 42 7] "or two in the ship. People in Nantucket invest their money in whaling"][[16 42 8] "vessels, the same way that you do yours in approved state stocks"][[16 42 9] "bringing in good interest."][[16 43 1] "Now, Bildad, like Peleg, and indeed many other Nantucketers, was a"][[16 43 2] "Quaker, the island having been originally settled by that sect; and to"][[16 43 3] "this day its inhabitants in general retain in an uncommon measure the"][[16 43 4] "peculiarities of the Quaker, only variously and anomalously modified"][[16 43 5] "by things altogether alien and heterogeneous. For some of these same"][[16 43 6] "Quakers are the most sanguinary of all sailors and whale-hunters. They"][[16 43 7] "are fighting Quakers; they are Quakers with a vengeance."][[16 44 1] "So that there are instances among them of men, who, named with Scripture"][[16 44 2] "names--a singularly common fashion on the island--and in childhood"][[16 44 3] "naturally imbibing the stately dramatic thee and thou of the Quaker"][[16 44 4] "idiom; still, from the audacious, daring, and boundless adventure"][[16 44 5] "of their subsequent lives, strangely blend with these unoutgrown"][[16 44 6] "peculiarities, a thousand bold dashes of character, not unworthy a"][[16 44 7] "Scandinavian sea-king, or a poetical Pagan Roman. And when these things"][[16 44 8] "unite in a man of greatly superior natural force, with a globular brain"][[16 44 9] "and a ponderous heart; who has also by the stillness and seclusion"][[16 44 10] "of many long night-watches in the remotest waters, and beneath"][[16 44 11] "constellations never seen here at the north, been led to think"][[16 44 12] "untraditionally and independently; receiving all nature's sweet or"][[16 44 13] "savage impressions fresh from her own virgin voluntary and confiding"][[16 44 14] "breast, and thereby chiefly, but with some help from accidental"][[16 44 15] "advantages, to learn a bold and nervous lofty language--that man makes"][[16 44 16] "one in a whole nation's census--a mighty pageant creature, formed for"][[16 44 17] "noble tragedies. Nor will it at all detract from him, dramatically"][[16 44 18] "regarded, if either by birth or other circumstances, he have what seems"][[16 44 19] "a half wilful overruling morbidness at the bottom of his nature. For all"][[16 44 20] "men tragically great are made so through a certain morbidness. Be sure"][[16 44 21] "of this, O young ambition, all mortal greatness is but disease. But,"][[16 44 22] "as yet we have not to do with such an one, but with quite another; and"][[16 44 23] "still a man, who, if indeed peculiar, it only results again from another"][[16 44 24] "phase of the Quaker, modified by individual circumstances."][[16 45 1] "Like Captain Peleg, Captain Bildad was a well-to-do, retired whaleman."][[16 45 2] "But unlike Captain Peleg--who cared not a rush for what are called"][[16 45 3] "serious things, and indeed deemed those self-same serious things the"][[16 45 4] "veriest of all trifles--Captain Bildad had not only been originally"][[16 45 5] "educated according to the strictest sect of Nantucket Quakerism, but all"][[16 45 6] "his subsequent ocean life, and the sight of many unclad, lovely island"][[16 45 7] "creatures, round the Horn--all that had not moved this native born"][[16 45 8] "Quaker one single jot, had not so much as altered one angle of his"][[16 45 9] "vest. Still, for all this immutableness, was there some lack of"][[16 45 10] "common consistency about worthy Captain Peleg. Though refusing, from"][[16 45 11] "conscientious scruples, to bear arms against land invaders, yet himself"][[16 45 12] "had illimitably invaded the Atlantic and Pacific; and though a sworn foe"][[16 45 13] "to human bloodshed, yet had he in his straight-bodied coat, spilled tuns"][[16 45 14] "upon tuns of leviathan gore. How now in the contemplative evening of his"][[16 45 15] "days, the pious Bildad reconciled these things in the reminiscence, I do"][[16 45 16] "not know; but it did not seem to concern him much, and very probably"][[16 45 17] "he had long since come to the sage and sensible conclusion that a man's"][[16 45 18] "religion is one thing, and this practical world quite another. This"][[16 45 19] "world pays dividends. Rising from a little cabin-boy in short clothes"][[16 45 20] "of the drabbest drab, to a harpooneer in a broad shad-bellied waistcoat;"][[16 45 21] "from that becoming boat-header, chief-mate, and captain, and finally a"][[16 45 22] "ship owner; Bildad, as I hinted before, had concluded his adventurous"][[16 45 23] "career by wholly retiring from active life at the goodly age of"][[16 45 24] "sixty, and dedicating his remaining days to the quiet receiving of his"][[16 45 25] "well-earned income."][[16 46 1] "Now, Bildad, I am sorry to say, had the reputation of being an"][[16 46 2] "incorrigible old hunks, and in his sea-going days, a bitter, hard"][[16 46 3] "task-master. They told me in Nantucket, though it certainly seems a"][[16 46 4] "curious story, that when he sailed the old Categut whaleman, his crew,"][[16 46 5] "upon arriving home, were mostly all carried ashore to the hospital, sore"][[16 46 6] "exhausted and worn out. For a pious man, especially for a Quaker, he was"][[16 46 7] "certainly rather hard-hearted, to say the least. He never used to swear,"][[16 46 8] "though, at his men, they said; but somehow he got an inordinate"][[16 46 9] "quantity of cruel, unmitigated hard work out of them. When Bildad was a"][[16 46 10] "chief-mate, to have his drab-coloured eye intently looking at you, made"][[16 46 11] "you feel completely nervous, till you could clutch something--a hammer"][[16 46 12] "or a marling-spike, and go to work like mad, at something or other,"][[16 46 13] "never mind what. Indolence and idleness perished before him. His own"][[16 46 14] "person was the exact embodiment of his utilitarian character. On his"][[16 46 15] "long, gaunt body, he carried no spare flesh, no superfluous beard,"][[16 46 16] "his chin having a soft, economical nap to it, like the worn nap of his"][[16 46 17] "broad-brimmed hat."][[16 47 1] "Such, then, was the person that I saw seated on the transom when I"][[16 47 2] "followed Captain Peleg down into the cabin. The space between the decks"][[16 47 3] "was small; and there, bolt-upright, sat old Bildad, who always sat so,"][[16 47 4] "and never leaned, and this to save his coat tails. His broad-brim was"][[16 47 5] "placed beside him; his legs were stiffly crossed; his drab vesture was"][[16 47 6] "buttoned up to his chin; and spectacles on nose, he seemed absorbed in"][[16 47 7] "reading from a ponderous volume."][[16 48 1] "\"Bildad,\" cried Captain Peleg, \"at it again, Bildad, eh? Ye have been"][[16 48 2] "studying those Scriptures, now, for the last thirty years, to my certain"][[16 48 3] "knowledge. How far ye got, Bildad?\""][[16 49 1] "As if long habituated to such profane talk from his old shipmate,"][[16 49 2] "Bildad, without noticing his present irreverence, quietly looked up, and"][[16 49 3] "seeing me, glanced again inquiringly towards Peleg."][[16 50 1] "\"He says he's our man, Bildad,\" said Peleg, \"he wants to ship.\""][[16 51 1] "\"Dost thee?\" said Bildad, in a hollow tone, and turning round to me."][[16 52 1] "\"I dost,\" said I unconsciously, he was so intense a Quaker."][[16 53 1] "\"What do ye think of him, Bildad?\" said Peleg."][[16 54 1] "\"He'll do,\" said Bildad, eyeing me, and then went on spelling away at"][[16 54 2] "his book in a mumbling tone quite audible."][[16 55 1] "I thought him the queerest old Quaker I ever saw, especially as Peleg,"][[16 55 2] "his friend and old shipmate, seemed such a blusterer. But I said"][[16 55 3] "nothing, only looking round me sharply. Peleg now threw open a chest,"][[16 55 4] "and drawing forth the ship's articles, placed pen and ink before him,"][[16 55 5] "and seated himself at a little table. I began to think it was high time"][[16 55 6] "to settle with myself at what terms I would be willing to engage for the"][[16 55 7] "voyage. I was already aware that in the whaling business they paid no"][[16 55 8] "wages; but all hands, including the captain, received certain shares of"][[16 55 9] "the profits called lays, and that these lays were proportioned to the"][[16 55 10] "degree of importance pertaining to the respective duties of the ship's"][[16 55 11] "company. I was also aware that being a green hand at whaling, my own"][[16 55 12] "lay would not be very large; but considering that I was used to the sea,"][[16 55 13] "could steer a ship, splice a rope, and all that, I made no doubt that"][[16 55 14] "from all I had heard I should be offered at least the th lay--that"][[16 55 15] "is, the th part of the clear net proceeds of the voyage, whatever"][[16 55 16] "that might eventually amount to. And though the th lay was what they"][[16 55 17] "call a rather LONG LAY, yet it was better than nothing; and if we had a"][[16 55 18] "lucky voyage, might pretty nearly pay for the clothing I would wear out"][[16 55 19] "on it, not to speak of my three years' beef and board, for which I would"][[16 55 20] "not have to pay one stiver."][[16 56 1] "It might be thought that this was a poor way to accumulate a princely"][[16 56 2] "fortune--and so it was, a very poor way indeed. But I am one of those"][[16 56 3] "that never take on about princely fortunes, and am quite content if the"][[16 56 4] "world is ready to board and lodge me, while I am putting up at this grim"][[16 56 5] "sign of the Thunder Cloud. Upon the whole, I thought that the th lay"][[16 56 6] "would be about the fair thing, but would not have been surprised had I"][[16 56 7] "been offered the th, considering I was of a broad-shouldered make."][[16 57 1] "But one thing, nevertheless, that made me a little distrustful about"][[16 57 2] "receiving a generous share of the profits was this: Ashore, I had heard"][[16 57 3] "something of both Captain Peleg and his unaccountable old crony Bildad;"][[16 57 4] "how that they being the principal proprietors of the Pequod, therefore"][[16 57 5] "the other and more inconsiderable and scattered owners, left nearly the"][[16 57 6] "whole management of the ship's affairs to these two. And I did not know"][[16 57 7] "but what the stingy old Bildad might have a mighty deal to say about"][[16 57 8] "shipping hands, especially as I now found him on board the Pequod,"][[16 57 9] "quite at home there in the cabin, and reading his Bible as if at his"][[16 57 10] "own fireside. Now while Peleg was vainly trying to mend a pen with his"][[16 57 11] "jack-knife, old Bildad, to my no small surprise, considering that he was"][[16 57 12] "such an interested party in these proceedings; Bildad never heeded"][[16 57 13] "us, but went on mumbling to himself out of his book, \"LAY not up for"][[16 57 14] "yourselves treasures upon earth, where moth--\""][[16 58 1] "\"Well, Captain Bildad,\" interrupted Peleg, \"what d'ye say, what lay"][[16 58 2] "shall we give this young man?\""][[16 59 1] "\"Thou knowest best,\" was the sepulchral reply, \"the seven hundred and"][[16 59 2] "seventy-seventh wouldn't be too much, would it?--'where moth and rust do"][[16 59 3] "corrupt, but LAY--'\""][[16 60 1] "LAY, indeed, thought I, and such a lay! the seven hundred and"][[16 60 2] "seventy-seventh! Well, old Bildad, you are determined that I, for one,"][[16 60 3] "shall not LAY up many LAYS here below, where moth and rust do corrupt."][[16 60 4] "It was an exceedingly LONG LAY that, indeed; and though from the"][[16 60 5] "magnitude of the figure it might at first deceive a landsman, yet"][[16 60 6] "the slightest consideration will show that though seven hundred and"][[16 60 7] "seventy-seven is a pretty large number, yet, when you come to make"][[16 60 8] "a TEENTH of it, you will then see, I say, that the seven hundred and"][[16 60 9] "seventy-seventh part of a farthing is a good deal less than seven"][[16 60 10] "hundred and seventy-seven gold doubloons; and so I thought at the time."][[16 61 1] "\"Why, blast your eyes, Bildad,\" cried Peleg, \"thou dost not want to"][[16 61 2] "swindle this young man! he must have more than that.\""][[16 62 1] "\"Seven hundred and seventy-seventh,\" again said Bildad, without lifting"][[16 62 2] "his eyes; and then went on mumbling--\"for where your treasure is, there"][[16 62 3] "will your heart be also.\""][[16 63 1] "\"I am going to put him down for the three hundredth,\" said Peleg, \"do ye"][[16 63 2] "hear that, Bildad! The three hundredth lay, I say.\""][[16 64 1] "Bildad laid down his book, and turning solemnly towards him said,"][[16 64 2] "\"Captain Peleg, thou hast a generous heart; but thou must consider the"][[16 64 3] "duty thou owest to the other owners of this ship--widows and orphans,"][[16 64 4] "many of them--and that if we too abundantly reward the labors of this"][[16 64 5] "young man, we may be taking the bread from those widows and those"][[16 64 6] "orphans. The seven hundred and seventy-seventh lay, Captain Peleg.\""][[16 65 1] "\"Thou Bildad!\" roared Peleg, starting up and clattering about the"][[16 65 2] "cabin. \"Blast ye, Captain Bildad, if I had followed thy advice in these"][[16 65 3] "matters, I would afore now had a conscience to lug about that would be"][[16 65 4] "heavy enough to founder the largest ship that ever sailed round Cape"][[16 65 5] "Horn.\""][[16 66 1] "\"Captain Peleg,\" said Bildad steadily, \"thy conscience may be drawing"][[16 66 2] "ten inches of water, or ten fathoms, I can't tell; but as thou art still"][[16 66 3] "an impenitent man, Captain Peleg, I greatly fear lest thy conscience be"][[16 66 4] "but a leaky one; and will in the end sink thee foundering down to the"][[16 66 5] "fiery pit, Captain Peleg.\""][[16 67 1] "\"Fiery pit! fiery pit! ye insult me, man; past all natural bearing, ye"][[16 67 2] "insult me. Bildad, say that again to me, and"][[16 67 4] "start my soul-bolts, but I'll--I'll--yes, I'll swallow a live goat with"][[16 67 5] "all his hair and horns on. Out of the cabin, ye canting, drab-coloured"][[16 67 6] "son of a wooden gun--a straight wake with ye!\""][[16 68 1] "As he thundered out this he made a rush at Bildad, but with a marvellous"][[16 68 2] "oblique, sliding celerity, Bildad for that time eluded him."][[16 69 1] "Alarmed at this terrible outburst between the two principal and"][[16 69 2] "responsible owners of the ship, and feeling half a mind to give up"][[16 69 3] "all idea of sailing in a vessel so questionably owned and temporarily"][[16 69 4] "commanded, I stepped aside from the door to give egress to Bildad, who,"][[16 69 5] "I made no doubt, was all eagerness to vanish from before the awakened"][[16 69 6] "wrath of Peleg. He seemed quite used to impenitent Peleg and his ways. Well then, down ye go here, Ishmael,"][[16 69 16] "for the three hundredth lay.\""][[16 70 1] "\"Captain Peleg,\" said I, \"I have a friend with me who wants to ship"][[16 70 2] "too--shall I bring him down to-morrow?\""][[16 71 1] "\"To be sure,\" said Peleg. \"Fetch him along, and we'll look at him.\""][[16 72 1] "\"What lay does he want?\" groaned Bildad, glancing up from the book in"][[16 72 2] "which he had again been burying himself."][[16 73 1] "\"Oh! never thee mind about that, Bildad,\" said Peleg. \"Has he ever"][[16 73 2] "whaled it any?\" turning to me."][[16 74 1] "\"Killed more whales than I can count, Captain Peleg.\""][[16 75 1] "\"Well, bring him along then.\""][[16 76 1] "And, after signing the papers, off I went; nothing doubting but that I"][[16 76 2] "had done a good morning's work, and that the Pequod was the identical"][[16 76 3] "ship that Yojo had provided to carry Queequeg and me round the Cape."][[16 77 1] "But I had not proceeded far, when I began to bethink me that the Captain"][[16 77 2] "with whom I was to sail yet remained unseen by me; though, indeed, in"][[16 77 3] "many cases, a whale-ship will be completely fitted out, and receive all"][[16 77 4] "her crew on board, ere the captain makes himself visible by arriving"][[16 77 5] "to take command; for sometimes these voyages are so prolonged, and the"][[16 77 6] "shore intervals at home so exceedingly brief, that if the captain have"][[16 77 7] "a family, or any absorbing concernment of that sort, he does not trouble"][[16 77 8] "himself much about his ship in port, but leaves her to the owners till"][[16 77 9] "all is ready for sea. However, it is always as well to have a look at"][[16 77 10] "him before irrevocably committing yourself into his hands. Turning back"][[16 77 11] "I accosted Captain Peleg, inquiring where Captain Ahab was to be found."][[16 78 1] "\"And what dost thou want of Captain Ahab? It's all right enough; thou"][[16 78 2] "art shipped.\""][[16 79 1] "\"Yes, but I should like to see him.\""][[16 80 1] "\"But I don't think thou wilt be able to at present. I don't know exactly"][[16 80 2] "what's the matter with him; but he keeps close inside the house; a sort"][[16 80 3] "of sick, and yet he don't look so. In fact, he ain't sick; but no, he"][[16 80 4] "isn't well either. Any how, young man, he won't always see me, so I"][[16 80 5] "don't suppose he will thee. He's a queer man, Captain Ahab--so some"][[16 80 6] "think--but a good one. Oh, thou'lt like him well enough; no fear, no"][[16 80 7] "fear. He's a grand, ungodly, god-like man, Captain Ahab; doesn't speak"][[16 80 8] "much; but, when he does speak, then you may well listen. Mark ye, be"][[16 80 9] "forewarned; Ahab's above the common; Ahab's been in colleges, as well as"][[16 80 10] "'mong the cannibals; been used to deeper wonders than the waves; fixed"][[16 80 11] "his fiery lance in mightier, stranger foes than whales. His lance!"][[16 80 12] "aye, the keenest and the surest that out of all our isle! Oh! he ain't"][[16 80 13] "Captain Bildad; no, and he ain't Captain Peleg; HE'S AHAB, boy; and Ahab"][[16 80 14] "of old, thou knowest, was a crowned king!\""][[16 81 1] "\"And a very vile one. When that wicked king was slain, the dogs, did"][[16 81 2] "they not lick his blood?\""][[16 82 1] "\"Come hither to me--hither, hither,\" said Peleg, with a significance in"][[16 82 2] "his eye that almost startled me. \"Look ye, lad; never say that on board"][[16 82 3] "the Pequod. Never say it anywhere. Captain Ahab did not name himself."][[16 82 4] "'Twas a foolish, ignorant whim of his crazy, widowed mother, who died"][[16 82 5] "when he was only a twelvemonth old. And yet the old squaw Tistig, at"][[16 82 6] "Gayhead, said that the name would somehow prove prophetic. And, perhaps,"][[16 82 7] "other fools like her may tell thee the same. I wish to warn thee. It's a"][[16 82 8] "lie. I know Captain Ahab well; I've sailed with him as mate years ago;"][[16 82 9] "I know what he is--a good man--not a pious, good man, like Bildad, but"][[16 82 10] "a swearing good man--something like me--only there's a good deal more of"][[16 82 11] "him. Aye, aye, I know that he was never very jolly; and I know that on"][[16 82 12] "the passage home, he was a little out of his mind for a spell; but it"][[16 82 13] "was the sharp shooting pains in his bleeding stump that brought that"][[16 82 14] "about, as any one might see. I know, too, that ever since he lost"][[16 82 15] "his leg last voyage by that accursed whale, he's been a kind of"][[16 82 16] "moody--desperate moody, and savage sometimes; but that will all pass"][[16 82 17] "off. And once for all, let me tell thee and assure thee, young man, it's"][[16 82 18] "better to sail with a moody good captain than a laughing bad one. So"][[16 82 19] "good-bye to thee--and wrong not Captain Ahab, because he happens to"][[16 82 20] "have a wicked name. Besides, my boy, he has a wife--not three voyages"][[16 82 21] "wedded--a sweet, resigned girl. Think of that; by that sweet girl that"][[16 82 22] "old man has a child: hold ye then there can be any utter, hopeless"][[16 82 23] "harm in Ahab? No, no, my lad; stricken, blasted, if he be, Ahab has his"][[16 82 24] "humanities!\""][[16 83 1] "As I walked away, I was full of thoughtfulness; what had been"][[16 83 2] "incidentally revealed to me of Captain Ahab, filled me with a certain"][[16 83 3] "wild vagueness of painfulness concerning him. And somehow, at the time,"][[16 83 4] "I felt a sympathy and a sorrow for him, but for I don't know what,"][[16 83 5] "unless it was the cruel loss of his leg. And yet I also felt a strange"][[16 83 6] "awe of him; but that sort of awe, which I cannot at all describe, was"][[16 83 7] "not exactly awe; I do not know what it was. But I felt it; and it did"][[16 83 8] "not disincline me towards him; though I felt impatience at what seemed"][[16 83 9] "like mystery in him, so imperfectly as he was known to me then. However,"][[16 83 10] "my thoughts were at length carried in other directions, so that for the"][[16 83 11] "present dark Ahab slipped my mind."][[17 0 0] "CHAPTER 17. The Ramadan."][[17 2 1] "As Queequeg's Ramadan, or Fasting and Humiliation, was to continue all"][[17 2 2] "day, I did not choose to disturb him till towards night-fall; for I"][[17 2 3] "cherish the greatest respect towards everybody's religious obligations,"][[17 2 4] "never mind how comical, and could not find it in my heart to undervalue"][[17 2 5] "even a congregation of ants worshipping a toad-stool; or those other"][[17 2 6] "creatures in certain parts of our earth, who with a degree of footmanism"][[17 2 7] "quite unprecedented in other planets, bow down before the torso of"][[17 2 8] "a deceased landed proprietor merely on account of the inordinate"][[17 2 9] "possessions yet owned and rented in his name."][[17 3 1] "I say, we good Presbyterian Christians should be charitable in these"][[17 3 2] "things, and not fancy ourselves so vastly superior to other mortals,"][[17 3 3] "pagans and what not, because of their half-crazy conceits on these"][[17 3 4] "subjects. There was Queequeg, now, certainly entertaining the most"][[17 3 5] "absurd notions about Yojo and his Ramadan;--but what of that? Queequeg"][[17 3 6] "thought he knew what he was about, I suppose; he seemed to be content;"][[17 3 7] "and there let him rest. All our arguing with him would not avail; let"][[17 3 8] "him be, I say: and Heaven have mercy on us all--Presbyterians and Pagans"][[17 3 9] "alike--for we are all somehow dreadfully cracked about the head, and"][[17 3 10] "sadly need mending."][[17 4 1] "Towards evening, when I felt assured that all his performances and"][[17 4 2] "rituals must be over, I went up to his room and knocked at the door; but"][[17 4 3] "no answer. I tried to open it, but it was fastened inside. \"Queequeg,\""][[17 4 4] "said I softly through the key-hole:--all silent. \"I say, Queequeg! why"][[17 4 5] "don't you speak? It's I--Ishmael.\" But all remained still as before. I"][[17 4 6] "began to grow alarmed. I had allowed him such abundant time; I thought"][[17 4 7] "he might have had an apoplectic fit. I looked through the key-hole; but"][[17 4 8] "the door opening into an odd corner of the room, the key-hole prospect"][[17 4 9] "was but a crooked and sinister one. I could only see part of the"][[17 4 10] "foot-board of the bed and a line of the wall, but nothing more. I"][[17 4 11] "was surprised to behold resting against the wall the wooden shaft of"][[17 4 12] "Queequeg's harpoon, which the landlady the evening previous had taken"][[17 4 13] "from him, before our mounting to the chamber. That's strange, thought I;"][[17 4 14] "but at any rate, since the harpoon stands yonder, and he seldom or"][[17 4 15] "never goes abroad without it, therefore he must be inside here, and no"][[17 4 16] "possible mistake."][[17 5 1] "\"Queequeg!--Queequeg!\"--all still. Something must have happened."][[17 5 2] "Apoplexy! I tried to burst open the door; but it stubbornly resisted."][[17 5 3] "Running down stairs, I quickly stated my suspicions to the first person"][[17 5 4] "I met--the chamber-maid. \"La! la!\" she cried, \"I thought something must"][[17 5 5] "be the matter. I went to make the bed after breakfast, and the door was"][[17 5 6] "locked; and not a mouse to be heard; and it's been just so silent ever"][[17 5 7] "since. But I thought, may be, you had both gone off and locked your"][[17 5 8] "baggage in for safe keeping. La! la, ma'am!--Mistress! murder! Mrs."][[17 5 9] "Hussey! apoplexy!\"--and with these cries, she ran towards the kitchen, I"][[17 5 10] "following."][[17 6 1] "Mrs. Hussey soon appeared, with a mustard-pot in one hand and a"][[17 6 2] "vinegar-cruet in the other, having just broken away from the occupation"][[17 6 3] "of attending to the castors, and scolding her little black boy meantime."][[17 7 1] "\"Wood-house!\" cried I, \"which way to it? Run for God's sake, and fetch"][[17 7 2] "something to pry open the door--the axe!--the axe! he's had a stroke;"][[17 7 3] "depend upon it!\"--and so saying I was unmethodically rushing up stairs"][[17 7 4] "again empty-handed, when Mrs. Hussey interposed the mustard-pot and"][[17 7 5] "vinegar-cruet, and the entire castor of her countenance."][[17 8 1] "\"What's the matter with you, young man?\""][[17 9 1] "\"Get the axe! For God's sake, run for the doctor, some one, while I pry"][[17 9 2] "it open!\""][[17 10 1] "\"Look here,\" said the landlady, quickly putting down the vinegar-cruet,"][[17 10 2] "so as to have one hand free; \"look here; are you talking about prying"][[17 10 3] "open any of my doors?\"--and with that she seized my arm. \"What's the"][[17 10 4] "matter with you? What's the matter with you, shipmate?\""][[17 11 1] "In as calm, but rapid a manner as possible, I gave her to understand the"][[17 11 2] "whole case. Unconsciously clapping the vinegar-cruet to one side of her"][[17 11 3] "nose, she ruminated for an instant; then exclaimed--\"No! I haven't seen"][[17 11 4] "it since I put it there.\" Running to a little closet under the landing"][[17 11 5] "of the stairs, she glanced in, and returning, told me that Queequeg's"][[17 11 6] "harpoon was missing. \"He's killed himself,\" she cried. \"It's unfort'nate"][[17 11 7] "Stiggs done over again there goes another counterpane--God pity his poor"][[17 11 8] "mother!--it will be the ruin of my house. Has the poor lad a sister?"][[17 11 9] "Where's that girl?--there, Betty, go to Snarles the Painter, and tell"][[17 11 10] "him to paint me a sign, with--\"no suicides permitted here, and no"][[17 11 11] "smoking in the parlor;\"--might as well kill both birds at once. Kill?"][[17 11 12] "The Lord be merciful to his ghost! What's that noise there? You, young"][[17 11 13] "man, avast there!\""][[17 12 1] "And running up after me, she caught me as I was again trying to force"][[17 12 2] "open the door."][[17 13 1] "\"I don't allow it; I won't have my premises spoiled. Go for the"][[17 13 2] "locksmith, there's one about a mile from here. But avast!\" putting her"][[17 13 3] "hand in her side-pocket, \"here's a key that'll fit, I guess; let's"][[17 13 4] "see.\" And with that, she turned it in the lock; but, alas! Queequeg's"][[17 13 5] "supplemental bolt remained unwithdrawn within."][[17 14 1] "\"Have to burst it open,\" said I, and was running down the entry a"][[17 14 2] "little, for a good start, when the landlady caught at me, again vowing"][[17 14 3] "I should not break down her premises; but I tore from her, and with a"][[17 14 4] "sudden bodily rush dashed myself full against the mark."][[17 15 1] "With a prodigious noise the door flew open, and the knob slamming"][[17 15 2] "against the wall, sent the plaster to the ceiling; and there, good"][[17 15 3] "heavens! there sat Queequeg, altogether cool and self-collected; right"][[17 15 4] "in the middle of the room; squatting on his hams, and holding Yojo on"][[17 15 5] "top of his head. He looked neither one way nor the other way, but sat"][[17 15 6] "like a carved image with scarce a sign of active life."][[17 16 1] "\"Queequeg,\" said I, going up to him, \"Queequeg, what's the matter with"][[17 16 2] "you?\""][[17 17 1] "\"He hain't been a sittin' so all day, has he?\" said the landlady."][[17 18 1] "But all we said, not a word could we drag out of him; I almost felt"][[17 18 2] "like pushing him over, so as to change his position, for it was almost"][[17 18 3] "intolerable, it seemed so painfully and unnaturally constrained;"][[17 18 4] "especially, as in all probability he had been sitting so for upwards of"][[17 18 5] "eight or ten hours, going too without his regular meals."][[17 19 1] "\"Mrs. Hussey,\" said I, \"he's ALIVE at all events; so leave us, if you"][[17 19 2] "please, and I will see to this strange affair myself.\""][[17 20 1] "Closing the door upon the landlady, I endeavored to prevail upon"][[17 20 2] "Queequeg to take a chair; but in vain. There he sat; and all he could"][[17 20 3] "do--for all my polite arts and blandishments--he would not move a peg,"][[17 20 4] "nor say a single word, nor even look at me, nor notice my presence in"][[17 20 5] "the slightest way."][[17 21 1] "I wonder, thought I, if this can possibly be a part of his Ramadan; do"][[17 21 2] "they fast on their hams that way in his native island. It must be so;"][[17 21 3] "yes, it's part of his creed, I suppose; well, then, let him rest; he'll"][[17 21 4] "get up sooner or later, no doubt. It can't last for ever, thank God,"][[17 21 5] "and his Ramadan only comes once a year; and I don't believe it's very"][[17 21 6] "punctual then."][[17 22 1] "I went down to supper. After sitting a long time listening to the long"][[17 22 2] "stories of some sailors who had just come from a plum-pudding voyage, as"][[17 22 3] "they called it (that is, a short whaling-voyage in a schooner or brig,"][[17 22 4] "confined to the north of the line, in the Atlantic Ocean only); after"][[17 22 5] "listening to these plum-puddingers till nearly eleven o'clock, I went"][[17 22 6] "up stairs to go to bed, feeling quite sure by this time Queequeg must"][[17 22 7] "certainly have brought his Ramadan to a termination. But no; there he"][[17 22 8] "was just where I had left him; he had not stirred an inch. I began to"][[17 22 9] "grow vexed with him; it seemed so downright senseless and insane to be"][[17 22 10] "sitting there all day and half the night on his hams in a cold room,"][[17 22 11] "holding a piece of wood on his head."][[17 23 1] "\"For heaven's sake, Queequeg, get up and shake yourself; get up and have"][[17 23 2] "some supper. You'll starve; you'll kill yourself, Queequeg.\" But not a"][[17 23 3] "word did he reply."][[17 24 1] "Despairing of him, therefore, I determined to go to bed and to sleep;"][[17 24 2] "and no doubt, before a great while, he would follow me. But previous to"][[17 24 3] "turning in, I took my heavy bearskin jacket, and threw it over him, as"][[17 24 4] "it promised to be a very cold night; and he had nothing but his ordinary"][[17 24 5] "round jacket on. For some time, do all I would, I could not get into"][[17 24 6] "the faintest doze. I had blown out the candle; and the mere thought"][[17 24 7] "of Queequeg--not four feet off--sitting there in that uneasy position,"][[17 24 8] "stark alone in the cold and dark; this made me really wretched. Think of"][[17 24 9] "it; sleeping all night in the same room with a wide awake pagan on his"][[17 24 10] "hams in this dreary, unaccountable Ramadan!"][[17 25 1] "But somehow I dropped off at last, and knew nothing more till break of"][[17 25 2] "day; when, looking over the bedside, there squatted Queequeg, as if he"][[17 25 3] "had been screwed down to the floor. But as soon as the first glimpse of"][[17 25 4] "sun entered the window, up he got, with stiff and grating joints,"][[17 25 5] "but with a cheerful look; limped towards me where I lay; pressed his"][[17 25 6] "forehead again against mine; and said his Ramadan was over."][[17 26 1] "Now, as I before hinted, I have no objection to any person's religion,"][[17 26 2] "be it what it may, so long as that person does not kill or insult any"][[17 26 3] "other person, because that other person don't believe it also. But when"][[17 26 4] "a man's religion becomes really frantic; when it is a positive torment"][[17 26 5] "to him; and, in fine, makes this earth of ours an uncomfortable inn to"][[17 26 6] "lodge in; then I think it high time to take that individual aside and"][[17 26 7] "argue the point with him."][[17 27 1] "And just so I now did with Queequeg. \"Queequeg,\" said I, \"get into bed"][[17 27 2] "now, and lie and listen to me.\" I then went on, beginning with the rise"][[17 27 3] "and progress of the primitive religions, and coming down to the various"][[17 27 4] "religions of the present time, during which time I labored to show"][[17 27 5] "Queequeg that all these Lents, Ramadans, and prolonged ham-squattings in"][[17 27 6] "cold, cheerless rooms were stark nonsense; bad for the health; useless"][[17 27 7] "for the soul; opposed, in short, to the obvious laws of Hygiene and"][[17 27 8] "common sense. I told him, too, that he being in other things such an"][[17 27 9] "extremely sensible and sagacious savage, it pained me, very badly pained"][[17 27 10] "me, to see him now so deplorably foolish about this ridiculous Ramadan"][[17 27 11] "of his. Besides, argued I, fasting makes the body cave in; hence the"][[17 27 12] "spirit caves in; and all thoughts born of a fast must necessarily be"][[17 27 13] "half-starved. This is the reason why most dyspeptic religionists cherish"][[17 27 14] "such melancholy notions about their hereafters. In one word, Queequeg,"][[17 27 15] "said I, rather digressively; hell is an idea first born on an undigested"][[17 27 16] "apple-dumpling; and since then perpetuated through the hereditary"][[17 27 17] "dyspepsias nurtured by Ramadans."][[17 28 1] "I then asked Queequeg whether he himself was ever troubled with"][[17 28 2] "dyspepsia; expressing the idea very plainly, so that he could take it"][[17 28 3] "in. He said no; only upon one memorable occasion. It was after a great"][[17 28 4] "feast given by his father the king, on the gaining of a great battle"][[17 28 5] "wherein fifty of the enemy had been killed by about two o'clock in the"][[17 28 6] "afternoon, and all cooked and eaten that very evening."][[17 29 1] "\"No more, Queequeg,\" said I, shuddering; \"that will do;\" for I knew the"][[17 29 2] "inferences without his further hinting them. I had seen a sailor who had"][[17 29 3] "visited that very island, and he told me that it was the custom, when"][[17 29 4] "a great battle had been gained there, to barbecue all the slain in the"][[17 29 5] "yard or garden of the victor; and then, one by one, they were placed"][[17 29 6] "in great wooden trenchers, and garnished round like a pilau, with"][[17 29 7] "breadfruit and cocoanuts; and with some parsley in their mouths, were"][[17 29 8] "sent round with the victor's compliments to all his friends, just as"][[17 29 9] "though these presents were so many Christmas turkeys."][[17 30 1] "After all, I do not think that my remarks about religion made much"][[17 30 2] "impression upon Queequeg. Because, in the first place, he somehow seemed"][[17 30 3] "dull of hearing on that important subject, unless considered from his"][[17 30 4] "own point of view; and, in the second place, he did not more than one"][[17 30 5] "third understand me, couch my ideas simply as I would; and, finally, he"][[17 30 6] "no doubt thought he knew a good deal more about the true religion than"][[17 30 7] "I did. He looked at me with a sort of condescending concern and"][[17 30 8] "compassion, as though he thought it a great pity that such a sensible"][[17 30 9] "young man should be so hopelessly lost to evangelical pagan piety."][[17 31 1] "At last we rose and dressed; and Queequeg, taking a prodigiously hearty"][[17 31 2] "breakfast of chowders of all sorts, so that the landlady should not"][[17 31 3] "make much profit by reason of his Ramadan, we sallied out to board the"][[17 31 4] "Pequod, sauntering along, and picking our teeth with halibut bones."][[18 0 0] "CHAPTER 18. His Mark."][[18 2 1] "As we were walking down the end of the wharf towards the ship, Queequeg"][[18 2 2] "carrying his harpoon, Captain Peleg in his gruff voice loudly hailed us"][[18 2 3] "from his wigwam, saying he had not suspected my friend was a cannibal,"][[18 2 4] "and furthermore announcing that he let no cannibals on board that craft,"][[18 2 5] "unless they previously produced their papers."][[18 3 1] "\"What do you mean by that, Captain Peleg?\" said I, now jumping on the"][[18 3 2] "bulwarks, and leaving my comrade standing on the wharf."][[18 4 1] "\"I mean,\" he replied, \"he must show his papers.\""][[18 5 1] "\"Yes,\" said Captain Bildad in his hollow voice, sticking his head from"][[18 5 2] "behind Peleg's, out of the wigwam. \"He must show that he's converted."][[18 5 3] "Son of darkness,\" he added, turning to Queequeg, \"art thou at present in"][[18 5 4] "communion with any Christian church?\""][[18 6 1] "\"Why,\" said I, \"he's a member of the first Congregational Church.\" Here"][[18 6 2] "be it said, that many tattooed savages sailing in Nantucket ships at"][[18 6 3] "last come to be converted into the churches."][[18 7 1] "\"First Congregational Church,\" cried Bildad, \"what! that worships in"][[18 7 2] "Deacon Deuteronomy Coleman's meeting-house?\" and so saying, taking"][[18 7 3] "out his spectacles, he rubbed them with his great yellow bandana"][[18 7 4] "handkerchief, and putting them on very carefully, came out of the"][[18 7 5] "wigwam, and leaning stiffly over the bulwarks, took a good long look at"][[18 7 6] "Queequeg."][[18 8 1] "\"How long hath he been a member?\" he then said, turning to me; \"not very"][[18 8 2] "long, I rather guess, young man.\""][[18 9 1] "\"No,\" said Peleg, \"and he hasn't been baptized right either, or it would"][[18 9 2] "have washed some of that devil's blue off his face.\""][[18 10 1] "\"Do tell, now,\" cried Bildad, \"is this Philistine a regular member of"][[18 10 2] "Deacon Deuteronomy's meeting? I never saw him going there, and I pass it"][[18 10 3] "every Lord's day.\""][[18 11 1] "\"I don't know anything about Deacon Deuteronomy or his meeting,\" said"][[18 11 2] "I; \"all I know is, that Queequeg here is a born member of the First"][[18 11 3] "Congregational Church. He is a deacon himself, Queequeg is.\""][[18 12 1] "\"Young man,\" said Bildad sternly, \"thou art skylarking with me--explain"][[18 12 2] "thyself, thou young Hittite. What church dost thee mean? answer me.\""][[18 13 1] "Finding myself thus hard pushed, I replied. \"I mean, sir, the same"][[18 13 2] "ancient Catholic Church to which you and I, and Captain Peleg there,"][[18 13 3] "and Queequeg here, and all of us, and every mother's son and soul of"][[18 13 4] "us belong; the great and everlasting First Congregation of this whole"][[18 13 5] "worshipping world; we all belong to that; only some of us cherish some"][[18 13 6] "queer crotchets no ways touching the grand belief; in THAT we all join"][[18 13 7] "hands.\""][[18 14 1] "\"Splice, thou mean'st SPLICE hands,\" cried Peleg, drawing nearer. \"Young"][[18 14 2] "man, you'd better ship for a missionary, instead of a fore-mast hand;"][[18 14 3] "I never heard a better sermon. Deacon Deuteronomy--why Father Mapple"][[18 14 4] "himself couldn't beat it, and he's reckoned something. Come aboard, come"][[18 14 5] "aboard; never mind about the papers. I say, tell Quohog there--what's"][[18 14 6] "that you call him? tell Quohog to step along. By the great anchor, what"][[18 14 7] "a harpoon he's got there! looks like good stuff that; and he handles it"][[18 14 8] "about right. I say, Quohog, or whatever your name is, did you ever stand"][[18 14 9] "in the head of a whale-boat? did you ever strike a fish?\""][[18 15 1] "Without saying a word, Queequeg, in his wild sort of way, jumped upon"][[18 15 2] "the bulwarks, from thence into the bows of one of the whale-boats"][[18 15 3] "hanging to the side; and then bracing his left knee, and poising his"][[18 15 4] "harpoon, cried out in some such way as this:--"][[18 16 1] "\"Cap'ain, you see him small drop tar on water dere? You see him? well,"][[18 16 2] "spose him one whale eye, well, den!\" and taking sharp aim at it, he"][[18 16 3] "darted the iron right over old Bildad's broad brim, clean across the"][[18 16 4] "ship's decks, and struck the glistening tar spot out of sight."][[18 17 1] "\"Now,\" said Queequeg, quietly hauling in the line, \"spos-ee him whale-e"][[18 17 2] "eye; why, dad whale dead.\""][[18 18 1] "\"Quick, Bildad,\" said Peleg, his partner, who, aghast at the close"][[18 18 2] "vicinity of the flying harpoon, had retreated towards the cabin gangway."][[18 18 3] "\"Quick, I say, you Bildad, and get the ship's papers. We must have"][[18 18 4] "Hedgehog there, I mean Quohog, in one of our boats. Look ye, Quohog,"][[18 18 5] "we'll give ye the ninetieth lay, and that's more than ever was given a"][[18 18 6] "harpooneer yet out of Nantucket.\""][[18 19 1] "So down we went into the cabin, and to my great joy Queequeg was soon"][[18 19 2] "enrolled among the same ship's company to which I myself belonged."][[18 20 1] "When all preliminaries were over and Peleg had got everything ready for"][[18 20 2] "signing, he turned to me and said, \"I guess, Quohog there don't know how"][[18 20 3] "to write, does he? I say, Quohog, blast ye! dost thou sign thy name or"][[18 20 4] "make thy mark?\""][[18 21 1] "But at this question, Queequeg, who had twice or thrice before taken"][[18 21 2] "part in similar ceremonies, looked no ways abashed; but taking the"][[18 21 3] "offered pen, copied upon the paper, in the proper place, an exact"][[18 21 4] "counterpart of a queer round figure which was tattooed upon his arm; so"][[18 21 5] "that through Captain Peleg's obstinate mistake touching his appellative,"][[18 21 6] "it stood something like this:--"][[18 22 1] "Quohog. his X mark."][[18 23 1] "Meanwhile Captain Bildad sat earnestly and steadfastly eyeing Queequeg,"][[18 23 2] "and at last rising solemnly and fumbling in the huge pockets of his"][[18 23 3] "broad-skirted drab coat, took out a bundle of tracts, and selecting"][[18 23 4] "one entitled \"The Latter Day Coming; or No Time to Lose,\" placed it in"][[18 23 5] "Queequeg's hands, and then grasping them and the book with both his,"][[18 23 6] "looked earnestly into his eyes, and said, \"Son of darkness, I must do my"][[18 23 7] "duty by thee; I am part owner of this ship, and feel concerned for the"][[18 23 8] "souls of all its crew; if thou still clingest to thy Pagan ways, which I"][[18 23 9] "sadly fear, I beseech thee, remain not for aye a Belial bondsman. Spurn"][[18 23 10] "the idol Bell, and the hideous dragon; turn from the wrath to come; mind"][[18 23 11] "thine eye, I say; oh! goodness gracious! steer clear of the fiery pit!\""][[18 24 1] "Something of the salt sea yet lingered in old Bildad's language,"][[18 24 2] "heterogeneously mixed with Scriptural and domestic phrases."][[18 25 1] "\"Avast there, avast there, Bildad, avast now spoiling our harpooneer,\""][[18 25 2] "cried Peleg. \"Pious harpooneers never make good voyagers--it takes the shark"][[18 25 3] "out of 'em; no harpooneer is worth a straw who aint pretty sharkish."][[18 25 4] "There was young Nat Swaine, once the bravest boat-header out of all"][[18 25 5] "Nantucket and the Vineyard; he joined the meeting, and never came to"][[18 25 6] "good. He got so frightened about his plaguy soul, that he shrinked and"][[18 25 7] "sheered away from whales, for fear of after-claps, in case he got stove"][[18 25 8] "and went to Davy Jones.\""][[18 26 1] "\"Peleg! Peleg!\" said Bildad, lifting his eyes and hands, \"thou thyself,"][[18 26 2] "as I myself, hast seen many a perilous time; thou knowest, Peleg, what"][[18 26 3] "it is to have the fear of death; how, then, can'st thou prate in this"][[18 26 4] "ungodly guise. Thou beliest thine own heart, Peleg. Tell me, when this"][[18 26 5] "same Pequod here had her three masts overboard in that typhoon on Japan,"][[18 26 6] "that same voyage when thou went mate with Captain Ahab, did'st thou not"][[18 26 7] "think of Death and the Judgment then?\""][[18 27 1] "\"Hear him, hear him now,\" cried Peleg, marching across the cabin, and"][[18 27 2] "thrusting his hands far down into his pockets,--\"hear him, all of ye."][[18 27 3] "Think of that! When every moment we thought the ship would sink!"][[18 27 4] "Death and the Judgment then? What? With all three masts making such an"][[18 27 5] "everlasting thundering against the side; and every sea breaking over us,"][[18 27 6] "fore and aft. Think of Death and the Judgment then? No! no time to think"][[18 27 7] "about Death then. Life was what Captain Ahab and I was thinking of;"][[18 27 8] "and how to save all hands--how to rig jury-masts--how to get into the"][[18 27 9] "nearest port; that was what I was thinking of.\""][[18 28 1] "Bildad said no more, but buttoning up his coat, stalked on deck,"][[18 28 2] "where we followed him. There he stood, very quietly overlooking some"][[18 28 3] "sailmakers who were mending a top-sail in the waist. Now and then"][[18 28 4] "he stooped to pick up a patch, or save an end of tarred twine, which"][[18 28 5] "otherwise might have been wasted."][[19 0 0] "CHAPTER 19. The Prophet."][[19 2 1] "\"Shipmates, have ye shipped in that ship?\""][[19 3 1] "Queequeg and I had just left the Pequod, and were sauntering away from"][[19 3 2] "the water, for the moment each occupied with his own thoughts, when"][[19 3 3] "the above words were put to us by a stranger, who, pausing before us,"][[19 3 4] "levelled his massive forefinger at the vessel in question. He was but"][[19 3 5] "shabbily apparelled in faded jacket and patched trowsers; a rag of a"][[19 3 6] "black handkerchief investing his neck. A confluent small-pox had in all"][[19 3 7] "directions flowed over his face, and left it like the complicated ribbed"][[19 3 8] "bed of a torrent, when the rushing waters have been dried up."][[19 4 1] "\"Have ye shipped in her?\" he repeated."][[19 5 1] "\"You mean the ship Pequod, I suppose,\" said I, trying to gain a little"][[19 5 2] "more time for an uninterrupted look at him."][[19 6 1] "\"Aye, the Pequod--that ship there,\" he said, drawing back his whole"][[19 6 2] "arm, and then rapidly shoving it straight out from him, with the fixed"][[19 6 3] "bayonet of his pointed finger darted full at the object."][[19 7 1] "\"Yes,\" said I, \"we have just signed the articles.\""][[19 8 1] "\"Anything down there about your souls?\""][[19 9 1] "\"About what?\""][[19 10 1] "\"Oh, perhaps you hav'n't got any,\" he said quickly. \"No matter though,"][[19 10 2] "I know many chaps that hav'n't got any,--good luck to 'em; and they are"][[19 10 3] "all the better off for it. A soul's a sort of a fifth wheel to a wagon.\""][[19 11 1] "\"What are you jabbering about, shipmate?\" said I."][[19 12 1] "\"HE'S got enough, though, to make up for all deficiencies of that sort"][[19 12 2] "in other chaps,\" abruptly said the stranger, placing a nervous emphasis"][[19 12 3] "upon the word HE."][[19 13 1] "\"Queequeg,\" said I, \"let's go; this fellow has broken loose from"][[19 13 2] "somewhere; he's talking about something and somebody we don't know.\""][[19 14 1] "\"Stop!\" cried the stranger. \"Ye said true--ye hav'n't seen Old Thunder"][[19 14 2] "yet, have ye?\""][[19 15 1] "\"Who's Old Thunder?\" said I, again riveted with the insane earnestness"][[19 15 2] "of his manner."][[19 16 1] "\"Captain Ahab.\""][[19 17 1] "\"What! the captain of our ship, the Pequod?\""][[19 18 1] "\"Aye, among some of us old sailor chaps, he goes by that name. Ye"][[19 18 2] "hav'n't seen him yet, have ye?\""][[19 19 1] "\"No, we hav'n't. He's sick they say, but is getting better, and will be"][[19 19 2] "all right again before long.\""][[19 20 1] "\"All right again before long!\" laughed the stranger, with a solemnly"][[19 20 2] "derisive sort of laugh. \"Look ye; when Captain Ahab is all right, then"][[19 20 3] "this left arm of mine will be all right; not before.\""][[19 21 1] "\"What do you know about him?\""][[19 22 1] "\"What did they TELL you about him? Say that!\""][[19 23 1] "\"They didn't tell much of anything about him; only I've heard that he's"][[19 23 2] "a good whale-hunter, and a good captain to his crew.\""][[19 24 1] "\"That's true, that's true--yes, both true enough. But you must jump when"][[19 24 2] "he gives an order. Step and growl; growl and go--that's the word with"][[19 24 3] "Captain Ahab. But nothing about that thing that happened to him off Cape"][[19 24 4] "Horn, long ago, when he lay like dead for three days and nights;"][[19 24 5] "nothing about that deadly skrimmage with the Spaniard afore the altar in"][[19 24 6] "Santa?--heard nothing about that, eh? Nothing about the silver calabash"][[19 24 7] "he spat into? And nothing about his losing his leg last voyage,"][[19 24 8] "according to the prophecy. Didn't ye hear a word about them matters and"][[19 24 9] "something more, eh? No, I don't think ye did; how could ye? Who knows"][[19 24 10] "it? Not all Nantucket, I guess. But hows'ever, mayhap, ye've heard tell"][[19 24 11] "about the leg, and how he lost it; aye, ye have heard of that, I dare"][[19 24 12] "say. Oh yes, THAT every one knows a'most--I mean they know he's only one"][[19 24 13] "leg; and that a parmacetti took the other off.\""][[19 25 1] "\"My friend,\" said I, \"what all this gibberish of yours is about, I"][[19 25 2] "don't know, and I don't much care; for it seems to me that you must be a"][[19 25 3] "little damaged in the head. But if you are speaking of Captain Ahab, of"][[19 25 4] "that ship there, the Pequod, then let me tell you, that I know all about"][[19 25 5] "the loss of his leg.\""][[19 26 1] "\"ALL about it, eh--sure you do?--all?\""][[19 27 1] "\"Pretty sure.\""][[19 28 1] "With finger pointed and eye levelled at the Pequod, the beggar-like"][[19 28 2] "stranger stood a moment, as if in a troubled reverie; then starting a"][[19 28 3] "little, turned and said:--\"Ye've shipped, have ye? Anyhow, it's all fixed"][[19 28 6] "and arranged a'ready; and some sailors or other must go with him, I"][[19 28 7] "suppose; as well these as any other men, God pity 'em! Morning to ye,"][[19 28 8] "shipmates, morning; the ineffable heavens bless ye; I'm sorry I stopped"][[19 28 9] "ye.\""][[19 29 1] "\"Look here, friend,\" said I, \"if you have anything important to tell"][[19 29 2] "us, out with it; but if you are only trying to bamboozle us, you are"][[19 29 3] "mistaken in your game; that's all I have to say.\""][[19 30 1] "\"And it's said very well, and I like to hear a chap talk up that way;"][[19 30 2] "you are just the man for him--the likes of ye.
