It"][[19 31 2] "is the easiest thing in the world for a man to look as if he had a great"][[19 31 3] "secret in him.\""][[19 32 1] "\"Morning to ye, shipmates, morning.\""][[19 33 1] "\"Morning it is,\" said I. \"Come along, Queequeg, let's leave this crazy"][[19 33 2] "man. But stop, tell me your name, will you?\""][[19 34 1] "\"Elijah.\""][[19 35 1] "Elijah! thought I, and we walked away, both commenting, after each"][[19 35 2] "other's fashion, upon this ragged old sailor; and agreed that he was"][[19 35 3] "nothing but a humbug, trying to be a bugbear. But we had not gone"][[19 35 4] "perhaps above a hundred yards, when chancing to turn a corner, and"][[19 35 5] "looking back as I did so, who should be seen but Elijah following us,"][[19 35 6] "though at a distance. Somehow, the sight of him struck me so, that I"][[19 35 7] "said nothing to Queequeg of his being behind, but passed on with my"][[19 35 8] "comrade, anxious to see whether the stranger would turn the same corner"][[19 35 9] "that we did. He did; and then it seemed to me that he was dogging"][[19 35 10] "us, but with what intent I could not for the life of me imagine. This"][[19 35 11] "circumstance, coupled with his ambiguous, half-hinting, half-revealing,"][[19 35 12] "shrouded sort of talk, now begat in me all kinds of vague wonderments"][[19 35 13] "and half-apprehensions, and all connected with the Pequod; and Captain"][[19 35 14] "Ahab; and the leg he had lost; and the Cape Horn fit; and the silver"][[19 35 15] "calabash; and what Captain Peleg had said of him, when I left the ship"][[19 35 16] "the day previous; and the prediction of the squaw Tistig; and the voyage"][[19 35 17] "we had bound ourselves to sail; and a hundred other shadowy things."][[19 36 1] "I was resolved to satisfy myself whether this ragged Elijah was really"][[19 36 2] "dogging us or not, and with that intent crossed the way with Queequeg,"][[19 36 3] "and on that side of it retraced our steps. But Elijah passed on, without"][[19 36 4] "seeming to notice us. This relieved me; and once more, and finally as it"][[19 36 5] "seemed to me, I pronounced him in my heart, a humbug."][[20 0 0] "CHAPTER 20. All Astir."][[20 2 1] "A day or two passed, and there was great activity aboard the Pequod."][[20 2 2] "Not only were the old sails being mended, but new sails were coming on"][[20 2 3] "board, and bolts of canvas, and coils of rigging; in short, everything"][[20 2 4] "betokened that the ship's preparations were hurrying to a close. Captain"][[20 2 5] "Peleg seldom or never went ashore, but sat in his wigwam keeping a sharp"][[20 2 6] "look-out upon the hands: Bildad did all the purchasing and providing"][[20 2 7] "at the stores; and the men employed in the hold and on the rigging were"][[20 2 8] "working till long after night-fall."][[20 3 1] "On the day following Queequeg's signing the articles, word was given at"][[20 3 2] "all the inns where the ship's company were stopping, that their chests"][[20 3 3] "must be on board before night, for there was no telling how soon"][[20 3 4] "the vessel might be sailing. So Queequeg and I got down our traps,"][[20 3 5] "resolving, however, to sleep ashore till the last. But it seems they"][[20 3 6] "always give very long notice in these cases, and the ship did not sail"][[20 3 7] "for several days. But no wonder; there was a good deal to be done, and"][[20 3 8] "there is no telling how many things to be thought of, before the Pequod"][[20 3 9] "was fully equipped."][[20 4 1] "Every one knows what a multitude of things--beds, sauce-pans, knives"][[20 4 2] "and forks, shovels and tongs, napkins, nut-crackers, and what not, are"][[20 4 3] "indispensable to the business of housekeeping. Just so with whaling,"][[20 4 4] "which necessitates a three-years' housekeeping upon the wide ocean,"][[20 4 5] "far from all grocers, costermongers, doctors, bakers, and bankers. And"][[20 4 6] "though this also holds true of merchant vessels, yet not by any means"][[20 4 7] "to the same extent as with whalemen. For besides the great length of the"][[20 4 8] "whaling voyage, the numerous articles peculiar to the prosecution of the"][[20 4 9] "fishery, and the impossibility of replacing them at the remote harbors"][[20 4 10] "usually frequented, it must be remembered, that of all ships, whaling"][[20 4 11] "vessels are the most exposed to accidents of all kinds, and especially"][[20 4 12] "to the destruction and loss of the very things upon which the success of"][[20 4 13] "the voyage most depends. Hence, the spare boats, spare spars, and spare"][[20 4 14] "lines and harpoons, and spare everythings, almost, but a spare Captain"][[20 4 15] "and duplicate ship."][[20 5 1] "At the period of our arrival at the Island, the heaviest storage of the"][[20 5 2] "Pequod had been almost completed; comprising her beef, bread, water,"][[20 5 3] "fuel, and iron hoops and staves. But, as before hinted, for some time"][[20 5 4] "there was a continual fetching and carrying on board of divers odds and"][[20 5 5] "ends of things, both large and small."][[20 6 1] "Chief among those who did this fetching and carrying was Captain"][[20 6 2] "Bildad's sister, a lean old lady of a most determined and indefatigable"][[20 6 3] "spirit, but withal very kindhearted, who seemed resolved that, if SHE"][[20 6 4] "could help it, nothing should be found wanting in the Pequod, after once"][[20 6 5] "fairly getting to sea. At one time she would come on board with a jar"][[20 6 6] "of pickles for the steward's pantry; another time with a bunch of quills"][[20 6 7] "for the chief mate's desk, where he kept his log; a third time with a"][[20 6 8] "roll of flannel for the small of some one's rheumatic back. Never did"][[20 6 9] "any woman better deserve her name, which was Charity--Aunt Charity, as"][[20 6 10] "everybody called her. And like a sister of charity did this charitable"][[20 6 11] "Aunt Charity bustle about hither and thither, ready to turn her hand"][[20 6 12] "and heart to anything that promised to yield safety, comfort, and"][[20 6 13] "consolation to all on board a ship in which her beloved brother"][[20 6 14] "Bildad was concerned, and in which she herself owned a score or two of"][[20 6 15] "well-saved dollars."][[20 7 1] "But it was startling to see this excellent hearted Quakeress coming on"][[20 7 2] "board, as she did the last day, with a long oil-ladle in one hand, and"][[20 7 3] "a still longer whaling lance in the other. Nor was Bildad himself nor"][[20 7 4] "Captain Peleg at all backward. As for Bildad, he carried about with him"][[20 7 5] "a long list of the articles needed, and at every fresh arrival, down"][[20 7 6] "went his mark opposite that article upon the paper. Every once in a"][[20 7 7] "while Peleg came hobbling out of his whalebone den, roaring at the men"][[20 7 8] "down the hatchways, roaring up to the riggers at the mast-head, and then"][[20 7 9] "concluded by roaring back into his wigwam."][[20 8 1] "During these days of preparation, Queequeg and I often visited the"][[20 8 2] "craft, and as often I asked about Captain Ahab, and how he was, and when"][[20 8 3] "he was going to come on board his ship. To these questions they would"][[20 8 4] "answer, that he was getting better and better, and was expected aboard"][[20 8 5] "every day; meantime, the two captains, Peleg and Bildad, could attend"][[20 8 6] "to everything necessary to fit the vessel for the voyage. If I had been"][[20 8 7] "downright honest with myself, I would have seen very plainly in my heart"][[20 8 8] "that I did but half fancy being committed this way to so long a voyage,"][[20 8 9] "without once laying my eyes on the man who was to be the absolute"][[20 8 10] "dictator of it, so soon as the ship sailed out upon the open sea."][[20 8 11] "But when a man suspects any wrong, it sometimes happens that if he be"][[20 8 12] "already involved in the matter, he insensibly strives to cover up his"][[20 8 13] "suspicions even from himself. And much this way it was with me. I said"][[20 8 14] "nothing, and tried to think nothing."][[20 9 1] "At last it was given out that some time next day the ship would"][[20 9 2] "certainly sail. So next morning, Queequeg and I took a very early start."][[21 0 0] "CHAPTER 21. Going Aboard."][[21 2 1] "It was nearly six o'clock, but only grey imperfect misty dawn, when we"][[21 2 2] "drew nigh the wharf."][[21 3 1] "\"There are some sailors running ahead there, if I see right,\" said I to"][[21 3 2] "Queequeg, \"it can't be shadows; she's off by sunrise, I guess; come on!\""][[21 4 1] "\"Avast!\" cried a voice, whose owner at the same time coming close behind"][[21 4 2] "us, laid a hand upon both our shoulders, and then insinuating himself"][[21 4 3] "between us, stood stooping forward a little, in the uncertain twilight,"][[21 4 4] "strangely peering from Queequeg to me. Besides, it was very convenient on"][[21 27 10] "an excursion; much better than those garden-chairs which are convertible"][[21 27 11] "into walking-sticks; upon occasion, a chief calling his attendant, and"][[21 27 12] "desiring him to make a settee of himself under a spreading tree, perhaps"][[21 27 13] "in some damp marshy place."][[21 28 1] "While narrating these things, every time Queequeg received the tomahawk"][[21 28 2] "from me, he flourished the hatchet-side of it over the sleeper's head."][[21 29 1] "\"What's that for, Queequeg?\""][[21 30 1] "\"Perry easy, kill-e; oh! perry easy!\""][[21 31 1] "He was going on with some wild reminiscences about his tomahawk-pipe,"][[21 31 2] "which, it seemed, had in its two uses both brained his foes and soothed"][[21 31 3] "his soul, when we were directly attracted to the sleeping rigger. The"][[21 31 4] "strong vapour now completely filling the contracted hole, it began"][[21 31 5] "to tell upon him. Merry Christmas."][[22 2 1] "At length, towards noon, upon the final dismissal of the ship's riggers,"][[22 2 2] "and after the Pequod had been hauled out from the wharf, and after the"][[22 2 3] "ever-thoughtful Charity had come off in a whale-boat, with her last"][[22 2 4] "gift--a night-cap for Stubb, the second mate, her brother-in-law, and a"][[22 2 5] "spare Bible for the steward--after all this, the two Captains, Peleg"][[22 2 6] "and Bildad, issued from the cabin, and turning to the chief mate, Peleg"][[22 2 7] "said:"][[22 3 1] "\"Now, Mr. Starbuck, are you sure everything is right? Here upon the very point of starting for the voyage, Captain"][[22 5 2] "Peleg and Captain Bildad were going it with a high hand on the"][[22 5 3] "quarter-deck, just as if they were to be joint-commanders at sea, as"][[22 5 4] "well as to all appearances in port. And all this seemed natural enough; especially as in the merchant"][[22 5 11] "service many captains never show themselves on deck for a considerable"][[22 5 12] "time after heaving up the anchor, but remain over the cabin table,"][[22 5 13] "having a farewell merry-making with their shore friends, before they"][[22 5 14] "quit the ship for good with the pilot."][[22 6 1] "But there was not much chance to think over the matter, for Captain"][[22 6 2] "Peleg was now all alive. The Lee Shore."][[23 2 1] "Some chapters back, one Bulkington was spoken of, a tall, newlanded"][[23 2 2] "mariner, encountered in New Bedford at the inn."][[23 3 1] "When on that shivering winter's night, the Pequod thrust her vindictive"][[23 3 2] "bows into the cold malicious waves, who should I see standing at her"][[23 3 3] "helm but Bulkington! I looked with sympathetic awe and fearfulness upon"][[23 3 4] "the man, who in mid-winter just landed from a four years' dangerous"][[23 3 5] "voyage, could so unrestingly push off again for still another"][[23 3 6] "tempestuous term. The land seemed scorching to his feet. Wonderfullest"][[23 3 7] "things are ever the unmentionable; deep memories yield no epitaphs; this"][[23 3 8] "six-inch chapter is the stoneless grave of Bulkington. Let me only say"][[23 3 9] "that it fared with him as with the storm-tossed ship, that miserably"][[23 3 10] "drives along the leeward land. The port would fain give succor; the port"][[23 3 11] "is pitiful; in the port is safety, comfort, hearthstone, supper, warm"][[23 3 12] "blankets, friends, all that's kind to our mortalities. But in that gale,"][[23 3 13] "the port, the land, is that ship's direst jeopardy; she must fly all"][[23 3 14] "hospitality; one touch of land, though it but graze the keel, would make"][[23 3 15] "her shudder through and through. With all her might she crowds all sail"][[23 3 16] "off shore; in so doing, fights 'gainst the very winds that fain would"][[23 3 17] "blow her homeward; seeks all the lashed sea's landlessness again;"][[23 3 18] "for refuge's sake forlornly rushing into peril; her only friend her"][[23 3 19] "bitterest foe!"][[23 4 1] "Know ye now, Bulkington? Glimpses do ye seem to see of that mortally"][[23 4 2] "intolerable truth; that all deep, earnest thinking is but the intrepid"][[23 4 3] "effort of the soul to keep the open independence of her sea; while"][[23 4 4] "the wildest winds of heaven and earth conspire to cast her on the"][[23 4 5] "treacherous, slavish shore?"][[23 5 1] "But as in landlessness alone resides highest truth, shoreless,"][[23 5 2] "indefinite as God--so, better is it to perish in that howling infinite,"][[23 5 3] "than be ingloriously dashed upon the lee, even if that were safety!"][[23 5 4] "For worm-like, then, oh! who would craven crawl to land! Up from the spray of thy"][[23 5 7] "ocean-perishing--straight up, leaps thy apotheosis!"][[24 0 0] "CHAPTER 24. The Advocate."][[24 2 1] "As Queequeg and I are now fairly embarked in this business of whaling;"][[24 2 2] "and as this business of whaling has somehow come to be regarded among"][[24 2 3] "landsmen as a rather unpoetical and disreputable pursuit; therefore, I"][[24 2 4] "am all anxiety to convince ye, ye landsmen, of the injustice hereby done"][[24 2 5] "to us hunters of whales."][[24 3 1] "In the first place, it may be deemed almost superfluous to establish"][[24 3 2] "the fact, that among people at large, the business of whaling is not"][[24 3 3] "accounted on a level with what are called the liberal professions. If a"][[24 3 4] "stranger were introduced into any miscellaneous metropolitan society,"][[24 3 5] "it would but slightly advance the general opinion of his merits, were"][[24 3 6] "he presented to the company as a harpooneer, say; and if in emulation"][[24 3 7] "of the naval officers he should append the initials S.W.F. (Sperm"][[24 3 8] "Whale Fishery) to his visiting card, such a procedure would be deemed"][[24 3 9] "pre-eminently presuming and ridiculous."][[24 4 1] "Doubtless one leading reason why the world declines honouring us"][[24 4 2] "whalemen, is this: they think that, at best, our vocation amounts to a"][[24 4 3] "butchering sort of business; and that when actively engaged therein, we"][[24 4 4] "are surrounded by all manner of defilements. Butchers we are, that is"][[24 4 5] "true. But butchers, also, and butchers of the bloodiest badge have been"][[24 4 6] "all Martial Commanders whom the world invariably delights to honour. And"][[24 4 7] "as for the matter of the alleged uncleanliness of our business, ye shall"][[24 4 8] "soon be initiated into certain facts hitherto pretty generally unknown,"][[24 4 9] "and which, upon the whole, will triumphantly plant the sperm whale-ship"][[24 4 10] "at least among the cleanliest things of this tidy earth. But even"][[24 4 11] "granting the charge in question to be true; what disordered slippery"][[24 4 12] "decks of a whale-ship are comparable to the unspeakable carrion of those"][[24 4 13] "battle-fields from which so many soldiers return to drink in all ladies'"][[24 4 14] "plaudits? And if the idea of peril so much enhances the popular conceit"][[24 4 15] "of the soldier's profession; let me assure ye that many a veteran"][[24 4 16] "who has freely marched up to a battery, would quickly recoil at the"][[24 4 17] "apparition of the sperm whale's vast tail, fanning into eddies the air"][[24 4 18] "over his head. For what are the comprehensible terrors of man compared"][[24 4 19] "with the interlinked terrors and wonders of God!"][[24 5 1] "But, though the world scouts at us whale hunters, yet does it"][[24 5 2] "unwittingly pay us the profoundest homage; yea, an all-abounding"][[24 5 3] "adoration! for almost all the tapers, lamps, and candles that burn round"][[24 5 4] "the globe, burn, as before so many shrines, to our glory!"][[24 6 1] "But look at this matter in other lights; weigh it in all sorts of"][[24 6 2] "scales; see what we whalemen are, and have been."][[24 7 1] "Why did the Dutch in De Witt's time have admirals of their whaling"][[24 7 2] "fleets? Why did Louis XVI. of France, at his own personal expense, fit"][[24 7 3] "out whaling ships from Dunkirk, and politely invite to that town some"][[24 7 4] "score or two of families from our own island of Nantucket? Why did"][[24 7 5] "Britain between the years  and  pay to her whalemen in bounties"][[24 7 6] "upwards of L,,? And lastly, how comes it that we whalemen of"][[24 7 7] "America now outnumber all the rest of the banded whalemen in the world;"][[24 7 8] "sail a navy of upwards of seven hundred vessels; manned by eighteen"][[24 7 9] "thousand men; yearly consuming ,, of dollars; the ships worth,"][[24 7 10] "at the time of sailing, $,,! and every year importing into our"][[24 7 11] "harbors a well reaped harvest of $,,. How comes all this, if"][[24 7 12] "there be not something puissant in whaling?"][[24 8 1] "But this is not the half; look again."][[24 9 1] "I freely assert, that the cosmopolite philosopher cannot, for his life,"][[24 9 2] "point out one single peaceful influence, which within the last sixty"][[24 9 3] "years has operated more potentially upon the whole broad world, taken in"][[24 9 4] "one aggregate, than the high and mighty business of whaling. One way"][[24 9 5] "and another, it has begotten events so remarkable in themselves, and so"][[24 9 6] "continuously momentous in their sequential issues, that whaling may"][[24 9 7] "well be regarded as that Egyptian mother, who bore offspring themselves"][[24 9 8] "pregnant from her womb. It would be a hopeless, endless task to"][[24 9 9] "catalogue all these things. Let a handful suffice. For many years past"][[24 9 10] "the whale-ship has been the pioneer in ferreting out the remotest and"][[24 9 11] "least known parts of the earth. She has explored seas and archipelagoes"][[24 9 12] "which had no chart, where no Cook or Vancouver had ever sailed. If"][[24 9 13] "American and European men-of-war now peacefully ride in once savage"][[24 9 14] "harbors, let them fire salutes to the honour and glory of the"][[24 9 15] "whale-ship, which originally showed them the way, and first interpreted"][[24 9 16] "between them and the savages. They may celebrate as they will the heroes"][[24 9 17] "of Exploring Expeditions, your Cooks, your Krusensterns; but I say that"][[24 9 18] "scores of anonymous Captains have sailed out of Nantucket, that were"][[24 9 19] "as great, and greater than your Cook and your Krusenstern. For in their"][[24 9 20] "succourless empty-handedness, they, in the heathenish sharked waters,"][[24 9 21] "and by the beaches of unrecorded, javelin islands, battled with virgin"][[24 9 22] "wonders and terrors that Cook with all his marines and muskets would"][[24 9 23] "not willingly have dared. All that is made such a flourish of in the old"][[24 9 24] "South Sea Voyages, those things were but the life-time commonplaces of"][[24 9 25] "our heroic Nantucketers. Often, adventures which Vancouver dedicates"][[24 9 26] "three chapters to, these men accounted unworthy of being set down in the"][[24 9 27] "ship's common log. Ah, the world! Oh, the world!"][[24 10 1] "Until the whale fishery rounded Cape Horn, no commerce but colonial,"][[24 10 2] "scarcely any intercourse but colonial, was carried on between Europe and"][[24 10 3] "the long line of the opulent Spanish provinces on the Pacific coast."][[24 10 4] "It was the whaleman who first broke through the jealous policy of the"][[24 10 5] "Spanish crown, touching those colonies; and, if space permitted, it"][[24 10 6] "might be distinctly shown how from those whalemen at last eventuated the"][[24 10 7] "liberation of Peru, Chili, and Bolivia from the yoke of Old Spain, and"][[24 10 8] "the establishment of the eternal democracy in those parts."][[24 11 1] "That great America on the other side of the sphere, Australia, was given"][[24 11 2] "to the enlightened world by the whaleman. After its first blunder-born"][[24 11 3] "discovery by a Dutchman, all other ships long shunned those shores"][[24 11 4] "as pestiferously barbarous; but the whale-ship touched there. The"][[24 11 5] "whale-ship is the true mother of that now mighty colony. Moreover,"][[24 11 6] "in the infancy of the first Australian settlement, the emigrants were"][[24 11 7] "several times saved from starvation by the benevolent biscuit of the"][[24 11 8] "whale-ship luckily dropping an anchor in their waters. The uncounted"][[24 11 9] "isles of all Polynesia confess the same truth, and do commercial homage"][[24 11 10] "to the whale-ship, that cleared the way for the missionary and the"][[24 11 11] "merchant, and in many cases carried the primitive missionaries to their"][[24 11 12] "first destinations. If that double-bolted land, Japan, is ever to become"][[24 11 13] "hospitable, it is the whale-ship alone to whom the credit will be due;"][[24 11 14] "for already she is on the threshold."][[24 12 1] "But if, in the face of all this, you still declare that whaling has no"][[24 12 2] "aesthetically noble associations connected with it, then am I ready to"][[24 12 3] "shiver fifty lances with you there, and unhorse you with a split helmet"][[24 12 4] "every time."][[24 13 1] "The whale has no famous author, and whaling no famous chronicler, you"][[24 13 2] "will say."][[24 14 1] "THE WHALE NO FAMOUS AUTHOR, AND WHALING NO FAMOUS CHRONICLER? Whaling is imperial! By old English statutory"][[24 18 2] "law, the whale is declared \"a royal fish.\"*"][[24 19 1] "Oh, that's only nominal! The whale himself has never figured in any"][[24 19 2] "grand imposing way."][[24 20 1] "THE WHALE NEVER FIGURED IN ANY GRAND IMPOSING WAY? In one of the mighty"][[24 20 2] "triumphs given to a Roman general upon his entering the world's capital,"][[24 20 3] "the bones of a whale, brought all the way from the Syrian coast, were"][[24 20 4] "the most conspicuous object in the cymballed procession.*"][[24 22 1] "*See subsequent chapters for something more on this head."][[24 24 1] "Grant it, since you cite it; but, say what you will, there is no real"][[24 24 2] "dignity in whaling."][[24 25 1] "NO DIGNITY IN WHALING? The dignity of our calling the very heavens"][[24 25 2] "attest. Cetus is a constellation in the South! No more! Drive down your"][[24 25 3] "hat in presence of the Czar, and take it off to Queequeg! No more! I"][[24 25 4] "know a man that, in his lifetime, has taken three hundred and fifty"][[24 25 5] "whales. I account that man more honourable than that great captain of"][[24 25 6] "antiquity who boasted of taking as many walled towns."][[24 26 1] "And, as for me, if, by any possibility, there be any as yet undiscovered"][[24 26 2] "prime thing in me; if I shall ever deserve any real repute in that small"][[24 26 3] "but high hushed world which I might not be unreasonably ambitious of; if"][[24 26 4] "hereafter I shall do anything that, upon the whole, a man might rather"][[24 26 5] "have done than to have left undone; if, at my death, my executors, or"][[24 26 6] "more properly my creditors, find any precious MSS. in my desk, then here"][[24 26 7] "I prospectively ascribe all the honour and the glory to whaling; for a"][[24 26 8] "whale-ship was my Yale College and my Harvard."][[25 0 0] "CHAPTER 25. Postscript."][[25 2 1] "In behalf of the dignity of whaling, I would fain advance naught but"][[25 2 2] "substantiated facts. But after embattling his facts, an advocate who"][[25 2 3] "should wholly suppress a not unreasonable surmise, which might"][[25 2 4] "tell eloquently upon his cause--such an advocate, would he not be"][[25 2 5] "blameworthy?"][[25 3 1] "It is well known that at the coronation of kings and queens, even modern"][[25 3 2] "ones, a certain curious process of seasoning them for their functions is"][[25 3 3] "gone through. There is a saltcellar of state, so called, and there"][[25 3 4] "may be a castor of state. How they use the salt, precisely--who knows?"][[25 3 5] "Certain I am, however, that a king's head is solemnly oiled at his"][[25 3 6] "coronation, even as a head of salad. Can it be, though, that they"][[25 3 7] "anoint it with a view of making its interior run well, as they anoint"][[25 3 8] "machinery? Much might be ruminated here, concerning the essential"][[25 3 9] "dignity of this regal process, because in common life we esteem but"][[25 3 10] "meanly and contemptibly a fellow who anoints his hair, and palpably"][[25 3 11] "smells of that anointing. In truth, a mature man who uses hair-oil,"][[25 3 12] "unless medicinally, that man has probably got a quoggy spot in him"][[25 3 13] "somewhere. As a general rule, he can't amount to much in his totality."][[25 4 1] "But the only thing to be considered here, is this--what kind of oil is"][[25 4 2] "used at coronations? Certainly it cannot be olive oil, nor macassar oil,"][[25 4 3] "nor castor oil, nor bear's oil, nor train oil, nor cod-liver oil. What"][[25 4 4] "then can it possibly be, but sperm oil in its unmanufactured, unpolluted"][[25 4 5] "state, the sweetest of all oils?"][[25 5 1] "Think of that, ye loyal Britons! we whalemen supply your kings and"][[25 5 2] "queens with coronation stuff!"][[26 0 0] "CHAPTER 26. Knights and Squires."][[26 2 1] "The chief mate of the Pequod was Starbuck, a native of Nantucket, and a"][[26 2 2] "Quaker by descent. He was a long, earnest man, and though born on an icy"][[26 2 3] "coast, seemed well adapted to endure hot latitudes, his flesh being hard"][[26 2 4] "as twice-baked biscuit. Transported to the Indies, his live blood would"][[26 2 5] "not spoil like bottled ale. He must have been born in some time of"][[26 2 6] "general drought and famine, or upon one of those fast days for which"][[26 2 7] "his state is famous. Only some thirty arid summers had he seen; those"][[26 2 8] "summers had dried up all his physical superfluousness. But this, his"][[26 2 9] "thinness, so to speak, seemed no more the token of wasting anxieties and"][[26 2 10] "cares, than it seemed the indication of any bodily blight. It was merely"][[26 2 11] "the condensation of the man. He was by no means ill-looking; quite the"][[26 2 12] "contrary. His pure tight skin was an excellent fit; and closely wrapped"][[26 2 13] "up in it, and embalmed with inner health and strength, like a revivified"][[26 2 14] "Egyptian, this Starbuck seemed prepared to endure for long ages to come,"][[26 2 15] "and to endure always, as now; for be it Polar snow or torrid sun, like"][[26 2 16] "a patent chronometer, his interior vitality was warranted to do well"][[26 2 17] "in all climates. Looking into his eyes, you seemed to see there the yet"][[26 2 18] "lingering images of those thousand-fold perils he had calmly confronted"][[26 2 19] "through life. A staid, steadfast man, whose life for the most part was a"][[26 2 20] "telling pantomime of action, and not a tame chapter of sounds. Yet, for"][[26 2 21] "all his hardy sobriety and fortitude, there were certain qualities"][[26 2 22] "in him which at times affected, and in some cases seemed well nigh to"][[26 2 23] "overbalance all the rest. Uncommonly conscientious for a seaman, and"][[26 2 24] "endued with a deep natural reverence, the wild watery loneliness of his"][[26 2 25] "life did therefore strongly incline him to superstition; but to that"][[26 2 26] "sort of superstition, which in some organizations seems rather to"][[26 2 27] "spring, somehow, from intelligence than from ignorance. Outward portents"][[26 2 28] "and inward presentiments were his. And if at times these things bent the"][[26 2 29] "welded iron of his soul, much more did his far-away domestic memories"][[26 2 30] "of his young Cape wife and child, tend to bend him still more from the"][[26 2 31] "original ruggedness of his nature, and open him still further to those"][[26 2 32] "latent influences which, in some honest-hearted men, restrain the gush"][[26 2 33] "of dare-devil daring, so often evinced by others in the more perilous"][[26 2 34] "vicissitudes of the fishery. \"I will have no man in my boat,\" said"][[26 2 35] "Starbuck, \"who is not afraid of a whale.\" By this, he seemed to mean,"][[26 2 36] "not only that the most reliable and useful courage was that which arises"][[26 2 37] "from the fair estimation of the encountered peril, but that an utterly"][[26 2 38] "fearless man is a far more dangerous comrade than a coward."][[26 3 1] "\"Aye, aye,\" said Stubb, the second mate, \"Starbuck, there, is as careful"][[26 3 2] "a man as you'll find anywhere in this fishery.\" But we shall ere long"][[26 3 3] "see what that word \"careful\" precisely means when used by a man like"][[26 3 4] "Stubb, or almost any other whale hunter."][[26 4 1] "Starbuck was no crusader after perils; in him courage was not a"][[26 4 2] "sentiment; but a thing simply useful to him, and always at hand upon all"][[26 4 3] "mortally practical occasions. Besides, he thought, perhaps, that in this"][[26 4 4] "business of whaling, courage was one of the great staple outfits of"][[26 4 5] "the ship, like her beef and her bread, and not to be foolishly wasted."][[26 4 6] "Wherefore he had no fancy for lowering for whales after sun-down; nor"][[26 4 7] "for persisting in fighting a fish that too much persisted in fighting"][[26 4 8] "him. For, thought Starbuck, I am here in this critical ocean to kill"][[26 4 9] "whales for my living, and not to be killed by them for theirs; and that"][[26 4 10] "hundreds of men had been so killed Starbuck well knew. What doom was"][[26 4 11] "his own father's? Where, in the bottomless deeps, could he find the torn"][[26 4 12] "limbs of his brother?"][[26 5 1] "With memories like these in him, and, moreover, given to a certain"][[26 5 2] "superstitiousness, as has been said; the courage of this Starbuck which"][[26 5 3] "could, nevertheless, still flourish, must indeed have been extreme. But"][[26 5 4] "it was not in reasonable nature that a man so organized, and with such"][[26 5 5] "terrible experiences and remembrances as he had; it was not in nature"][[26 5 6] "that these things should fail in latently engendering an element in"][[26 5 7] "him, which, under suitable circumstances, would break out from its"][[26 5 8] "confinement, and burn all his courage up. And brave as he might be, it"][[26 5 9] "was that sort of bravery chiefly, visible in some intrepid men, which,"][[26 5 10] "while generally abiding firm in the conflict with seas, or winds, or"][[26 5 11] "whales, or any of the ordinary irrational horrors of the world, yet"][[26 5 12] "cannot withstand those more terrific, because more spiritual terrors,"][[26 5 13] "which sometimes menace you from the concentrating brow of an enraged and"][[26 5 14] "mighty man."][[26 6 1] "But were the coming narrative to reveal in any instance, the complete"][[26 6 2] "abasement of poor Starbuck's fortitude, scarce might I have the heart to"][[26 6 3] "write it; for it is a thing most sorrowful, nay shocking, to expose"][[26 6 4] "the fall of valour in the soul. Men may seem detestable as joint"][[26 6 5] "stock-companies and nations; knaves, fools, and murderers there may be;"][[26 6 6] "men may have mean and meagre faces; but man, in the ideal, is so noble"][[26 6 7] "and so sparkling, such a grand and glowing creature, that over any"][[26 6 8] "ignominious blemish in him all his fellows should run to throw their"][[26 6 9] "costliest robes. That immaculate manliness we feel within ourselves,"][[26 6 10] "so far within us, that it remains intact though all the outer character"][[26 6 11] "seem gone; bleeds with keenest anguish at the undraped spectacle of"][[26 6 12] "a valor-ruined man. Nor can piety itself, at such a shameful sight,"][[26 6 13] "completely stifle her upbraidings against the permitting stars. But this"][[26 6 14] "august dignity I treat of, is not the dignity of kings and robes, but"][[26 6 15] "that abounding dignity which has no robed investiture. Thou shalt see it"][[26 6 16] "shining in the arm that wields a pick or drives a spike; that democratic"][[26 6 17] "dignity which, on all hands, radiates without end from God; Himself! The"][[26 6 18] "great God absolute! The centre and circumference of all democracy! His"][[26 6 19] "omnipresence, our divine equality!"][[26 7 1] "If, then, to meanest mariners, and renegades and castaways, I shall"][[26 7 2] "hereafter ascribe high qualities, though dark; weave round them tragic"][[26 7 3] "graces; if even the most mournful, perchance the most abased, among them"][[26 7 4] "all, shall at times lift himself to the exalted mounts; if I shall touch"][[26 7 5] "that workman's arm with some ethereal light; if I shall spread a rainbow"][[26 7 6] "over his disastrous set of sun; then against all mortal critics bear"][[26 7 7] "me out in it, thou Just Spirit of Equality, which hast spread one royal"][[26 7 8] "mantle of humanity over all my kind! Bear me out in it, thou great"][[26 7 9] "democratic God! who didst not refuse to the swart convict, Bunyan, the"][[26 7 10] "pale, poetic pearl; Thou who didst clothe with doubly hammered leaves"][[26 7 11] "of finest gold, the stumped and paupered arm of old Cervantes; Thou who"][[26 7 12] "didst pick up Andrew Jackson from the pebbles; who didst hurl him upon a"][[26 7 13] "war-horse; who didst thunder him higher than a throne! Thou who, in all"][[26 7 14] "Thy mighty, earthly marchings, ever cullest Thy selectest champions from"][[26 7 15] "the kingly commons; bear me out in it, O God!"][[27 0 0] "CHAPTER 27. Knights and Squires."][[27 2 1] "Stubb was the second mate. He was a native of Cape Cod; and hence,"][[27 2 2] "according to local usage, was called a Cape-Cod-man. A happy-go-lucky;"][[27 2 3] "neither craven nor valiant; taking perils as they came with an"][[27 2 4] "indifferent air; and while engaged in the most imminent crisis of the"][[27 2 5] "chase, toiling away, calm and collected as a journeyman joiner engaged"][[27 2 6] "for the year. Good-humored, easy, and careless, he presided over his"][[27 2 7] "whale-boat as if the most deadly encounter were but a dinner, and his"][[27 2 8] "crew all invited guests. He was as particular about the comfortable"][[27 2 9] "arrangement of his part of the boat, as an old stage-driver is about the"][[27 2 10] "snugness of his box. When close to the whale, in the very death-lock of"][[27 2 11] "the fight, he handled his unpitying lance coolly and off-handedly, as"][[27 2 12] "a whistling tinker his hammer. He would hum over his old rigadig tunes"][[27 2 13] "while flank and flank with the most exasperated monster. Long usage had,"][[27 2 14] "for this Stubb, converted the jaws of death into an easy chair. What he"][[27 2 15] "thought of death itself, there is no telling. Whether he ever thought of"][[27 2 16] "it at all, might be a question; but, if he ever did chance to cast his"][[27 2 17] "mind that way after a comfortable dinner, no doubt, like a good sailor,"][[27 2 18] "he took it to be a sort of call of the watch to tumble aloft, and bestir"][[27 2 19] "themselves there, about something which he would find out when he obeyed"][[27 2 20] "the order, and not sooner."][[27 3 1] "What, perhaps, with other things, made Stubb such an easy-going,"][[27 3 2] "unfearing man, so cheerily trudging off with the burden of life in a"][[27 3 3] "world full of grave pedlars, all bowed to the ground with their packs;"][[27 3 4] "what helped to bring about that almost impious good-humor of his; that"][[27 3 5] "thing must have been his pipe. For, like his nose, his short, black"][[27 3 6] "little pipe was one of the regular features of his face. You would"][[27 3 7] "almost as soon have expected him to turn out of his bunk without his"][[27 3 8] "nose as without his pipe. He kept a whole row of pipes there ready"][[27 3 9] "loaded, stuck in a rack, within easy reach of his hand; and, whenever he"][[27 3 10] "turned in, he smoked them all out in succession, lighting one from"][[27 3 11] "the other to the end of the chapter; then loading them again to be in"][[27 3 12] "readiness anew. For, when Stubb dressed, instead of first putting his"][[27 3 13] "legs into his trowsers, he put his pipe into his mouth."][[27 4 1] "I say this continual smoking must have been one cause, at least, of his"][[27 4 2] "peculiar disposition; for every one knows that this earthly air, whether"][[27 4 3] "ashore or afloat, is terribly infected with the nameless miseries of"][[27 4 4] "the numberless mortals who have died exhaling it; and as in time of the"][[27 4 5] "cholera, some people go about with a camphorated handkerchief to their"][[27 4 6] "mouths; so, likewise, against all mortal tribulations, Stubb's tobacco"][[27 4 7] "smoke might have operated as a sort of disinfecting agent."][[27 5 1] "The third mate was Flask, a native of Tisbury, in Martha's Vineyard. A"][[27 5 2] "short, stout, ruddy young fellow, very pugnacious concerning whales,"][[27 5 3] "who somehow seemed to think that the great leviathans had personally"][[27 5 4] "and hereditarily affronted him; and therefore it was a sort of point of"][[27 5 5] "honour with him, to destroy them whenever encountered. So utterly lost"][[27 5 6] "was he to all sense of reverence for the many marvels of their majestic"][[27 5 7] "bulk and mystic ways; and so dead to anything like an apprehension of"][[27 5 8] "any possible danger from encountering them; that in his poor opinion,"][[27 5 9] "the wondrous whale was but a species of magnified mouse, or at least"][[27 5 10] "water-rat, requiring only a little circumvention and some small"][[27 5 11] "application of time and trouble in order to kill and boil. This"][[27 5 12] "ignorant, unconscious fearlessness of his made him a little waggish in"][[27 5 13] "the matter of whales; he followed these fish for the fun of it; and a"][[27 5 14] "three years' voyage round Cape Horn was only a jolly joke that lasted"][[27 5 15] "that length of time. As a carpenter's nails are divided into wrought"][[27 5 16] "nails and cut nails; so mankind may be similarly divided. Little Flask"][[27 5 17] "was one of the wrought ones; made to clinch tight and last long. They"][[27 5 18] "called him King-Post on board of the Pequod; because, in form, he could"][[27 5 19] "be well likened to the short, square timber known by that name in Arctic"][[27 5 20] "whalers; and which by the means of many radiating side timbers inserted"][[27 5 21] "into it, serves to brace the ship against the icy concussions of those"][[27 5 22] "battering seas."][[27 6 1] "Now these three mates--Starbuck, Stubb, and Flask, were momentous"][[27 6 2] "men. They it was who by universal prescription commanded three of the"][[27 6 3] "Pequod's boats as headsmen. In that grand order of battle in which"][[27 6 4] "Captain Ahab would probably marshal his forces to descend on the whales,"][[27 6 5] "these three headsmen were as captains of companies. Or, being armed with"][[27 6 6] "their long keen whaling spears, they were as a picked trio of lancers;"][[27 6 7] "even as the harpooneers were flingers of javelins."][[27 7 1] "And since in this famous fishery, each mate or headsman, like a Gothic"][[27 7 2] "Knight of old, is always accompanied by his boat-steerer or harpooneer,"][[27 7 3] "who in certain conjunctures provides him with a fresh lance, when"][[27 7 4] "the former one has been badly twisted, or elbowed in the assault; and"][[27 7 5] "moreover, as there generally subsists between the two, a close intimacy"][[27 7 6] "and friendliness; it is therefore but meet, that in this place we set"][[27 7 7] "down who the Pequod's harpooneers were, and to what headsman each of"][[27 7 8] "them belonged."][[27 8 1] "First of all was Queequeg, whom Starbuck, the chief mate, had selected"][[27 8 2] "for his squire. But Queequeg is already known."][[27 9 1] "Next was Tashtego, an unmixed Indian from Gay Head, the most westerly"][[27 9 2] "promontory of Martha's Vineyard, where there still exists the last"][[27 9 3] "remnant of a village of red men, which has long supplied the neighboring"][[27 9 4] "island of Nantucket with many of her most daring harpooneers. In the"][[27 9 5] "fishery, they usually go by the generic name of Gay-Headers. Tashtego's"][[27 9 6] "long, lean, sable hair, his high cheek bones, and black rounding"][[27 9 7] "eyes--for an Indian, Oriental in their largeness, but Antarctic in their"][[27 9 8] "glittering expression--all this sufficiently proclaimed him an inheritor"][[27 9 9] "of the unvitiated blood of those proud warrior hunters, who, in quest"][[27 9 10] "of the great New England moose, had scoured, bow in hand, the aboriginal"][[27 9 11] "forests of the main. But no longer snuffing in the trail of the wild"][[27 9 12] "beasts of the woodland, Tashtego now hunted in the wake of the great"][[27 9 13] "whales of the sea; the unerring harpoon of the son fitly replacing the"][[27 9 14] "infallible arrow of the sires. To look at the tawny brawn of his lithe"][[27 9 15] "snaky limbs, you would almost have credited the superstitions of some of"][[27 9 16] "the earlier Puritans, and half-believed this wild Indian to be a son"][[27 9 17] "of the Prince of the Powers of the Air. Tashtego was Stubb the second"][[27 9 18] "mate's squire."][[27 10 1] "Third among the harpooneers was Daggoo, a gigantic, coal-black"][[27 10 2] "negro-savage, with a lion-like tread--an Ahasuerus to behold. Suspended"][[27 10 3] "from his ears were two golden hoops, so large that the sailors called"][[27 10 4] "them ring-bolts, and would talk of securing the top-sail halyards to"][[27 10 5] "them. In his youth Daggoo had voluntarily shipped on board of a whaler,"][[27 10 6] "lying in a lonely bay on his native coast. And never having been"][[27 10 7] "anywhere in the world but in Africa, Nantucket, and the pagan harbors"][[27 10 8] "most frequented by whalemen; and having now led for many years the bold"][[27 10 9] "life of the fishery in the ships of owners uncommonly heedful of what"][[27 10 10] "manner of men they shipped; Daggoo retained all his barbaric virtues,"][[27 10 11] "and erect as a giraffe, moved about the decks in all the pomp of six"][[27 10 12] "feet five in his socks. There was a corporeal humility in looking up at"][[27 10 13] "him; and a white man standing before him seemed a white flag come to"][[27 10 14] "beg truce of a fortress. Curious to tell, this imperial negro, Ahasuerus"][[27 10 15] "Daggoo, was the Squire of little Flask, who looked like a chess-man"][[27 10 16] "beside him. As for the residue of the Pequod's company, be it said, that"][[27 10 17] "at the present day not one in two of the many thousand men before the"][[27 10 18] "mast employed in the American whale fishery, are Americans born, though"][[27 10 19] "pretty nearly all the officers are. Herein it is the same with the"][[27 10 20] "American whale fishery as with the American army and military and"][[27 10 21] "merchant navies, and the engineering forces employed in the construction"][[27 10 22] "of the American Canals and Railroads. The same, I say, because in all"][[27 10 23] "these cases the native American liberally provides the brains, the rest"][[27 10 24] "of the world as generously supplying the muscles. No small number of"][[27 10 25] "these whaling seamen belong to the Azores, where the outward bound"][[27 10 26] "Nantucket whalers frequently touch to augment their crews from the hardy"][[27 10 27] "peasants of those rocky shores. In like manner, the Greenland whalers"][[27 10 28] "sailing out of Hull or London, put in at the Shetland Islands, to"][[27 10 29] "receive the full complement of their crew. Upon the passage homewards,"][[27 10 30] "they drop them there again. How it is, there is no telling, but"][[27 10 31] "Islanders seem to make the best whalemen. They were nearly all Islanders"][[27 10 32] "in the Pequod, ISOLATOES too, I call such, not acknowledging the common"][[27 10 33] "continent of men, but each ISOLATO living on a separate continent of his"][[27 10 34] "own. Yet now, federated along one keel, what a set these Isolatoes were!"][[27 10 35] "An Anacharsis Clootz deputation from all the isles of the sea, and all"][[27 10 36] "the ends of the earth, accompanying Old Ahab in the Pequod to lay the"][[27 10 37] "world's grievances before that bar from which not very many of them ever"][[27 10 38] "come back. Black Little Pip--he never did--oh, no! he went before. Poor"][[27 10 39] "Alabama boy! On the grim Pequod's forecastle, ye shall ere long see him,"][[27 10 40] "beating his tambourine; prelusive of the eternal time, when sent for,"][[27 10 41] "to the great quarter-deck on high, he was bid strike in with angels, and"][[27 10 42] "beat his tambourine in glory; called a coward here, hailed a hero there!"][[28 0 0] "CHAPTER 28. Ahab."][[28 2 1] "For several days after leaving Nantucket, nothing above hatches was seen"][[28 2 2] "of Captain Ahab. The mates regularly relieved each other at the watches,"][[28 2 3] "and for aught that could be seen to the contrary, they seemed to be the"][[28 2 4] "only commanders of the ship; only they sometimes issued from the cabin"][[28 2 5] "with orders so sudden and peremptory, that after all it was plain they"][[28 2 6] "but commanded vicariously. Yes, their supreme lord and dictator was"][[28 2 7] "there, though hitherto unseen by any eyes not permitted to penetrate"][[28 2 8] "into the now sacred retreat of the cabin."][[28 3 1] "Every time I ascended to the deck from my watches below, I instantly"][[28 3 2] "gazed aft to mark if any strange face were visible; for my first vague"][[28 3 3] "disquietude touching the unknown captain, now in the seclusion of the"][[28 3 4] "sea, became almost a perturbation. This was strangely heightened"][[28 3 5] "at times by the ragged Elijah's diabolical incoherences uninvitedly"][[28 3 6] "recurring to me, with a subtle energy I could not have before conceived"][[28 3 7] "of. But poorly could I withstand them, much as in other moods I was"][[28 3 8] "almost ready to smile at the solemn whimsicalities of that outlandish"][[28 3 9] "prophet of the wharves. But whatever it was of apprehensiveness or"][[28 3 10] "uneasiness--to call it so--which I felt, yet whenever I came to look"][[28 3 11] "about me in the ship, it seemed against all warrantry to cherish such"][[28 3 12] "emotions. For though the harpooneers, with the great body of the crew,"][[28 3 13] "were a far more barbaric, heathenish, and motley set than any of the"][[28 3 14] "tame merchant-ship companies which my previous experiences had made me"][[28 3 15] "acquainted with, still I ascribed this--and rightly ascribed it--to the"][[28 3 16] "fierce uniqueness of the very nature of that wild Scandinavian vocation"][[28 3 17] "in which I had so abandonedly embarked. But it was especially the aspect"][[28 3 18] "of the three chief officers of the ship, the mates, which was most"][[28 3 19] "forcibly calculated to allay these colourless misgivings, and induce"][[28 3 20] "confidence and cheerfulness in every presentment of the voyage. Three"][[28 3 21] "better, more likely sea-officers and men, each in his own different way,"][[28 3 22] "could not readily be found, and they were every one of them Americans; a"][[28 3 23] "Nantucketer, a Vineyarder, a Cape man. Now, it being Christmas when the"][[28 3 24] "ship shot from out her harbor, for a space we had biting Polar weather,"][[28 3 25] "though all the time running away from it to the southward; and by every"][[28 3 26] "degree and minute of latitude which we sailed, gradually leaving that"][[28 3 27] "merciless winter, and all its intolerable weather behind us. It was one"][[28 3 28] "of those less lowering, but still grey and gloomy enough mornings of the"][[28 3 29] "transition, when with a fair wind the ship was rushing through the water"][[28 3 30] "with a vindictive sort of leaping and melancholy rapidity, that as I"][[28 3 31] "mounted to the deck at the call of the forenoon watch, so soon as I"][[28 3 32] "levelled my glance towards the taffrail, foreboding shivers ran over me."][[28 3 33] "Reality outran apprehension; Captain Ahab stood upon his quarter-deck."][[28 4 1] "There seemed no sign of common bodily illness about him, nor of the"][[28 4 2] "recovery from any. He looked like a man cut away from the stake, when"][[28 4 3] "the fire has overrunningly wasted all the limbs without consuming them,"][[28 4 4] "or taking away one particle from their compacted aged robustness. His"][[28 4 5] "whole high, broad form, seemed made of solid bronze, and shaped in an"][[28 4 6] "unalterable mould, like Cellini's cast Perseus. Threading its way out"][[28 4 7] "from among his grey hairs, and continuing right down one side of his"][[28 4 8] "tawny scorched face and neck, till it disappeared in his clothing,"][[28 4 9] "you saw a slender rod-like mark, lividly whitish. It resembled that"][[28 4 10] "perpendicular seam sometimes made in the straight, lofty trunk of"][[28 4 11] "a great tree, when the upper lightning tearingly darts down it, and"][[28 4 12] "without wrenching a single twig, peels and grooves out the bark from top"][[28 4 13] "to bottom, ere running off into the soil, leaving the tree still greenly"][[28 4 14] "alive, but branded. Whether that mark was born with him, or whether it"][[28 4 15] "was the scar left by some desperate wound, no one could certainly say."][[28 4 16] "By some tacit consent, throughout the voyage little or no allusion was"][[28 4 17] "made to it, especially by the mates. But once Tashtego's senior, an old"][[28 4 18] "Gay-Head Indian among the crew, superstitiously asserted that not till"][[28 4 19] "he was full forty years old did Ahab become that way branded, and"][[28 4 20] "then it came upon him, not in the fury of any mortal fray, but in"][[28 4 21] "an elemental strife at sea. Yet, this wild hint seemed inferentially"][[28 4 22] "negatived, by what a grey Manxman insinuated, an old sepulchral man,"][[28 4 23] "who, having never before sailed out of Nantucket, had never ere this"][[28 4 24] "laid eye upon wild Ahab. Nevertheless, the old sea-traditions, the"][[28 4 25] "immemorial credulities, popularly invested this old Manxman with"][[28 4 26] "preternatural powers of discernment. So that no white sailor seriously"][[28 4 27] "contradicted him when he said that if ever Captain Ahab should"][[28 4 28] "be tranquilly laid out--which might hardly come to pass, so he"][[28 4 29] "muttered--then, whoever should do that last office for the dead, would"][[28 4 30] "find a birth-mark on him from crown to sole."][[28 5 1] "So powerfully did the whole grim aspect of Ahab affect me, and the livid"][[28 5 2] "brand which streaked it, that for the first few moments I hardly noted"][[28 5 3] "that not a little of this overbearing grimness was owing to the barbaric"][[28 5 4] "white leg upon which he partly stood. It had previously come to me that"][[28 5 5] "this ivory leg had at sea been fashioned from the polished bone of"][[28 5 6] "the sperm whale's jaw. \"Aye, he was dismasted off Japan,\" said the old"][[28 5 7] "Gay-Head Indian once; \"but like his dismasted craft, he shipped another"][[28 5 8] "mast without coming home for it. He has a quiver of 'em.\""][[28 6 1] "I was struck with the singular posture he maintained. Upon each side of"][[28 6 2] "the Pequod's quarter deck, and pretty close to the mizzen shrouds, there"][[28 6 3] "was an auger hole, bored about half an inch or so, into the plank."][[28 6 4] "His bone leg steadied in that hole; one arm elevated, and holding by a"][[28 6 5] "shroud; Captain Ahab stood erect, looking straight out beyond the"][[28 6 6] "ship's ever-pitching prow. There was an infinity of firmest fortitude,"][[28 6 7] "a determinate, unsurrenderable wilfulness, in the fixed and fearless,"][[28 6 8] "forward dedication of that glance. Not a word he spoke; nor did his"][[28 6 9] "officers say aught to him; though by all their minutest gestures"][[28 6 10] "and expressions, they plainly showed the uneasy, if not painful,"][[28 6 11] "consciousness of being under a troubled master-eye. And not only that,"][[28 6 12] "but moody stricken Ahab stood before them with a crucifixion in his"][[28 6 13] "face; in all the nameless regal overbearing dignity of some mighty woe."][[28 7 1] "Ere long, from his first visit in the air, he withdrew into his cabin."][[28 7 2] "But after that morning, he was every day visible to the crew; either"][[28 7 3] "standing in his pivot-hole, or seated upon an ivory stool he had; or"][[28 7 4] "heavily walking the deck. As the sky grew less gloomy; indeed, began to"][[28 7 5] "grow a little genial, he became still less and less a recluse; as"][[28 7 6] "if, when the ship had sailed from home, nothing but the dead wintry"][[28 7 7] "bleakness of the sea had then kept him so secluded. And, by and by, it"][[28 7 8] "came to pass, that he was almost continually in the air; but, as yet,"][[28 7 9] "for all that he said, or perceptibly did, on the at last sunny deck,"][[28 7 10] "he seemed as unnecessary there as another mast. But the Pequod was"][[28 7 11] "only making a passage now; not regularly cruising; nearly all whaling"][[28 7 12] "preparatives needing supervision the mates were fully competent to, so"][[28 7 13] "that there was little or nothing, out of himself, to employ or excite"][[28 7 14] "Ahab, now; and thus chase away, for that one interval, the clouds that"][[28 7 15] "layer upon layer were piled upon his brow, as ever all clouds choose the"][[28 7 16] "loftiest peaks to pile themselves upon."][[28 8 1] "Nevertheless, ere long, the warm, warbling persuasiveness of the"][[28 8 2] "pleasant, holiday weather we came to, seemed gradually to charm him from"][[28 8 3] "his mood. For, as when the red-cheeked, dancing girls, April and May,"][[28 8 4] "trip home to the wintry, misanthropic woods; even the barest, ruggedest,"][[28 8 5] "most thunder-cloven old oak will at least send forth some few green"][[28 8 6] "sprouts, to welcome such glad-hearted visitants; so Ahab did, in the"][[28 8 7] "end, a little respond to the playful allurings of that girlish air. More"][[28 8 8] "than once did he put forth the faint blossom of a look, which, in any"][[28 8 9] "other man, would have soon flowered out in a smile."][[29 0 0] "CHAPTER 29. Enter Ahab; to Him, Stubb."][[29 2 1] "Some days elapsed, and ice and icebergs all astern, the Pequod now"][[29 2 2] "went rolling through the bright Quito spring, which, at sea, almost"][[29 2 3] "perpetually reigns on the threshold of the eternal August of the Tropic."][[29 2 4] "The warmly cool, clear, ringing, perfumed, overflowing, redundant days,"][[29 2 5] "were as crystal goblets of Persian sherbet, heaped up--flaked up, with"][[29 2 6] "rose-water snow. The starred and stately nights seemed haughty dames in"][[29 2 7] "jewelled velvets, nursing at home in lonely pride, the memory of their"][[29 2 8] "absent conquering Earls, the golden helmeted suns! For sleeping man,"][[29 2 9] "'twas hard to choose between such winsome days and such seducing nights."][[29 2 10] "But all the witcheries of that unwaning weather did not merely lend new"][[29 2 11] "spells and potencies to the outward world. Inward they turned upon the"][[29 2 12] "soul, especially when the still mild hours of eve came on; then, memory"][[29 2 13] "shot her crystals as the clear ice most forms of noiseless twilights."][[29 2 14] "And all these subtle agencies, more and more they wrought on Ahab's"][[29 2 15] "texture."][[29 3 1] "Old age is always wakeful; as if, the longer linked with life, the less"][[29 3 2] "man has to do with aught that looks like death. Among sea-commanders,"][[29 3 3] "the old greybeards will oftenest leave their berths to visit the"][[29 3 4] "night-cloaked deck. It was so with Ahab; only that now, of late, he"][[29 3 5] "seemed so much to live in the open air, that truly speaking, his visits"][[29 3 6] "were more to the cabin, than from the cabin to the planks. \"It feels"][[29 3 7] "like going down into one's tomb,\"--he would mutter to himself--\"for an"][[29 3 8] "old captain like me to be descending this narrow scuttle, to go to my"][[29 3 9] "grave-dug berth.\""][[29 4 1] "So, almost every twenty-four hours, when the watches of the night were"][[29 4 2] "set, and the band on deck sentinelled the slumbers of the band below;"][[29 4 3] "and when if a rope was to be hauled upon the forecastle, the sailors"][[29 4 4] "flung it not rudely down, as by day, but with some cautiousness dropt"][[29 4 5] "it to its place for fear of disturbing their slumbering shipmates; when"][[29 4 6] "this sort of steady quietude would begin to prevail, habitually, the"][[29 4 7] "silent steersman would watch the cabin-scuttle; and ere long the old man"][[29 4 8] "would emerge, gripping at the iron banister, to help his crippled way."][[29 4 9] "Some considering touch of humanity was in him; for at times like these,"][[29 4 10] "he usually abstained from patrolling the quarter-deck; because to his"][[29 4 11] "wearied mates, seeking repose within six inches of his ivory heel, such"][[29 4 12] "would have been the reverberating crack and din of that bony step, that"][[29 4 13] "their dreams would have been on the crunching teeth of sharks. But once,"][[29 4 14] "the mood was on him too deep for common regardings; and as with heavy,"][[29 4 15] "lumber-like pace he was measuring the ship from taffrail to mainmast,"][[29 4 16] "Stubb, the old second mate, came up from below, with a certain"][[29 4 17] "unassured, deprecating humorousness, hinted that if Captain Ahab was"][[29 4 18] "pleased to walk the planks, then, no one could say nay; but there might"][[29 4 19] "be some way of muffling the noise; hinting something indistinctly and"][[29 4 20] "hesitatingly about a globe of tow, and the insertion into it, of the"][[29 4 21] "ivory heel. Ah! Stubb, thou didst not know Ahab then."][[29 5 1] "\"Am I a cannon-ball, Stubb,\" said Ahab, \"that thou wouldst wad me that"][[29 5 2] "fashion? But go thy ways; I had forgot. Below to thy nightly grave;"][[29 5 3] "where such as ye sleep between shrouds, to use ye to the filling one at"][[29 5 4] "last.--Down, dog, and kennel!\""][[29 6 1] "Starting at the unforseen concluding exclamation of the so suddenly"][[29 6 2] "scornful old man, Stubb was speechless a moment; then said excitedly, \"I"][[29 6 3] "am not used to be spoken to that way, sir; I do but less than half like"][[29 6 4] "it, sir.\""][[29 7 1] "\"Avast! gritted Ahab between his set teeth, and violently moving away,"][[29 7 2] "as if to avoid some passionate temptation."][[29 8 1] "\"No, sir; not yet,\" said Stubb, emboldened, \"I will not tamely be called"][[29 8 2] "a dog, sir.\""][[29 9 1] "\"Then be called ten times a donkey, and a mule, and an ass, and begone,"][[29 9 2] "or I'll clear the world of thee!\""][[29 10 1] "As he said this, Ahab advanced upon him with such overbearing terrors in"][[29 10 2] "his aspect, that Stubb involuntarily retreated."][[29 11 1] "\"I was never served so before without giving a hard blow for it,\""][[29 11 2] "muttered Stubb, as he found himself descending the cabin-scuttle. \"It's"][[29 11 3] "very queer. Yes, that was the thought coming up in me; but it would be the"][[29 11 6] "first time I ever DID pray. He aint in his bed now, either, more"][[29 11 11] "than three hours out of the twenty-four; and he don't sleep then. Didn't"][[29 11 12] "that Dough-Boy, the steward, tell me that of a morning he always finds"][[29 11 13] "the old man's hammock clothes all rumpled and tumbled, and the sheets"][[29 11 14] "down at the foot, and the coverlid almost tied into knots, and the"][[29 11 15] "pillow a sort of frightful hot, as though a baked brick had been on"][[29 11 16] "it? Well, well; I don't know what it is, but the Lord keep me"][[29 11 19] "from catching it. He's full of riddles; I wonder what he goes into the"][[29 11 20] "after hold for, every night, as Dough-Boy tells me he suspects; what's"][[29 11 21] "that for, I should like to know? Who's made appointments with him in"][[29 11 22] "the hold? Ain't that queer, now? But there's no telling, it's the old"][[29 11 23] "game--Here goes for a snooze. Damn me, it's worth a fellow's while to be"][[29 11 24] "born into the world, if only to fall right asleep. And now that I think"][[29 11 25] "of it, that's about the first thing babies do, and that's a sort of"][[29 11 26] "queer, too. Damn me, but all things are queer, come to think of 'em. But"][[29 11 27] "that's against my principles. Think not, is my eleventh commandment; and"][[29 11 28] "sleep when you can, is my twelfth--So here goes again. But how's that?"][[29 11 29] "didn't he call me a dog? blazes! he called me ten times a donkey, and"][[29 11 30] "piled a lot of jackasses on top of THAT! He might as well have kicked"][[29 11 31] "me, and done with it. Maybe he DID kick me, and I didn't observe it,"][[29 11 32] "I was so taken all aback with his brow, somehow. The Pipe."][[30 2 1] "When Stubb had departed, Ahab stood for a while leaning over the"][[30 2 2] "bulwarks; and then, as had been usual with him of late, calling a sailor"][[30 2 3] "of the watch, he sent him below for his ivory stool, and also his pipe."][[30 2 4] "Lighting the pipe at the binnacle lamp and planting the stool on the"][[30 2 5] "weather side of the deck, he sat and smoked."][[30 3 1] "In old Norse times, the thrones of the sea-loving Danish kings were"][[30 3 2] "fabricated, saith tradition, of the tusks of the narwhale. How could one"][[30 3 3] "look at Ahab then, seated on that tripod of bones, without bethinking"][[30 3 4] "him of the royalty it symbolized? Queen Mab."][[31 2 1] "Next morning Stubb accosted Flask."][[31 3 1] "\"Such a queer dream, King-Post, I never had. You know the old man's"][[31 3 2] "ivory leg, well I dreamed he kicked me with it; and when I tried to kick"][[31 3 3] "back, upon my soul, my little man, I kicked my leg right off! And then,"][[31 3 4] "presto! Ahab seemed a pyramid, and I, like a blazing fool, kept kicking"][[31 3 5] "at it. But what was still more curious, Flask--you know how curious all"][[31 3 6] "dreams are--through all this rage that I was in, I somehow seemed to be"][[31 3 7] "thinking to myself, that after all, it was not much of an insult, that"][[31 3 8] "kick from Ahab. 'Why,' thinks I, 'what's the row? It's not a real leg,"][[31 3 9] "only a false leg.' And there's a mighty difference between a living"][[31 3 10] "thump and a dead thump. That's what makes a blow from the hand, Flask,"][[31 3 11] "fifty times more savage to bear than a blow from a cane. The living"][[31 3 12] "member--that makes the living insult, my little man. And thinks I to"][[31 3 13] "myself all the while, mind, while I was stubbing my silly toes against"][[31 3 14] "that cursed pyramid--so confoundedly contradictory was it all, all"][[31 3 15] "the while, I say, I was thinking to myself, 'what's his leg now, but"][[31 3 16] "a cane--a whalebone cane. Yes,' thinks I, 'it was only a playful"][[31 3 17] "cudgelling--in fact, only a whaleboning that he gave me--not a base"][[31 3 18] "kick. Besides,' thinks I, 'look at it once; why, the end of it--the foot"][[31 3 19] "part--what a small sort of end it is; whereas, if a broad footed farmer"][[31 3 20] "kicked me, THERE'S a devilish broad insult. But this insult is whittled"][[31 3 21] "down to a point only.' But now comes the greatest joke of the"][[31 3 22] "dream, Flask. 'And what business is"][[31 3 27] "that of yours, I should like to know, Mr. Humpback? Cetology."][[32 2 1] "Already we are boldly launched upon the deep; but soon we shall be lost"][[32 2 2] "in its unshored, harbourless immensities. Ere that come to pass; ere the"][[32 2 3] "Pequod's weedy hull rolls side by side with the barnacled hulls of the"][[32 2 4] "leviathan; at the outset it is but well to attend to a matter almost"][[32 2 5] "indispensable to a thorough appreciative understanding of the more"][[32 2 6] "special leviathanic revelations and allusions of all sorts which are to"][[32 2 7] "follow."][[32 3 1] "It is some systematized exhibition of the whale in his broad genera,"][[32 3 2] "that I would now fain put before you. Yet is it no easy task. The"][[32 3 3] "classification of the constituents of a chaos, nothing less is here"][[32 3 4] "essayed. Listen to what the best and latest authorities have laid down."][[32 4 1] "\"No branch of Zoology is so much involved as that which is entitled"][[32 4 2] "Cetology,\" says Captain Scoresby, A.D. ."][[32 5 1] "\"It is not my intention, were it in my power, to enter into the"][[32 5 2] "inquiry as to the true method of dividing the cetacea into groups and"][[32 5 3] "families.... Utter confusion exists among the historians of this animal\""][[32 5 4] "(sperm whale), says Surgeon Beale, A.D. ."][[32 6 1] "\"Unfitness to pursue our research in the unfathomable waters.\""][[32 6 2] "\"Impenetrable veil covering our knowledge of the cetacea.\" \"A field"][[32 6 3] "strewn with thorns.\" \"All these incomplete indications but serve to"][[32 6 4] "torture us naturalists.\""][[32 7 1] "Thus speak of the whale, the great Cuvier, and John Hunter, and Lesson,"][[32 7 2] "those lights of zoology and anatomy. Nevertheless, though of real"][[32 7 3] "knowledge there be little, yet of books there are a plenty; and so in"][[32 7 4] "some small degree, with cetology, or the science of whales. Many are"][[32 7 5] "the men, small and great, old and new, landsmen and seamen, who have at"][[32 7 6] "large or in little, written of the whale. Run over a few:--The Authors"][[32 7 7] "of the Bible; Aristotle; Pliny; Aldrovandi; Sir Thomas Browne; Gesner;"][[32 7 8] "Ray; Linnaeus; Rondeletius; Willoughby; Green; Artedi; Sibbald; Brisson;"][[32 7 9] "Marten; Lacepede; Bonneterre; Desmarest; Baron Cuvier; Frederick Cuvier;"][[32 7 10] "John Hunter; Owen; Scoresby; Beale; Bennett; J. Ross Browne; the"][[32 7 11] "Author of Miriam Coffin; Olmstead; and the Rev. T. Cheever. But to what"][[32 7 12] "ultimate generalizing purpose all these have written, the above cited"][[32 7 13] "extracts will show."][[32 8 1] "Of the names in this list of whale authors, only those following Owen"][[32 8 2] "ever saw living whales; and but one of them was a real professional"][[32 8 3] "harpooneer and whaleman. I mean Captain Scoresby. On the separate"][[32 8 4] "subject of the Greenland or right-whale, he is the best existing"][[32 8 5] "authority. But Scoresby knew nothing and says nothing of the great"][[32 8 6] "sperm whale, compared with which the Greenland whale is almost unworthy"][[32 8 7] "mentioning. And here be it said, that the Greenland whale is an usurper"][[32 8 8] "upon the throne of the seas. He is not even by any means the largest"][[32 8 9] "of the whales. Yet, owing to the long priority of his claims, and the"][[32 8 10] "profound ignorance which, till some seventy years back, invested the"][[32 8 11] "then fabulous or utterly unknown sperm-whale, and which ignorance to"][[32 8 12] "this present day still reigns in all but some few scientific retreats"][[32 8 13] "and whale-ports; this usurpation has been every way complete. Reference"][[32 8 14] "to nearly all the leviathanic allusions in the great poets of past days,"][[32 8 15] "will satisfy you that the Greenland whale, without one rival, was to"][[32 8 16] "them the monarch of the seas. But the time has at last come for a new"][[32 8 17] "proclamation. This is Charing Cross; hear ye! good people all,--the"][[32 8 18] "Greenland whale is deposed,--the great sperm whale now reigneth!"][[32 9 1] "There are only two books in being which at all pretend to put the living"][[32 9 2] "sperm whale before you, and at the same time, in the remotest degree"][[32 9 3] "succeed in the attempt. Those books are Beale's and Bennett's; both in"][[32 9 4] "their time surgeons to English South-Sea whale-ships, and both exact and"][[32 9 5] "reliable men. The original matter touching the sperm whale to be found"][[32 9 6] "in their volumes is necessarily small; but so far as it goes, it is of"][[32 9 7] "excellent quality, though mostly confined to scientific description. As"][[32 9 8] "yet, however, the sperm whale, scientific or poetic, lives not complete"][[32 9 9] "in any literature. Far above all other hunted whales, his is an"][[32 9 10] "unwritten life."][[32 10 1] "Now the various species of whales need some sort of popular"][[32 10 2] "comprehensive classification, if only an easy outline one for the"][[32 10 3] "present, hereafter to be filled in all its departments by subsequent"][[32 10 4] "laborers. As no better man advances to take this matter in hand, I"][[32 10 5] "hereupon offer my own poor endeavors. I promise nothing complete;"][[32 10 6] "because any human thing supposed to be complete, must for that very"][[32 10 7] "reason infallibly be faulty. I shall not pretend to a minute anatomical"][[32 10 8] "description of the various species, or--in this place at least--to much"][[32 10 9] "of any description. My object here is simply to project the draught of a"][[32 10 10] "systematization of cetology. I am the architect, not the builder."][[32 11 1] "But it is a ponderous task; no ordinary letter-sorter in the Post-Office"][[32 11 2] "is equal to it. To grope down into the bottom of the sea after them;"][[32 11 3] "to have one's hands among the unspeakable foundations, ribs, and very"][[32 11 4] "pelvis of the world; this is a fearful thing. What am I that I should"][[32 11 5] "essay to hook the nose of this leviathan! The awful tauntings in Job"][[32 11 6] "might well appal me. Will he the (leviathan) make a covenant with thee?"][[32 11 7] "Behold the hope of him is vain! But I have swam through libraries and"][[32 11 8] "sailed through oceans; I have had to do with whales with these visible"][[32 11 9] "hands; I am in earnest; and I will try. There are some preliminaries to"][[32 11 10] "settle."][[32 12 1] "First: The uncertain, unsettled condition of this science of Cetology"][[32 12 2] "is in the very vestibule attested by the fact, that in some quarters it"][[32 12 3] "still remains a moot point whether a whale be a fish. In his System of"][[32 12 4] "Nature, A.D. , Linnaeus declares, \"I hereby separate the whales from"][[32 12 5] "the fish.\" But of my own knowledge, I know that down to the year ,"][[32 12 6] "sharks and shad, alewives and herring, against Linnaeus's express edict,"][[32 12 7] "were still found dividing the possession of the same seas with the"][[32 12 8] "Leviathan."][[32 13 1] "The grounds upon which Linnaeus would fain have banished the whales from"][[32 13 2] "the waters, he states as follows: \"On account of their warm bilocular"][[32 13 3] "heart, their lungs, their movable eyelids, their hollow ears, penem"][[32 13 4] "intrantem feminam mammis lactantem,\" and finally, \"ex lege naturae jure"][[32 13 5] "meritoque.\" I submitted all this to my friends Simeon Macey and Charley"][[32 13 6] "Coffin, of Nantucket, both messmates of mine in a certain voyage, and"][[32 13 7] "they united in the opinion that the reasons set forth were altogether"][[32 13 8] "insufficient. Charley profanely hinted they were humbug."][[32 14 1] "Be it known that, waiving all argument, I take the good old fashioned"][[32 14 2] "ground that the whale is a fish, and call upon holy Jonah to back me."][[32 14 3] "This fundamental thing settled, the next point is, in what internal"][[32 14 4] "respect does the whale differ from other fish. Above, Linnaeus has given"][[32 14 5] "you those items. But in brief, they are these: lungs and warm blood;"][[32 14 6] "whereas, all other fish are lungless and cold blooded."][[32 15 1] "Next: how shall we define the whale, by his obvious externals, so as"][[32 15 2] "conspicuously to label him for all time to come? To be short, then, a"][[32 15 3] "whale is A SPOUTING FISH WITH A HORIZONTAL TAIL. There you have"][[32 15 4] "him. However contracted, that definition is the result of expanded"][[32 15 5] "meditation. A walrus spouts much like a whale, but the walrus is not a"][[32 15 6] "fish, because he is amphibious. But the last term of the definition is"][[32 15 7] "still more cogent, as coupled with the first. Almost any one must have"][[32 15 8] "noticed that all the fish familiar to landsmen have not a flat, but a"][[32 15 9] "vertical, or up-and-down tail. Whereas, among spouting fish the tail,"][[32 15 10] "though it may be similarly shaped, invariably assumes a horizontal"][[32 15 11] "position."][[32 16 1] "By the above definition of what a whale is, I do by no means exclude"][[32 16 2] "from the leviathanic brotherhood any sea creature hitherto identified"][[32 16 3] "with the whale by the best informed Nantucketers; nor, on the other"][[32 16 4] "hand, link with it any fish hitherto authoritatively regarded as alien.*"][[32 16 5] "Hence, all the smaller, spouting, and horizontal tailed fish must be"][[32 16 6] "included in this ground-plan of Cetology. Now, then, come the grand"][[32 16 7] "divisions of the entire whale host."][[32 18 1] "*I am aware that down to the present time, the fish styled Lamatins and"][[32 18 2] "Dugongs (Pig-fish and Sow-fish of the Coffins of Nantucket) are included"][[32 18 3] "by many naturalists among the whales. But as these pig-fish are a noisy,"][[32 18 4] "contemptible set, mostly lurking in the mouths of rivers, and feeding on"][[32 18 5] "wet hay, and especially as they do not spout, I deny their credentials"][[32 18 6] "as whales; and have presented them with their passports to quit the"][[32 18 7] "Kingdom of Cetology."][[32 20 1] "First: According to magnitude I divide the whales into three primary"][[32 20 2] "BOOKS (subdivisible into CHAPTERS), and these shall comprehend them all,"][[32 20 3] "both small and large."][[32 21 1] "I. THE FOLIO WHALE; II. the OCTAVO WHALE; III. the DUODECIMO WHALE."][[32 22 1] "As the type of the FOLIO I present the SPERM WHALE; of the OCTAVO, the"][[32 22 2] "GRAMPUS; of the DUODECIMO, the PORPOISE."][[32 23 1] "FOLIOS. Among these I here include the following chapters:--I. The SPERM"][[32 23 2] "WHALE; II. the RIGHT WHALE; III. the FIN-BACK WHALE; IV. the HUMP-BACKED"][[32 23 3] "WHALE; V. the RAZOR-BACK WHALE; VI. the SULPHUR-BOTTOM WHALE."][[32 24 1] "BOOK I. (FOLIO), CHAPTER I. (SPERM WHALE).--This whale, among the"][[32 24 2] "English of old vaguely known as the Trumpa whale, and the Physeter"][[32 24 3] "whale, and the Anvil Headed whale, is the present Cachalot of the"][[32 24 4] "French, and the Pottsfich of the Germans, and the Macrocephalus of the"][[32 24 5] "Long Words. He is, without doubt, the largest inhabitant of the globe;"][[32 24 6] "the most formidable of all whales to encounter; the most majestic in"][[32 24 7] "aspect; and lastly, by far the most valuable in commerce; he being"][[32 24 8] "the only creature from which that valuable substance, spermaceti, is"][[32 24 9] "obtained. All his peculiarities will, in many other places, be enlarged"][[32 24 10] "upon. It is chiefly with his name that I now have to do. Philologically"][[32 24 11] "considered, it is absurd. Some centuries ago, when the Sperm whale was"][[32 24 12] "almost wholly unknown in his own proper individuality, and when his oil"][[32 24 13] "was only accidentally obtained from the stranded fish; in those days"][[32 24 14] "spermaceti, it would seem, was popularly supposed to be derived from a"][[32 24 15] "creature identical with the one then known in England as the Greenland"][[32 24 16] "or Right Whale. It was the idea also, that this same spermaceti was that"][[32 24 17] "quickening humor of the Greenland Whale which the first syllable of"][[32 24 18] "the word literally expresses. In those times, also, spermaceti was"][[32 24 19] "exceedingly scarce, not being used for light, but only as an ointment"][[32 24 20] "and medicament. It was only to be had from the druggists as you nowadays"][[32 24 21] "buy an ounce of rhubarb. When, as I opine, in the course of time, the"][[32 24 22] "true nature of spermaceti became known, its original name was still"][[32 24 23] "retained by the dealers; no doubt to enhance its value by a notion so"][[32 24 24] "strangely significant of its scarcity. And so the appellation must at"][[32 24 25] "last have come to be bestowed upon the whale from which this spermaceti"][[32 24 26] "was really derived."][[32 25 1] "BOOK I. (FOLIO), CHAPTER II. (RIGHT WHALE).--In one respect this is the"][[32 25 2] "most venerable of the leviathans, being the one first regularly hunted"][[32 25 3] "by man. It yields the article commonly known as whalebone or baleen; and"][[32 25 4] "the oil specially known as \"whale oil,\" an inferior article in commerce."][[32 25 5] "Among the fishermen, he is indiscriminately designated by all the"][[32 25 6] "following titles: The Whale; the Greenland Whale; the Black Whale;"][[32 25 7] "the Great Whale; the True Whale; the Right Whale. There is a deal of"][[32 25 8] "obscurity concerning the identity of the species thus multitudinously"][[32 25 9] "baptised. What then is the whale, which I include in the second species"][[32 25 10] "of my Folios? It is the Great Mysticetus of the English naturalists; the"][[32 25 11] "Greenland Whale of the English whalemen; the Baliene Ordinaire of the"][[32 25 12] "French whalemen; the Growlands Walfish of the Swedes. It is the whale"][[32 25 13] "which for more than two centuries past has been hunted by the Dutch and"][[32 25 14] "English in the Arctic seas; it is the whale which the American fishermen"][[32 25 15] "have long pursued in the Indian ocean, on the Brazil Banks, on the Nor'"][[32 25 16] "West Coast, and various other parts of the world, designated by them"][[32 25 17] "Right Whale Cruising Grounds."][[32 26 1] "Some pretend to see a difference between the Greenland whale of the"][[32 26 2] "English and the right whale of the Americans. But they precisely agree"][[32 26 3] "in all their grand features; nor has there yet been presented a single"][[32 26 4] "determinate fact upon which to ground a radical distinction. It is by"][[32 26 5] "endless subdivisions based upon the most inconclusive differences, that"][[32 26 6] "some departments of natural history become so repellingly intricate. The"][[32 26 7] "right whale will be elsewhere treated of at some length, with reference"][[32 26 8] "to elucidating the sperm whale."][[32 27 1] "BOOK I. (FOLIO), CHAPTER III. (FIN-BACK).--Under this head I reckon"][[32 27 2] "a monster which, by the various names of Fin-Back, Tall-Spout, and"][[32 27 3] "Long-John, has been seen almost in every sea and is commonly the whale"][[32 27 4] "whose distant jet is so often descried by passengers crossing the"][[32 27 5] "Atlantic, in the New York packet-tracks. In the length he attains, and"][[32 27 6] "in his baleen, the Fin-back resembles the right whale, but is of a less"][[32 27 7] "portly girth, and a lighter colour, approaching to olive.
