His great lips"][[32 27 8] "present a cable-like aspect, formed by the intertwisting, slanting folds"][[32 27 9] "of large wrinkles. His grand distinguishing feature, the fin, from which"][[32 27 10] "he derives his name, is often a conspicuous object. This fin is some"][[32 27 11] "three or four feet long, growing vertically from the hinder part of the"][[32 27 12] "back, of an angular shape, and with a very sharp pointed end. Even if"][[32 27 13] "not the slightest other part of the creature be visible, this isolated"][[32 27 14] "fin will, at times, be seen plainly projecting from the surface. When"][[32 27 15] "the sea is moderately calm, and slightly marked with spherical ripples,"][[32 27 16] "and this gnomon-like fin stands up and casts shadows upon the wrinkled"][[32 27 17] "surface, it may well be supposed that the watery circle surrounding it"][[32 27 18] "somewhat resembles a dial, with its style and wavy hour-lines graved on"][[32 27 19] "it. On that Ahaz-dial the shadow often goes back. The Fin-Back is not"][[32 27 20] "gregarious. He seems a whale-hater, as some men are man-haters. Very"][[32 27 21] "shy; always going solitary; unexpectedly rising to the surface in the"][[32 27 22] "remotest and most sullen waters; his straight and single lofty jet"][[32 27 23] "rising like a tall misanthropic spear upon a barren plain; gifted with"][[32 27 24] "such wondrous power and velocity in swimming, as to defy all present"][[32 27 25] "pursuit from man; this leviathan seems the banished and unconquerable"][[32 27 26] "Cain of his race, bearing for his mark that style upon his back. From"][[32 27 27] "having the baleen in his mouth, the Fin-Back is sometimes included with"][[32 27 28] "the right whale, among a theoretic species denominated WHALEBONE WHALES,"][[32 27 29] "that is, whales with baleen. Of these so called Whalebone whales, there"][[32 27 30] "would seem to be several varieties, most of which, however, are little"][[32 27 31] "known. Broad-nosed whales and beaked whales; pike-headed whales; bunched"][[32 27 32] "whales; under-jawed whales and rostrated whales, are the fishermen's"][[32 27 33] "names for a few sorts."][[32 28 1] "In connection with this appellative of \"Whalebone whales,\" it is of"][[32 28 2] "great importance to mention, that however such a nomenclature may be"][[32 28 3] "convenient in facilitating allusions to some kind of whales, yet it is"][[32 28 4] "in vain to attempt a clear classification of the Leviathan, founded upon"][[32 28 5] "either his baleen, or hump, or fin, or teeth; notwithstanding that those"][[32 28 6] "marked parts or features very obviously seem better adapted to afford"][[32 28 7] "the basis for a regular system of Cetology than any other detached"][[32 28 8] "bodily distinctions, which the whale, in his kinds, presents. How"][[32 28 9] "then? The baleen, hump, back-fin, and teeth; these are things whose"][[32 28 10] "peculiarities are indiscriminately dispersed among all sorts of whales,"][[32 28 11] "without any regard to what may be the nature of their structure in other"][[32 28 12] "and more essential particulars. Thus, the sperm whale and the humpbacked"][[32 28 13] "whale, each has a hump; but there the similitude ceases. Then, this same"][[32 28 14] "humpbacked whale and the Greenland whale, each of these has baleen;"][[32 28 15] "but there again the similitude ceases. And it is just the same with the"][[32 28 16] "other parts above mentioned. In various sorts of whales, they form such"][[32 28 17] "irregular combinations; or, in the case of any one of them detached,"][[32 28 18] "such an irregular isolation; as utterly to defy all general"][[32 28 19] "methodization formed upon such a basis. On this rock every one of the"][[32 28 20] "whale-naturalists has split."][[32 29 1] "But it may possibly be conceived that, in the internal parts of the"][[32 29 2] "whale, in his anatomy--there, at least, we shall be able to hit the"][[32 29 3] "right classification. Nay; what thing, for example, is there in the"][[32 29 4] "Greenland whale's anatomy more striking than his baleen? Yet we have"][[32 29 5] "seen that by his baleen it is impossible correctly to classify the"][[32 29 6] "Greenland whale. And if you descend into the bowels of the various"][[32 29 7] "leviathans, why there you will not find distinctions a fiftieth part as"][[32 29 8] "available to the systematizer as those external ones already enumerated."][[32 29 9] "What then remains? nothing but to take hold of the whales bodily, in"][[32 29 10] "their entire liberal volume, and boldly sort them that way. And this is"][[32 29 11] "the Bibliographical system here adopted; and it is the only one that can"][[32 29 12] "possibly succeed, for it alone is practicable. To proceed."][[32 30 1] "BOOK I. (FOLIO) CHAPTER IV. (HUMP-BACK).--This whale is often seen on"][[32 30 2] "the northern American coast. He has been frequently captured there, and"][[32 30 3] "towed into harbor. He has a great pack on him like a peddler; or you"][[32 30 4] "might call him the Elephant and Castle whale. At any rate, the popular"][[32 30 5] "name for him does not sufficiently distinguish him, since the sperm"][[32 30 6] "whale also has a hump though a smaller one. His oil is not very"][[32 30 7] "valuable. He has baleen. He is the most gamesome and light-hearted of"][[32 30 8] "all the whales, making more gay foam and white water generally than any"][[32 30 9] "other of them."][[32 31 1] "BOOK I. (FOLIO), CHAPTER V. (RAZOR-BACK).--Of this whale little is known"][[32 31 2] "but his name. I have seen him at a distance off Cape Horn. Of a retiring"][[32 31 3] "nature, he eludes both hunters and philosophers. Though no coward, he"][[32 31 4] "has never yet shown any part of him but his back, which rises in a long"][[32 31 5] "sharp ridge. Let him go. I know little more of him, nor does anybody"][[32 31 6] "else."][[32 32 1] "BOOK I. (FOLIO), CHAPTER VI. (SULPHUR-BOTTOM).--Another retiring"][[32 32 2] "gentleman, with a brimstone belly, doubtless got by scraping along the"][[32 32 3] "Tartarian tiles in some of his profounder divings. He is seldom seen;"][[32 32 4] "at least I have never seen him except in the remoter southern seas,"][[32 32 5] "and then always at too great a distance to study his countenance. He is"][[32 32 6] "never chased; he would run away with rope-walks of line. Prodigies are"][[32 32 7] "told of him. Adieu, Sulphur Bottom! I can say nothing more that is true"][[32 32 8] "of ye, nor can the oldest Nantucketer."][[32 33 1] "Thus ends BOOK I. (FOLIO), and now begins BOOK II. (OCTAVO)."][[32 34 1] "OCTAVOES.*--These embrace the whales of middling magnitude, among which"][[32 34 2] "present may be numbered:--I., the GRAMPUS; II., the BLACK FISH; III.,"][[32 34 3] "the NARWHALE; IV., the THRASHER; V., the KILLER."][[32 36 1] "*Why this book of whales is not denominated the Quarto is very plain."][[32 36 2] "Because, while the whales of this order, though smaller than those of"][[32 36 3] "the former order, nevertheless retain a proportionate likeness to them"][[32 36 4] "in figure, yet the bookbinder's Quarto volume in its dimensioned form"][[32 36 5] "does not preserve the shape of the Folio volume, but the Octavo volume"][[32 36 6] "does."][[32 38 1] "BOOK II. (OCTAVO), CHAPTER I. (GRAMPUS).--Though this fish, whose"][[32 38 2] "loud sonorous breathing, or rather blowing, has furnished a proverb"][[32 38 3] "to landsmen, is so well known a denizen of the deep, yet is he not"][[32 38 4] "popularly classed among whales. But possessing all the grand distinctive"][[32 38 5] "features of the leviathan, most naturalists have recognised him for one."][[32 38 6] "He is of moderate octavo size, varying from fifteen to twenty-five feet"][[32 38 7] "in length, and of corresponding dimensions round the waist. He swims in"][[32 38 8] "herds; he is never regularly hunted, though his oil is considerable in"][[32 38 9] "quantity, and pretty good for light. By some fishermen his approach is"][[32 38 10] "regarded as premonitory of the advance of the great sperm whale."][[32 39 1] "BOOK II. (OCTAVO), CHAPTER II. (BLACK FISH).--I give the popular"][[32 39 2] "fishermen's names for all these fish, for generally they are the best."][[32 39 3] "Where any name happens to be vague or inexpressive, I shall say so,"][[32 39 4] "and suggest another. I do so now, touching the Black Fish, so-called,"][[32 39 5] "because blackness is the rule among almost all whales. So, call him the"][[32 39 6] "Hyena Whale, if you please. His voracity is well known, and from the"][[32 39 7] "circumstance that the inner angles of his lips are curved upwards, he"][[32 39 8] "carries an everlasting Mephistophelean grin on his face. This whale"][[32 39 9] "averages some sixteen or eighteen feet in length. He is found in almost"][[32 39 10] "all latitudes. He has a peculiar way of showing his dorsal hooked fin"][[32 39 11] "in swimming, which looks something like a Roman nose. When not more"][[32 39 12] "profitably employed, the sperm whale hunters sometimes capture the Hyena"][[32 39 13] "whale, to keep up the supply of cheap oil for domestic employment--as"][[32 39 14] "some frugal housekeepers, in the absence of company, and quite alone by"][[32 39 15] "themselves, burn unsavory tallow instead of odorous wax. Though their"][[32 39 16] "blubber is very thin, some of these whales will yield you upwards of"][[32 39 17] "thirty gallons of oil."][[32 40 1] "BOOK II. (OCTAVO), CHAPTER III. (NARWHALE), that is, NOSTRIL"][[32 40 2] "WHALE.--Another instance of a curiously named whale, so named I suppose"][[32 40 3] "from his peculiar horn being originally mistaken for a peaked nose. The"][[32 40 4] "creature is some sixteen feet in length, while its horn averages five"][[32 40 5] "feet, though some exceed ten, and even attain to fifteen feet. Strictly"][[32 40 6] "speaking, this horn is but a lengthened tusk, growing out from the jaw"][[32 40 7] "in a line a little depressed from the horizontal. But it is only"][[32 40 8] "found on the sinister side, which has an ill effect, giving its owner"][[32 40 9] "something analogous to the aspect of a clumsy left-handed man. What"][[32 40 10] "precise purpose this ivory horn or lance answers, it would be hard to"][[32 40 11] "say. It does not seem to be used like the blade of the sword-fish and"][[32 40 12] "bill-fish; though some sailors tell me that the Narwhale employs it for"][[32 40 13] "a rake in turning over the bottom of the sea for food. Charley Coffin"][[32 40 14] "said it was used for an ice-piercer; for the Narwhale, rising to the"][[32 40 15] "surface of the Polar Sea, and finding it sheeted with ice, thrusts his"][[32 40 16] "horn up, and so breaks through. But you cannot prove either of these"][[32 40 17] "surmises to be correct. My own opinion is, that however this one-sided"][[32 40 18] "horn may really be used by the Narwhale--however that may be--it would"][[32 40 19] "certainly be very convenient to him for a folder in reading pamphlets."][[32 40 20] "The Narwhale I have heard called the Tusked whale, the Horned whale, and"][[32 40 21] "the Unicorn whale. He is certainly a curious example of the Unicornism"][[32 40 22] "to be found in almost every kingdom of animated nature. From certain"][[32 40 23] "cloistered old authors I have gathered that this same sea-unicorn's horn"][[32 40 24] "was in ancient days regarded as the great antidote against poison,"][[32 40 25] "and as such, preparations of it brought immense prices. It was also"][[32 40 26] "distilled to a volatile salts for fainting ladies, the same way that the"][[32 40 27] "horns of the male deer are manufactured into hartshorn. Originally it"][[32 40 28] "was in itself accounted an object of great curiosity. Black Letter tells"][[32 40 29] "me that Sir Martin Frobisher on his return from that voyage, when"][[32 40 30] "Queen Bess did gallantly wave her jewelled hand to him from a window"][[32 40 31] "of Greenwich Palace, as his bold ship sailed down the Thames; \"when Sir"][[32 40 32] "Martin returned from that voyage,\" saith Black Letter, \"on bended knees"][[32 40 33] "he presented to her highness a prodigious long horn of the Narwhale,"][[32 40 34] "which for a long period after hung in the castle at Windsor.\" An Irish"][[32 40 35] "author avers that the Earl of Leicester, on bended knees, did likewise"][[32 40 36] "present to her highness another horn, pertaining to a land beast of the"][[32 40 37] "unicorn nature."][[32 41 1] "The Narwhale has a very picturesque, leopard-like look, being of a"][[32 41 2] "milk-white ground colour, dotted with round and oblong spots of black."][[32 41 3] "His oil is very superior, clear and fine; but there is little of it, and"][[32 41 4] "he is seldom hunted. He is mostly found in the circumpolar seas."][[32 42 1] "BOOK II. (OCTAVO), CHAPTER IV. (KILLER).--Of this whale little is"][[32 42 2] "precisely known to the Nantucketer, and nothing at all to the professed"][[32 42 3] "naturalist. From what I have seen of him at a distance, I should say"][[32 42 4] "that he was about the bigness of a grampus. He is very savage--a sort of"][[32 42 5] "Feegee fish. He sometimes takes the great Folio whales by the lip, and"][[32 42 6] "hangs there like a leech, till the mighty brute is worried to death. The"][[32 42 7] "Killer is never hunted. I never heard what sort of oil he has. Exception"][[32 42 8] "might be taken to the name bestowed upon this whale, on the ground"][[32 42 9] "of its indistinctness. For we are all killers, on land and on sea;"][[32 42 10] "Bonapartes and Sharks included."][[32 43 1] "BOOK II. (OCTAVO), CHAPTER V. (THRASHER).--This gentleman is famous for"][[32 43 2] "his tail, which he uses for a ferule in thrashing his foes. He mounts"][[32 43 3] "the Folio whale's back, and as he swims, he works his passage by"][[32 43 4] "flogging him; as some schoolmasters get along in the world by a similar"][[32 43 5] "process. Still less is known of the Thrasher than of the Killer. Both"][[32 43 6] "are outlaws, even in the lawless seas."][[32 44 1] "Thus ends BOOK II. (OCTAVO), and begins BOOK III. (DUODECIMO)."][[32 45 1] "DUODECIMOES.--These include the smaller whales. I. The Huzza Porpoise."][[32 45 2] "II. The Algerine Porpoise. III. The Mealy-mouthed Porpoise."][[32 46 1] "To those who have not chanced specially to study the subject, it may"][[32 46 2] "possibly seem strange, that fishes not commonly exceeding four or five"][[32 46 3] "feet should be marshalled among WHALES--a word, which, in the popular"][[32 46 4] "sense, always conveys an idea of hugeness. But the creatures set"][[32 46 5] "down above as Duodecimoes are infallibly whales, by the terms of my"][[32 46 6] "definition of what a whale is--i.e. a spouting fish, with a horizontal"][[32 46 7] "tail."][[32 47 1] "BOOK III. (DUODECIMO), CHAPTER . (HUZZA PORPOISE).--This is the"][[32 47 2] "common porpoise found almost all over the globe. The name is of my own"][[32 47 3] "bestowal; for there are more than one sort of porpoises, and something"][[32 47 4] "must be done to distinguish them. I call him thus, because he always"][[32 47 5] "swims in hilarious shoals, which upon the broad sea keep tossing"][[32 47 6] "themselves to heaven like caps in a Fourth-of-July crowd. Their"][[32 47 7] "appearance is generally hailed with delight by the mariner. Full of fine"][[32 47 8] "spirits, they invariably come from the breezy billows to windward. They"][[32 47 9] "are the lads that always live before the wind. They are accounted a"][[32 47 10] "lucky omen. If you yourself can withstand three cheers at beholding"][[32 47 11] "these vivacious fish, then heaven help ye; the spirit of godly"][[32 47 12] "gamesomeness is not in ye. A well-fed, plump Huzza Porpoise will"][[32 47 13] "yield you one good gallon of good oil. But the fine and delicate fluid"][[32 47 14] "extracted from his jaws is exceedingly valuable. It is in request among"][[32 47 15] "jewellers and watchmakers. Sailors put it on their hones. Porpoise"][[32 47 16] "meat is good eating, you know. It may never have occurred to you that"][[32 47 17] "a porpoise spouts. Indeed, his spout is so small that it is not very"][[32 47 18] "readily discernible. But the next time you have a chance, watch him; and"][[32 47 19] "you will then see the great Sperm whale himself in miniature."][[32 48 1] "BOOK III. (DUODECIMO), CHAPTER II. (ALGERINE PORPOISE).--A pirate. Very"][[32 48 2] "savage. He is only found, I think, in the Pacific. He is somewhat larger"][[32 48 3] "than the Huzza Porpoise, but much of the same general make. Provoke him,"][[32 48 4] "and he will buckle to a shark. I have lowered for him many times, but"][[32 48 5] "never yet saw him captured."][[32 49 1] "BOOK III. (DUODECIMO), CHAPTER III. (MEALY-MOUTHED PORPOISE).--The"][[32 49 2] "largest kind of Porpoise; and only found in the Pacific, so far as it is"][[32 49 3] "known. The only English name, by which he has hitherto been designated,"][[32 49 4] "is that of the fishers--Right-Whale Porpoise, from the circumstance that"][[32 49 5] "he is chiefly found in the vicinity of that Folio. In shape, he differs"][[32 49 6] "in some degree from the Huzza Porpoise, being of a less rotund and jolly"][[32 49 7] "girth; indeed, he is of quite a neat and gentleman-like figure. He has"][[32 49 8] "no fins on his back (most other porpoises have), he has a lovely tail,"][[32 49 9] "and sentimental Indian eyes of a hazel hue. But his mealy-mouth spoils"][[32 49 10] "all. Though his entire back down to his side fins is of a deep sable,"][[32 49 11] "yet a boundary line, distinct as the mark in a ship's hull, called"][[32 49 12] "the \"bright waist,\" that line streaks him from stem to stern, with two"][[32 49 13] "separate colours, black above and white below. The white comprises part"][[32 49 14] "of his head, and the whole of his mouth, which makes him look as if he"][[32 49 15] "had just escaped from a felonious visit to a meal-bag. A most mean and"][[32 49 16] "mealy aspect! His oil is much like that of the common porpoise."][[32 51 1] "Beyond the DUODECIMO, this system does not proceed, inasmuch as"][[32 51 2] "the Porpoise is the smallest of the whales. Above, you have all the"][[32 51 3] "Leviathans of note. But there are a rabble of uncertain, fugitive,"][[32 51 4] "half-fabulous whales, which, as an American whaleman, I know by"][[32 51 5] "reputation, but not personally. I shall enumerate them by their"][[32 51 6] "fore-castle appellations; for possibly such a list may be valuable to"][[32 51 7] "future investigators, who may complete what I have here but begun. If"][[32 51 8] "any of the following whales, shall hereafter be caught and marked, then"][[32 51 9] "he can readily be incorporated into this System, according to his Folio,"][[32 51 10] "Octavo, or Duodecimo magnitude:--The Bottle-Nose Whale; the Junk Whale;"][[32 51 11] "the Pudding-Headed Whale; the Cape Whale; the Leading Whale; the Cannon"][[32 51 12] "Whale; the Scragg Whale; the Coppered Whale; the Elephant Whale; the"][[32 51 13] "Iceberg Whale; the Quog Whale; the Blue Whale; etc. From Icelandic,"][[32 51 14] "Dutch, and old English authorities, there might be quoted other lists of"][[32 51 15] "uncertain whales, blessed with all manner of uncouth names. But I omit"][[32 51 16] "them as altogether obsolete; and can hardly help suspecting them for"][[32 51 17] "mere sounds, full of Leviathanism, but signifying nothing."][[32 52 1] "Finally: It was stated at the outset, that this system would not be"][[32 52 2] "here, and at once, perfected. You cannot but plainly see that I have"][[32 52 3] "kept my word. But I now leave my cetological System standing thus"][[32 52 4] "unfinished, even as the great Cathedral of Cologne was left, with the"][[32 52 5] "crane still standing upon the top of the uncompleted tower. For small"][[32 52 6] "erections may be finished by their first architects; grand ones, true"][[32 52 7] "ones, ever leave the copestone to posterity. God keep me from ever"][[32 52 8] "completing anything. This whole book is but a draught--nay, but the"][[32 52 9] "draught of a draught. Oh, Time, Strength, Cash, and Patience!"][[33 0 0] "CHAPTER 33. The Specksnyder."][[33 2 1] "Concerning the officers of the whale-craft, this seems as good a place"][[33 2 2] "as any to set down a little domestic peculiarity on ship-board, arising"][[33 2 3] "from the existence of the harpooneer class of officers, a class unknown"][[33 2 4] "of course in any other marine than the whale-fleet."][[33 3 1] "The large importance attached to the harpooneer's vocation is evinced"][[33 3 2] "by the fact, that originally in the old Dutch Fishery, two centuries"][[33 3 3] "and more ago, the command of a whale ship was not wholly lodged in"][[33 3 4] "the person now called the captain, but was divided between him and an"][[33 3 5] "officer called the Specksnyder. Literally this word means Fat-Cutter;"][[33 3 6] "usage, however, in time made it equivalent to Chief Harpooneer. In"][[33 3 7] "those days, the captain's authority was restricted to the navigation"][[33 3 8] "and general management of the vessel; while over the whale-hunting"][[33 3 9] "department and all its concerns, the Specksnyder or Chief Harpooneer"][[33 3 10] "reigned supreme. In the British Greenland Fishery, under the corrupted"][[33 3 11] "title of Specksioneer, this old Dutch official is still retained, but"][[33 3 12] "his former dignity is sadly abridged. At present he ranks simply"][[33 3 13] "as senior Harpooneer; and as such, is but one of the captain's more"][[33 3 14] "inferior subalterns. Nevertheless, as upon the good conduct of the"][[33 3 15] "harpooneers the success of a whaling voyage largely depends, and since"][[33 3 16] "in the American Fishery he is not only an important officer in the boat,"][[33 3 17] "but under certain circumstances (night watches on a whaling ground) the"][[33 3 18] "command of the ship's deck is also his; therefore the grand political"][[33 3 19] "maxim of the sea demands, that he should nominally live apart from"][[33 3 20] "the men before the mast, and be in some way distinguished as their"][[33 3 21] "professional superior; though always, by them, familiarly regarded as"][[33 3 22] "their social equal."][[33 4 1] "Now, the grand distinction drawn between officer and man at sea, is"][[33 4 2] "this--the first lives aft, the last forward. Hence, in whale-ships and"][[33 4 3] "merchantmen alike, the mates have their quarters with the captain; and"][[33 4 4] "so, too, in most of the American whalers the harpooneers are lodged in"][[33 4 5] "the after part of the ship. That is to say, they take their meals in the"][[33 4 6] "captain's cabin, and sleep in a place indirectly communicating with it."][[33 5 1] "Though the long period of a Southern whaling voyage (by far the longest"][[33 5 2] "of all voyages now or ever made by man), the peculiar perils of it, and"][[33 5 3] "the community of interest prevailing among a company, all of whom, high"][[33 5 4] "or low, depend for their profits, not upon fixed wages, but upon their"][[33 5 5] "common luck, together with their common vigilance, intrepidity, and"][[33 5 6] "hard work; though all these things do in some cases tend to beget a less"][[33 5 7] "rigorous discipline than in merchantmen generally; yet, never mind"][[33 5 8] "how much like an old Mesopotamian family these whalemen may, in some"][[33 5 9] "primitive instances, live together; for all that, the punctilious"][[33 5 10] "externals, at least, of the quarter-deck are seldom materially relaxed,"][[33 5 11] "and in no instance done away. Indeed, many are the Nantucket ships in"][[33 5 12] "which you will see the skipper parading his quarter-deck with an elated"][[33 5 13] "grandeur not surpassed in any military navy; nay, extorting almost"][[33 5 14] "as much outward homage as if he wore the imperial purple, and not the"][[33 5 15] "shabbiest of pilot-cloth."][[33 6 1] "And though of all men the moody captain of the Pequod was the least"][[33 6 2] "given to that sort of shallowest assumption; and though the only homage"][[33 6 3] "he ever exacted, was implicit, instantaneous obedience; though he"][[33 6 4] "required no man to remove the shoes from his feet ere stepping upon"][[33 6 5] "the quarter-deck; and though there were times when, owing to peculiar"][[33 6 6] "circumstances connected with events hereafter to be detailed, he"][[33 6 7] "addressed them in unusual terms, whether of condescension or IN"][[33 6 8] "TERROREM, or otherwise; yet even Captain Ahab was by no means"][[33 6 9] "unobservant of the paramount forms and usages of the sea."][[33 7 1] "Nor, perhaps, will it fail to be eventually perceived, that behind those"][[33 7 2] "forms and usages, as it were, he sometimes masked himself; incidentally"][[33 7 3] "making use of them for other and more private ends than they were"][[33 7 4] "legitimately intended to subserve. That certain sultanism of his brain,"][[33 7 5] "which had otherwise in a good degree remained unmanifested; through"][[33 7 6] "those forms that same sultanism became incarnate in an irresistible"][[33 7 7] "dictatorship. For be a man's intellectual superiority what it will,"][[33 7 8] "it can never assume the practical, available supremacy over other men,"][[33 7 9] "without the aid of some sort of external arts and entrenchments, always,"][[33 7 10] "in themselves, more or less paltry and base. This it is, that for ever"][[33 7 11] "keeps God's true princes of the Empire from the world's hustings; and"][[33 7 12] "leaves the highest honours that this air can give, to those men who"][[33 7 13] "become famous more through their infinite inferiority to the choice"][[33 7 14] "hidden handful of the Divine Inert, than through their undoubted"][[33 7 15] "superiority over the dead level of the mass. Such large virtue lurks"][[33 7 16] "in these small things when extreme political superstitions invest them,"][[33 7 17] "that in some royal instances even to idiot imbecility they have imparted"][[33 7 18] "potency. But when, as in the case of Nicholas the Czar, the ringed crown"][[33 7 19] "of geographical empire encircles an imperial brain; then, the plebeian"][[33 7 20] "herds crouch abased before the tremendous centralization. Nor, will the"][[33 7 21] "tragic dramatist who would depict mortal indomitableness in its fullest"][[33 7 22] "sweep and direct swing, ever forget a hint, incidentally so important in"][[33 7 23] "his art, as the one now alluded to."][[33 8 1] "But Ahab, my Captain, still moves before me in all his Nantucket"][[33 8 2] "grimness and shagginess; and in this episode touching Emperors and"][[33 8 3] "Kings, I must not conceal that I have only to do with a poor old"][[33 8 4] "whale-hunter like him; and, therefore, all outward majestical trappings"][[33 8 5] "and housings are denied me. Oh, Ahab! what shall be grand in thee, it"][[33 8 6] "must needs be plucked at from the skies, and dived for in the deep, and"][[33 8 7] "featured in the unbodied air!"][[34 0 0] "CHAPTER 34. The Cabin-Table."][[34 2 1] "It is noon; and Dough-Boy, the steward, thrusting his pale loaf-of-bread"][[34 2 2] "face from the cabin-scuttle, announces dinner to his lord and"][[34 2 3] "master; who, sitting in the lee quarter-boat, has just been taking an"][[34 2 4] "observation of the sun; and is now mutely reckoning the latitude on the"][[34 2 5] "smooth, medallion-shaped tablet, reserved for that daily purpose on"][[34 2 6] "the upper part of his ivory leg. From his complete inattention to the"][[34 2 7] "tidings, you would think that moody Ahab had not heard his menial. But"][[34 2 8] "presently, catching hold of the mizen shrouds, he swings himself to"][[34 2 9] "the deck, and in an even, unexhilarated voice, saying, \"Dinner, Mr."][[34 2 10] "Starbuck,\" disappears into the cabin."][[34 3 1] "When the last echo of his sultan's step has died away, and Starbuck, the"][[34 3 2] "first Emir, has every reason to suppose that he is seated, then Starbuck"][[34 3 3] "rouses from his quietude, takes a few turns along the planks, and, after"][[34 3 4] "a grave peep into the binnacle, says, with some touch of pleasantness,"][[34 3 5] "\"Dinner, Mr. Stubb,\" and descends the scuttle. The second Emir lounges"][[34 3 6] "about the rigging awhile, and then slightly shaking the main brace, to"][[34 3 7] "see whether it will be all right with that important rope, he likewise"][[34 3 8] "takes up the old burden, and with a rapid \"Dinner, Mr. Flask,\" follows"][[34 3 9] "after his predecessors."][[34 4 1] "But the third Emir, now seeing himself all alone on the quarter-deck,"][[34 4 2] "seems to feel relieved from some curious restraint; for, tipping all"][[34 4 3] "sorts of knowing winks in all sorts of directions, and kicking off his"][[34 4 4] "shoes, he strikes into a sharp but noiseless squall of a hornpipe right"][[34 4 5] "over the Grand Turk's head; and then, by a dexterous sleight, pitching"][[34 4 6] "his cap up into the mizentop for a shelf, he goes down rollicking so"][[34 4 7] "far at least as he remains visible from the deck, reversing all other"][[34 4 8] "processions, by bringing up the rear with music. But ere stepping into"][[34 4 9] "the cabin doorway below, he pauses, ships a new face altogether, and,"][[34 4 10] "then, independent, hilarious little Flask enters King Ahab's presence,"][[34 4 11] "in the character of Abjectus, or the Slave."][[34 5 1] "It is not the least among the strange things bred by the intense"][[34 5 2] "artificialness of sea-usages, that while in the open air of the deck"][[34 5 3] "some officers will, upon provocation, bear themselves boldly and"][[34 5 4] "defyingly enough towards their commander; yet, ten to one, let those"][[34 5 5] "very officers the next moment go down to their customary dinner in that"][[34 5 6] "same commander's cabin, and straightway their inoffensive, not to say"][[34 5 7] "deprecatory and humble air towards him, as he sits at the head of"][[34 5 8] "the table; this is marvellous, sometimes most comical. Wherefore this"][[34 5 9] "difference? A problem? Perhaps not. To have been Belshazzar, King of"][[34 5 10] "Babylon; and to have been Belshazzar, not haughtily but courteously,"][[34 5 11] "therein certainly must have been some touch of mundane grandeur. But he"][[34 5 12] "who in the rightly regal and intelligent spirit presides over his own"][[34 5 13] "private dinner-table of invited guests, that man's unchallenged power"][[34 5 14] "and dominion of individual influence for the time; that man's royalty of"][[34 5 15] "state transcends Belshazzar's, for Belshazzar was not the greatest. Who"][[34 5 16] "has but once dined his friends, has tasted what it is to be Caesar. It"][[34 5 17] "is a witchery of social czarship which there is no withstanding. Now,"][[34 5 18] "if to this consideration you superadd the official supremacy of a"][[34 5 19] "ship-master, then, by inference, you will derive the cause of that"][[34 5 20] "peculiarity of sea-life just mentioned."][[34 6 1] "Over his ivory-inlaid table, Ahab presided like a mute, maned"][[34 6 2] "sea-lion on the white coral beach, surrounded by his warlike but still"][[34 6 3] "deferential cubs. In his own proper turn, each officer waited to be"][[34 6 4] "served. They were as little children before Ahab; and yet, in Ahab,"][[34 6 5] "there seemed not to lurk the smallest social arrogance. With one mind,"][[34 6 6] "their intent eyes all fastened upon the old man's knife, as he carved"][[34 6 7] "the chief dish before him. I do not suppose that for the world they"][[34 6 8] "would have profaned that moment with the slightest observation, even"][[34 6 9] "upon so neutral a topic as the weather. No! And when reaching out his"][[34 6 10] "knife and fork, between which the slice of beef was locked, Ahab thereby"][[34 6 11] "motioned Starbuck's plate towards him, the mate received his meat as"][[34 6 12] "though receiving alms; and cut it tenderly; and a little started"][[34 6 13] "if, perchance, the knife grazed against the plate; and chewed it"][[34 6 14] "noiselessly; and swallowed it, not without circumspection. For, like"][[34 6 15] "the Coronation banquet at Frankfort, where the German Emperor profoundly"][[34 6 16] "dines with the seven Imperial Electors, so these cabin meals were"][[34 6 17] "somehow solemn meals, eaten in awful silence; and yet at table old Ahab"][[34 6 18] "forbade not conversation; only he himself was dumb. What a relief it was"][[34 6 19] "to choking Stubb, when a rat made a sudden racket in the hold below. And"][[34 6 20] "poor little Flask, he was the youngest son, and little boy of this weary"][[34 6 21] "family party. His were the shinbones of the saline beef; his would have"][[34 6 22] "been the drumsticks. For Flask to have presumed to help himself, this"][[34 6 23] "must have seemed to him tantamount to larceny in the first degree. Had"][[34 6 24] "he helped himself at that table, doubtless, never more would he have"][[34 6 25] "been able to hold his head up in this honest world; nevertheless,"][[34 6 26] "strange to say, Ahab never forbade him. And had Flask helped himself,"][[34 6 27] "the chances were Ahab had never so much as noticed it. Least of all, did"][[34 6 28] "Flask presume to help himself to butter. Whether he thought the owners"][[34 6 29] "of the ship denied it to him, on account of its clotting his clear,"][[34 6 30] "sunny complexion; or whether he deemed that, on so long a voyage in such"][[34 6 31] "marketless waters, butter was at a premium, and therefore was not for"][[34 6 32] "him, a subaltern; however it was, Flask, alas! was a butterless man!"][[34 7 1] "Another thing. Flask was the last person down at the dinner, and Flask"][[34 7 2] "is the first man up. Consider! For hereby Flask's dinner was badly"][[34 7 3] "jammed in point of time. Starbuck and Stubb both had the start of him;"][[34 7 4] "and yet they also have the privilege of lounging in the rear. If Stubb"][[34 7 5] "even, who is but a peg higher than Flask, happens to have but a small"][[34 7 6] "appetite, and soon shows symptoms of concluding his repast, then Flask"][[34 7 7] "must bestir himself, he will not get more than three mouthfuls that day;"][[34 7 8] "for it is against holy usage for Stubb to precede Flask to the deck."][[34 7 9] "Therefore it was that Flask once admitted in private, that ever since he"][[34 7 10] "had arisen to the dignity of an officer, from that moment he had never"][[34 7 11] "known what it was to be otherwise than hungry, more or less. For what"][[34 7 12] "he ate did not so much relieve his hunger, as keep it immortal in him."][[34 7 13] "Peace and satisfaction, thought Flask, have for ever departed from"][[34 7 14] "my stomach. I am an officer; but, how I wish I could fish a bit of"][[34 7 15] "old-fashioned beef in the forecastle, as I used to when I was before the"][[34 7 16] "mast. There's the fruits of promotion now; there's the vanity of glory:"][[34 7 17] "there's the insanity of life! Besides, if it were so that any mere"][[34 7 18] "sailor of the Pequod had a grudge against Flask in Flask's official"][[34 7 19] "capacity, all that sailor had to do, in order to obtain ample vengeance,"][[34 7 20] "was to go aft at dinner-time, and get a peep at Flask through the cabin"][[34 7 21] "sky-light, sitting silly and dumfoundered before awful Ahab."][[34 8 1] "Now, Ahab and his three mates formed what may be called the first table"][[34 8 2] "in the Pequod's cabin. After their departure, taking place in inverted"][[34 8 3] "order to their arrival, the canvas cloth was cleared, or rather was"][[34 8 4] "restored to some hurried order by the pallid steward. And then the three"][[34 8 5] "harpooneers were bidden to the feast, they being its residuary legatees."][[34 8 6] "They made a sort of temporary servants' hall of the high and mighty"][[34 8 7] "cabin."][[34 9 1] "In strange contrast to the hardly tolerable constraint and nameless"][[34 9 2] "invisible domineerings of the captain's table, was the entire care-free"][[34 9 3] "license and ease, the almost frantic democracy of those inferior fellows"][[34 9 4] "the harpooneers. While their masters, the mates, seemed afraid of the"][[34 9 5] "sound of the hinges of their own jaws, the harpooneers chewed their food"][[34 9 6] "with such a relish that there was a report to it. They dined like lords;"][[34 9 7] "they filled their bellies like Indian ships all day loading with spices."][[34 9 8] "Such portentous appetites had Queequeg and Tashtego, that to fill out"][[34 9 9] "the vacancies made by the previous repast, often the pale Dough-Boy was"][[34 9 10] "fain to bring on a great baron of salt-junk, seemingly quarried out of"][[34 9 11] "the solid ox. And if he were not lively about it, if he did not go with"][[34 9 12] "a nimble hop-skip-and-jump, then Tashtego had an ungentlemanly way of"][[34 9 13] "accelerating him by darting a fork at his back, harpoon-wise. And once"][[34 9 14] "Daggoo, seized with a sudden humor, assisted Dough-Boy's memory by"][[34 9 15] "snatching him up bodily, and thrusting his head into a great empty"][[34 9 16] "wooden trencher, while Tashtego, knife in hand, began laying out the"][[34 9 17] "circle preliminary to scalping him. He was naturally a very nervous,"][[34 9 18] "shuddering sort of little fellow, this bread-faced steward; the progeny"][[34 9 19] "of a bankrupt baker and a hospital nurse. And what with the standing"][[34 9 20] "spectacle of the black terrific Ahab, and the periodical tumultuous"][[34 9 21] "visitations of these three savages, Dough-Boy's whole life was one"][[34 9 22] "continual lip-quiver. Commonly, after seeing the harpooneers furnished"][[34 9 23] "with all things they demanded, he would escape from their clutches into"][[34 9 24] "his little pantry adjoining, and fearfully peep out at them through the"][[34 9 25] "blinds of its door, till all was over."][[34 10 1] "It was a sight to see Queequeg seated over against Tashtego, opposing"][[34 10 2] "his filed teeth to the Indian's: crosswise to them, Daggoo seated on the"][[34 10 3] "floor, for a bench would have brought his hearse-plumed head to the low"][[34 10 4] "carlines; at every motion of his colossal limbs, making the low cabin"][[34 10 5] "framework to shake, as when an African elephant goes passenger in a"][[34 10 6] "ship. But for all this, the great negro was wonderfully abstemious,"][[34 10 7] "not to say dainty. It seemed hardly possible that by such comparatively"][[34 10 8] "small mouthfuls he could keep up the vitality diffused through so broad,"][[34 10 9] "baronial, and superb a person. But, doubtless, this noble savage fed"][[34 10 10] "strong and drank deep of the abounding element of air; and through his"][[34 10 11] "dilated nostrils snuffed in the sublime life of the worlds. Not by"][[34 10 12] "beef or by bread, are giants made or nourished. But Queequeg, he had a"][[34 10 13] "mortal, barbaric smack of the lip in eating--an ugly sound enough--so"][[34 10 14] "much so, that the trembling Dough-Boy almost looked to see whether"][[34 10 15] "any marks of teeth lurked in his own lean arms. And when he would hear"][[34 10 16] "Tashtego singing out for him to produce himself, that his bones might be"][[34 10 17] "picked, the simple-witted steward all but shattered the crockery hanging"][[34 10 18] "round him in the pantry, by his sudden fits of the palsy. Nor did the"][[34 10 19] "whetstone which the harpooneers carried in their pockets, for their"][[34 10 20] "lances and other weapons; and with which whetstones, at dinner, they"][[34 10 21] "would ostentatiously sharpen their knives; that grating sound did not at"][[34 10 22] "all tend to tranquillize poor Dough-Boy. How could he forget that in his"][[34 10 23] "Island days, Queequeg, for one, must certainly have been guilty of some"][[34 10 24] "murderous, convivial indiscretions. Alas! Dough-Boy! hard fares the"][[34 10 25] "white waiter who waits upon cannibals. Not a napkin should he carry on"][[34 10 26] "his arm, but a buckler. In good time, though, to his great delight,"][[34 10 27] "the three salt-sea warriors would rise and depart; to his credulous,"][[34 10 28] "fable-mongering ears, all their martial bones jingling in them at every"][[34 10 29] "step, like Moorish scimetars in scabbards."][[34 11 1] "But, though these barbarians dined in the cabin, and nominally lived"][[34 11 2] "there; still, being anything but sedentary in their habits, they were"][[34 11 3] "scarcely ever in it except at mealtimes, and just before sleeping-time,"][[34 11 4] "when they passed through it to their own peculiar quarters."][[34 12 1] "In this one matter, Ahab seemed no exception to most American whale"][[34 12 2] "captains, who, as a set, rather incline to the opinion that by rights"][[34 12 3] "the ship's cabin belongs to them; and that it is by courtesy alone that"][[34 12 4] "anybody else is, at any time, permitted there. So that, in real truth,"][[34 12 5] "the mates and harpooneers of the Pequod might more properly be said to"][[34 12 6] "have lived out of the cabin than in it. For when they did enter it, it"][[34 12 7] "was something as a street-door enters a house; turning inwards for"][[34 12 8] "a moment, only to be turned out the next; and, as a permanent thing,"][[34 12 9] "residing in the open air. Nor did they lose much hereby; in the cabin"][[34 12 10] "was no companionship; socially, Ahab was inaccessible. Though nominally"][[34 12 11] "included in the census of Christendom, he was still an alien to it. He"][[34 12 12] "lived in the world, as the last of the Grisly Bears lived in settled"][[34 12 13] "Missouri. And as when Spring and Summer had departed, that wild Logan of"][[34 12 14] "the woods, burying himself in the hollow of a tree, lived out the winter"][[34 12 15] "there, sucking his own paws; so, in his inclement, howling old age,"][[34 12 16] "Ahab's soul, shut up in the caved trunk of his body, there fed upon the"][[34 12 17] "sullen paws of its gloom!"][[35 0 0] "CHAPTER 35. The Mast-Head."][[35 2 1] "It was during the more pleasant weather, that in due rotation with the"][[35 2 2] "other seamen my first mast-head came round."][[35 3 1] "In most American whalemen the mast-heads are manned almost"][[35 3 2] "simultaneously with the vessel's leaving her port; even though she may"][[35 3 3] "have fifteen thousand miles, and more, to sail ere reaching her proper"][[35 3 4] "cruising ground. And if, after a three, four, or five years' voyage"][[35 3 5] "she is drawing nigh home with anything empty in her--say, an empty vial"][[35 3 6] "even--then, her mast-heads are kept manned to the last; and not till her"][[35 3 7] "skysail-poles sail in among the spires of the port, does she altogether"][[35 3 8] "relinquish the hope of capturing one whale more."][[35 4 1] "Now, as the business of standing mast-heads, ashore or afloat, is a very"][[35 4 2] "ancient and interesting one, let us in some measure expatiate here."][[35 4 3] "I take it, that the earliest standers of mast-heads were the old"][[35 4 4] "Egyptians; because, in all my researches, I find none prior to them."][[35 4 5] "For though their progenitors, the builders of Babel, must doubtless, by"][[35 4 6] "their tower, have intended to rear the loftiest mast-head in all Asia,"][[35 4 7] "or Africa either; yet (ere the final truck was put to it) as that great"][[35 4 8] "stone mast of theirs may be said to have gone by the board, in the dread"][[35 4 9] "gale of God's wrath; therefore, we cannot give these Babel builders"][[35 4 10] "priority over the Egyptians. And that the Egyptians were a nation of"][[35 4 11] "mast-head standers, is an assertion based upon the general belief among"][[35 4 12] "archaeologists, that the first pyramids were founded for astronomical"][[35 4 13] "purposes: a theory singularly supported by the peculiar stair-like"][[35 4 14] "formation of all four sides of those edifices; whereby, with prodigious"][[35 4 15] "long upliftings of their legs, those old astronomers were wont to mount"][[35 4 16] "to the apex, and sing out for new stars; even as the look-outs of a"][[35 4 17] "modern ship sing out for a sail, or a whale just bearing in sight. In"][[35 4 18] "Saint Stylites, the famous Christian hermit of old times, who built him"][[35 4 19] "a lofty stone pillar in the desert and spent the whole latter portion of"][[35 4 20] "his life on its summit, hoisting his food from the ground with a"][[35 4 21] "tackle; in him we have a remarkable instance of a dauntless"][[35 4 22] "stander-of-mast-heads; who was not to be driven from his place by fogs"][[35 4 23] "or frosts, rain, hail, or sleet; but valiantly facing everything out to"][[35 4 24] "the last, literally died at his post. Of modern standers-of-mast-heads"][[35 4 25] "we have but a lifeless set; mere stone, iron, and bronze men; who,"][[35 4 26] "though well capable of facing out a stiff gale, are still entirely"][[35 4 27] "incompetent to the business of singing out upon discovering any strange"][[35 4 28] "sight. There is Napoleon; who, upon the top of the column of Vendome,"][[35 4 29] "stands with arms folded, some one hundred and fifty feet in the air;"][[35 4 30] "careless, now, who rules the decks below; whether Louis Philippe, Louis"][[35 4 31] "Blanc, or Louis the Devil. Great Washington, too, stands high aloft on"][[35 4 32] "his towering main-mast in Baltimore, and like one of Hercules' pillars,"][[35 4 33] "his column marks that point of human grandeur beyond which few mortals"][[35 4 34] "will go. Admiral Nelson, also, on a capstan of gun-metal, stands his"][[35 4 35] "mast-head in Trafalgar Square; and ever when most obscured by that"][[35 4 36] "London smoke, token is yet given that a hidden hero is there; for"][[35 4 37] "where there is smoke, must be fire. But neither great Washington, nor"][[35 4 38] "Napoleon, nor Nelson, will answer a single hail from below, however"][[35 4 39] "madly invoked to befriend by their counsels the distracted decks"][[35 4 40] "upon which they gaze; however it may be surmised, that their spirits"][[35 4 41] "penetrate through the thick haze of the future, and descry what shoals"][[35 4 42] "and what rocks must be shunned."][[35 5 1] "It may seem unwarrantable to couple in any respect the mast-head"][[35 5 2] "standers of the land with those of the sea; but that in truth it is"][[35 5 3] "not so, is plainly evinced by an item for which Obed Macy, the sole"][[35 5 4] "historian of Nantucket, stands accountable. The worthy Obed tells us,"][[35 5 5] "that in the early times of the whale fishery, ere ships were regularly"][[35 5 6] "launched in pursuit of the game, the people of that island erected lofty"][[35 5 7] "spars along the sea-coast, to which the look-outs ascended by means"][[35 5 8] "of nailed cleats, something as fowls go upstairs in a hen-house. A few"][[35 5 9] "years ago this same plan was adopted by the Bay whalemen of New Zealand,"][[35 5 10] "who, upon descrying the game, gave notice to the ready-manned boats nigh"][[35 5 11] "the beach. But this custom has now become obsolete; turn we then to the"][[35 5 12] "one proper mast-head, that of a whale-ship at sea. The three mast-heads"][[35 5 13] "are kept manned from sun-rise to sun-set; the seamen taking their"][[35 5 14] "regular turns (as at the helm), and relieving each other every two"][[35 5 15] "hours. In the serene weather of the tropics it is exceedingly pleasant"][[35 5 16] "the mast-head; nay, to a dreamy meditative man it is delightful. There"][[35 5 17] "you stand, a hundred feet above the silent decks, striding along the"][[35 5 18] "deep, as if the masts were gigantic stilts, while beneath you and"][[35 5 19] "between your legs, as it were, swim the hugest monsters of the sea, even"][[35 5 20] "as ships once sailed between the boots of the famous Colossus at old"][[35 5 21] "Rhodes. There you stand, lost in the infinite series of the sea, with"][[35 5 22] "nothing ruffled but the waves. The tranced ship indolently rolls; the"][[35 5 23] "drowsy trade winds blow; everything resolves you into languor. For the"][[35 5 24] "most part, in this tropic whaling life, a sublime uneventfulness invests"][[35 5 25] "you; you hear no news; read no gazettes; extras with startling accounts"][[35 5 26] "of commonplaces never delude you into unnecessary excitements; you hear"][[35 5 27] "of no domestic afflictions; bankrupt securities; fall of stocks; are"][[35 5 28] "never troubled with the thought of what you shall have for dinner--for"][[35 5 29] "all your meals for three years and more are snugly stowed in casks, and"][[35 5 30] "your bill of fare is immutable."][[35 6 1] "In one of those southern whalesmen, on a long three or four years'"][[35 6 2] "voyage, as often happens, the sum of the various hours you spend at the"][[35 6 3] "mast-head would amount to several entire months. And it is much to be"][[35 6 4] "deplored that the place to which you devote so considerable a portion"][[35 6 5] "of the whole term of your natural life, should be so sadly destitute"][[35 6 6] "of anything approaching to a cosy inhabitiveness, or adapted to breed a"][[35 6 7] "comfortable localness of feeling, such as pertains to a bed, a hammock,"][[35 6 8] "a hearse, a sentry box, a pulpit, a coach, or any other of those small"][[35 6 9] "and snug contrivances in which men temporarily isolate themselves. Your"][[35 6 10] "most usual point of perch is the head of the t' gallant-mast, where you"][[35 6 11] "stand upon two thin parallel sticks (almost peculiar to whalemen) called"][[35 6 12] "the t' gallant cross-trees. Here, tossed about by the sea, the beginner"][[35 6 13] "feels about as cosy as he would standing on a bull's horns. To be sure,"][[35 6 14] "in cold weather you may carry your house aloft with you, in the shape of"][[35 6 15] "a watch-coat; but properly speaking the thickest watch-coat is no more"][[35 6 16] "of a house than the unclad body; for as the soul is glued inside of its"][[35 6 17] "fleshy tabernacle, and cannot freely move about in it, nor even move out"][[35 6 18] "of it, without running great risk of perishing (like an ignorant pilgrim"][[35 6 19] "crossing the snowy Alps in winter); so a watch-coat is not so much of"][[35 6 20] "a house as it is a mere envelope, or additional skin encasing you. You"][[35 6 21] "cannot put a shelf or chest of drawers in your body, and no more can you"][[35 6 22] "make a convenient closet of your watch-coat."][[35 7 1] "Concerning all this, it is much to be deplored that the mast-heads of a"][[35 7 2] "southern whale ship are unprovided with those enviable little tents"][[35 7 3] "or pulpits, called CROW'S-NESTS, in which the look-outs of a Greenland"][[35 7 4] "whaler are protected from the inclement weather of the frozen seas. In"][[35 7 5] "the fireside narrative of Captain Sleet, entitled \"A Voyage among the"][[35 7 6] "Icebergs, in quest of the Greenland Whale, and incidentally for the"][[35 7 7] "re-discovery of the Lost Icelandic Colonies of Old Greenland;\" in"][[35 7 8] "this admirable volume, all standers of mast-heads are furnished with"][[35 7 9] "a charmingly circumstantial account of the then recently invented"][[35 7 10] "CROW'S-NEST of the Glacier, which was the name of Captain Sleet's good"][[35 7 11] "craft. He called it the SLEET'S CROW'S-NEST, in honour of himself; he"][[35 7 12] "being the original inventor and patentee, and free from all ridiculous"][[35 7 13] "false delicacy, and holding that if we call our own children after our"][[35 7 14] "own names (we fathers being the original inventors and patentees), so"][[35 7 15] "likewise should we denominate after ourselves any other apparatus we"][[35 7 16] "may beget. In shape, the Sleet's crow's-nest is something like a large"][[35 7 17] "tierce or pipe; it is open above, however, where it is furnished with"][[35 7 18] "a movable side-screen to keep to windward of your head in a hard gale."][[35 7 19] "Being fixed on the summit of the mast, you ascend into it through a"][[35 7 20] "little trap-hatch in the bottom. On the after side, or side next the"][[35 7 21] "stern of the ship, is a comfortable seat, with a locker underneath for"][[35 7 22] "umbrellas, comforters, and coats. In front is a leather rack, in which"][[35 7 23] "to keep your speaking trumpet, pipe, telescope, and other nautical"][[35 7 24] "conveniences. When Captain Sleet in person stood his mast-head in this"][[35 7 25] "crow's-nest of his, he tells us that he always had a rifle with him"][[35 7 26] "(also fixed in the rack), together with a powder flask and shot, for"][[35 7 27] "the purpose of popping off the stray narwhales, or vagrant sea unicorns"][[35 7 28] "infesting those waters; for you cannot successfully shoot at them from"][[35 7 29] "the deck owing to the resistance of the water, but to shoot down upon"][[35 7 30] "them is a very different thing. Now, it was plainly a labor of love"][[35 7 31] "for Captain Sleet to describe, as he does, all the little detailed"][[35 7 32] "conveniences of his crow's-nest; but though he so enlarges upon many"][[35 7 33] "of these, and though he treats us to a very scientific account of his"][[35 7 34] "experiments in this crow's-nest, with a small compass he kept there for"][[35 7 35] "the purpose of counteracting the errors resulting from what is called"][[35 7 36] "the \"local attraction\" of all binnacle magnets; an error ascribable to"][[35 7 37] "the horizontal vicinity of the iron in the ship's planks, and in the"][[35 7 38] "Glacier's case, perhaps, to there having been so many broken-down"][[35 7 39] "blacksmiths among her crew; I say, that though the Captain is very"][[35 7 40] "discreet and scientific here, yet, for all his learned \"binnacle"][[35 7 41] "deviations,\" \"azimuth compass observations,\" and \"approximate errors,\""][[35 7 42] "he knows very well, Captain Sleet, that he was not so much immersed"][[35 7 43] "in those profound magnetic meditations, as to fail being attracted"][[35 7 44] "occasionally towards that well replenished little case-bottle, so nicely"][[35 7 45] "tucked in on one side of his crow's nest, within easy reach of his hand."][[35 7 46] "Though, upon the whole, I greatly admire and even love the brave, the"][[35 7 47] "honest, and learned Captain; yet I take it very ill of him that he"][[35 7 48] "should so utterly ignore that case-bottle, seeing what a faithful friend"][[35 7 49] "and comforter it must have been, while with mittened fingers and hooded"][[35 7 50] "head he was studying the mathematics aloft there in that bird's nest"][[35 7 51] "within three or four perches of the pole."][[35 8 1] "But if we Southern whale-fishers are not so snugly housed aloft as"][[35 8 2] "Captain Sleet and his Greenlandmen were; yet that disadvantage is"][[35 8 3] "greatly counter-balanced by the widely contrasting serenity of those"][[35 8 4] "seductive seas in which we South fishers mostly float. For one, I used"][[35 8 5] "to lounge up the rigging very leisurely, resting in the top to have a"][[35 8 6] "chat with Queequeg, or any one else off duty whom I might find there;"][[35 8 7] "then ascending a little way further, and throwing a lazy leg over the"][[35 8 8] "top-sail yard, take a preliminary view of the watery pastures, and so at"][[35 8 9] "last mount to my ultimate destination."][[35 9 1] "Let me make a clean breast of it here, and frankly admit that I kept but"][[35 9 2] "sorry guard. With the problem of the universe revolving in me, how"][[35 9 3] "could I--being left completely to myself at such a thought-engendering"][[35 9 4] "altitude--how could I but lightly hold my obligations to observe all"][[35 9 5] "whale-ships' standing orders, \"Keep your weather eye open, and sing out"][[35 9 6] "every time.\""][[35 10 1] "And let me in this place movingly admonish you, ye ship-owners of"][[35 10 2] "Nantucket! Beware of enlisting in your vigilant fisheries any lad with"][[35 10 3] "lean brow and hollow eye; given to unseasonable meditativeness; and who"][[35 10 4] "offers to ship with the Phaedon instead of Bowditch in his head. Beware"][[35 10 5] "of such an one, I say; your whales must be seen before they can be"][[35 10 6] "killed; and this sunken-eyed young Platonist will tow you ten wakes"][[35 10 7] "round the world, and never make you one pint of sperm the richer. Nor"][[35 10 8] "are these monitions at all unneeded. For nowadays, the whale-fishery"][[35 10 9] "furnishes an asylum for many romantic, melancholy, and absent-minded"][[35 10 10] "young men, disgusted with the carking cares of earth, and seeking"][[35 10 11] "sentiment in tar and blubber. Childe Harold not unfrequently perches"][[35 10 12] "himself upon the mast-head of some luckless disappointed whale-ship, and"][[35 10 13] "in moody phrase ejaculates:--"][[35 11 1] "\"Roll on, thou deep and dark blue ocean, roll! Ten thousand"][[35 11 2] "blubber-hunters sweep over thee in vain.\""][[35 12 1] "Very often do the captains of such ships take those absent-minded"][[35 12 2] "young philosophers to task, upbraiding them with not feeling sufficient"][[35 12 3] "\"interest\" in the voyage; half-hinting that they are so hopelessly lost"][[35 12 4] "to all honourable ambition, as that in their secret souls they would"][[35 12 5] "rather not see whales than otherwise. But all in vain; those young"][[35 12 6] "Platonists have a notion that their vision is imperfect; they are"][[35 12 7] "short-sighted; what use, then, to strain the visual nerve? They have"][[35 12 8] "left their opera-glasses at home."][[35 13 1] "\"Why, thou monkey,\" said a harpooneer to one of these lads, \"we've been"][[35 13 2] "cruising now hard upon three years, and thou hast not raised a whale"][[35 13 3] "yet. Whales are scarce as hen's teeth whenever thou art up here.\""][[35 13 4] "Perhaps they were; or perhaps there might have been shoals of them in"][[35 13 5] "the far horizon; but lulled into such an opium-like listlessness of"][[35 13 6] "vacant, unconscious reverie is this absent-minded youth by the blending"][[35 13 7] "cadence of waves with thoughts, that at last he loses his identity;"][[35 13 8] "takes the mystic ocean at his feet for the visible image of that deep,"][[35 13 9] "blue, bottomless soul, pervading mankind and nature; and every"][[35 13 10] "strange, half-seen, gliding, beautiful thing that eludes him; every"][[35 13 11] "dimly-discovered, uprising fin of some undiscernible form, seems to him"][[35 13 12] "the embodiment of those elusive thoughts that only people the soul by"][[35 13 13] "continually flitting through it. In this enchanted mood, thy spirit ebbs"][[35 13 14] "away to whence it came; becomes diffused through time and space; like"][[35 13 15] "Crammer's sprinkled Pantheistic ashes, forming at last a part of every"][[35 13 16] "shore the round globe over."][[35 14 1] "There is no life in thee, now, except that rocking life imparted by a"][[35 14 2] "gently rolling ship; by her, borrowed from the sea; by the sea, from"][[35 14 3] "the inscrutable tides of God. But while this sleep, this dream is on ye,"][[35 14 4] "move your foot or hand an inch; slip your hold at all; and your identity"][[35 14 5] "comes back in horror. Over Descartian vortices you hover. And perhaps,"][[35 14 6] "at mid-day, in the fairest weather, with one half-throttled shriek you"][[35 14 7] "drop through that transparent air into the summer sea, no more to rise"][[35 14 8] "for ever. Heed it well, ye Pantheists!"][[36 0 0] "CHAPTER 36. The Quarter-Deck."][[36 2 1] "(ENTER AHAB: THEN, ALL)"][[36 4 1] "It was not a great while after the affair of the pipe, that one"][[36 4 2] "morning shortly after breakfast, Ahab, as was his wont, ascended the"][[36 4 3] "cabin-gangway to the deck. There most sea-captains usually walk at that"][[36 4 4] "hour, as country gentlemen, after the same meal, take a few turns in the"][[36 4 5] "garden."][[36 5 1] "Soon his steady, ivory stride was heard, as to and fro he paced his old"][[36 5 2] "rounds, upon planks so familiar to his tread, that they were all over"][[36 5 3] "dented, like geological stones, with the peculiar mark of his walk. Did"][[36 5 4] "you fixedly gaze, too, upon that ribbed and dented brow; there also,"][[36 5 5] "you would see still stranger foot-prints--the foot-prints of his one"][[36 5 6] "unsleeping, ever-pacing thought."][[36 6 1] "But on the occasion in question, those dents looked deeper, even as"][[36 6 2] "his nervous step that morning left a deeper mark. And, so full of his"][[36 6 3] "thought was Ahab, that at every uniform turn that he made, now at the"][[36 6 4] "main-mast and now at the binnacle, you could almost see that thought"][[36 6 5] "turn in him as he turned, and pace in him as he paced; so completely"][[36 6 6] "possessing him, indeed, that it all but seemed the inward mould of every"][[36 6 7] "outer movement."][[36 7 1] "\"D'ye mark him, Flask?\" whispered Stubb; \"the chick that's in him pecks"][[36 7 2] "the shell. 'Twill soon be out.\""][[36 8 1] "The hours wore on;--Ahab now shut up within his cabin; anon, pacing the"][[36 8 2] "deck, with the same intense bigotry of purpose in his aspect."][[36 9 1] "It drew near the close of day. Suddenly he came to a halt by the"][[36 9 2] "bulwarks, and inserting his bone leg into the auger-hole there, and with"][[36 9 3] "one hand grasping a shroud, he ordered Starbuck to send everybody aft."][[36 10 1] "\"Sir!\" said the mate, astonished at an order seldom or never given on"][[36 10 2] "ship-board except in some extraordinary case."][[36 11 1] "\"Send everybody aft,\" repeated Ahab. \"Mast-heads, there! come down!\""][[36 12 1] "When the entire ship's company were assembled, and with curious and not"][[36 12 2] "wholly unapprehensive faces, were eyeing him, for he looked not unlike"][[36 12 3] "the weather horizon when a storm is coming up, Ahab, after rapidly"][[36 12 4] "glancing over the bulwarks, and then darting his eyes among the crew,"][[36 12 5] "started from his standpoint; and as though not a soul were nigh him"][[36 12 6] "resumed his heavy turns upon the deck. With bent head and half-slouched"][[36 12 7] "hat he continued to pace, unmindful of the wondering whispering among"][[36 12 8] "the men; till Stubb cautiously whispered to Flask, that Ahab must have"][[36 12 9] "summoned them there for the purpose of witnessing a pedestrian feat. But"][[36 12 10] "this did not last long. Vehemently pausing, he cried:--"][[36 13 1] "\"What do ye do when ye see a whale, men?\""][[36 14 1] "\"Sing out for him!\" was the impulsive rejoinder from a score of clubbed"][[36 14 2] "voices."][[36 15 1] "\"Good!\" cried Ahab, with a wild approval in his tones; observing the"][[36 15 2] "hearty animation into which his unexpected question had so magnetically"][[36 15 3] "thrown them."][[36 16 1] "\"And what do ye next, men?\""][[36 17 1] "\"Lower away, and after him!\""][[36 18 1] "\"And what tune is it ye pull to, men?\""][[36 19 1] "\"A dead whale or a stove boat!\""][[36 20 1] "More and more strangely and fiercely glad and approving, grew the"][[36 20 2] "countenance of the old man at every shout; while the mariners began"][[36 20 3] "to gaze curiously at each other, as if marvelling how it was that they"][[36 20 4] "themselves became so excited at such seemingly purposeless questions."][[36 21 1] "But, they were all eagerness again, as Ahab, now half-revolving in his"][[36 21 2] "pivot-hole, with one hand reaching high up a shroud, and tightly, almost"][[36 21 3] "convulsively grasping it, addressed them thus:--"][[36 22 1] "\"All ye mast-headers have before now heard me give orders about a white"][[36 22 2] "whale. Look ye! d'ye see this Spanish ounce of gold?\"--holding up a"][[36 22 3] "broad bright coin to the sun--\"it is a sixteen dollar piece, men. D'ye"][[36 22 4] "see it? Mr. Starbuck, hand me yon top-maul.\""][[36 23 1] "While the mate was getting the hammer, Ahab, without speaking, was"][[36 23 2] "slowly rubbing the gold piece against the skirts of his jacket, as if"][[36 23 3] "to heighten its lustre, and without using any words was meanwhile"][[36 23 4] "lowly humming to himself, producing a sound so strangely muffled and"][[36 23 5] "inarticulate that it seemed the mechanical humming of the wheels of his"][[36 23 6] "vitality in him."][[36 24 1] "Receiving the top-maul from Starbuck, he advanced towards the main-mast"][[36 24 2] "with the hammer uplifted in one hand, exhibiting the gold with the"][[36 24 3] "other, and with a high raised voice exclaiming: \"Whosoever of ye"][[36 24 4] "raises me a white-headed whale with a wrinkled brow and a crooked jaw;"][[36 24 5] "whosoever of ye raises me that white-headed whale, with three holes"][[36 24 6] "punctured in his starboard fluke--look ye, whosoever of ye raises me"][[36 24 7] "that same white whale, he shall have this gold ounce, my boys!\""][[36 25 1] "\"Huzza! huzza!\" cried the seamen, as with swinging tarpaulins they"][[36 25 2] "hailed the act of nailing the gold to the mast."][[36 26 1] "\"It's a white whale, I say,\" resumed Ahab, as he threw down the topmaul:"][[36 26 2] "\"a white whale. Sunset."][[37 2 1] "THE CABIN; BY THE STERN WINDOWS; AHAB SITTING ALONE, AND GAZING OUT."][[37 4 1] "I leave a white and turbid wake; pale waters, paler cheeks, where'er I"][[37 4 2] "sail. The envious billows sidelong swell to whelm my track; let them;"][[37 4 3] "but first I pass."][[37 5 1] "Yonder, by ever-brimming goblet's rim, the warm waves blush like wine."][[37 5 2] "The gold brow plumbs the blue. The diver sun--slow dived from noon--goes"][[37 5 3] "down; my soul mounts up! she wearies with her endless hill. Is, then,"][[37 5 4] "the crown too heavy that I wear? this Iron Crown of Lombardy. Yet is"][[37 5 5] "it bright with many a gem; I the wearer, see not its far flashings; but"][[37 5 6] "darkly feel that I wear that, that dazzlingly confounds. 'Tis iron--that"][[37 5 7] "I know--not gold. 'Tis split, too--that I feel; the jagged edge galls"][[37 5 8] "me so, my brain seems to beat against the solid metal; aye, steel skull,"][[37 5 9] "mine; the sort that needs no helmet in the most brain-battering fight!"][[37 6 1] "Dry heat upon my brow? Oh! time was, when as the sunrise nobly spurred"][[37 6 2] "me, so the sunset soothed. No more. This lovely light, it lights not me;"][[37 6 3] "all loveliness is anguish to me, since I can ne'er enjoy. Gifted with"][[37 6 4] "the high perception, I lack the low, enjoying power; damned, most subtly"][[37 6 5] "and most malignantly! damned in the midst of Paradise! Good night--good"][[37 6 6] "night! (WAVING HIS HAND, HE MOVES FROM THE WINDOW.)"][[37 7 1] "'Twas not so hard a task. I thought to find one stubborn, at the least;"][[37 7 2] "but my one cogged circle fits into all their various wheels, and they"][[37 7 3] "revolve.
