Moby Dick."][[41 2 1] "I, Ishmael, was one of that crew; my shouts had gone up with the rest;"][[41 2 2] "my oath had been welded with theirs; and stronger I shouted, and more"][[41 2 3] "did I hammer and clinch my oath, because of the dread in my soul. A"][[41 2 4] "wild, mystical, sympathetical feeling was in me; Ahab's quenchless feud"][[41 2 5] "seemed mine. With greedy ears I learned the history of that murderous"][[41 2 6] "monster against whom I and all the others had taken our oaths of"][[41 2 7] "violence and revenge."][[41 3 1] "For some time past, though at intervals only, the unaccompanied,"][[41 3 2] "secluded White Whale had haunted those uncivilized seas mostly"][[41 3 3] "frequented by the Sperm Whale fishermen. But not all of them knew of his"][[41 3 4] "existence; only a few of them, comparatively, had knowingly seen him;"][[41 3 5] "while the number who as yet had actually and knowingly given battle to"][[41 3 6] "him, was small indeed. For, owing to the large number of whale-cruisers;"][[41 3 7] "the disorderly way they were sprinkled over the entire watery"][[41 3 8] "circumference, many of them adventurously pushing their quest along"][[41 3 9] "solitary latitudes, so as seldom or never for a whole twelvemonth or"][[41 3 10] "more on a stretch, to encounter a single news-telling sail of any sort;"][[41 3 11] "the inordinate length of each separate voyage; the irregularity of the"][[41 3 12] "times of sailing from home; all these, with other circumstances, direct"][[41 3 13] "and indirect, long obstructed the spread through the whole world-wide"][[41 3 14] "whaling-fleet of the special individualizing tidings concerning Moby"][[41 3 15] "Dick. It was hardly to be doubted, that several vessels reported to have"][[41 3 16] "encountered, at such or such a time, or on such or such a meridian,"][[41 3 17] "a Sperm Whale of uncommon magnitude and malignity, which whale, after"][[41 3 18] "doing great mischief to his assailants, had completely escaped them; to"][[41 3 19] "some minds it was not an unfair presumption, I say, that the whale in"][[41 3 20] "question must have been no other than Moby Dick. Yet as of late the"][[41 3 21] "Sperm Whale fishery had been marked by various and not unfrequent"][[41 3 22] "instances of great ferocity, cunning, and malice in the monster"][[41 3 23] "attacked; therefore it was, that those who by accident ignorantly gave"][[41 3 24] "battle to Moby Dick; such hunters, perhaps, for the most part, were"][[41 3 25] "content to ascribe the peculiar terror he bred, more, as it were, to"][[41 3 26] "the perils of the Sperm Whale fishery at large, than to the individual"][[41 3 27] "cause. In that way, mostly, the disastrous encounter between Ahab and"][[41 3 28] "the whale had hitherto been popularly regarded."][[41 4 1] "And as for those who, previously hearing of the White Whale, by chance"][[41 4 2] "caught sight of him; in the beginning of the thing they had every one of"][[41 4 3] "them, almost, as boldly and fearlessly lowered for him, as for any other"][[41 4 4] "whale of that species. But at length, such calamities did ensue in these"][[41 4 5] "assaults--not restricted to sprained wrists and ankles, broken limbs, or"][[41 4 6] "devouring amputations--but fatal to the last degree of fatality; those"][[41 4 7] "repeated disastrous repulses, all accumulating and piling their terrors"][[41 4 8] "upon Moby Dick; those things had gone far to shake the fortitude of many"][[41 4 9] "brave hunters, to whom the story of the White Whale had eventually come."][[41 5 1] "Nor did wild rumors of all sorts fail to exaggerate, and still the more"][[41 5 2] "horrify the true histories of these deadly encounters. For not only do"][[41 5 3] "fabulous rumors naturally grow out of the very body of all surprising"][[41 5 4] "terrible events,--as the smitten tree gives birth to its fungi; but, in"][[41 5 5] "maritime life, far more than in that of terra firma, wild rumors abound,"][[41 5 6] "wherever there is any adequate reality for them to cling to. And as the"][[41 5 7] "sea surpasses the land in this matter, so the whale fishery surpasses"][[41 5 8] "every other sort of maritime life, in the wonderfulness and fearfulness"][[41 5 9] "of the rumors which sometimes circulate there. For not only are whalemen"][[41 5 10] "as a body unexempt from that ignorance and superstitiousness hereditary"][[41 5 11] "to all sailors; but of all sailors, they are by all odds the most"][[41 5 12] "directly brought into contact with whatever is appallingly astonishing"][[41 5 13] "in the sea; face to face they not only eye its greatest marvels, but,"][[41 5 14] "hand to jaw, give battle to them. Alone, in such remotest waters, that"][[41 5 15] "though you sailed a thousand miles, and passed a thousand shores, you"][[41 5 16] "would not come to any chiseled hearth-stone, or aught hospitable beneath"][[41 5 17] "that part of the sun; in such latitudes and longitudes, pursuing too"][[41 5 18] "such a calling as he does, the whaleman is wrapped by influences all"][[41 5 19] "tending to make his fancy pregnant with many a mighty birth."][[41 6 1] "No wonder, then, that ever gathering volume from the mere transit over"][[41 6 2] "the widest watery spaces, the outblown rumors of the White Whale did"][[41 6 3] "in the end incorporate with themselves all manner of morbid hints,"][[41 6 4] "and half-formed foetal suggestions of supernatural agencies, which"][[41 6 5] "eventually invested Moby Dick with new terrors unborrowed from anything"][[41 6 6] "that visibly appears. So that in many cases such a panic did he finally"][[41 6 7] "strike, that few who by those rumors, at least, had heard of the White"][[41 6 8] "Whale, few of those hunters were willing to encounter the perils of his"][[41 6 9] "jaw."][[41 7 1] "But there were still other and more vital practical influences at work."][[41 7 2] "Not even at the present day has the original prestige of the Sperm"][[41 7 3] "Whale, as fearfully distinguished from all other species of the"][[41 7 4] "leviathan, died out of the minds of the whalemen as a body. There are"][[41 7 5] "those this day among them, who, though intelligent and courageous"][[41 7 6] "enough in offering battle to the Greenland or Right whale, would"][[41 7 7] "perhaps--either from professional inexperience, or incompetency, or"][[41 7 8] "timidity, decline a contest with the Sperm Whale; at any rate, there are"][[41 7 9] "plenty of whalemen, especially among those whaling nations not sailing"][[41 7 10] "under the American flag, who have never hostilely encountered the Sperm"][[41 7 11] "Whale, but whose sole knowledge of the leviathan is restricted to"][[41 7 12] "the ignoble monster primitively pursued in the North; seated on their"][[41 7 13] "hatches, these men will hearken with a childish fireside interest"][[41 7 14] "and awe, to the wild, strange tales of Southern whaling. Nor is the"][[41 7 15] "pre-eminent tremendousness of the great Sperm Whale anywhere more"][[41 7 16] "feelingly comprehended, than on board of those prows which stem him."][[41 8 1] "And as if the now tested reality of his might had in former"][[41 8 2] "legendary times thrown its shadow before it; we find some book"][[41 8 3] "naturalists--Olassen and Povelson--declaring the Sperm Whale not only to"][[41 8 4] "be a consternation to every other creature in the sea, but also to be so"][[41 8 5] "incredibly ferocious as continually to be athirst for human blood. Nor"][[41 8 6] "even down to so late a time as Cuvier's, were these or almost similar"][[41 8 7] "impressions effaced. For in his Natural History, the Baron himself"][[41 8 8] "affirms that at sight of the Sperm Whale, all fish (sharks included) are"][[41 8 9] "\"struck with the most lively terrors,\" and \"often in the precipitancy of"][[41 8 10] "their flight dash themselves against the rocks with such violence as to"][[41 8 11] "cause instantaneous death.\" And however the general experiences in the"][[41 8 12] "fishery may amend such reports as these; yet in their full terribleness,"][[41 8 13] "even to the bloodthirsty item of Povelson, the superstitious belief in"][[41 8 14] "them is, in some vicissitudes of their vocation, revived in the minds of"][[41 8 15] "the hunters."][[41 9 1] "So that overawed by the rumors and portents concerning him, not a few of"][[41 9 2] "the fishermen recalled, in reference to Moby Dick, the earlier days"][[41 9 3] "of the Sperm Whale fishery, when it was oftentimes hard to induce long"][[41 9 4] "practised Right whalemen to embark in the perils of this new and daring"][[41 9 5] "warfare; such men protesting that although other leviathans might be"][[41 9 6] "hopefully pursued, yet to chase and point lance at such an apparition"][[41 9 7] "as the Sperm Whale was not for mortal man. That to attempt it, would"][[41 9 8] "be inevitably to be torn into a quick eternity. On this head, there are"][[41 9 9] "some remarkable documents that may be consulted."][[41 10 1] "Nevertheless, some there were, who even in the face of these things"][[41 10 2] "were ready to give chase to Moby Dick; and a still greater number who,"][[41 10 3] "chancing only to hear of him distantly and vaguely, without the"][[41 10 4] "specific details of any certain calamity, and without superstitious"][[41 10 5] "accompaniments, were sufficiently hardy not to flee from the battle if"][[41 10 6] "offered."][[41 11 1] "One of the wild suggestions referred to, as at last coming to be linked"][[41 11 2] "with the White Whale in the minds of the superstitiously inclined,"][[41 11 3] "was the unearthly conceit that Moby Dick was ubiquitous; that he had"][[41 11 4] "actually been encountered in opposite latitudes at one and the same"][[41 11 5] "instant of time."][[41 12 1] "Nor, credulous as such minds must have been, was this conceit altogether"][[41 12 2] "without some faint show of superstitious probability. For as the secrets"][[41 12 3] "of the currents in the seas have never yet been divulged, even to"][[41 12 4] "the most erudite research; so the hidden ways of the Sperm Whale"][[41 12 5] "when beneath the surface remain, in great part, unaccountable to his"][[41 12 6] "pursuers; and from time to time have originated the most curious and"][[41 12 7] "contradictory speculations regarding them, especially concerning the"][[41 12 8] "mystic modes whereby, after sounding to a great depth, he transports"][[41 12 9] "himself with such vast swiftness to the most widely distant points."][[41 13 1] "It is a thing well known to both American and English whale-ships, and"][[41 13 2] "as well a thing placed upon authoritative record years ago by Scoresby,"][[41 13 3] "that some whales have been captured far north in the Pacific, in whose"][[41 13 4] "bodies have been found the barbs of harpoons darted in the Greenland"][[41 13 5] "seas. Nor is it to be gainsaid, that in some of these instances it has"][[41 13 6] "been declared that the interval of time between the two assaults could"][[41 13 7] "not have exceeded very many days. Hence, by inference, it has been"][[41 13 8] "believed by some whalemen, that the Nor' West Passage, so long a problem"][[41 13 9] "to man, was never a problem to the whale. So that here, in the real"][[41 13 10] "living experience of living men, the prodigies related in old times of"][[41 13 11] "the inland Strello mountain in Portugal (near whose top there was said"][[41 13 12] "to be a lake in which the wrecks of ships floated up to the surface);"][[41 13 13] "and that still more wonderful story of the Arethusa fountain near"][[41 13 14] "Syracuse (whose waters were believed to have come from the Holy Land"][[41 13 15] "by an underground passage); these fabulous narrations are almost fully"][[41 13 16] "equalled by the realities of the whalemen."][[41 14 1] "Forced into familiarity, then, with such prodigies as these; and knowing"][[41 14 2] "that after repeated, intrepid assaults, the White Whale had escaped"][[41 14 3] "alive; it cannot be much matter of surprise that some whalemen should"][[41 14 4] "go still further in their superstitions; declaring Moby Dick not only"][[41 14 5] "ubiquitous, but immortal (for immortality is but ubiquity in time); that"][[41 14 6] "though groves of spears should be planted in his flanks, he would still"][[41 14 7] "swim away unharmed; or if indeed he should ever be made to spout thick"][[41 14 8] "blood, such a sight would be but a ghastly deception; for again in"][[41 14 9] "unensanguined billows hundreds of leagues away, his unsullied jet would"][[41 14 10] "once more be seen."][[41 15 1] "But even stripped of these supernatural surmisings, there was enough in"][[41 15 2] "the earthly make and incontestable character of the monster to strike"][[41 15 3] "the imagination with unwonted power. For, it was not so much his"][[41 15 4] "uncommon bulk that so much distinguished him from other sperm whales,"][[41 15 5] "but, as was elsewhere thrown out--a peculiar snow-white wrinkled"][[41 15 6] "forehead, and a high, pyramidical white hump. These were his prominent"][[41 15 7] "features; the tokens whereby, even in the limitless, uncharted seas, he"][[41 15 8] "revealed his identity, at a long distance, to those who knew him."][[41 16 1] "The rest of his body was so streaked, and spotted, and marbled with"][[41 16 2] "the same shrouded hue, that, in the end, he had gained his distinctive"][[41 16 3] "appellation of the White Whale; a name, indeed, literally justified by"][[41 16 4] "his vivid aspect, when seen gliding at high noon through a dark blue"][[41 16 5] "sea, leaving a milky-way wake of creamy foam, all spangled with golden"][[41 16 6] "gleamings."][[41 17 1] "Nor was it his unwonted magnitude, nor his remarkable hue, nor yet his"][[41 17 2] "deformed lower jaw, that so much invested the whale with natural terror,"][[41 17 3] "as that unexampled, intelligent malignity which, according to specific"][[41 17 4] "accounts, he had over and over again evinced in his assaults. More than"][[41 17 5] "all, his treacherous retreats struck more of dismay than perhaps aught"][[41 17 6] "else. For, when swimming before his exulting pursuers, with every"][[41 17 7] "apparent symptom of alarm, he had several times been known to turn"][[41 17 8] "round suddenly, and, bearing down upon them, either stave their boats to"][[41 17 9] "splinters, or drive them back in consternation to their ship."][[41 18 1] "Already several fatalities had attended his chase. But though similar"][[41 18 2] "disasters, however little bruited ashore, were by no means unusual"][[41 18 3] "in the fishery; yet, in most instances, such seemed the White Whale's"][[41 18 4] "infernal aforethought of ferocity, that every dismembering or death"][[41 18 5] "that he caused, was not wholly regarded as having been inflicted by an"][[41 18 6] "unintelligent agent."][[41 19 1] "Judge, then, to what pitches of inflamed, distracted fury the minds of"][[41 19 2] "his more desperate hunters were impelled, when amid the chips of chewed"][[41 19 3] "boats, and the sinking limbs of torn comrades, they swam out of the"][[41 19 4] "white curds of the whale's direful wrath into the serene, exasperating"][[41 19 5] "sunlight, that smiled on, as if at a birth or a bridal."][[41 20 1] "His three boats stove around him, and oars and men both whirling in the"][[41 20 2] "eddies; one captain, seizing the line-knife from his broken prow, had"][[41 20 3] "dashed at the whale, as an Arkansas duellist at his foe, blindly seeking"][[41 20 4] "with a six inch blade to reach the fathom-deep life of the whale."][[41 20 5] "That captain was Ahab. And then it was, that suddenly sweeping his"][[41 20 6] "sickle-shaped lower jaw beneath him, Moby Dick had reaped away Ahab's"][[41 20 7] "leg, as a mower a blade of grass in the field. No turbaned Turk, no"][[41 20 8] "hired Venetian or Malay, could have smote him with more seeming malice."][[41 20 9] "Small reason was there to doubt, then, that ever since that almost fatal"][[41 20 10] "encounter, Ahab had cherished a wild vindictiveness against the whale,"][[41 20 11] "all the more fell for that in his frantic morbidness he at last came"][[41 20 12] "to identify with him, not only all his bodily woes, but all his"][[41 20 13] "intellectual and spiritual exasperations. The White Whale swam before"][[41 20 14] "him as the monomaniac incarnation of all those malicious agencies which"][[41 20 15] "some deep men feel eating in them, till they are left living on with"][[41 20 16] "half a heart and half a lung. That intangible malignity which has been"][[41 20 17] "from the beginning; to whose dominion even the modern Christians ascribe"][[41 20 18] "one-half of the worlds; which the ancient Ophites of the east reverenced"][[41 20 19] "in their statue devil;--Ahab did not fall down and worship it like them;"][[41 20 20] "but deliriously transferring its idea to the abhorred white whale, he"][[41 20 21] "pitted himself, all mutilated, against it. All that most maddens and"][[41 20 22] "torments; all that stirs up the lees of things; all truth with malice"][[41 20 23] "in it; all that cracks the sinews and cakes the brain; all the subtle"][[41 20 24] "demonisms of life and thought; all evil, to crazy Ahab, were visibly"][[41 20 25] "personified, and made practically assailable in Moby Dick. He piled upon"][[41 20 26] "the whale's white hump the sum of all the general rage and hate felt"][[41 20 27] "by his whole race from Adam down; and then, as if his chest had been a"][[41 20 28] "mortar, he burst his hot heart's shell upon it."][[41 21 1] "It is not probable that this monomania in him took its instant rise at"][[41 21 2] "the precise time of his bodily dismemberment. Then, in darting at the"][[41 21 3] "monster, knife in hand, he had but given loose to a sudden, passionate,"][[41 21 4] "corporal animosity; and when he received the stroke that tore him, he"][[41 21 5] "probably but felt the agonizing bodily laceration, but nothing more."][[41 21 6] "Yet, when by this collision forced to turn towards home, and for long"][[41 21 7] "months of days and weeks, Ahab and anguish lay stretched together in one"][[41 21 8] "hammock, rounding in mid winter that dreary, howling Patagonian Cape;"][[41 21 9] "then it was, that his torn body and gashed soul bled into one another;"][[41 21 10] "and so interfusing, made him mad. That it was only then, on the homeward"][[41 21 11] "voyage, after the encounter, that the final monomania seized him, seems"][[41 21 12] "all but certain from the fact that, at intervals during the passage,"][[41 21 13] "he was a raving lunatic; and, though unlimbed of a leg, yet such vital"][[41 21 14] "strength yet lurked in his Egyptian chest, and was moreover intensified"][[41 21 15] "by his delirium, that his mates were forced to lace him fast, even"][[41 21 16] "there, as he sailed, raving in his hammock. In a strait-jacket, he swung"][[41 21 17] "to the mad rockings of the gales. And, when running into more sufferable"][[41 21 18] "latitudes, the ship, with mild stun'sails spread, floated across the"][[41 21 19] "tranquil tropics, and, to all appearances, the old man's delirium seemed"][[41 21 20] "left behind him with the Cape Horn swells, and he came forth from his"][[41 21 21] "dark den into the blessed light and air; even then, when he bore that"][[41 21 22] "firm, collected front, however pale, and issued his calm orders once"][[41 21 23] "again; and his mates thanked God the direful madness was now gone; even"][[41 21 24] "then, Ahab, in his hidden self, raved on. Human madness is oftentimes a"][[41 21 25] "cunning and most feline thing. When you think it fled, it may have but"][[41 21 26] "become transfigured into some still subtler form. Ahab's full lunacy"][[41 21 27] "subsided not, but deepeningly contracted; like the unabated Hudson,"][[41 21 28] "when that noble Northman flows narrowly, but unfathomably through the"][[41 21 29] "Highland gorge. But, as in his narrow-flowing monomania, not one jot of"][[41 21 30] "Ahab's broad madness had been left behind; so in that broad madness, not"][[41 21 31] "one jot of his great natural intellect had perished. That before living"][[41 21 32] "agent, now became the living instrument. If such a furious trope may"][[41 21 33] "stand, his special lunacy stormed his general sanity, and carried it,"][[41 21 34] "and turned all its concentred cannon upon its own mad mark; so that far"][[41 21 35] "from having lost his strength, Ahab, to that one end, did now possess a"][[41 21 36] "thousand fold more potency than ever he had sanely brought to bear upon"][[41 21 37] "any one reasonable object."][[41 22 1] "This is much; yet Ahab's larger, darker, deeper part remains unhinted."][[41 22 2] "But vain to popularize profundities, and all truth is profound. Winding"][[41 22 3] "far down from within the very heart of this spiked Hotel de Cluny where"][[41 22 4] "we here stand--however grand and wonderful, now quit it;--and take your"][[41 22 5] "way, ye nobler, sadder souls, to those vast Roman halls of Thermes;"][[41 22 6] "where far beneath the fantastic towers of man's upper earth, his root"][[41 22 7] "of grandeur, his whole awful essence sits in bearded state; an antique"][[41 22 8] "buried beneath antiquities, and throned on torsoes! So with a broken"][[41 22 9] "throne, the great gods mock that captive king; so like a Caryatid, he"][[41 22 10] "patient sits, upholding on his frozen brow the piled entablatures of"][[41 22 11] "ages. Wind ye down there, ye prouder, sadder souls! question that proud,"][[41 22 12] "sad king! A family likeness! aye, he did beget ye, ye young exiled"][[41 22 13] "royalties; and from your grim sire only will the old State-secret come."][[41 23 1] "Now, in his heart, Ahab had some glimpse of this, namely: all my means"][[41 23 2] "are sane, my motive and my object mad. Yet without power to kill, or"][[41 23 3] "change, or shun the fact; he likewise knew that to mankind he did long"][[41 23 4] "dissemble; in some sort, did still. But that thing of his dissembling"][[41 23 5] "was only subject to his perceptibility, not to his will determinate."][[41 23 6] "Nevertheless, so well did he succeed in that dissembling, that when"][[41 23 7] "with ivory leg he stepped ashore at last, no Nantucketer thought him"][[41 23 8] "otherwise than but naturally grieved, and that to the quick, with the"][[41 23 9] "terrible casualty which had overtaken him."][[41 24 1] "The report of his undeniable delirium at sea was likewise popularly"][[41 24 2] "ascribed to a kindred cause. And so too, all the added moodiness which"][[41 24 3] "always afterwards, to the very day of sailing in the Pequod on the"][[41 24 4] "present voyage, sat brooding on his brow. Nor is it so very unlikely,"][[41 24 5] "that far from distrusting his fitness for another whaling voyage, on"][[41 24 6] "account of such dark symptoms, the calculating people of that prudent"][[41 24 7] "isle were inclined to harbor the conceit, that for those very reasons he"][[41 24 8] "was all the better qualified and set on edge, for a pursuit so full"][[41 24 9] "of rage and wildness as the bloody hunt of whales. Gnawed within and"][[41 24 10] "scorched without, with the infixed, unrelenting fangs of some incurable"][[41 24 11] "idea; such an one, could he be found, would seem the very man to dart"][[41 24 12] "his iron and lift his lance against the most appalling of all brutes."][[41 24 13] "Or, if for any reason thought to be corporeally incapacitated for that,"][[41 24 14] "yet such an one would seem superlatively competent to cheer and howl on"][[41 24 15] "his underlings to the attack. But be all this as it may, certain it is,"][[41 24 16] "that with the mad secret of his unabated rage bolted up and keyed in"][[41 24 17] "him, Ahab had purposely sailed upon the present voyage with the one only"][[41 24 18] "and all-engrossing object of hunting the White Whale. Had any one of his"][[41 24 19] "old acquaintances on shore but half dreamed of what was lurking in him"][[41 24 20] "then, how soon would their aghast and righteous souls have wrenched the"][[41 24 21] "ship from such a fiendish man! They were bent on profitable cruises, the"][[41 24 22] "profit to be counted down in dollars from the mint. He was intent on an"][[41 24 23] "audacious, immitigable, and supernatural revenge."][[41 25 1] "Here, then, was this grey-headed, ungodly old man, chasing with curses a"][[41 25 2] "Job's whale round the world, at the head of a crew, too, chiefly made"][[41 25 3] "up of mongrel renegades, and castaways, and cannibals--morally enfeebled"][[41 25 4] "also, by the incompetence of mere unaided virtue or right-mindedness in"][[41 25 5] "Starbuck, the invunerable jollity of indifference and recklessness in"][[41 25 6] "Stubb, and the pervading mediocrity in Flask. Such a crew, so officered,"][[41 25 7] "seemed specially picked and packed by some infernal fatality to help him"][[41 25 8] "to his monomaniac revenge. How it was that they so aboundingly responded"][[41 25 9] "to the old man's ire--by what evil magic their souls were possessed,"][[41 25 10] "that at times his hate seemed almost theirs; the White Whale as much"][[41 25 11] "their insufferable foe as his; how all this came to be--what the White"][[41 25 12] "Whale was to them, or how to their unconscious understandings, also, in"][[41 25 13] "some dim, unsuspected way, he might have seemed the gliding great demon"][[41 25 14] "of the seas of life,--all this to explain, would be to dive deeper than"][[41 25 15] "Ishmael can go. The subterranean miner that works in us all, how can one"][[41 25 16] "tell whither leads his shaft by the ever shifting, muffled sound of his"][[41 25 17] "pick? Who does not feel the irresistible arm drag? What skiff in tow"][[41 25 18] "of a seventy-four can stand still? For one, I gave myself up to the"][[41 25 19] "abandonment of the time and the place; but while yet all a-rush to"][[41 25 20] "encounter the whale, could see naught in that brute but the deadliest"][[41 25 21] "ill."][[42 0 0] "CHAPTER 42. The Whiteness of The Whale."][[42 2 1] "What the white whale was to Ahab, has been hinted; what, at times, he"][[42 2 2] "was to me, as yet remains unsaid."][[42 3 1] "Aside from those more obvious considerations touching Moby Dick, which"][[42 3 2] "could not but occasionally awaken in any man's soul some alarm, there"][[42 3 3] "was another thought, or rather vague, nameless horror concerning him,"][[42 3 4] "which at times by its intensity completely overpowered all the rest; and"][[42 3 5] "yet so mystical and well nigh ineffable was it, that I almost despair of"][[42 3 6] "putting it in a comprehensible form. It was the whiteness of the whale"][[42 3 7] "that above all things appalled me. But how can I hope to explain myself"][[42 3 8] "here; and yet, in some dim, random way, explain myself I must, else all"][[42 3 9] "these chapters might be naught."][[42 4 1] "Though in many natural objects, whiteness refiningly enhances beauty, as"][[42 4 2] "if imparting some special virtue of its own, as in marbles, japonicas,"][[42 4 3] "and pearls; and though various nations have in some way recognised a"][[42 4 4] "certain royal preeminence in this hue; even the barbaric, grand old"][[42 4 5] "kings of Pegu placing the title \"Lord of the White Elephants\" above all"][[42 4 6] "their other magniloquent ascriptions of dominion; and the modern kings"][[42 4 7] "of Siam unfurling the same snow-white quadruped in the royal standard;"][[42 4 8] "and the Hanoverian flag bearing the one figure of a snow-white charger;"][[42 4 9] "and the great Austrian Empire, Caesarian, heir to overlording Rome,"][[42 4 10] "having for the imperial colour the same imperial hue; and though this"][[42 4 11] "pre-eminence in it applies to the human race itself, giving the white"][[42 4 12] "man ideal mastership over every dusky tribe; and though, besides, all"][[42 4 13] "this, whiteness has been even made significant of gladness, for among"][[42 4 14] "the Romans a white stone marked a joyful day; and though in other mortal"][[42 4 15] "sympathies and symbolizings, this same hue is made the emblem of many"][[42 4 16] "touching, noble things--the innocence of brides, the benignity of age;"][[42 4 17] "though among the Red Men of America the giving of the white belt"][[42 4 18] "of wampum was the deepest pledge of honour; though in many climes,"][[42 4 19] "whiteness typifies the majesty of Justice in the ermine of the Judge,"][[42 4 20] "and contributes to the daily state of kings and queens drawn by"][[42 4 21] "milk-white steeds; though even in the higher mysteries of the most"][[42 4 22] "august religions it has been made the symbol of the divine spotlessness"][[42 4 23] "and power; by the Persian fire worshippers, the white forked flame being"][[42 4 24] "held the holiest on the altar; and in the Greek mythologies, Great Jove"][[42 4 25] "himself being made incarnate in a snow-white bull; and though to the"][[42 4 26] "noble Iroquois, the midwinter sacrifice of the sacred White Dog was"][[42 4 27] "by far the holiest festival of their theology, that spotless, faithful"][[42 4 28] "creature being held the purest envoy they could send to the Great Spirit"][[42 4 29] "with the annual tidings of their own fidelity; and though directly from"][[42 4 30] "the Latin word for white, all Christian priests derive the name of"][[42 4 31] "one part of their sacred vesture, the alb or tunic, worn beneath the"][[42 4 32] "cassock; and though among the holy pomps of the Romish faith, white is"][[42 4 33] "specially employed in the celebration of the Passion of our Lord; though"][[42 4 34] "in the Vision of St. John, white robes are given to the redeemed, and"][[42 4 35] "the four-and-twenty elders stand clothed in white before the great-white"][[42 4 36] "throne, and the Holy One that sitteth there white like wool; yet for all"][[42 4 37] "these accumulated associations, with whatever is sweet, and honourable,"][[42 4 38] "and sublime, there yet lurks an elusive something in the innermost idea"][[42 4 39] "of this hue, which strikes more of panic to the soul than that redness"][[42 4 40] "which affrights in blood."][[42 5 1] "This elusive quality it is, which causes the thought of whiteness, when"][[42 5 2] "divorced from more kindly associations, and coupled with any object"][[42 5 3] "terrible in itself, to heighten that terror to the furthest bounds."][[42 5 4] "Witness the white bear of the poles, and the white shark of the tropics;"][[42 5 5] "what but their smooth, flaky whiteness makes them the transcendent"][[42 5 6] "horrors they are? That ghastly whiteness it is which imparts such an"][[42 5 7] "abhorrent mildness, even more loathsome than terrific, to the dumb"][[42 5 8] "gloating of their aspect. So that not the fierce-fanged tiger in his"][[42 5 9] "heraldic coat can so stagger courage as the white-shrouded bear or"][[42 5 10] "shark.*"][[42 7 1] "*With reference to the Polar bear, it may possibly be urged by him"][[42 7 2] "who would fain go still deeper into this matter, that it is not"][[42 7 3] "the whiteness, separately regarded, which heightens the intolerable"][[42 7 4] "hideousness of that brute; for, analysed, that heightened hideousness,"][[42 7 5] "it might be said, only rises from the circumstance, that the"][[42 7 6] "irresponsible ferociousness of the creature stands invested in the"][[42 7 7] "fleece of celestial innocence and love; and hence, by bringing together"][[42 7 8] "two such opposite emotions in our minds, the Polar bear frightens us"][[42 7 9] "with so unnatural a contrast. But even assuming all this to be true;"][[42 7 10] "yet, were it not for the whiteness, you would not have that intensified"][[42 7 11] "terror."][[42 8 1] "As for the white shark, the white gliding ghostliness of repose in that"][[42 8 2] "creature, when beheld in his ordinary moods, strangely tallies with the"][[42 8 3] "same quality in the Polar quadruped. This peculiarity is most vividly"][[42 8 4] "hit by the French in the name they bestow upon that fish. The Romish"][[42 8 5] "mass for the dead begins with \"Requiem eternam\" (eternal rest), whence"][[42 8 6] "REQUIEM denominating the mass itself, and any other funeral music. Now,"][[42 8 7] "in allusion to the white, silent stillness of death in this shark, and"][[42 8 8] "the mild deadliness of his habits, the French call him REQUIN."][[42 10 1] "Bethink thee of the albatross, whence come those clouds of spiritual"][[42 10 2] "wonderment and pale dread, in which that white phantom sails in all"][[42 10 3] "imaginations? Not Coleridge first threw that spell; but God's great,"][[42 10 4] "unflattering laureate, Nature.*"][[42 12 1] "*I remember the first albatross I ever saw. It was during a prolonged"][[42 12 2] "gale, in waters hard upon the Antarctic seas. From my forenoon watch"][[42 12 3] "below, I ascended to the overclouded deck; and there, dashed upon the"][[42 12 4] "main hatches, I saw a regal, feathery thing of unspotted whiteness, and"][[42 12 5] "with a hooked, Roman bill sublime. At intervals, it arched forth"][[42 12 6] "its vast archangel wings, as if to embrace some holy ark. Wondrous"][[42 12 7] "flutterings and throbbings shook it. Though bodily unharmed, it uttered"][[42 12 8] "cries, as some king's ghost in supernatural distress. Through its"][[42 12 9] "inexpressible, strange eyes, methought I peeped to secrets which took"][[42 12 10] "hold of God. As Abraham before the angels, I bowed myself; the white"][[42 12 11] "thing was so white, its wings so wide, and in those for ever exiled"][[42 12 12] "waters, I had lost the miserable warping memories of traditions and of"][[42 12 13] "towns. Long I gazed at that prodigy of plumage. I cannot tell, can only"][[42 12 14] "hint, the things that darted through me then. But at last I awoke; and"][[42 12 15] "turning, asked a sailor what bird was this. A goney, he replied. Goney!"][[42 12 16] "never had heard that name before; is it conceivable that this glorious"][[42 12 17] "thing is utterly unknown to men ashore! never! But some time after, I"][[42 12 18] "learned that goney was some seaman's name for albatross. So that by no"][[42 12 19] "possibility could Coleridge's wild Rhyme have had aught to do with those"][[42 12 20] "mystical impressions which were mine, when I saw that bird upon our"][[42 12 21] "deck. For neither had I then read the Rhyme, nor knew the bird to be"][[42 12 22] "an albatross. Yet, in saying this, I do but indirectly burnish a little"][[42 12 23] "brighter the noble merit of the poem and the poet."][[42 13 1] "I assert, then, that in the wondrous bodily whiteness of the bird"][[42 13 2] "chiefly lurks the secret of the spell; a truth the more evinced in this,"][[42 13 3] "that by a solecism of terms there are birds called grey albatrosses;"][[42 13 4] "and these I have frequently seen, but never with such emotions as when I"][[42 13 5] "beheld the Antarctic fowl."][[42 14 1] "But how had the mystic thing been caught? Whisper it not, and I will"][[42 14 2] "tell; with a treacherous hook and line, as the fowl floated on the sea."][[42 14 3] "At last the Captain made a postman of it; tying a lettered, leathern"][[42 14 4] "tally round its neck, with the ship's time and place; and then letting"][[42 14 5] "it escape. But I doubt not, that leathern tally, meant for man, was"][[42 14 6] "taken off in Heaven, when the white fowl flew to join the wing-folding,"][[42 14 7] "the invoking, and adoring cherubim!"][[42 16 1] "Most famous in our Western annals and Indian traditions is that of"][[42 16 2] "the White Steed of the Prairies; a magnificent milk-white charger,"][[42 16 3] "large-eyed, small-headed, bluff-chested, and with the dignity of a"][[42 16 4] "thousand monarchs in his lofty, overscorning carriage. He was the"][[42 16 5] "elected Xerxes of vast herds of wild horses, whose pastures in those"][[42 16 6] "days were only fenced by the Rocky Mountains and the Alleghanies. At"][[42 16 7] "their flaming head he westward trooped it like that chosen star which"][[42 16 8] "every evening leads on the hosts of light. The flashing cascade of his"][[42 16 9] "mane, the curving comet of his tail, invested him with housings more"][[42 16 10] "resplendent than gold and silver-beaters could have furnished him. A"][[42 16 11] "most imperial and archangelical apparition of that unfallen, western"][[42 16 12] "world, which to the eyes of the old trappers and hunters revived the"][[42 16 13] "glories of those primeval times when Adam walked majestic as a god,"][[42 16 14] "bluff-browed and fearless as this mighty steed. Whether marching amid"][[42 16 15] "his aides and marshals in the van of countless cohorts that endlessly"][[42 16 16] "streamed it over the plains, like an Ohio; or whether with his"][[42 16 17] "circumambient subjects browsing all around at the horizon, the White"][[42 16 18] "Steed gallopingly reviewed them with warm nostrils reddening through his"][[42 16 19] "cool milkiness; in whatever aspect he presented himself, always to the"][[42 16 20] "bravest Indians he was the object of trembling reverence and awe. Nor"][[42 16 21] "can it be questioned from what stands on legendary record of this noble"][[42 16 22] "horse, that it was his spiritual whiteness chiefly, which so clothed him"][[42 16 23] "with divineness; and that this divineness had that in it which, though"][[42 16 24] "commanding worship, at the same time enforced a certain nameless terror."][[42 17 1] "But there are other instances where this whiteness loses all that"][[42 17 2] "accessory and strange glory which invests it in the White Steed and"][[42 17 3] "Albatross."][[42 18 1] "What is it that in the Albino man so peculiarly repels and often shocks"][[42 18 2] "the eye, as that sometimes he is loathed by his own kith and kin! It"][[42 18 3] "is that whiteness which invests him, a thing expressed by the name"][[42 18 4] "he bears. The Albino is as well made as other men--has no substantive"][[42 18 5] "deformity--and yet this mere aspect of all-pervading whiteness makes him"][[42 18 6] "more strangely hideous than the ugliest abortion. Why should this be so?"][[42 19 1] "Nor, in quite other aspects, does Nature in her least palpable but"][[42 19 2] "not the less malicious agencies, fail to enlist among her forces"][[42 19 3] "this crowning attribute of the terrible. From its snowy aspect, the"][[42 19 4] "gauntleted ghost of the Southern Seas has been denominated the White"][[42 19 5] "Squall. Nor, in some historic instances, has the art of human malice"][[42 19 6] "omitted so potent an auxiliary. How wildly it heightens the effect of"][[42 19 7] "that passage in Froissart, when, masked in the snowy symbol of their"][[42 19 8] "faction, the desperate White Hoods of Ghent murder their bailiff in the"][[42 19 9] "market-place!"][[42 20 1] "Nor, in some things, does the common, hereditary experience of all"][[42 20 2] "mankind fail to bear witness to the supernaturalism of this hue. It"][[42 20 3] "cannot well be doubted, that the one visible quality in the aspect of"][[42 20 4] "the dead which most appals the gazer, is the marble pallor lingering"][[42 20 5] "there; as if indeed that pallor were as much like the badge of"][[42 20 6] "consternation in the other world, as of mortal trepidation here. And"][[42 20 7] "from that pallor of the dead, we borrow the expressive hue of the shroud"][[42 20 8] "in which we wrap them. Nor even in our superstitions do we fail to"][[42 20 9] "throw the same snowy mantle round our phantoms; all ghosts rising in a"][[42 20 10] "milk-white fog--Yea, while these terrors seize us, let us add, that even"][[42 20 11] "the king of terrors, when personified by the evangelist, rides on his"][[42 20 12] "pallid horse."][[42 21 1] "Therefore, in his other moods, symbolize whatever grand or gracious"][[42 21 2] "thing he will by whiteness, no man can deny that in its profoundest"][[42 21 3] "idealized significance it calls up a peculiar apparition to the soul."][[42 22 1] "But though without dissent this point be fixed, how is mortal man to"][[42 22 2] "account for it? To analyse it, would seem impossible. Can we, then,"][[42 22 3] "by the citation of some of those instances wherein this thing of"][[42 22 4] "whiteness--though for the time either wholly or in great part stripped"][[42 22 5] "of all direct associations calculated to impart to it aught fearful,"][[42 22 6] "but nevertheless, is found to exert over us the same sorcery, however"][[42 22 7] "modified;--can we thus hope to light upon some chance clue to conduct us"][[42 22 8] "to the hidden cause we seek?"][[42 23 1] "Let us try. But in a matter like this, subtlety appeals to subtlety,"][[42 23 2] "and without imagination no man can follow another into these halls. And"][[42 23 3] "though, doubtless, some at least of the imaginative impressions about"][[42 23 4] "to be presented may have been shared by most men, yet few perhaps were"][[42 23 5] "entirely conscious of them at the time, and therefore may not be able to"][[42 23 6] "recall them now."][[42 24 1] "Why to the man of untutored ideality, who happens to be but loosely"][[42 24 2] "acquainted with the peculiar character of the day, does the bare mention"][[42 24 3] "of Whitsuntide marshal in the fancy such long, dreary, speechless"][[42 24 4] "processions of slow-pacing pilgrims, down-cast and hooded with"][[42 24 5] "new-fallen snow? Or, to the unread, unsophisticated Protestant of the"][[42 24 6] "Middle American States, why does the passing mention of a White Friar or"][[42 24 7] "a White Nun, evoke such an eyeless statue in the soul?"][[42 25 1] "Or what is there apart from the traditions of dungeoned warriors and"][[42 25 2] "kings (which will not wholly account for it) that makes the White"][[42 25 3] "Tower of London tell so much more strongly on the imagination of"][[42 25 4] "an untravelled American, than those other storied structures, its"][[42 25 5] "neighbors--the Byward Tower, or even the Bloody? And those sublimer"][[42 25 6] "towers, the White Mountains of New Hampshire, whence, in peculiar moods,"][[42 25 7] "comes that gigantic ghostliness over the soul at the bare mention of"][[42 25 8] "that name, while the thought of Virginia's Blue Ridge is full of a soft,"][[42 25 9] "dewy, distant dreaminess? Or why, irrespective of all latitudes and"][[42 25 10] "longitudes, does the name of the White Sea exert such a spectralness"][[42 25 11] "over the fancy, while that of the Yellow Sea lulls us with mortal"][[42 25 12] "thoughts of long lacquered mild afternoons on the waves, followed by"][[42 25 13] "the gaudiest and yet sleepiest of sunsets? Or, to choose a wholly"][[42 25 14] "unsubstantial instance, purely addressed to the fancy, why, in reading"][[42 25 15] "the old fairy tales of Central Europe, does \"the tall pale man\" of the"][[42 25 16] "Hartz forests, whose changeless pallor unrustlingly glides through the"][[42 25 17] "green of the groves--why is this phantom more terrible than all the"][[42 25 18] "whooping imps of the Blocksburg?"][[42 26 1] "Nor is it, altogether, the remembrance of her cathedral-toppling"][[42 26 2] "earthquakes; nor the stampedoes of her frantic seas; nor the"][[42 26 3] "tearlessness of arid skies that never rain; nor the sight of her wide"][[42 26 4] "field of leaning spires, wrenched cope-stones, and crosses all adroop"][[42 26 5] "(like canted yards of anchored fleets); and her suburban avenues of"][[42 26 6] "house-walls lying over upon each other, as a tossed pack of cards;--it"][[42 26 7] "is not these things alone which make tearless Lima, the strangest,"][[42 26 8] "saddest city thou can'st see. For Lima has taken the white veil; and"][[42 26 9] "there is a higher horror in this whiteness of her woe. Old as Pizarro,"][[42 26 10] "this whiteness keeps her ruins for ever new; admits not the cheerful"][[42 26 11] "greenness of complete decay; spreads over her broken ramparts the rigid"][[42 26 12] "pallor of an apoplexy that fixes its own distortions."][[42 27 1] "I know that, to the common apprehension, this phenomenon of whiteness"][[42 27 2] "is not confessed to be the prime agent in exaggerating the terror of"][[42 27 3] "objects otherwise terrible; nor to the unimaginative mind is there aught"][[42 27 4] "of terror in those appearances whose awfulness to another mind almost"][[42 27 5] "solely consists in this one phenomenon, especially when exhibited under"][[42 27 6] "any form at all approaching to muteness or universality. What I mean"][[42 27 7] "by these two statements may perhaps be respectively elucidated by the"][[42 27 8] "following examples."][[42 28 1] "First: The mariner, when drawing nigh the coasts of foreign lands, if by"][[42 28 2] "night he hear the roar of breakers, starts to vigilance, and feels just"][[42 28 3] "enough of trepidation to sharpen all his faculties; but under precisely"][[42 28 4] "similar circumstances, let him be called from his hammock to view his"][[42 28 5] "ship sailing through a midnight sea of milky whiteness--as if from"][[42 28 6] "encircling headlands shoals of combed white bears were swimming round"][[42 28 7] "him, then he feels a silent, superstitious dread; the shrouded phantom"][[42 28 8] "of the whitened waters is horrible to him as a real ghost; in vain the"][[42 28 9] "lead assures him he is still off soundings; heart and helm they both go"][[42 28 10] "down; he never rests till blue water is under him again. Yet where is"][[42 28 11] "the mariner who will tell thee, \"Sir, it was not so much the fear of"][[42 28 12] "striking hidden rocks, as the fear of that hideous whiteness that so"][[42 28 13] "stirred me?\""][[42 29 1] "Second: To the native Indian of Peru, the continual sight of the"][[42 29 2] "snowhowdahed Andes conveys naught of dread, except, perhaps, in the"][[42 29 3] "mere fancying of the eternal frosted desolateness reigning at such vast"][[42 29 4] "altitudes, and the natural conceit of what a fearfulness it would be"][[42 29 5] "to lose oneself in such inhuman solitudes. Much the same is it with the"][[42 29 6] "backwoodsman of the West, who with comparative indifference views an"][[42 29 7] "unbounded prairie sheeted with driven snow, no shadow of tree or twig"][[42 29 8] "to break the fixed trance of whiteness. Not so the sailor, beholding the"][[42 29 9] "scenery of the Antarctic seas; where at times, by some infernal trick"][[42 29 10] "of legerdemain in the powers of frost and air, he, shivering and half"][[42 29 11] "shipwrecked, instead of rainbows speaking hope and solace to his misery,"][[42 29 12] "views what seems a boundless churchyard grinning upon him with its lean"][[42 29 13] "ice monuments and splintered crosses."][[42 30 1] "But thou sayest, methinks that white-lead chapter about whiteness is but"][[42 30 2] "a white flag hung out from a craven soul; thou surrenderest to a hypo,"][[42 30 3] "Ishmael."][[42 31 1] "Tell me, why this strong young colt, foaled in some peaceful valley of"][[42 31 2] "Vermont, far removed from all beasts of prey--why is it that upon the"][[42 31 3] "sunniest day, if you but shake a fresh buffalo robe behind him, so that"][[42 31 4] "he cannot even see it, but only smells its wild animal muskiness--why"][[42 31 5] "will he start, snort, and with bursting eyes paw the ground in phrensies"][[42 31 6] "of affright? There is no remembrance in him of any gorings of wild"][[42 31 7] "creatures in his green northern home, so that the strange muskiness he"][[42 31 8] "smells cannot recall to him anything associated with the experience of"][[42 31 9] "former perils; for what knows he, this New England colt, of the black"][[42 31 10] "bisons of distant Oregon?"][[42 32 1] "No; but here thou beholdest even in a dumb brute, the instinct of the"][[42 32 2] "knowledge of the demonism in the world. Though thousands of miles from"][[42 32 3] "Oregon, still when he smells that savage musk, the rending, goring bison"][[42 32 4] "herds are as present as to the deserted wild foal of the prairies, which"][[42 32 5] "this instant they may be trampling into dust."][[42 33 1] "Thus, then, the muffled rollings of a milky sea; the bleak rustlings"][[42 33 2] "of the festooned frosts of mountains; the desolate shiftings of the"][[42 33 3] "windrowed snows of prairies; all these, to Ishmael, are as the shaking"][[42 33 4] "of that buffalo robe to the frightened colt!"][[42 34 1] "Though neither knows where lie the nameless things of which the mystic"][[42 34 2] "sign gives forth such hints; yet with me, as with the colt, somewhere"][[42 34 3] "those things must exist. Though in many of its aspects this visible"][[42 34 4] "world seems formed in love, the invisible spheres were formed in fright."][[42 35 1] "But not yet have we solved the incantation of this whiteness, and"][[42 35 2] "learned why it appeals with such power to the soul; and more strange"][[42 35 3] "and far more portentous--why, as we have seen, it is at once the"][[42 35 4] "most meaning symbol of spiritual things, nay, the very veil of the"][[42 35 5] "Christian's Deity; and yet should be as it is, the intensifying agent in"][[42 35 6] "things the most appalling to mankind."][[42 36 1] "Is it that by its indefiniteness it shadows forth the heartless voids"][[42 36 2] "and immensities of the universe, and thus stabs us from behind with the"][[42 36 3] "thought of annihilation, when beholding the white depths of the milky"][[42 36 4] "way? Or is it, that as in essence whiteness is not so much a colour as"][[42 36 5] "the visible absence of colour; and at the same time the concrete of all"][[42 36 6] "colours; is it for these reasons that there is such a dumb blankness,"][[42 36 7] "full of meaning, in a wide landscape of snows--a colourless, all-colour"][[42 36 8] "of atheism from which we shrink? And when we consider that other theory"][[42 36 9] "of the natural philosophers, that all other earthly hues--every stately"][[42 36 10] "or lovely emblazoning--the sweet tinges of sunset skies and woods; yea,"][[42 36 11] "and the gilded velvets of butterflies, and the butterfly cheeks of"][[42 36 12] "young girls; all these are but subtile deceits, not actually inherent"][[42 36 13] "in substances, but only laid on from without; so that all deified Nature"][[42 36 14] "absolutely paints like the harlot, whose allurements cover nothing but"][[42 36 15] "the charnel-house within; and when we proceed further, and consider that"][[42 36 16] "the mystical cosmetic which produces every one of her hues, the great"][[42 36 17] "principle of light, for ever remains white or colourless in itself, and"][[42 36 18] "if operating without medium upon matter, would touch all objects, even"][[42 36 19] "tulips and roses, with its own blank tinge--pondering all this, the"][[42 36 20] "palsied universe lies before us a leper; and like wilful travellers in"][[42 36 21] "Lapland, who refuse to wear coloured and colouring glasses upon their"][[42 36 22] "eyes, so the wretched infidel gazes himself blind at the monumental"][[42 36 23] "white shroud that wraps all the prospect around him. And of all these"][[42 36 24] "things the Albino whale was the symbol. Wonder ye then at the fiery"][[42 36 25] "hunt?"][[43 0 0] "CHAPTER 43. Hark!"][[43 2 1] "\"HIST! Did you hear that noise, Cabaco?\""][[43 3 1] "It was the middle-watch; a fair moonlight; the seamen were standing in a"][[43 3 2] "cordon, extending from one of the fresh-water butts in the waist, to the"][[43 3 3] "scuttle-butt near the taffrail. In this manner, they passed the buckets"][[43 3 4] "to fill the scuttle-butt. From hand to hand, the buckets went in the deepest silence,"][[43 3 7] "only broken by the occasional flap of a sail, and the steady hum of the"][[43 3 8] "unceasingly advancing keel."][[43 4 1] "It was in the midst of this repose, that Archy, one of the cordon, whose"][[43 4 2] "post was near the after-hatches, whispered to his neighbor, a Cholo, the"][[43 4 3] "words above."][[43 5 1] "\"Hist! did you hear that noise, Cabaco?\""][[43 6 1] "\"Take the bucket, will ye, Archy? what noise d'ye mean?\""][[43 7 1] "\"There it is again--under the hatches--don't you hear it--a cough--it"][[43 7 2] "sounded like a cough.\""][[43 8 1] "\"Cough be damned!
