The Chart."][[44 2 1] "Had you followed Captain Ahab down into his cabin after the squall that"][[44 2 2] "took place on the night succeeding that wild ratification of his purpose"][[44 2 3] "with his crew, you would have seen him go to a locker in the transom,"][[44 2 4] "and bringing out a large wrinkled roll of yellowish sea charts, spread"][[44 2 5] "them before him on his screwed-down table. Then seating himself before"][[44 2 6] "it, you would have seen him intently study the various lines and"][[44 2 7] "shadings which there met his eye; and with slow but steady pencil trace"][[44 2 8] "additional courses over spaces that before were blank. At intervals, he"][[44 2 9] "would refer to piles of old log-books beside him, wherein were set down"][[44 2 10] "the seasons and places in which, on various former voyages of various"][[44 2 11] "ships, sperm whales had been captured or seen."][[44 3 1] "While thus employed, the heavy pewter lamp suspended in chains over his"][[44 3 2] "head, continually rocked with the motion of the ship, and for ever threw"][[44 3 3] "shifting gleams and shadows of lines upon his wrinkled brow, till it"][[44 3 4] "almost seemed that while he himself was marking out lines and courses"][[44 3 5] "on the wrinkled charts, some invisible pencil was also tracing lines and"][[44 3 6] "courses upon the deeply marked chart of his forehead."][[44 4 1] "But it was not this night in particular that, in the solitude of his"][[44 4 2] "cabin, Ahab thus pondered over his charts. Almost every night they were"][[44 4 3] "brought out; almost every night some pencil marks were effaced, and"][[44 4 4] "others were substituted. For with the charts of all four oceans before"][[44 4 5] "him, Ahab was threading a maze of currents and eddies, with a view to"][[44 4 6] "the more certain accomplishment of that monomaniac thought of his soul."][[44 5 1] "Now, to any one not fully acquainted with the ways of the leviathans,"][[44 5 2] "it might seem an absurdly hopeless task thus to seek out one solitary"][[44 5 3] "creature in the unhooped oceans of this planet. But not so did it"][[44 5 4] "seem to Ahab, who knew the sets of all tides and currents; and thereby"][[44 5 5] "calculating the driftings of the sperm whale's food; and, also, calling"][[44 5 6] "to mind the regular, ascertained seasons for hunting him in particular"][[44 5 7] "latitudes; could arrive at reasonable surmises, almost approaching to"][[44 5 8] "certainties, concerning the timeliest day to be upon this or that ground"][[44 5 9] "in search of his prey."][[44 6 1] "So assured, indeed, is the fact concerning the periodicalness of the"][[44 6 2] "sperm whale's resorting to given waters, that many hunters believe that,"][[44 6 3] "could he be closely observed and studied throughout the world; were the"][[44 6 4] "logs for one voyage of the entire whale fleet carefully collated,"][[44 6 5] "then the migrations of the sperm whale would be found to correspond in"][[44 6 6] "invariability to those of the herring-shoals or the flights of swallows."][[44 6 7] "On this hint, attempts have been made to construct elaborate migratory"][[44 6 8] "charts of the sperm whale.*"][[44 7 1] "*Since the above was written, the statement is happily borne"][[44 7 2] "out by an official circular, issued by Lieutenant Maury, of"][[44 7 3] "the National Observatory, Washington, April th, . By"][[44 7 4] "that circular, it appears that precisely such a chart is in"][[44 7 5] "course of completion; and portions of it are presented in"][[44 7 6] "the circular. \"This chart divides the ocean into districts"][[44 7 7] "of five degrees of latitude by five degrees of longitude;"][[44 7 8] "perpendicularly through each of which districts are twelve"][[44 7 9] "columns for the twelve months; and horizontally through each"][[44 7 10] "of which districts are three lines; one to show the number"][[44 7 11] "of days that have been spent in each month in every"][[44 7 12] "district, and the two others to show the number of days in"][[44 7 13] "which whales, sperm or right, have been seen.\""][[44 8 1] "Besides, when making a passage from one feeding-ground to another, the"][[44 8 2] "sperm whales, guided by some infallible instinct--say, rather, secret"][[44 8 3] "intelligence from the Deity--mostly swim in VEINS, as they are called;"][[44 8 4] "continuing their way along a given ocean-line with such undeviating"][[44 8 5] "exactitude, that no ship ever sailed her course, by any chart, with"][[44 8 6] "one tithe of such marvellous precision. Though, in these cases, the"][[44 8 7] "direction taken by any one whale be straight as a surveyor's parallel,"][[44 8 8] "and though the line of advance be strictly confined to its own"][[44 8 9] "unavoidable, straight wake, yet the arbitrary VEIN in which at these"][[44 8 10] "times he is said to swim, generally embraces some few miles in width"][[44 8 11] "(more or less, as the vein is presumed to expand or contract); but"][[44 8 12] "never exceeds the visual sweep from the whale-ship's mast-heads,"][[44 8 13] "when circumspectly gliding along this magic zone. The sum is, that at"][[44 8 14] "particular seasons within that breadth and along that path, migrating"][[44 8 15] "whales may with great confidence be looked for."][[44 9 1] "And hence not only at substantiated times, upon well known separate"][[44 9 2] "feeding-grounds, could Ahab hope to encounter his prey; but in crossing"][[44 9 3] "the widest expanses of water between those grounds he could, by his"][[44 9 4] "art, so place and time himself on his way, as even then not to be wholly"][[44 9 5] "without prospect of a meeting."][[44 10 1] "There was a circumstance which at first sight seemed to entangle his"][[44 10 2] "delirious but still methodical scheme. But not so in the reality,"][[44 10 3] "perhaps. Though the gregarious sperm whales have their regular seasons"][[44 10 4] "for particular grounds, yet in general you cannot conclude that the"][[44 10 5] "herds which haunted such and such a latitude or longitude this year,"][[44 10 6] "say, will turn out to be identically the same with those that were found"][[44 10 7] "there the preceding season; though there are peculiar and unquestionable"][[44 10 8] "instances where the contrary of this has proved true. In general, the"][[44 10 9] "same remark, only within a less wide limit, applies to the solitaries"][[44 10 10] "and hermits among the matured, aged sperm whales. So that though Moby"][[44 10 11] "Dick had in a former year been seen, for example, on what is called the"][[44 10 12] "Seychelle ground in the Indian ocean, or Volcano Bay on the Japanese"][[44 10 13] "Coast; yet it did not follow, that were the Pequod to visit either of"][[44 10 14] "those spots at any subsequent corresponding season, she would infallibly"][[44 10 15] "encounter him there. So, too, with some other feeding grounds, where"][[44 10 16] "he had at times revealed himself. But all these seemed only his casual"][[44 10 17] "stopping-places and ocean-inns, so to speak, not his places of prolonged"][[44 10 18] "abode. And where Ahab's chances of accomplishing his object have"][[44 10 19] "hitherto been spoken of, allusion has only been made to whatever"][[44 10 20] "way-side, antecedent, extra prospects were his, ere a particular"][[44 10 21] "set time or place were attained, when all possibilities would become"][[44 10 22] "probabilities, and, as Ahab fondly thought, every possibility the next"][[44 10 23] "thing to a certainty. That particular set time and place were conjoined"][[44 10 24] "in the one technical phrase--the Season-on-the-Line. For there and then,"][[44 10 25] "for several consecutive years, Moby Dick had been periodically descried,"][[44 10 26] "lingering in those waters for awhile, as the sun, in its annual round,"][[44 10 27] "loiters for a predicted interval in any one sign of the Zodiac. There"][[44 10 28] "it was, too, that most of the deadly encounters with the white whale had"][[44 10 29] "taken place; there the waves were storied with his deeds; there also was"][[44 10 30] "that tragic spot where the monomaniac old man had found the awful motive"][[44 10 31] "to his vengeance. But in the cautious comprehensiveness and unloitering"][[44 10 32] "vigilance with which Ahab threw his brooding soul into this unfaltering"][[44 10 33] "hunt, he would not permit himself to rest all his hopes upon the one"][[44 10 34] "crowning fact above mentioned, however flattering it might be to those"][[44 10 35] "hopes; nor in the sleeplessness of his vow could he so tranquillize his"][[44 10 36] "unquiet heart as to postpone all intervening quest."][[44 11 1] "Now, the Pequod had sailed from Nantucket at the very beginning of the"][[44 11 2] "Season-on-the-Line. No possible endeavor then could enable her commander"][[44 11 3] "to make the great passage southwards, double Cape Horn, and then running"][[44 11 4] "down sixty degrees of latitude arrive in the equatorial Pacific in time"][[44 11 5] "to cruise there. Therefore, he must wait for the next ensuing season."][[44 11 6] "Yet the premature hour of the Pequod's sailing had, perhaps, been"][[44 11 7] "correctly selected by Ahab, with a view to this very complexion of"][[44 11 8] "things. Because, an interval of three hundred and sixty-five days"][[44 11 9] "and nights was before him; an interval which, instead of impatiently"][[44 11 10] "enduring ashore, he would spend in a miscellaneous hunt; if by chance"][[44 11 11] "the White Whale, spending his vacation in seas far remote from his"][[44 11 12] "periodical feeding-grounds, should turn up his wrinkled brow off the"][[44 11 13] "Persian Gulf, or in the Bengal Bay, or China Seas, or in any other"][[44 11 14] "waters haunted by his race. So that Monsoons, Pampas, Nor'-Westers,"][[44 11 15] "Harmattans, Trades; any wind but the Levanter and Simoon, might"][[44 11 16] "blow Moby Dick into the devious zig-zag world-circle of the Pequod's"][[44 11 17] "circumnavigating wake."][[44 12 1] "But granting all this; yet, regarded discreetly and coolly, seems it not"][[44 12 2] "but a mad idea, this; that in the broad boundless ocean, one solitary"][[44 12 3] "whale, even if encountered, should be thought capable of individual"][[44 12 4] "recognition from his hunter, even as a white-bearded Mufti in the"][[44 12 5] "thronged thoroughfares of Constantinople? Yes. For the peculiar"][[44 12 6] "snow-white brow of Moby Dick, and his snow-white hump, could not but"][[44 12 7] "be unmistakable. And have I not tallied the whale, Ahab would mutter"][[44 12 8] "to himself, as after poring over his charts till long after midnight he"][[44 12 9] "would throw himself back in reveries--tallied him, and shall he escape?"][[44 12 10] "His broad fins are bored, and scalloped out like a lost sheep's ear! And"][[44 12 11] "here, his mad mind would run on in a breathless race; till a weariness"][[44 12 12] "and faintness of pondering came over him; and in the open air of the"][[44 12 13] "deck he would seek to recover his strength. Ah, God! what trances"][[44 12 14] "of torments does that man endure who is consumed with one unachieved"][[44 12 15] "revengeful desire. He sleeps with clenched hands; and wakes with his own"][[44 12 16] "bloody nails in his palms."][[44 13 1] "Often, when forced from his hammock by exhausting and intolerably vivid"][[44 13 2] "dreams of the night, which, resuming his own intense thoughts through"][[44 13 3] "the day, carried them on amid a clashing of phrensies, and whirled them"][[44 13 4] "round and round and round in his blazing brain, till the very throbbing"][[44 13 5] "of his life-spot became insufferable anguish; and when, as was sometimes"][[44 13 6] "the case, these spiritual throes in him heaved his being up from its"][[44 13 7] "base, and a chasm seemed opening in him, from which forked flames and"][[44 13 8] "lightnings shot up, and accursed fiends beckoned him to leap down among"][[44 13 9] "them; when this hell in himself yawned beneath him, a wild cry would be"][[44 13 10] "heard through the ship; and with glaring eyes Ahab would burst from his"][[44 13 11] "state room, as though escaping from a bed that was on fire. Yet these,"][[44 13 12] "perhaps, instead of being the unsuppressable symptoms of some latent"][[44 13 13] "weakness, or fright at his own resolve, were but the plainest tokens"][[44 13 14] "of its intensity. For, at such times, crazy Ahab, the scheming,"][[44 13 15] "unappeasedly steadfast hunter of the white whale; this Ahab that had"][[44 13 16] "gone to his hammock, was not the agent that so caused him to burst from"][[44 13 17] "it in horror again. The latter was the eternal, living principle or"][[44 13 18] "soul in him; and in sleep, being for the time dissociated from the"][[44 13 19] "characterizing mind, which at other times employed it for its outer"][[44 13 20] "vehicle or agent, it spontaneously sought escape from the scorching"][[44 13 21] "contiguity of the frantic thing, of which, for the time, it was no"][[44 13 22] "longer an integral. But as the mind does not exist unless leagued with"][[44 13 23] "the soul, therefore it must have been that, in Ahab's case, yielding up"][[44 13 24] "all his thoughts and fancies to his one supreme purpose; that purpose,"][[44 13 25] "by its own sheer inveteracy of will, forced itself against gods and"][[44 13 26] "devils into a kind of self-assumed, independent being of its own. Nay,"][[44 13 27] "could grimly live and burn, while the common vitality to which it was"][[44 13 28] "conjoined, fled horror-stricken from the unbidden and unfathered birth."][[44 13 29] "Therefore, the tormented spirit that glared out of bodily eyes, when"][[44 13 30] "what seemed Ahab rushed from his room, was for the time but a vacated"][[44 13 31] "thing, a formless somnambulistic being, a ray of living light, to be"][[44 13 32] "sure, but without an object to colour, and therefore a blankness in"][[44 13 33] "itself. God help thee, old man, thy thoughts have created a creature"][[44 13 34] "in thee; and he whose intense thinking thus makes him a Prometheus; a"][[44 13 35] "vulture feeds upon that heart for ever; that vulture the very creature"][[44 13 36] "he creates."][[45 0 0] "CHAPTER 45. The Affidavit."][[45 2 1] "So far as what there may be of a narrative in this book; and, indeed, as"][[45 2 2] "indirectly touching one or two very interesting and curious particulars"][[45 2 3] "in the habits of sperm whales, the foregoing chapter, in its earlier"][[45 2 4] "part, is as important a one as will be found in this volume; but the"][[45 2 5] "leading matter of it requires to be still further and more familiarly"][[45 2 6] "enlarged upon, in order to be adequately understood, and moreover to"][[45 2 7] "take away any incredulity which a profound ignorance of the entire"][[45 2 8] "subject may induce in some minds, as to the natural verity of the main"][[45 2 9] "points of this affair."][[45 3 1] "I care not to perform this part of my task methodically; but shall"][[45 3 2] "be content to produce the desired impression by separate citations of"][[45 3 3] "items, practically or reliably known to me as a whaleman; and from these"][[45 3 4] "citations, I take it--the conclusion aimed at will naturally follow of"][[45 3 5] "itself."][[45 4 1] "First: I have personally known three instances where a whale, after"][[45 4 2] "receiving a harpoon, has effected a complete escape; and, after an"][[45 4 3] "interval (in one instance of three years), has been again struck by"][[45 4 4] "the same hand, and slain; when the two irons, both marked by the same"][[45 4 5] "private cypher, have been taken from the body. In the instance where"][[45 4 6] "three years intervened between the flinging of the two harpoons; and I"][[45 4 7] "think it may have been something more than that; the man who darted"][[45 4 8] "them happening, in the interval, to go in a trading ship on a voyage to"][[45 4 9] "Africa, went ashore there, joined a discovery party, and penetrated far"][[45 4 10] "into the interior, where he travelled for a period of nearly two years,"][[45 4 11] "often endangered by serpents, savages, tigers, poisonous miasmas,"][[45 4 12] "with all the other common perils incident to wandering in the heart of"][[45 4 13] "unknown regions. Meanwhile, the whale he had struck must also have"][[45 4 14] "been on its travels; no doubt it had thrice circumnavigated the globe,"][[45 4 15] "brushing with its flanks all the coasts of Africa; but to no purpose."][[45 4 16] "This man and this whale again came together, and the one vanquished the"][[45 4 17] "other. I say I, myself, have known three instances similar to this; that"][[45 4 18] "is in two of them I saw the whales struck; and, upon the second attack,"][[45 4 19] "saw the two irons with the respective marks cut in them, afterwards"][[45 4 20] "taken from the dead fish. In the three-year instance, it so fell out"][[45 4 21] "that I was in the boat both times, first and last, and the last time"][[45 4 22] "distinctly recognised a peculiar sort of huge mole under the whale's"][[45 4 23] "eye, which I had observed there three years previous. I say three years,"][[45 4 24] "but I am pretty sure it was more than that. Here are three instances,"][[45 4 25] "then, which I personally know the truth of; but I have heard of many"][[45 4 26] "other instances from persons whose veracity in the matter there is no"][[45 4 27] "good ground to impeach."][[45 5 1] "Secondly: It is well known in the Sperm Whale Fishery, however ignorant"][[45 5 2] "the world ashore may be of it, that there have been several memorable"][[45 5 3] "historical instances where a particular whale in the ocean has been at"][[45 5 4] "distant times and places popularly cognisable. Why such a whale became"][[45 5 5] "thus marked was not altogether and originally owing to his bodily"][[45 5 6] "peculiarities as distinguished from other whales; for however peculiar"][[45 5 7] "in that respect any chance whale may be, they soon put an end to his"][[45 5 8] "peculiarities by killing him, and boiling him down into a peculiarly"][[45 5 9] "valuable oil. No: the reason was this: that from the fatal experiences"][[45 5 10] "of the fishery there hung a terrible prestige of perilousness about"][[45 5 11] "such a whale as there did about Rinaldo Rinaldini, insomuch that"][[45 5 12] "most fishermen were content to recognise him by merely touching their"][[45 5 13] "tarpaulins when he would be discovered lounging by them on the sea,"][[45 5 14] "without seeking to cultivate a more intimate acquaintance. Like some"][[45 5 15] "poor devils ashore that happen to know an irascible great man, they"][[45 5 16] "make distant unobtrusive salutations to him in the street, lest if they"][[45 5 17] "pursued the acquaintance further, they might receive a summary thump for"][[45 5 18] "their presumption."][[45 6 1] "But not only did each of these famous whales enjoy great individual"][[45 6 2] "celebrity--Nay, you may call it an ocean-wide renown; not only was he"][[45 6 3] "famous in life and now is immortal in forecastle stories after death,"][[45 6 4] "but he was admitted into all the rights, privileges, and distinctions of"][[45 6 5] "a name; had as much a name indeed as Cambyses or Caesar. Was it not so,"][[45 6 6] "O Timor Tom! thou famed leviathan, scarred like an iceberg, who so long"][[45 6 7] "did'st lurk in the Oriental straits of that name, whose spout was oft"][[45 6 8] "seen from the palmy beach of Ombay? Was it not so, O New Zealand Jack!"][[45 6 9] "thou terror of all cruisers that crossed their wakes in the vicinity of"][[45 6 10] "the Tattoo Land? Was it not so, O Morquan! King of Japan, whose lofty"][[45 6 11] "jet they say at times assumed the semblance of a snow-white cross"][[45 6 12] "against the sky? Was it not so, O Don Miguel! thou Chilian whale, marked"][[45 6 13] "like an old tortoise with mystic hieroglyphics upon the back! In plain"][[45 6 14] "prose, here are four whales as well known to the students of Cetacean"][[45 6 15] "History as Marius or Sylla to the classic scholar."][[45 7 1] "But this is not all. New Zealand Tom and Don Miguel, after at various"][[45 7 2] "times creating great havoc among the boats of different vessels, were"][[45 7 3] "finally gone in quest of, systematically hunted out, chased and killed"][[45 7 4] "by valiant whaling captains, who heaved up their anchors with"][[45 7 5] "that express object as much in view, as in setting out through the"][[45 7 6] "Narragansett Woods, Captain Butler of old had it in his mind to capture"][[45 7 7] "that notorious murderous savage Annawon, the headmost warrior of the"][[45 7 8] "Indian King Philip."][[45 8 1] "I do not know where I can find a better place than just here, to make"][[45 8 2] "mention of one or two other things, which to me seem important, as in"][[45 8 3] "printed form establishing in all respects the reasonableness of the"][[45 8 4] "whole story of the White Whale, more especially the catastrophe. For"][[45 8 5] "this is one of those disheartening instances where truth requires full"][[45 8 6] "as much bolstering as error. So ignorant are most landsmen of some of"][[45 8 7] "the plainest and most palpable wonders of the world, that without"][[45 8 8] "some hints touching the plain facts, historical and otherwise, of the"][[45 8 9] "fishery, they might scout at Moby Dick as a monstrous fable, or still"][[45 8 10] "worse and more detestable, a hideous and intolerable allegory."][[45 9 1] "First: Though most men have some vague flitting ideas of the general"][[45 9 2] "perils of the grand fishery, yet they have nothing like a fixed, vivid"][[45 9 3] "conception of those perils, and the frequency with which they recur."][[45 9 4] "One reason perhaps is, that not one in fifty of the actual disasters and"][[45 9 5] "deaths by casualties in the fishery, ever finds a public record at home,"][[45 9 6] "however transient and immediately forgotten that record. Do you suppose"][[45 9 7] "that that poor fellow there, who this moment perhaps caught by the"][[45 9 8] "whale-line off the coast of New Guinea, is being carried down to the"][[45 9 9] "bottom of the sea by the sounding leviathan--do you suppose that that"][[45 9 10] "poor fellow's name will appear in the newspaper obituary you will read"][[45 9 11] "to-morrow at your breakfast? No: because the mails are very irregular"][[45 9 12] "between here and New Guinea. In fact, did you ever hear what might be"][[45 9 13] "called regular news direct or indirect from New Guinea? Yet I tell you"][[45 9 14] "that upon one particular voyage which I made to the Pacific, among many"][[45 9 15] "others we spoke thirty different ships, every one of which had had a"][[45 9 16] "death by a whale, some of them more than one, and three that had each"][[45 9 17] "lost a boat's crew. For God's sake, be economical with your lamps and"][[45 9 18] "candles! not a gallon you burn, but at least one drop of man's blood was"][[45 9 19] "spilled for it."][[45 10 1] "Secondly: People ashore have indeed some indefinite idea that a whale is"][[45 10 2] "an enormous creature of enormous power; but I have ever found that when"][[45 10 3] "narrating to them some specific example of this two-fold enormousness,"][[45 10 4] "they have significantly complimented me upon my facetiousness; when, I"][[45 10 5] "declare upon my soul, I had no more idea of being facetious than Moses,"][[45 10 6] "when he wrote the history of the plagues of Egypt."][[45 11 1] "But fortunately the special point I here seek can be established upon"][[45 11 2] "testimony entirely independent of my own. That point is this: The Sperm"][[45 11 3] "Whale is in some cases sufficiently powerful, knowing, and judiciously"][[45 11 4] "malicious, as with direct aforethought to stave in, utterly destroy, and"][[45 11 5] "sink a large ship; and what is more, the Sperm Whale HAS done it."][[45 12 1] "First: In the year  the ship Essex, Captain Pollard, of Nantucket,"][[45 12 2] "was cruising in the Pacific Ocean. One day she saw spouts, lowered her"][[45 12 3] "boats, and gave chase to a shoal of sperm whales. Ere long, several of"][[45 12 4] "the whales were wounded; when, suddenly, a very large whale escaping"][[45 12 5] "from the boats, issued from the shoal, and bore directly down upon the"][[45 12 6] "ship. Dashing his forehead against her hull, he so stove her in, that in"][[45 12 7] "less than \"ten minutes\" she settled down and fell over. Not a surviving"][[45 12 8] "plank of her has been seen since. After the severest exposure, part of"][[45 12 9] "the crew reached the land in their boats. Being returned home at last,"][[45 12 10] "Captain Pollard once more sailed for the Pacific in command of another"][[45 12 11] "ship, but the gods shipwrecked him again upon unknown rocks and"][[45 12 12] "breakers; for the second time his ship was utterly lost, and forthwith"][[45 12 13] "forswearing the sea, he has never tempted it since. At this day Captain"][[45 12 14] "Pollard is a resident of Nantucket. I have seen Owen Chace, who was"][[45 12 15] "chief mate of the Essex at the time of the tragedy; I have read his"][[45 12 16] "plain and faithful narrative; I have conversed with his son; and all"][[45 12 17] "this within a few miles of the scene of the catastrophe.*"][[45 14 1] "*The following are extracts from Chace's narrative: \"Every fact seemed"][[45 14 2] "to warrant me in concluding that it was anything but chance which"][[45 14 3] "directed his operations; he made two several attacks upon the ship, at"][[45 14 4] "a short interval between them, both of which, according to their"][[45 14 5] "direction, were calculated to do us the most injury, by being made"][[45 14 6] "ahead, and thereby combining the speed of the two objects for the shock;"][[45 14 7] "to effect which, the exact manoeuvres which he made were necessary. His"][[45 14 8] "aspect was most horrible, and such as indicated resentment and fury. He"][[45 14 9] "came directly from the shoal which we had just before entered, and in"][[45 14 10] "which we had struck three of his companions, as if fired with revenge"][[45 14 11] "for their sufferings.\" Again: \"At all events, the whole circumstances"][[45 14 12] "taken together, all happening before my own eyes, and producing, at the"][[45 14 13] "time, impressions in my mind of decided, calculating mischief, on the"][[45 14 14] "part of the whale (many of which impressions I cannot now recall),"][[45 14 15] "induce me to be satisfied that I am correct in my opinion.\""][[45 15 1] "Here are his reflections some time after quitting the ship, during"][[45 15 2] "a black night in an open boat, when almost despairing of reaching any"][[45 15 3] "hospitable shore. \"The dark ocean and swelling waters were nothing; the"][[45 15 4] "fears of being swallowed up by some dreadful tempest, or dashed"][[45 15 5] "upon hidden rocks, with all the other ordinary subjects of fearful"][[45 15 6] "contemplation, seemed scarcely entitled to a moment's thought; the"][[45 15 7] "dismal looking wreck, and THE HORRID ASPECT AND REVENGE OF THE WHALE,"][[45 15 8] "wholly engrossed my reflections, until day again made its appearance.\""][[45 16 1] "In another place--p. ,--he speaks of \"THE MYSTERIOUS AND MORTAL ATTACK"][[45 16 2] "OF THE ANIMAL.\""][[45 18 1] "Secondly: The ship Union, also of Nantucket, was in the year"][[45 18 2] "totally lost off the Azores by a similar onset, but the authentic"][[45 18 3] "particulars of this catastrophe I have never chanced to encounter,"][[45 18 4] "though from the whale hunters I have now and then heard casual allusions"][[45 18 5] "to it."][[45 19 1] "Thirdly: Some eighteen or twenty years ago Commodore J---, then"][[45 19 2] "commanding an American sloop-of-war of the first class, happened to be"][[45 19 3] "dining with a party of whaling captains, on board a Nantucket ship in"][[45 19 4] "the harbor of Oahu, Sandwich Islands. Conversation turning upon whales,"][[45 19 5] "the Commodore was pleased to be sceptical touching the amazing strength"][[45 19 6] "ascribed to them by the professional gentlemen present. He peremptorily"][[45 19 7] "denied for example, that any whale could so smite his stout sloop-of-war"][[45 19 8] "as to cause her to leak so much as a thimbleful. Very good; but there"][[45 19 9] "is more coming. Some weeks after, the Commodore set sail in this"][[45 19 10] "impregnable craft for Valparaiso. But he was stopped on the way by a"][[45 19 11] "portly sperm whale, that begged a few moments' confidential business"][[45 19 12] "with him. That business consisted in fetching the Commodore's craft such"][[45 19 13] "a thwack, that with all his pumps going he made straight for the nearest"][[45 19 14] "port to heave down and repair. I am not superstitious, but I consider"][[45 19 15] "the Commodore's interview with that whale as providential. Was not Saul"][[45 19 16] "of Tarsus converted from unbelief by a similar fright? I tell you, the"][[45 19 17] "sperm whale will stand no nonsense."][[45 20 1] "I will now refer you to Langsdorff's Voyages for a little circumstance"][[45 20 2] "in point, peculiarly interesting to the writer hereof. Langsdorff, you"][[45 20 3] "must know by the way, was attached to the Russian Admiral Krusenstern's"][[45 20 4] "famous Discovery Expedition in the beginning of the present century."][[45 20 5] "Captain Langsdorff thus begins his seventeenth chapter:"][[45 21 1] "\"By the thirteenth of May our ship was ready to sail, and the next day"][[45 21 2] "we were out in the open sea, on our way to Ochotsh. The weather was very"][[45 21 3] "clear and fine, but so intolerably cold that we were obliged to keep on"][[45 21 4] "our fur clothing. For some days we had very little wind; it was not"][[45 21 5] "till the nineteenth that a brisk gale from the northwest sprang up. An"][[45 21 6] "uncommon large whale, the body of which was larger than the ship itself,"][[45 21 7] "lay almost at the surface of the water, but was not perceived by any"][[45 21 8] "one on board till the moment when the ship, which was in full sail,"][[45 21 9] "was almost upon him, so that it was impossible to prevent its striking"][[45 21 10] "against him. We were thus placed in the most imminent danger, as this"][[45 21 11] "gigantic creature, setting up its back, raised the ship three feet at"][[45 21 12] "least out of the water. The masts reeled, and the sails fell altogether,"][[45 21 13] "while we who were below all sprang instantly upon the deck, concluding"][[45 21 14] "that we had struck upon some rock; instead of this we saw the monster"][[45 21 15] "sailing off with the utmost gravity and solemnity. Captain D'Wolf"][[45 21 16] "applied immediately to the pumps to examine whether or not the vessel"][[45 21 17] "had received any damage from the shock, but we found that very happily"][[45 21 18] "it had escaped entirely uninjured.\""][[45 22 1] "Now, the Captain D'Wolf here alluded to as commanding the ship in"][[45 22 2] "question, is a New Englander, who, after a long life of unusual"][[45 22 3] "adventures as a sea-captain, this day resides in the village of"][[45 22 4] "Dorchester near Boston. I have the honour of being a nephew of his. I"][[45 22 5] "have particularly questioned him concerning this passage in Langsdorff."][[45 22 6] "He substantiates every word. The ship, however, was by no means a large"][[45 22 7] "one: a Russian craft built on the Siberian coast, and purchased by my"][[45 22 8] "uncle after bartering away the vessel in which he sailed from home."][[45 23 1] "In that up and down manly book of old-fashioned adventure, so full, too,"][[45 23 2] "of honest wonders--the voyage of Lionel Wafer, one of ancient Dampier's"][[45 23 3] "old chums--I found a little matter set down so like that just quoted"][[45 23 4] "from Langsdorff, that I cannot forbear inserting it here for a"][[45 23 5] "corroborative example, if such be needed."][[45 24 1] "Lionel, it seems, was on his way to \"John Ferdinando,\" as he calls"][[45 24 2] "the modern Juan Fernandes. \"In our way thither,\" he says, \"about four"][[45 24 3] "o'clock in the morning, when we were about one hundred and fifty leagues"][[45 24 4] "from the Main of America, our ship felt a terrible shock, which put our"][[45 24 5] "men in such consternation that they could hardly tell where they were"][[45 24 6] "or what to think; but every one began to prepare for death. And, indeed,"][[45 24 7] "the shock was so sudden and violent, that we took it for granted the"][[45 24 8] "ship had struck against a rock; but when the amazement was a little"][[45 24 9] "over, we cast the lead, and sounded, but found no ground..... The"][[45 24 10] "suddenness of the shock made the guns leap in their carriages, and"][[45 24 11] "several of the men were shaken out of their hammocks. Captain Davis, who"][[45 24 12] "lay with his head on a gun, was thrown out of his cabin!\" Lionel then"][[45 24 13] "goes on to impute the shock to an earthquake, and seems to substantiate"][[45 24 14] "the imputation by stating that a great earthquake, somewhere about"][[45 24 15] "that time, did actually do great mischief along the Spanish land. But"][[45 24 16] "I should not much wonder if, in the darkness of that early hour of the"][[45 24 17] "morning, the shock was after all caused by an unseen whale vertically"][[45 24 18] "bumping the hull from beneath."][[45 25 1] "I might proceed with several more examples, one way or another known to"][[45 25 2] "me, of the great power and malice at times of the sperm whale. In more"][[45 25 3] "than one instance, he has been known, not only to chase the assailing"][[45 25 4] "boats back to their ships, but to pursue the ship itself, and long"][[45 25 5] "withstand all the lances hurled at him from its decks. The English ship"][[45 25 6] "Pusie Hall can tell a story on that head; and, as for his strength,"][[45 25 7] "let me say, that there have been examples where the lines attached to a"][[45 25 8] "running sperm whale have, in a calm, been transferred to the ship, and"][[45 25 9] "secured there; the whale towing her great hull through the water, as a"][[45 25 10] "horse walks off with a cart. Again, it is very often observed that, if"][[45 25 11] "the sperm whale, once struck, is allowed time to rally, he then acts,"][[45 25 12] "not so often with blind rage, as with wilful, deliberate designs of"][[45 25 13] "destruction to his pursuers; nor is it without conveying some eloquent"][[45 25 14] "indication of his character, that upon being attacked he will frequently"][[45 25 15] "open his mouth, and retain it in that dread expansion for several"][[45 25 16] "consecutive minutes. But I must be content with only one more and a"][[45 25 17] "concluding illustration; a remarkable and most significant one, by which"][[45 25 18] "you will not fail to see, that not only is the most marvellous event in"][[45 25 19] "this book corroborated by plain facts of the present day, but that these"][[45 25 20] "marvels (like all marvels) are mere repetitions of the ages; so that for"][[45 25 21] "the millionth time we say amen with Solomon--Verily there is nothing new"][[45 25 22] "under the sun."][[45 26 1] "In the sixth Christian century lived Procopius, a Christian magistrate"][[45 26 2] "of Constantinople, in the days when Justinian was Emperor and Belisarius"][[45 26 3] "general. As many know, he wrote the history of his own times, a work"][[45 26 4] "every way of uncommon value. By the best authorities, he has always been"][[45 26 5] "considered a most trustworthy and unexaggerating historian, except in"][[45 26 6] "some one or two particulars, not at all affecting the matter presently"][[45 26 7] "to be mentioned."][[45 27 1] "Now, in this history of his, Procopius mentions that, during the term"][[45 27 2] "of his prefecture at Constantinople, a great sea-monster was captured"][[45 27 3] "in the neighboring Propontis, or Sea of Marmora, after having destroyed"][[45 27 4] "vessels at intervals in those waters for a period of more than fifty"][[45 27 5] "years. A fact thus set down in substantial history cannot easily be"][[45 27 6] "gainsaid. Nor is there any reason it should be. Of what precise species"][[45 27 7] "this sea-monster was, is not mentioned. But as he destroyed ships, as"][[45 27 8] "well as for other reasons, he must have been a whale; and I am strongly"][[45 27 9] "inclined to think a sperm whale. And I will tell you why. For a long"][[45 27 10] "time I fancied that the sperm whale had been always unknown in the"][[45 27 11] "Mediterranean and the deep waters connecting with it. Even now I am"][[45 27 12] "certain that those seas are not, and perhaps never can be, in the"][[45 27 13] "present constitution of things, a place for his habitual gregarious"][[45 27 14] "resort. But further investigations have recently proved to me, that in"][[45 27 15] "modern times there have been isolated instances of the presence of the"][[45 27 16] "sperm whale in the Mediterranean. I am told, on good authority, that"][[45 27 17] "on the Barbary coast, a Commodore Davis of the British navy found"][[45 27 18] "the skeleton of a sperm whale. Now, as a vessel of war readily passes"][[45 27 19] "through the Dardanelles, hence a sperm whale could, by the same route,"][[45 27 20] "pass out of the Mediterranean into the Propontis."][[45 28 1] "In the Propontis, as far as I can learn, none of that peculiar substance"][[45 28 2] "called BRIT is to be found, the aliment of the right whale. But I have"][[45 28 3] "every reason to believe that the food of the sperm whale--squid or"][[45 28 4] "cuttle-fish--lurks at the bottom of that sea, because large creatures,"][[45 28 5] "but by no means the largest of that sort, have been found at its"][[45 28 6] "surface. If, then, you properly put these statements together, and"][[45 28 7] "reason upon them a bit, you will clearly perceive that, according to all"][[45 28 8] "human reasoning, Procopius's sea-monster, that for half a century stove"][[45 28 9] "the ships of a Roman Emperor, must in all probability have been a sperm"][[45 28 10] "whale."][[46 0 0] "CHAPTER 46. Surmises."][[46 2 1] "Though, consumed with the hot fire of his purpose, Ahab in all his"][[46 2 2] "thoughts and actions ever had in view the ultimate capture of Moby Dick;"][[46 2 3] "though he seemed ready to sacrifice all mortal interests to that one"][[46 2 4] "passion; nevertheless it may have been that he was by nature and long"][[46 2 5] "habituation far too wedded to a fiery whaleman's ways, altogether to"][[46 2 6] "abandon the collateral prosecution of the voyage. Or at least if"][[46 2 7] "this were otherwise, there were not wanting other motives much more"][[46 2 8] "influential with him. It would be refining too much, perhaps, even"][[46 2 9] "considering his monomania, to hint that his vindictiveness towards the"][[46 2 10] "White Whale might have possibly extended itself in some degree to all"][[46 2 11] "sperm whales, and that the more monsters he slew by so much the more he"][[46 2 12] "multiplied the chances that each subsequently encountered whale would"][[46 2 13] "prove to be the hated one he hunted. But if such an hypothesis be indeed"][[46 2 14] "exceptionable, there were still additional considerations which, though"][[46 2 15] "not so strictly according with the wildness of his ruling passion, yet"][[46 2 16] "were by no means incapable of swaying him."][[46 3 1] "To accomplish his object Ahab must use tools; and of all tools used in"][[46 3 2] "the shadow of the moon, men are most apt to get out of order. He knew,"][[46 3 3] "for example, that however magnetic his ascendency in some respects was"][[46 3 4] "over Starbuck, yet that ascendency did not cover the complete spiritual"][[46 3 5] "man any more than mere corporeal superiority involves intellectual"][[46 3 6] "mastership; for to the purely spiritual, the intellectual but stand in a"][[46 3 7] "sort of corporeal relation. Starbuck's body and Starbuck's coerced will"][[46 3 8] "were Ahab's, so long as Ahab kept his magnet at Starbuck's brain; still"][[46 3 9] "he knew that for all this the chief mate, in his soul, abhorred his"][[46 3 10] "captain's quest, and could he, would joyfully disintegrate himself from"][[46 3 11] "it, or even frustrate it. It might be that a long interval would elapse"][[46 3 12] "ere the White Whale was seen. During that long interval Starbuck"][[46 3 13] "would ever be apt to fall into open relapses of rebellion against his"][[46 3 14] "captain's leadership, unless some ordinary, prudential, circumstantial"][[46 3 15] "influences were brought to bear upon him. Not only that, but the subtle"][[46 3 16] "insanity of Ahab respecting Moby Dick was noways more significantly"][[46 3 17] "manifested than in his superlative sense and shrewdness in foreseeing"][[46 3 18] "that, for the present, the hunt should in some way be stripped of that"][[46 3 19] "strange imaginative impiousness which naturally invested it; that"][[46 3 20] "the full terror of the voyage must be kept withdrawn into the obscure"][[46 3 21] "background (for few men's courage is proof against protracted meditation"][[46 3 22] "unrelieved by action); that when they stood their long night watches,"][[46 3 23] "his officers and men must have some nearer things to think of than Moby"][[46 3 24] "Dick. For however eagerly and impetuously the savage crew had hailed the"][[46 3 25] "announcement of his quest; yet all sailors of all sorts are more or less"][[46 3 26] "capricious and unreliable--they live in the varying outer weather, and"][[46 3 27] "they inhale its fickleness--and when retained for any object remote and"][[46 3 28] "blank in the pursuit, however promissory of life and passion in the"][[46 3 29] "end, it is above all things requisite that temporary interests and"][[46 3 30] "employments should intervene and hold them healthily suspended for the"][[46 3 31] "final dash."][[46 4 1] "Nor was Ahab unmindful of another thing. In times of strong emotion"][[46 4 2] "mankind disdain all base considerations; but such times are evanescent."][[46 4 3] "The permanent constitutional condition of the manufactured man, thought"][[46 4 4] "Ahab, is sordidness. Granting that the White Whale fully incites the"][[46 4 5] "hearts of this my savage crew, and playing round their savageness even"][[46 4 6] "breeds a certain generous knight-errantism in them, still, while for the"][[46 4 7] "love of it they give chase to Moby Dick, they must also have food"][[46 4 8] "for their more common, daily appetites. For even the high lifted and"][[46 4 9] "chivalric Crusaders of old times were not content to traverse two"][[46 4 10] "thousand miles of land to fight for their holy sepulchre, without"][[46 4 11] "committing burglaries, picking pockets, and gaining other pious"][[46 4 12] "perquisites by the way. Had they been strictly held to their one final"][[46 4 13] "and romantic object--that final and romantic object, too many would have"][[46 4 14] "turned from in disgust. I will not strip these men, thought Ahab, of all"][[46 4 15] "hopes of cash--aye, cash. They may scorn cash now; but let some months"][[46 4 16] "go by, and no perspective promise of it to them, and then this same"][[46 4 17] "quiescent cash all at once mutinying in them, this same cash would soon"][[46 4 18] "cashier Ahab."][[46 5 1] "Nor was there wanting still another precautionary motive more related"][[46 5 2] "to Ahab personally. Having impulsively, it is probable, and perhaps"][[46 5 3] "somewhat prematurely revealed the prime but private purpose of the"][[46 5 4] "Pequod's voyage, Ahab was now entirely conscious that, in so doing,"][[46 5 5] "he had indirectly laid himself open to the unanswerable charge of"][[46 5 6] "usurpation; and with perfect impunity, both moral and legal, his crew"][[46 5 7] "if so disposed, and to that end competent, could refuse all further"][[46 5 8] "obedience to him, and even violently wrest from him the command. From"][[46 5 9] "even the barely hinted imputation of usurpation, and the possible"][[46 5 10] "consequences of such a suppressed impression gaining ground, Ahab must"][[46 5 11] "of course have been most anxious to protect himself. That protection"][[46 5 12] "could only consist in his own predominating brain and heart and hand,"][[46 5 13] "backed by a heedful, closely calculating attention to every minute"][[46 5 14] "atmospheric influence which it was possible for his crew to be subjected"][[46 5 15] "to."][[46 6 1] "For all these reasons then, and others perhaps too analytic to be"][[46 6 2] "verbally developed here, Ahab plainly saw that he must still in a good"][[46 6 3] "degree continue true to the natural, nominal purpose of the Pequod's"][[46 6 4] "voyage; observe all customary usages; and not only that, but force"][[46 6 5] "himself to evince all his well known passionate interest in the general"][[46 6 6] "pursuit of his profession."][[46 7 1] "Be all this as it may, his voice was now often heard hailing the three"][[46 7 2] "mast-heads and admonishing them to keep a bright look-out, and not omit"][[46 7 3] "reporting even a porpoise. This vigilance was not long without reward."][[47 0 0] "CHAPTER 47. The Mat-Maker."][[47 2 1] "It was a cloudy, sultry afternoon; the seamen were lazily lounging"][[47 2 2] "about the decks, or vacantly gazing over into the lead-coloured waters."][[47 2 3] "Queequeg and I were mildly employed weaving what is called a sword-mat,"][[47 2 4] "for an additional lashing to our boat. So still and subdued and yet"][[47 2 5] "somehow preluding was all the scene, and such an incantation of reverie"][[47 2 6] "lurked in the air, that each silent sailor seemed resolved into his own"][[47 2 7] "invisible self."][[47 3 1] "I was the attendant or page of Queequeg, while busy at the mat. As I"][[47 3 2] "kept passing and repassing the filling or woof of marline between"][[47 3 3] "the long yarns of the warp, using my own hand for the shuttle, and as"][[47 3 4] "Queequeg, standing sideways, ever and anon slid his heavy oaken sword"][[47 3 5] "between the threads, and idly looking off upon the water, carelessly and"][[47 3 6] "unthinkingly drove home every yarn: I say so strange a dreaminess did"][[47 3 7] "there then reign all over the ship and all over the sea, only broken by"][[47 3 8] "the intermitting dull sound of the sword, that it seemed as if this were"][[47 3 9] "the Loom of Time, and I myself were a shuttle mechanically weaving"][[47 3 10] "and weaving away at the Fates. There lay the fixed threads of the warp"][[47 3 11] "subject to but one single, ever returning, unchanging vibration, and"][[47 3 12] "that vibration merely enough to admit of the crosswise interblending"][[47 3 13] "of other threads with its own. This warp seemed necessity; and here,"][[47 3 14] "thought I, with my own hand I ply my own shuttle and weave my own"][[47 3 15] "destiny into these unalterable threads. Meantime, Queequeg's impulsive,"][[47 3 16] "indifferent sword, sometimes hitting the woof slantingly, or crookedly,"][[47 3 17] "or strongly, or weakly, as the case might be; and by this difference"][[47 3 18] "in the concluding blow producing a corresponding contrast in the final"][[47 3 19] "aspect of the completed fabric; this savage's sword, thought I,"][[47 3 20] "which thus finally shapes and fashions both warp and woof; this"][[47 3 21] "easy, indifferent sword must be chance--aye, chance, free will, and"][[47 3 22] "necessity--nowise incompatible--all interweavingly working together."][[47 3 23] "The straight warp of necessity, not to be swerved from its ultimate"][[47 3 24] "course--its every alternating vibration, indeed, only tending to that;"][[47 3 25] "free will still free to ply her shuttle between given threads; and"][[47 3 26] "chance, though restrained in its play within the right lines of"][[47 3 27] "necessity, and sideways in its motions directed by free will, though"][[47 3 28] "thus prescribed to by both, chance by turns rules either, and has the"][[47 3 29] "last featuring blow at events."][[47 5 1] "Thus we were weaving and weaving away when I started at a sound so"][[47 5 2] "strange, long drawn, and musically wild and unearthly, that the ball"][[47 5 3] "of free will dropped from my hand, and I stood gazing up at the clouds"][[47 5 4] "whence that voice dropped like a wing. High aloft in the cross-trees was"][[47 5 5] "that mad Gay-Header, Tashtego. His body was reaching eagerly forward,"][[47 5 6] "his hand stretched out like a wand, and at brief sudden intervals he"][[47 5 7] "continued his cries. To be sure the same sound was that very moment"][[47 5 8] "perhaps being heard all over the seas, from hundreds of whalemen's"][[47 5 9] "look-outs perched as high in the air; but from few of those lungs could"][[47 5 10] "that accustomed old cry have derived such a marvellous cadence as from"][[47 5 11] "Tashtego the Indian's."][[47 6 1] "As he stood hovering over you half suspended in air, so wildly and"][[47 6 2] "eagerly peering towards the horizon, you would have thought him some"][[47 6 3] "prophet or seer beholding the shadows of Fate, and by those wild cries"][[47 6 4] "announcing their coming."][[47 7 1] "\"There she blows! there! there! there! she blows! she blows!\""][[47 8 1] "\"Where-away?\""][[47 9 1] "\"On the lee-beam, about two miles off! a school of them!\""][[47 10 1] "Instantly all was commotion."][[47 11 1] "The Sperm Whale blows as a clock ticks, with the same undeviating and"][[47 11 2] "reliable uniformity. And thereby whalemen distinguish this fish from"][[47 11 3] "other tribes of his genus."][[47 12 1] "\"There go flukes!\" was now the cry from Tashtego; and the whales"][[47 12 2] "disappeared."][[47 13 1] "\"Quick, steward!\" cried Ahab. \"Time! time!\""][[47 14 1] "Dough-Boy hurried below, glanced at the watch, and reported the exact"][[47 14 2] "minute to Ahab."][[47 15 1] "The ship was now kept away from the wind, and she went gently rolling"][[47 15 2] "before it. He loaded it, and rammed"][[48 32 7] "home the loading with his thumb-end; but hardly had he ignited his match"][[48 32 8] "across the rough sandpaper of his hand, when Tashtego, his harpooneer,"][[48 32 9] "whose eyes had been setting to windward like two fixed stars, suddenly"][[48 32 10] "dropped like light from his erect attitude to his seat, crying out in a"][[48 32 11] "quick phrensy of hurry, \"Down, down all, and give way!--there they are!\""][[48 33 1] "To a landsman, no whale, nor any sign of a herring, would have been"][[48 33 2] "visible at that moment; nothing but a troubled bit of greenish white"][[48 33 3] "water, and thin scattered puffs of vapour hovering over it, and"][[48 33 4] "suffusingly blowing off to leeward, like the confused scud from white"][[48 33 5] "rolling billows. The air around suddenly vibrated and tingled, as it"][[48 33 6] "were, like the air over intensely heated plates of iron. Beneath this"][[48 33 7] "atmospheric waving and curling, and partially beneath a thin layer of"][[48 33 8] "water, also, the whales were swimming. Seen in advance of all the other"][[48 33 9] "indications, the puffs of vapour they spouted, seemed their forerunning"][[48 33 10] "couriers and detached flying outriders."][[48 34 1] "All four boats were now in keen pursuit of that one spot of troubled"][[48 34 2] "water and air. But it bade fair to outstrip them; it flew on and on,"][[48 34 3] "as a mass of interblending bubbles borne down a rapid stream from the"][[48 34 4] "hills."][[48 35 1] "\"Pull, pull, my good boys,\" said Starbuck, in the lowest possible but"][[48 35 2] "intensest concentrated whisper to his men; while the sharp fixed glance"][[48 35 3] "from his eyes darted straight ahead of the bow, almost seemed as two"][[48 35 4] "visible needles in two unerring binnacle compasses. He did not say much"][[48 35 5] "to his crew, though, nor did his crew say anything to him. Only the"][[48 35 6] "silence of the boat was at intervals startlingly pierced by one of his"][[48 35 7] "peculiar whispers, now harsh with command, now soft with entreaty."][[48 36 1] "How different the loud little King-Post. \"Sing out and say something,"][[48 36 2] "my hearties. Roar and pull, my thunderbolts! Beach me, beach me on their"][[48 36 3] "black backs, boys; only do that for me, and I'll sign over to you my"][[48 36 4] "Martha's Vineyard plantation, boys; including wife and children, boys."][[48 36 5] "Lay me on--lay me on! O Lord, Lord! but I shall go stark, staring mad!"][[48 36 6] "See! see that white water!\" And so shouting, he pulled his hat from his"][[48 36 7] "head, and stamped up and down on it; then picking it up, flirted it far"][[48 36 8] "off upon the sea; and finally fell to rearing and plunging in the boat's"][[48 36 9] "stern like a crazed colt from the prairie."][[48 37 1] "\"Look at that chap now,\" philosophically drawled Stubb, who, with his"][[48 37 2] "unlighted short pipe, mechanically retained between his teeth, at a"][[48 37 3] "short distance, followed after--\"He's got fits, that Flask has. Fits?"][[48 37 4] "yes, give him fits--that's the very word--pitch fits into 'em. Merrily,"][[48 37 5] "merrily, hearts-alive. Pudding for supper, you know;--merry's the word."][[48 37 6] "Pull, babes--pull, sucklings--pull, all. But what the devil are you"][[48 37 7] "hurrying about? Softly, softly, and steadily, my men. Only pull, and"][[48 37 8] "keep pulling; nothing more. Crack all your backbones, and bite your"][[48 37 9] "knives in two--that's all. Take it easy--why don't ye take it easy, I"][[48 37 10] "say, and burst all your livers and lungs!\""][[48 38 1] "But what it was that inscrutable Ahab said to that tiger-yellow crew of"][[48 38 2] "his--these were words best omitted here; for you live under the blessed"][[48 38 3] "light of the evangelical land. Only the infidel sharks in the audacious"][[48 38 4] "seas may give ear to such words, when, with tornado brow, and eyes of"][[48 38 5] "red murder, and foam-glued lips, Ahab leaped after his prey."][[48 39 1] "Meanwhile, all the boats tore on. The repeated specific allusions of"][[48 39 2] "Flask to \"that whale,\" as he called the fictitious monster which"][[48 39 3] "he declared to be incessantly tantalizing his boat's bow with its"][[48 39 4] "tail--these allusions of his were at times so vivid and life-like, that"][[48 39 5] "they would cause some one or two of his men to snatch a fearful look"][[48 39 6] "over the shoulder. But this was against all rule; for the oarsmen"][[48 39 7] "must put out their eyes, and ram a skewer through their necks; usage"][[48 39 8] "pronouncing that they must have no organs but ears, and no limbs but"][[48 39 9] "arms, in these critical moments."][[48 40 1] "It was a sight full of quick wonder and awe! The vast swells of the"][[48 40 2] "omnipotent sea; the surging, hollow roar they made, as they rolled along"][[48 40 3] "the eight gunwales, like gigantic bowls in a boundless bowling-green;"][[48 40 4] "the brief suspended agony of the boat, as it would tip for an instant on"][[48 40 5] "the knife-like edge of the sharper waves, that almost seemed threatening"][[48 40 6] "to cut it in two; the sudden profound dip into the watery glens and"][[48 40 7] "hollows; the keen spurrings and goadings to gain the top of the opposite"][[48 40 8] "hill; the headlong, sled-like slide down its other side;--all these,"][[48 40 9] "with the cries of the headsmen and harpooneers, and the shuddering gasps"][[48 40 10] "of the oarsmen, with the wondrous sight of the ivory Pequod bearing"][[48 40 11] "down upon her boats with outstretched sails, like a wild hen after her"][[48 40 12] "screaming brood;--all this was thrilling."][[48 41 1] "Not the raw recruit, marching from the bosom of his wife into the fever"][[48 41 2] "heat of his first battle; not the dead man's ghost encountering the"][[48 41 3] "first unknown phantom in the other world;--neither of these can feel"][[48 41 4] "stranger and stronger emotions than that man does, who for the first"][[48 41 5] "time finds himself pulling into the charmed, churned circle of the"][[48 41 6] "hunted sperm whale."][[48 42 1] "The dancing white water made by the chase was now becoming more and more"][[48 42 2] "visible, owing to the increasing darkness of the dun cloud-shadows"][[48 42 3] "flung upon the sea. The jets of vapour no longer blended, but tilted"][[48 42 4] "everywhere to right and left; the whales seemed separating their wakes."][[48 42 5] "The boats were pulled more apart; Starbuck giving chase to three whales"][[48 42 6] "running dead to leeward. Our sail was now set, and, with the still"][[48 42 7] "rising wind, we rushed along; the boat going with such madness through"][[48 42 8] "the water, that the lee oars could scarcely be worked rapidly enough to"][[48 42 9] "escape being torn from the row-locks."][[48 43 1] "Soon we were running through a suffusing wide veil of mist; neither ship"][[48 43 2] "nor boat to be seen."][[48 44 1] "\"Give way, men,\" whispered Starbuck, drawing still further aft the sheet"][[48 44 2] "of his sail; \"there is time to kill a fish yet before the squall comes."][[48 44 3] "There's white water again!--close to! Spring!\""][[48 45 1] "Soon after, two cries in quick succession on each side of us denoted"][[48 45 2] "that the other boats had got fast; but hardly were they overheard, when"][[48 45 3] "with a lightning-like hurtling whisper Starbuck said: \"Stand up!\" and"][[48 45 4] "Queequeg, harpoon in hand, sprang to his feet."][[48 46 1] "Though not one of the oarsmen was then facing the life and death peril"][[48 46 2] "so close to them ahead, yet with their eyes on the intense countenance"][[48 46 3] "of the mate in the stern of the boat, they knew that the imminent"][[48 46 4] "instant had come; they heard, too, an enormous wallowing sound as of"][[48 46 5] "fifty elephants stirring in their litter. THERE, THERE, give it to him!\" whispered Starbuck."][[48 48 1] "A short rushing sound leaped out of the boat; it was the darted iron of"][[48 48 2] "Queequeg. Then all in one welded commotion came an invisible push from"][[48 48 3] "astern, while forward the boat seemed striking on a ledge; the sail"][[48 48 4] "collapsed and exploded; a gush of scalding vapour shot up near by;"][[48 48 5] "something rolled and tumbled like an earthquake beneath us. The whole"][[48 48 6] "crew were half suffocated as they were tossed helter-skelter into the"][[48 48 7] "white curdling cream of the squall. Squall, whale, and harpoon had all"][[48 48 8] "blended together; and the whale, merely grazed by the iron, escaped."][[48 49 1] "Though completely swamped, the boat was nearly unharmed. Swimming round"][[48 49 2] "it we picked up the floating oars, and lashing them across the gunwale,"][[48 49 3] "tumbled back to our places. There we sat up to our knees in the sea, the"][[48 49 4] "water covering every rib and plank, so that to our downward gazing eyes"][[48 49 5] "the suspended craft seemed a coral boat grown up to us from the bottom"][[48 49 6] "of the ocean."][[48 50 1] "The wind increased to a howl; the waves dashed their bucklers together;"][[48 50 2] "the whole squall roared, forked, and crackled around us like a white"][[48 50 3] "fire upon the prairie, in which, unconsumed, we were burning; immortal"][[48 50 4] "in these jaws of death! In vain we hailed the other boats; as well roar"][[48 50 5] "to the live coals down the chimney of a flaming furnace as hail those"][[48 50 6] "boats in that storm. Meanwhile the driving scud, rack, and mist, grew"][[48 50 7] "darker with the shadows of night; no sign of the ship could be seen."][[48 50 8] "The rising sea forbade all attempts to bale out the boat. The oars were"][[48 50 9] "useless as propellers, performing now the office of life-preservers."][[48 50 10] "So, cutting the lashing of the waterproof match keg, after many failures"][[48 50 11] "Starbuck contrived to ignite the lamp in the lantern; then stretching"][[48 50 12] "it on a waif pole, handed it to Queequeg as the standard-bearer of this"][[48 50 13] "forlorn hope. There, then, he sat, holding up that imbecile candle in"][[48 50 14] "the heart of that almighty forlornness. There, then, he sat, the sign"][[48 50 15] "and symbol of a man without faith, hopelessly holding up hope in the"][[48 50 16] "midst of despair."][[48 51 1] "Wet, drenched through, and shivering cold, despairing of ship or boat,"][[48 51 2] "we lifted up our eyes as the dawn came on. The mist still spread over"][[48 51 3] "the sea, the empty lantern lay crushed in the bottom of the boat."][[48 51 4] "Suddenly Queequeg started to his feet, hollowing his hand to his ear."][[48 51 5] "We all heard a faint creaking, as of ropes and yards hitherto muffled by"][[48 51 6] "the storm. Affrighted, we all sprang into the sea as"][[48 51 8] "the ship at last loomed into view, bearing right down upon us within a"][[48 51 9] "distance of not much more than its length."][[48 52 1] "Floating on the waves we saw the abandoned boat, as for one instant it"][[48 52 2] "tossed and gaped beneath the ship's bows like a chip at the base of a"][[48 52 3] "cataract; and then the vast hull rolled over it, and it was seen no"][[48 52 4] "more till it came up weltering astern. Again we swam for it, were dashed"][[48 52 5] "against it by the seas, and were at last taken up and safely landed on"][[48 52 6] "board. Ere the squall came close to, the other boats had cut loose from"][[48 52 7] "their fish and returned to the ship in good time. The ship had given us"][[48 52 8] "up, but was still cruising, if haply it might light upon some token of"][[48 52 9] "our perishing,--an oar or a lance pole."][[49 0 0] "CHAPTER 49. The Hyena."][[49 2 1] "There are certain queer times and occasions in this strange mixed affair"][[49 2 2] "we call life when a man takes this whole universe for a vast practical"][[49 2 3] "joke, though the wit thereof he but dimly discerns, and more than"][[49 2 4] "suspects that the joke is at nobody's expense but his own. However,"][[49 2 5] "nothing dispirits, and nothing seems worth while disputing. He bolts"][[49 2 6] "down all events, all creeds, and beliefs, and persuasions, all hard"][[49 2 7] "things visible and invisible, never mind how knobby; as an ostrich of"][[49 2 8] "potent digestion gobbles down bullets and gun flints. And as for small"][[49 2 9] "difficulties and worryings, prospects of sudden disaster, peril of"][[49 2 10] "life and limb; all these, and death itself, seem to him only sly,"][[49 2 11] "good-natured hits, and jolly punches in the side bestowed by the unseen"][[49 2 12] "and unaccountable old joker. That odd sort of wayward mood I am speaking"][[49 2 13] "of, comes over a man only in some time of extreme tribulation; it comes"][[49 2 14] "in the very midst of his earnestness, so that what just before might"][[49 2 15] "have seemed to him a thing most momentous, now seems but a part of the"][[49 2 16] "general joke. There is nothing like the perils of whaling to breed this"][[49 2 17] "free and easy sort of genial, desperado philosophy; and with it I now"][[49 2 18] "regarded this whole voyage of the Pequod, and the great White Whale its"][[49 2 19] "object."][[49 3 1] "\"Queequeg,\" said I, when they had dragged me, the last man, to the deck,"][[49 3 2] "and I was still shaking myself in my jacket to fling off the water;"][[49 3 3] "\"Queequeg, my fine friend, does this sort of thing often happen?\""][[49 3 4] "Without much emotion, though soaked through just like me, he gave me to"][[49 3 5] "understand that such things did often happen."][[49 4 1] "\"Mr. Stubb,\" said I, turning to that worthy, who, buttoned up in his"][[49 4 2] "oil-jacket, was now calmly smoking his pipe in the rain; \"Mr. Stubb, I"][[49 4 3] "think I have heard you say that of all whalemen you ever met, our chief"][[49 4 4] "mate, Mr. Starbuck, is by far the most careful and prudent. I suppose"][[49 4 5] "then, that going plump on a flying whale with your sail set in a foggy"][[49 4 6] "squall is the height of a whaleman's discretion?\""][[49 5 1] "\"Certain. I've lowered for whales from a leaking ship in a gale off Cape"][[49 5 2] "Horn.\""][[49 6 1] "\"Mr. Flask,\" said I, turning to little King-Post, who was standing close"][[49 6 2] "by; \"you are experienced in these things, and I am not. Will you tell"][[49 6 3] "me whether it is an unalterable law in this fishery, Mr. Flask, for an"][[49 6 4] "oarsman to break his own back pulling himself back-foremost into death's"][[49 6 5] "jaws?\""][[49 7 1] "\"Can't you twist that smaller?\" said Flask. \"Yes, that's the law."][[49 7 2] "I should like to see a boat's crew backing water up to a whale face"][[49 7 3] "foremost. Ha, ha! the whale would give them squint for squint, mind"][[49 7 4] "that!\""][[49 8 1] "Here then, from three impartial witnesses, I had a deliberate statement"][[49 8 2] "of the entire case. Considering, therefore, that squalls and capsizings"][[49 8 3] "in the water and consequent bivouacks on the deep, were matters"][[49 8 4] "of common occurrence in this kind of life; considering that at the"][[49 8 5] "superlatively critical instant of going on to the whale I must resign my"][[49 8 6] "life into the hands of him who steered the boat--oftentimes a fellow who"][[49 8 7] "at that very moment is in his impetuousness upon the point of scuttling"][[49 8 8] "the craft with his own frantic stampings; considering that the"][[49 8 9] "particular disaster to our own particular boat was chiefly to be imputed"][[49 8 10] "to Starbuck's driving on to his whale almost in the teeth of a squall,"][[49 8 11] "and considering that Starbuck, notwithstanding, was famous for his"][[49 8 12] "great heedfulness in the fishery; considering that I belonged to this"][[49 8 13] "uncommonly prudent Starbuck's boat; and finally considering in what a"][[49 8 14] "devil's chase I was implicated, touching the White Whale: taking all"][[49 8 15] "things together, I say, I thought I might as well go below and make a"][[49 8 16] "rough draft of my will. \"Queequeg,\" said I, \"come along, you shall be my"][[49 8 17] "lawyer, executor, and legatee.\""][[49 9 1] "It may seem strange that of all men sailors should be tinkering at their"][[49 9 2] "last wills and testaments, but there are no people in the world more"][[49 9 3] "fond of that diversion. This was the fourth time in my nautical life"][[49 9 4] "that I had done the same thing. After the ceremony was concluded upon"][[49 9 5] "the present occasion, I felt all the easier; a stone was rolled away"][[49 9 6] "from my heart. Besides, all the days I should now live would be as good"][[49 9 7] "as the days that Lazarus lived after his resurrection; a supplementary"][[49 9 8] "clean gain of so many months or weeks as the case might be. I survived"][[49 9 9] "myself; my death and burial were locked up in my chest. Ahab's Boat and Crew. Fedallah."][[50 2 1] "\"Who would have thought it, Flask!\" cried Stubb; \"if I had but one leg"][[50 2 2] "you would not catch me in a boat, unless maybe to stop the plug-hole"][[50 2 3] "with my timber toe. Oh! he's a wonderful old man!\""][[50 3 1] "\"I don't think it so strange, after all, on that account,\" said Flask."][[50 3 2] "\"If his leg were off at the hip, now, it would be a different thing."][[50 3 3] "That would disable him; but he has one knee, and good part of the other"][[50 3 4] "left, you know.\""][[50 4 1] "\"I don't know that, my little man; I never yet saw him kneel.\""][[50 6 1] "Among whale-wise people it has often been argued whether, considering"][[50 6 2] "the paramount importance of his life to the success of the voyage, it is"][[50 6 3] "right for a whaling captain to jeopardize that life in the active perils"][[50 6 4] "of the chase. So Tamerlane's soldiers often argued with tears in their"][[50 6 5] "eyes, whether that invaluable life of his ought to be carried into the"][[50 6 6] "thickest of the fight."][[50 7 1] "But with Ahab the question assumed a modified aspect. Considering"][[50 7 2] "that with two legs man is but a hobbling wight in all times of danger;"][[50 7 3] "considering that the pursuit of whales is always under great and"][[50 7 4] "extraordinary difficulties; that every individual moment, indeed, then"][[50 7 5] "comprises a peril; under these circumstances is it wise for any"][[50 7 6] "maimed man to enter a whale-boat in the hunt? As a general thing, the"][[50 7 7] "joint-owners of the Pequod must have plainly thought not."][[50 8 1] "Ahab well knew that although his friends at home would think little of"][[50 8 2] "his entering a boat in certain comparatively harmless vicissitudes of"][[50 8 3] "the chase, for the sake of being near the scene of action and giving"][[50 8 4] "his orders in person, yet for Captain Ahab to have a boat actually"][[50 8 5] "apportioned to him as a regular headsman in the hunt--above all for"][[50 8 6] "Captain Ahab to be supplied with five extra men, as that same boat's"][[50 8 7] "crew, he well knew that such generous conceits never entered the heads"][[50 8 8] "of the owners of the Pequod. Therefore he had not solicited a boat's"][[50 8 9] "crew from them, nor had he in any way hinted his desires on that head."][[50 8 10] "Nevertheless he had taken private measures of his own touching all"][[50 8 11] "that matter. Until Cabaco's published discovery, the sailors had little"][[50 8 12] "foreseen it, though to be sure when, after being a little while out"][[50 8 13] "of port, all hands had concluded the customary business of fitting the"][[50 8 14] "whaleboats for service; when some time after this Ahab was now and then"][[50 8 15] "found bestirring himself in the matter of making thole-pins with his"][[50 8 16] "own hands for what was thought to be one of the spare boats, and even"][[50 8 17] "solicitously cutting the small wooden skewers, which when the line is"][[50 8 18] "running out are pinned over the groove in the bow: when all this was"][[50 8 19] "observed in him, and particularly his solicitude in having an extra"][[50 8 20] "coat of sheathing in the bottom of the boat, as if to make it better"][[50 8 21] "withstand the pointed pressure of his ivory limb; and also the anxiety"][[50 8 22] "he evinced in exactly shaping the thigh board, or clumsy cleat, as it is"][[50 8 23] "sometimes called, the horizontal piece in the boat's bow for bracing the"][[50 8 24] "knee against in darting or stabbing at the whale; when it was observed"][[50 8 25] "how often he stood up in that boat with his solitary knee fixed in the"][[50 8 26] "semi-circular depression in the cleat, and with the carpenter's chisel"][[50 8 27] "gouged out a little here and straightened it a little there; all these"][[50 8 28] "things, I say, had awakened much interest and curiosity at the time. But"][[50 8 29] "almost everybody supposed that this particular preparative heedfulness"][[50 8 30] "in Ahab must only be with a view to the ultimate chase of Moby Dick;"][[50 8 31] "for he had already revealed his intention to hunt that mortal monster"][[50 8 32] "in person. But such a supposition did by no means involve the remotest"][[50 8 33] "suspicion as to any boat's crew being assigned to that boat."][[50 9 1] "Now, with the subordinate phantoms, what wonder remained soon waned"][[50 9 2] "away; for in a whaler wonders soon wane. Besides, now and then such"][[50 9 3] "unaccountable odds and ends of strange nations come up from the unknown"][[50 9 4] "nooks and ash-holes of the earth to man these floating outlaws of"][[50 9 5] "whalers; and the ships themselves often pick up such queer castaway"][[50 9 6] "creatures found tossing about the open sea on planks, bits of wreck,"][[50 9 7] "oars, whaleboats, canoes, blown-off Japanese junks, and what not; that"][[50 9 8] "Beelzebub himself might climb up the side and step down into the cabin"][[50 9 9] "to chat with the captain, and it would not create any unsubduable"][[50 9 10] "excitement in the forecastle."][[50 10 1] "But be all this as it may, certain it is that while the subordinate"][[50 10 2] "phantoms soon found their place among the crew, though still as it were"][[50 10 3] "somehow distinct from them, yet that hair-turbaned Fedallah remained"][[50 10 4] "a muffled mystery to the last. Whence he came in a mannerly world like"][[50 10 5] "this, by what sort of unaccountable tie he soon evinced himself to be"][[50 10 6] "linked with Ahab's peculiar fortunes; nay, so far as to have some sort"][[50 10 7] "of a half-hinted influence; Heaven knows, but it might have been even"][[50 10 8] "authority over him; all this none knew. But one cannot sustain"][[50 10 9] "an indifferent air concerning Fedallah. He was such a creature as"][[50 10 10] "civilized, domestic people in the temperate zone only see in their"][[50 10 11] "dreams, and that but dimly; but the like of whom now and then glide"][[50 10 12] "among the unchanging Asiatic communities, especially the Oriental isles"][[50 10 13] "to the east of the continent--those insulated, immemorial, unalterable"][[50 10 14] "countries, which even in these modern days still preserve much of the"][[50 10 15] "ghostly aboriginalness of earth's primal generations, when the memory of"][[50 10 16] "the first man was a distinct recollection, and all men his descendants,"][[50 10 17] "unknowing whence he came, eyed each other as real phantoms, and asked of"][[50 10 18] "the sun and the moon why they were created and to what end; when though,"][[50 10 19] "according to Genesis, the angels indeed consorted with the daughters of"][[50 10 20] "men, the devils also, add the uncanonical Rabbins, indulged in mundane"][[50 10 21] "amours."][[51 0 0] "CHAPTER 51. The Spirit-Spout."][[51 2 1] "Days, weeks passed, and under easy sail, the ivory Pequod had slowly"][[51 2 2] "swept across four several cruising-grounds; that off the Azores; off the"][[51 2 3] "Cape de Verdes; on the Plate (so called), being off the mouth of the"][[51 2 4] "Rio de la Plata; and the Carrol Ground, an unstaked, watery locality,"][[51 2 5] "southerly from St. Helena."][[51 3 1] "It was while gliding through these latter waters that one serene and"][[51 3 2] "moonlight night, when all the waves rolled by like scrolls of silver;"][[51 3 3] "and, by their soft, suffusing seethings, made what seemed a silvery"][[51 3 4] "silence, not a solitude; on such a silent night a silvery jet was seen"][[51 3 5] "far in advance of the white bubbles at the bow. Lit up by the moon, it"][[51 3 6] "looked celestial; seemed some plumed and glittering god uprising from"][[51 3 7] "the sea. Fedallah first descried this jet. For of these moonlight"][[51 3 8] "nights, it was his wont to mount to the main-mast head, and stand a"][[51 3 9] "look-out there, with the same precision as if it had been day. And yet,"][[51 3 10] "though herds of whales were seen by night, not one whaleman in a hundred"][[51 3 11] "would venture a lowering for them. You may think with what emotions,"][[51 3 12] "then, the seamen beheld this old Oriental perched aloft at such unusual"][[51 3 13] "hours; his turban and the moon, companions in one sky. But when, after"][[51 3 14] "spending his uniform interval there for several successive nights"][[51 3 15] "without uttering a single sound; when, after all this silence, his"][[51 3 16] "unearthly voice was heard announcing that silvery, moon-lit jet, every"][[51 3 17] "reclining mariner started to his feet as if some winged spirit had"][[51 3 18] "lighted in the rigging, and hailed the mortal crew. \"There she blows!\""][[51 3 19] "Had the trump of judgment blown, they could not have quivered more; yet"][[51 3 20] "still they felt no terror; rather pleasure. For though it was a most"][[51 3 21] "unwonted hour, yet so impressive was the cry, and so deliriously"][[51 3 22] "exciting, that almost every soul on board instinctively desired a"][[51 3 23] "lowering."][[51 4 1] "Walking the deck with quick, side-lunging strides, Ahab commanded the"][[51 4 2] "t'gallant sails and royals to be set, and every stunsail spread. The"][[51 4 3] "best man in the ship must take the helm. Then, with every mast-head"][[51 4 4] "manned, the piled-up craft rolled down before the wind. The strange,"][[51 4 5] "upheaving, lifting tendency of the taffrail breeze filling the hollows"][[51 4 6] "of so many sails, made the buoyant, hovering deck to feel like air"][[51 4 7] "beneath the feet; while still she rushed along, as if two antagonistic"][[51 4 8] "influences were struggling in her--one to mount direct to heaven, the"][[51 4 9] "other to drive yawingly to some horizontal goal. And had you watched"][[51 4 10] "Ahab's face that night, you would have thought that in him also two"][[51 4 11] "different things were warring. While his one live leg made lively echoes"][[51 4 12] "along the deck, every stroke of his dead limb sounded like a coffin-tap."][[51 4 13] "On life and death this old man walked. But though the ship so swiftly"][[51 4 14] "sped, and though from every eye, like arrows, the eager glances shot,"][[51 4 15] "yet the silvery jet was no more seen that night. Every sailor swore he"][[51 4 16] "saw it once, but not a second time."][[51 5 1] "This midnight-spout had almost grown a forgotten thing, when, some days"][[51 5 2] "after, lo! at the same silent hour, it was again announced: again it"][[51 5 3] "was descried by all; but upon making sail to overtake it, once more it"][[51 5 4] "disappeared as if it had never been. And so it served us night after"][[51 5 5] "night, till no one heeded it but to wonder at it. Mysteriously"][[51 5 6] "jetted into the clear moonlight, or starlight, as the case might be;"][[51 5 7] "disappearing again for one whole day, or two days, or three; and somehow"][[51 5 8] "seeming at every distinct repetition to be advancing still further and"][[51 5 9] "further in our van, this solitary jet seemed for ever alluring us on."][[51 6 1] "Nor with the immemorial superstition of their race, and in accordance"][[51 6 2] "with the preternaturalness, as it seemed, which in many things invested"][[51 6 3] "the Pequod, were there wanting some of the seamen who swore that"][[51 6 4] "whenever and wherever descried; at however remote times, or in however"][[51 6 5] "far apart latitudes and longitudes, that unnearable spout was cast"][[51 6 6] "by one self-same whale; and that whale, Moby Dick.
