For a time, there"][[51 6 7] "reigned, too, a sense of peculiar dread at this flitting apparition,"][[51 6 8] "as if it were treacherously beckoning us on and on, in order that the"][[51 6 9] "monster might turn round upon us, and rend us at last in the remotest"][[51 6 10] "and most savage seas."][[51 7 1] "These temporary apprehensions, so vague but so awful, derived a wondrous"][[51 7 2] "potency from the contrasting serenity of the weather, in which, beneath"][[51 7 3] "all its blue blandness, some thought there lurked a devilish charm, as"][[51 7 4] "for days and days we voyaged along, through seas so wearily, lonesomely"][[51 7 5] "mild, that all space, in repugnance to our vengeful errand, seemed"][[51 7 6] "vacating itself of life before our urn-like prow."][[51 8 1] "But, at last, when turning to the eastward, the Cape winds began howling"][[51 8 2] "around us, and we rose and fell upon the long, troubled seas that are"][[51 8 3] "there; when the ivory-tusked Pequod sharply bowed to the blast, and"][[51 8 4] "gored the dark waves in her madness, till, like showers of silver chips,"][[51 8 5] "the foam-flakes flew over her bulwarks; then all this desolate vacuity"][[51 8 6] "of life went away, but gave place to sights more dismal than before."][[51 9 1] "Close to our bows, strange forms in the water darted hither and thither"][[51 9 2] "before us; while thick in our rear flew the inscrutable sea-ravens. And"][[51 9 3] "every morning, perched on our stays, rows of these birds were seen; and"][[51 9 4] "spite of our hootings, for a long time obstinately clung to the hemp,"][[51 9 5] "as though they deemed our ship some drifting, uninhabited craft; a thing"][[51 9 6] "appointed to desolation, and therefore fit roosting-place for their"][[51 9 7] "homeless selves. And heaved and heaved, still unrestingly heaved the"][[51 9 8] "black sea, as if its vast tides were a conscience; and the great mundane"][[51 9 9] "soul were in anguish and remorse for the long sin and suffering it had"][[51 9 10] "bred."][[51 10 1] "Cape of Good Hope, do they call ye? Rather Cape Tormentoto, as called"][[51 10 2] "of yore; for long allured by the perfidious silences that before had"][[51 10 3] "attended us, we found ourselves launched into this tormented sea,"][[51 10 4] "where guilty beings transformed into those fowls and these fish, seemed"][[51 10 5] "condemned to swim on everlastingly without any haven in store, or beat"][[51 10 6] "that black air without any horizon. But calm, snow-white, and unvarying;"][[51 10 7] "still directing its fountain of feathers to the sky; still beckoning us"][[51 10 8] "on from before, the solitary jet would at times be descried."][[51 11 1] "During all this blackness of the elements, Ahab, though assuming for the"][[51 11 2] "time the almost continual command of the drenched and dangerous deck,"][[51 11 3] "manifested the gloomiest reserve; and more seldom than ever addressed"][[51 11 4] "his mates. In tempestuous times like these, after everything above and"][[51 11 5] "aloft has been secured, nothing more can be done but passively to await"][[51 11 6] "the issue of the gale. Then Captain and crew become practical fatalists."][[51 11 7] "So, with his ivory leg inserted into its accustomed hole, and with one"][[51 11 8] "hand firmly grasping a shroud, Ahab for hours and hours would stand"][[51 11 9] "gazing dead to windward, while an occasional squall of sleet or snow"][[51 11 10] "would all but congeal his very eyelashes together. Meantime, the crew"][[51 11 11] "driven from the forward part of the ship by the perilous seas that"][[51 11 12] "burstingly broke over its bows, stood in a line along the bulwarks in"][[51 11 13] "the waist; and the better to guard against the leaping waves, each man"][[51 11 14] "had slipped himself into a sort of bowline secured to the rail, in which"][[51 11 15] "he swung as in a loosened belt. Few or no words were spoken; and the"][[51 11 16] "silent ship, as if manned by painted sailors in wax, day after day tore"][[51 11 17] "on through all the swift madness and gladness of the demoniac waves."][[51 11 18] "By night the same muteness of humanity before the shrieks of the"][[51 11 19] "ocean prevailed; still in silence the men swung in the bowlines; still"][[51 11 20] "wordless Ahab stood up to the blast. Even when wearied nature seemed"][[51 11 21] "demanding repose he would not seek that repose in his hammock. Never"][[51 11 22] "could Starbuck forget the old man's aspect, when one night going down"][[51 11 23] "into the cabin to mark how the barometer stood, he saw him with"][[51 11 24] "closed eyes sitting straight in his floor-screwed chair; the rain"][[51 11 25] "and half-melted sleet of the storm from which he had some time before"][[51 11 26] "emerged, still slowly dripping from the unremoved hat and coat. On the"][[51 11 27] "table beside him lay unrolled one of those charts of tides and currents"][[51 11 28] "which have previously been spoken of. His lantern swung from his tightly"][[51 11 29] "clenched hand. Though the body was erect, the head was thrown back so"][[51 11 30] "that the closed eyes were pointed towards the needle of the tell-tale"][[51 11 31] "that swung from a beam in the ceiling.*"][[51 13 1] "*The cabin-compass is called the tell-tale, because without going to the"][[51 13 2] "compass at the helm, the Captain, while below, can inform himself of the"][[51 13 3] "course of the ship."][[51 15 1] "Terrible old man! thought Starbuck with a shudder, sleeping in this"][[51 15 2] "gale, still thou steadfastly eyest thy purpose."][[52 0 0] "CHAPTER 52. The Albatross."][[52 2 1] "South-eastward from the Cape, off the distant Crozetts, a good cruising"][[52 2 2] "ground for Right Whalemen, a sail loomed ahead, the Goney (Albatross)"][[52 2 3] "by name. As she slowly drew nigh, from my lofty perch at the"][[52 2 4] "fore-mast-head, I had a good view of that sight so remarkable to a tyro"][[52 2 5] "in the far ocean fisheries--a whaler at sea, and long absent from home."][[52 3 1] "As if the waves had been fullers, this craft was bleached like the"][[52 3 2] "skeleton of a stranded walrus. All down her sides, this spectral"][[52 3 3] "appearance was traced with long channels of reddened rust, while all her"][[52 3 4] "spars and her rigging were like the thick branches of trees furred over"][[52 3 5] "with hoar-frost. Only her lower sails were set. A wild sight it was to"][[52 3 6] "see her long-bearded look-outs at those three mast-heads. They seemed"][[52 3 7] "clad in the skins of beasts, so torn and bepatched the raiment that had"][[52 3 8] "survived nearly four years of cruising. Standing in iron hoops nailed to"][[52 3 9] "the mast, they swayed and swung over a fathomless sea; and though, when"][[52 3 10] "the ship slowly glided close under our stern, we six men in the air"][[52 3 11] "came so nigh to each other that we might almost have leaped from the"][[52 3 12] "mast-heads of one ship to those of the other; yet, those forlorn-looking"][[52 3 13] "fishermen, mildly eyeing us as they passed, said not one word to our own"][[52 3 14] "look-outs, while the quarter-deck hail was being heard from below."][[52 4 1] "\"Ship ahoy! Have ye seen the White Whale?\""][[52 5 1] "But as the strange captain, leaning over the pallid bulwarks, was in the"][[52 5 2] "act of putting his trumpet to his mouth, it somehow fell from his hand"][[52 5 3] "into the sea; and the wind now rising amain, he in vain strove to make"][[52 5 4] "himself heard without it. Meantime his ship was still increasing the"][[52 5 5] "distance between. While in various silent ways the seamen of the Pequod"][[52 5 6] "were evincing their observance of this ominous incident at the first"][[52 5 7] "mere mention of the White Whale's name to another ship, Ahab for a"][[52 5 8] "moment paused; it almost seemed as though he would have lowered a boat"][[52 5 9] "to board the stranger, had not the threatening wind forbade. But taking"][[52 5 10] "advantage of his windward position, he again seized his trumpet, and"][[52 5 11] "knowing by her aspect that the stranger vessel was a Nantucketer and"][[52 5 12] "shortly bound home, he loudly hailed--\"Ahoy there! This is the Pequod,"][[52 5 13] "bound round the world! Tell them to address all future letters to the"][[52 5 14] "Pacific ocean! and this time three years, if I am not at home, tell them"][[52 5 15] "to address them to--\""][[52 6 1] "At that moment the two wakes were fairly crossed, and instantly, then,"][[52 6 2] "in accordance with their singular ways, shoals of small harmless fish,"][[52 6 3] "that for some days before had been placidly swimming by our side, darted"][[52 6 4] "away with what seemed shuddering fins, and ranged themselves fore and"][[52 6 5] "aft with the stranger's flanks. Though in the course of his continual"][[52 6 6] "voyagings Ahab must often before have noticed a similar sight, yet, to"][[52 6 7] "any monomaniac man, the veriest trifles capriciously carry meanings."][[52 7 1] "\"Swim away from me, do ye?\" murmured Ahab, gazing over into the water."][[52 7 2] "There seemed but little in the words, but the tone conveyed more of deep"][[52 7 3] "helpless sadness than the insane old man had ever before evinced. But"][[52 7 4] "turning to the steersman, who thus far had been holding the ship in the"][[52 7 5] "wind to diminish her headway, he cried out in his old lion voice,--\"Up"][[52 7 6] "helm! Keep her off round the world!\""][[52 8 1] "Round the world! There is much in that sound to inspire proud feelings;"][[52 8 2] "but whereto does all that circumnavigation conduct? Only through"][[52 8 3] "numberless perils to the very point whence we started, where those that"][[52 8 4] "we left behind secure, were all the time before us."][[52 9 1] "Were this world an endless plain, and by sailing eastward we could for"][[52 9 2] "ever reach new distances, and discover sights more sweet and strange"][[52 9 3] "than any Cyclades or Islands of King Solomon, then there were promise"][[52 9 4] "in the voyage. But in pursuit of those far mysteries we dream of, or in"][[52 9 5] "tormented chase of that demon phantom that, some time or other, swims"][[52 9 6] "before all human hearts; while chasing such over this round globe, they"][[52 9 7] "either lead us on in barren mazes or midway leave us whelmed."][[53 0 0] "CHAPTER 53. The Gam."][[53 2 1] "The ostensible reason why Ahab did not go on board of the whaler we had"][[53 2 2] "spoken was this: the wind and sea betokened storms. But even had"][[53 2 3] "this not been the case, he would not after all, perhaps, have boarded"][[53 2 4] "her--judging by his subsequent conduct on similar occasions--if so it"][[53 2 5] "had been that, by the process of hailing, he had obtained a negative"][[53 2 6] "answer to the question he put. For, as it eventually turned out, he"][[53 2 7] "cared not to consort, even for five minutes, with any stranger captain,"][[53 2 8] "except he could contribute some of that information he so absorbingly"][[53 2 9] "sought. But all this might remain inadequately estimated, were not"][[53 2 10] "something said here of the peculiar usages of whaling-vessels when"][[53 2 11] "meeting each other in foreign seas, and especially on a common"][[53 2 12] "cruising-ground."][[53 3 1] "If two strangers crossing the Pine Barrens in New York State, or the"][[53 3 2] "equally desolate Salisbury Plain in England; if casually encountering"][[53 3 3] "each other in such inhospitable wilds, these twain, for the life of"][[53 3 4] "them, cannot well avoid a mutual salutation; and stopping for a moment"][[53 3 5] "to interchange the news; and, perhaps, sitting down for a while"][[53 3 6] "and resting in concert: then, how much more natural that upon the"][[53 3 7] "illimitable Pine Barrens and Salisbury Plains of the sea, two whaling"][[53 3 8] "vessels descrying each other at the ends of the earth--off lone"][[53 3 9] "Fanning's Island, or the far away King's Mills; how much more natural,"][[53 3 10] "I say, that under such circumstances these ships should not only"][[53 3 11] "interchange hails, but come into still closer, more friendly and"][[53 3 12] "sociable contact. And especially would this seem to be a matter of"][[53 3 13] "course, in the case of vessels owned in one seaport, and whose captains,"][[53 3 14] "officers, and not a few of the men are personally known to each other;"][[53 3 15] "and consequently, have all sorts of dear domestic things to talk about."][[53 4 1] "For the long absent ship, the outward-bounder, perhaps, has letters on"][[53 4 2] "board; at any rate, she will be sure to let her have some papers of a"][[53 4 3] "date a year or two later than the last one on her blurred and thumb-worn"][[53 4 4] "files. And in return for that courtesy, the outward-bound ship would"][[53 4 5] "receive the latest whaling intelligence from the cruising-ground to"][[53 4 6] "which she may be destined, a thing of the utmost importance to her. And"][[53 4 7] "in degree, all this will hold true concerning whaling vessels crossing"][[53 4 8] "each other's track on the cruising-ground itself, even though they"][[53 4 9] "are equally long absent from home. For one of them may have received a"][[53 4 10] "transfer of letters from some third, and now far remote vessel; and"][[53 4 11] "some of those letters may be for the people of the ship she now meets."][[53 4 12] "Besides, they would exchange the whaling news, and have an agreeable"][[53 4 13] "chat. For not only would they meet with all the sympathies of sailors,"][[53 4 14] "but likewise with all the peculiar congenialities arising from a common"][[53 4 15] "pursuit and mutually shared privations and perils."][[53 5 1] "Nor would difference of country make any very essential difference;"][[53 5 2] "that is, so long as both parties speak one language, as is the case"][[53 5 3] "with Americans and English. Though, to be sure, from the small number of"][[53 5 4] "English whalers, such meetings do not very often occur, and when they"][[53 5 5] "do occur there is too apt to be a sort of shyness between them; for your"][[53 5 6] "Englishman is rather reserved, and your Yankee, he does not fancy that"][[53 5 7] "sort of thing in anybody but himself. Besides, the English whalers"][[53 5 8] "sometimes affect a kind of metropolitan superiority over the American"][[53 5 9] "whalers; regarding the long, lean Nantucketer, with his nondescript"][[53 5 10] "provincialisms, as a sort of sea-peasant. But where this superiority"][[53 5 11] "in the English whalemen does really consist, it would be hard to say,"][[53 5 12] "seeing that the Yankees in one day, collectively, kill more whales than"][[53 5 13] "all the English, collectively, in ten years. But this is a harmless"][[53 5 14] "little foible in the English whale-hunters, which the Nantucketer does"][[53 5 15] "not take much to heart; probably, because he knows that he has a few"][[53 5 16] "foibles himself."][[53 6 1] "So, then, we see that of all ships separately sailing the sea, the"][[53 6 2] "whalers have most reason to be sociable--and they are so. Whereas, some"][[53 6 3] "merchant ships crossing each other's wake in the mid-Atlantic, will"][[53 6 4] "oftentimes pass on without so much as a single word of recognition,"][[53 6 5] "mutually cutting each other on the high seas, like a brace of dandies in"][[53 6 6] "Broadway; and all the time indulging, perhaps, in finical criticism upon"][[53 6 7] "each other's rig. As for Men-of-War, when they chance to meet at sea,"][[53 6 8] "they first go through such a string of silly bowings and scrapings, such"][[53 6 9] "a ducking of ensigns, that there does not seem to be much right-down"][[53 6 10] "hearty good-will and brotherly love about it at all. As touching"][[53 6 11] "Slave-ships meeting, why, they are in such a prodigious hurry, they run"][[53 6 12] "away from each other as soon as possible. And as for Pirates, when they"][[53 6 13] "chance to cross each other's cross-bones, the first hail is--\"How many"][[53 6 14] "skulls?\"--the same way that whalers hail--\"How many barrels?\" And that"][[53 6 15] "question once answered, pirates straightway steer apart, for they are"][[53 6 16] "infernal villains on both sides, and don't like to see overmuch of each"][[53 6 17] "other's villanous likenesses."][[53 7 1] "But look at the godly, honest, unostentatious, hospitable, sociable,"][[53 7 2] "free-and-easy whaler! What does the whaler do when she meets another"][[53 7 3] "whaler in any sort of decent weather? She has a \"GAM,\" a thing so"][[53 7 4] "utterly unknown to all other ships that they never heard of the name"][[53 7 5] "even; and if by chance they should hear of it, they only grin at it, and"][[53 7 6] "repeat gamesome stuff about \"spouters\" and \"blubber-boilers,\" and such"][[53 7 7] "like pretty exclamations. Why it is that all Merchant-seamen, and also"][[53 7 8] "all Pirates and Man-of-War's men, and Slave-ship sailors, cherish such"][[53 7 9] "a scornful feeling towards Whale-ships; this is a question it would be"][[53 7 10] "hard to answer. Because, in the case of pirates, say, I should like to"][[53 7 11] "know whether that profession of theirs has any peculiar glory about"][[53 7 12] "it. It sometimes ends in uncommon elevation, indeed; but only at the"][[53 7 13] "gallows. And besides, when a man is elevated in that odd fashion, he has"][[53 7 14] "no proper foundation for his superior altitude. Hence, I conclude,"][[53 7 15] "that in boasting himself to be high lifted above a whaleman, in that"][[53 7 16] "assertion the pirate has no solid basis to stand on."][[53 8 1] "But what is a GAM? You might wear out your index-finger running up and"][[53 8 2] "down the columns of dictionaries, and never find the word. Dr. Johnson"][[53 8 3] "never attained to that erudition; Noah Webster's ark does not hold it."][[53 8 4] "Nevertheless, this same expressive word has now for many years been in"][[53 8 5] "constant use among some fifteen thousand true born Yankees. Certainly,"][[53 8 6] "it needs a definition, and should be incorporated into the Lexicon. With"][[53 8 7] "that view, let me learnedly define it."][[53 9 1] "GAM. NOUN--A SOCIAL MEETING OF TWO (OR MORE) WHALESHIPS, GENERALLY ON A"][[53 9 2] "CRUISING-GROUND; WHEN, AFTER EXCHANGING HAILS, THEY EXCHANGE VISITS BY"][[53 9 3] "BOATS' CREWS; THE TWO CAPTAINS REMAINING, FOR THE TIME, ON BOARD OF ONE"][[53 9 4] "SHIP, AND THE TWO CHIEF MATES ON THE OTHER."][[53 10 1] "There is another little item about Gamming which must not be forgotten"][[53 10 2] "here. All professions have their own little peculiarities of detail; so"][[53 10 3] "has the whale fishery. In a pirate, man-of-war, or slave ship, when"][[53 10 4] "the captain is rowed anywhere in his boat, he always sits in the stern"][[53 10 5] "sheets on a comfortable, sometimes cushioned seat there, and often"][[53 10 6] "steers himself with a pretty little milliner's tiller decorated with"][[53 10 7] "gay cords and ribbons. But the whale-boat has no seat astern, no sofa of"][[53 10 8] "that sort whatever, and no tiller at all. High times indeed, if whaling"][[53 10 9] "captains were wheeled about the water on castors like gouty old aldermen"][[53 10 10] "in patent chairs. And as for a tiller, the whale-boat never admits of"][[53 10 11] "any such effeminacy; and therefore as in gamming a complete boat's crew"][[53 10 12] "must leave the ship, and hence as the boat steerer or harpooneer is of"][[53 10 13] "the number, that subordinate is the steersman upon the occasion, and"][[53 10 14] "the captain, having no place to sit in, is pulled off to his visit"][[53 10 15] "all standing like a pine tree. And often you will notice that being"][[53 10 16] "conscious of the eyes of the whole visible world resting on him from"][[53 10 17] "the sides of the two ships, this standing captain is all alive to the"][[53 10 18] "importance of sustaining his dignity by maintaining his legs. Nor is"][[53 10 19] "this any very easy matter; for in his rear is the immense projecting"][[53 10 20] "steering oar hitting him now and then in the small of his back, the"][[53 10 21] "after-oar reciprocating by rapping his knees in front. He is thus"][[53 10 22] "completely wedged before and behind, and can only expand himself"][[53 10 23] "sideways by settling down on his stretched legs; but a sudden, violent"][[53 10 24] "pitch of the boat will often go far to topple him, because length of"][[53 10 25] "foundation is nothing without corresponding breadth. Merely make a"][[53 10 26] "spread angle of two poles, and you cannot stand them up. Then, again,"][[53 10 27] "it would never do in plain sight of the world's riveted eyes, it would"][[53 10 28] "never do, I say, for this straddling captain to be seen steadying"][[53 10 29] "himself the slightest particle by catching hold of anything with"][[53 10 30] "his hands; indeed, as token of his entire, buoyant self-command, he"][[53 10 31] "generally carries his hands in his trowsers' pockets; but perhaps being"][[53 10 32] "generally very large, heavy hands, he carries them there for ballast."][[53 10 33] "Nevertheless there have occurred instances, well authenticated ones too,"][[53 10 34] "where the captain has been known for an uncommonly critical moment or"][[53 10 35] "two, in a sudden squall say--to seize hold of the nearest oarsman's"][[53 10 36] "hair, and hold on there like grim death."][[54 0 0] "CHAPTER 54. The Town-Ho's Story."][[54 2 1] "(AS TOLD AT THE GOLDEN INN)"][[54 4 1] "The Cape of Good Hope, and all the watery region round about there, is"][[54 4 2] "much like some noted four corners of a great highway, where you meet"][[54 4 3] "more travellers than in any other part."][[54 5 1] "It was not very long after speaking the Goney that another"][[54 5 2] "homeward-bound whaleman, the Town-Ho,* was encountered. She was manned"][[54 5 3] "almost wholly by Polynesians. In the short gam that ensued she gave"][[54 5 4] "us strong news of Moby Dick. To some the general interest in the White"][[54 5 5] "Whale was now wildly heightened by a circumstance of the Town-Ho's"][[54 5 6] "story, which seemed obscurely to involve with the whale a certain"][[54 5 7] "wondrous, inverted visitation of one of those so called judgments of God"][[54 5 8] "which at times are said to overtake some men. This latter circumstance,"][[54 5 9] "with its own particular accompaniments, forming what may be called the"][[54 5 10] "secret part of the tragedy about to be narrated, never reached the ears"][[54 5 11] "of Captain Ahab or his mates. For that secret part of the story was"][[54 5 12] "unknown to the captain of the Town-Ho himself. It was the private"][[54 5 13] "property of three confederate white seamen of that ship, one of whom, it"][[54 5 14] "seems, communicated it to Tashtego with Romish injunctions of secrecy,"][[54 5 15] "but the following night Tashtego rambled in his sleep, and revealed"][[54 5 16] "so much of it in that way, that when he was wakened he could not well"][[54 5 17] "withhold the rest. Nevertheless, so potent an influence did this thing"][[54 5 18] "have on those seamen in the Pequod who came to the full knowledge of"][[54 5 19] "it, and by such a strange delicacy, to call it so, were they governed in"][[54 5 20] "this matter, that they kept the secret among themselves so that it never"][[54 5 21] "transpired abaft the Pequod's main-mast. Interweaving in its proper"][[54 5 22] "place this darker thread with the story as publicly narrated on the"][[54 5 23] "ship, the whole of this strange affair I now proceed to put on lasting"][[54 5 24] "record."][[54 7 1] "*The ancient whale-cry upon first sighting a whale from the mast-head,"][[54 7 2] "still used by whalemen in hunting the famous Gallipagos terrapin."][[54 9 1] "For my humor's sake, I shall preserve the style in which I once narrated"][[54 9 2] "it at Lima, to a lounging circle of my Spanish friends, one saint's eve,"][[54 9 3] "smoking upon the thick-gilt tiled piazza of the Golden Inn. Of those"][[54 9 4] "fine cavaliers, the young Dons, Pedro and Sebastian, were on the closer"][[54 9 5] "terms with me; and hence the interluding questions they occasionally"][[54 9 6] "put, and which are duly answered at the time."][[54 10 1] "\"Some two years prior to my first learning the events which I am about"][[54 10 2] "rehearsing to you, gentlemen, the Town-Ho, Sperm Whaler of Nantucket,"][[54 10 3] "was cruising in your Pacific here, not very many days' sail eastward"][[54 10 4] "from the eaves of this good Golden Inn. She was somewhere to the"][[54 10 5] "northward of the Line. One morning upon handling the pumps, according to"][[54 10 6] "daily usage, it was observed that she made more water in her hold than"][[54 10 7] "common. They supposed a sword-fish had stabbed her, gentlemen. But the"][[54 10 8] "captain, having some unusual reason for believing that rare good luck"][[54 10 9] "awaited him in those latitudes; and therefore being very averse to quit"][[54 10 10] "them, and the leak not being then considered at all dangerous, though,"][[54 10 11] "indeed, they could not find it after searching the hold as low down"][[54 10 12] "as was possible in rather heavy weather, the ship still continued her"][[54 10 13] "cruisings, the mariners working at the pumps at wide and easy intervals;"][[54 10 14] "but no good luck came; more days went by, and not only was the leak yet"][[54 10 15] "undiscovered, but it sensibly increased. So much so, that now taking"][[54 10 16] "some alarm, the captain, making all sail, stood away for the nearest"][[54 10 17] "harbor among the islands, there to have his hull hove out and repaired."][[54 11 1] "\"Though no small passage was before her, yet, if the commonest chance"][[54 11 2] "favoured, he did not at all fear that his ship would founder by the way,"][[54 11 3] "because his pumps were of the best, and being periodically relieved at"][[54 11 4] "them, those six-and-thirty men of his could easily keep the ship free;"][[54 11 5] "never mind if the leak should double on her. In truth, well nigh the"][[54 11 6] "whole of this passage being attended by very prosperous breezes, the"][[54 11 7] "Town-Ho had all but certainly arrived in perfect safety at her port"][[54 11 8] "without the occurrence of the least fatality, had it not been for the"][[54 11 9] "brutal overbearing of Radney, the mate, a Vineyarder, and the bitterly"][[54 11 10] "provoked vengeance of Steelkilt, a Lakeman and desperado from Buffalo."][[54 12 1] "\"'Lakeman!--Buffalo! Pray, what is a Lakeman, and where is Buffalo?'"][[54 12 2] "said Don Sebastian, rising in his swinging mat of grass."][[54 13 1] "\"On the eastern shore of our Lake Erie, Don; but--I crave your"][[54 13 2] "courtesy--may be, you shall soon hear further of all that. Now,"][[54 13 3] "gentlemen, in square-sail brigs and three-masted ships, well-nigh as"][[54 13 4] "large and stout as any that ever sailed out of your old Callao to far"][[54 13 5] "Manilla; this Lakeman, in the land-locked heart of our America, had yet"][[54 13 6] "been nurtured by all those agrarian freebooting impressions popularly"][[54 13 7] "connected with the open ocean. For in their interflowing aggregate,"][[54 13 8] "those grand fresh-water seas of ours,--Erie, and Ontario, and Huron, and"][[54 13 9] "Superior, and Michigan,--possess an ocean-like expansiveness, with many"][[54 13 10] "of the ocean's noblest traits; with many of its rimmed varieties of"][[54 13 11] "races and of climes. They contain round archipelagoes of romantic isles,"][[54 13 12] "even as the Polynesian waters do; in large part, are shored by two great"][[54 13 13] "contrasting nations, as the Atlantic is; they furnish long maritime"][[54 13 14] "approaches to our numerous territorial colonies from the East, dotted"][[54 13 15] "all round their banks; here and there are frowned upon by batteries,"][[54 13 16] "and by the goat-like craggy guns of lofty Mackinaw; they have heard the"][[54 13 17] "fleet thunderings of naval victories; at intervals, they yield their"][[54 13 18] "beaches to wild barbarians, whose red painted faces flash from out"][[54 13 19] "their peltry wigwams; for leagues and leagues are flanked by ancient"][[54 13 20] "and unentered forests, where the gaunt pines stand like serried lines"][[54 13 21] "of kings in Gothic genealogies; those same woods harboring wild Afric"][[54 13 22] "beasts of prey, and silken creatures whose exported furs give robes"][[54 13 23] "to Tartar Emperors; they mirror the paved capitals of Buffalo and"][[54 13 24] "Cleveland, as well as Winnebago villages; they float alike the"][[54 13 25] "full-rigged merchant ship, the armed cruiser of the State, the steamer,"][[54 13 26] "and the beech canoe; they are swept by Borean and dismasting blasts as"][[54 13 27] "direful as any that lash the salted wave; they know what shipwrecks are,"][[54 13 28] "for out of sight of land, however inland, they have drowned full many"][[54 13 29] "a midnight ship with all its shrieking crew. Thus, gentlemen, though"][[54 13 30] "an inlander, Steelkilt was wild-ocean born, and wild-ocean nurtured;"][[54 13 31] "as much of an audacious mariner as any. And for Radney, though in his"][[54 13 32] "infancy he may have laid him down on the lone Nantucket beach, to nurse"][[54 13 33] "at his maternal sea; though in after life he had long followed our"][[54 13 34] "austere Atlantic and your contemplative Pacific; yet was he quite as"][[54 13 35] "vengeful and full of social quarrel as the backwoods seaman, fresh"][[54 13 36] "from the latitudes of buck-horn handled bowie-knives. Yet was this"][[54 13 37] "Nantucketer a man with some good-hearted traits; and this Lakeman, a"][[54 13 38] "mariner, who though a sort of devil indeed, might yet by inflexible"][[54 13 39] "firmness, only tempered by that common decency of human recognition"][[54 13 40] "which is the meanest slave's right; thus treated, this Steelkilt had"][[54 13 41] "long been retained harmless and docile. At all events, he had proved"][[54 13 42] "so thus far; but Radney was doomed and made mad, and Steelkilt--but,"][[54 13 43] "gentlemen, you shall hear."][[54 14 1] "\"It was not more than a day or two at the furthest after pointing"][[54 14 2] "her prow for her island haven, that the Town-Ho's leak seemed again"][[54 14 3] "increasing, but only so as to require an hour or more at the pumps"][[54 14 4] "every day. You must know that in a settled and civilized ocean like our"][[54 14 5] "Atlantic, for example, some skippers think little of pumping their whole"][[54 14 6] "way across it; though of a still, sleepy night, should the officer of"][[54 14 7] "the deck happen to forget his duty in that respect, the probability"][[54 14 8] "would be that he and his shipmates would never again remember it, on"][[54 14 9] "account of all hands gently subsiding to the bottom. Nor in the"][[54 14 10] "solitary and savage seas far from you to the westward, gentlemen, is it"][[54 14 11] "altogether unusual for ships to keep clanging at their pump-handles in"][[54 14 12] "full chorus even for a voyage of considerable length; that is, if it lie"][[54 14 13] "along a tolerably accessible coast, or if any other reasonable retreat"][[54 14 14] "is afforded them. It is only when a leaky vessel is in some very out of"][[54 14 15] "the way part of those waters, some really landless latitude, that her"][[54 14 16] "captain begins to feel a little anxious."][[54 15 1] "\"Much this way had it been with the Town-Ho; so when her leak was found"][[54 15 2] "gaining once more, there was in truth some small concern manifested by"][[54 15 3] "several of her company; especially by Radney the mate. He commanded"][[54 15 4] "the upper sails to be well hoisted, sheeted home anew, and every way"][[54 15 5] "expanded to the breeze. Now this Radney, I suppose, was as little of a"][[54 15 6] "coward, and as little inclined to any sort of nervous apprehensiveness"][[54 15 7] "touching his own person as any fearless, unthinking creature on land or"][[54 15 8] "on sea that you can conveniently imagine, gentlemen. Therefore when"][[54 15 9] "he betrayed this solicitude about the safety of the ship, some of the"][[54 15 10] "seamen declared that it was only on account of his being a part owner in"][[54 15 11] "her. So when they were working that evening at the pumps, there was on"][[54 15 12] "this head no small gamesomeness slily going on among them, as they stood"][[54 15 13] "with their feet continually overflowed by the rippling clear water;"][[54 15 14] "clear as any mountain spring, gentlemen--that bubbling from the pumps"][[54 15 15] "ran across the deck, and poured itself out in steady spouts at the lee"][[54 15 16] "scupper-holes."][[54 16 1] "\"Now, as you well know, it is not seldom the case in this conventional"][[54 16 2] "world of ours--watery or otherwise; that when a person placed in command"][[54 16 3] "over his fellow-men finds one of them to be very significantly his"][[54 16 4] "superior in general pride of manhood, straightway against that man he"][[54 16 5] "conceives an unconquerable dislike and bitterness; and if he have a"][[54 16 6] "chance he will pull down and pulverize that subaltern's tower, and"][[54 16 7] "make a little heap of dust of it. Be this conceit of mine as it may,"][[54 16 8] "gentlemen, at all events Steelkilt was a tall and noble animal with a"][[54 16 9] "head like a Roman, and a flowing golden beard like the tasseled housings"][[54 16 10] "of your last viceroy's snorting charger; and a brain, and a heart, and"][[54 16 11] "a soul in him, gentlemen, which had made Steelkilt Charlemagne, had he"][[54 16 12] "been born son to Charlemagne's father. But Radney, the mate, was ugly"][[54 16 13] "as a mule; yet as hardy, as stubborn, as malicious. He did not love"][[54 16 14] "Steelkilt, and Steelkilt knew it."][[54 17 1] "\"Espying the mate drawing near as he was toiling at the pump with the"][[54 17 2] "rest, the Lakeman affected not to notice him, but unawed, went on with"][[54 17 3] "his gay banterings."][[54 18 1] "\"'Aye, aye, my merry lads, it's a lively leak this; hold a cannikin, one"][[54 18 2] "of ye, and let's have a taste. By the Lord, it's worth bottling! I tell"][[54 18 3] "ye what, men, old Rad's investment must go for it! he had best cut away"][[54 18 4] "his part of the hull and tow it home. The fact is, boys, that sword-fish"][[54 18 5] "only began the job; he's come back again with a gang of ship-carpenters,"][[54 18 6] "saw-fish, and file-fish, and what not; and the whole posse of 'em"][[54 18 7] "are now hard at work cutting and slashing at the bottom; making"][[54 18 8] "improvements, I suppose. If old Rad were here now, I'd tell him to jump"][[54 18 9] "overboard and scatter 'em. They're playing the devil with his estate, I"][[54 18 10] "can tell him. But he's a simple old soul,--Rad, and a beauty too. Boys,"][[54 18 11] "they say the rest of his property is invested in looking-glasses. I"][[54 18 12] "wonder if he'd give a poor devil like me the model of his nose.'"][[54 19 1] "\"'Damn your eyes! what's that pump stopping for?' roared Radney,"][[54 19 2] "pretending not to have heard the sailors' talk. 'Thunder away at it!'"][[54 20 1] "\"'Aye, aye, sir,' said Steelkilt, merry as a cricket. 'Lively, boys,"][[54 20 2] "lively, now!' And with that the pump clanged like fifty fire-engines;"][[54 20 3] "the men tossed their hats off to it, and ere long that peculiar gasping"][[54 20 4] "of the lungs was heard which denotes the fullest tension of life's"][[54 20 5] "utmost energies."][[54 21 1] "\"Quitting the pump at last, with the rest of his band, the Lakeman went"][[54 21 2] "forward all panting, and sat himself down on the windlass; his face"][[54 21 3] "fiery red, his eyes bloodshot, and wiping the profuse sweat from his"][[54 21 4] "brow. Now what cozening fiend it was, gentlemen, that possessed Radney"][[54 21 5] "to meddle with such a man in that corporeally exasperated state, I know"][[54 21 6] "not; but so it happened. Intolerably striding along the deck, the mate"][[54 21 7] "commanded him to get a broom and sweep down the planks, and also a"][[54 21 8] "shovel, and remove some offensive matters consequent upon allowing a pig"][[54 21 9] "to run at large."][[54 22 1] "\"Now, gentlemen, sweeping a ship's deck at sea is a piece of household"][[54 22 2] "work which in all times but raging gales is regularly attended to every"][[54 22 3] "evening; it has been known to be done in the case of ships actually"][[54 22 4] "foundering at the time. Such, gentlemen, is the inflexibility of"][[54 22 5] "sea-usages and the instinctive love of neatness in seamen; some of whom"][[54 22 6] "would not willingly drown without first washing their faces. But in all"][[54 22 7] "vessels this broom business is the prescriptive province of the boys,"][[54 22 8] "if boys there be aboard. Besides, it was the stronger men in the Town-Ho"][[54 22 9] "that had been divided into gangs, taking turns at the pumps; and being"][[54 22 10] "the most athletic seaman of them all, Steelkilt had been regularly"][[54 22 11] "assigned captain of one of the gangs; consequently he should have"][[54 22 12] "been freed from any trivial business not connected with truly nautical"][[54 22 13] "duties, such being the case with his comrades. I mention all these"][[54 22 14] "particulars so that you may understand exactly how this affair stood"][[54 22 15] "between the two men."][[54 23 1] "\"But there was more than this: the order about the shovel was almost as"][[54 23 2] "plainly meant to sting and insult Steelkilt, as though Radney had spat"][[54 23 3] "in his face. Any man who has gone sailor in a whale-ship will"][[54 23 4] "understand this; and all this and doubtless much more, the Lakeman fully"][[54 23 5] "comprehended when the mate uttered his command. But as he sat still for"][[54 23 6] "a moment, and as he steadfastly looked into the mate's malignant eye and"][[54 23 7] "perceived the stacks of powder-casks heaped up in him and the slow-match"][[54 23 8] "silently burning along towards them; as he instinctively saw all"][[54 23 9] "this, that strange forbearance and unwillingness to stir up the deeper"][[54 23 10] "passionateness in any already ireful being--a repugnance most felt, when"][[54 23 11] "felt at all, by really valiant men even when aggrieved--this nameless"][[54 23 12] "phantom feeling, gentlemen, stole over Steelkilt."][[54 24 1] "\"Therefore, in his ordinary tone, only a little broken by the bodily"][[54 24 2] "exhaustion he was temporarily in, he answered him saying that sweeping"][[54 24 3] "the deck was not his business, and he would not do it. And then, without"][[54 24 4] "at all alluding to the shovel, he pointed to three lads as the customary"][[54 24 5] "sweepers; who, not being billeted at the pumps, had done little or"][[54 24 6] "nothing all day. To this, Radney replied with an oath, in a most"][[54 24 7] "domineering and outrageous manner unconditionally reiterating his"][[54 24 8] "command; meanwhile advancing upon the still seated Lakeman, with an"][[54 24 9] "uplifted cooper's club hammer which he had snatched from a cask near by."][[54 25 1] "\"Heated and irritated as he was by his spasmodic toil at the pumps, for"][[54 25 2] "all his first nameless feeling of forbearance the sweating Steelkilt"][[54 25 3] "could but ill brook this bearing in the mate; but somehow still"][[54 25 4] "smothering the conflagration within him, without speaking he remained"][[54 25 5] "doggedly rooted to his seat, till at last the incensed Radney shook the"][[54 25 6] "hammer within a few inches of his face, furiously commanding him to do"][[54 25 7] "his bidding."][[54 26 1] "\"Steelkilt rose, and slowly retreating round the windlass, steadily"][[54 26 2] "followed by the mate with his menacing hammer, deliberately repeated his"][[54 26 3] "intention not to obey. Seeing, however, that his forbearance had not"][[54 26 4] "the slightest effect, by an awful and unspeakable intimation with his"][[54 26 5] "twisted hand he warned off the foolish and infatuated man; but it was to"][[54 26 6] "no purpose. And in this way the two went once slowly round the windlass;"][[54 26 7] "when, resolved at last no longer to retreat, bethinking him that he had"][[54 26 8] "now forborne as much as comported with his humor, the Lakeman paused on"][[54 26 9] "the hatches and thus spoke to the officer:"][[54 27 1] "\"'Mr. Radney, I will not obey you. Take that hammer away, or look to"][[54 27 2] "yourself.' But the predestinated mate coming still closer to him, where"][[54 27 3] "the Lakeman stood fixed, now shook the heavy hammer within an inch of"][[54 27 4] "his teeth; meanwhile repeating a string of insufferable maledictions."][[54 27 5] "Retreating not the thousandth part of an inch; stabbing him in the eye"][[54 27 6] "with the unflinching poniard of his glance, Steelkilt, clenching"][[54 27 7] "his right hand behind him and creepingly drawing it back, told his"][[54 27 8] "persecutor that if the hammer but grazed his cheek he (Steelkilt) would"][[54 27 9] "murder him. But, gentlemen, the fool had been branded for the slaughter"][[54 27 10] "by the gods. Immediately the hammer touched the cheek; the next instant"][[54 27 11] "the lower jaw of the mate was stove in his head; he fell on the hatch"][[54 27 12] "spouting blood like a whale."][[54 28 1] "\"Ere the cry could go aft Steelkilt was shaking one of the backstays"][[54 28 2] "leading far aloft to where two of his comrades were standing their"][[54 28 3] "mastheads. They were both Canallers."][[54 29 1] "\"'Canallers!' cried Don Pedro. 'We have seen many whale-ships in our"][[54 29 2] "harbours, but never heard of your Canallers. Pardon: who and what are"][[54 29 3] "they?'"][[54 30 1] "\"'Canallers, Don, are the boatmen belonging to our grand Erie Canal. You"][[54 30 2] "must have heard of it.'"][[54 31 1] "\"'Nay, Senor; hereabouts in this dull, warm, most lazy, and hereditary"][[54 31 2] "land, we know but little of your vigorous North.'"][[54 32 1] "\"'Aye? Well then, Don, refill my cup. Your chicha's very fine; and"][[54 32 2] "ere proceeding further I will tell ye what our Canallers are; for such"][[54 32 3] "information may throw side-light upon my story.'"][[54 33 1] "\"For three hundred and sixty miles, gentlemen, through the entire"][[54 33 2] "breadth of the state of New York; through numerous populous cities and"][[54 33 3] "most thriving villages; through long, dismal, uninhabited swamps, and"][[54 33 4] "affluent, cultivated fields, unrivalled for fertility; by billiard-room"][[54 33 5] "and bar-room; through the holy-of-holies of great forests; on Roman"][[54 33 6] "arches over Indian rivers; through sun and shade; by happy hearts or"][[54 33 7] "broken; through all the wide contrasting scenery of those noble Mohawk"][[54 33 8] "counties; and especially, by rows of snow-white chapels, whose spires"][[54 33 9] "stand almost like milestones, flows one continual stream of Venetianly"][[54 33 10] "corrupt and often lawless life. There's your true Ashantee, gentlemen;"][[54 33 11] "there howl your pagans; where you ever find them, next door to you;"][[54 33 12] "under the long-flung shadow, and the snug patronising lee of churches."][[54 33 13] "For by some curious fatality, as it is often noted of your metropolitan"][[54 33 14] "freebooters that they ever encamp around the halls of justice, so"][[54 33 15] "sinners, gentlemen, most abound in holiest vicinities."][[54 34 1] "\"'Is that a friar passing?' said Don Pedro, looking downwards into the"][[54 34 2] "crowded plazza, with humorous concern."][[54 35 1] "\"'Well for our northern friend, Dame Isabella's Inquisition wanes in"][[54 35 2] "Lima,' laughed Don Sebastian. 'Proceed, Senor.'"][[54 36 1] "\"'A moment! Pardon!' cried another of the company. 'In the name of all"][[54 36 2] "us Limeese, I but desire to express to you, sir sailor, that we have by"][[54 36 3] "no means overlooked your delicacy in not substituting present Lima"][[54 36 4] "for distant Venice in your corrupt comparison. Oh! do not bow and look"][[54 36 5] "surprised; you know the proverb all along this coast--\"Corrupt as"][[54 36 6] "Lima.\" It but bears out your saying, too; churches more plentiful than"][[54 36 7] "billiard-tables, and for ever open--and \"Corrupt as Lima.\" So, too,"][[54 36 8] "Venice; I have been there; the holy city of the blessed evangelist, St."][[54 36 9] "Mark!--St. Dominic, purge it! Your cup! Thanks: here I refill; now, you"][[54 36 10] "pour out again.'"][[54 37 1] "\"Freely depicted in his own vocation, gentlemen, the Canaller would make"][[54 37 2] "a fine dramatic hero, so abundantly and picturesquely wicked is he. Like"][[54 37 3] "Mark Antony, for days and days along his green-turfed, flowery Nile,"][[54 37 4] "he indolently floats, openly toying with his red-cheeked Cleopatra,"][[54 37 5] "ripening his apricot thigh upon the sunny deck. But ashore, all this"][[54 37 6] "effeminacy is dashed. The brigandish guise which the Canaller so proudly"][[54 37 7] "sports; his slouched and gaily-ribboned hat betoken his grand features."][[54 37 8] "A terror to the smiling innocence of the villages through which he"][[54 37 9] "floats; his swart visage and bold swagger are not unshunned in cities."][[54 37 10] "Once a vagabond on his own canal, I have received good turns from one of"][[54 37 11] "these Canallers; I thank him heartily; would fain be not ungrateful;"][[54 37 12] "but it is often one of the prime redeeming qualities of your man of"][[54 37 13] "violence, that at times he has as stiff an arm to back a poor stranger"][[54 37 14] "in a strait, as to plunder a wealthy one. In sum, gentlemen, what the"][[54 37 15] "wildness of this canal life is, is emphatically evinced by this; that"][[54 37 16] "our wild whale-fishery contains so many of its most finished graduates,"][[54 37 17] "and that scarce any race of mankind, except Sydney men, are so much"][[54 37 18] "distrusted by our whaling captains. Nor does it at all diminish the"][[54 37 19] "curiousness of this matter, that to many thousands of our rural boys and"][[54 37 20] "young men born along its line, the probationary life of the Grand Canal"][[54 37 21] "furnishes the sole transition between quietly reaping in a Christian"][[54 37 22] "corn-field, and recklessly ploughing the waters of the most barbaric"][[54 37 23] "seas."][[54 38 1] "\"'I see! I see!' impetuously exclaimed Don Pedro, spilling his chicha"][[54 38 2] "upon his silvery ruffles. 'No need to travel! The world's one Lima. I"][[54 38 3] "had thought, now, that at your temperate North the generations were cold"][[54 38 4] "and holy as the hills.--But the story.'"][[54 39 1] "\"I left off, gentlemen, where the Lakeman shook the backstay. Hardly"][[54 39 2] "had he done so, when he was surrounded by the three junior mates and the"][[54 39 3] "four harpooneers, who all crowded him to the deck. But sliding down the"][[54 39 4] "ropes like baleful comets, the two Canallers rushed into the uproar, and"][[54 39 5] "sought to drag their man out of it towards the forecastle. Others of the"][[54 39 6] "sailors joined with them in this attempt, and a twisted turmoil ensued;"][[54 39 7] "while standing out of harm's way, the valiant captain danced up and down"][[54 39 8] "with a whale-pike, calling upon his officers to manhandle that atrocious"][[54 39 9] "scoundrel, and smoke him along to the quarter-deck. At intervals, he ran"][[54 39 10] "close up to the revolving border of the confusion, and prying into"][[54 39 11] "the heart of it with his pike, sought to prick out the object of his"][[54 39 12] "resentment. But Steelkilt and his desperadoes were too much for them"][[54 39 13] "all; they succeeded in gaining the forecastle deck, where, hastily"][[54 39 14] "slewing about three or four large casks in a line with the windlass,"][[54 39 15] "these sea-Parisians entrenched themselves behind the barricade."][[54 40 1] "\"'Come out of that, ye pirates!' roared the captain, now menacing them"][[54 40 2] "with a pistol in each hand, just brought to him by the steward. 'Come"][[54 40 3] "out of that, ye cut-throats!'"][[54 41 1] "\"Steelkilt leaped on the barricade, and striding up and down there,"][[54 41 2] "defied the worst the pistols could do; but gave the captain to"][[54 41 3] "understand distinctly, that his (Steelkilt's) death would be the signal"][[54 41 4] "for a murderous mutiny on the part of all hands. Fearing in his heart"][[54 41 5] "lest this might prove but too true, the captain a little desisted, but"][[54 41 6] "still commanded the insurgents instantly to return to their duty."][[54 42 1] "\"'Will you promise not to touch us, if we do?' demanded their"][[54 42 2] "ringleader."][[54 43 1] "\"'Turn to! turn to!--I make no promise;--to your duty! Do you want to"][[54 43 2] "sink the ship, by knocking off at a time like this? Turn to!' and he"][[54 43 3] "once more raised a pistol."][[54 44 1] "\"'Sink the ship?' cried Steelkilt. 'Aye, let her sink. Not a man of us"][[54 44 2] "turns to, unless you swear not to raise a rope-yarn against us. What say"][[54 44 3] "ye, men?' turning to his comrades. A fierce cheer was their response."][[54 45 1] "\"The Lakeman now patrolled the barricade, all the while keeping his eye"][[54 45 2] "on the Captain, and jerking out such sentences as these:--'It's not our"][[54 45 3] "fault; we didn't want it; I told him to take his hammer away; it was"][[54 45 4] "boy's business; he might have known me before this; I told him not to"][[54 45 5] "prick the buffalo; I believe I have broken a finger here against his"][[54 45 6] "cursed jaw; ain't those mincing knives down in the forecastle there,"][[54 45 7] "men? look to those handspikes, my hearties. Captain, by God, look to"][[54 45 8] "yourself; say the word; don't be a fool; forget it all; we are ready"][[54 45 9] "to turn to; treat us decently, and we're your men; but we won't be"][[54 45 10] "flogged.'"][[54 46 1] "\"'Turn to! I make no promises, turn to, I say!'"][[54 47 1] "\"'Look ye, now,' cried the Lakeman, flinging out his arm towards him,"][[54 47 2] "'there are a few of us here (and I am one of them) who have shipped"][[54 47 3] "for the cruise, d'ye see; now as you well know, sir, we can claim our"][[54 47 4] "discharge as soon as the anchor is down; so we don't want a row; it's"][[54 47 5] "not our interest; we want to be peaceable; we are ready to work, but we"][[54 47 6] "won't be flogged.'"][[54 48 1] "\"'Turn to!' roared the Captain."][[54 49 1] "\"Steelkilt glanced round him a moment, and then said:--'I tell you what"][[54 49 2] "it is now, Captain, rather than kill ye, and be hung for such a shabby"][[54 49 3] "rascal, we won't lift a hand against ye unless ye attack us; but till"][[54 49 4] "you say the word about not flogging us, we don't do a hand's turn.'"][[54 50 1] "\"'Down into the forecastle then, down with ye, I'll keep ye there till"][[54 50 2] "ye're sick of it. Down ye go.'"][[54 51 1] "\"'Shall we?' cried the ringleader to his men. Most of them were against"][[54 51 2] "it; but at length, in obedience to Steelkilt, they preceded him down"][[54 51 3] "into their dark den, growlingly disappearing, like bears into a cave."][[54 52 1] "\"As the Lakeman's bare head was just level with the planks, the Captain"][[54 52 2] "and his posse leaped the barricade, and rapidly drawing over the slide"][[54 52 3] "of the scuttle, planted their group of hands upon it, and loudly called"][[54 52 4] "for the steward to bring the heavy brass padlock belonging to the"][[54 52 5] "companionway."][[54 53 1] "\"Then opening the slide a little, the Captain whispered something"][[54 53 2] "down the crack, closed it, and turned the key upon them--ten in"][[54 53 3] "number--leaving on deck some twenty or more, who thus far had remained"][[54 53 4] "neutral."][[54 54 1] "\"All night a wide-awake watch was kept by all the officers, forward and"][[54 54 2] "aft, especially about the forecastle scuttle and fore hatchway; at which"][[54 54 3] "last place it was feared the insurgents might emerge, after breaking"][[54 54 4] "through the bulkhead below. But the hours of darkness passed in peace;"][[54 54 5] "the men who still remained at their duty toiling hard at the pumps,"][[54 54 6] "whose clinking and clanking at intervals through the dreary night"][[54 54 7] "dismally resounded through the ship."][[54 55 1] "\"At sunrise the Captain went forward, and knocking on the deck, summoned"][[54 55 2] "the prisoners to work; but with a yell they refused. Water was then"][[54 55 3] "lowered down to them, and a couple of handfuls of biscuit were tossed"][[54 55 4] "after it; when again turning the key upon them and pocketing it, the"][[54 55 5] "Captain returned to the quarter-deck. Twice every day for three days"][[54 55 6] "this was repeated; but on the fourth morning a confused wrangling, and"][[54 55 7] "then a scuffling was heard, as the customary summons was delivered; and"][[54 55 8] "suddenly four men burst up from the forecastle, saying they were ready"][[54 55 9] "to turn to. The fetid closeness of the air, and a famishing diet, united"][[54 55 10] "perhaps to some fears of ultimate retribution, had constrained them to"][[54 55 11] "surrender at discretion. Emboldened by this, the Captain reiterated his"][[54 55 12] "demand to the rest, but Steelkilt shouted up to him a terrific hint to"][[54 55 13] "stop his babbling and betake himself where he belonged. On the fifth"][[54 55 14] "morning three others of the mutineers bolted up into the air from the"][[54 55 15] "desperate arms below that sought to restrain them. Only three were left."][[54 56 1] "\"'Better turn to, now?' said the Captain with a heartless jeer."][[54 57 1] "\"'Shut us up again, will ye!' cried Steelkilt."][[54 58 1] "\"'Oh certainly,' said the Captain, and the key clicked."][[54 59 1] "\"It was at this point, gentlemen, that enraged by the defection of seven"][[54 59 2] "of his former associates, and stung by the mocking voice that had last"][[54 59 3] "hailed him, and maddened by his long entombment in a place as black as"][[54 59 4] "the bowels of despair; it was then that Steelkilt proposed to the two"][[54 59 5] "Canallers, thus far apparently of one mind with him, to burst out of"][[54 59 6] "their hole at the next summoning of the garrison; and armed with their"][[54 59 7] "keen mincing knives (long, crescentic, heavy implements with a handle"][[54 59 8] "at each end) run amuck from the bowsprit to the taffrail; and if by any"][[54 59 9] "devilishness of desperation possible, seize the ship. For himself, he"][[54 59 10] "would do this, he said, whether they joined him or not. That was the"][[54 59 11] "last night he should spend in that den. But the scheme met with no"][[54 59 12] "opposition on the part of the other two; they swore they were ready for"][[54 59 13] "that, or for any other mad thing, for anything in short but a surrender."][[54 59 14] "And what was more, they each insisted upon being the first man on deck,"][[54 59 15] "when the time to make the rush should come. But to this their leader as"][[54 59 16] "fiercely objected, reserving that priority for himself; particularly as"][[54 59 17] "his two comrades would not yield, the one to the other, in the matter;"][[54 59 18] "and both of them could not be first, for the ladder would but admit one"][[54 59 19] "man at a time. And here, gentlemen, the foul play of these miscreants"][[54 59 20] "must come out."][[54 60 1] "\"Upon hearing the frantic project of their leader, each in his own"][[54 60 2] "separate soul had suddenly lighted, it would seem, upon the same piece"][[54 60 3] "of treachery, namely: to be foremost in breaking out, in order to be"][[54 60 4] "the first of the three, though the last of the ten, to surrender; and"][[54 60 5] "thereby secure whatever small chance of pardon such conduct might merit."][[54 60 6] "But when Steelkilt made known his determination still to lead them to"][[54 60 7] "the last, they in some way, by some subtle chemistry of villany, mixed"][[54 60 8] "their before secret treacheries together; and when their leader"][[54 60 9] "fell into a doze, verbally opened their souls to each other in three"][[54 60 10] "sentences; and bound the sleeper with cords, and gagged him with cords;"][[54 60 11] "and shrieked out for the Captain at midnight."][[54 61 1] "\"Thinking murder at hand, and smelling in the dark for the blood, he and"][[54 61 2] "all his armed mates and harpooneers rushed for the forecastle. In a"][[54 61 3] "few minutes the scuttle was opened, and, bound hand and foot, the still"][[54 61 4] "struggling ringleader was shoved up into the air by his perfidious"][[54 61 5] "allies, who at once claimed the honour of securing a man who had been"][[54 61 6] "fully ripe for murder. But all these were collared, and dragged along"][[54 61 7] "the deck like dead cattle; and, side by side, were seized up into the"][[54 61 8] "mizzen rigging, like three quarters of meat, and there they hung till"][[54 61 9] "morning. 'Damn ye,' cried the Captain, pacing to and fro before them,"][[54 61 10] "'the vultures would not touch ye, ye villains!'"][[54 62 1] "\"At sunrise he summoned all hands; and separating those who had rebelled"][[54 62 2] "from those who had taken no part in the mutiny, he told the former that"][[54 62 3] "he had a good mind to flog them all round--thought, upon the whole,"][[54 62 4] "he would do so--he ought to--justice demanded it; but for the present,"][[54 62 5] "considering their timely surrender, he would let them go with a"][[54 62 6] "reprimand, which he accordingly administered in the vernacular."][[54 63 1] "\"'But as for you, ye carrion rogues,' turning to the three men in the"][[54 63 2] "rigging--'for you, I mean to mince ye up for the try-pots;' and,"][[54 63 3] "seizing a rope, he applied it with all his might to the backs of the"][[54 63 4] "two traitors, till they yelled no more, but lifelessly hung their heads"][[54 63 5] "sideways, as the two crucified thieves are drawn."][[54 64 1] "\"'My wrist is sprained with ye!' he cried, at last; 'but there is still"][[54 64 2] "rope enough left for you, my fine bantam, that wouldn't give up. Take"][[54 64 3] "that gag from his mouth, and let us hear what he can say for himself.'"][[54 65 1] "\"For a moment the exhausted mutineer made a tremulous motion of his"][[54 65 2] "cramped jaws, and then painfully twisting round his head, said in a sort"][[54 65 3] "of hiss, 'What I say is this--and mind it well--if you flog me, I murder"][[54 65 4] "you!'"][[54 66 1] "\"'Say ye so? then see how ye frighten me'--and the Captain drew off with"][[54 66 2] "the rope to strike."][[54 67 1] "\"'Best not,' hissed the Lakeman."][[54 68 1] "\"'But I must,'--and the rope was once more drawn back for the stroke."][[54 69 1] "\"Steelkilt here hissed out something, inaudible to all but the Captain;"][[54 69 2] "who, to the amazement of all hands, started back, paced the deck rapidly"][[54 69 3] "two or three times, and then suddenly throwing down his rope, said, 'I"][[54 69 4] "won't do it--let him go--cut him down: d'ye hear?'"][[54 70 1] "\"But as the junior mates were hurrying to execute the order, a pale man,"][[54 70 2] "with a bandaged head, arrested them--Radney the chief mate. Ever since"][[54 70 3] "the blow, he had lain in his berth; but that morning, hearing the tumult"][[54 70 4] "on the deck, he had crept out, and thus far had watched the whole"][[54 70 5] "scene. Such was the state of his mouth, that he could hardly speak;"][[54 70 6] "but mumbling something about his being willing and able to do what the"][[54 70 7] "captain dared not attempt, he snatched the rope and advanced to his"][[54 70 8] "pinioned foe."][[54 71 1] "\"'You are a coward!' hissed the Lakeman."][[54 72 1] "\"'So I am, but take that.' The mate was in the very act of striking,"][[54 72 2] "when another hiss stayed his uplifted arm. He paused: and then pausing"][[54 72 3] "no more, made good his word, spite of Steelkilt's threat, whatever that"][[54 72 4] "might have been. The three men were then cut down, all hands were turned"][[54 72 5] "to, and, sullenly worked by the moody seamen, the iron pumps clanged as"][[54 72 6] "before."][[54 73 1] "\"Just after dark that day, when one watch had retired below, a clamor"][[54 73 2] "was heard in the forecastle; and the two trembling traitors running up,"][[54 73 3] "besieged the cabin door, saying they durst not consort with the crew."][[54 73 4] "Entreaties, cuffs, and kicks could not drive them back, so at their own"][[54 73 5] "instance they were put down in the ship's run for salvation. Still, no"][[54 73 6] "sign of mutiny reappeared among the rest. On the contrary, it seemed,"][[54 73 7] "that mainly at Steelkilt's instigation, they had resolved to maintain"][[54 73 8] "the strictest peacefulness, obey all orders to the last, and, when the"][[54 73 9] "ship reached port, desert her in a body. But in order to insure the"][[54 73 10] "speediest end to the voyage, they all agreed to another thing--namely,"][[54 73 11] "not to sing out for whales, in case any should be discovered. For,"][[54 73 12] "spite of her leak, and spite of all her other perils, the Town-Ho still"][[54 73 13] "maintained her mast-heads, and her captain was just as willing to"][[54 73 14] "lower for a fish that moment, as on the day his craft first struck the"][[54 73 15] "cruising ground; and Radney the mate was quite as ready to change his"][[54 73 16] "berth for a boat, and with his bandaged mouth seek to gag in death the"][[54 73 17] "vital jaw of the whale."][[54 74 1] "\"But though the Lakeman had induced the seamen to adopt this sort of"][[54 74 2] "passiveness in their conduct, he kept his own counsel (at least till all"][[54 74 3] "was over) concerning his own proper and private revenge upon the man who"][[54 74 4] "had stung him in the ventricles of his heart. He was in Radney the chief"][[54 74 5] "mate's watch; and as if the infatuated man sought to run more than"][[54 74 6] "half way to meet his doom, after the scene at the rigging, he insisted,"][[54 74 7] "against the express counsel of the captain, upon resuming the head"][[54 74 8] "of his watch at night. Upon this, and one or two other circumstances,"][[54 74 9] "Steelkilt systematically built the plan of his revenge."][[54 75 1] "\"During the night, Radney had an unseamanlike way of sitting on the"][[54 75 2] "bulwarks of the quarter-deck, and leaning his arm upon the gunwale of"][[54 75 3] "the boat which was hoisted up there, a little above the ship's side."][[54 75 4] "In this attitude, it was well known, he sometimes dozed. There was a"][[54 75 5] "considerable vacancy between the boat and the ship, and down between"][[54 75 6] "this was the sea. Steelkilt calculated his time, and found that his next"][[54 75 7] "trick at the helm would come round at two o'clock, in the morning of the"][[54 75 8] "third day from that in which he had been betrayed. At his leisure,"][[54 75 9] "he employed the interval in braiding something very carefully in his"][[54 75 10] "watches below."][[54 76 1] "\"'What are you making there?' said a shipmate."][[54 77 1] "\"'What do you think? what does it look like?'"][[54 78 1] "\"'Like a lanyard for your bag; but it's an odd one, seems to me.'"][[54 79 1] "\"'Yes, rather oddish,' said the Lakeman, holding it at arm's length"][[54 79 2] "before him; 'but I think it will answer. Shipmate, I haven't enough"][[54 79 3] "twine,--have you any?'"][[54 80 1] "\"But there was none in the forecastle."][[54 81 1] "\"'Then I must get some from old Rad;' and he rose to go aft."][[54 82 1] "\"'You don't mean to go a begging to HIM!' said a sailor."][[54 83 1] "\"'Why not? Do you think he won't do me a turn, when it's to help himself"][[54 83 2] "in the end, shipmate?' and going to the mate, he looked at him"][[54 83 3] "quietly, and asked him for some twine to mend his hammock. It was given"][[54 83 4] "him--neither twine nor lanyard were seen again; but the next night"][[54 83 5] "an iron ball, closely netted, partly rolled from the pocket of the"][[54 83 6] "Lakeman's monkey jacket, as he was tucking the coat into his hammock for"][[54 83 7] "a pillow. Twenty-four hours after, his trick at the silent helm--nigh"][[54 83 8] "to the man who was apt to doze over the grave always ready dug to"][[54 83 9] "the seaman's hand--that fatal hour was then to come; and in the"][[54 83 10] "fore-ordaining soul of Steelkilt, the mate was already stark and"][[54 83 11] "stretched as a corpse, with his forehead crushed in."][[54 84 1] "\"But, gentlemen, a fool saved the would-be murderer from the bloody"][[54 84 2] "deed he had planned. Yet complete revenge he had, and without being the"][[54 84 3] "avenger. For by a mysterious fatality, Heaven itself seemed to step in"][[54 84 4] "to take out of his hands into its own the damning thing he would have"][[54 84 5] "done."][[54 85 1] "\"It was just between daybreak and sunrise of the morning of the second"][[54 85 2] "day, when they were washing down the decks, that a stupid Teneriffe man,"][[54 85 3] "drawing water in the main-chains, all at once shouted out, 'There she"][[54 85 4] "rolls! there she rolls!' Jesu, what a whale! It was Moby Dick."][[54 86 1] "\"'Moby Dick!' cried Don Sebastian; 'St. Dominic! Sir sailor, but do"][[54 86 2] "whales have christenings? Whom call you Moby Dick?'"][[54 87 1] "\"'A very white, and famous, and most deadly immortal monster, Don;--but"][[54 87 2] "that would be too long a story.'"][[54 88 1] "\"'How? how?' cried all the young Spaniards, crowding."][[54 89 1] "\"'Nay, Dons, Dons--nay, nay! I cannot rehearse that now. Let me get more"][[54 89 2] "into the air, Sirs.'"][[54 90 1] "\"'The chicha! the chicha!' cried Don Pedro; 'our vigorous friend looks"][[54 90 2] "faint;--fill up his empty glass!'"][[54 91 1] "\"No need, gentlemen; one moment, and I proceed.--Now, gentlemen,"][[54 91 2] "so suddenly perceiving the snowy whale within fifty yards of the"][[54 91 3] "ship--forgetful of the compact among the crew--in the excitement of the"][[54 91 4] "moment, the Teneriffe man had instinctively and involuntarily lifted"][[54 91 5] "his voice for the monster, though for some little time past it had been"][[54 91 6] "plainly beheld from the three sullen mast-heads. All was now a phrensy."][[54 91 7] "'The White Whale--the White Whale!' was the cry from captain, mates,"][[54 91 8] "and harpooneers, who, undeterred by fearful rumours, were all anxious"][[54 91 9] "to capture so famous and precious a fish; while the dogged crew eyed"][[54 91 10] "askance, and with curses, the appalling beauty of the vast milky mass,"][[54 91 11] "that lit up by a horizontal spangling sun, shifted and glistened like"][[54 91 12] "a living opal in the blue morning sea. Gentlemen, a strange fatality"][[54 91 13] "pervades the whole career of these events, as if verily mapped out"][[54 91 14] "before the world itself was charted. The mutineer was the bowsman of the"][[54 91 15] "mate, and when fast to a fish, it was his duty to sit next him, while"][[54 91 16] "Radney stood up with his lance in the prow, and haul in or slacken"][[54 91 17] "the line, at the word of command. Moreover, when the four boats were"][[54 91 18] "lowered, the mate's got the start; and none howled more fiercely with"][[54 91 19] "delight than did Steelkilt, as he strained at his oar. After a stiff"][[54 91 20] "pull, their harpooneer got fast, and, spear in hand, Radney sprang to"][[54 91 21] "the bow. He was always a furious man, it seems, in a boat. And now his"][[54 91 22] "bandaged cry was, to beach him on the whale's topmost back. Nothing"][[54 91 23] "loath, his bowsman hauled him up and up, through a blinding foam that"][[54 91 24] "blent two whitenesses together; till of a sudden the boat struck as"][[54 91 25] "against a sunken ledge, and keeling over, spilled out the standing mate."][[54 91 26] "That instant, as he fell on the whale's slippery back, the boat righted,"][[54 91 27] "and was dashed aside by the swell, while Radney was tossed over into the"][[54 91 28] "sea, on the other flank of the whale. He struck out through the spray,"][[54 91 29] "and, for an instant, was dimly seen through that veil, wildly seeking to"][[54 91 30] "remove himself from the eye of Moby Dick. But the whale rushed round"][[54 91 31] "in a sudden maelstrom; seized the swimmer between his jaws; and rearing"][[54 91 32] "high up with him, plunged headlong again, and went down."][[54 92 1] "\"Meantime, at the first tap of the boat's bottom, the Lakeman had"][[54 92 2] "slackened the line, so as to drop astern from the whirlpool; calmly"][[54 92 3] "looking on, he thought his own thoughts. But, at some distance, Moby Dick rose"][[54 92 6] "again, with some tatters of Radney's red woollen shirt, caught in the"][[54 92 7] "teeth that had destroyed him. All four boats gave chase again; but the"][[54 92 8] "whale eluded them, and finally wholly disappeared."][[54 93 1] "\"In good time, the Town-Ho reached her port--a savage, solitary"][[54 93 2] "place--where no civilized creature resided. There, headed by the"][[54 93 3] "Lakeman, all but five or six of the foremastmen deliberately deserted"][[54 93 4] "among the palms; eventually, as it turned out, seizing a large double"][[54 93 5] "war-canoe of the savages, and setting sail for some other harbor."][[54 94 1] "\"The ship's company being reduced to but a handful, the captain called"][[54 94 2] "upon the Islanders to assist him in the laborious business of heaving"][[54 94 3] "down the ship to stop the leak. The captain"][[54 95 5] "presented a pistol. Let me board you a moment--I come in peace.' With that he"][[54 99 2] "leaped from the canoe, swam to the boat; and climbing the gunwale, stood"][[54 99 3] "face to face with the captain."][[54 100 1] "\"'Cross your arms, sir; throw back your head. I see no need of this.'"][[54 113 1] "\"'Excuse me for running after you, Don Sebastian; but may I also beg"][[54 113 2] "that you will be particular in procuring the largest sized Evangelists"][[54 113 3] "you can.'"][[54 114 1] "\"'This is the priest, he brings you the Evangelists,' said Don Sebastian,"][[54 114 2] "gravely, returning with a tall and solemn figure."][[54 115 1] "\"'Let me remove my hat. I know it to be"][[54 116 3] "true; it happened on this ball; I trod the ship; I knew the crew; I have"][[54 116 4] "seen and talked with Steelkilt since the death of Radney.'\""][[55 0 0] "CHAPTER 55. Of the Monstrous Pictures of Whales."][[55 2 1] "I shall ere long paint to you as well as one can without canvas,"][[55 2 2] "something like the true form of the whale as he actually appears to the"][[55 2 3] "eye of the whaleman when in his own absolute body the whale is moored"][[55 2 4] "alongside the whale-ship so that he can be fairly stepped upon there."][[55 2 5] "It may be worth while, therefore, previously to advert to those"][[55 2 6] "curious imaginary portraits of him which even down to the present day"][[55 2 7] "confidently challenge the faith of the landsman. It is time to set the"][[55 2 8] "world right in this matter, by proving such pictures of the whale all"][[55 2 9] "wrong."][[55 3 1] "It may be that the primal source of all those pictorial delusions will"][[55 3 2] "be found among the oldest Hindoo, Egyptian, and Grecian sculptures. For"][[55 3 3] "ever since those inventive but unscrupulous times when on the marble"][[55 3 4] "panellings of temples, the pedestals of statues, and on shields,"][[55 3 5] "medallions, cups, and coins, the dolphin was drawn in scales of"][[55 3 6] "chain-armor like Saladin's, and a helmeted head like St. George's; ever"][[55 3 7] "since then has something of the same sort of license prevailed, not"][[55 3 8] "only in most popular pictures of the whale, but in many scientific"][[55 3 9] "presentations of him."][[55 4 1] "Now, by all odds, the most ancient extant portrait anyways purporting to"][[55 4 2] "be the whale's, is to be found in the famous cavern-pagoda of Elephanta,"][[55 4 3] "in India. The Brahmins maintain that in the almost endless sculptures of"][[55 4 4] "that immemorial pagoda, all the trades and pursuits, every conceivable"][[55 4 5] "avocation of man, were prefigured ages before any of them actually came"][[55 4 6] "into being. No wonder then, that in some sort our noble profession of"][[55 4 7] "whaling should have been there shadowed forth. The Hindoo whale"][[55 4 8] "referred to, occurs in a separate department of the wall, depicting the"][[55 4 9] "incarnation of Vishnu in the form of leviathan, learnedly known as the"][[55 4 10] "Matse Avatar. But though this sculpture is half man and half whale, so"][[55 4 11] "as only to give the tail of the latter, yet that small section of him is"][[55 4 12] "all wrong. It looks more like the tapering tail of an anaconda, than the"][[55 4 13] "broad palms of the true whale's majestic flukes."][[55 5 1] "But go to the old Galleries, and look now at a great Christian painter's"][[55 5 2] "portrait of this fish; for he succeeds no better than the antediluvian"][[55 5 3] "Hindoo. It is Guido's picture of Perseus rescuing Andromeda from the"][[55 5 4] "sea-monster or whale. Where did Guido get the model of such a strange"][[55 5 5] "creature as that? Nor does Hogarth, in painting the same scene in his"][[55 5 6] "own \"Perseus Descending,\" make out one whit better. The huge corpulence"][[55 5 7] "of that Hogarthian monster undulates on the surface, scarcely drawing"][[55 5 8] "one inch of water. It has a sort of howdah on its back, and its"][[55 5 9] "distended tusked mouth into which the billows are rolling, might be"][[55 5 10] "taken for the Traitors' Gate leading from the Thames by water into the"][[55 5 11] "Tower. Then, there are the Prodromus whales of old Scotch Sibbald, and"][[55 5 12] "Jonah's whale, as depicted in the prints of old Bibles and the cuts of"][[55 5 13] "old primers. What shall be said of these? As for the book-binder's whale"][[55 5 14] "winding like a vine-stalk round the stock of a descending anchor--as"][[55 5 15] "stamped and gilded on the backs and title-pages of many books both"][[55 5 16] "old and new--that is a very picturesque but purely fabulous creature,"][[55 5 17] "imitated, I take it, from the like figures on antique vases."][[55 5 18] "Though universally denominated a dolphin, I nevertheless call this"][[55 5 19] "book-binder's fish an attempt at a whale; because it was so intended"][[55 5 20] "when the device was first introduced. It was introduced by an old"][[55 5 21] "Italian publisher somewhere about the th century, during the Revival"][[55 5 22] "of Learning; and in those days, and even down to a comparatively"][[55 5 23] "late period, dolphins were popularly supposed to be a species of the"][[55 5 24] "Leviathan."][[55 6 1] "In the vignettes and other embellishments of some ancient books you will"][[55 6 2] "at times meet with very curious touches at the whale, where all manner"][[55 6 3] "of spouts, jets d'eau, hot springs and cold, Saratoga and Baden-Baden,"][[55 6 4] "come bubbling up from his unexhausted brain. In the title-page of the"][[55 6 5] "original edition of the \"Advancement of Learning\" you will find some"][[55 6 6] "curious whales."][[55 7 1] "But quitting all these unprofessional attempts, let us glance at those"][[55 7 2] "pictures of leviathan purporting to be sober, scientific delineations,"][[55 7 3] "by those who know. In old Harris's collection of voyages there are some"][[55 7 4] "plates of whales extracted from a Dutch book of voyages, A.D. ,"][[55 7 5] "entitled \"A Whaling Voyage to Spitzbergen in the ship Jonas in the"][[55 7 6] "Whale, Peter Peterson of Friesland, master.\" In one of those plates the"][[55 7 7] "whales, like great rafts of logs, are represented lying among ice-isles,"][[55 7 8] "with white bears running over their living backs. In another plate, the"][[55 7 9] "prodigious blunder is made of representing the whale with perpendicular"][[55 7 10] "flukes."][[55 8 1] "Then again, there is an imposing quarto, written by one Captain Colnett,"][[55 8 2] "a Post Captain in the English navy, entitled \"A Voyage round Cape Horn"][[55 8 3] "into the South Seas, for the purpose of extending the Spermaceti Whale"][[55 8 4] "Fisheries.\" In this book is an outline purporting to be a \"Picture of"][[55 8 5] "a Physeter or Spermaceti whale, drawn by scale from one killed on the"][[55 8 6] "coast of Mexico, August, , and hoisted on deck.\" I doubt not the"][[55 8 7] "captain had this veracious picture taken for the benefit of his marines."][[55 8 8] "To mention but one thing about it, let me say that it has an eye which"][[55 8 9] "applied, according to the accompanying scale, to a full grown sperm"][[55 8 10] "whale, would make the eye of that whale a bow-window some five feet"][[55 8 11] "long. Ah, my gallant captain, why did ye not give us Jonah looking out"][[55 8 12] "of that eye!"][[55 9 1] "Nor are the most conscientious compilations of Natural History for"][[55 9 2] "the benefit of the young and tender, free from the same heinousness of"][[55 9 3] "mistake. Look at that popular work \"Goldsmith's Animated Nature.\" In the"][[55 9 4] "abridged London edition of , there are plates of an alleged \"whale\""][[55 9 5] "and a \"narwhale.\" I do not wish to seem inelegant, but this unsightly"][[55 9 6] "whale looks much like an amputated sow; and, as for the narwhale, one"][[55 9 7] "glimpse at it is enough to amaze one, that in this nineteenth century"][[55 9 8] "such a hippogriff could be palmed for genuine upon any intelligent"][[55 9 9] "public of schoolboys."][[55 10 1] "Then, again, in , Bernard Germain, Count de Lacepede, a great"][[55 10 2] "naturalist, published a scientific systemized whale book, wherein are"][[55 10 3] "several pictures of the different species of the Leviathan. All these"][[55 10 4] "are not only incorrect, but the picture of the Mysticetus or Greenland"][[55 10 5] "whale (that is to say, the Right whale), even Scoresby, a long"][[55 10 6] "experienced man as touching that species, declares not to have its"][[55 10 7] "counterpart in nature."][[55 11 1] "But the placing of the cap-sheaf to all this blundering business was"][[55 11 2] "reserved for the scientific Frederick Cuvier, brother to the famous"][[55 11 3] "Baron. In , he published a Natural History of Whales, in which he"][[55 11 4] "gives what he calls a picture of the Sperm Whale. Before showing that"][[55 11 5] "picture to any Nantucketer, you had best provide for your summary"][[55 11 6] "retreat from Nantucket. In a word, Frederick Cuvier's Sperm Whale is not"][[55 11 7] "a Sperm Whale, but a squash. Of course, he never had the benefit of"][[55 11 8] "a whaling voyage (such men seldom have), but whence he derived that"][[55 11 9] "picture, who can tell? Perhaps he got it as his scientific predecessor"][[55 11 10] "in the same field, Desmarest, got one of his authentic abortions; that"][[55 11 11] "is, from a Chinese drawing. And what sort of lively lads with the pencil"][[55 11 12] "those Chinese are, many queer cups and saucers inform us."][[55 12 1] "As for the sign-painters' whales seen in the streets hanging over the"][[55 12 2] "shops of oil-dealers, what shall be said of them?
