They are generally"][[55 12 3] "Richard III. whales, with dromedary humps, and very savage; breakfasting"][[55 12 4] "on three or four sailor tarts, that is whaleboats full of mariners:"][[55 12 5] "their deformities floundering in seas of blood and blue paint."][[55 13 1] "But these manifold mistakes in depicting the whale are not so very"][[55 13 2] "surprising after all. Consider! Most of the scientific drawings have"][[55 13 3] "been taken from the stranded fish; and these are about as correct as a"][[55 13 4] "drawing of a wrecked ship, with broken back, would correctly represent"][[55 13 5] "the noble animal itself in all its undashed pride of hull and spars."][[55 13 6] "Though elephants have stood for their full-lengths, the living Leviathan"][[55 13 7] "has never yet fairly floated himself for his portrait. The living whale,"][[55 13 8] "in his full majesty and significance, is only to be seen at sea in"][[55 13 9] "unfathomable waters; and afloat the vast bulk of him is out of sight,"][[55 13 10] "like a launched line-of-battle ship; and out of that element it is a"][[55 13 11] "thing eternally impossible for mortal man to hoist him bodily into the"][[55 13 12] "air, so as to preserve all his mighty swells and undulations. And, not"][[55 13 13] "to speak of the highly presumable difference of contour between a young"][[55 13 14] "sucking whale and a full-grown Platonian Leviathan; yet, even in the"][[55 13 15] "case of one of those young sucking whales hoisted to a ship's deck, such"][[55 13 16] "is then the outlandish, eel-like, limbered, varying shape of him, that"][[55 13 17] "his precise expression the devil himself could not catch."][[55 14 1] "But it may be fancied, that from the naked skeleton of the stranded"][[55 14 2] "whale, accurate hints may be derived touching his true form. Not at all."][[55 14 3] "For it is one of the more curious things about this Leviathan, that"][[55 14 4] "his skeleton gives very little idea of his general shape. Though Jeremy"][[55 14 5] "Bentham's skeleton, which hangs for candelabra in the library of one of"][[55 14 6] "his executors, correctly conveys the idea of a burly-browed utilitarian"][[55 14 7] "old gentleman, with all Jeremy's other leading personal characteristics;"][[55 14 8] "yet nothing of this kind could be inferred from any leviathan's"][[55 14 9] "articulated bones. In fact, as the great Hunter says, the mere skeleton"][[55 14 10] "of the whale bears the same relation to the fully invested and padded"][[55 14 11] "animal as the insect does to the chrysalis that so roundingly envelopes"][[55 14 12] "it. This peculiarity is strikingly evinced in the head, as in some"][[55 14 13] "part of this book will be incidentally shown. It is also very curiously"][[55 14 14] "displayed in the side fin, the bones of which almost exactly answer to"][[55 14 15] "the bones of the human hand, minus only the thumb. This fin has four"][[55 14 16] "regular bone-fingers, the index, middle, ring, and little finger. But"][[55 14 17] "all these are permanently lodged in their fleshy covering, as the human"][[55 14 18] "fingers in an artificial covering. \"However recklessly the whale may"][[55 14 19] "sometimes serve us,\" said humorous Stubb one day, \"he can never be truly"][[55 14 20] "said to handle us without mittens.\""][[55 15 1] "For all these reasons, then, any way you may look at it, you must needs"][[55 15 2] "conclude that the great Leviathan is that one creature in the world"][[55 15 3] "which must remain unpainted to the last. True, one portrait may hit"][[55 15 4] "the mark much nearer than another, but none can hit it with any very"][[55 15 5] "considerable degree of exactness. So there is no earthly way of finding"][[55 15 6] "out precisely what the whale really looks like. And the only mode in"][[55 15 7] "which you can derive even a tolerable idea of his living contour, is"][[55 15 8] "by going a whaling yourself; but by so doing, you run no small risk of"][[55 15 9] "being eternally stove and sunk by him. Wherefore, it seems to me you had"][[55 15 10] "best not be too fastidious in your curiosity touching this Leviathan."][[56 0 0] "CHAPTER 56. Of the Less Erroneous Pictures of Whales, and the True"][[56 0 1] "Pictures of Whaling Scenes."][[56 2 1] "In connexion with the monstrous pictures of whales, I am strongly"][[56 2 2] "tempted here to enter upon those still more monstrous stories of"][[56 2 3] "them which are to be found in certain books, both ancient and modern,"][[56 2 4] "especially in Pliny, Purchas, Hackluyt, Harris, Cuvier, etc. But I pass"][[56 2 5] "that matter by."][[56 3 1] "I know of only four published outlines of the great Sperm Whale;"][[56 3 2] "Colnett's, Huggins's, Frederick Cuvier's, and Beale's. In the previous"][[56 3 3] "chapter Colnett and Cuvier have been referred to. Huggins's is far"][[56 3 4] "better than theirs; but, by great odds, Beale's is the best. All Beale's"][[56 3 5] "drawings of this whale are good, excepting the middle figure in the"][[56 3 6] "picture of three whales in various attitudes, capping his second"][[56 3 7] "chapter. His frontispiece, boats attacking Sperm Whales, though no"][[56 3 8] "doubt calculated to excite the civil scepticism of some parlor men, is"][[56 3 9] "admirably correct and life-like in its general effect. Some of the Sperm"][[56 3 10] "Whale drawings in J. Ross Browne are pretty correct in contour; but they"][[56 3 11] "are wretchedly engraved. That is not his fault though."][[56 4 1] "Of the Right Whale, the best outline pictures are in Scoresby; but they"][[56 4 2] "are drawn on too small a scale to convey a desirable impression. He has"][[56 4 3] "but one picture of whaling scenes, and this is a sad deficiency, because"][[56 4 4] "it is by such pictures only, when at all well done, that you can derive"][[56 4 5] "anything like a truthful idea of the living whale as seen by his living"][[56 4 6] "hunters."][[56 5 1] "But, taken for all in all, by far the finest, though in some details"][[56 5 2] "not the most correct, presentations of whales and whaling scenes to"][[56 5 3] "be anywhere found, are two large French engravings, well executed,"][[56 5 4] "and taken from paintings by one Garnery. Respectively, they represent"][[56 5 5] "attacks on the Sperm and Right Whale. In the first engraving a noble"][[56 5 6] "Sperm Whale is depicted in full majesty of might, just risen beneath"][[56 5 7] "the boat from the profundities of the ocean, and bearing high in the air"][[56 5 8] "upon his back the terrific wreck of the stoven planks. The prow of"][[56 5 9] "the boat is partially unbroken, and is drawn just balancing upon"][[56 5 10] "the monster's spine; and standing in that prow, for that one single"][[56 5 11] "incomputable flash of time, you behold an oarsman, half shrouded by the"][[56 5 12] "incensed boiling spout of the whale, and in the act of leaping, as if"][[56 5 13] "from a precipice. The action of the whole thing is wonderfully good and"][[56 5 14] "true. The half-emptied line-tub floats on the whitened sea; the wooden"][[56 5 15] "poles of the spilled harpoons obliquely bob in it; the heads of the"][[56 5 16] "swimming crew are scattered about the whale in contrasting expressions"][[56 5 17] "of affright; while in the black stormy distance the ship is bearing down"][[56 5 18] "upon the scene. Serious fault might be found with the anatomical details"][[56 5 19] "of this whale, but let that pass; since, for the life of me, I could not"][[56 5 20] "draw so good a one."][[56 6 1] "In the second engraving, the boat is in the act of drawing alongside"][[56 6 2] "the barnacled flank of a large running Right Whale, that rolls his black"][[56 6 3] "weedy bulk in the sea like some mossy rock-slide from the Patagonian"][[56 6 4] "cliffs. His jets are erect, full, and black like soot; so that from so"][[56 6 5] "abounding a smoke in the chimney, you would think there must be a brave"][[56 6 6] "supper cooking in the great bowels below. Sea fowls are pecking at the"][[56 6 7] "small crabs, shell-fish, and other sea candies and maccaroni, which the"][[56 6 8] "Right Whale sometimes carries on his pestilent back. And all the while"][[56 6 9] "the thick-lipped leviathan is rushing through the deep, leaving tons of"][[56 6 10] "tumultuous white curds in his wake, and causing the slight boat to rock"][[56 6 11] "in the swells like a skiff caught nigh the paddle-wheels of an ocean"][[56 6 12] "steamer. Thus, the foreground is all raging commotion; but behind, in"][[56 6 13] "admirable artistic contrast, is the glassy level of a sea becalmed, the"][[56 6 14] "drooping unstarched sails of the powerless ship, and the inert mass of"][[56 6 15] "a dead whale, a conquered fortress, with the flag of capture lazily"][[56 6 16] "hanging from the whale-pole inserted into his spout-hole."][[56 7 1] "Who Garnery the painter is, or was, I know not. But my life for it he"][[56 7 2] "was either practically conversant with his subject, or else marvellously"][[56 7 3] "tutored by some experienced whaleman. The French are the lads for"][[56 7 4] "painting action. Go and gaze upon all the paintings of Europe, and"][[56 7 5] "where will you find such a gallery of living and breathing commotion"][[56 7 6] "on canvas, as in that triumphal hall at Versailles; where the beholder"][[56 7 7] "fights his way, pell-mell, through the consecutive great battles of"][[56 7 8] "France; where every sword seems a flash of the Northern Lights, and the"][[56 7 9] "successive armed kings and Emperors dash by, like a charge of crowned"][[56 7 10] "centaurs? Not wholly unworthy of a place in that gallery, are these sea"][[56 7 11] "battle-pieces of Garnery."][[56 8 1] "The natural aptitude of the French for seizing the picturesqueness of"][[56 8 2] "things seems to be peculiarly evinced in what paintings and engravings"][[56 8 3] "they have of their whaling scenes. With not one tenth of England's"][[56 8 4] "experience in the fishery, and not the thousandth part of that of the"][[56 8 5] "Americans, they have nevertheless furnished both nations with the only"][[56 8 6] "finished sketches at all capable of conveying the real spirit of"][[56 8 7] "the whale hunt. For the most part, the English and American whale"][[56 8 8] "draughtsmen seem entirely content with presenting the mechanical outline"][[56 8 9] "of things, such as the vacant profile of the whale; which, so far as"][[56 8 10] "picturesqueness of effect is concerned, is about tantamount to sketching"][[56 8 11] "the profile of a pyramid. Even Scoresby, the justly renowned Right"][[56 8 12] "whaleman, after giving us a stiff full length of the Greenland whale,"][[56 8 13] "and three or four delicate miniatures of narwhales and porpoises, treats"][[56 8 14] "us to a series of classical engravings of boat hooks, chopping knives,"][[56 8 15] "and grapnels; and with the microscopic diligence of a Leuwenhoeck"][[56 8 16] "submits to the inspection of a shivering world ninety-six fac-similes of"][[56 8 17] "magnified Arctic snow crystals. I mean no disparagement to the excellent"][[56 8 18] "voyager (I honour him for a veteran), but in so important a matter it"][[56 8 19] "was certainly an oversight not to have procured for every crystal a"][[56 8 20] "sworn affidavit taken before a Greenland Justice of the Peace."][[56 9 1] "In addition to those fine engravings from Garnery, there are two other"][[56 9 2] "French engravings worthy of note, by some one who subscribes himself"][[56 9 3] "\"H. Durand.\" One of them, though not precisely adapted to our present"][[56 9 4] "purpose, nevertheless deserves mention on other accounts. It is a quiet"][[56 9 5] "noon-scene among the isles of the Pacific; a French whaler anchored,"][[56 9 6] "inshore, in a calm, and lazily taking water on board; the loosened sails"][[56 9 7] "of the ship, and the long leaves of the palms in the background, both"][[56 9 8] "drooping together in the breezeless air. The effect is very fine, when"][[56 9 9] "considered with reference to its presenting the hardy fishermen under"][[56 9 10] "one of their few aspects of oriental repose. The other engraving is"][[56 9 11] "quite a different affair: the ship hove-to upon the open sea, and in the"][[56 9 12] "very heart of the Leviathanic life, with a Right Whale alongside; the"][[56 9 13] "vessel (in the act of cutting-in) hove over to the monster as if to a"][[56 9 14] "quay; and a boat, hurriedly pushing off from this scene of activity, is"][[56 9 15] "about giving chase to whales in the distance. The harpoons and lances"][[56 9 16] "lie levelled for use; three oarsmen are just setting the mast in its"][[56 9 17] "hole; while from a sudden roll of the sea, the little craft stands"][[56 9 18] "half-erect out of the water, like a rearing horse. From the ship, the"][[56 9 19] "smoke of the torments of the boiling whale is going up like the smoke"][[56 9 20] "over a village of smithies; and to windward, a black cloud, rising up"][[56 9 21] "with earnest of squalls and rains, seems to quicken the activity of the"][[56 9 22] "excited seamen."][[57 0 0] "CHAPTER 57. Of Whales in Paint; in Teeth; in Wood; in Sheet-Iron; in"][[57 0 1] "Stone; in Mountains; in Stars."][[57 2 1] "On Tower-hill, as you go down to the London docks, you may have seen a"][[57 2 2] "crippled beggar (or KEDGER, as the sailors say) holding a painted board"][[57 2 3] "before him, representing the tragic scene in which he lost his leg."][[57 2 4] "There are three whales and three boats; and one of the boats (presumed"][[57 2 5] "to contain the missing leg in all its original integrity) is being"][[57 2 6] "crunched by the jaws of the foremost whale. Any time these ten years,"][[57 2 7] "they tell me, has that man held up that picture, and exhibited that"][[57 2 8] "stump to an incredulous world. But the time of his justification has"][[57 2 9] "now come. His three whales are as good whales as were ever published in"][[57 2 10] "Wapping, at any rate; and his stump as unquestionable a stump as any you"][[57 2 11] "will find in the western clearings. But, though for ever mounted on"][[57 2 12] "that stump, never a stump-speech does the poor whaleman make; but, with"][[57 2 13] "downcast eyes, stands ruefully contemplating his own amputation."][[57 3 1] "Throughout the Pacific, and also in Nantucket, and New Bedford, and"][[57 3 2] "Sag Harbor, you will come across lively sketches of whales and"][[57 3 3] "whaling-scenes, graven by the fishermen themselves on Sperm Whale-teeth,"][[57 3 4] "or ladies' busks wrought out of the Right Whale-bone, and other"][[57 3 5] "like skrimshander articles, as the whalemen call the numerous little"][[57 3 6] "ingenious contrivances they elaborately carve out of the rough material,"][[57 3 7] "in their hours of ocean leisure. Some of them have little boxes"][[57 3 8] "of dentistical-looking implements, specially intended for the"][[57 3 9] "skrimshandering business. But, in general, they toil with their"][[57 3 10] "jack-knives alone; and, with that almost omnipotent tool of the sailor,"][[57 3 11] "they will turn you out anything you please, in the way of a mariner's"][[57 3 12] "fancy."][[57 4 1] "Long exile from Christendom and civilization inevitably restores a man"][[57 4 2] "to that condition in which God placed him, i.e. what is called savagery."][[57 4 3] "Your true whale-hunter is as much a savage as an Iroquois. I myself am a"][[57 4 4] "savage, owning no allegiance but to the King of the Cannibals; and ready"][[57 4 5] "at any moment to rebel against him."][[57 5 1] "Now, one of the peculiar characteristics of the savage in his domestic"][[57 5 2] "hours, is his wonderful patience of industry. An ancient Hawaiian"][[57 5 3] "war-club or spear-paddle, in its full multiplicity and elaboration of"][[57 5 4] "carving, is as great a trophy of human perseverance as a Latin lexicon."][[57 5 5] "For, with but a bit of broken sea-shell or a shark's tooth, that"][[57 5 6] "miraculous intricacy of wooden net-work has been achieved; and it has"][[57 5 7] "cost steady years of steady application."][[57 6 1] "As with the Hawaiian savage, so with the white sailor-savage. With the"][[57 6 2] "same marvellous patience, and with the same single shark's tooth, of"][[57 6 3] "his one poor jack-knife, he will carve you a bit of bone sculpture, not"][[57 6 4] "quite as workmanlike, but as close packed in its maziness of design,"][[57 6 5] "as the Greek savage, Achilles's shield; and full of barbaric spirit"][[57 6 6] "and suggestiveness, as the prints of that fine old Dutch savage, Albert"][[57 6 7] "Durer."][[57 7 1] "Wooden whales, or whales cut in profile out of the small dark slabs of"][[57 7 2] "the noble South Sea war-wood, are frequently met with in the forecastles"][[57 7 3] "of American whalers. Some of them are done with much accuracy."][[57 8 1] "At some old gable-roofed country houses you will see brass whales hung"][[57 8 2] "by the tail for knockers to the road-side door. When the porter is"][[57 8 3] "sleepy, the anvil-headed whale would be best. But these knocking"][[57 8 4] "whales are seldom remarkable as faithful essays. On the spires of some"][[57 8 5] "old-fashioned churches you will see sheet-iron whales placed there for"][[57 8 6] "weather-cocks; but they are so elevated, and besides that are to all"][[57 8 7] "intents and purposes so labelled with \"HANDS OFF!\" you cannot examine"][[57 8 8] "them closely enough to decide upon their merit."][[57 9 1] "In bony, ribby regions of the earth, where at the base of high broken"][[57 9 2] "cliffs masses of rock lie strewn in fantastic groupings upon the"][[57 9 3] "plain, you will often discover images as of the petrified forms of the"][[57 9 4] "Leviathan partly merged in grass, which of a windy day breaks against"][[57 9 5] "them in a surf of green surges."][[57 10 1] "Then, again, in mountainous countries where the traveller is continually"][[57 10 2] "girdled by amphitheatrical heights; here and there from some lucky"][[57 10 3] "point of view you will catch passing glimpses of the profiles of"][[57 10 4] "whales defined along the undulating ridges. But you must be a thorough"][[57 10 5] "whaleman, to see these sights; and not only that, but if you wish"][[57 10 6] "to return to such a sight again, you must be sure and take the exact"][[57 10 7] "intersecting latitude and longitude of your first stand-point, else"][[57 10 8] "so chance-like are such observations of the hills, that your precise,"][[57 10 9] "previous stand-point would require a laborious re-discovery; like the"][[57 10 10] "Soloma Islands, which still remain incognita, though once high-ruffed"][[57 10 11] "Mendanna trod them and old Figuera chronicled them."][[57 11 1] "Nor when expandingly lifted by your subject, can you fail to trace out"][[57 11 2] "great whales in the starry heavens, and boats in pursuit of them; as"][[57 11 3] "when long filled with thoughts of war the Eastern nations saw armies"][[57 11 4] "locked in battle among the clouds. Thus at the North have I chased"][[57 11 5] "Leviathan round and round the Pole with the revolutions of the bright"][[57 11 6] "points that first defined him to me. And beneath the effulgent Antarctic"][[57 11 7] "skies I have boarded the Argo-Navis, and joined the chase against the"][[57 11 8] "starry Cetus far beyond the utmost stretch of Hydrus and the Flying"][[57 11 9] "Fish."][[57 12 1] "With a frigate's anchors for my bridle-bitts and fasces of harpoons for"][[57 12 2] "spurs, would I could mount that whale and leap the topmost skies, to"][[57 12 3] "see whether the fabled heavens with all their countless tents really lie"][[57 12 4] "encamped beyond my mortal sight!"][[58 0 0] "CHAPTER 58. Brit."][[58 2 1] "Steering north-eastward from the Crozetts, we fell in with vast meadows"][[58 2 2] "of brit, the minute, yellow substance, upon which the Right Whale"][[58 2 3] "largely feeds. For leagues and leagues it undulated round us, so that we"][[58 2 4] "seemed to be sailing through boundless fields of ripe and golden wheat."][[58 3 1] "On the second day, numbers of Right Whales were seen, who, secure from"][[58 3 2] "the attack of a Sperm Whaler like the Pequod, with open jaws sluggishly"][[58 3 3] "swam through the brit, which, adhering to the fringing fibres of that"][[58 3 4] "wondrous Venetian blind in their mouths, was in that manner separated"][[58 3 5] "from the water that escaped at the lip."][[58 4 1] "As morning mowers, who side by side slowly and seethingly advance"][[58 4 2] "their scythes through the long wet grass of marshy meads; even so these"][[58 4 3] "monsters swam, making a strange, grassy, cutting sound; and leaving"][[58 4 4] "behind them endless swaths of blue upon the yellow sea.*"][[58 6 1] "*That part of the sea known among whalemen as the \"Brazil Banks\" does"][[58 6 2] "not bear that name as the Banks of Newfoundland do, because of there"][[58 6 3] "being shallows and soundings there, but because of this remarkable"][[58 6 4] "meadow-like appearance, caused by the vast drifts of brit continually"][[58 6 5] "floating in those latitudes, where the Right Whale is often chased."][[58 8 1] "But it was only the sound they made as they parted the brit which at all"][[58 8 2] "reminded one of mowers. Seen from the mast-heads, especially when they"][[58 8 3] "paused and were stationary for a while, their vast black forms looked"][[58 8 4] "more like lifeless masses of rock than anything else. And as in the"][[58 8 5] "great hunting countries of India, the stranger at a distance will"][[58 8 6] "sometimes pass on the plains recumbent elephants without knowing them"][[58 8 7] "to be such, taking them for bare, blackened elevations of the soil; even"][[58 8 8] "so, often, with him, who for the first time beholds this species of the"][[58 8 9] "leviathans of the sea. And even when recognised at last, their immense"][[58 8 10] "magnitude renders it very hard really to believe that such bulky masses"][[58 8 11] "of overgrowth can possibly be instinct, in all parts, with the same sort"][[58 8 12] "of life that lives in a dog or a horse."][[58 9 1] "Indeed, in other respects, you can hardly regard any creatures of the"][[58 9 2] "deep with the same feelings that you do those of the shore. For though"][[58 9 3] "some old naturalists have maintained that all creatures of the land are"][[58 9 4] "of their kind in the sea; and though taking a broad general view of"][[58 9 5] "the thing, this may very well be; yet coming to specialties, where, for"][[58 9 6] "example, does the ocean furnish any fish that in disposition answers to"][[58 9 7] "the sagacious kindness of the dog? The accursed shark alone can in any"][[58 9 8] "generic respect be said to bear comparative analogy to him."][[58 10 1] "But though, to landsmen in general, the native inhabitants of the"][[58 10 2] "seas have ever been regarded with emotions unspeakably unsocial and"][[58 10 3] "repelling; though we know the sea to be an everlasting terra incognita,"][[58 10 4] "so that Columbus sailed over numberless unknown worlds to discover his"][[58 10 5] "one superficial western one; though, by vast odds, the most terrific"][[58 10 6] "of all mortal disasters have immemorially and indiscriminately befallen"][[58 10 7] "tens and hundreds of thousands of those who have gone upon the waters;"][[58 10 8] "though but a moment's consideration will teach, that however baby man"][[58 10 9] "may brag of his science and skill, and however much, in a flattering"][[58 10 10] "future, that science and skill may augment; yet for ever and for ever,"][[58 10 11] "to the crack of doom, the sea will insult and murder him, and pulverize"][[58 10 12] "the stateliest, stiffest frigate he can make; nevertheless, by the"][[58 10 13] "continual repetition of these very impressions, man has lost that sense"][[58 10 14] "of the full awfulness of the sea which aboriginally belongs to it."][[58 11 1] "The first boat we read of, floated on an ocean, that with Portuguese"][[58 11 2] "vengeance had whelmed a whole world without leaving so much as a widow."][[58 11 3] "That same ocean rolls now; that same ocean destroyed the wrecked ships"][[58 11 4] "of last year. Yea, foolish mortals, Noah's flood is not yet subsided;"][[58 11 5] "two thirds of the fair world it yet covers."][[58 12 1] "Wherein differ the sea and the land, that a miracle upon one is not a"][[58 12 2] "miracle upon the other? Preternatural terrors rested upon the Hebrews,"][[58 12 3] "when under the feet of Korah and his company the live ground opened"][[58 12 4] "and swallowed them up for ever; yet not a modern sun ever sets, but in"][[58 12 5] "precisely the same manner the live sea swallows up ships and crews."][[58 13 1] "But not only is the sea such a foe to man who is an alien to it, but it"][[58 13 2] "is also a fiend to its own off-spring; worse than the Persian host who"][[58 13 3] "murdered his own guests; sparing not the creatures which itself hath"][[58 13 4] "spawned. Like a savage tigress that tossing in the jungle overlays her"][[58 13 5] "own cubs, so the sea dashes even the mightiest whales against the rocks,"][[58 13 6] "and leaves them there side by side with the split wrecks of ships. No"][[58 13 7] "mercy, no power but its own controls it. Panting and snorting like a mad"][[58 13 8] "battle steed that has lost its rider, the masterless ocean overruns the"][[58 13 9] "globe."][[58 14 1] "Consider the subtleness of the sea; how its most dreaded creatures glide"][[58 14 2] "under water, unapparent for the most part, and treacherously hidden"][[58 14 3] "beneath the loveliest tints of azure. Consider also the devilish"][[58 14 4] "brilliance and beauty of many of its most remorseless tribes, as the"][[58 14 5] "dainty embellished shape of many species of sharks. Consider, once more,"][[58 14 6] "the universal cannibalism of the sea; all whose creatures prey upon each"][[58 14 7] "other, carrying on eternal war since the world began."][[58 15 1] "Consider all this; and then turn to this green, gentle, and most docile"][[58 15 2] "earth; consider them both, the sea and the land; and do you not find a"][[58 15 3] "strange analogy to something in yourself? For as this appalling ocean"][[58 15 4] "surrounds the verdant land, so in the soul of man there lies one insular"][[58 15 5] "Tahiti, full of peace and joy, but encompassed by all the horrors of the"][[58 15 6] "half known life. God keep thee! Push not off from that isle, thou canst"][[58 15 7] "never return!"][[59 0 0] "CHAPTER 59. Squid."][[59 2 1] "Slowly wading through the meadows of brit, the Pequod still held on her"][[59 2 2] "way north-eastward towards the island of Java; a gentle air impelling"][[59 2 3] "her keel, so that in the surrounding serenity her three tall tapering"][[59 2 4] "masts mildly waved to that languid breeze, as three mild palms on a"][[59 2 5] "plain. And still, at wide intervals in the silvery night, the lonely,"][[59 2 6] "alluring jet would be seen."][[59 3 1] "But one transparent blue morning, when a stillness almost preternatural"][[59 3 2] "spread over the sea, however unattended with any stagnant calm; when"][[59 3 3] "the long burnished sun-glade on the waters seemed a golden finger laid"][[59 3 4] "across them, enjoining some secrecy; when the slippered waves whispered"][[59 3 5] "together as they softly ran on; in this profound hush of the visible"][[59 3 6] "sphere a strange spectre was seen by Daggoo from the main-mast-head."][[59 4 1] "In the distance, a great white mass lazily rose, and rising higher and"][[59 4 2] "higher, and disentangling itself from the azure, at last gleamed before"][[59 4 3] "our prow like a snow-slide, new slid from the hills. Thus glistening"][[59 4 4] "for a moment, as slowly it subsided, and sank. Then once more arose,"][[59 4 5] "and silently gleamed. It seemed not a whale; and yet is this Moby Dick?"][[59 4 6] "thought Daggoo. Again the phantom went down, but on re-appearing once"][[59 4 7] "more, with a stiletto-like cry that startled every man from his nod, the"][[59 4 8] "negro yelled out--\"There! there again! there she breaches! right ahead!"][[59 4 9] "The White Whale, the White Whale!\""][[59 5 1] "Upon this, the seamen rushed to the yard-arms, as in swarming-time the"][[59 5 2] "bees rush to the boughs. Bare-headed in the sultry sun, Ahab stood on"][[59 5 3] "the bowsprit, and with one hand pushed far behind in readiness to wave"][[59 5 4] "his orders to the helmsman, cast his eager glance in the direction"][[59 5 5] "indicated aloft by the outstretched motionless arm of Daggoo."][[59 6 1] "Whether the flitting attendance of the one still and solitary jet had"][[59 6 2] "gradually worked upon Ahab, so that he was now prepared to connect the"][[59 6 3] "ideas of mildness and repose with the first sight of the particular"][[59 6 4] "whale he pursued; however this was, or whether his eagerness betrayed"][[59 6 5] "him; whichever way it might have been, no sooner did he distinctly"][[59 6 6] "perceive the white mass, than with a quick intensity he instantly gave"][[59 6 7] "orders for lowering."][[59 7 1] "The four boats were soon on the water; Ahab's in advance, and all"][[59 7 2] "swiftly pulling towards their prey. Soon it went down, and while, with"][[59 7 3] "oars suspended, we were awaiting its reappearance, lo! in the same"][[59 7 4] "spot where it sank, once more it slowly rose. Almost forgetting for"][[59 7 5] "the moment all thoughts of Moby Dick, we now gazed at the most wondrous"][[59 7 6] "phenomenon which the secret seas have hitherto revealed to mankind."][[59 7 7] "A vast pulpy mass, furlongs in length and breadth, of a glancing"][[59 7 8] "cream-colour, lay floating on the water, innumerable long arms radiating"][[59 7 9] "from its centre, and curling and twisting like a nest of anacondas, as"][[59 7 10] "if blindly to clutch at any hapless object within reach. No perceptible"][[59 7 11] "face or front did it have; no conceivable token of either sensation or"][[59 7 12] "instinct; but undulated there on the billows, an unearthly, formless,"][[59 7 13] "chance-like apparition of life."][[59 8 1] "As with a low sucking sound it slowly disappeared again, Starbuck still"][[59 8 2] "gazing at the agitated waters where it had sunk, with a wild voice"][[59 8 3] "exclaimed--\"Almost rather had I seen Moby Dick and fought him, than to"][[59 8 4] "have seen thee, thou white ghost!\""][[59 9 1] "\"What was it, Sir?\" said Flask."][[59 10 1] "\"The great live squid, which, they say, few whale-ships ever beheld, and"][[59 10 2] "returned to their ports to tell of it.\""][[59 11 1] "But Ahab said nothing; turning his boat, he sailed back to the vessel;"][[59 11 2] "the rest as silently following."][[59 12 1] "Whatever superstitions the sperm whalemen in general have connected with"][[59 12 2] "the sight of this object, certain it is, that a glimpse of it being"][[59 12 3] "so very unusual, that circumstance has gone far to invest it with"][[59 12 4] "portentousness. So rarely is it beheld, that though one and all of them"][[59 12 5] "declare it to be the largest animated thing in the ocean, yet very few"][[59 12 6] "of them have any but the most vague ideas concerning its true nature and"][[59 12 7] "form; notwithstanding, they believe it to furnish to the sperm whale"][[59 12 8] "his only food. For though other species of whales find their food above"][[59 12 9] "water, and may be seen by man in the act of feeding, the spermaceti"][[59 12 10] "whale obtains his whole food in unknown zones below the surface; and"][[59 12 11] "only by inference is it that any one can tell of what, precisely, that"][[59 12 12] "food consists. At times, when closely pursued, he will disgorge what"][[59 12 13] "are supposed to be the detached arms of the squid; some of them thus"][[59 12 14] "exhibited exceeding twenty and thirty feet in length. They fancy that"][[59 12 15] "the monster to which these arms belonged ordinarily clings by them to"][[59 12 16] "the bed of the ocean; and that the sperm whale, unlike other species, is"][[59 12 17] "supplied with teeth in order to attack and tear it."][[59 13 1] "There seems some ground to imagine that the great Kraken of Bishop"][[59 13 2] "Pontoppodan may ultimately resolve itself into Squid. The manner in"][[59 13 3] "which the Bishop describes it, as alternately rising and sinking, with"][[59 13 4] "some other particulars he narrates, in all this the two correspond."][[59 13 5] "But much abatement is necessary with respect to the incredible bulk he"][[59 13 6] "assigns it."][[59 14 1] "By some naturalists who have vaguely heard rumors of the mysterious"][[59 14 2] "creature, here spoken of, it is included among the class of cuttle-fish,"][[59 14 3] "to which, indeed, in certain external respects it would seem to belong,"][[59 14 4] "but only as the Anak of the tribe."][[60 0 0] "CHAPTER 60. The Line."][[60 2 1] "With reference to the whaling scene shortly to be described, as well as"][[60 2 2] "for the better understanding of all similar scenes elsewhere presented,"][[60 2 3] "I have here to speak of the magical, sometimes horrible whale-line."][[60 3 1] "The line originally used in the fishery was of the best hemp, slightly"][[60 3 2] "vapoured with tar, not impregnated with it, as in the case of ordinary"][[60 3 3] "ropes; for while tar, as ordinarily used, makes the hemp more pliable to"][[60 3 4] "the rope-maker, and also renders the rope itself more convenient to the"][[60 3 5] "sailor for common ship use; yet, not only would the ordinary quantity"][[60 3 6] "too much stiffen the whale-line for the close coiling to which it must"][[60 3 7] "be subjected; but as most seamen are beginning to learn, tar in general"][[60 3 8] "by no means adds to the rope's durability or strength, however much it"][[60 3 9] "may give it compactness and gloss."][[60 4 1] "Of late years the Manilla rope has in the American fishery almost"][[60 4 2] "entirely superseded hemp as a material for whale-lines; for, though not"][[60 4 3] "so durable as hemp, it is stronger, and far more soft and elastic; and"][[60 4 4] "I will add (since there is an aesthetics in all things), is much more"][[60 4 5] "handsome and becoming to the boat, than hemp. Hemp is a dusky, dark"][[60 4 6] "fellow, a sort of Indian; but Manilla is as a golden-haired Circassian"][[60 4 7] "to behold."][[60 5 1] "The whale-line is only two-thirds of an inch in thickness. At first"][[60 5 2] "sight, you would not think it so strong as it really is. By experiment"][[60 5 3] "its one and fifty yarns will each suspend a weight of one hundred and"][[60 5 4] "twenty pounds; so that the whole rope will bear a strain nearly equal"][[60 5 5] "to three tons. In length, the common sperm whale-line measures something"][[60 5 6] "over two hundred fathoms. Towards the stern of the boat it is spirally"][[60 5 7] "coiled away in the tub, not like the worm-pipe of a still though, but so"][[60 5 8] "as to form one round, cheese-shaped mass of densely bedded \"sheaves,\" or"][[60 5 9] "layers of concentric spiralizations, without any hollow but the \"heart,\""][[60 5 10] "or minute vertical tube formed at the axis of the cheese. As the least"][[60 5 11] "tangle or kink in the coiling would, in running out, infallibly take"][[60 5 12] "somebody's arm, leg, or entire body off, the utmost precaution is used"][[60 5 13] "in stowing the line in its tub. Some harpooneers will consume almost an"][[60 5 14] "entire morning in this business, carrying the line high aloft and then"][[60 5 15] "reeving it downwards through a block towards the tub, so as in the act"][[60 5 16] "of coiling to free it from all possible wrinkles and twists."][[60 6 1] "In the English boats two tubs are used instead of one; the same line"][[60 6 2] "being continuously coiled in both tubs. There is some advantage in this;"][[60 6 3] "because these twin-tubs being so small they fit more readily into the"][[60 6 4] "boat, and do not strain it so much; whereas, the American tub, nearly"][[60 6 5] "three feet in diameter and of proportionate depth, makes a rather bulky"][[60 6 6] "freight for a craft whose planks are but one half-inch in thickness; for"][[60 6 7] "the bottom of the whale-boat is like critical ice, which will bear up"][[60 6 8] "a considerable distributed weight, but not very much of a concentrated"][[60 6 9] "one. When the painted canvas cover is clapped on the American line-tub,"][[60 6 10] "the boat looks as if it were pulling off with a prodigious great"][[60 6 11] "wedding-cake to present to the whales."][[60 7 1] "Both ends of the line are exposed; the lower end terminating in an"][[60 7 2] "eye-splice or loop coming up from the bottom against the side of the"][[60 7 3] "tub, and hanging over its edge completely disengaged from everything."][[60 7 4] "This arrangement of the lower end is necessary on two accounts. First:"][[60 7 5] "In order to facilitate the fastening to it of an additional line from a"][[60 7 6] "neighboring boat, in case the stricken whale should sound so deep as"][[60 7 7] "to threaten to carry off the entire line originally attached to the"][[60 7 8] "harpoon. In these instances, the whale of course is shifted like a mug"][[60 7 9] "of ale, as it were, from the one boat to the other; though the"][[60 7 10] "first boat always hovers at hand to assist its consort. Second: This"][[60 7 11] "arrangement is indispensable for common safety's sake; for were the"][[60 7 12] "lower end of the line in any way attached to the boat, and were the"][[60 7 13] "whale then to run the line out to the end almost in a single, smoking"][[60 7 14] "minute as he sometimes does, he would not stop there, for the doomed"][[60 7 15] "boat would infallibly be dragged down after him into the profundity of"][[60 7 16] "the sea; and in that case no town-crier would ever find her again."][[60 8 1] "Before lowering the boat for the chase, the upper end of the line is"][[60 8 2] "taken aft from the tub, and passing round the loggerhead there, is again"][[60 8 3] "carried forward the entire length of the boat, resting crosswise upon"][[60 8 4] "the loom or handle of every man's oar, so that it jogs against his wrist"][[60 8 5] "in rowing; and also passing between the men, as they alternately sit at"][[60 8 6] "the opposite gunwales, to the leaded chocks or grooves in the extreme"][[60 8 7] "pointed prow of the boat, where a wooden pin or skewer the size of a"][[60 8 8] "common quill, prevents it from slipping out. From the chocks it hangs"][[60 8 9] "in a slight festoon over the bows, and is then passed inside the boat"][[60 8 10] "again; and some ten or twenty fathoms (called box-line) being coiled"][[60 8 11] "upon the box in the bows, it continues its way to the gunwale still a"][[60 8 12] "little further aft, and is then attached to the short-warp--the rope"][[60 8 13] "which is immediately connected with the harpoon; but previous to that"][[60 8 14] "connexion, the short-warp goes through sundry mystifications too tedious"][[60 8 15] "to detail."][[60 9 1] "Thus the whale-line folds the whole boat in its complicated coils,"][[60 9 2] "twisting and writhing around it in almost every direction. All the"][[60 9 3] "oarsmen are involved in its perilous contortions; so that to the timid"][[60 9 4] "eye of the landsman, they seem as Indian jugglers, with the deadliest"][[60 9 5] "snakes sportively festooning their limbs. Nor can any son of mortal"][[60 9 6] "woman, for the first time, seat himself amid those hempen intricacies,"][[60 9 7] "and while straining his utmost at the oar, bethink him that at any"][[60 9 8] "unknown instant the harpoon may be darted, and all these horrible"][[60 9 9] "contortions be put in play like ringed lightnings; he cannot be thus"][[60 9 10] "circumstanced without a shudder that makes the very marrow in his bones"][[60 9 11] "to quiver in him like a shaken jelly. Yet habit--strange thing! what"][[60 9 12] "cannot habit accomplish?--Gayer sallies, more merry mirth, better jokes,"][[60 9 13] "and brighter repartees, you never heard over your mahogany, than you"][[60 9 14] "will hear over the half-inch white cedar of the whale-boat, when thus"][[60 9 15] "hung in hangman's nooses; and, like the six burghers of Calais before"][[60 9 16] "King Edward, the six men composing the crew pull into the jaws of death,"][[60 9 17] "with a halter around every neck, as you may say."][[60 10 1] "Perhaps a very little thought will now enable you to account for"][[60 10 2] "those repeated whaling disasters--some few of which are casually"][[60 10 3] "chronicled--of this man or that man being taken out of the boat by the"][[60 10 4] "line, and lost. For, when the line is darting out, to be seated then in"][[60 10 5] "the boat, is like being seated in the midst of the manifold whizzings"][[60 10 6] "of a steam-engine in full play, when every flying beam, and shaft, and"][[60 10 7] "wheel, is grazing you. It is worse; for you cannot sit motionless in the"][[60 10 8] "heart of these perils, because the boat is rocking like a cradle, and"][[60 10 9] "you are pitched one way and the other, without the slightest warning;"][[60 10 10] "and only by a certain self-adjusting buoyancy and simultaneousness of"][[60 10 11] "volition and action, can you escape being made a Mazeppa of, and run"][[60 10 12] "away with where the all-seeing sun himself could never pierce you out."][[60 11 1] "Again: as the profound calm which only apparently precedes and"][[60 11 2] "prophesies of the storm, is perhaps more awful than the storm itself;"][[60 11 3] "for, indeed, the calm is but the wrapper and envelope of the storm; and"][[60 11 4] "contains it in itself, as the seemingly harmless rifle holds the fatal"][[60 11 5] "powder, and the ball, and the explosion; so the graceful repose of the"][[60 11 6] "line, as it silently serpentines about the oarsmen before being brought"][[60 11 7] "into actual play--this is a thing which carries more of true terror than"][[60 11 8] "any other aspect of this dangerous affair. But why say more? All men"][[60 11 9] "live enveloped in whale-lines. All are born with halters round their"][[60 11 10] "necks; but it is only when caught in the swift, sudden turn of death,"][[60 11 11] "that mortals realize the silent, subtle, ever-present perils of life."][[60 11 12] "And if you be a philosopher, though seated in the whale-boat, you would"][[60 11 13] "not at heart feel one whit more of terror, than though seated before"][[60 11 14] "your evening fire with a poker, and not a harpoon, by your side."][[61 0 0] "CHAPTER 61. Stubb Kills a Whale."][[61 2 1] "If to Starbuck the apparition of the Squid was a thing of portents, to"][[61 2 2] "Queequeg it was quite a different object."][[61 3 1] "\"When you see him 'quid,\" said the savage, honing his harpoon in the bow"][[61 3 2] "of his hoisted boat, \"then you quick see him 'parm whale.\""][[61 4 1] "The next day was exceedingly still and sultry, and with nothing special"][[61 4 2] "to engage them, the Pequod's crew could hardly resist the spell of sleep"][[61 4 3] "induced by such a vacant sea. For this part of the Indian Ocean through"][[61 4 4] "which we then were voyaging is not what whalemen call a lively ground;"][[61 4 5] "that is, it affords fewer glimpses of porpoises, dolphins, flying-fish,"][[61 4 6] "and other vivacious denizens of more stirring waters, than those off the"][[61 4 7] "Rio de la Plata, or the in-shore ground off Peru."][[61 5 1] "It was my turn to stand at the foremast-head; and with my shoulders"][[61 5 2] "leaning against the slackened royal shrouds, to and fro I idly swayed in"][[61 5 3] "what seemed an enchanted air. No resolution could withstand it; in that"][[61 5 4] "dreamy mood losing all consciousness, at last my soul went out of my"][[61 5 5] "body; though my body still continued to sway as a pendulum will, long"][[61 5 6] "after the power which first moved it is withdrawn."][[61 6 1] "Ere forgetfulness altogether came over me, I had noticed that the seamen"][[61 6 2] "at the main and mizzen-mast-heads were already drowsy. So that at last"][[61 6 3] "all three of us lifelessly swung from the spars, and for every swing"][[61 6 4] "that we made there was a nod from below from the slumbering helmsman."][[61 6 5] "The waves, too, nodded their indolent crests; and across the wide trance"][[61 6 6] "of the sea, east nodded to west, and the sun over all."][[61 7 1] "Suddenly bubbles seemed bursting beneath my closed eyes; like vices my"][[61 7 2] "hands grasped the shrouds; some invisible, gracious agency preserved me;"][[61 7 3] "with a shock I came back to life. And lo! close under our lee, not forty"][[61 7 4] "fathoms off, a gigantic Sperm Whale lay rolling in the water like the"][[61 7 5] "capsized hull of a frigate, his broad, glossy back, of an Ethiopian hue,"][[61 7 6] "glistening in the sun's rays like a mirror. But lazily undulating in"][[61 7 7] "the trough of the sea, and ever and anon tranquilly spouting his vapoury"][[61 7 8] "jet, the whale looked like a portly burgher smoking his pipe of a warm"][[61 7 9] "afternoon. But that pipe, poor whale, was thy last. As if struck by some"][[61 7 10] "enchanter's wand, the sleepy ship and every sleeper in it all at once"][[61 7 11] "started into wakefulness; and more than a score of voices from all parts"][[61 7 12] "of the vessel, simultaneously with the three notes from aloft, shouted"][[61 7 13] "forth the accustomed cry, as the great fish slowly and regularly spouted"][[61 7 14] "the sparkling brine into the air."][[61 8 1] "\"Clear away the boats! Luff!\" cried Ahab. And obeying his own order, he"][[61 8 2] "dashed the helm down before the helmsman could handle the spokes."][[61 9 1] "The sudden exclamations of the crew must have alarmed the whale; and ere"][[61 9 2] "the boats were down, majestically turning, he swam away to the leeward,"][[61 9 3] "but with such a steady tranquillity, and making so few ripples as he"][[61 9 4] "swam, that thinking after all he might not as yet be alarmed, Ahab gave"][[61 9 5] "orders that not an oar should be used, and no man must speak but in"][[61 9 6] "whispers. So seated like Ontario Indians on the gunwales of the boats,"][[61 9 7] "we swiftly but silently paddled along; the calm not admitting of the"][[61 9 8] "noiseless sails being set. Presently, as we thus glided in chase, the"][[61 9 9] "monster perpendicularly flitted his tail forty feet into the air, and"][[61 9 10] "then sank out of sight like a tower swallowed up."][[61 10 1] "\"There go flukes!\" was the cry, an announcement immediately followed by"][[61 10 2] "Stubb's producing his match and igniting his pipe, for now a respite was"][[61 10 3] "granted. After the full interval of his sounding had elapsed, the whale"][[61 10 4] "rose again, and being now in advance of the smoker's boat, and much"][[61 10 5] "nearer to it than to any of the others, Stubb counted upon the honour"][[61 10 6] "of the capture. It was obvious, now, that the whale had at length become"][[61 10 7] "aware of his pursuers. All silence of cautiousness was therefore no"][[61 10 8] "longer of use. Paddles were dropped, and oars came loudly into play. And"][[61 10 9] "still puffing at his pipe, Stubb cheered on his crew to the assault."][[61 11 1] "Yes, a mighty change had come over the fish. All alive to his jeopardy,"][[61 11 2] "he was going \"head out\"; that part obliquely projecting from the mad"][[61 11 3] "yeast which he brewed.*"][[61 13 1] "*It will be seen in some other place of what a very light substance"][[61 13 2] "the entire interior of the sperm whale's enormous head consists. Though"][[61 13 3] "apparently the most massive, it is by far the most buoyant part about"][[61 13 4] "him. So that with ease he elevates it in the air, and invariably does"][[61 13 5] "so when going at his utmost speed. Besides, such is the breadth of the"][[61 13 6] "upper part of the front of his head, and such the tapering cut-water"][[61 13 7] "formation of the lower part, that by obliquely elevating his head, he"][[61 13 8] "thereby may be said to transform himself from a bluff-bowed sluggish"][[61 13 9] "galliot into a sharppointed New York pilot-boat."][[61 15 1] "\"Start her, start her, my men! Don't hurry yourselves; take plenty of"][[61 15 2] "time--but start her; start her like thunder-claps, that's all,\" cried"][[61 15 3] "Stubb, spluttering out the smoke as he spoke. \"Start her, now; give 'em"][[61 15 4] "the long and strong stroke, Tashtego. Start her, Tash, my boy--start"][[61 15 5] "her, all; but keep cool, keep cool--cucumbers is the word--easy,"][[61 15 6] "easy--only start her like grim death and grinning devils, and raise the"][[61 15 7] "buried dead perpendicular out of their graves, boys--that's all. Start"][[61 15 8] "her!\""][[61 16 1] "\"Woo-hoo! Wa-hee!\" screamed the Gay-Header in reply, raising some"][[61 16 2] "old war-whoop to the skies; as every oarsman in the strained boat"][[61 16 3] "involuntarily bounced forward with the one tremendous leading stroke"][[61 16 4] "which the eager Indian gave."][[61 17 1] "But his wild screams were answered by others quite as wild. \"Kee-hee!"][[61 17 2] "Kee-hee!\" yelled Daggoo, straining forwards and backwards on his seat,"][[61 17 3] "like a pacing tiger in his cage."][[61 18 1] "\"Ka-la! Koo-loo!\" howled Queequeg, as if smacking his lips over a"][[61 18 2] "mouthful of Grenadier's steak. And thus with oars and yells the keels"][[61 18 3] "cut the sea. Meanwhile, Stubb retaining his place in the van, still"][[61 18 4] "encouraged his men to the onset, all the while puffing the smoke from"][[61 18 5] "his mouth. Like desperadoes they tugged and they strained, till the"][[61 18 6] "welcome cry was heard--\"Stand up, Tashtego!--give it to him!\" The"][[61 18 7] "harpoon was hurled. \"Stern all!\" The oarsmen backed water; the same"][[61 18 8] "moment something went hot and hissing along every one of their wrists."][[61 18 9] "It was the magical line. An instant before, Stubb had swiftly caught two"][[61 18 10] "additional turns with it round the loggerhead, whence, by reason of its"][[61 18 11] "increased rapid circlings, a hempen blue smoke now jetted up and mingled"][[61 18 12] "with the steady fumes from his pipe. As the line passed round and"][[61 18 13] "round the loggerhead; so also, just before reaching that point, it"][[61 18 14] "blisteringly passed through and through both of Stubb's hands, from"][[61 18 15] "which the hand-cloths, or squares of quilted canvas sometimes worn at"][[61 18 16] "these times, had accidentally dropped. It was like holding an enemy's"][[61 18 17] "sharp two-edged sword by the blade, and that enemy all the time striving"][[61 18 18] "to wrest it out of your clutch."][[61 19 1] "\"Wet the line! wet the line!\" cried Stubb to the tub oarsman (him seated"][[61 19 2] "by the tub) who, snatching off his hat, dashed sea-water into it.* More"][[61 19 3] "turns were taken, so that the line began holding its place. The boat now"][[61 19 4] "flew through the boiling water like a shark all fins. Stubb and Tashtego"][[61 19 5] "here changed places--stem for stern--a staggering business truly in that"][[61 19 6] "rocking commotion."][[61 21 1] "*Partly to show the indispensableness of this act, it may here be"][[61 21 2] "stated, that, in the old Dutch fishery, a mop was used to dash the"][[61 21 3] "running line with water; in many other ships, a wooden piggin, or"][[61 21 4] "bailer, is set apart for that purpose. Your hat, however, is the most"][[61 21 5] "convenient."][[61 23 1] "From the vibrating line extending the entire length of the upper part of"][[61 23 2] "the boat, and from its now being more tight than a harpstring, you would"][[61 23 3] "have thought the craft had two keels--one cleaving the water, the other"][[61 23 4] "the air--as the boat churned on through both opposing elements at once."][[61 23 5] "A continual cascade played at the bows; a ceaseless whirling eddy in"][[61 23 6] "her wake; and, at the slightest motion from within, even but of a little"][[61 23 7] "finger, the vibrating, cracking craft canted over her spasmodic gunwale"][[61 23 8] "into the sea. Thus they rushed; each man with might and main clinging"][[61 23 9] "to his seat, to prevent being tossed to the foam; and the tall form of"][[61 23 10] "Tashtego at the steering oar crouching almost double, in order to bring"][[61 23 11] "down his centre of gravity. Whole Atlantics and Pacifics seemed passed"][[61 23 12] "as they shot on their way, till at length the whale somewhat slackened"][[61 23 13] "his flight."][[61 24 1] "\"Haul in--haul in!\" cried Stubb to the bowsman! and, facing round"][[61 24 2] "towards the whale, all hands began pulling the boat up to him, while yet"][[61 24 3] "the boat was being towed on. Soon ranging up by his flank, Stubb, firmly"][[61 24 4] "planting his knee in the clumsy cleat, darted dart after dart into the"][[61 24 5] "flying fish; at the word of command, the boat alternately sterning"][[61 24 6] "out of the way of the whale's horrible wallow, and then ranging up for"][[61 24 7] "another fling."][[61 25 1] "The red tide now poured from all sides of the monster like brooks down a"][[61 25 2] "hill. His tormented body rolled not in brine but in blood, which bubbled"][[61 25 3] "and seethed for furlongs behind in their wake. The slanting sun playing"][[61 25 4] "upon this crimson pond in the sea, sent back its reflection into every"][[61 25 5] "face, so that they all glowed to each other like red men. And all"][[61 25 6] "the while, jet after jet of white smoke was agonizingly shot from the"][[61 25 7] "spiracle of the whale, and vehement puff after puff from the mouth of"][[61 25 8] "the excited headsman; as at every dart, hauling in upon his crooked"][[61 25 9] "lance (by the line attached to it), Stubb straightened it again and"][[61 25 10] "again, by a few rapid blows against the gunwale, then again and again"][[61 25 11] "sent it into the whale."][[61 26 1] "\"Pull up--pull up!\" he now cried to the bowsman, as the waning whale"][[61 26 2] "relaxed in his wrath. \"Pull up!--close to!\" and the boat ranged along"][[61 26 3] "the fish's flank. When reaching far over the bow, Stubb slowly churned"][[61 26 4] "his long sharp lance into the fish, and kept it there, carefully"][[61 26 5] "churning and churning, as if cautiously seeking to feel after some gold"][[61 26 6] "watch that the whale might have swallowed, and which he was fearful of"][[61 26 7] "breaking ere he could hook it out. But that gold watch he sought was the"][[61 26 8] "innermost life of the fish. And now it is struck; for, starting from"][[61 26 9] "his trance into that unspeakable thing called his \"flurry,\" the monster"][[61 26 10] "horribly wallowed in his blood, overwrapped himself in impenetrable,"][[61 26 11] "mad, boiling spray, so that the imperilled craft, instantly dropping"][[61 26 12] "astern, had much ado blindly to struggle out from that phrensied"][[61 26 13] "twilight into the clear air of the day."][[61 27 1] "And now abating in his flurry, the whale once more rolled out into view;"][[61 27 2] "surging from side to side; spasmodically dilating and contracting his"][[61 27 3] "spout-hole, with sharp, cracking, agonized respirations. At last, gush"][[61 27 4] "after gush of clotted red gore, as if it had been the purple lees of red"][[61 27 5] "wine, shot into the frighted air; and falling back again, ran dripping"][[61 27 6] "down his motionless flanks into the sea. His heart had burst!"][[61 28 1] "\"He's dead, Mr. Stubb,\" said Daggoo."][[61 29 1] "\"Yes; both pipes smoked out!\" and withdrawing his own from his mouth,"][[61 29 2] "Stubb scattered the dead ashes over the water; and, for a moment, stood"][[61 29 3] "thoughtfully eyeing the vast corpse he had made."][[62 0 0] "CHAPTER 62. The Dart."][[62 2 1] "A word concerning an incident in the last chapter."][[62 3 1] "According to the invariable usage of the fishery, the whale-boat pushes"][[62 3 2] "off from the ship, with the headsman or whale-killer as temporary"][[62 3 3] "steersman, and the harpooneer or whale-fastener pulling the foremost"][[62 3 4] "oar, the one known as the harpooneer-oar. Now it needs a strong, nervous"][[62 3 5] "arm to strike the first iron into the fish; for often, in what is called"][[62 3 6] "a long dart, the heavy implement has to be flung to the distance of"][[62 3 7] "twenty or thirty feet. But however prolonged and exhausting the chase,"][[62 3 8] "the harpooneer is expected to pull his oar meanwhile to the uttermost;"][[62 3 9] "indeed, he is expected to set an example of superhuman activity to the"][[62 3 10] "rest, not only by incredible rowing, but by repeated loud and intrepid"][[62 3 11] "exclamations; and what it is to keep shouting at the top of one's"][[62 3 12] "compass, while all the other muscles are strained and half started--what"][[62 3 13] "that is none know but those who have tried it. For one, I cannot bawl"][[62 3 14] "very heartily and work very recklessly at one and the same time. In this"][[62 3 15] "straining, bawling state, then, with his back to the fish, all at once"][[62 3 16] "the exhausted harpooneer hears the exciting cry--\"Stand up, and give it"][[62 3 17] "to him!\" He now has to drop and secure his oar, turn round on his"][[62 3 18] "centre half way, seize his harpoon from the crotch, and with what little"][[62 3 19] "strength may remain, he essays to pitch it somehow into the whale. No"][[62 3 20] "wonder, taking the whole fleet of whalemen in a body, that out of fifty"][[62 3 21] "fair chances for a dart, not five are successful; no wonder that so many"][[62 3 22] "hapless harpooneers are madly cursed and disrated; no wonder that some"][[62 3 23] "of them actually burst their blood-vessels in the boat; no wonder that"][[62 3 24] "some sperm whalemen are absent four years with four barrels; no wonder"][[62 3 25] "that to many ship owners, whaling is but a losing concern; for it is the"][[62 3 26] "harpooneer that makes the voyage, and if you take the breath out of his"][[62 3 27] "body how can you expect to find it there when most wanted!"][[62 4 1] "Again, if the dart be successful, then at the second critical instant,"][[62 4 2] "that is, when the whale starts to run, the boatheader and harpooneer"][[62 4 3] "likewise start to running fore and aft, to the imminent jeopardy of"][[62 4 4] "themselves and every one else. It is then they change places; and"][[62 4 5] "the headsman, the chief officer of the little craft, takes his proper"][[62 4 6] "station in the bows of the boat."][[62 5 1] "Now, I care not who maintains the contrary, but all this is both foolish"][[62 5 2] "and unnecessary. The headsman should stay in the bows from first to"][[62 5 3] "last; he should both dart the harpoon and the lance, and no rowing"][[62 5 4] "whatever should be expected of him, except under circumstances obvious"][[62 5 5] "to any fisherman. I know that this would sometimes involve a slight loss"][[62 5 6] "of speed in the chase; but long experience in various whalemen of more"][[62 5 7] "than one nation has convinced me that in the vast majority of failures"][[62 5 8] "in the fishery, it has not by any means been so much the speed of the"][[62 5 9] "whale as the before described exhaustion of the harpooneer that has"][[62 5 10] "caused them."][[62 6 1] "To insure the greatest efficiency in the dart, the harpooneers of this"][[62 6 2] "world must start to their feet from out of idleness, and not from out of"][[62 6 3] "toil."][[63 0 0] "CHAPTER 63. The Crotch."][[63 2 1] "Out of the trunk, the branches grow; out of them, the twigs. So, in"][[63 2 2] "productive subjects, grow the chapters."][[63 3 1] "The crotch alluded to on a previous page deserves independent mention."][[63 3 2] "It is a notched stick of a peculiar form, some two feet in length, which"][[63 3 3] "is perpendicularly inserted into the starboard gunwale near the bow,"][[63 3 4] "for the purpose of furnishing a rest for the wooden extremity of the"][[63 3 5] "harpoon, whose other naked, barbed end slopingly projects from the prow."][[63 3 6] "Thereby the weapon is instantly at hand to its hurler, who snatches it"][[63 3 7] "up as readily from its rest as a backwoodsman swings his rifle from"][[63 3 8] "the wall. It is customary to have two harpoons reposing in the crotch,"][[63 3 9] "respectively called the first and second irons."][[63 4 1] "But these two harpoons, each by its own cord, are both connected with"][[63 4 2] "the line; the object being this: to dart them both, if possible, one"][[63 4 3] "instantly after the other into the same whale; so that if, in the coming"][[63 4 4] "drag, one should draw out, the other may still retain a hold. It is a"][[63 4 5] "doubling of the chances. But it very often happens that owing to the"][[63 4 6] "instantaneous, violent, convulsive running of the whale upon receiving"][[63 4 7] "the first iron, it becomes impossible for the harpooneer, however"][[63 4 8] "lightning-like in his movements, to pitch the second iron into him."][[63 4 9] "Nevertheless, as the second iron is already connected with the line,"][[63 4 10] "and the line is running, hence that weapon must, at all events, be"][[63 4 11] "anticipatingly tossed out of the boat, somehow and somewhere; else the"][[63 4 12] "most terrible jeopardy would involve all hands. Tumbled into the water,"][[63 4 13] "it accordingly is in such cases; the spare coils of box line (mentioned"][[63 4 14] "in a preceding chapter) making this feat, in most instances, prudently"][[63 4 15] "practicable. But this critical act is not always unattended with the"][[63 4 16] "saddest and most fatal casualties."][[63 5 1] "Furthermore: you must know that when the second iron is thrown"][[63 5 2] "overboard, it thenceforth becomes a dangling, sharp-edged terror,"][[63 5 3] "skittishly curvetting about both boat and whale, entangling the lines,"][[63 5 4] "or cutting them, and making a prodigious sensation in all directions."][[63 5 5] "Nor, in general, is it possible to secure it again until the whale is"][[63 5 6] "fairly captured and a corpse."][[63 6 1] "Consider, now, how it must be in the case of four boats all engaging"][[63 6 2] "one unusually strong, active, and knowing whale; when owing to these"][[63 6 3] "qualities in him, as well as to the thousand concurring accidents of"][[63 6 4] "such an audacious enterprise, eight or ten loose second irons may be"][[63 6 5] "simultaneously dangling about him. For, of course, each boat is supplied"][[63 6 6] "with several harpoons to bend on to the line should the first one"][[63 6 7] "be ineffectually darted without recovery. All these particulars are"][[63 6 8] "faithfully narrated here, as they will not fail to elucidate several"][[63 6 9] "most important, however intricate passages, in scenes hereafter to be"][[63 6 10] "painted."][[64 0 0] "CHAPTER 64. Stubb's Supper."][[64 2 1] "Stubb's whale had been killed some distance from the ship. It was"][[64 2 2] "a calm; so, forming a tandem of three boats, we commenced the slow"][[64 2 3] "business of towing the trophy to the Pequod. And now, as we eighteen men"][[64 2 4] "with our thirty-six arms, and one hundred and eighty thumbs and fingers,"][[64 2 5] "slowly toiled hour after hour upon that inert, sluggish corpse in the"][[64 2 6] "sea; and it seemed hardly to budge at all, except at long intervals;"][[64 2 7] "good evidence was hereby furnished of the enormousness of the mass we"][[64 2 8] "moved. For, upon the great canal of Hang-Ho, or whatever they call"][[64 2 9] "it, in China, four or five laborers on the foot-path will draw a bulky"][[64 2 10] "freighted junk at the rate of a mile an hour; but this grand argosy we"][[64 2 11] "towed heavily forged along, as if laden with pig-lead in bulk."][[64 3 1] "Darkness came on; but three lights up and down in the Pequod's"][[64 3 2] "main-rigging dimly guided our way; till drawing nearer we saw Ahab"][[64 3 3] "dropping one of several more lanterns over the bulwarks. Vacantly eyeing"][[64 3 4] "the heaving whale for a moment, he issued the usual orders for securing"][[64 3 5] "it for the night, and then handing his lantern to a seaman, went his way"][[64 3 6] "into the cabin, and did not come forward again until morning."][[64 4 1] "Though, in overseeing the pursuit of this whale, Captain Ahab had"][[64 4 2] "evinced his customary activity, to call it so; yet now that the creature"][[64 4 3] "was dead, some vague dissatisfaction, or impatience, or despair, seemed"][[64 4 4] "working in him; as if the sight of that dead body reminded him that"][[64 4 5] "Moby Dick was yet to be slain; and though a thousand other whales were"][[64 4 6] "brought to his ship, all that would not one jot advance his grand,"][[64 4 7] "monomaniac object. Very soon you would have thought from the sound on"][[64 4 8] "the Pequod's decks, that all hands were preparing to cast anchor in"][[64 4 9] "the deep; for heavy chains are being dragged along the deck, and thrust"][[64 4 10] "rattling out of the port-holes. But by those clanking links, the vast"][[64 4 11] "corpse itself, not the ship, is to be moored. Tied by the head to the"][[64 4 12] "stern, and by the tail to the bows, the whale now lies with its black"][[64 4 13] "hull close to the vessel's and seen through the darkness of the night,"][[64 4 14] "which obscured the spars and rigging aloft, the two--ship and whale,"][[64 4 15] "seemed yoked together like colossal bullocks, whereof one reclines while"][[64 4 16] "the other remains standing.*"][[64 6 1] "*A little item may as well be related here. The strongest and most"][[64 6 2] "reliable hold which the ship has upon the whale when moored alongside,"][[64 6 3] "is by the flukes or tail; and as from its greater density that part"][[64 6 4] "is relatively heavier than any other (excepting the side-fins), its"][[64 6 5] "flexibility even in death, causes it to sink low beneath the surface; so"][[64 6 6] "that with the hand you cannot get at it from the boat, in order to"][[64 6 7] "put the chain round it. But this difficulty is ingeniously overcome: a"][[64 6 8] "small, strong line is prepared with a wooden float at its outer end, and"][[64 6 9] "a weight in its middle, while the other end is secured to the ship. By"][[64 6 10] "adroit management the wooden float is made to rise on the other side"][[64 6 11] "of the mass, so that now having girdled the whale, the chain is readily"][[64 6 12] "made to follow suit; and being slipped along the body, is at last locked"][[64 6 13] "fast round the smallest part of the tail, at the point of junction with"][[64 6 14] "its broad flukes or lobes."][[64 8 1] "If moody Ahab was now all quiescence, at least so far as could be known"][[64 8 2] "on deck, Stubb, his second mate, flushed with conquest, betrayed an"][[64 8 3] "unusual but still good-natured excitement. Such an unwonted bustle was"][[64 8 4] "he in that the staid Starbuck, his official superior, quietly resigned"][[64 8 5] "to him for the time the sole management of affairs. One small, helping"][[64 8 6] "cause of all this liveliness in Stubb, was soon made strangely manifest."][[64 8 7] "Stubb was a high liver; he was somewhat intemperately fond of the whale"][[64 8 8] "as a flavorish thing to his palate."][[64 9 1] "\"A steak, a steak, ere I sleep! You, Daggoo! overboard you go, and cut"][[64 9 2] "me one from his small!\""][[64 10 1] "Here be it known, that though these wild fishermen do not, as a general"][[64 10 2] "thing, and according to the great military maxim, make the enemy defray"][[64 10 3] "the current expenses of the war (at least before realizing the proceeds"][[64 10 4] "of the voyage), yet now and then you find some of these Nantucketers"][[64 10 5] "who have a genuine relish for that particular part of the Sperm Whale"][[64 10 6] "designated by Stubb; comprising the tapering extremity of the body."][[64 11 1] "About midnight that steak was cut and cooked; and lighted by two"][[64 11 2] "lanterns of sperm oil, Stubb stoutly stood up to his spermaceti supper"][[64 11 3] "at the capstan-head, as if that capstan were a sideboard. Nor was Stubb"][[64 11 4] "the only banqueter on whale's flesh that night. Mingling their mumblings"][[64 11 5] "with his own mastications, thousands on thousands of sharks, swarming"][[64 11 6] "round the dead leviathan, smackingly feasted on its fatness. The few"][[64 11 7] "sleepers below in their bunks were often startled by the sharp slapping"][[64 11 8] "of their tails against the hull, within a few inches of the sleepers'"][[64 11 9] "hearts. Peering over the side you could just see them (as before you"][[64 11 10] "heard them) wallowing in the sullen, black waters, and turning over on"][[64 11 11] "their backs as they scooped out huge globular pieces of the whale of the"][[64 11 12] "bigness of a human head. This particular feat of the shark seems all"][[64 11 13] "but miraculous. How at such an apparently unassailable surface, they"][[64 11 14] "contrive to gouge out such symmetrical mouthfuls, remains a part of the"][[64 11 15] "universal problem of all things. The mark they thus leave on the whale,"][[64 11 16] "may best be likened to the hollow made by a carpenter in countersinking"][[64 11 17] "for a screw."][[64 12 1] "Though amid all the smoking horror and diabolism of a sea-fight, sharks"][[64 12 2] "will be seen longingly gazing up to the ship's decks, like hungry dogs"][[64 12 3] "round a table where red meat is being carved, ready to bolt down"][[64 12 4] "every killed man that is tossed to them; and though, while the valiant"][[64 12 5] "butchers over the deck-table are thus cannibally carving each other's"][[64 12 6] "live meat with carving-knives all gilded and tasselled, the sharks,"][[64 12 7] "also, with their jewel-hilted mouths, are quarrelsomely carving away"][[64 12 8] "under the table at the dead meat; and though, were you to turn the whole"][[64 12 9] "affair upside down, it would still be pretty much the same thing, that"][[64 12 10] "is to say, a shocking sharkish business enough for all parties; and"][[64 12 11] "though sharks also are the invariable outriders of all slave ships"][[64 12 12] "crossing the Atlantic, systematically trotting alongside, to be handy in"][[64 12 13] "case a parcel is to be carried anywhere, or a dead slave to be decently"][[64 12 14] "buried; and though one or two other like instances might be set down,"][[64 12 15] "touching the set terms, places, and occasions, when sharks do most"][[64 12 16] "socially congregate, and most hilariously feast; yet is there no"][[64 12 17] "conceivable time or occasion when you will find them in such countless"][[64 12 18] "numbers, and in gayer or more jovial spirits, than around a dead sperm"][[64 12 19] "whale, moored by night to a whaleship at sea. If you have never"][[64 12 20] "seen that sight, then suspend your decision about the propriety of"][[64 12 21] "devil-worship, and the expediency of conciliating the devil."][[64 13 1] "But, as yet, Stubb heeded not the mumblings of the banquet that was"][[64 13 2] "going on so nigh him, no more than the sharks heeded the smacking of his"][[64 13 3] "own epicurean lips."][[64 14 1] "\"Cook, cook!--where's that old Fleece?\" he cried at length, widening"][[64 14 2] "his legs still further, as if to form a more secure base for his supper;"][[64 14 3] "and, at the same time darting his fork into the dish, as if stabbing"][[64 14 4] "with his lance; \"cook, you cook!--sail this way, cook!\""][[64 15 1] "The old black, not in any very high glee at having been previously"][[64 15 2] "roused from his warm hammock at a most unseasonable hour, came shambling"][[64 15 3] "along from his galley, for, like many old blacks, there was something"][[64 15 4] "the matter with his knee-pans, which he did not keep well scoured like"][[64 15 5] "his other pans; this old Fleece, as they called him, came shuffling and"][[64 15 6] "limping along, assisting his step with his tongs, which, after a clumsy"][[64 15 7] "fashion, were made of straightened iron hoops; this old Ebony floundered"][[64 15 8] "along, and in obedience to the word of command, came to a dead stop on"][[64 15 9] "the opposite side of Stubb's sideboard; when, with both hands folded"][[64 15 10] "before him, and resting on his two-legged cane, he bowed his arched back"][[64 15 11] "still further over, at the same time sideways inclining his head, so as"][[64 15 12] "to bring his best ear into play."][[64 16 1] "\"Cook,\" said Stubb, rapidly lifting a rather reddish morsel to his"][[64 16 2] "mouth, \"don't you think this steak is rather overdone? You've been"][[64 16 3] "beating this steak too much, cook; it's too tender. Don't I always say"][[64 16 4] "that to be good, a whale-steak must be tough? There are those sharks"][[64 16 5] "now over the side, don't you see they prefer it tough and rare? What a"][[64 16 6] "shindy they are kicking up! Cook, go and talk to 'em; tell 'em they are"][[64 16 7] "welcome to help themselves civilly, and in moderation, but they must"][[64 16 8] "keep quiet. Blast me, if I can hear my own voice. Away, cook, and"][[64 16 9] "deliver my message. Here, take this lantern,\" snatching one from his"][[64 16 10] "sideboard; \"now then, go and preach to 'em!\""][[64 17 1] "Sullenly taking the offered lantern, old Fleece limped across the deck"][[64 17 2] "to the bulwarks; and then, with one hand dropping his light low over the"][[64 17 3] "sea, so as to get a good view of his congregation, with the other hand"][[64 17 4] "he solemnly flourished his tongs, and leaning far over the side in a"][[64 17 5] "mumbling voice began addressing the sharks, while Stubb, softly crawling"][[64 17 6] "behind, overheard all that was said."][[64 18 1] "\"Fellow-critters: I'se ordered here to say dat you must stop dat dam"][[64 18 2] "noise dare. You hear? Stop dat dam smackin' ob de lips! Massa Stubb say"][[64 18 3] "dat you can fill your dam bellies up to de hatchings, but by Gor! you"][[64 18 4] "must stop dat dam racket!\""][[64 19 1] "\"Cook,\" here interposed Stubb, accompanying the word with a sudden slap"][[64 19 2] "on the shoulder,--\"Cook! why, damn your eyes, you mustn't swear that way"][[64 19 3] "when you're preaching. That's no way to convert sinners, cook!\""][[64 20 1] "\"Who dat? Den preach to him yourself,\" sullenly turning to go."][[64 21 1] "\"No, cook; go on, go on.\""][[64 22 1] "\"Well, den, Belubed fellow-critters:\"--"][[64 23 1] "\"Right!\" exclaimed Stubb, approvingly, \"coax 'em to it; try that,\" and"][[64 23 2] "Fleece continued."][[64 24 1] "\"Do you is all sharks, and by natur wery woracious, yet I zay to you,"][[64 24 2] "fellow-critters, dat dat woraciousness--'top dat dam slappin' ob de"][[64 24 3] "tail! How you tink to hear, spose you keep up such a dam slappin' and"][[64 24 4] "bitin' dare?\""][[64 25 1] "\"Cook,\" cried Stubb, collaring him, \"I won't have that swearing. Talk to"][[64 25 2] "'em gentlemanly.\""][[64 26 1] "Once more the sermon proceeded."][[64 27 1] "\"Your woraciousness, fellow-critters, I don't blame ye so much for; dat"][[64 27 2] "is natur, and can't be helped; but to gobern dat wicked natur, dat is de"][[64 27 3] "pint. You is sharks, sartin; but if you gobern de shark in you, why den"][[64 27 4] "you be angel; for all angel is not'ing more dan de shark well goberned."][[64 27 5] "Now, look here, bred'ren, just try wonst to be cibil, a helping"][[64 27 6] "yourselbs from dat whale. Don't be tearin' de blubber out your"][[64 27 7] "neighbour's mout, I say. Is not one shark dood right as toder to dat"][[64 27 8] "whale? And, by Gor, none on you has de right to dat whale; dat whale"][[64 27 9] "belong to some one else. I know some o' you has berry brig mout, brigger"][[64 27 10] "dan oders; but den de brig mouts sometimes has de small bellies; so dat"][[64 27 11] "de brigness of de mout is not to swaller wid, but to bit off de blubber"][[64 27 12] "for de small fry ob sharks, dat can't get into de scrouge to help"][[64 27 13] "demselves.\""][[64 28 1] "\"Well done, old Fleece!\" cried Stubb, \"that's Christianity; go on.\""][[64 29 1] "\"No use goin' on; de dam willains will keep a scougin' and slappin' each"][[64 29 2] "oder, Massa Stubb; dey don't hear one word; no use a-preaching to"][[64 29 3] "such dam g'uttons as you call 'em, till dare bellies is full, and dare"][[64 29 4] "bellies is bottomless; and when dey do get 'em full, dey wont hear you"][[64 29 5] "den; for den dey sink in the sea, go fast to sleep on de coral, and"][[64 29 6] "can't hear noting at all, no more, for eber and eber.\""][[64 30 1] "\"Upon my soul, I am about of the same opinion; so give the benediction,"][[64 30 2] "Fleece, and I'll away to my supper.\""][[64 31 1] "Upon this, Fleece, holding both hands over the fishy mob, raised his"][[64 31 2] "shrill voice, and cried--"][[64 32 1] "\"Cussed fellow-critters! Kick up de damndest row as ever you can; fill"][[64 32 2] "your dam bellies 'till dey bust--and den die.\""][[64 33 1] "\"Now, cook,\" said Stubb, resuming his supper at the capstan; \"stand"][[64 33 2] "just where you stood before, there, over against me, and pay particular"][[64 33 3] "attention.\""][[64 34 1] "\"All 'dention,\" said Fleece, again stooping over upon his tongs in the"][[64 34 2] "desired position."][[64 35 1] "\"Well,\" said Stubb, helping himself freely meanwhile; \"I shall now go"][[64 35 2] "back to the subject of this steak. And fetch"][[64 53 2] "him where?\""][[64 54 1] "\"Up dere,\" said Fleece, holding his tongs straight over his head, and"][[64 54 2] "keeping it there very solemnly."][[64 55 1] "\"So, then, you expect to go up into our main-top, do you, cook, when you"][[64 55 2] "are dead? But don't you know the higher you climb, the colder it gets?"][[64 55 3] "Main-top, eh?\""][[64 56 1] "\"Didn't say dat t'all,\" said Fleece, again in the sulks."][[64 57 1] "\"You said up there, didn't you? and now look yourself, and see where"][[64 57 2] "your tongs are pointing. But, perhaps you expect to get into heaven by"][[64 57 3] "crawling through the lubber's hole, cook; but, no, no, cook, you don't"][[64 57 4] "get there, except you go the regular way, round by the rigging. It's a"][[64 57 5] "ticklish business, but must be done, or else it's no go. But none of"][[64 57 6] "us are in heaven yet. Drop your tongs, cook, and hear my orders. Do ye"][[64 57 7] "hear? Hold your hat in one hand, and clap t'other a'top of your heart,"][[64 57 8] "when I'm giving my orders, cook. What! that your heart, there?--that's"][[64 57 9] "your gizzard! Aloft! aloft!--that's it--now you have it. Hold it there"][[64 57 10] "now, and pay attention.\""][[64 58 1] "\"All 'dention,\" said the old black, with both hands placed as desired,"][[64 58 2] "vainly wriggling his grizzled head, as if to get both ears in front at"][[64 58 3] "one and the same time."][[64 59 1] "\"Well then, cook, you see this whale-steak of yours was so very bad,"][[64 59 2] "that I have put it out of sight as soon as possible; you see that, don't"][[64 59 3] "you? As for the ends of the"][[64 59 9] "flukes, have them soused, cook.
