Whale-balls for breakfast--don't forget.\""][[64 62 1] "\"Wish, by gor! whale eat him, 'stead of him eat whale. I'm bressed if"][[64 62 2] "he ain't more of shark dan Massa Shark hisself,\" muttered the old man,"][[64 62 3] "limping away; with which sage ejaculation he went to his hammock."][[65 0 0] "CHAPTER 65. The Whale as a Dish."][[65 2 1] "That mortal man should feed upon the creature that feeds his lamp, and,"][[65 2 2] "like Stubb, eat him by his own light, as you may say; this seems so"][[65 2 3] "outlandish a thing that one must needs go a little into the history and"][[65 2 4] "philosophy of it."][[65 3 1] "It is upon record, that three centuries ago the tongue of the Right"][[65 3 2] "Whale was esteemed a great delicacy in France, and commanded large"][[65 3 3] "prices there. Also, that in Henry VIIIth's time, a certain cook of the"][[65 3 4] "court obtained a handsome reward for inventing an admirable sauce to be"][[65 3 5] "eaten with barbacued porpoises, which, you remember, are a species of"][[65 3 6] "whale. Porpoises, indeed, are to this day considered fine eating. The"][[65 3 7] "meat is made into balls about the size of billiard balls, and being well"][[65 3 8] "seasoned and spiced might be taken for turtle-balls or veal balls."][[65 3 9] "The old monks of Dunfermline were very fond of them. They had a great"][[65 3 10] "porpoise grant from the crown."][[65 4 1] "The fact is, that among his hunters at least, the whale would by all"][[65 4 2] "hands be considered a noble dish, were there not so much of him; but"][[65 4 3] "when you come to sit down before a meat-pie nearly one hundred feet"][[65 4 4] "long, it takes away your appetite. Only the most unprejudiced of men"][[65 4 5] "like Stubb, nowadays partake of cooked whales; but the Esquimaux are not"][[65 4 6] "so fastidious. We all know how they live upon whales, and have rare"][[65 4 7] "old vintages of prime old train oil. Zogranda, one of their most famous"][[65 4 8] "doctors, recommends strips of blubber for infants, as being exceedingly"][[65 4 9] "juicy and nourishing. And this reminds me that certain Englishmen, who"][[65 4 10] "long ago were accidentally left in Greenland by a whaling vessel--that"][[65 4 11] "these men actually lived for several months on the mouldy scraps of"][[65 4 12] "whales which had been left ashore after trying out the blubber. Among"][[65 4 13] "the Dutch whalemen these scraps are called \"fritters\"; which, indeed,"][[65 4 14] "they greatly resemble, being brown and crisp, and smelling something"][[65 4 15] "like old Amsterdam housewives' dough-nuts or oly-cooks, when fresh. They"][[65 4 16] "have such an eatable look that the most self-denying stranger can hardly"][[65 4 17] "keep his hands off."][[65 5 1] "But what further depreciates the whale as a civilized dish, is his"][[65 5 2] "exceeding richness. He is the great prize ox of the sea, too fat to be"][[65 5 3] "delicately good. Look at his hump, which would be as fine eating as"][[65 5 4] "the buffalo's (which is esteemed a rare dish), were it not such a solid"][[65 5 5] "pyramid of fat. But the spermaceti itself, how bland and creamy that"][[65 5 6] "is; like the transparent, half-jellied, white meat of a cocoanut in the"][[65 5 7] "third month of its growth, yet far too rich to supply a substitute for"][[65 5 8] "butter. Nevertheless, many whalemen have a method of absorbing it into"][[65 5 9] "some other substance, and then partaking of it. In the long try"][[65 5 10] "watches of the night it is a common thing for the seamen to dip their"][[65 5 11] "ship-biscuit into the huge oil-pots and let them fry there awhile. Many"][[65 5 12] "a good supper have I thus made."][[65 6 1] "In the case of a small Sperm Whale the brains are accounted a fine dish."][[65 6 2] "The casket of the skull is broken into with an axe, and the two plump,"][[65 6 3] "whitish lobes being withdrawn (precisely resembling two large puddings),"][[65 6 4] "they are then mixed with flour, and cooked into a most delectable mess,"][[65 6 5] "in flavor somewhat resembling calves' head, which is quite a dish among"][[65 6 6] "some epicures; and every one knows that some young bucks among the"][[65 6 7] "epicures, by continually dining upon calves' brains, by and by get to"][[65 6 8] "have a little brains of their own, so as to be able to tell a"][[65 6 9] "calf's head from their own heads; which, indeed, requires uncommon"][[65 6 10] "discrimination. And that is the reason why a young buck with an"][[65 6 11] "intelligent looking calf's head before him, is somehow one of the"][[65 6 12] "saddest sights you can see. The head looks a sort of reproachfully at"][[65 6 13] "him, with an \"Et tu Brute!\" expression."][[65 7 1] "It is not, perhaps, entirely because the whale is so excessively"][[65 7 2] "unctuous that landsmen seem to regard the eating of him with abhorrence;"][[65 7 3] "that appears to result, in some way, from the consideration before"][[65 7 4] "mentioned: i.e. that a man should eat a newly murdered thing of the sea,"][[65 7 5] "and eat it too by its own light. But no doubt the first man that ever"][[65 7 6] "murdered an ox was regarded as a murderer; perhaps he was hung; and if"][[65 7 7] "he had been put on his trial by oxen, he certainly would have been; and"][[65 7 8] "he certainly deserved it if any murderer does. Go to the meat-market"][[65 7 9] "of a Saturday night and see the crowds of live bipeds staring up at the"][[65 7 10] "long rows of dead quadrupeds. Does not that sight take a tooth out of"][[65 7 11] "the cannibal's jaw? Cannibals? who is not a cannibal? I tell you it will"][[65 7 12] "be more tolerable for the Fejee that salted down a lean missionary in"][[65 7 13] "his cellar against a coming famine; it will be more tolerable for that"][[65 7 14] "provident Fejee, I say, in the day of judgment, than for thee, civilized"][[65 7 15] "and enlightened gourmand, who nailest geese to the ground and feastest"][[65 7 16] "on their bloated livers in thy pate-de-foie-gras."][[65 8 1] "But Stubb, he eats the whale by its own light, does he? and that is"][[65 8 2] "adding insult to injury, is it? Look at your knife-handle, there, my"][[65 8 3] "civilized and enlightened gourmand dining off that roast beef, what is"][[65 8 4] "that handle made of?--what but the bones of the brother of the very ox"][[65 8 5] "you are eating? And what do you pick your teeth with, after devouring"][[65 8 6] "that fat goose? With a feather of the same fowl. And with what quill did"][[65 8 7] "the Secretary of the Society for the Suppression of Cruelty to Ganders"][[65 8 8] "formally indite his circulars? It is only within the last month or two"][[65 8 9] "that that society passed a resolution to patronise nothing but steel"][[65 8 10] "pens."][[66 0 0] "CHAPTER 66. The Shark Massacre."][[66 2 1] "When in the Southern Fishery, a captured Sperm Whale, after long and"][[66 2 2] "weary toil, is brought alongside late at night, it is not, as a general"][[66 2 3] "thing at least, customary to proceed at once to the business of cutting"][[66 2 4] "him in. For that business is an exceedingly laborious one; is not very"][[66 2 5] "soon completed; and requires all hands to set about it. Therefore, the"][[66 2 6] "common usage is to take in all sail; lash the helm a'lee; and then send"][[66 2 7] "every one below to his hammock till daylight, with the reservation that,"][[66 2 8] "until that time, anchor-watches shall be kept; that is, two and two for"][[66 2 9] "an hour, each couple, the crew in rotation shall mount the deck to see"][[66 2 10] "that all goes well."][[66 3 1] "But sometimes, especially upon the Line in the Pacific, this plan will"][[66 3 2] "not answer at all; because such incalculable hosts of sharks gather"][[66 3 3] "round the moored carcase, that were he left so for six hours, say, on a"][[66 3 4] "stretch, little more than the skeleton would be visible by morning."][[66 3 5] "In most other parts of the ocean, however, where these fish do not so"][[66 3 6] "largely abound, their wondrous voracity can be at times considerably"][[66 3 7] "diminished, by vigorously stirring them up with sharp whaling-spades,"][[66 3 8] "a procedure notwithstanding, which, in some instances, only seems to"][[66 3 9] "tickle them into still greater activity. But it was not thus in the"][[66 3 10] "present case with the Pequod's sharks; though, to be sure, any man"][[66 3 11] "unaccustomed to such sights, to have looked over her side that night,"][[66 3 12] "would have almost thought the whole round sea was one huge cheese, and"][[66 3 13] "those sharks the maggots in it."][[66 4 1] "Nevertheless, upon Stubb setting the anchor-watch after his supper was"][[66 4 2] "concluded; and when, accordingly, Queequeg and a forecastle seaman"][[66 4 3] "came on deck, no small excitement was created among the sharks; for"][[66 4 4] "immediately suspending the cutting stages over the side, and lowering"][[66 4 5] "three lanterns, so that they cast long gleams of light over the turbid"][[66 4 6] "sea, these two mariners, darting their long whaling-spades, kept up an"][[66 4 7] "incessant murdering of the sharks,* by striking the keen steel deep"][[66 4 8] "into their skulls, seemingly their only vital part. But in the foamy"][[66 4 9] "confusion of their mixed and struggling hosts, the marksmen could not"][[66 4 10] "always hit their mark; and this brought about new revelations of the"][[66 4 11] "incredible ferocity of the foe. They viciously snapped, not only at each"][[66 4 12] "other's disembowelments, but like flexible bows, bent round, and bit"][[66 4 13] "their own; till those entrails seemed swallowed over and over again by"][[66 4 14] "the same mouth, to be oppositely voided by the gaping wound. Nor was"][[66 4 15] "this all. It was unsafe to meddle with the corpses and ghosts of these"][[66 4 16] "creatures. A sort of generic or Pantheistic vitality seemed to lurk in"][[66 4 17] "their very joints and bones, after what might be called the individual"][[66 4 18] "life had departed. Killed and hoisted on deck for the sake of his skin,"][[66 4 19] "one of these sharks almost took poor Queequeg's hand off, when he tried"][[66 4 20] "to shut down the dead lid of his murderous jaw."][[66 6 1] "*The whaling-spade used for cutting-in is made of the very best steel;"][[66 6 2] "is about the bigness of a man's spread hand; and in general shape,"][[66 6 3] "corresponds to the garden implement after which it is named; only its"][[66 6 4] "sides are perfectly flat, and its upper end considerably narrower than"][[66 6 5] "the lower. This weapon is always kept as sharp as possible; and when"][[66 6 6] "being used is occasionally honed, just like a razor. In its socket, a"][[66 6 7] "stiff pole, from twenty to thirty feet long, is inserted for a handle."][[66 8 1] "\"Queequeg no care what god made him shark,\" said the savage, agonizingly"][[66 8 2] "lifting his hand up and down; \"wedder Fejee god or Nantucket god; but de"][[66 8 3] "god wat made shark must be one dam Ingin.\""][[67 0 0] "CHAPTER 67. Cutting In."][[67 2 1] "It was a Saturday night, and such a Sabbath as followed! Ex officio"][[67 2 2] "professors of Sabbath breaking are all whalemen. The ivory Pequod was"][[67 2 3] "turned into what seemed a shamble; every sailor a butcher. You would"][[67 2 4] "have thought we were offering up ten thousand red oxen to the sea gods."][[67 3 1] "In the first place, the enormous cutting tackles, among other ponderous"][[67 3 2] "things comprising a cluster of blocks generally painted green, and which"][[67 3 3] "no single man can possibly lift--this vast bunch of grapes was swayed up"][[67 3 4] "to the main-top and firmly lashed to the lower mast-head, the strongest"][[67 3 5] "point anywhere above a ship's deck. The end of the hawser-like rope"][[67 3 6] "winding through these intricacies, was then conducted to the windlass,"][[67 3 7] "and the huge lower block of the tackles was swung over the whale; to"][[67 3 8] "this block the great blubber hook, weighing some one hundred pounds, was"][[67 3 9] "attached. And now suspended in stages over the side, Starbuck and Stubb,"][[67 3 10] "the mates, armed with their long spades, began cutting a hole in the"][[67 3 11] "body for the insertion of the hook just above the nearest of the two"][[67 3 12] "side-fins. This done, a broad, semicircular line is cut round the hole,"][[67 3 13] "the hook is inserted, and the main body of the crew striking up a wild"][[67 3 14] "chorus, now commence heaving in one dense crowd at the windlass. When"][[67 3 15] "instantly, the entire ship careens over on her side; every bolt in"][[67 3 16] "her starts like the nail-heads of an old house in frosty weather; she"][[67 3 17] "trembles, quivers, and nods her frighted mast-heads to the sky. More"][[67 3 18] "and more she leans over to the whale, while every gasping heave of the"][[67 3 19] "windlass is answered by a helping heave from the billows; till at last,"][[67 3 20] "a swift, startling snap is heard; with a great swash the ship rolls"][[67 3 21] "upwards and backwards from the whale, and the triumphant tackle rises"][[67 3 22] "into sight dragging after it the disengaged semicircular end of the"][[67 3 23] "first strip of blubber. Now as the blubber envelopes the whale precisely"][[67 3 24] "as the rind does an orange, so is it stripped off from the body"][[67 3 25] "precisely as an orange is sometimes stripped by spiralizing it. For the"][[67 3 26] "strain constantly kept up by the windlass continually keeps the whale"][[67 3 27] "rolling over and over in the water, and as the blubber in one strip"][[67 3 28] "uniformly peels off along the line called the \"scarf,\" simultaneously"][[67 3 29] "cut by the spades of Starbuck and Stubb, the mates; and just as fast as"][[67 3 30] "it is thus peeled off, and indeed by that very act itself, it is all the"][[67 3 31] "time being hoisted higher and higher aloft till its upper end grazes the"][[67 3 32] "main-top; the men at the windlass then cease heaving, and for a moment"][[67 3 33] "or two the prodigious blood-dripping mass sways to and fro as if let"][[67 3 34] "down from the sky, and every one present must take good heed to dodge"][[67 3 35] "it when it swings, else it may box his ears and pitch him headlong"][[67 3 36] "overboard."][[67 4 1] "One of the attending harpooneers now advances with a long, keen weapon"][[67 4 2] "called a boarding-sword, and watching his chance he dexterously slices"][[67 4 3] "out a considerable hole in the lower part of the swaying mass. Into this"][[67 4 4] "hole, the end of the second alternating great tackle is then hooked"][[67 4 5] "so as to retain a hold upon the blubber, in order to prepare for what"][[67 4 6] "follows. Whereupon, this accomplished swordsman, warning all hands to"][[67 4 7] "stand off, once more makes a scientific dash at the mass, and with a few"][[67 4 8] "sidelong, desperate, lunging slicings, severs it completely in twain;"][[67 4 9] "so that while the short lower part is still fast, the long upper strip,"][[67 4 10] "called a blanket-piece, swings clear, and is all ready for lowering."][[67 4 11] "The heavers forward now resume their song, and while the one tackle is"][[67 4 12] "peeling and hoisting a second strip from the whale, the other is slowly"][[67 4 13] "slackened away, and down goes the first strip through the main hatchway"][[67 4 14] "right beneath, into an unfurnished parlor called the blubber-room. Into"][[67 4 15] "this twilight apartment sundry nimble hands keep coiling away the long"][[67 4 16] "blanket-piece as if it were a great live mass of plaited serpents."][[67 4 17] "And thus the work proceeds; the two tackles hoisting and lowering"][[67 4 18] "simultaneously; both whale and windlass heaving, the heavers singing,"][[67 4 19] "the blubber-room gentlemen coiling, the mates scarfing, the ship"][[67 4 20] "straining, and all hands swearing occasionally, by way of assuaging the"][[67 4 21] "general friction."][[68 0 0] "CHAPTER 68. The Blanket."][[68 2 1] "I have given no small attention to that not unvexed subject, the skin of"][[68 2 2] "the whale. I have had controversies about it with experienced whalemen"][[68 2 3] "afloat, and learned naturalists ashore. My original opinion remains"][[68 2 4] "unchanged; but it is only an opinion."][[68 3 1] "The question is, what and where is the skin of the whale? Already you"][[68 3 2] "know what his blubber is. That blubber is something of the consistence"][[68 3 3] "of firm, close-grained beef, but tougher, more elastic and compact, and"][[68 3 4] "ranges from eight or ten to twelve and fifteen inches in thickness."][[68 4 1] "Now, however preposterous it may at first seem to talk of any creature's"][[68 4 2] "skin as being of that sort of consistence and thickness, yet in point"][[68 4 3] "of fact these are no arguments against such a presumption; because you"][[68 4 4] "cannot raise any other dense enveloping layer from the whale's body but"][[68 4 5] "that same blubber; and the outermost enveloping layer of any animal, if"][[68 4 6] "reasonably dense, what can that be but the skin? True, from the unmarred"][[68 4 7] "dead body of the whale, you may scrape off with your hand an infinitely"][[68 4 8] "thin, transparent substance, somewhat resembling the thinnest shreds"][[68 4 9] "of isinglass, only it is almost as flexible and soft as satin; that is,"][[68 4 10] "previous to being dried, when it not only contracts and thickens, but"][[68 4 11] "becomes rather hard and brittle. I have several such dried bits, which"][[68 4 12] "I use for marks in my whale-books. It is transparent, as I said before;"][[68 4 13] "and being laid upon the printed page, I have sometimes pleased myself"][[68 4 14] "with fancying it exerted a magnifying influence. At any rate, it is"][[68 4 15] "pleasant to read about whales through their own spectacles, as you may"][[68 4 16] "say. But what I am driving at here is this. That same infinitely thin,"][[68 4 17] "isinglass substance, which, I admit, invests the entire body of the"][[68 4 18] "whale, is not so much to be regarded as the skin of the creature, as"][[68 4 19] "the skin of the skin, so to speak; for it were simply ridiculous to say,"][[68 4 20] "that the proper skin of the tremendous whale is thinner and more tender"][[68 4 21] "than the skin of a new-born child. But no more of this."][[68 5 1] "Assuming the blubber to be the skin of the whale; then, when this skin,"][[68 5 2] "as in the case of a very large Sperm Whale, will yield the bulk of one"][[68 5 3] "hundred barrels of oil; and, when it is considered that, in quantity, or"][[68 5 4] "rather weight, that oil, in its expressed state, is only three fourths,"][[68 5 5] "and not the entire substance of the coat; some idea may hence be had"][[68 5 6] "of the enormousness of that animated mass, a mere part of whose mere"][[68 5 7] "integument yields such a lake of liquid as that. Reckoning ten barrels"][[68 5 8] "to the ton, you have ten tons for the net weight of only three quarters"][[68 5 9] "of the stuff of the whale's skin."][[68 6 1] "In life, the visible surface of the Sperm Whale is not the least among"][[68 6 2] "the many marvels he presents. Almost invariably it is all over obliquely"][[68 6 3] "crossed and re-crossed with numberless straight marks in thick array,"][[68 6 4] "something like those in the finest Italian line engravings. But these"][[68 6 5] "marks do not seem to be impressed upon the isinglass substance above"][[68 6 6] "mentioned, but seem to be seen through it, as if they were engraved"][[68 6 7] "upon the body itself. Nor is this all. In some instances, to the quick,"][[68 6 8] "observant eye, those linear marks, as in a veritable engraving, but"][[68 6 9] "afford the ground for far other delineations. These are hieroglyphical;"][[68 6 10] "that is, if you call those mysterious cyphers on the walls of pyramids"][[68 6 11] "hieroglyphics, then that is the proper word to use in the present"][[68 6 12] "connexion. By my retentive memory of the hieroglyphics upon one Sperm"][[68 6 13] "Whale in particular, I was much struck with a plate representing the old"][[68 6 14] "Indian characters chiselled on the famous hieroglyphic palisades on"][[68 6 15] "the banks of the Upper Mississippi. Like those mystic rocks, too, the"][[68 6 16] "mystic-marked whale remains undecipherable. This allusion to the Indian"][[68 6 17] "rocks reminds me of another thing. Besides all the other phenomena which"][[68 6 18] "the exterior of the Sperm Whale presents, he not seldom displays the"][[68 6 19] "back, and more especially his flanks, effaced in great part of the"][[68 6 20] "regular linear appearance, by reason of numerous rude scratches,"][[68 6 21] "altogether of an irregular, random aspect. I should say that those New"][[68 6 22] "England rocks on the sea-coast, which Agassiz imagines to bear the marks"][[68 6 23] "of violent scraping contact with vast floating icebergs--I should say,"][[68 6 24] "that those rocks must not a little resemble the Sperm Whale in this"][[68 6 25] "particular. It also seems to me that such scratches in the whale are"][[68 6 26] "probably made by hostile contact with other whales; for I have most"][[68 6 27] "remarked them in the large, full-grown bulls of the species."][[68 7 1] "A word or two more concerning this matter of the skin or blubber of"][[68 7 2] "the whale. It has already been said, that it is stript from him in long"][[68 7 3] "pieces, called blanket-pieces. Like most sea-terms, this one is very"][[68 7 4] "happy and significant. For the whale is indeed wrapt up in his blubber"][[68 7 5] "as in a real blanket or counterpane; or, still better, an Indian poncho"][[68 7 6] "slipt over his head, and skirting his extremity. It is by reason of this"][[68 7 7] "cosy blanketing of his body, that the whale is enabled to keep himself"][[68 7 8] "comfortable in all weathers, in all seas, times, and tides. What would"][[68 7 9] "become of a Greenland whale, say, in those shuddering, icy seas of the"][[68 7 10] "North, if unsupplied with his cosy surtout? True, other fish are"][[68 7 11] "found exceedingly brisk in those Hyperborean waters; but these, be it"][[68 7 12] "observed, are your cold-blooded, lungless fish, whose very bellies"][[68 7 13] "are refrigerators; creatures, that warm themselves under the lee of"][[68 7 14] "an iceberg, as a traveller in winter would bask before an inn fire;"][[68 7 15] "whereas, like man, the whale has lungs and warm blood. Freeze his blood,"][[68 7 16] "and he dies. How wonderful is it then--except after explanation--that"][[68 7 17] "this great monster, to whom corporeal warmth is as indispensable as it"][[68 7 18] "is to man; how wonderful that he should be found at home, immersed"][[68 7 19] "to his lips for life in those Arctic waters! where, when seamen fall"][[68 7 20] "overboard, they are sometimes found, months afterwards, perpendicularly"][[68 7 21] "frozen into the hearts of fields of ice, as a fly is found glued"][[68 7 22] "in amber. But more surprising is it to know, as has been proved by"][[68 7 23] "experiment, that the blood of a Polar whale is warmer than that of a"][[68 7 24] "Borneo negro in summer."][[68 8 1] "It does seem to me, that herein we see the rare virtue of a strong"][[68 8 2] "individual vitality, and the rare virtue of thick walls, and the rare"][[68 8 3] "virtue of interior spaciousness. Oh, man! admire and model thyself after"][[68 8 4] "the whale! Do thou, too, remain warm among ice. Do thou, too, live in"][[68 8 5] "this world without being of it. Be cool at the equator; keep thy blood"][[68 8 6] "fluid at the Pole. Like the great dome of St. Peter's, and like the"][[68 8 7] "great whale, retain, O man! in all seasons a temperature of thine own."][[68 9 1] "But how easy and how hopeless to teach these fine things! Of erections,"][[68 9 2] "how few are domed like St. Peter's! of creatures, how few vast as the"][[68 9 3] "whale!"][[69 0 0] "CHAPTER 69. The Funeral."][[69 2 1] "Haul in the chains! Let the carcase go astern!"][[69 3 1] "The vast tackles have now done their duty. The peeled white body of the"][[69 3 2] "beheaded whale flashes like a marble sepulchre; though changed in hue,"][[69 3 3] "it has not perceptibly lost anything in bulk. It is still colossal."][[69 3 4] "Slowly it floats more and more away, the water round it torn and"][[69 3 5] "splashed by the insatiate sharks, and the air above vexed with rapacious"][[69 3 6] "flights of screaming fowls, whose beaks are like so many insulting"][[69 3 7] "poniards in the whale. The vast white headless phantom floats further"][[69 3 8] "and further from the ship, and every rod that it so floats, what seem"][[69 3 9] "square roods of sharks and cubic roods of fowls, augment the murderous"][[69 3 10] "din. For hours and hours from the almost stationary ship that hideous"][[69 3 11] "sight is seen. Beneath the unclouded and mild azure sky, upon the fair"][[69 3 12] "face of the pleasant sea, wafted by the joyous breezes, that great mass"][[69 3 13] "of death floats on and on, till lost in infinite perspectives."][[69 4 1] "There's a most doleful and most mocking funeral! The sea-vultures all in"][[69 4 2] "pious mourning, the air-sharks all punctiliously in black or speckled."][[69 4 3] "In life but few of them would have helped the whale, I ween, if"][[69 4 4] "peradventure he had needed it; but upon the banquet of his funeral they"][[69 4 5] "most piously do pounce. Oh, horrible vultureism of earth! from which not"][[69 4 6] "the mightiest whale is free."][[69 5 1] "Nor is this the end. Desecrated as the body is, a vengeful ghost"][[69 5 2] "survives and hovers over it to scare. Espied by some timid man-of-war or"][[69 5 3] "blundering discovery-vessel from afar, when the distance obscuring the"][[69 5 4] "swarming fowls, nevertheless still shows the white mass floating in"][[69 5 5] "the sun, and the white spray heaving high against it; straightway the"][[69 5 6] "whale's unharming corpse, with trembling fingers is set down in the"][[69 5 7] "log--SHOALS, ROCKS, AND BREAKERS HEREABOUTS: BEWARE! And for years"][[69 5 8] "afterwards, perhaps, ships shun the place; leaping over it as silly"][[69 5 9] "sheep leap over a vacuum, because their leader originally leaped there"][[69 5 10] "when a stick was held. There's your law of precedents; there's your"][[69 5 11] "utility of traditions; there's the story of your obstinate survival of"][[69 5 12] "old beliefs never bottomed on the earth, and now not even hovering in"][[69 5 13] "the air! There's orthodoxy!"][[69 6 1] "Thus, while in life the great whale's body may have been a real terror"][[69 6 2] "to his foes, in his death his ghost becomes a powerless panic to a"][[69 6 3] "world."][[69 7 1] "Are you a believer in ghosts, my friend? There are other ghosts than"][[69 7 2] "the Cock-Lane one, and far deeper men than Doctor Johnson who believe in"][[69 7 3] "them."][[70 0 0] "CHAPTER 70. The Sphynx."][[70 2 1] "It should not have been omitted that previous to completely stripping"][[70 2 2] "the body of the leviathan, he was beheaded. Now, the beheading of the"][[70 2 3] "Sperm Whale is a scientific anatomical feat, upon which experienced"][[70 2 4] "whale surgeons very much pride themselves: and not without reason."][[70 3 1] "Consider that the whale has nothing that can properly be called a neck;"][[70 3 2] "on the contrary, where his head and body seem to join, there, in that"][[70 3 3] "very place, is the thickest part of him. Remember, also, that the"][[70 3 4] "surgeon must operate from above, some eight or ten feet intervening"][[70 3 5] "between him and his subject, and that subject almost hidden in a"][[70 3 6] "discoloured, rolling, and oftentimes tumultuous and bursting sea. Bear"][[70 3 7] "in mind, too, that under these untoward circumstances he has to cut many"][[70 3 8] "feet deep in the flesh; and in that subterraneous manner, without so"][[70 3 9] "much as getting one single peep into the ever-contracting gash thus"][[70 3 10] "made, he must skilfully steer clear of all adjacent, interdicted parts,"][[70 3 11] "and exactly divide the spine at a critical point hard by its insertion"][[70 3 12] "into the skull. Do you not marvel, then, at Stubb's boast, that he"][[70 3 13] "demanded but ten minutes to behead a sperm whale?"][[70 4 1] "When first severed, the head is dropped astern and held there by a cable"][[70 4 2] "till the body is stripped. That done, if it belong to a small whale"][[70 4 3] "it is hoisted on deck to be deliberately disposed of. But, with a full"][[70 4 4] "grown leviathan this is impossible; for the sperm whale's head embraces"][[70 4 5] "nearly one third of his entire bulk, and completely to suspend such a"][[70 4 6] "burden as that, even by the immense tackles of a whaler, this were as"][[70 4 7] "vain a thing as to attempt weighing a Dutch barn in jewellers' scales."][[70 5 1] "The Pequod's whale being decapitated and the body stripped, the head was"][[70 5 2] "hoisted against the ship's side--about half way out of the sea, so that"][[70 5 3] "it might yet in great part be buoyed up by its native element. And there"][[70 5 4] "with the strained craft steeply leaning over to it, by reason of the"][[70 5 5] "enormous downward drag from the lower mast-head, and every yard-arm"][[70 5 6] "on that side projecting like a crane over the waves; there, that"][[70 5 7] "blood-dripping head hung to the Pequod's waist like the giant"][[70 5 8] "Holofernes's from the girdle of Judith."][[70 6 1] "When this last task was accomplished it was noon, and the seamen went"][[70 6 2] "below to their dinner. Silence reigned over the before tumultuous but"][[70 6 3] "now deserted deck. An intense copper calm, like a universal yellow"][[70 6 4] "lotus, was more and more unfolding its noiseless measureless leaves upon"][[70 6 5] "the sea."][[70 7 1] "A short space elapsed, and up into this noiselessness came Ahab alone"][[70 7 2] "from his cabin. Taking a few turns on the quarter-deck, he paused to"][[70 7 3] "gaze over the side, then slowly getting into the main-chains he"][[70 7 4] "took Stubb's long spade--still remaining there after the whale's"][[70 7 5] "Decapitation--and striking it into the lower part of the half-suspended"][[70 7 6] "mass, placed its other end crutch-wise under one arm, and so stood"][[70 7 7] "leaning over with eyes attentively fixed on this head."][[70 8 1] "It was a black and hooded head; and hanging there in the midst of so"][[70 8 2] "intense a calm, it seemed the Sphynx's in the desert. \"Speak, thou vast"][[70 8 3] "and venerable head,\" muttered Ahab, \"which, though ungarnished with a"][[70 8 4] "beard, yet here and there lookest hoary with mosses; speak, mighty head,"][[70 8 5] "and tell us the secret thing that is in thee. Of all divers, thou hast"][[70 8 6] "dived the deepest. That head upon which the upper sun now gleams, has"][[70 8 7] "moved amid this world's foundations. Where unrecorded names and navies"][[70 8 8] "rust, and untold hopes and anchors rot; where in her murderous hold this"][[70 8 9] "frigate earth is ballasted with bones of millions of the drowned; there,"][[70 8 10] "in that awful water-land, there was thy most familiar home. Thou hast"][[70 8 11] "been where bell or diver never went; hast slept by many a sailor's side,"][[70 8 12] "where sleepless mothers would give their lives to lay them down. Thou"][[70 8 13] "saw'st the locked lovers when leaping from their flaming ship; heart"][[70 8 14] "to heart they sank beneath the exulting wave; true to each other, when"][[70 8 15] "heaven seemed false to them. Thou saw'st the murdered mate when tossed"][[70 8 16] "by pirates from the midnight deck; for hours he fell into the deeper"][[70 8 17] "midnight of the insatiate maw; and his murderers still sailed on"][[70 8 18] "unharmed--while swift lightnings shivered the neighboring ship that"][[70 8 19] "would have borne a righteous husband to outstretched, longing arms. O"][[70 8 20] "head! thou hast seen enough to split the planets and make an infidel of"][[70 8 21] "Abraham, and not one syllable is thine!\""][[70 9 1] "\"Sail ho!\" cried a triumphant voice from the main-mast-head."][[70 10 1] "\"Aye? Well, now, that's cheering,\" cried Ahab, suddenly erecting"][[70 10 2] "himself, while whole thunder-clouds swept aside from his brow."][[70 10 3] "\"That lively cry upon this deadly calm might almost convert a better"][[70 10 4] "man.--Where away?\""][[70 11 1] "\"Three points on the starboard bow, sir, and bringing down her breeze to"][[70 11 2] "us!"][[70 12 1] "\"Better and better, man. Would now St. Paul would come along that way,"][[70 12 2] "and to my breezelessness bring his breeze! O Nature, and O soul of man!"][[70 12 3] "how far beyond all utterance are your linked analogies! not the smallest"][[70 12 4] "atom stirs or lives on matter, but has its cunning duplicate in mind.\""][[71 0 0] "CHAPTER 71. The Jeroboam's Story."][[71 2 1] "Hand in hand, ship and breeze blew on; but the breeze came faster than"][[71 2 2] "the ship, and soon the Pequod began to rock."][[71 3 1] "By and by, through the glass the stranger's boats and manned mast-heads"][[71 3 2] "proved her a whale-ship. But as she was so far to windward, and shooting"][[71 3 3] "by, apparently making a passage to some other ground, the Pequod could"][[71 3 4] "not hope to reach her. So the signal was set to see what response would"][[71 3 5] "be made."][[71 4 1] "Here be it said, that like the vessels of military marines, the ships of"][[71 4 2] "the American Whale Fleet have each a private signal; all which signals"][[71 4 3] "being collected in a book with the names of the respective vessels"][[71 4 4] "attached, every captain is provided with it. Thereby, the whale"][[71 4 5] "commanders are enabled to recognise each other upon the ocean, even at"][[71 4 6] "considerable distances and with no small facility."][[71 5 1] "The Pequod's signal was at last responded to by the stranger's setting"][[71 5 2] "her own; which proved the ship to be the Jeroboam of Nantucket. Squaring"][[71 5 3] "her yards, she bore down, ranged abeam under the Pequod's lee, and"][[71 5 4] "lowered a boat; it soon drew nigh; but, as the side-ladder was being"][[71 5 5] "rigged by Starbuck's order to accommodate the visiting captain, the"][[71 5 6] "stranger in question waved his hand from his boat's stern in token"][[71 5 7] "of that proceeding being entirely unnecessary. It turned out that"][[71 5 8] "the Jeroboam had a malignant epidemic on board, and that Mayhew, her"][[71 5 9] "captain, was fearful of infecting the Pequod's company. For, though"][[71 5 10] "himself and boat's crew remained untainted, and though his ship was half"][[71 5 11] "a rifle-shot off, and an incorruptible sea and air rolling and flowing"][[71 5 12] "between; yet conscientiously adhering to the timid quarantine of the"][[71 5 13] "land, he peremptorily refused to come into direct contact with the"][[71 5 14] "Pequod."][[71 6 1] "But this did by no means prevent all communications. Preserving an"][[71 6 2] "interval of some few yards between itself and the ship, the Jeroboam's"][[71 6 3] "boat by the occasional use of its oars contrived to keep parallel to the"][[71 6 4] "Pequod, as she heavily forged through the sea (for by this time it blew"][[71 6 5] "very fresh), with her main-topsail aback; though, indeed, at times by"][[71 6 6] "the sudden onset of a large rolling wave, the boat would be pushed some"][[71 6 7] "way ahead; but would be soon skilfully brought to her proper bearings"][[71 6 8] "again. Subject to this, and other the like interruptions now and then, a"][[71 6 9] "conversation was sustained between the two parties; but at intervals not"][[71 6 10] "without still another interruption of a very different sort."][[71 7 1] "Pulling an oar in the Jeroboam's boat, was a man of a singular"][[71 7 2] "appearance, even in that wild whaling life where individual notabilities"][[71 7 3] "make up all totalities. He was a small, short, youngish man, sprinkled"][[71 7 4] "all over his face with freckles, and wearing redundant yellow hair. A"][[71 7 5] "long-skirted, cabalistically-cut coat of a faded walnut tinge enveloped"][[71 7 6] "him; the overlapping sleeves of which were rolled up on his wrists. A"][[71 7 7] "deep, settled, fanatic delirium was in his eyes."][[71 8 1] "So soon as this figure had been first descried, Stubb had"][[71 8 2] "exclaimed--\"That's he! that's he!--the long-togged scaramouch the"][[71 8 3] "Town-Ho's company told us of!\" Stubb here alluded to a strange story"][[71 8 4] "told of the Jeroboam, and a certain man among her crew, some time"][[71 8 5] "previous when the Pequod spoke the Town-Ho. According to this account"][[71 8 6] "and what was subsequently learned, it seemed that the scaramouch in"][[71 8 7] "question had gained a wonderful ascendency over almost everybody in the"][[71 8 8] "Jeroboam. His story was this:"][[71 9 1] "He had been originally nurtured among the crazy society of Neskyeuna"][[71 9 2] "Shakers, where he had been a great prophet; in their cracked, secret"][[71 9 3] "meetings having several times descended from heaven by the way of a"][[71 9 4] "trap-door, announcing the speedy opening of the seventh vial, which he"][[71 9 5] "carried in his vest-pocket; but, which, instead of containing gunpowder,"][[71 9 6] "was supposed to be charged with laudanum. A strange, apostolic whim"][[71 9 7] "having seized him, he had left Neskyeuna for Nantucket, where, with"][[71 9 8] "that cunning peculiar to craziness, he assumed a steady, common-sense"][[71 9 9] "exterior, and offered himself as a green-hand candidate for the"][[71 9 10] "Jeroboam's whaling voyage. They engaged him; but straightway upon"][[71 9 11] "the ship's getting out of sight of land, his insanity broke out in a"][[71 9 12] "freshet. He announced himself as the archangel Gabriel, and commanded"][[71 9 13] "the captain to jump overboard. He published his manifesto, whereby"][[71 9 14] "he set himself forth as the deliverer of the isles of the sea and"][[71 9 15] "vicar-general of all Oceanica. The unflinching earnestness with which he"][[71 9 16] "declared these things;--the dark, daring play of his sleepless, excited"][[71 9 17] "imagination, and all the preternatural terrors of real delirium, united"][[71 9 18] "to invest this Gabriel in the minds of the majority of the ignorant"][[71 9 19] "crew, with an atmosphere of sacredness. Moreover, they were afraid of"][[71 9 20] "him. As such a man, however, was not of much practical use in the ship,"][[71 9 21] "especially as he refused to work except when he pleased, the incredulous"][[71 9 22] "captain would fain have been rid of him; but apprised that that"][[71 9 23] "individual's intention was to land him in the first convenient port, the"][[71 9 24] "archangel forthwith opened all his seals and vials--devoting the ship"][[71 9 25] "and all hands to unconditional perdition, in case this intention was"][[71 9 26] "carried out. So strongly did he work upon his disciples among the crew,"][[71 9 27] "that at last in a body they went to the captain and told him if Gabriel"][[71 9 28] "was sent from the ship, not a man of them would remain. He was therefore"][[71 9 29] "forced to relinquish his plan. Nor would they permit Gabriel to be any"][[71 9 30] "way maltreated, say or do what he would; so that it came to pass that"][[71 9 31] "Gabriel had the complete freedom of the ship. The consequence of all"][[71 9 32] "this was, that the archangel cared little or nothing for the captain and"][[71 9 33] "mates; and since the epidemic had broken out, he carried a higher hand"][[71 9 34] "than ever; declaring that the plague, as he called it, was at his sole"][[71 9 35] "command; nor should it be stayed but according to his good pleasure."][[71 9 36] "The sailors, mostly poor devils, cringed, and some of them fawned before"][[71 9 37] "him; in obedience to his instructions, sometimes rendering him personal"][[71 9 38] "homage, as to a god. Such things may seem incredible; but, however"][[71 9 39] "wondrous, they are true. Nor is the history of fanatics half so striking"][[71 9 40] "in respect to the measureless self-deception of the fanatic himself, as"][[71 9 41] "his measureless power of deceiving and bedevilling so many others. But"][[71 9 42] "it is time to return to the Pequod."][[71 10 1] "\"I fear not thy epidemic, man,\" said Ahab from the bulwarks, to Captain"][[71 10 2] "Mayhew, who stood in the boat's stern; \"come on board.\""][[71 11 1] "But now Gabriel started to his feet."][[71 12 1] "\"Think, think of the fevers, yellow and bilious! Beware of the horrible"][[71 12 2] "plague!\""][[71 13 1] "\"Gabriel! Gabriel!\" cried Captain Mayhew; \"thou must either--\" But"][[71 13 2] "that instant a headlong wave shot the boat far ahead, and its seethings"][[71 13 3] "drowned all speech."][[71 14 1] "\"Hast thou seen the White Whale?\" demanded Ahab, when the boat drifted"][[71 14 2] "back."][[71 15 1] "\"Think, think of thy whale-boat, stoven and sunk! Beware of the horrible"][[71 15 2] "tail!\""][[71 16 1] "\"I tell thee again, Gabriel, that--\" But again the boat tore ahead as if"][[71 16 2] "dragged by fiends. Nothing was said for some moments, while a succession"][[71 16 3] "of riotous waves rolled by, which by one of those occasional caprices"][[71 16 4] "of the seas were tumbling, not heaving it. Meantime, the hoisted sperm"][[71 16 5] "whale's head jogged about very violently, and Gabriel was seen eyeing"][[71 16 6] "it with rather more apprehensiveness than his archangel nature seemed to"][[71 16 7] "warrant."][[71 17 1] "When this interlude was over, Captain Mayhew began a dark story"][[71 17 2] "concerning Moby Dick; not, however, without frequent interruptions from"][[71 17 3] "Gabriel, whenever his name was mentioned, and the crazy sea that seemed"][[71 17 4] "leagued with him."][[71 18 1] "It seemed that the Jeroboam had not long left home, when upon speaking"][[71 18 2] "a whale-ship, her people were reliably apprised of the existence of Moby"][[71 18 3] "Dick, and the havoc he had made. Greedily sucking in this intelligence,"][[71 18 4] "Gabriel solemnly warned the captain against attacking the White"][[71 18 5] "Whale, in case the monster should be seen; in his gibbering insanity,"][[71 18 6] "pronouncing the White Whale to be no less a being than the Shaker God"][[71 18 7] "incarnated; the Shakers receiving the Bible. But when, some year or two"][[71 18 8] "afterwards, Moby Dick was fairly sighted from the mast-heads, Macey, the"][[71 18 9] "chief mate, burned with ardour to encounter him; and the captain himself"][[71 18 10] "being not unwilling to let him have the opportunity, despite all"][[71 18 11] "the archangel's denunciations and forewarnings, Macey succeeded in"][[71 18 12] "persuading five men to man his boat. With them he pushed off; and, after"][[71 18 13] "much weary pulling, and many perilous, unsuccessful onsets, he at last"][[71 18 14] "succeeded in getting one iron fast. Meantime, Gabriel, ascending to"][[71 18 15] "the main-royal mast-head, was tossing one arm in frantic gestures, and"][[71 18 16] "hurling forth prophecies of speedy doom to the sacrilegious assailants"][[71 18 17] "of his divinity. Now, while Macey, the mate, was standing up in his"][[71 18 18] "boat's bow, and with all the reckless energy of his tribe was venting"][[71 18 19] "his wild exclamations upon the whale, and essaying to get a fair chance"][[71 18 20] "for his poised lance, lo! a broad white shadow rose from the sea; by its"][[71 18 21] "quick, fanning motion, temporarily taking the breath out of the bodies"][[71 18 22] "of the oarsmen. Next instant, the luckless mate, so full of furious"][[71 18 23] "life, was smitten bodily into the air, and making a long arc in his"][[71 18 24] "descent, fell into the sea at the distance of about fifty yards. Not a"][[71 18 25] "chip of the boat was harmed, nor a hair of any oarsman's head; but the"][[71 18 26] "mate for ever sank."][[71 19 1] "It is well to parenthesize here, that of the fatal accidents in the"][[71 19 2] "Sperm-Whale Fishery, this kind is perhaps almost as frequent as any."][[71 19 3] "Sometimes, nothing is injured but the man who is thus annihilated;"][[71 19 4] "oftener the boat's bow is knocked off, or the thigh-board, in which the"][[71 19 5] "headsman stands, is torn from its place and accompanies the body. But"][[71 19 6] "strangest of all is the circumstance, that in more instances than one,"][[71 19 7] "when the body has been recovered, not a single mark of violence is"][[71 19 8] "discernible; the man being stark dead."][[71 20 1] "The whole calamity, with the falling form of Macey, was plainly descried"][[71 20 2] "from the ship. Raising a piercing shriek--\"The vial! the vial!\" Gabriel"][[71 20 3] "called off the terror-stricken crew from the further hunting of the"][[71 20 4] "whale. This terrible event clothed the archangel with added influence;"][[71 20 5] "because his credulous disciples believed that he had specifically"][[71 20 6] "fore-announced it, instead of only making a general prophecy, which any"][[71 20 7] "one might have done, and so have chanced to hit one of many marks in the"][[71 20 8] "wide margin allowed. He became a nameless terror to the ship."][[71 21 1] "Mayhew having concluded his narration, Ahab put such questions to"][[71 21 2] "him, that the stranger captain could not forbear inquiring whether he"][[71 21 3] "intended to hunt the White Whale, if opportunity should offer. To which"][[71 21 4] "Ahab answered--\"Aye.\" Straightway, then, Gabriel once more started"][[71 21 5] "to his feet, glaring upon the old man, and vehemently exclaimed, with"][[71 21 6] "downward pointed finger--\"Think, think of the blasphemer--dead, and down"][[71 21 7] "there!--beware of the blasphemer's end!\""][[71 22 1] "Ahab stolidly turned aside; then said to Mayhew, \"Captain, I have"][[71 22 2] "just bethought me of my letter-bag; there is a letter for one of thy"][[71 22 3] "officers, if I mistake not. Starbuck, look over the bag.\""][[71 23 1] "Every whale-ship takes out a goodly number of letters for various ships,"][[71 23 2] "whose delivery to the persons to whom they may be addressed, depends"][[71 23 3] "upon the mere chance of encountering them in the four oceans. Thus,"][[71 23 4] "most letters never reach their mark; and many are only received after"][[71 23 5] "attaining an age of two or three years or more."][[71 24 1] "Soon Starbuck returned with a letter in his hand. It was sorely tumbled,"][[71 24 2] "damp, and covered with a dull, spotted, green mould, in consequence"][[71 24 3] "of being kept in a dark locker of the cabin. Of such a letter, Death"][[71 24 4] "himself might well have been the post-boy."][[71 25 1] "\"Can'st not read it?\" cried Ahab. \"Give it me, man. Aye, aye, it's but"][[71 25 2] "a dim scrawl;--what's this?\" As he was studying it out, Starbuck took a"][[71 25 3] "long cutting-spade pole, and with his knife slightly split the end, to"][[71 25 4] "insert the letter there, and in that way, hand it to the boat, without"][[71 25 5] "its coming any closer to the ship."][[71 26 1] "Meantime, Ahab holding the letter, muttered, \"Mr. Har--yes, Mr."][[71 26 2] "Harry--(a woman's pinny hand,--the man's wife, I'll wager)--Aye--Mr."][[71 26 3] "Harry Macey, Ship Jeroboam;--why it's Macey, and he's dead!\""][[71 27 1] "\"Poor fellow! poor fellow! and from his wife,\" sighed Mayhew; \"but let"][[71 27 2] "me have it.\""][[71 28 1] "\"Nay, keep it thyself,\" cried Gabriel to Ahab; \"thou art soon going that"][[71 28 2] "way.\""][[71 29 1] "\"Curses throttle thee!\" yelled Ahab. \"Captain Mayhew, stand by now to"][[71 29 2] "receive it\"; and taking the fatal missive from Starbuck's hands, he"][[71 29 3] "caught it in the slit of the pole, and reached it over towards the boat."][[71 29 4] "But as he did so, the oarsmen expectantly desisted from rowing; the boat"][[71 29 5] "drifted a little towards the ship's stern; so that, as if by magic, the"][[71 29 6] "letter suddenly ranged along with Gabriel's eager hand. He clutched it"][[71 29 7] "in an instant, seized the boat-knife, and impaling the letter on it,"][[71 29 8] "sent it thus loaded back into the ship. It fell at Ahab's feet. Then"][[71 29 9] "Gabriel shrieked out to his comrades to give way with their oars, and in"][[71 29 10] "that manner the mutinous boat rapidly shot away from the Pequod."][[71 30 1] "As, after this interlude, the seamen resumed their work upon the jacket"][[71 30 2] "of the whale, many strange things were hinted in reference to this wild"][[71 30 3] "affair."][[72 0 0] "CHAPTER 72. The Monkey-Rope."][[72 2 1] "In the tumultuous business of cutting-in and attending to a whale, there"][[72 2 2] "is much running backwards and forwards among the crew. Now hands are"][[72 2 3] "wanted here, and then again hands are wanted there. There is no staying"][[72 2 4] "in any one place; for at one and the same time everything has to be done"][[72 2 5] "everywhere. It is much the same with him who endeavors the description"][[72 2 6] "of the scene. We must now retrace our way a little. It was mentioned"][[72 2 7] "that upon first breaking ground in the whale's back, the blubber-hook"][[72 2 8] "was inserted into the original hole there cut by the spades of the"][[72 2 9] "mates. But how did so clumsy and weighty a mass as that same hook"][[72 2 10] "get fixed in that hole? It was inserted there by my particular friend"][[72 2 11] "Queequeg, whose duty it was, as harpooneer, to descend upon the"][[72 2 12] "monster's back for the special purpose referred to. But in very many"][[72 2 13] "cases, circumstances require that the harpooneer shall remain on the"][[72 2 14] "whale till the whole tensing or stripping operation is concluded. The"][[72 2 15] "whale, be it observed, lies almost entirely submerged, excepting the"][[72 2 16] "immediate parts operated upon. So down there, some ten feet below the"][[72 2 17] "level of the deck, the poor harpooneer flounders about, half on the"][[72 2 18] "whale and half in the water, as the vast mass revolves like a tread-mill"][[72 2 19] "beneath him. On the occasion in question, Queequeg figured in the"][[72 2 20] "Highland costume--a shirt and socks--in which to my eyes, at least,"][[72 2 21] "he appeared to uncommon advantage; and no one had a better chance to"][[72 2 22] "observe him, as will presently be seen."][[72 3 1] "Being the savage's bowsman, that is, the person who pulled the bow-oar"][[72 3 2] "in his boat (the second one from forward), it was my cheerful duty to"][[72 3 3] "attend upon him while taking that hard-scrabble scramble upon the dead"][[72 3 4] "whale's back. You have seen Italian organ-boys holding a dancing-ape by"][[72 3 5] "a long cord. Just so, from the ship's steep side, did I hold Queequeg"][[72 3 6] "down there in the sea, by what is technically called in the fishery"][[72 3 7] "a monkey-rope, attached to a strong strip of canvas belted round his"][[72 3 8] "waist."][[72 4 1] "It was a humorously perilous business for both of us. For, before we"][[72 4 2] "proceed further, it must be said that the monkey-rope was fast at"][[72 4 3] "both ends; fast to Queequeg's broad canvas belt, and fast to my narrow"][[72 4 4] "leather one. So that for better or for worse, we two, for the time, were"][[72 4 5] "wedded; and should poor Queequeg sink to rise no more, then both usage"][[72 4 6] "and honour demanded, that instead of cutting the cord, it should drag"][[72 4 7] "me down in his wake. So, then, an elongated Siamese ligature united us."][[72 4 8] "Queequeg was my own inseparable twin brother; nor could I any way get"][[72 4 9] "rid of the dangerous liabilities which the hempen bond entailed."][[72 5 1] "So strongly and metaphysically did I conceive of my situation then, that"][[72 5 2] "while earnestly watching his motions, I seemed distinctly to perceive"][[72 5 3] "that my own individuality was now merged in a joint stock company of"][[72 5 4] "two; that my free will had received a mortal wound; and that another's"][[72 5 5] "mistake or misfortune might plunge innocent me into unmerited disaster"][[72 5 6] "and death. Therefore, I saw that here was a sort of interregnum in"][[72 5 7] "Providence; for its even-handed equity never could have so gross an"][[72 5 8] "injustice. And yet still further pondering--while I jerked him now"][[72 5 9] "and then from between the whale and ship, which would threaten to jam"][[72 5 10] "him--still further pondering, I say, I saw that this situation of mine"][[72 5 11] "was the precise situation of every mortal that breathes; only, in most"][[72 5 12] "cases, he, one way or other, has this Siamese connexion with a plurality"][[72 5 13] "of other mortals. If your banker breaks, you snap; if your apothecary by"][[72 5 14] "mistake sends you poison in your pills, you die. True, you may say"][[72 5 15] "that, by exceeding caution, you may possibly escape these and the"][[72 5 16] "multitudinous other evil chances of life. But handle Queequeg's"][[72 5 17] "monkey-rope heedfully as I would, sometimes he jerked it so, that I came"][[72 5 18] "very near sliding overboard. Nor could I possibly forget that, do what I"][[72 5 19] "would, I only had the management of one end of it.*"][[72 7 1] "*The monkey-rope is found in all whalers; but it was only in the Pequod"][[72 7 2] "that the monkey and his holder were ever tied together. This improvement"][[72 7 3] "upon the original usage was introduced by no less a man than Stubb,"][[72 7 4] "in order to afford the imperilled harpooneer the strongest possible"][[72 7 5] "guarantee for the faithfulness and vigilance of his monkey-rope holder."][[72 9 1] "I have hinted that I would often jerk poor Queequeg from between the"][[72 9 2] "whale and the ship--where he would occasionally fall, from the incessant"][[72 9 3] "rolling and swaying of both. But this was not the only jamming jeopardy"][[72 9 4] "he was exposed to. Unappalled by the massacre made upon them during the"][[72 9 5] "night, the sharks now freshly and more keenly allured by the before pent"][[72 9 6] "blood which began to flow from the carcass--the rabid creatures swarmed"][[72 9 7] "round it like bees in a beehive."][[72 10 1] "And right in among those sharks was Queequeg; who often pushed them"][[72 10 2] "aside with his floundering feet. A thing altogether incredible were"][[72 10 3] "it not that attracted by such prey as a dead whale, the otherwise"][[72 10 4] "miscellaneously carnivorous shark will seldom touch a man."][[72 11 1] "Nevertheless, it may well be believed that since they have such a"][[72 11 2] "ravenous finger in the pie, it is deemed but wise to look sharp to them."][[72 11 3] "Accordingly, besides the monkey-rope, with which I now and then jerked"][[72 11 4] "the poor fellow from too close a vicinity to the maw of what seemed"][[72 11 5] "a peculiarly ferocious shark--he was provided with still another"][[72 11 6] "protection. Suspended over the side in one of the stages, Tashtego"][[72 11 7] "and Daggoo continually flourished over his head a couple of keen"][[72 11 8] "whale-spades, wherewith they slaughtered as many sharks as they could"][[72 11 9] "reach. This procedure of theirs, to be sure, was very disinterested and"][[72 11 10] "benevolent of them. They meant Queequeg's best happiness, I admit; but"][[72 11 11] "in their hasty zeal to befriend him, and from the circumstance that both"][[72 11 12] "he and the sharks were at times half hidden by the blood-muddled water,"][[72 11 13] "those indiscreet spades of theirs would come nearer amputating a leg"][[72 11 14] "than a tail. But poor Queequeg, I suppose, straining and gasping there"][[72 11 15] "with that great iron hook--poor Queequeg, I suppose, only prayed to his"][[72 11 16] "Yojo, and gave up his life into the hands of his gods."][[72 12 1] "Well, well, my dear comrade and twin-brother, thought I, as I drew in"][[72 12 2] "and then slacked off the rope to every swell of the sea--what matters"][[72 12 3] "it, after all? Are you not the precious image of each and all of us men"][[72 12 4] "in this whaling world? That unsounded ocean you gasp in, is Life; those"][[72 12 5] "sharks, your foes; those spades, your friends; and what between sharks"][[72 12 6] "and spades you are in a sad pickle and peril, poor lad."][[72 13 1] "But courage! there is good cheer in store for you, Queequeg. For now, as"][[72 13 2] "with blue lips and blood-shot eyes the exhausted savage at last climbs"][[72 13 3] "up the chains and stands all dripping and involuntarily trembling over"][[72 13 4] "the side; the steward advances, and with a benevolent, consolatory"][[72 13 5] "glance hands him--what? Some hot Cognac? No! hands him, ye gods! hands"][[72 13 6] "him a cup of tepid ginger and water!"][[72 14 1] "\"Ginger? Do I smell ginger?\" suspiciously asked Stubb, coming near."][[72 14 2] "\"Yes, this must be ginger,\" peering into the as yet untasted cup. Then"][[72 14 3] "standing as if incredulous for a while, he calmly walked towards the"][[72 14 4] "astonished steward slowly saying, \"Ginger? ginger? and will you have"][[72 14 5] "the goodness to tell me, Mr. Dough-Boy, where lies the virtue of ginger?"][[72 14 6] "Ginger! is ginger the sort of fuel you use, Dough-boy, to kindle a fire"][[72 14 7] "in this shivering cannibal? Ginger!--what the devil is ginger?"][[72 14 8] "Sea-coal? firewood?--lucifer matches?--tinder?--gunpowder?--what the"][[72 14 9] "devil is ginger, I say, that you offer this cup to our poor Queequeg"][[72 14 10] "here.\""][[72 15 1] "\"There is some sneaking Temperance Society movement about this"][[72 15 2] "business,\" he suddenly added, now approaching Starbuck, who had just"][[72 15 3] "come from forward. \"Will you look at that kannakin, sir; smell of it,"][[72 15 4] "if you please.\" Then watching the mate's countenance, he added, \"The"][[72 15 5] "steward, Mr. Starbuck, had the face to offer that calomel and jalap"][[72 15 6] "to Queequeg, there, this instant off the whale. Is the steward an"][[72 15 7] "apothecary, sir? and may I ask whether this is the sort of bitters by"][[72 15 8] "which he blows back the life into a half-drowned man?\""][[72 16 1] "\"I trust not,\" said Starbuck, \"it is poor stuff enough.\""][[72 17 1] "\"Aye, aye, steward,\" cried Stubb, \"we'll teach you to drug a"][[72 17 2] "harpooneer; none of your apothecary's medicine here; you want to poison"][[72 17 3] "us, do ye? You have got out insurances on our lives and want to murder"][[72 17 4] "us all, and pocket the proceeds, do ye?\""][[72 18 1] "\"It was not me,\" cried Dough-Boy, \"it was Aunt Charity that brought the"][[72 18 2] "ginger on board; and bade me never give the harpooneers any spirits, but"][[72 18 3] "only this ginger-jub--so she called it.\""][[72 19 1] "\"Ginger-jub! you gingerly rascal! take that! and run along with ye"][[72 19 2] "to the lockers, and get something better. I hope I do no wrong, Mr."][[72 19 3] "Starbuck. It is the captain's orders--grog for the harpooneer on a"][[72 19 4] "whale.\""][[72 20 1] "\"Enough,\" replied Starbuck, \"only don't hit him again, but--\""][[72 21 1] "\"Oh, I never hurt when I hit, except when I hit a whale or something of"][[72 21 2] "that sort; and this fellow's a weazel. What were you about saying, sir?\""][[72 22 1] "\"Only this: go down with him, and get what thou wantest thyself.\""][[72 23 1] "When Stubb reappeared, he came with a dark flask in one hand, and a sort"][[72 23 2] "of tea-caddy in the other. The first contained strong spirits, and was"][[72 23 3] "handed to Queequeg; the second was Aunt Charity's gift, and that was"][[72 23 4] "freely given to the waves."][[73 0 0] "CHAPTER 73. Stubb and Flask Kill a Right Whale; and Then Have a Talk"][[73 0 1] "Over Him."][[73 2 1] "It must be borne in mind that all this time we have a Sperm Whale's"][[73 2 2] "prodigious head hanging to the Pequod's side. But we must let it"][[73 2 3] "continue hanging there a while till we can get a chance to attend to it."][[73 2 4] "For the present other matters press, and the best we can do now for the"][[73 2 5] "head, is to pray heaven the tackles may hold."][[73 3 1] "Now, during the past night and forenoon, the Pequod had gradually"][[73 3 2] "drifted into a sea, which, by its occasional patches of yellow brit,"][[73 3 3] "gave unusual tokens of the vicinity of Right Whales, a species of the"][[73 3 4] "Leviathan that but few supposed to be at this particular time lurking"][[73 3 5] "anywhere near. And though all hands commonly disdained the capture of"][[73 3 6] "those inferior creatures; and though the Pequod was not commissioned to"][[73 3 7] "cruise for them at all, and though she had passed numbers of them near"][[73 3 8] "the Crozetts without lowering a boat; yet now that a Sperm Whale"][[73 3 9] "had been brought alongside and beheaded, to the surprise of all, the"][[73 3 10] "announcement was made that a Right Whale should be captured that day, if"][[73 3 11] "opportunity offered."][[73 4 1] "Nor was this long wanting. Tall spouts were seen to leeward; and two"][[73 4 2] "boats, Stubb's and Flask's, were detached in pursuit. Pulling further"][[73 4 3] "and further away, they at last became almost invisible to the men at"][[73 4 4] "the mast-head. But suddenly in the distance, they saw a great heap of"][[73 4 5] "tumultuous white water, and soon after news came from aloft that one or"][[73 4 6] "both the boats must be fast. An interval passed and the boats were in"][[73 4 7] "plain sight, in the act of being dragged right towards the ship by the"][[73 4 8] "towing whale. So close did the monster come to the hull, that at"][[73 4 9] "first it seemed as if he meant it malice; but suddenly going down in a"][[73 4 10] "maelstrom, within three rods of the planks, he wholly disappeared from"][[73 4 11] "view, as if diving under the keel. \"Cut, cut!\" was the cry from the"][[73 4 12] "ship to the boats, which, for one instant, seemed on the point of being"][[73 4 13] "brought with a deadly dash against the vessel's side. But having plenty"][[73 4 14] "of line yet in the tubs, and the whale not sounding very rapidly, they"][[73 4 15] "paid out abundance of rope, and at the same time pulled with all their"][[73 4 16] "might so as to get ahead of the ship. For a few minutes the struggle was"][[73 4 17] "intensely critical; for while they still slacked out the tightened line"][[73 4 18] "in one direction, and still plied their oars in another, the contending"][[73 4 19] "strain threatened to take them under. But it was only a few feet advance"][[73 4 20] "they sought to gain. And they stuck to it till they did gain it; when"][[73 4 21] "instantly, a swift tremor was felt running like lightning along the"][[73 4 22] "keel, as the strained line, scraping beneath the ship, suddenly rose"][[73 4 23] "to view under her bows, snapping and quivering; and so flinging off its"][[73 4 24] "drippings, that the drops fell like bits of broken glass on the water,"][[73 4 25] "while the whale beyond also rose to sight, and once more the boats were"][[73 4 26] "free to fly. But the fagged whale abated his speed, and blindly altering"][[73 4 27] "his course, went round the stern of the ship towing the two boats after"][[73 4 28] "him, so that they performed a complete circuit."][[73 5 1] "Meantime, they hauled more and more upon their lines, till close"][[73 5 2] "flanking him on both sides, Stubb answered Flask with lance for"][[73 5 3] "lance; and thus round and round the Pequod the battle went, while the"][[73 5 4] "multitudes of sharks that had before swum round the Sperm Whale's body,"][[73 5 5] "rushed to the fresh blood that was spilled, thirstily drinking at every"][[73 5 6] "new gash, as the eager Israelites did at the new bursting fountains that"][[73 5 7] "poured from the smitten rock."][[73 6 1] "At last his spout grew thick, and with a frightful roll and vomit, he"][[73 6 2] "turned upon his back a corpse."][[73 7 1] "While the two headsmen were engaged in making fast cords to his flukes,"][[73 7 2] "and in other ways getting the mass in readiness for towing, some"][[73 7 3] "conversation ensued between them."][[73 8 1] "\"I wonder what the old man wants with this lump of foul lard,\" said"][[73 8 2] "Stubb, not without some disgust at the thought of having to do with so"][[73 8 3] "ignoble a leviathan."][[73 9 1] "\"Wants with it?\" said Flask, coiling some spare line in the boat's bow,"][[73 9 2] "\"did you never hear that the ship which but once has a Sperm Whale's"][[73 9 3] "head hoisted on her starboard side, and at the same time a Right Whale's"][[73 9 4] "on the larboard; did you never hear, Stubb, that that ship can never"][[73 9 5] "afterwards capsize?\""][[73 10 1] "\"Why not?"][[73 11 1] "\"I don't know, but I heard that gamboge ghost of a Fedallah saying so,"][[73 11 2] "and he seems to know all about ships' charms. But I sometimes think"][[73 11 3] "he'll charm the ship to no good at last. I don't half like that chap,"][[73 11 4] "Stubb. Did you ever notice how that tusk of his is a sort of carved into"][[73 11 5] "a snake's head, Stubb?\""][[73 12 1] "\"Sink him! Blast him! now that I think of"][[73 12 9] "it, he's always wanting oakum to stuff into the toes of his boots.\""][[73 13 1] "\"He sleeps in his boots, don't he? He hasn't got any hammock; but I've"][[73 13 2] "seen him lay of nights in a coil of rigging.\""][[73 14 1] "\"No doubt, and it's because of his cursed tail; he coils it down, do ye"][[73 14 2] "see, in the eye of the rigging.\""][[73 15 1] "\"What's the old man have so much to do with him for?\""][[73 16 1] "\"Striking up a swap or a bargain, I suppose.\""][[73 17 1] "\"Bargain?--about what?\""][[73 18 1] "\"Why, do ye see, the old man is hard bent after that White Whale, and"][[73 18 2] "the devil there is trying to come round him, and get him to swap away"][[73 18 3] "his silver watch, or his soul, or something of that sort, and then he'll"][[73 18 4] "surrender Moby Dick.\""][[73 19 1] "\"Pooh! Stubb, you are skylarking; how can Fedallah do that?\""][[73 20 1] "\"I don't know, Flask, but the devil is a curious chap, and a wicked"][[73 20 2] "one, I tell ye. Why, they say as how he went a sauntering into the"][[73 20 3] "old flag-ship once, switching his tail about devilish easy and"][[73 20 4] "gentlemanlike, and inquiring if the old governor was at home. Well, he"][[73 20 5] "was at home, and asked the devil what he wanted. The devil, switching"][[73 20 6] "his hoofs, up and says, 'I want John.' 'What for?' says the old"][[73 20 7] "governor.
