As before, the Pequod steeply"][[73 41 2] "leaned over towards the sperm whale's head, now, by the counterpoise of"][[73 41 3] "both heads, she regained her even keel; though sorely strained, you may"][[73 41 4] "well believe. So, when on one side you hoist in Locke's head, you go"][[73 41 5] "over that way; but now, on the other side, hoist in Kant's and you come"][[73 41 6] "back again; but in very poor plight. Thus, some minds for ever keep"][[73 41 7] "trimming boat. Oh, ye foolish! throw all these thunder-heads overboard,"][[73 41 8] "and then you will float light and right."][[73 42 1] "In disposing of the body of a right whale, when brought alongside the"][[73 42 2] "ship, the same preliminary proceedings commonly take place as in the"][[73 42 3] "case of a sperm whale; only, in the latter instance, the head is cut off"][[73 42 4] "whole, but in the former the lips and tongue are separately removed and"][[73 42 5] "hoisted on deck, with all the well known black bone attached to what is"][[73 42 6] "called the crown-piece. But nothing like this, in the present case,"][[73 42 7] "had been done. The carcases of both whales had dropped astern; and"][[73 42 8] "the head-laden ship not a little resembled a mule carrying a pair of"][[73 42 9] "overburdening panniers."][[73 43 1] "Meantime, Fedallah was calmly eyeing the right whale's head, and ever"][[73 43 2] "and anon glancing from the deep wrinkles there to the lines in his own"][[73 43 3] "hand. And Ahab chanced so to stand, that the Parsee occupied his shadow;"][[73 43 4] "while, if the Parsee's shadow was there at all it seemed only to"][[73 43 5] "blend with, and lengthen Ahab's. As the crew toiled on, Laplandish"][[73 43 6] "speculations were bandied among them, concerning all these passing"][[73 43 7] "things."][[74 0 0] "CHAPTER 74. The Sperm Whale's Head--Contrasted View."][[74 2 1] "Here, now, are two great whales, laying their heads together; let us"][[74 2 2] "join them, and lay together our own."][[74 3 1] "Of the grand order of folio leviathans, the Sperm Whale and the Right"][[74 3 2] "Whale are by far the most noteworthy. They are the only whales regularly"][[74 3 3] "hunted by man. To the Nantucketer, they present the two extremes of all"][[74 3 4] "the known varieties of the whale. As the external difference between"][[74 3 5] "them is mainly observable in their heads; and as a head of each is this"][[74 3 6] "moment hanging from the Pequod's side; and as we may freely go from one"][[74 3 7] "to the other, by merely stepping across the deck:--where, I should like"][[74 3 8] "to know, will you obtain a better chance to study practical cetology"][[74 3 9] "than here?"][[74 4 1] "In the first place, you are struck by the general contrast between these"][[74 4 2] "heads. Both are massive enough in all conscience; but there is a certain"][[74 4 3] "mathematical symmetry in the Sperm Whale's which the Right Whale's sadly"][[74 4 4] "lacks. There is more character in the Sperm Whale's head. As you behold"][[74 4 5] "it, you involuntarily yield the immense superiority to him, in point"][[74 4 6] "of pervading dignity. In the present instance, too, this dignity is"][[74 4 7] "heightened by the pepper and salt colour of his head at the summit,"][[74 4 8] "giving token of advanced age and large experience. In short, he is what"][[74 4 9] "the fishermen technically call a \"grey-headed whale.\""][[74 5 1] "Let us now note what is least dissimilar in these heads--namely, the two"][[74 5 2] "most important organs, the eye and the ear. Far back on the side of"][[74 5 3] "the head, and low down, near the angle of either whale's jaw, if you"][[74 5 4] "narrowly search, you will at last see a lashless eye, which you would"][[74 5 5] "fancy to be a young colt's eye; so out of all proportion is it to the"][[74 5 6] "magnitude of the head."][[74 6 1] "Now, from this peculiar sideway position of the whale's eyes, it is"][[74 6 2] "plain that he can never see an object which is exactly ahead, no more"][[74 6 3] "than he can one exactly astern. In a word, the position of the whale's"][[74 6 4] "eyes corresponds to that of a man's ears; and you may fancy, for"][[74 6 5] "yourself, how it would fare with you, did you sideways survey objects"][[74 6 6] "through your ears. You would find that you could only command some"][[74 6 7] "thirty degrees of vision in advance of the straight side-line of sight;"][[74 6 8] "and about thirty more behind it. If your bitterest foe were walking"][[74 6 9] "straight towards you, with dagger uplifted in broad day, you would not"][[74 6 10] "be able to see him, any more than if he were stealing upon you from"][[74 6 11] "behind. In a word, you would have two backs, so to speak; but, at the"][[74 6 12] "same time, also, two fronts (side fronts): for what is it that makes the"][[74 6 13] "front of a man--what, indeed, but his eyes?"][[74 7 1] "Moreover, while in most other animals that I can now think of, the eyes"][[74 7 2] "are so planted as imperceptibly to blend their visual power, so as to"][[74 7 3] "produce one picture and not two to the brain; the peculiar position of"][[74 7 4] "the whale's eyes, effectually divided as they are by many cubic feet of"][[74 7 5] "solid head, which towers between them like a great mountain separating"][[74 7 6] "two lakes in valleys; this, of course, must wholly separate the"][[74 7 7] "impressions which each independent organ imparts. The whale, therefore,"][[74 7 8] "must see one distinct picture on this side, and another distinct"][[74 7 9] "picture on that side; while all between must be profound darkness and"][[74 7 10] "nothingness to him. Man may, in effect, be said to look out on the world"][[74 7 11] "from a sentry-box with two joined sashes for his window. But with the"][[74 7 12] "whale, these two sashes are separately inserted, making two distinct"][[74 7 13] "windows, but sadly impairing the view. This peculiarity of the whale's"][[74 7 14] "eyes is a thing always to be borne in mind in the fishery; and to be"][[74 7 15] "remembered by the reader in some subsequent scenes."][[74 8 1] "A curious and most puzzling question might be started concerning this"][[74 8 2] "visual matter as touching the Leviathan. But I must be content with a"][[74 8 3] "hint. So long as a man's eyes are open in the light, the act of seeing"][[74 8 4] "is involuntary; that is, he cannot then help mechanically seeing"][[74 8 5] "whatever objects are before him. Nevertheless, any one's experience"][[74 8 6] "will teach him, that though he can take in an undiscriminating sweep of"][[74 8 7] "things at one glance, it is quite impossible for him, attentively,"][[74 8 8] "and completely, to examine any two things--however large or however"][[74 8 9] "small--at one and the same instant of time; never mind if they lie side"][[74 8 10] "by side and touch each other. But if you now come to separate these two"][[74 8 11] "objects, and surround each by a circle of profound darkness; then, in"][[74 8 12] "order to see one of them, in such a manner as to bring your mind to"][[74 8 13] "bear on it, the other will be utterly excluded from your contemporary"][[74 8 14] "consciousness. How is it, then, with the whale? True, both his eyes,"][[74 8 15] "in themselves, must simultaneously act; but is his brain so much more"][[74 8 16] "comprehensive, combining, and subtle than man's, that he can at the same"][[74 8 17] "moment of time attentively examine two distinct prospects, one on one"][[74 8 18] "side of him, and the other in an exactly opposite direction? If he"][[74 8 19] "can, then is it as marvellous a thing in him, as if a man were able"][[74 8 20] "simultaneously to go through the demonstrations of two distinct problems"][[74 8 21] "in Euclid. Nor, strictly investigated, is there any incongruity in this"][[74 8 22] "comparison."][[74 9 1] "It may be but an idle whim, but it has always seemed to me, that the"][[74 9 2] "extraordinary vacillations of movement displayed by some whales when"][[74 9 3] "beset by three or four boats; the timidity and liability to queer"][[74 9 4] "frights, so common to such whales; I think that all this indirectly"][[74 9 5] "proceeds from the helpless perplexity of volition, in which their"][[74 9 6] "divided and diametrically opposite powers of vision must involve them."][[74 10 1] "But the ear of the whale is full as curious as the eye. If you are an"][[74 10 2] "entire stranger to their race, you might hunt over these two heads"][[74 10 3] "for hours, and never discover that organ. The ear has no external leaf"][[74 10 4] "whatever; and into the hole itself you can hardly insert a quill, so"][[74 10 5] "wondrously minute is it. It is lodged a little behind the eye. With"][[74 10 6] "respect to their ears, this important difference is to be observed"][[74 10 7] "between the sperm whale and the right. While the ear of the former has"][[74 10 8] "an external opening, that of the latter is entirely and evenly covered"][[74 10 9] "over with a membrane, so as to be quite imperceptible from without."][[74 11 1] "Is it not curious, that so vast a being as the whale should see the"][[74 11 2] "world through so small an eye, and hear the thunder through an ear which"][[74 11 3] "is smaller than a hare's? But if his eyes were broad as the lens of"][[74 11 4] "Herschel's great telescope; and his ears capacious as the porches of"][[74 11 5] "cathedrals; would that make him any longer of sight, or sharper of"][[74 11 6] "hearing? Not at all.--Why then do you try to \"enlarge\" your mind?"][[74 11 7] "Subtilize it."][[74 12 1] "Let us now with whatever levers and steam-engines we have at hand, cant"][[74 12 2] "over the sperm whale's head, that it may lie bottom up; then, ascending"][[74 12 3] "by a ladder to the summit, have a peep down the mouth; and were it not"][[74 12 4] "that the body is now completely separated from it, with a lantern we"][[74 12 5] "might descend into the great Kentucky Mammoth Cave of his stomach. But"][[74 12 6] "let us hold on here by this tooth, and look about us where we are. What"][[74 12 7] "a really beautiful and chaste-looking mouth! from floor to ceiling,"][[74 12 8] "lined, or rather papered with a glistening white membrane, glossy as"][[74 12 9] "bridal satins."][[74 13 1] "But come out now, and look at this portentous lower jaw, which seems"][[74 13 2] "like the long narrow lid of an immense snuff-box, with the hinge at one"][[74 13 3] "end, instead of one side. If you pry it up, so as to get it overhead,"][[74 13 4] "and expose its rows of teeth, it seems a terrific portcullis; and such,"][[74 13 5] "alas! it proves to many a poor wight in the fishery, upon whom these"][[74 13 6] "spikes fall with impaling force. But far more terrible is it to behold,"][[74 13 7] "when fathoms down in the sea, you see some sulky whale, floating there"][[74 13 8] "suspended, with his prodigious jaw, some fifteen feet long, hanging"][[74 13 9] "straight down at right-angles with his body, for all the world like a"][[74 13 10] "ship's jib-boom. This whale is not dead; he is only dispirited; out of"][[74 13 11] "sorts, perhaps; hypochondriac; and so supine, that the hinges of his"][[74 13 12] "jaw have relaxed, leaving him there in that ungainly sort of plight, a"][[74 13 13] "reproach to all his tribe, who must, no doubt, imprecate lock-jaws upon"][[74 13 14] "him."][[74 14 1] "In most cases this lower jaw--being easily unhinged by a practised"][[74 14 2] "artist--is disengaged and hoisted on deck for the purpose of extracting"][[74 14 3] "the ivory teeth, and furnishing a supply of that hard white whalebone"][[74 14 4] "with which the fishermen fashion all sorts of curious articles,"][[74 14 5] "including canes, umbrella-stocks, and handles to riding-whips."][[74 15 1] "With a long, weary hoist the jaw is dragged on board, as if it were an"][[74 15 2] "anchor; and when the proper time comes--some few days after the other"][[74 15 3] "work--Queequeg, Daggoo, and Tashtego, being all accomplished dentists,"][[74 15 4] "are set to drawing teeth. With a keen cutting-spade, Queequeg lances"][[74 15 5] "the gums; then the jaw is lashed down to ringbolts, and a tackle being"][[74 15 6] "rigged from aloft, they drag out these teeth, as Michigan oxen drag"][[74 15 7] "stumps of old oaks out of wild wood lands. There are generally forty-two"][[74 15 8] "teeth in all; in old whales, much worn down, but undecayed; nor filled"][[74 15 9] "after our artificial fashion. The jaw is afterwards sawn into slabs, and"][[74 15 10] "piled away like joists for building houses."][[75 0 0] "CHAPTER 75. The Right Whale's Head--Contrasted View."][[75 2 1] "Crossing the deck, let us now have a good long look at the Right Whale's"][[75 2 2] "head."][[75 3 1] "As in general shape the noble Sperm Whale's head may be compared to a"][[75 3 2] "Roman war-chariot (especially in front, where it is so broadly rounded);"][[75 3 3] "so, at a broad view, the Right Whale's head bears a rather inelegant"][[75 3 4] "resemblance to a gigantic galliot-toed shoe. Two hundred years ago an"][[75 3 5] "old Dutch voyager likened its shape to that of a shoemaker's last. And"][[75 3 6] "in this same last or shoe, that old woman of the nursery tale, with"][[75 3 7] "the swarming brood, might very comfortably be lodged, she and all her"][[75 3 8] "progeny."][[75 4 1] "But as you come nearer to this great head it begins to assume different"][[75 4 2] "aspects, according to your point of view. If you stand on its summit and"][[75 4 3] "look at these two F-shaped spoutholes, you would take the whole head"][[75 4 4] "for an enormous bass-viol, and these spiracles, the apertures in its"][[75 4 5] "sounding-board. Then, again, if you fix your eye upon this strange,"][[75 4 6] "crested, comb-like incrustation on the top of the mass--this green,"][[75 4 7] "barnacled thing, which the Greenlanders call the \"crown,\" and the"][[75 4 8] "Southern fishers the \"bonnet\" of the Right Whale; fixing your eyes"][[75 4 9] "solely on this, you would take the head for the trunk of some huge oak,"][[75 4 10] "with a bird's nest in its crotch. At any rate, when you watch those live"][[75 4 11] "crabs that nestle here on this bonnet, such an idea will be almost"][[75 4 12] "sure to occur to you; unless, indeed, your fancy has been fixed by the"][[75 4 13] "technical term \"crown\" also bestowed upon it; in which case you will"][[75 4 14] "take great interest in thinking how this mighty monster is actually a"][[75 4 15] "diademed king of the sea, whose green crown has been put together for"][[75 4 16] "him in this marvellous manner. But if this whale be a king, he is a very"][[75 4 17] "sulky looking fellow to grace a diadem. Look at that hanging lower lip!"][[75 4 18] "what a huge sulk and pout is there! a sulk and pout, by carpenter's"][[75 4 19] "measurement, about twenty feet long and five feet deep; a sulk and pout"][[75 4 20] "that will yield you some  gallons of oil and more."][[75 5 1] "A great pity, now, that this unfortunate whale should be hare-lipped."][[75 5 2] "The fissure is about a foot across. Probably the mother during an"][[75 5 3] "important interval was sailing down the Peruvian coast, when earthquakes"][[75 5 4] "caused the beach to gape. Over this lip, as over a slippery threshold,"][[75 5 5] "we now slide into the mouth. Upon my word were I at Mackinaw, I should"][[75 5 6] "take this to be the inside of an Indian wigwam. Good Lord! is this the"][[75 5 7] "road that Jonah went? The roof is about twelve feet high, and runs to a"][[75 5 8] "pretty sharp angle, as if there were a regular ridge-pole there; while"][[75 5 9] "these ribbed, arched, hairy sides, present us with those wondrous, half"][[75 5 10] "vertical, scimetar-shaped slats of whalebone, say three hundred on a"][[75 5 11] "side, which depending from the upper part of the head or crown"][[75 5 12] "bone, form those Venetian blinds which have elsewhere been cursorily"][[75 5 13] "mentioned. The edges of these bones are fringed with hairy fibres,"][[75 5 14] "through which the Right Whale strains the water, and in whose"][[75 5 15] "intricacies he retains the small fish, when openmouthed he goes through"][[75 5 16] "the seas of brit in feeding time. In the central blinds of bone, as they"][[75 5 17] "stand in their natural order, there are certain curious marks, curves,"][[75 5 18] "hollows, and ridges, whereby some whalemen calculate the creature's age,"][[75 5 19] "as the age of an oak by its circular rings. Though the certainty of this"][[75 5 20] "criterion is far from demonstrable, yet it has the savor of analogical"][[75 5 21] "probability. At any rate, if we yield to it, we must grant a far greater"][[75 5 22] "age to the Right Whale than at first glance will seem reasonable."][[75 6 1] "In old times, there seem to have prevailed the most curious fancies"][[75 6 2] "concerning these blinds. One voyager in Purchas calls them the wondrous"][[75 6 3] "\"whiskers\" inside of the whale's mouth;* another, \"hogs' bristles\"; a"][[75 6 4] "third old gentleman in Hackluyt uses the following elegant language:"][[75 6 5] "\"There are about two hundred and fifty fins growing on each side of his"][[75 6 6] "upper CHOP, which arch over his tongue on each side of his mouth.\""][[75 8 1] "*This reminds us that the Right Whale really has a sort of whisker, or"][[75 8 2] "rather a moustache, consisting of a few scattered white hairs on the"][[75 8 3] "upper part of the outer end of the lower jaw. Sometimes these"][[75 8 4] "tufts impart a rather brigandish expression to his otherwise solemn"][[75 8 5] "countenance."][[75 10 1] "As every one knows, these same \"hogs' bristles,\" \"fins,\" \"whiskers,\""][[75 10 2] "\"blinds,\" or whatever you please, furnish to the ladies their busks and"][[75 10 3] "other stiffening contrivances. But in this particular, the demand has"][[75 10 4] "long been on the decline. It was in Queen Anne's time that the bone was"][[75 10 5] "in its glory, the farthingale being then all the fashion. And as those"][[75 10 6] "ancient dames moved about gaily, though in the jaws of the whale, as"][[75 10 7] "you may say; even so, in a shower, with the like thoughtlessness, do we"][[75 10 8] "nowadays fly under the same jaws for protection; the umbrella being a"][[75 10 9] "tent spread over the same bone."][[75 11 1] "But now forget all about blinds and whiskers for a moment, and, standing"][[75 11 2] "in the Right Whale's mouth, look around you afresh. Seeing all these"][[75 11 3] "colonnades of bone so methodically ranged about, would you not think"][[75 11 4] "you were inside of the great Haarlem organ, and gazing upon its"][[75 11 5] "thousand pipes? For a carpet to the organ we have a rug of the softest"][[75 11 6] "Turkey--the tongue, which is glued, as it were, to the floor of the"][[75 11 7] "mouth. It is very fat and tender, and apt to tear in pieces in hoisting"][[75 11 8] "it on deck. This particular tongue now before us; at a passing glance I"][[75 11 9] "should say it was a six-barreler; that is, it will yield you about that"][[75 11 10] "amount of oil."][[75 12 1] "Ere this, you must have plainly seen the truth of what I started"][[75 12 2] "with--that the Sperm Whale and the Right Whale have almost entirely"][[75 12 3] "different heads. To sum up, then: in the Right Whale's there is no great"][[75 12 4] "well of sperm; no ivory teeth at all; no long, slender mandible of a"][[75 12 5] "lower jaw, like the Sperm Whale's. Nor in the Sperm Whale are there any"][[75 12 6] "of those blinds of bone; no huge lower lip; and scarcely anything of a"][[75 12 7] "tongue. Again, the Right Whale has two external spout-holes, the Sperm"][[75 12 8] "Whale only one."][[75 13 1] "Look your last, now, on these venerable hooded heads, while they yet lie"][[75 13 2] "together; for one will soon sink, unrecorded, in the sea; the other will"][[75 13 3] "not be very long in following."][[75 14 1] "Can you catch the expression of the Sperm Whale's there? It is the same"][[75 14 2] "he died with, only some of the longer wrinkles in the forehead seem"][[75 14 3] "now faded away. I think his broad brow to be full of a prairie-like"][[75 14 4] "placidity, born of a speculative indifference as to death. But mark the"][[75 14 5] "other head's expression. See that amazing lower lip, pressed by accident"][[75 14 6] "against the vessel's side, so as firmly to embrace the jaw. Does not"][[75 14 7] "this whole head seem to speak of an enormous practical resolution in"][[75 14 8] "facing death? This Right Whale I take to have been a Stoic; the Sperm"][[75 14 9] "Whale, a Platonian, who might have taken up Spinoza in his latter years."][[76 0 0] "CHAPTER 76. The Battering-Ram."][[76 2 1] "Ere quitting, for the nonce, the Sperm Whale's head, I would have"][[76 2 2] "you, as a sensible physiologist, simply--particularly remark its front"][[76 2 3] "aspect, in all its compacted collectedness. I would have you investigate"][[76 2 4] "it now with the sole view of forming to yourself some unexaggerated,"][[76 2 5] "intelligent estimate of whatever battering-ram power may be lodged"][[76 2 6] "there. Here is a vital point; for you must either satisfactorily settle"][[76 2 7] "this matter with yourself, or for ever remain an infidel as to one of"][[76 2 8] "the most appalling, but not the less true events, perhaps anywhere to be"][[76 2 9] "found in all recorded history."][[76 3 1] "You observe that in the ordinary swimming position of the Sperm Whale,"][[76 3 2] "the front of his head presents an almost wholly vertical plane to the"][[76 3 3] "water; you observe that the lower part of that front slopes considerably"][[76 3 4] "backwards, so as to furnish more of a retreat for the long socket which"][[76 3 5] "receives the boom-like lower jaw; you observe that the mouth is entirely"][[76 3 6] "under the head, much in the same way, indeed, as though your own mouth"][[76 3 7] "were entirely under your chin. Moreover you observe that the whale has"][[76 3 8] "no external nose; and that what nose he has--his spout hole--is on the"][[76 3 9] "top of his head; you observe that his eyes and ears are at the sides"][[76 3 10] "of his head, nearly one third of his entire length from the front."][[76 3 11] "Wherefore, you must now have perceived that the front of the Sperm"][[76 3 12] "Whale's head is a dead, blind wall, without a single organ or tender"][[76 3 13] "prominence of any sort whatsoever. Furthermore, you are now to consider"][[76 3 14] "that only in the extreme, lower, backward sloping part of the front of"][[76 3 15] "the head, is there the slightest vestige of bone; and not till you"][[76 3 16] "get near twenty feet from the forehead do you come to the full cranial"][[76 3 17] "development. So that this whole enormous boneless mass is as one wad."][[76 3 18] "Finally, though, as will soon be revealed, its contents partly comprise"][[76 3 19] "the most delicate oil; yet, you are now to be apprised of the nature of"][[76 3 20] "the substance which so impregnably invests all that apparent effeminacy."][[76 3 21] "In some previous place I have described to you how the blubber wraps the"][[76 3 22] "body of the whale, as the rind wraps an orange. Just so with the head;"][[76 3 23] "but with this difference: about the head this envelope, though not so"][[76 3 24] "thick, is of a boneless toughness, inestimable by any man who has not"][[76 3 25] "handled it. The severest pointed harpoon, the sharpest lance darted by"][[76 3 26] "the strongest human arm, impotently rebounds from it. It is as though"][[76 3 27] "the forehead of the Sperm Whale were paved with horses' hoofs. I do not"][[76 3 28] "think that any sensation lurks in it."][[76 4 1] "Bethink yourself also of another thing. When two large, loaded Indiamen"][[76 4 2] "chance to crowd and crush towards each other in the docks, what do the"][[76 4 3] "sailors do? They do not suspend between them, at the point of coming"][[76 4 4] "contact, any merely hard substance, like iron or wood. No, they hold"][[76 4 5] "there a large, round wad of tow and cork, enveloped in the thickest"][[76 4 6] "and toughest of ox-hide. That bravely and uninjured takes the jam which"][[76 4 7] "would have snapped all their oaken handspikes and iron crow-bars. By"][[76 4 8] "itself this sufficiently illustrates the obvious fact I drive at. But"][[76 4 9] "supplementary to this, it has hypothetically occurred to me, that"][[76 4 10] "as ordinary fish possess what is called a swimming bladder in them,"][[76 4 11] "capable, at will, of distension or contraction; and as the Sperm Whale,"][[76 4 12] "as far as I know, has no such provision in him; considering, too,"][[76 4 13] "the otherwise inexplicable manner in which he now depresses his head"][[76 4 14] "altogether beneath the surface, and anon swims with it high elevated out"][[76 4 15] "of the water; considering the unobstructed elasticity of its envelope;"][[76 4 16] "considering the unique interior of his head; it has hypothetically"][[76 4 17] "occurred to me, I say, that those mystical lung-celled honeycombs there"][[76 4 18] "may possibly have some hitherto unknown and unsuspected connexion with"][[76 4 19] "the outer air, so as to be susceptible to atmospheric distension and"][[76 4 20] "contraction. If this be so, fancy the irresistibleness of that might, to"][[76 4 21] "which the most impalpable and destructive of all elements contributes."][[76 5 1] "Now, mark. Unerringly impelling this dead, impregnable, uninjurable"][[76 5 2] "wall, and this most buoyant thing within; there swims behind it all a"][[76 5 3] "mass of tremendous life, only to be adequately estimated as piled wood"][[76 5 4] "is--by the cord; and all obedient to one volition, as the smallest"][[76 5 5] "insect. So that when I shall hereafter detail to you all the"][[76 5 6] "specialities and concentrations of potency everywhere lurking in this"][[76 5 7] "expansive monster; when I shall show you some of his more inconsiderable"][[76 5 8] "braining feats; I trust you will have renounced all ignorant"][[76 5 9] "incredulity, and be ready to abide by this; that though the Sperm Whale"][[76 5 10] "stove a passage through the Isthmus of Darien, and mixed the Atlantic"][[76 5 11] "with the Pacific, you would not elevate one hair of your eye-brow. For"][[76 5 12] "unless you own the whale, you are but a provincial and sentimentalist"][[76 5 13] "in Truth. But clear Truth is a thing for salamander giants only to"][[76 5 14] "encounter; how small the chances for the provincials then? What befell"][[76 5 15] "the weakling youth lifting the dread goddess's veil at Lais?"][[77 0 0] "CHAPTER 77. The Great Heidelburgh Tun."][[77 2 1] "Now comes the Baling of the Case. But to comprehend it aright, you must"][[77 2 2] "know something of the curious internal structure of the thing operated"][[77 2 3] "upon."][[77 3 1] "Regarding the Sperm Whale's head as a solid oblong, you may, on an"][[77 3 2] "inclined plane, sideways divide it into two quoins,* whereof the lower"][[77 3 3] "is the bony structure, forming the cranium and jaws, and the upper an"][[77 3 4] "unctuous mass wholly free from bones; its broad forward end forming the"][[77 3 5] "expanded vertical apparent forehead of the whale. At the middle of the"][[77 3 6] "forehead horizontally subdivide this upper quoin, and then you have two"][[77 3 7] "almost equal parts, which before were naturally divided by an internal"][[77 3 8] "wall of a thick tendinous substance."][[77 5 1] "*Quoin is not a Euclidean term. It belongs to the pure nautical"][[77 5 2] "mathematics. I know not that it has been defined before. A quoin is a"][[77 5 3] "solid which differs from a wedge in having its sharp end formed by the"][[77 5 4] "steep inclination of one side, instead of the mutual tapering of both"][[77 5 5] "sides."][[77 7 1] "The lower subdivided part, called the junk, is one immense honeycomb"][[77 7 2] "of oil, formed by the crossing and recrossing, into ten thousand"][[77 7 3] "infiltrated cells, of tough elastic white fibres throughout its whole"][[77 7 4] "extent. The upper part, known as the Case, may be regarded as the great"][[77 7 5] "Heidelburgh Tun of the Sperm Whale. And as that famous great tierce is"][[77 7 6] "mystically carved in front, so the whale's vast plaited forehead forms"][[77 7 7] "innumerable strange devices for the emblematical adornment of his"][[77 7 8] "wondrous tun. Moreover, as that of Heidelburgh was always replenished"][[77 7 9] "with the most excellent of the wines of the Rhenish valleys, so the tun"][[77 7 10] "of the whale contains by far the most precious of all his oily vintages;"][[77 7 11] "namely, the highly-prized spermaceti, in its absolutely pure, limpid,"][[77 7 12] "and odoriferous state. Nor is this precious substance found unalloyed"][[77 7 13] "in any other part of the creature. Though in life it remains perfectly"][[77 7 14] "fluid, yet, upon exposure to the air, after death, it soon begins to"][[77 7 15] "concrete; sending forth beautiful crystalline shoots, as when the"][[77 7 16] "first thin delicate ice is just forming in water. A large whale's"][[77 7 17] "case generally yields about five hundred gallons of sperm, though from"][[77 7 18] "unavoidable circumstances, considerable of it is spilled, leaks, and"][[77 7 19] "dribbles away, or is otherwise irrevocably lost in the ticklish business"][[77 7 20] "of securing what you can."][[77 8 1] "I know not with what fine and costly material the Heidelburgh Tun"][[77 8 2] "was coated within, but in superlative richness that coating could not"][[77 8 3] "possibly have compared with the silken pearl-coloured membrane, like the"][[77 8 4] "lining of a fine pelisse, forming the inner surface of the Sperm Whale's"][[77 8 5] "case."][[77 9 1] "It will have been seen that the Heidelburgh Tun of the Sperm Whale"][[77 9 2] "embraces the entire length of the entire top of the head; and since--as"][[77 9 3] "has been elsewhere set forth--the head embraces one third of the whole"][[77 9 4] "length of the creature, then setting that length down at eighty feet for"][[77 9 5] "a good sized whale, you have more than twenty-six feet for the depth"][[77 9 6] "of the tun, when it is lengthwise hoisted up and down against a ship's"][[77 9 7] "side."][[77 10 1] "As in decapitating the whale, the operator's instrument is brought close"][[77 10 2] "to the spot where an entrance is subsequently forced into the spermaceti"][[77 10 3] "magazine; he has, therefore, to be uncommonly heedful, lest a careless,"][[77 10 4] "untimely stroke should invade the sanctuary and wastingly let out its"][[77 10 5] "invaluable contents. It is this decapitated end of the head, also, which"][[77 10 6] "is at last elevated out of the water, and retained in that position by"][[77 10 7] "the enormous cutting tackles, whose hempen combinations, on one side,"][[77 10 8] "make quite a wilderness of ropes in that quarter."][[77 11 1] "Thus much being said, attend now, I pray you, to that marvellous and--in"][[77 11 2] "this particular instance--almost fatal operation whereby the Sperm"][[77 11 3] "Whale's great Heidelburgh Tun is tapped."][[78 0 0] "CHAPTER 78. Cistern and Buckets."][[78 2 1] "Nimble as a cat, Tashtego mounts aloft; and without altering his erect"][[78 2 2] "posture, runs straight out upon the overhanging mainyard-arm, to the"][[78 2 3] "part where it exactly projects over the hoisted Tun. He has carried"][[78 2 4] "with him a light tackle called a whip, consisting of only two parts,"][[78 2 5] "travelling through a single-sheaved block. Securing this block, so that"][[78 2 6] "it hangs down from the yard-arm, he swings one end of the rope, till it"][[78 2 7] "is caught and firmly held by a hand on deck. Then, hand-over-hand, down"][[78 2 8] "the other part, the Indian drops through the air, till dexterously he"][[78 2 9] "lands on the summit of the head. There--still high elevated above the"][[78 2 10] "rest of the company, to whom he vivaciously cries--he seems some Turkish"][[78 2 11] "Muezzin calling the good people to prayers from the top of a tower. A"][[78 2 12] "short-handled sharp spade being sent up to him, he diligently searches"][[78 2 13] "for the proper place to begin breaking into the Tun. In this business"][[78 2 14] "he proceeds very heedfully, like a treasure-hunter in some old house,"][[78 2 15] "sounding the walls to find where the gold is masoned in. By the time"][[78 2 16] "this cautious search is over, a stout iron-bound bucket, precisely like"][[78 2 17] "a well-bucket, has been attached to one end of the whip; while the other"][[78 2 18] "end, being stretched across the deck, is there held by two or three"][[78 2 19] "alert hands. These last now hoist the bucket within grasp of the Indian,"][[78 2 20] "to whom another person has reached up a very long pole. Inserting this"][[78 2 21] "pole into the bucket, Tashtego downward guides the bucket into the Tun,"][[78 2 22] "till it entirely disappears; then giving the word to the seamen at the"][[78 2 23] "whip, up comes the bucket again, all bubbling like a dairy-maid's pail"][[78 2 24] "of new milk. Carefully lowered from its height, the full-freighted"][[78 2 25] "vessel is caught by an appointed hand, and quickly emptied into a large"][[78 2 26] "tub. Then remounting aloft, it again goes through the same round until"][[78 2 27] "the deep cistern will yield no more. Towards the end, Tashtego has to"][[78 2 28] "ram his long pole harder and harder, and deeper and deeper into the Tun,"][[78 2 29] "until some twenty feet of the pole have gone down."][[78 3 1] "Now, the people of the Pequod had been baling some time in this way;"][[78 3 2] "several tubs had been filled with the fragrant sperm; when all at once a"][[78 3 3] "queer accident happened. Whether it was that Tashtego, that wild Indian,"][[78 3 4] "was so heedless and reckless as to let go for a moment his one-handed"][[78 3 5] "hold on the great cabled tackles suspending the head; or whether the"][[78 3 6] "place where he stood was so treacherous and oozy; or whether the Evil"][[78 3 7] "One himself would have it to fall out so, without stating his particular"][[78 3 8] "reasons; how it was exactly, there is no telling now; but, on a sudden,"][[78 3 9] "as the eightieth or ninetieth bucket came suckingly up--my God! poor"][[78 3 10] "Tashtego--like the twin reciprocating bucket in a veritable well,"][[78 3 11] "dropped head-foremost down into this great Tun of Heidelburgh, and with"][[78 3 12] "a horrible oily gurgling, went clean out of sight!"][[78 4 1] "\"Man overboard!\" cried Daggoo, who amid the general consternation first"][[78 4 2] "came to his senses. \"Swing the bucket this way!\" and putting one foot"][[78 4 3] "into it, so as the better to secure his slippery hand-hold on the whip"][[78 4 4] "itself, the hoisters ran him high up to the top of the head, almost"][[78 4 5] "before Tashtego could have reached its interior bottom. Meantime,"][[78 4 6] "there was a terrible tumult. Looking over the side, they saw the before"][[78 4 7] "lifeless head throbbing and heaving just below the surface of the sea,"][[78 4 8] "as if that moment seized with some momentous idea; whereas it was only"][[78 4 9] "the poor Indian unconsciously revealing by those struggles the perilous"][[78 4 10] "depth to which he had sunk."][[78 5 1] "At this instant, while Daggoo, on the summit of the head, was clearing"][[78 5 2] "the whip--which had somehow got foul of the great cutting tackles--a"][[78 5 3] "sharp cracking noise was heard; and to the unspeakable horror of all,"][[78 5 4] "one of the two enormous hooks suspending the head tore out, and with"][[78 5 5] "a vast vibration the enormous mass sideways swung, till the drunk ship"][[78 5 6] "reeled and shook as if smitten by an iceberg. The one remaining hook,"][[78 5 7] "upon which the entire strain now depended, seemed every instant to be"][[78 5 8] "on the point of giving way; an event still more likely from the violent"][[78 5 9] "motions of the head."][[78 6 1] "\"Come down, come down!\" yelled the seamen to Daggoo, but with one hand"][[78 6 2] "holding on to the heavy tackles, so that if the head should drop, he"][[78 6 3] "would still remain suspended; the negro having cleared the foul line,"][[78 6 4] "rammed down the bucket into the now collapsed well, meaning that the"][[78 6 5] "buried harpooneer should grasp it, and so be hoisted out."][[78 7 1] "\"In heaven's name, man,\" cried Stubb, \"are you ramming home a cartridge"][[78 7 2] "there?--Avast! How will that help him; jamming that iron-bound bucket on"][[78 7 3] "top of his head? Avast, will ye!\""][[78 8 1] "\"Stand clear of the tackle!\" cried a voice like the bursting of a"][[78 8 2] "rocket."][[78 9 1] "Almost in the same instant, with a thunder-boom, the enormous mass"][[78 9 2] "dropped into the sea, like Niagara's Table-Rock into the whirlpool; the"][[78 9 3] "suddenly relieved hull rolled away from it, to far down her glittering"][[78 9 4] "copper; and all caught their breath, as half swinging--now over the"][[78 9 5] "sailors' heads, and now over the water--Daggoo, through a thick mist of"][[78 9 6] "spray, was dimly beheld clinging to the pendulous tackles, while poor,"][[78 9 7] "buried-alive Tashtego was sinking utterly down to the bottom of the sea!"][[78 9 8] "But hardly had the blinding vapour cleared away, when a naked figure"][[78 9 9] "with a boarding-sword in his hand, was for one swift moment seen"][[78 9 10] "hovering over the bulwarks. The next, a loud splash announced that my"][[78 9 11] "brave Queequeg had dived to the rescue. One packed rush was made to the"][[78 9 12] "side, and every eye counted every ripple, as moment followed moment, and"][[78 9 13] "no sign of either the sinker or the diver could be seen. Some hands now"][[78 9 14] "jumped into a boat alongside, and pushed a little off from the ship."][[78 10 1] "\"Ha! ha!\" cried Daggoo, all at once, from his now quiet, swinging perch"][[78 10 2] "overhead; and looking further off from the side, we saw an arm thrust"][[78 10 3] "upright from the blue waves; a sight strange to see, as an arm thrust"][[78 10 4] "forth from the grass over a grave."][[78 11 1] "\"Both! both!--it is both!\"--cried Daggoo again with a joyful shout; and"][[78 11 2] "soon after, Queequeg was seen boldly striking out with one hand, and"][[78 11 3] "with the other clutching the long hair of the Indian. Drawn into the"][[78 11 4] "waiting boat, they were quickly brought to the deck; but Tashtego was"][[78 11 5] "long in coming to, and Queequeg did not look very brisk."][[78 12 1] "Now, how had this noble rescue been accomplished? Why, diving after"][[78 12 2] "the slowly descending head, Queequeg with his keen sword had made"][[78 12 3] "side lunges near its bottom, so as to scuttle a large hole there; then"][[78 12 4] "dropping his sword, had thrust his long arm far inwards and upwards,"][[78 12 5] "and so hauled out poor Tash by the head. He averred, that upon first"][[78 12 6] "thrusting in for him, a leg was presented; but well knowing that that"][[78 12 7] "was not as it ought to be, and might occasion great trouble;--he had"][[78 12 8] "thrust back the leg, and by a dexterous heave and toss, had wrought a"][[78 12 9] "somerset upon the Indian; so that with the next trial, he came forth in"][[78 12 10] "the good old way--head foremost. As for the great head itself, that was"][[78 12 11] "doing as well as could be expected."][[78 13 1] "And thus, through the courage and great skill in obstetrics of Queequeg,"][[78 13 2] "the deliverance, or rather, delivery of Tashtego, was successfully"][[78 13 3] "accomplished, in the teeth, too, of the most untoward and apparently"][[78 13 4] "hopeless impediments; which is a lesson by no means to be forgotten."][[78 13 5] "Midwifery should be taught in the same course with fencing and boxing,"][[78 13 6] "riding and rowing."][[78 14 1] "I know that this queer adventure of the Gay-Header's will be sure to"][[78 14 2] "seem incredible to some landsmen, though they themselves may have either"][[78 14 3] "seen or heard of some one's falling into a cistern ashore; an accident"][[78 14 4] "which not seldom happens, and with much less reason too than the"][[78 14 5] "Indian's, considering the exceeding slipperiness of the curb of the"][[78 14 6] "Sperm Whale's well."][[78 15 1] "But, peradventure, it may be sagaciously urged, how is this? We thought"][[78 15 2] "the tissued, infiltrated head of the Sperm Whale, was the lightest and"][[78 15 3] "most corky part about him; and yet thou makest it sink in an element of"][[78 15 4] "a far greater specific gravity than itself. We have thee there. Not at"][[78 15 5] "all, but I have ye; for at the time poor Tash fell in, the case had been"][[78 15 6] "nearly emptied of its lighter contents, leaving little but the dense"][[78 15 7] "tendinous wall of the well--a double welded, hammered substance, as I"][[78 15 8] "have before said, much heavier than the sea water, and a lump of which"][[78 15 9] "sinks in it like lead almost. But the tendency to rapid sinking in this"][[78 15 10] "substance was in the present instance materially counteracted by the"][[78 15 11] "other parts of the head remaining undetached from it, so that it sank"][[78 15 12] "very slowly and deliberately indeed, affording Queequeg a fair chance"][[78 15 13] "for performing his agile obstetrics on the run, as you may say. Yes, it"][[78 15 14] "was a running delivery, so it was."][[78 16 1] "Now, had Tashtego perished in that head, it had been a very precious"][[78 16 2] "perishing; smothered in the very whitest and daintiest of fragrant"][[78 16 3] "spermaceti; coffined, hearsed, and tombed in the secret inner chamber"][[78 16 4] "and sanctum sanctorum of the whale. Only one sweeter end can readily be"][[78 16 5] "recalled--the delicious death of an Ohio honey-hunter, who seeking honey"][[78 16 6] "in the crotch of a hollow tree, found such exceeding store of it, that"][[78 16 7] "leaning too far over, it sucked him in, so that he died embalmed."][[78 16 8] "How many, think ye, have likewise fallen into Plato's honey head, and"][[78 16 9] "sweetly perished there?"][[79 0 0] "CHAPTER 79. The Prairie."][[79 2 1] "To scan the lines of his face, or feel the bumps on the head of this"][[79 2 2] "Leviathan; this is a thing which no Physiognomist or Phrenologist has as"][[79 2 3] "yet undertaken. Such an enterprise would seem almost as hopeful as for"][[79 2 4] "Lavater to have scrutinized the wrinkles on the Rock of Gibraltar,"][[79 2 5] "or for Gall to have mounted a ladder and manipulated the Dome of the"][[79 2 6] "Pantheon. Still, in that famous work of his, Lavater not only treats"][[79 2 7] "of the various faces of men, but also attentively studies the faces"][[79 2 8] "of horses, birds, serpents, and fish; and dwells in detail upon the"][[79 2 9] "modifications of expression discernible therein. Nor have Gall and"][[79 2 10] "his disciple Spurzheim failed to throw out some hints touching the"][[79 2 11] "phrenological characteristics of other beings than man. Therefore,"][[79 2 12] "though I am but ill qualified for a pioneer, in the application of these"][[79 2 13] "two semi-sciences to the whale, I will do my endeavor. I try all things;"][[79 2 14] "I achieve what I can."][[79 3 1] "Physiognomically regarded, the Sperm Whale is an anomalous creature."][[79 3 2] "He has no proper nose. And since the nose is the central and most"][[79 3 3] "conspicuous of the features; and since it perhaps most modifies and"][[79 3 4] "finally controls their combined expression; hence it would seem that its"][[79 3 5] "entire absence, as an external appendage, must very largely affect"][[79 3 6] "the countenance of the whale. For as in landscape gardening, a spire,"][[79 3 7] "cupola, monument, or tower of some sort, is deemed almost indispensable"][[79 3 8] "to the completion of the scene; so no face can be physiognomically in"][[79 3 9] "keeping without the elevated open-work belfry of the nose. Dash the nose"][[79 3 10] "from Phidias's marble Jove, and what a sorry remainder! Nevertheless,"][[79 3 11] "Leviathan is of so mighty a magnitude, all his proportions are so"][[79 3 12] "stately, that the same deficiency which in the sculptured Jove were"][[79 3 13] "hideous, in him is no blemish at all. Nay, it is an added grandeur. A"][[79 3 14] "nose to the whale would have been impertinent. As on your physiognomical"][[79 3 15] "voyage you sail round his vast head in your jolly-boat, your noble"][[79 3 16] "conceptions of him are never insulted by the reflection that he has a"][[79 3 17] "nose to be pulled. A pestilent conceit, which so often will insist upon"][[79 3 18] "obtruding even when beholding the mightiest royal beadle on his throne."][[79 4 1] "In some particulars, perhaps the most imposing physiognomical view to"][[79 4 2] "be had of the Sperm Whale, is that of the full front of his head. This"][[79 4 3] "aspect is sublime."][[79 5 1] "In thought, a fine human brow is like the East when troubled with the"][[79 5 2] "morning. In the repose of the pasture, the curled brow of the bull has a"][[79 5 3] "touch of the grand in it. Pushing heavy cannon up mountain defiles, the"][[79 5 4] "elephant's brow is majestic. Human or animal, the mystical brow is as"][[79 5 5] "that great golden seal affixed by the German Emperors to their decrees."][[79 5 6] "It signifies--\"God: done this day by my hand.\" But in most creatures,"][[79 5 7] "nay in man himself, very often the brow is but a mere strip of alpine"][[79 5 8] "land lying along the snow line. Few are the foreheads which like"][[79 5 9] "Shakespeare's or Melancthon's rise so high, and descend so low, that the"][[79 5 10] "eyes themselves seem clear, eternal, tideless mountain lakes; and all"][[79 5 11] "above them in the forehead's wrinkles, you seem to track the antlered"][[79 5 12] "thoughts descending there to drink, as the Highland hunters track the"][[79 5 13] "snow prints of the deer. But in the great Sperm Whale, this high and"][[79 5 14] "mighty god-like dignity inherent in the brow is so immensely amplified,"][[79 5 15] "that gazing on it, in that full front view, you feel the Deity and the"][[79 5 16] "dread powers more forcibly than in beholding any other object in living"][[79 5 17] "nature. For you see no one point precisely; not one distinct feature is"][[79 5 18] "revealed; no nose, eyes, ears, or mouth; no face; he has none, proper;"][[79 5 19] "nothing but that one broad firmament of a forehead, pleated with"][[79 5 20] "riddles; dumbly lowering with the doom of boats, and ships, and men."][[79 5 21] "Nor, in profile, does this wondrous brow diminish; though that way"][[79 5 22] "viewed its grandeur does not domineer upon you so. In profile, you"][[79 5 23] "plainly perceive that horizontal, semi-crescentic depression in the"][[79 5 24] "forehead's middle, which, in man, is Lavater's mark of genius."][[79 6 1] "But how? Genius in the Sperm Whale? Has the Sperm Whale ever written"][[79 6 2] "a book, spoken a speech? No, his great genius is declared in his"][[79 6 3] "doing nothing particular to prove it. It is moreover declared in his"][[79 6 4] "pyramidical silence. And this reminds me that had the great Sperm Whale"][[79 6 5] "been known to the young Orient World, he would have been deified by"][[79 6 6] "their child-magian thoughts. They deified the crocodile of the Nile,"][[79 6 7] "because the crocodile is tongueless; and the Sperm Whale has no"][[79 6 8] "tongue, or at least it is so exceedingly small, as to be incapable of"][[79 6 9] "protrusion. If hereafter any highly cultured, poetical nation shall lure"][[79 6 10] "back to their birth-right, the merry May-day gods of old; and livingly"][[79 6 11] "enthrone them again in the now egotistical sky; in the now unhaunted"][[79 6 12] "hill; then be sure, exalted to Jove's high seat, the great Sperm Whale"][[79 6 13] "shall lord it."][[79 7 1] "Champollion deciphered the wrinkled granite hieroglyphics. But there is"][[79 7 2] "no Champollion to decipher the Egypt of every man's and every being's"][[79 7 3] "face. Physiognomy, like every other human science, is but a passing"][[79 7 4] "fable. If then, Sir William Jones, who read in thirty languages, could"][[79 7 5] "not read the simplest peasant's face in its profounder and more subtle"][[79 7 6] "meanings, how may unlettered Ishmael hope to read the awful Chaldee of"][[79 7 7] "the Sperm Whale's brow? I but put that brow before you. Read it if you"][[79 7 8] "can."][[80 0 0] "CHAPTER 80. The Nut."][[80 2 1] "If the Sperm Whale be physiognomically a Sphinx, to the phrenologist his"][[80 2 2] "brain seems that geometrical circle which it is impossible to square."][[80 3 1] "In the full-grown creature the skull will measure at least twenty feet"][[80 3 2] "in length. Unhinge the lower jaw, and the side view of this skull is as"][[80 3 3] "the side of a moderately inclined plane resting throughout on a level"][[80 3 4] "base. But in life--as we have elsewhere seen--this inclined plane is"][[80 3 5] "angularly filled up, and almost squared by the enormous superincumbent"][[80 3 6] "mass of the junk and sperm. At the high end the skull forms a crater to"][[80 3 7] "bed that part of the mass; while under the long floor of this crater--in"][[80 3 8] "another cavity seldom exceeding ten inches in length and as many in"][[80 3 9] "depth--reposes the mere handful of this monster's brain. The brain is at"][[80 3 10] "least twenty feet from his apparent forehead in life; it is hidden"][[80 3 11] "away behind its vast outworks, like the innermost citadel within the"][[80 3 12] "amplified fortifications of Quebec. So like a choice casket is it"][[80 3 13] "secreted in him, that I have known some whalemen who peremptorily deny"][[80 3 14] "that the Sperm Whale has any other brain than that palpable semblance"][[80 3 15] "of one formed by the cubic-yards of his sperm magazine. Lying in strange"][[80 3 16] "folds, courses, and convolutions, to their apprehensions, it seems more"][[80 3 17] "in keeping with the idea of his general might to regard that mystic part"][[80 3 18] "of him as the seat of his intelligence."][[80 4 1] "It is plain, then, that phrenologically the head of this Leviathan, in"][[80 4 2] "the creature's living intact state, is an entire delusion. As for his"][[80 4 3] "true brain, you can then see no indications of it, nor feel any. The"][[80 4 4] "whale, like all things that are mighty, wears a false brow to the common"][[80 4 5] "world."][[80 5 1] "If you unload his skull of its spermy heaps and then take a rear view"][[80 5 2] "of its rear end, which is the high end, you will be struck by its"][[80 5 3] "resemblance to the human skull, beheld in the same situation, and from"][[80 5 4] "the same point of view. Indeed, place this reversed skull (scaled down"][[80 5 5] "to the human magnitude) among a plate of men's skulls, and you would"][[80 5 6] "involuntarily confound it with them; and remarking the depressions on"][[80 5 7] "one part of its summit, in phrenological phrase you would say--This"][[80 5 8] "man had no self-esteem, and no veneration. And by those negations,"][[80 5 9] "considered along with the affirmative fact of his prodigious bulk and"][[80 5 10] "power, you can best form to yourself the truest, though not the most"][[80 5 11] "exhilarating conception of what the most exalted potency is."][[80 6 1] "But if from the comparative dimensions of the whale's proper brain, you"][[80 6 2] "deem it incapable of being adequately charted, then I have another idea"][[80 6 3] "for you. If you attentively regard almost any quadruped's spine,"][[80 6 4] "you will be struck with the resemblance of its vertebrae to a strung"][[80 6 5] "necklace of dwarfed skulls, all bearing rudimental resemblance to the"][[80 6 6] "skull proper. It is a German conceit, that the vertebrae are absolutely"][[80 6 7] "undeveloped skulls. But the curious external resemblance, I take it"][[80 6 8] "the Germans were not the first men to perceive. A foreign friend once"][[80 6 9] "pointed it out to me, in the skeleton of a foe he had slain, and with"][[80 6 10] "the vertebrae of which he was inlaying, in a sort of basso-relievo, the"][[80 6 11] "beaked prow of his canoe. Now, I consider that the phrenologists have"][[80 6 12] "omitted an important thing in not pushing their investigations from the"][[80 6 13] "cerebellum through the spinal canal. For I believe that much of a man's"][[80 6 14] "character will be found betokened in his backbone. I would rather feel"][[80 6 15] "your spine than your skull, whoever you are. A thin joist of a spine"][[80 6 16] "never yet upheld a full and noble soul. I rejoice in my spine, as in the"][[80 6 17] "firm audacious staff of that flag which I fling half out to the world."][[80 7 1] "Apply this spinal branch of phrenology to the Sperm Whale. His cranial"][[80 7 2] "cavity is continuous with the first neck-vertebra; and in that vertebra"][[80 7 3] "the bottom of the spinal canal will measure ten inches across, being"][[80 7 4] "eight in height, and of a triangular figure with the base downwards. As"][[80 7 5] "it passes through the remaining vertebrae the canal tapers in size, but"][[80 7 6] "for a considerable distance remains of large capacity. Now, of course,"][[80 7 7] "this canal is filled with much the same strangely fibrous substance--the"][[80 7 8] "spinal cord--as the brain; and directly communicates with the brain."][[80 7 9] "And what is still more, for many feet after emerging from the brain's"][[80 7 10] "cavity, the spinal cord remains of an undecreasing girth, almost"][[80 7 11] "equal to that of the brain. Under all these circumstances, would it be"][[80 7 12] "unreasonable to survey and map out the whale's spine phrenologically?"][[80 7 13] "For, viewed in this light, the wonderful comparative smallness of his"][[80 7 14] "brain proper is more than compensated by the wonderful comparative"][[80 7 15] "magnitude of his spinal cord."][[80 8 1] "But leaving this hint to operate as it may with the phrenologists, I"][[80 8 2] "would merely assume the spinal theory for a moment, in reference to the"][[80 8 3] "Sperm Whale's hump. This august hump, if I mistake not, rises over one"][[80 8 4] "of the larger vertebrae, and is, therefore, in some sort, the outer"][[80 8 5] "convex mould of it. From its relative situation then, I should call this"][[80 8 6] "high hump the organ of firmness or indomitableness in the Sperm Whale."][[80 8 7] "And that the great monster is indomitable, you will yet have reason to"][[80 8 8] "know."][[81 0 0] "CHAPTER 81. The Pequod Meets The Virgin."][[81 2 1] "The predestinated day arrived, and we duly met the ship Jungfrau, Derick"][[81 2 2] "De Deer, master, of Bremen."][[81 3 1] "At one time the greatest whaling people in the world, the Dutch and"][[81 3 2] "Germans are now among the least; but here and there at very wide"][[81 3 3] "intervals of latitude and longitude, you still occasionally meet with"][[81 3 4] "their flag in the Pacific."][[81 4 1] "For some reason, the Jungfrau seemed quite eager to pay her respects."][[81 4 2] "While yet some distance from the Pequod, she rounded to, and dropping a"][[81 4 3] "boat, her captain was impelled towards us, impatiently standing in the"][[81 4 4] "bows instead of the stern."][[81 5 1] "\"What has he in his hand there?\" cried Starbuck, pointing to something"][[81 5 2] "wavingly held by the German. \"Impossible!--a lamp-feeder!\""][[81 6 1] "\"Not that,\" said Stubb, \"no, no, it's a coffee-pot, Mr. Starbuck; he's"][[81 6 2] "coming off to make us our coffee, is the Yarman; don't you see that big"][[81 6 3] "tin can there alongside of him?--that's his boiling water. Oh! he's all"][[81 6 4] "right, is the Yarman.\""][[81 7 1] "\"Go along with you,\" cried Flask, \"it's a lamp-feeder and an oil-can."][[81 7 2] "He's out of oil, and has come a-begging.\""][[81 8 1] "However curious it may seem for an oil-ship to be borrowing oil on the"][[81 8 2] "whale-ground, and however much it may invertedly contradict the old"][[81 8 3] "proverb about carrying coals to Newcastle, yet sometimes such a thing"][[81 8 4] "really happens; and in the present case Captain Derick De Deer did"][[81 8 5] "indubitably conduct a lamp-feeder as Flask did declare."][[81 9 1] "As he mounted the deck, Ahab abruptly accosted him, without at all"][[81 9 2] "heeding what he had in his hand; but in his broken lingo, the German"][[81 9 3] "soon evinced his complete ignorance of the White Whale; immediately"][[81 9 4] "turning the conversation to his lamp-feeder and oil can, with some"][[81 9 5] "remarks touching his having to turn into his hammock at night in"][[81 9 6] "profound darkness--his last drop of Bremen oil being gone, and not a"][[81 9 7] "single flying-fish yet captured to supply the deficiency; concluding"][[81 9 8] "by hinting that his ship was indeed what in the Fishery is technically"][[81 9 9] "called a CLEAN one (that is, an empty one), well deserving the name of"][[81 9 10] "Jungfrau or the Virgin."][[81 10 1] "His necessities supplied, Derick departed; but he had not gained his"][[81 10 2] "ship's side, when whales were almost simultaneously raised from the"][[81 10 3] "mast-heads of both vessels; and so eager for the chase was Derick, that"][[81 10 4] "without pausing to put his oil-can and lamp-feeder aboard, he slewed"][[81 10 5] "round his boat and made after the leviathan lamp-feeders."][[81 11 1] "Now, the game having risen to leeward, he and the other three German"][[81 11 2] "boats that soon followed him, had considerably the start of the Pequod's"][[81 11 3] "keels. There were eight whales, an average pod. Aware of their danger,"][[81 11 4] "they were going all abreast with great speed straight before the wind,"][[81 11 5] "rubbing their flanks as closely as so many spans of horses in harness."][[81 11 6] "They left a great, wide wake, as though continually unrolling a great"][[81 11 7] "wide parchment upon the sea."][[81 12 1] "Full in this rapid wake, and many fathoms in the rear, swam a huge,"][[81 12 2] "humped old bull, which by his comparatively slow progress, as well as"][[81 12 3] "by the unusual yellowish incrustations overgrowing him, seemed afflicted"][[81 12 4] "with the jaundice, or some other infirmity. Whether this whale belonged"][[81 12 5] "to the pod in advance, seemed questionable; for it is not customary for"][[81 12 6] "such venerable leviathans to be at all social. Nevertheless, he stuck"][[81 12 7] "to their wake, though indeed their back water must have retarded him,"][[81 12 8] "because the white-bone or swell at his broad muzzle was a dashed one,"][[81 12 9] "like the swell formed when two hostile currents meet. His spout was"][[81 12 10] "short, slow, and laborious; coming forth with a choking sort of gush,"][[81 12 11] "and spending itself in torn shreds, followed by strange subterranean"][[81 12 12] "commotions in him, which seemed to have egress at his other buried"][[81 12 13] "extremity, causing the waters behind him to upbubble."][[81 13 1] "\"Who's got some paregoric?\" said Stubb, \"he has the stomach-ache, I'm"][[81 13 2] "afraid. Lord, think of having half an acre of stomach-ache! Adverse"][[81 13 3] "winds are holding mad Christmas in him, boys. It's the first foul wind"][[81 13 4] "I ever knew to blow from astern; but look, did ever whale yaw so before?"][[81 13 5] "it must be, he's lost his tiller.\""][[81 14 1] "As an overladen Indiaman bearing down the Hindostan coast with a deck"][[81 14 2] "load of frightened horses, careens, buries, rolls, and wallows on her"][[81 14 3] "way; so did this old whale heave his aged bulk, and now and then partly"][[81 14 4] "turning over on his cumbrous rib-ends, expose the cause of his devious"][[81 14 5] "wake in the unnatural stump of his starboard fin. Whether he had lost"][[81 14 6] "that fin in battle, or had been born without it, it were hard to say."][[81 15 1] "\"Only wait a bit, old chap, and I'll give ye a sling for that wounded"][[81 15 2] "arm,\" cried cruel Flask, pointing to the whale-line near him."][[81 16 1] "\"Mind he don't sling thee with it,\" cried Starbuck. \"Give way, or the"][[81 16 2] "German will have him.\""][[81 17 1] "With one intent all the combined rival boats were pointed for this"][[81 17 2] "one fish, because not only was he the largest, and therefore the most"][[81 17 3] "valuable whale, but he was nearest to them, and the other whales were"][[81 17 4] "going with such great velocity, moreover, as almost to defy pursuit"][[81 17 5] "for the time. But the bird has a"][[81 26 9] "voice, and with plaintive cries will make known her fear; but the fear"][[81 26 10] "of this vast dumb brute of the sea, was chained up and enchanted in him;"][[81 26 11] "he had no voice, save that choking respiration through his spiracle,"][[81 26 12] "and this made the sight of him unspeakably pitiable; while still, in his"][[81 26 13] "amazing bulk, portcullis jaw, and omnipotent tail, there was enough to"][[81 26 14] "appal the stoutest man who so pitied."][[81 27 1] "Seeing now that but a very few moments more would give the Pequod's"][[81 27 2] "boats the advantage, and rather than be thus foiled of his game, Derick"][[81 27 3] "chose to hazard what to him must have seemed a most unusually long dart,"][[81 27 4] "ere the last chance would for ever escape."][[81 28 1] "But no sooner did his harpooneer stand up for the stroke, than all three"][[81 28 2] "tigers--Queequeg, Tashtego, Daggoo--instinctively sprang to their feet,"][[81 28 3] "and standing in a diagonal row, simultaneously pointed their barbs; and"][[81 28 4] "darted over the head of the German harpooneer, their three Nantucket"][[81 28 5] "irons entered the whale. The"][[81 28 6] "three boats, in the first fury of the whale's headlong rush, bumped"][[81 28 7] "the German's aside with such force, that both Derick and his baffled"][[81 28 8] "harpooneer were spilled out, and sailed over by the three flying keels."][[81 29 1] "\"Don't be afraid, my butter-boxes,\" cried Stubb, casting a passing"][[81 29 2] "glance upon them as he shot by; \"ye'll be picked up presently--all"][[81 29 3] "right--I saw some sharks astern--St. Bernard's dogs, you know--relieve"][[81 29 4] "distressed travellers. Hurrah! this is the way to sail now. Every keel a"][[81 29 5] "sunbeam! Hurrah!--Here we go like three tin kettles at the tail of a mad"][[81 29 6] "cougar! This puts me in mind of fastening to an elephant in a tilbury on"][[81 29 7] "a plain--makes the wheel-spokes fly, boys, when you fasten to him that"][[81 29 8] "way; and there's danger of being pitched out too, when you strike a"][[81 29 9] "hill. Hurrah! this is the way a fellow feels when he's going to Davy"][[81 29 10] "Jones--all a rush down an endless inclined plane! Hurrah! this whale"][[81 29 11] "carries the everlasting mail!\""][[81 30 1] "But the monster's run was a brief one. Giving a sudden gasp, he"][[81 30 2] "tumultuously sounded. With a grating rush, the three lines flew round"][[81 30 3] "the loggerheads with such a force as to gouge deep grooves in them;"][[81 30 4] "while so fearful were the harpooneers that this rapid sounding would"][[81 30 5] "soon exhaust the lines, that using all their dexterous might, they"][[81 30 6] "caught repeated smoking turns with the rope to hold on; till at"][[81 30 7] "last--owing to the perpendicular strain from the lead-lined chocks of"][[81 30 8] "the boats, whence the three ropes went straight down into the blue--the"][[81 30 9] "gunwales of the bows were almost even with the water, while the three"][[81 30 10] "sterns tilted high in the air. And the whale soon ceasing to sound,"][[81 30 11] "for some time they remained in that attitude, fearful of expending more"][[81 30 12] "line, though the position was a little ticklish. But though boats have"][[81 30 13] "been taken down and lost in this way, yet it is this \"holding on,\" as it"][[81 30 14] "is called; this hooking up by the sharp barbs of his live flesh from"][[81 30 15] "the back; this it is that often torments the Leviathan into soon rising"][[81 30 16] "again to meet the sharp lance of his foes. Yet not to speak of the peril"][[81 30 17] "of the thing, it is to be doubted whether this course is always the"][[81 30 18] "best; for it is but reasonable to presume, that the longer the stricken"][[81 30 19] "whale stays under water, the more he is exhausted. Because, owing to the"][[81 30 20] "enormous surface of him--in a full grown sperm whale something less than"][[81 30 21] "square feet--the pressure of the water is immense. We all know"][[81 30 22] "what an astonishing atmospheric weight we ourselves stand up under; even"][[81 30 23] "here, above-ground, in the air; how vast, then, the burden of a whale,"][[81 30 24] "bearing on his back a column of two hundred fathoms of ocean! It must at"][[81 30 25] "least equal the weight of fifty atmospheres. One whaleman has estimated"][[81 30 26] "it at the weight of twenty line-of-battle ships, with all their guns,"][[81 30 27] "and stores, and men on board."][[81 31 1] "As the three boats lay there on that gently rolling sea, gazing down"][[81 31 2] "into its eternal blue noon; and as not a single groan or cry of any"][[81 31 3] "sort, nay, not so much as a ripple or a bubble came up from its depths;"][[81 31 4] "what landsman would have thought, that beneath all that silence and"][[81 31 5] "placidity, the utmost monster of the seas was writhing and wrenching in"][[81 31 6] "agony! Not eight inches of perpendicular rope were visible at the bows."][[81 31 7] "Seems it credible that by three such thin threads the great Leviathan"][[81 31 8] "was suspended like the big weight to an eight day clock. Suspended? and"][[81 31 9] "to what? To three bits of board. Is this the creature of whom it was"][[81 31 10] "once so triumphantly said--\"Canst thou fill his skin with barbed irons?"][[81 31 11] "or his head with fish-spears? The sword of him that layeth at him cannot"][[81 31 12] "hold, the spear, the dart, nor the habergeon: he esteemeth iron as"][[81 31 13] "straw; the arrow cannot make him flee; darts are counted as stubble;"][[81 31 14] "he laugheth at the shaking of a spear!\" This the creature? this he? Oh!"][[81 31 15] "that unfulfilments should follow the prophets. For with the strength"][[81 31 16] "of a thousand thighs in his tail, Leviathan had run his head under the"][[81 31 17] "mountains of the sea, to hide him from the Pequod's fish-spears!"][[81 32 1] "In that sloping afternoon sunlight, the shadows that the three boats"][[81 32 2] "sent down beneath the surface, must have been long enough and broad"][[81 32 3] "enough to shade half Xerxes' army. Who can tell how appalling to the"][[81 32 4] "wounded whale must have been such huge phantoms flitting over his head!"][[81 33 1] "\"Stand by, men; he stirs,\" cried Starbuck, as the three lines suddenly"][[81 33 2] "vibrated in the water, distinctly conducting upwards to them, as by"][[81 33 3] "magnetic wires, the life and death throbs of the whale, so that every"][[81 33 4] "oarsman felt them in his seat. The next moment, relieved in great part"][[81 33 5] "from the downward strain at the bows, the boats gave a sudden bounce"][[81 33 6] "upwards, as a small icefield will, when a dense herd of white bears are"][[81 33 7] "scared from it into the sea."][[81 34 1] "\"Haul in! Haul in!\" cried Starbuck again; \"he's rising.\""][[81 35 1] "The lines, of which, hardly an instant before, not one hand's breadth"][[81 35 2] "could have been gained, were now in long quick coils flung back all"][[81 35 3] "dripping into the boats, and soon the whale broke water within two"][[81 35 4] "ship's lengths of the hunters."][[81 36 1] "His motions plainly denoted his extreme exhaustion. In most land animals"][[81 36 2] "there are certain valves or flood-gates in many of their veins, whereby"][[81 36 3] "when wounded, the blood is in some degree at least instantly shut off in"][[81 36 4] "certain directions. Not so with the whale; one of whose peculiarities"][[81 36 5] "it is to have an entire non-valvular structure of the blood-vessels, so"][[81 36 6] "that when pierced even by so small a point as a harpoon, a deadly"][[81 36 7] "drain is at once begun upon his whole arterial system; and when this is"][[81 36 8] "heightened by the extraordinary pressure of water at a great distance"][[81 36 9] "below the surface, his life may be said to pour from him in incessant"][[81 36 10] "streams. Yet so vast is the quantity of blood in him, and so distant"][[81 36 11] "and numerous its interior fountains, that he will keep thus bleeding and"][[81 36 12] "bleeding for a considerable period; even as in a drought a river will"][[81 36 13] "flow, whose source is in the well-springs of far-off and undiscernible"][[81 36 14] "hills. Even now, when the boats pulled upon this whale, and perilously"][[81 36 15] "drew over his swaying flukes, and the lances were darted into him,"][[81 36 16] "they were followed by steady jets from the new made wound, which kept"][[81 36 17] "continually playing, while the natural spout-hole in his head was only"][[81 36 18] "at intervals, however rapid, sending its affrighted moisture into the"][[81 36 19] "air. From this last vent no blood yet came, because no vital part of him"][[81 36 20] "had thus far been struck. His life, as they significantly call it, was"][[81 36 21] "untouched."][[81 37 1] "As the boats now more closely surrounded him, the whole upper part of"][[81 37 2] "his form, with much of it that is ordinarily submerged, was plainly"][[81 37 3] "revealed. His eyes, or rather the places where his eyes had been, were"][[81 37 4] "beheld. As strange misgrown masses gather in the knot-holes of the"][[81 37 5] "noblest oaks when prostrate, so from the points which the whale's eyes"][[81 37 6] "had once occupied, now protruded blind bulbs, horribly pitiable to see."][[81 37 7] "But pity there was none. For all his old age, and his one arm, and his"][[81 37 8] "blind eyes, he must die the death and be murdered, in order to light the"][[81 37 9] "gay bridals and other merry-makings of men, and also to illuminate the"][[81 37 10] "solemn churches that preach unconditional inoffensiveness by all to all."][[81 37 11] "Still rolling in his blood, at last he partially disclosed a strangely"][[81 37 12] "discoloured bunch or protuberance, the size of a bushel, low down on the"][[81 37 13] "flank."][[81 38 1] "\"A nice spot,\" cried Flask; \"just let me prick him there once.\""][[81 39 1] "\"Avast!\" cried Starbuck, \"there's no need of that!\""][[81 40 1] "But humane Starbuck was too late. At the instant of the dart an"][[81 40 2] "ulcerous jet shot from this cruel wound, and goaded by it into more than"][[81 40 3] "sufferable anguish, the whale now spouting thick blood, with swift fury"][[81 40 4] "blindly darted at the craft, bespattering them and their glorying crews"][[81 40 5] "all over with showers of gore, capsizing Flask's boat and marring the"][[81 40 6] "bows. It was his death stroke. For, by this time, so spent was he by"][[81 40 7] "loss of blood, that he helplessly rolled away from the wreck he had"][[81 40 8] "made; lay panting on his side, impotently flapped with his stumped fin,"][[81 40 9] "then over and over slowly revolved like a waning world; turned up"][[81 40 10] "the white secrets of his belly; lay like a log, and died. It was most"][[81 40 11] "piteous, that last expiring spout. As when by unseen hands the water"][[81 40 12] "is gradually drawn off from some mighty fountain, and with half-stifled"][[81 40 13] "melancholy gurglings the spray-column lowers and lowers to the"][[81 40 14] "ground--so the last long dying spout of the whale."][[81 41 1] "Soon, while the crews were awaiting the arrival of the ship, the body"][[81 41 2] "showed symptoms of sinking with all its treasures unrifled. Immediately,"][[81 41 3] "by Starbuck's orders, lines were secured to it at different points, so"][[81 41 4] "that ere long every boat was a buoy; the sunken whale being suspended a"][[81 41 5] "few inches beneath them by the cords. By very heedful management, when"][[81 41 6] "the ship drew nigh, the whale was transferred to her side, and was"][[81 41 7] "strongly secured there by the stiffest fluke-chains, for it was plain"][[81 41 8] "that unless artificially upheld, the body would at once sink to the"][[81 41 9] "bottom."][[81 42 1] "It so chanced that almost upon first cutting into him with the spade,"][[81 42 2] "the entire length of a corroded harpoon was found imbedded in his flesh,"][[81 42 3] "on the lower part of the bunch before described. But as the stumps of"][[81 42 4] "harpoons are frequently found in the dead bodies of captured whales,"][[81 42 5] "with the flesh perfectly healed around them, and no prominence of any"][[81 42 6] "kind to denote their place; therefore, there must needs have been"][[81 42 7] "some other unknown reason in the present case fully to account for"][[81 42 8] "the ulceration alluded to. But still more curious was the fact of a"][[81 42 9] "lance-head of stone being found in him, not far from the buried iron,"][[81 42 10] "the flesh perfectly firm about it. Who had darted that stone lance? And"][[81 42 11] "when? It might have been darted by some Nor' West Indian long before"][[81 42 12] "America was discovered."][[81 43 1] "What other marvels might have been rummaged out of this monstrous"][[81 43 2] "cabinet there is no telling. But a sudden stop was put to further"][[81 43 3] "discoveries, by the ship's being unprecedentedly dragged over sideways"][[81 43 4] "to the sea, owing to the body's immensely increasing tendency to sink."][[81 43 5] "However, Starbuck, who had the ordering of affairs, hung on to it to the"][[81 43 6] "last; hung on to it so resolutely, indeed, that when at length the ship"][[81 43 7] "would have been capsized, if still persisting in locking arms with the"][[81 43 8] "body; then, when the command was given to break clear from it, such was"][[81 43 9] "the immovable strain upon the timber-heads to which the fluke-chains and"][[81 43 10] "cables were fastened, that it was impossible to cast them off. Meantime"][[81 43 11] "everything in the Pequod was aslant. To cross to the other side of the"][[81 43 12] "deck was like walking up the steep gabled roof of a house. The ship"][[81 43 13] "groaned and gasped. Many of the ivory inlayings of her bulwarks and"][[81 43 14] "cabins were started from their places, by the unnatural dislocation."][[81 43 15] "In vain handspikes and crows were brought to bear upon the immovable"][[81 43 16] "fluke-chains, to pry them adrift from the timberheads; and so low"][[81 43 17] "had the whale now settled that the submerged ends could not be at all"][[81 43 18] "approached, while every moment whole tons of ponderosity seemed added to"][[81 43 19] "the sinking bulk, and the ship seemed on the point of going over."][[81 44 1] "\"Hold on, hold on, won't ye?\" cried Stubb to the body, \"don't be in such"][[81 44 2] "a devil of a hurry to sink! By thunder, men, we must do something or go"][[81 44 3] "for it. No use prying there; avast, I say with your handspikes, and run"][[81 44 4] "one of ye for a prayer book and a pen-knife, and cut the big chains.\""][[81 45 1] "\"Knife? Aye, aye,\" cried Queequeg, and seizing the carpenter's heavy"][[81 45 2] "hatchet, he leaned out of a porthole, and steel to iron, began slashing"][[81 45 3] "at the largest fluke-chains. But a few strokes, full of sparks, were"][[81 45 4] "given, when the exceeding strain effected the rest. With a terrific"][[81 45 5] "snap, every fastening went adrift; the ship righted, the carcase sank."][[81 46 1] "Now, this occasional inevitable sinking of the recently killed Sperm"][[81 46 2] "Whale is a very curious thing; nor has any fisherman yet adequately"][[81 46 3] "accounted for it. Usually the dead Sperm Whale floats with great"][[81 46 4] "buoyancy, with its side or belly considerably elevated above the"][[81 46 5] "surface. If the only whales that thus sank were old, meagre, and"][[81 46 6] "broken-hearted creatures, their pads of lard diminished and all their"][[81 46 7] "bones heavy and rheumatic; then you might with some reason assert that"][[81 46 8] "this sinking is caused by an uncommon specific gravity in the fish so"][[81 46 9] "sinking, consequent upon this absence of buoyant matter in him. But it"][[81 46 10] "is not so. For young whales, in the highest health, and swelling with"][[81 46 11] "noble aspirations, prematurely cut off in the warm flush and May of"][[81 46 12] "life, with all their panting lard about them; even these brawny, buoyant"][[81 46 13] "heroes do sometimes sink."][[81 47 1] "Be it said, however, that the Sperm Whale is far less liable to this"][[81 47 2] "accident than any other species. Where one of that sort go down, twenty"][[81 47 3] "Right Whales do. This difference in the species is no doubt imputable in"][[81 47 4] "no small degree to the greater quantity of bone in the Right Whale;"][[81 47 5] "his Venetian blinds alone sometimes weighing more than a ton; from this"][[81 47 6] "incumbrance the Sperm Whale is wholly free. But there are instances"][[81 47 7] "where, after the lapse of many hours or several days, the sunken whale"][[81 47 8] "again rises, more buoyant than in life. But the reason of this"][[81 47 9] "is obvious. Gases are generated in him; he swells to a prodigious"][[81 47 10] "magnitude; becomes a sort of animal balloon. A line-of-battle ship could"][[81 47 11] "hardly keep him under then. In the Shore Whaling, on soundings, among"][[81 47 12] "the Bays of New Zealand, when a Right Whale gives token of sinking, they"][[81 47 13] "fasten buoys to him, with plenty of rope; so that when the body has gone"][[81 47 14] "down, they know where to look for it when it shall have ascended again."][[81 48 1] "It was not long after the sinking of the body that a cry was heard from"][[81 48 2] "the Pequod's mast-heads, announcing that the Jungfrau was again lowering"][[81 48 3] "her boats; though the only spout in sight was that of a Fin-Back,"][[81 48 4] "belonging to the species of uncapturable whales, because of its"][[81 48 5] "incredible power of swimming. Nevertheless, the Fin-Back's spout is so"][[81 48 6] "similar to the Sperm Whale's, that by unskilful fishermen it is often"][[81 48 7] "mistaken for it. And consequently Derick and all his host were now in"][[81 48 8] "valiant chase of this unnearable brute. The Virgin crowding all sail,"][[81 48 9] "made after her four young keels, and thus they all disappeared far to"][[81 48 10] "leeward, still in bold, hopeful chase."][[81 49 1] "Oh! many are the Fin-Backs, and many are the Dericks, my friend."][[82 0 0] "CHAPTER 82.
