The Honour and Glory of Whaling."][[82 2 1] "There are some enterprises in which a careful disorderliness is the true"][[82 2 2] "method."][[82 3 1] "The more I dive into this matter of whaling, and push my researches up"][[82 3 2] "to the very spring-head of it so much the more am I impressed with its"][[82 3 3] "great honourableness and antiquity; and especially when I find so many"][[82 3 4] "great demi-gods and heroes, prophets of all sorts, who one way or other"][[82 3 5] "have shed distinction upon it, I am transported with the reflection"][[82 3 6] "that I myself belong, though but subordinately, to so emblazoned a"][[82 3 7] "fraternity."][[82 4 1] "The gallant Perseus, a son of Jupiter, was the first whaleman; and"][[82 4 2] "to the eternal honour of our calling be it said, that the first whale"][[82 4 3] "attacked by our brotherhood was not killed with any sordid intent. Those"][[82 4 4] "were the knightly days of our profession, when we only bore arms to"][[82 4 5] "succor the distressed, and not to fill men's lamp-feeders. Every one"][[82 4 6] "knows the fine story of Perseus and Andromeda; how the lovely Andromeda,"][[82 4 7] "the daughter of a king, was tied to a rock on the sea-coast, and as"][[82 4 8] "Leviathan was in the very act of carrying her off, Perseus, the prince"][[82 4 9] "of whalemen, intrepidly advancing, harpooned the monster, and delivered"][[82 4 10] "and married the maid. It was an admirable artistic exploit, rarely"][[82 4 11] "achieved by the best harpooneers of the present day; inasmuch as this"][[82 4 12] "Leviathan was slain at the very first dart. And let no man doubt this"][[82 4 13] "Arkite story; for in the ancient Joppa, now Jaffa, on the Syrian coast,"][[82 4 14] "in one of the Pagan temples, there stood for many ages the vast skeleton"][[82 4 15] "of a whale, which the city's legends and all the inhabitants asserted to"][[82 4 16] "be the identical bones of the monster that Perseus slew. When the Romans"][[82 4 17] "took Joppa, the same skeleton was carried to Italy in triumph. What"][[82 4 18] "seems most singular and suggestively important in this story, is this:"][[82 4 19] "it was from Joppa that Jonah set sail."][[82 5 1] "Akin to the adventure of Perseus and Andromeda--indeed, by some supposed"][[82 5 2] "to be indirectly derived from it--is that famous story of St. George and"][[82 5 3] "the Dragon; which dragon I maintain to have been a whale; for in many"][[82 5 4] "old chronicles whales and dragons are strangely jumbled together, and"][[82 5 5] "often stand for each other. \"Thou art as a lion of the waters, and as a"][[82 5 6] "dragon of the sea,\" saith Ezekiel; hereby, plainly meaning a whale;"][[82 5 7] "in truth, some versions of the Bible use that word itself. Besides, it"][[82 5 8] "would much subtract from the glory of the exploit had St. George but"][[82 5 9] "encountered a crawling reptile of the land, instead of doing battle"][[82 5 10] "with the great monster of the deep. Any man may kill a snake, but only a"][[82 5 11] "Perseus, a St. George, a Coffin, have the heart in them to march boldly"][[82 5 12] "up to a whale."][[82 6 1] "Let not the modern paintings of this scene mislead us; for though"][[82 6 2] "the creature encountered by that valiant whaleman of old is vaguely"][[82 6 3] "represented of a griffin-like shape, and though the battle is depicted"][[82 6 4] "on land and the saint on horseback, yet considering the great ignorance"][[82 6 5] "of those times, when the true form of the whale was unknown to artists;"][[82 6 6] "and considering that as in Perseus' case, St. George's whale might have"][[82 6 7] "crawled up out of the sea on the beach; and considering that the animal"][[82 6 8] "ridden by St. George might have been only a large seal, or sea-horse;"][[82 6 9] "bearing all this in mind, it will not appear altogether incompatible"][[82 6 10] "with the sacred legend and the ancientest draughts of the scene, to"][[82 6 11] "hold this so-called dragon no other than the great Leviathan himself. In"][[82 6 12] "fact, placed before the strict and piercing truth, this whole story will"][[82 6 13] "fare like that fish, flesh, and fowl idol of the Philistines, Dagon by"][[82 6 14] "name; who being planted before the ark of Israel, his horse's head and"][[82 6 15] "both the palms of his hands fell off from him, and only the stump or"][[82 6 16] "fishy part of him remained. Thus, then, one of our own noble stamp, even"][[82 6 17] "a whaleman, is the tutelary guardian of England; and by good rights, we"][[82 6 18] "harpooneers of Nantucket should be enrolled in the most noble order"][[82 6 19] "of St. George. And therefore, let not the knights of that honourable"][[82 6 20] "company (none of whom, I venture to say, have ever had to do with a"][[82 6 21] "whale like their great patron), let them never eye a Nantucketer with"][[82 6 22] "disdain, since even in our woollen frocks and tarred trowsers we are"][[82 6 23] "much better entitled to St. George's decoration than they."][[82 7 1] "Whether to admit Hercules among us or not, concerning this I long"][[82 7 2] "remained dubious: for though according to the Greek mythologies, that"][[82 7 3] "antique Crockett and Kit Carson--that brawny doer of rejoicing good"][[82 7 4] "deeds, was swallowed down and thrown up by a whale; still, whether"][[82 7 5] "that strictly makes a whaleman of him, that might be mooted. It nowhere"][[82 7 6] "appears that he ever actually harpooned his fish, unless, indeed,"][[82 7 7] "from the inside. Nevertheless, he may be deemed a sort of involuntary"][[82 7 8] "whaleman; at any rate the whale caught him, if he did not the whale. I"][[82 7 9] "claim him for one of our clan."][[82 8 1] "But, by the best contradictory authorities, this Grecian story of"][[82 8 2] "Hercules and the whale is considered to be derived from the still more"][[82 8 3] "ancient Hebrew story of Jonah and the whale; and vice versa; certainly"][[82 8 4] "they are very similar. If I claim the demigod then, why not the prophet?"][[82 9 1] "Nor do heroes, saints, demigods, and prophets alone comprise the whole"][[82 9 2] "roll of our order. Our grand master is still to be named; for like royal"][[82 9 3] "kings of old times, we find the head waters of our fraternity in nothing"][[82 9 4] "short of the great gods themselves. That wondrous oriental story is now"][[82 9 5] "to be rehearsed from the Shaster, which gives us the dread Vishnoo, one"][[82 9 6] "of the three persons in the godhead of the Hindoos; gives us this divine"][[82 9 7] "Vishnoo himself for our Lord;--Vishnoo, who, by the first of his ten"][[82 9 8] "earthly incarnations, has for ever set apart and sanctified the whale."][[82 9 9] "When Brahma, or the God of Gods, saith the Shaster, resolved to recreate"][[82 9 10] "the world after one of its periodical dissolutions, he gave birth to"][[82 9 11] "Vishnoo, to preside over the work; but the Vedas, or mystical books,"][[82 9 12] "whose perusal would seem to have been indispensable to Vishnoo before"][[82 9 13] "beginning the creation, and which therefore must have contained"][[82 9 14] "something in the shape of practical hints to young architects, these"][[82 9 15] "Vedas were lying at the bottom of the waters; so Vishnoo became"][[82 9 16] "incarnate in a whale, and sounding down in him to the uttermost depths,"][[82 9 17] "rescued the sacred volumes. Was not this Vishnoo a whaleman, then? even"][[82 9 18] "as a man who rides a horse is called a horseman?"][[82 10 1] "Perseus, St. George, Hercules, Jonah, and Vishnoo! there's a member-roll"][[82 10 2] "for you! What club but the whaleman's can head off like that?"][[83 0 0] "CHAPTER 83. Jonah Historically Regarded."][[83 2 1] "Reference was made to the historical story of Jonah and the whale in the"][[83 2 2] "preceding chapter. Now some Nantucketers rather distrust this historical"][[83 2 3] "story of Jonah and the whale. But then there were some sceptical Greeks"][[83 2 4] "and Romans, who, standing out from the orthodox pagans of their times,"][[83 2 5] "equally doubted the story of Hercules and the whale, and Arion and the"][[83 2 6] "dolphin; and yet their doubting those traditions did not make those"][[83 2 7] "traditions one whit the less facts, for all that."][[83 3 1] "One old Sag-Harbor whaleman's chief reason for questioning the Hebrew"][[83 3 2] "story was this:--He had one of those quaint old-fashioned Bibles,"][[83 3 3] "embellished with curious, unscientific plates; one of which represented"][[83 3 4] "Jonah's whale with two spouts in his head--a peculiarity only true"][[83 3 5] "with respect to a species of the Leviathan (the Right Whale, and the"][[83 3 6] "varieties of that order), concerning which the fishermen have this"][[83 3 7] "saying, \"A penny roll would choke him\"; his swallow is so very small."][[83 3 8] "But, to this, Bishop Jebb's anticipative answer is ready. It is not"][[83 3 9] "necessary, hints the Bishop, that we consider Jonah as tombed in the"][[83 3 10] "whale's belly, but as temporarily lodged in some part of his mouth. And"][[83 3 11] "this seems reasonable enough in the good Bishop. For truly, the"][[83 3 12] "Right Whale's mouth would accommodate a couple of whist-tables, and"][[83 3 13] "comfortably seat all the players. Possibly, too, Jonah might have"][[83 3 14] "ensconced himself in a hollow tooth; but, on second thoughts, the Right"][[83 3 15] "Whale is toothless."][[83 4 1] "Another reason which Sag-Harbor (he went by that name) urged for his"][[83 4 2] "want of faith in this matter of the prophet, was something obscurely in"][[83 4 3] "reference to his incarcerated body and the whale's gastric juices. But"][[83 4 4] "this objection likewise falls to the ground, because a German exegetist"][[83 4 5] "supposes that Jonah must have taken refuge in the floating body of a"][[83 4 6] "DEAD whale--even as the French soldiers in the Russian campaign turned"][[83 4 7] "their dead horses into tents, and crawled into them. Besides, it has"][[83 4 8] "been divined by other continental commentators, that when Jonah was"][[83 4 9] "thrown overboard from the Joppa ship, he straightway effected his escape"][[83 4 10] "to another vessel near by, some vessel with a whale for a figure-head;"][[83 4 11] "and, I would add, possibly called \"The Whale,\" as some craft are"][[83 4 12] "nowadays christened the \"Shark,\" the \"Gull,\" the \"Eagle.\" Nor have there"][[83 4 13] "been wanting learned exegetists who have opined that the whale mentioned"][[83 4 14] "in the book of Jonah merely meant a life-preserver--an inflated bag"][[83 4 15] "of wind--which the endangered prophet swam to, and so was saved from a"][[83 4 16] "watery doom. Poor Sag-Harbor, therefore, seems worsted all round. But"][[83 4 17] "he had still another reason for his want of faith. It was this, if I"][[83 4 18] "remember right: Jonah was swallowed by the whale in the Mediterranean"][[83 4 19] "Sea, and after three days he was vomited up somewhere within three days'"][[83 4 20] "journey of Nineveh, a city on the Tigris, very much more than three"][[83 4 21] "days' journey across from the nearest point of the Mediterranean coast."][[83 4 22] "How is that?"][[83 5 1] "But was there no other way for the whale to land the prophet within that"][[83 5 2] "short distance of Nineveh? Yes. He might have carried him round by the"][[83 5 3] "way of the Cape of Good Hope. But not to speak of the passage through"][[83 5 4] "the whole length of the Mediterranean, and another passage up the"][[83 5 5] "Persian Gulf and Red Sea, such a supposition would involve the complete"][[83 5 6] "circumnavigation of all Africa in three days, not to speak of the Tigris"][[83 5 7] "waters, near the site of Nineveh, being too shallow for any whale to"][[83 5 8] "swim in. Besides, this idea of Jonah's weathering the Cape of Good Hope"][[83 5 9] "at so early a day would wrest the honour of the discovery of that great"][[83 5 10] "headland from Bartholomew Diaz, its reputed discoverer, and so make"][[83 5 11] "modern history a liar."][[83 6 1] "But all these foolish arguments of old Sag-Harbor only evinced his"][[83 6 2] "foolish pride of reason--a thing still more reprehensible in him, seeing"][[83 6 3] "that he had but little learning except what he had picked up from the"][[83 6 4] "sun and the sea. I say it only shows his foolish, impious pride, and"][[83 6 5] "abominable, devilish rebellion against the reverend clergy. For by a"][[83 6 6] "Portuguese Catholic priest, this very idea of Jonah's going to Nineveh"][[83 6 7] "via the Cape of Good Hope was advanced as a signal magnification of"][[83 6 8] "the general miracle. And so it was. Besides, to this day, the highly"][[83 6 9] "enlightened Turks devoutly believe in the historical story of Jonah. And"][[83 6 10] "some three centuries ago, an English traveller in old Harris's Voyages,"][[83 6 11] "speaks of a Turkish Mosque built in honour of Jonah, in which Mosque was"][[83 6 12] "a miraculous lamp that burnt without any oil."][[84 0 0] "CHAPTER 84. Pitchpoling."][[84 2 1] "To make them run easily and swiftly, the axles of carriages are"][[84 2 2] "anointed; and for much the same purpose, some whalers perform an"][[84 2 3] "analogous operation upon their boat; they grease the bottom. Nor is it"][[84 2 4] "to be doubted that as such a procedure can do no harm, it may possibly"][[84 2 5] "be of no contemptible advantage; considering that oil and water are"][[84 2 6] "hostile; that oil is a sliding thing, and that the object in view is to"][[84 2 7] "make the boat slide bravely. Queequeg believed strongly in anointing"][[84 2 8] "his boat, and one morning not long after the German ship Jungfrau"][[84 2 9] "disappeared, took more than customary pains in that occupation; crawling"][[84 2 10] "under its bottom, where it hung over the side, and rubbing in the"][[84 2 11] "unctuousness as though diligently seeking to insure a crop of hair from"][[84 2 12] "the craft's bald keel. He seemed to be working in obedience to some"][[84 2 13] "particular presentiment. Nor did it remain unwarranted by the event."][[84 3 1] "Towards noon whales were raised; but so soon as the ship sailed down to"][[84 3 2] "them, they turned and fled with swift precipitancy; a disordered flight,"][[84 3 3] "as of Cleopatra's barges from Actium."][[84 4 1] "Nevertheless, the boats pursued, and Stubb's was foremost. By great"][[84 4 2] "exertion, Tashtego at last succeeded in planting one iron; but the"][[84 4 3] "stricken whale, without at all sounding, still continued his horizontal"][[84 4 4] "flight, with added fleetness. Such unintermitted strainings upon the"][[84 4 5] "planted iron must sooner or later inevitably extract it. It became"][[84 4 6] "imperative to lance the flying whale, or be content to lose him. But"][[84 4 7] "to haul the boat up to his flank was impossible, he swam so fast and"][[84 4 8] "furious. What then remained?"][[84 5 1] "Of all the wondrous devices and dexterities, the sleights of hand and"][[84 5 2] "countless subtleties, to which the veteran whaleman is so often forced,"][[84 5 3] "none exceed that fine manoeuvre with the lance called pitchpoling. Small"][[84 5 4] "sword, or broad sword, in all its exercises boasts nothing like it. It"][[84 5 5] "is only indispensable with an inveterate running whale; its grand"][[84 5 6] "fact and feature is the wonderful distance to which the long lance is"][[84 5 7] "accurately darted from a violently rocking, jerking boat, under extreme"][[84 5 8] "headway. Steel and wood included, the entire spear is some ten or twelve"][[84 5 9] "feet in length; the staff is much slighter than that of the harpoon,"][[84 5 10] "and also of a lighter material--pine. It is furnished with a small rope"][[84 5 11] "called a warp, of considerable length, by which it can be hauled back to"][[84 5 12] "the hand after darting."][[84 6 1] "But before going further, it is important to mention here, that though"][[84 6 2] "the harpoon may be pitchpoled in the same way with the lance, yet it"][[84 6 3] "is seldom done; and when done, is still less frequently successful,"][[84 6 4] "on account of the greater weight and inferior length of the harpoon as"][[84 6 5] "compared with the lance, which in effect become serious drawbacks. As a"][[84 6 6] "general thing, therefore, you must first get fast to a whale, before any"][[84 6 7] "pitchpoling comes into play."][[84 7 1] "Look now at Stubb; a man who from his humorous, deliberate coolness and"][[84 7 2] "equanimity in the direst emergencies, was specially qualified to excel"][[84 7 3] "in pitchpoling. Look at him; he stands upright in the tossed bow of the"][[84 7 4] "flying boat; wrapt in fleecy foam, the towing whale is forty feet ahead."][[84 7 5] "Handling the long lance lightly, glancing twice or thrice along its"][[84 7 6] "length to see if it be exactly straight, Stubb whistlingly gathers up"][[84 7 7] "the coil of the warp in one hand, so as to secure its free end in his"][[84 7 8] "grasp, leaving the rest unobstructed. Then holding the lance full before"][[84 7 9] "his waistband's middle, he levels it at the whale; when, covering"][[84 7 10] "him with it, he steadily depresses the butt-end in his hand, thereby"][[84 7 11] "elevating the point till the weapon stands fairly balanced upon his"][[84 7 12] "palm, fifteen feet in the air. He minds you somewhat of a juggler,"][[84 7 13] "balancing a long staff on his chin. Next moment with a rapid, nameless"][[84 7 14] "impulse, in a superb lofty arch the bright steel spans the foaming"][[84 7 15] "distance, and quivers in the life spot of the whale. Instead of"][[84 7 16] "sparkling water, he now spouts red blood."][[84 8 1] "\"That drove the spigot out of him!\" cried Stubb. \"'Tis July's immortal"][[84 8 2] "Fourth; all fountains must run wine today! Would now, it were old"][[84 8 3] "Orleans whiskey, or old Ohio, or unspeakable old Monongahela! Then,"][[84 8 4] "Tashtego, lad, I'd have ye hold a canakin to the jet, and we'd drink"][[84 8 5] "round it! Yea, verily, hearts alive, we'd brew choice punch in the"][[84 8 6] "spread of his spout-hole there, and from that live punch-bowl quaff the"][[84 8 7] "living stuff.\""][[84 9 1] "Again and again to such gamesome talk, the dexterous dart is repeated,"][[84 9 2] "the spear returning to its master like a greyhound held in skilful"][[84 9 3] "leash. The agonized whale goes into his flurry; the tow-line is"][[84 9 4] "slackened, and the pitchpoler dropping astern, folds his hands, and"][[84 9 5] "mutely watches the monster die."][[85 0 0] "CHAPTER 85. The Fountain."][[85 2 1] "That for six thousand years--and no one knows how many millions of ages"][[85 2 2] "before--the great whales should have been spouting all over the sea,"][[85 2 3] "and sprinkling and mistifying the gardens of the deep, as with so"][[85 2 4] "many sprinkling or mistifying pots; and that for some centuries back,"][[85 2 5] "thousands of hunters should have been close by the fountain of the"][[85 2 6] "whale, watching these sprinklings and spoutings--that all this should"][[85 2 7] "be, and yet, that down to this blessed minute (fifteen and a quarter"][[85 2 8] "minutes past one o'clock P.M. of this sixteenth day of December, A.D."][[85 2 9] "), it should still remain a problem, whether these spoutings"][[85 2 10] "are, after all, really water, or nothing but vapour--this is surely a"][[85 2 11] "noteworthy thing."][[85 3 1] "Let us, then, look at this matter, along with some interesting items"][[85 3 2] "contingent. Every one knows that by the peculiar cunning of their"][[85 3 3] "gills, the finny tribes in general breathe the air which at all times is"][[85 3 4] "combined with the element in which they swim; hence, a herring or a cod"][[85 3 5] "might live a century, and never once raise its head above the surface."][[85 3 6] "But owing to his marked internal structure which gives him regular"][[85 3 7] "lungs, like a human being's, the whale can only live by inhaling the"][[85 3 8] "disengaged air in the open atmosphere. Wherefore the necessity for"][[85 3 9] "his periodical visits to the upper world. But he cannot in any degree"][[85 3 10] "breathe through his mouth, for, in his ordinary attitude, the Sperm"][[85 3 11] "Whale's mouth is buried at least eight feet beneath the surface; and"][[85 3 12] "what is still more, his windpipe has no connexion with his mouth. No, he"][[85 3 13] "breathes through his spiracle alone; and this is on the top of his head."][[85 4 1] "If I say, that in any creature breathing is only a function"][[85 4 2] "indispensable to vitality, inasmuch as it withdraws from the air a"][[85 4 3] "certain element, which being subsequently brought into contact with the"][[85 4 4] "blood imparts to the blood its vivifying principle, I do not think I"][[85 4 5] "shall err; though I may possibly use some superfluous scientific words."][[85 4 6] "Assume it, and it follows that if all the blood in a man could be"][[85 4 7] "aerated with one breath, he might then seal up his nostrils and not"][[85 4 8] "fetch another for a considerable time. That is to say, he would then"][[85 4 9] "live without breathing. Anomalous as it may seem, this is precisely the"][[85 4 10] "case with the whale, who systematically lives, by intervals, his full"][[85 4 11] "hour and more (when at the bottom) without drawing a single breath, or"][[85 4 12] "so much as in any way inhaling a particle of air; for, remember, he has"][[85 4 13] "no gills. How is this? Between his ribs and on each side of his spine"][[85 4 14] "he is supplied with a remarkable involved Cretan labyrinth of"][[85 4 15] "vermicelli-like vessels, which vessels, when he quits the surface, are"][[85 4 16] "completely distended with oxygenated blood. So that for an hour or more,"][[85 4 17] "a thousand fathoms in the sea, he carries a surplus stock of vitality in"][[85 4 18] "him, just as the camel crossing the waterless desert carries a surplus"][[85 4 19] "supply of drink for future use in its four supplementary stomachs."][[85 4 20] "The anatomical fact of this labyrinth is indisputable; and that the"][[85 4 21] "supposition founded upon it is reasonable and true, seems the more"][[85 4 22] "cogent to me, when I consider the otherwise inexplicable obstinacy of"][[85 4 23] "that leviathan in HAVING HIS SPOUTINGS OUT, as the fishermen phrase"][[85 4 24] "it. This is what I mean. If unmolested, upon rising to the surface, the"][[85 4 25] "Sperm Whale will continue there for a period of time exactly uniform"][[85 4 26] "with all his other unmolested risings. Say he stays eleven minutes, and"][[85 4 27] "jets seventy times, that is, respires seventy breaths; then whenever he"][[85 4 28] "rises again, he will be sure to have his seventy breaths over again, to"][[85 4 29] "a minute. Now, if after he fetches a few breaths you alarm him, so that"][[85 4 30] "he sounds, he will be always dodging up again to make good his regular"][[85 4 31] "allowance of air. And not till those seventy breaths are told, will he"][[85 4 32] "finally go down to stay out his full term below. Remark, however, that"][[85 4 33] "in different individuals these rates are different; but in any one"][[85 4 34] "they are alike. Now, why should the whale thus insist upon having his"][[85 4 35] "spoutings out, unless it be to replenish his reservoir of air, ere"][[85 4 36] "descending for good? How obvious is it, too, that this necessity for the"][[85 4 37] "whale's rising exposes him to all the fatal hazards of the chase. For"][[85 4 38] "not by hook or by net could this vast leviathan be caught, when sailing"][[85 4 39] "a thousand fathoms beneath the sunlight. Not so much thy skill, then, O"][[85 4 40] "hunter, as the great necessities that strike the victory to thee!"][[85 5 1] "In man, breathing is incessantly going on--one breath only serving"][[85 5 2] "for two or three pulsations; so that whatever other business he has to"][[85 5 3] "attend to, waking or sleeping, breathe he must, or die he will. But the"][[85 5 4] "Sperm Whale only breathes about one seventh or Sunday of his time."][[85 6 1] "It has been said that the whale only breathes through his spout-hole; if"][[85 6 2] "it could truthfully be added that his spouts are mixed with water, then"][[85 6 3] "I opine we should be furnished with the reason why his sense of smell"][[85 6 4] "seems obliterated in him; for the only thing about him that at all"][[85 6 5] "answers to his nose is that identical spout-hole; and being so clogged"][[85 6 6] "with two elements, it could not be expected to have the power of"][[85 6 7] "smelling. But owing to the mystery of the spout--whether it be water or"][[85 6 8] "whether it be vapour--no absolute certainty can as yet be arrived at on"][[85 6 9] "this head. Sure it is, nevertheless, that the Sperm Whale has no proper"][[85 6 10] "olfactories. But what does he want of them? No roses, no violets, no"][[85 6 11] "Cologne-water in the sea."][[85 7 1] "Furthermore, as his windpipe solely opens into the tube of his spouting"][[85 7 2] "canal, and as that long canal--like the grand Erie Canal--is furnished"][[85 7 3] "with a sort of locks (that open and shut) for the downward retention of"][[85 7 4] "air or the upward exclusion of water, therefore the whale has no voice;"][[85 7 5] "unless you insult him by saying, that when he so strangely rumbles,"][[85 7 6] "he talks through his nose. But then again, what has the whale to say?"][[85 7 7] "Seldom have I known any profound being that had anything to say to"][[85 7 8] "this world, unless forced to stammer out something by way of getting a"][[85 7 9] "living. Oh! happy that the world is such an excellent listener!"][[85 8 1] "Now, the spouting canal of the Sperm Whale, chiefly intended as it"][[85 8 2] "is for the conveyance of air, and for several feet laid along,"][[85 8 3] "horizontally, just beneath the upper surface of his head, and a little"][[85 8 4] "to one side; this curious canal is very much like a gas-pipe laid down"][[85 8 5] "in a city on one side of a street. But the question returns whether this"][[85 8 6] "gas-pipe is also a water-pipe; in other words, whether the spout of the"][[85 8 7] "Sperm Whale is the mere vapour of the exhaled breath, or whether that"][[85 8 8] "exhaled breath is mixed with water taken in at the mouth, and"][[85 8 9] "discharged through the spiracle. It is certain that the mouth indirectly"][[85 8 10] "communicates with the spouting canal; but it cannot be proved that this"][[85 8 11] "is for the purpose of discharging water through the spiracle. Because"][[85 8 12] "the greatest necessity for so doing would seem to be, when in feeding he"][[85 8 13] "accidentally takes in water. But the Sperm Whale's food is far beneath"][[85 8 14] "the surface, and there he cannot spout even if he would. Besides, if"][[85 8 15] "you regard him very closely, and time him with your watch, you will find"][[85 8 16] "that when unmolested, there is an undeviating rhyme between the periods"][[85 8 17] "of his jets and the ordinary periods of respiration."][[85 9 1] "But why pester one with all this reasoning on the subject? Speak out!"][[85 9 2] "You have seen him spout; then declare what the spout is; can you not"][[85 9 3] "tell water from air? My dear sir, in this world it is not so easy to"][[85 9 4] "settle these plain things. I have ever found your plain things the"][[85 9 5] "knottiest of all. And as for this whale spout, you might almost stand in"][[85 9 6] "it, and yet be undecided as to what it is precisely."][[85 10 1] "The central body of it is hidden in the snowy sparkling mist enveloping"][[85 10 2] "it; and how can you certainly tell whether any water falls from it,"][[85 10 3] "when, always, when you are close enough to a whale to get a close view"][[85 10 4] "of his spout, he is in a prodigious commotion, the water cascading"][[85 10 5] "all around him. And if at such times you should think that you really"][[85 10 6] "perceived drops of moisture in the spout, how do you know that they are"][[85 10 7] "not merely condensed from its vapour; or how do you know that they"][[85 10 8] "are not those identical drops superficially lodged in the spout-hole"][[85 10 9] "fissure, which is countersunk into the summit of the whale's head? For"][[85 10 10] "even when tranquilly swimming through the mid-day sea in a calm, with"][[85 10 11] "his elevated hump sun-dried as a dromedary's in the desert; even then,"][[85 10 12] "the whale always carries a small basin of water on his head, as under"][[85 10 13] "a blazing sun you will sometimes see a cavity in a rock filled up with"][[85 10 14] "rain."][[85 11 1] "Nor is it at all prudent for the hunter to be over curious touching the"][[85 11 2] "precise nature of the whale spout. It will not do for him to be peering"][[85 11 3] "into it, and putting his face in it. You cannot go with your pitcher to"][[85 11 4] "this fountain and fill it, and bring it away. For even when coming into"][[85 11 5] "slight contact with the outer, vapoury shreds of the jet, which will"][[85 11 6] "often happen, your skin will feverishly smart, from the acridness of"][[85 11 7] "the thing so touching it. And I know one, who coming into still closer"][[85 11 8] "contact with the spout, whether with some scientific object in view,"][[85 11 9] "or otherwise, I cannot say, the skin peeled off from his cheek and arm."][[85 11 10] "Wherefore, among whalemen, the spout is deemed poisonous; they try to"][[85 11 11] "evade it. Another thing; I have heard it said, and I do not much doubt"][[85 11 12] "it, that if the jet is fairly spouted into your eyes, it will blind you."][[85 11 13] "The wisest thing the investigator can do then, it seems to me, is to let"][[85 11 14] "this deadly spout alone."][[85 12 1] "Still, we can hypothesize, even if we cannot prove and establish. My"][[85 12 2] "hypothesis is this: that the spout is nothing but mist. And besides"][[85 12 3] "other reasons, to this conclusion I am impelled, by considerations"][[85 12 4] "touching the great inherent dignity and sublimity of the Sperm Whale;"][[85 12 5] "I account him no common, shallow being, inasmuch as it is an undisputed"][[85 12 6] "fact that he is never found on soundings, or near shores; all other"][[85 12 7] "whales sometimes are. He is both ponderous and profound. And I am"][[85 12 8] "convinced that from the heads of all ponderous profound beings, such as"][[85 12 9] "Plato, Pyrrho, the Devil, Jupiter, Dante, and so on, there always goes"][[85 12 10] "up a certain semi-visible steam, while in the act of thinking deep"][[85 12 11] "thoughts. While composing a little treatise on Eternity, I had the"][[85 12 12] "curiosity to place a mirror before me; and ere long saw reflected there,"][[85 12 13] "a curious involved worming and undulation in the atmosphere over my"][[85 12 14] "head. The invariable moisture of my hair, while plunged in deep thought,"][[85 12 15] "after six cups of hot tea in my thin shingled attic, of an August noon;"][[85 12 16] "this seems an additional argument for the above supposition."][[85 13 1] "And how nobly it raises our conceit of the mighty, misty monster, to"][[85 13 2] "behold him solemnly sailing through a calm tropical sea; his vast, mild"][[85 13 3] "head overhung by a canopy of vapour, engendered by his incommunicable"][[85 13 4] "contemplations, and that vapour--as you will sometimes see it--glorified"][[85 13 5] "by a rainbow, as if Heaven itself had put its seal upon his thoughts."][[85 13 6] "For, d'ye see, rainbows do not visit the clear air; they only irradiate"][[85 13 7] "vapour. And so, through all the thick mists of the dim doubts in my"][[85 13 8] "mind, divine intuitions now and then shoot, enkindling my fog with a"][[85 13 9] "heavenly ray. And for this I thank God; for all have doubts; many deny;"][[85 13 10] "but doubts or denials, few along with them, have intuitions. Doubts"][[85 13 11] "of all things earthly, and intuitions of some things heavenly; this"][[85 13 12] "combination makes neither believer nor infidel, but makes a man who"][[85 13 13] "regards them both with equal eye."][[86 0 0] "CHAPTER 86. The Tail."][[86 2 1] "Other poets have warbled the praises of the soft eye of the antelope,"][[86 2 2] "and the lovely plumage of the bird that never alights; less celestial, I"][[86 2 3] "celebrate a tail."][[86 3 1] "Reckoning the largest sized Sperm Whale's tail to begin at that point of"][[86 3 2] "the trunk where it tapers to about the girth of a man, it comprises"][[86 3 3] "upon its upper surface alone, an area of at least fifty square feet. The"][[86 3 4] "compact round body of its root expands into two broad, firm, flat palms"][[86 3 5] "or flukes, gradually shoaling away to less than an inch in thickness."][[86 3 6] "At the crotch or junction, these flukes slightly overlap, then sideways"][[86 3 7] "recede from each other like wings, leaving a wide vacancy between. In"][[86 3 8] "no living thing are the lines of beauty more exquisitely defined than in"][[86 3 9] "the crescentic borders of these flukes. At its utmost expansion in the"][[86 3 10] "full grown whale, the tail will considerably exceed twenty feet across."][[86 4 1] "The entire member seems a dense webbed bed of welded sinews; but cut"][[86 4 2] "into it, and you find that three distinct strata compose it:--upper,"][[86 4 3] "middle, and lower. The fibres in the upper and lower layers, are"][[86 4 4] "long and horizontal; those of the middle one, very short, and running"][[86 4 5] "crosswise between the outside layers. This triune structure, as much as"][[86 4 6] "anything else, imparts power to the tail. To the student of old Roman"][[86 4 7] "walls, the middle layer will furnish a curious parallel to the thin"][[86 4 8] "course of tiles always alternating with the stone in those wonderful"][[86 4 9] "relics of the antique, and which undoubtedly contribute so much to the"][[86 4 10] "great strength of the masonry."][[86 5 1] "But as if this vast local power in the tendinous tail were not enough,"][[86 5 2] "the whole bulk of the leviathan is knit over with a warp and woof of"][[86 5 3] "muscular fibres and filaments, which passing on either side the loins"][[86 5 4] "and running down into the flukes, insensibly blend with them, and"][[86 5 5] "largely contribute to their might; so that in the tail the confluent"][[86 5 6] "measureless force of the whole whale seems concentrated to a point."][[86 5 7] "Could annihilation occur to matter, this were the thing to do it."][[86 6 1] "Nor does this--its amazing strength, at all tend to cripple the graceful"][[86 6 2] "flexion of its motions; where infantileness of ease undulates through"][[86 6 3] "a Titanism of power. On the contrary, those motions derive their most"][[86 6 4] "appalling beauty from it. Real strength never impairs beauty or harmony,"][[86 6 5] "but it often bestows it; and in everything imposingly beautiful,"][[86 6 6] "strength has much to do with the magic. Take away the tied tendons that"][[86 6 7] "all over seem bursting from the marble in the carved Hercules, and its"][[86 6 8] "charm would be gone. As devout Eckerman lifted the linen sheet from the"][[86 6 9] "naked corpse of Goethe, he was overwhelmed with the massive chest of the"][[86 6 10] "man, that seemed as a Roman triumphal arch. When Angelo paints even God"][[86 6 11] "the Father in human form, mark what robustness is there. And whatever"][[86 6 12] "they may reveal of the divine love in the Son, the soft, curled,"][[86 6 13] "hermaphroditical Italian pictures, in which his idea has been most"][[86 6 14] "successfully embodied; these pictures, so destitute as they are of all"][[86 6 15] "brawniness, hint nothing of any power, but the mere negative, feminine"][[86 6 16] "one of submission and endurance, which on all hands it is conceded, form"][[86 6 17] "the peculiar practical virtues of his teachings."][[86 7 1] "Such is the subtle elasticity of the organ I treat of, that whether"][[86 7 2] "wielded in sport, or in earnest, or in anger, whatever be the mood it"][[86 7 3] "be in, its flexions are invariably marked by exceeding grace. Therein no"][[86 7 4] "fairy's arm can transcend it."][[86 8 1] "Five great motions are peculiar to it. First, when used as a fin for"][[86 8 2] "progression; Second, when used as a mace in battle; Third, in sweeping;"][[86 8 3] "Fourth, in lobtailing; Fifth, in peaking flukes."][[86 9 1] "First: Being horizontal in its position, the Leviathan's tail acts in"][[86 9 2] "a different manner from the tails of all other sea creatures. It never"][[86 9 3] "wriggles. In man or fish, wriggling is a sign of inferiority. To the"][[86 9 4] "whale, his tail is the sole means of propulsion. Scroll-wise coiled"][[86 9 5] "forwards beneath the body, and then rapidly sprung backwards, it is this"][[86 9 6] "which gives that singular darting, leaping motion to the monster when"][[86 9 7] "furiously swimming. His side-fins only serve to steer by."][[86 10 1] "Second: It is a little significant, that while one sperm whale only"][[86 10 2] "fights another sperm whale with his head and jaw, nevertheless, in his"][[86 10 3] "conflicts with man, he chiefly and contemptuously uses his tail. In"][[86 10 4] "striking at a boat, he swiftly curves away his flukes from it, and the"][[86 10 5] "blow is only inflicted by the recoil. If it be made in the unobstructed"][[86 10 6] "air, especially if it descend to its mark, the stroke is then simply"][[86 10 7] "irresistible. No ribs of man or boat can withstand it. Your only"][[86 10 8] "salvation lies in eluding it; but if it comes sideways through the"][[86 10 9] "opposing water, then partly owing to the light buoyancy of the whale"][[86 10 10] "boat, and the elasticity of its materials, a cracked rib or a dashed"][[86 10 11] "plank or two, a sort of stitch in the side, is generally the most"][[86 10 12] "serious result. These submerged side blows are so often received in the"][[86 10 13] "fishery, that they are accounted mere child's play. Some one strips off"][[86 10 14] "a frock, and the hole is stopped."][[86 11 1] "Third: I cannot demonstrate it, but it seems to me, that in the whale"][[86 11 2] "the sense of touch is concentrated in the tail; for in this respect"][[86 11 3] "there is a delicacy in it only equalled by the daintiness of the"][[86 11 4] "elephant's trunk. This delicacy is chiefly evinced in the action of"][[86 11 5] "sweeping, when in maidenly gentleness the whale with a certain soft"][[86 11 6] "slowness moves his immense flukes from side to side upon the surface"][[86 11 7] "of the sea; and if he feel but a sailor's whisker, woe to that sailor,"][[86 11 8] "whiskers and all. What tenderness there is in that preliminary touch!"][[86 11 9] "Had this tail any prehensile power, I should straightway bethink me of"][[86 11 10] "Darmonodes' elephant that so frequented the flower-market, and with"][[86 11 11] "low salutations presented nosegays to damsels, and then caressed their"][[86 11 12] "zones. On more accounts than one, a pity it is that the whale does not"][[86 11 13] "possess this prehensile virtue in his tail; for I have heard of yet"][[86 11 14] "another elephant, that when wounded in the fight, curved round his trunk"][[86 11 15] "and extracted the dart."][[86 12 1] "Fourth: Stealing unawares upon the whale in the fancied security of the"][[86 12 2] "middle of solitary seas, you find him unbent from the vast corpulence"][[86 12 3] "of his dignity, and kitten-like, he plays on the ocean as if it were a"][[86 12 4] "hearth. But still you see his power in his play. The broad palms of"][[86 12 5] "his tail are flirted high into the air; then smiting the surface, the"][[86 12 6] "thunderous concussion resounds for miles. You would almost think a great"][[86 12 7] "gun had been discharged; and if you noticed the light wreath of vapour"][[86 12 8] "from the spiracle at his other extremity, you would think that that was"][[86 12 9] "the smoke from the touch-hole."][[86 13 1] "Fifth: As in the ordinary floating posture of the leviathan the flukes"][[86 13 2] "lie considerably below the level of his back, they are then completely"][[86 13 3] "out of sight beneath the surface; but when he is about to plunge into"][[86 13 4] "the deeps, his entire flukes with at least thirty feet of his body are"][[86 13 5] "tossed erect in the air, and so remain vibrating a moment, till they"][[86 13 6] "downwards shoot out of view. Excepting the sublime BREACH--somewhere"][[86 13 7] "else to be described--this peaking of the whale's flukes is perhaps the"][[86 13 8] "grandest sight to be seen in all animated nature. Out of the bottomless"][[86 13 9] "profundities the gigantic tail seems spasmodically snatching at the"][[86 13 10] "highest heaven. So in dreams, have I seen majestic Satan thrusting forth"][[86 13 11] "his tormented colossal claw from the flame Baltic of Hell. But in"][[86 13 12] "gazing at such scenes, it is all in all what mood you are in; if in"][[86 13 13] "the Dantean, the devils will occur to you; if in that of Isaiah, the"][[86 13 14] "archangels. Standing at the mast-head of my ship during a sunrise that"][[86 13 15] "crimsoned sky and sea, I once saw a large herd of whales in the east,"][[86 13 16] "all heading towards the sun, and for a moment vibrating in concert with"][[86 13 17] "peaked flukes. As it seemed to me at the time, such a grand embodiment"][[86 13 18] "of adoration of the gods was never beheld, even in Persia, the home of"][[86 13 19] "the fire worshippers. As Ptolemy Philopater testified of the African"][[86 13 20] "elephant, I then testified of the whale, pronouncing him the most devout"][[86 13 21] "of all beings. For according to King Juba, the military elephants of"][[86 13 22] "antiquity often hailed the morning with their trunks uplifted in the"][[86 13 23] "profoundest silence."][[86 14 1] "The chance comparison in this chapter, between the whale and the"][[86 14 2] "elephant, so far as some aspects of the tail of the one and the trunk"][[86 14 3] "of the other are concerned, should not tend to place those two"][[86 14 4] "opposite organs on an equality, much less the creatures to which they"][[86 14 5] "respectively belong. For as the mightiest elephant is but a terrier"][[86 14 6] "to Leviathan, so, compared with Leviathan's tail, his trunk is but the"][[86 14 7] "stalk of a lily. The most direful blow from the elephant's trunk were as"][[86 14 8] "the playful tap of a fan, compared with the measureless crush and crash"][[86 14 9] "of the sperm whale's ponderous flukes, which in repeated instances have"][[86 14 10] "one after the other hurled entire boats with all their oars and crews"][[86 14 11] "into the air, very much as an Indian juggler tosses his balls.*"][[86 16 1] "*Though all comparison in the way of general bulk between the whale"][[86 16 2] "and the elephant is preposterous, inasmuch as in that particular the"][[86 16 3] "elephant stands in much the same respect to the whale that a dog does to"][[86 16 4] "the elephant; nevertheless, there are not wanting some points of curious"][[86 16 5] "similitude; among these is the spout. It is well known that the elephant"][[86 16 6] "will often draw up water or dust in his trunk, and then elevating it,"][[86 16 7] "jet it forth in a stream."][[86 18 1] "The more I consider this mighty tail, the more do I deplore my inability"][[86 18 2] "to express it. At times there are gestures in it, which, though they"][[86 18 3] "would well grace the hand of man, remain wholly inexplicable. In an"][[86 18 4] "extensive herd, so remarkable, occasionally, are these mystic gestures,"][[86 18 5] "that I have heard hunters who have declared them akin to Free-Mason"][[86 18 6] "signs and symbols; that the whale, indeed, by these methods"][[86 18 7] "intelligently conversed with the world. Nor are there wanting other"][[86 18 8] "motions of the whale in his general body, full of strangeness, and"][[86 18 9] "unaccountable to his most experienced assailant. Dissect him how I may,"][[86 18 10] "then, I but go skin deep; I know him not, and never will. But if I know"][[86 18 11] "not even the tail of this whale, how understand his head? much more,"][[86 18 12] "how comprehend his face, when face he has none? Thou shalt see my back"][[86 18 13] "parts, my tail, he seems to say, but my face shall not be seen. But I"][[86 18 14] "cannot completely make out his back parts; and hint what he will about"][[86 18 15] "his face, I say again he has no face."][[87 0 0] "CHAPTER 87. The Grand Armada."][[87 2 1] "The long and narrow peninsula of Malacca, extending south-eastward from"][[87 2 2] "the territories of Birmah, forms the most southerly point of all Asia."][[87 2 3] "In a continuous line from that peninsula stretch the long islands of"][[87 2 4] "Sumatra, Java, Bally, and Timor; which, with many others, form a"][[87 2 5] "vast mole, or rampart, lengthwise connecting Asia with Australia,"][[87 2 6] "and dividing the long unbroken Indian ocean from the thickly studded"][[87 2 7] "oriental archipelagoes. This rampart is pierced by several sally-ports"][[87 2 8] "for the convenience of ships and whales; conspicuous among which are the"][[87 2 9] "straits of Sunda and Malacca. By the straits of Sunda, chiefly, vessels"][[87 2 10] "bound to China from the west, emerge into the China seas."][[87 3 1] "Those narrow straits of Sunda divide Sumatra from Java; and standing"][[87 3 2] "midway in that vast rampart of islands, buttressed by that bold green"][[87 3 3] "promontory, known to seamen as Java Head; they not a little correspond"][[87 3 4] "to the central gateway opening into some vast walled empire: and"][[87 3 5] "considering the inexhaustible wealth of spices, and silks, and jewels,"][[87 3 6] "and gold, and ivory, with which the thousand islands of that oriental"][[87 3 7] "sea are enriched, it seems a significant provision of nature, that such"][[87 3 8] "treasures, by the very formation of the land, should at least bear the"][[87 3 9] "appearance, however ineffectual, of being guarded from the all-grasping"][[87 3 10] "western world. The shores of the Straits of Sunda are unsupplied"][[87 3 11] "with those domineering fortresses which guard the entrances to the"][[87 3 12] "Mediterranean, the Baltic, and the Propontis. Unlike the Danes, these"][[87 3 13] "Orientals do not demand the obsequious homage of lowered top-sails from"][[87 3 14] "the endless procession of ships before the wind, which for centuries"][[87 3 15] "past, by night and by day, have passed between the islands of Sumatra"][[87 3 16] "and Java, freighted with the costliest cargoes of the east. But while"][[87 3 17] "they freely waive a ceremonial like this, they do by no means renounce"][[87 3 18] "their claim to more solid tribute."][[87 4 1] "Time out of mind the piratical proas of the Malays, lurking among"][[87 4 2] "the low shaded coves and islets of Sumatra, have sallied out upon the"][[87 4 3] "vessels sailing through the straits, fiercely demanding tribute at the"][[87 4 4] "point of their spears. Though by the repeated bloody chastisements they"][[87 4 5] "have received at the hands of European cruisers, the audacity of these"][[87 4 6] "corsairs has of late been somewhat repressed; yet, even at the present"][[87 4 7] "day, we occasionally hear of English and American vessels, which, in"][[87 4 8] "those waters, have been remorselessly boarded and pillaged."][[87 5 1] "With a fair, fresh wind, the Pequod was now drawing nigh to these"][[87 5 2] "straits; Ahab purposing to pass through them into the Javan sea, and"][[87 5 3] "thence, cruising northwards, over waters known to be frequented here and"][[87 5 4] "there by the Sperm Whale, sweep inshore by the Philippine Islands, and"][[87 5 5] "gain the far coast of Japan, in time for the great whaling season there."][[87 5 6] "By these means, the circumnavigating Pequod would sweep almost all the"][[87 5 7] "known Sperm Whale cruising grounds of the world, previous to descending"][[87 5 8] "upon the Line in the Pacific; where Ahab, though everywhere else foiled"][[87 5 9] "in his pursuit, firmly counted upon giving battle to Moby Dick, in the"][[87 5 10] "sea he was most known to frequent; and at a season when he might most"][[87 5 11] "reasonably be presumed to be haunting it."][[87 6 1] "But how now? in this zoned quest, does Ahab touch no land? does his crew"][[87 6 2] "drink air? Surely, he will stop for water. Nay. For a long time, now,"][[87 6 3] "the circus-running sun has raced within his fiery ring, and needs"][[87 6 4] "no sustenance but what's in himself. So Ahab. Mark this, too, in the"][[87 6 5] "whaler. While other hulls are loaded down with alien stuff, to be"][[87 6 6] "transferred to foreign wharves; the world-wandering whale-ship carries"][[87 6 7] "no cargo but herself and crew, their weapons and their wants. She has a"][[87 6 8] "whole lake's contents bottled in her ample hold. She is ballasted with"][[87 6 9] "utilities; not altogether with unusable pig-lead and kentledge. She"][[87 6 10] "carries years' water in her. Clear old prime Nantucket water; which,"][[87 6 11] "when three years afloat, the Nantucketer, in the Pacific, prefers to"][[87 6 12] "drink before the brackish fluid, but yesterday rafted off in casks, from"][[87 6 13] "the Peruvian or Indian streams. Hence it is, that, while other ships may"][[87 6 14] "have gone to China from New York, and back again, touching at a score"][[87 6 15] "of ports, the whale-ship, in all that interval, may not have sighted"][[87 6 16] "one grain of soil; her crew having seen no man but floating seamen like"][[87 6 17] "themselves. So that did you carry them the news that another flood had"][[87 6 18] "come; they would only answer--\"Well, boys, here's the ark!\""][[87 7 1] "Now, as many Sperm Whales had been captured off the western coast of"][[87 7 2] "Java, in the near vicinity of the Straits of Sunda; indeed, as most of"][[87 7 3] "the ground, roundabout, was generally recognised by the fishermen as an"][[87 7 4] "excellent spot for cruising; therefore, as the Pequod gained more"][[87 7 5] "and more upon Java Head, the look-outs were repeatedly hailed, and"][[87 7 6] "admonished to keep wide awake. But though the green palmy cliffs of the"][[87 7 7] "land soon loomed on the starboard bow, and with delighted nostrils"][[87 7 8] "the fresh cinnamon was snuffed in the air, yet not a single jet was"][[87 7 9] "descried. Almost renouncing all thought of falling in with any game"][[87 7 10] "hereabouts, the ship had well nigh entered the straits, when the"][[87 7 11] "customary cheering cry was heard from aloft, and ere long a spectacle of"][[87 7 12] "singular magnificence saluted us."][[87 8 1] "But here be it premised, that owing to the unwearied activity with which"][[87 8 2] "of late they have been hunted over all four oceans, the Sperm Whales,"][[87 8 3] "instead of almost invariably sailing in small detached companies, as in"][[87 8 4] "former times, are now frequently met with in extensive herds, sometimes"][[87 8 5] "embracing so great a multitude, that it would almost seem as if"][[87 8 6] "numerous nations of them had sworn solemn league and covenant for mutual"][[87 8 7] "assistance and protection. To this aggregation of the Sperm Whale into"][[87 8 8] "such immense caravans, may be imputed the circumstance that even in the"][[87 8 9] "best cruising grounds, you may now sometimes sail for weeks and months"][[87 8 10] "together, without being greeted by a single spout; and then be suddenly"][[87 8 11] "saluted by what sometimes seems thousands on thousands."][[87 9 1] "Broad on both bows, at the distance of some two or three miles, and"][[87 9 2] "forming a great semicircle, embracing one half of the level horizon,"][[87 9 3] "a continuous chain of whale-jets were up-playing and sparkling in the"][[87 9 4] "noon-day air. Unlike the straight perpendicular twin-jets of the Right"][[87 9 5] "Whale, which, dividing at top, fall over in two branches, like the cleft"][[87 9 6] "drooping boughs of a willow, the single forward-slanting spout of the"][[87 9 7] "Sperm Whale presents a thick curled bush of white mist, continually"][[87 9 8] "rising and falling away to leeward."][[87 10 1] "Seen from the Pequod's deck, then, as she would rise on a high hill of"][[87 10 2] "the sea, this host of vapoury spouts, individually curling up into the"][[87 10 3] "air, and beheld through a blending atmosphere of bluish haze, showed"][[87 10 4] "like the thousand cheerful chimneys of some dense metropolis, descried"][[87 10 5] "of a balmy autumnal morning, by some horseman on a height."][[87 11 1] "As marching armies approaching an unfriendly defile in the mountains,"][[87 11 2] "accelerate their march, all eagerness to place that perilous passage in"][[87 11 3] "their rear, and once more expand in comparative security upon the plain;"][[87 11 4] "even so did this vast fleet of whales now seem hurrying forward through"][[87 11 5] "the straits; gradually contracting the wings of their semicircle, and"][[87 11 6] "swimming on, in one solid, but still crescentic centre."][[87 12 1] "Crowding all sail the Pequod pressed after them; the harpooneers"][[87 12 2] "handling their weapons, and loudly cheering from the heads of their"][[87 12 3] "yet suspended boats. If the wind only held, little doubt had they, that"][[87 12 4] "chased through these Straits of Sunda, the vast host would only deploy"][[87 12 5] "into the Oriental seas to witness the capture of not a few of their"][[87 12 6] "number. And who could tell whether, in that congregated caravan, Moby"][[87 12 7] "Dick himself might not temporarily be swimming, like the worshipped"][[87 12 8] "white-elephant in the coronation procession of the Siamese! So with"][[87 12 9] "stun-sail piled on stun-sail, we sailed along, driving these leviathans"][[87 12 10] "before us; when, of a sudden, the voice of Tashtego was heard, loudly"][[87 12 11] "directing attention to something in our wake."][[87 13 1] "Corresponding to the crescent in our van, we beheld another in our rear."][[87 13 2] "It seemed formed of detached white vapours, rising and falling something"][[87 13 3] "like the spouts of the whales; only they did not so completely come and"][[87 13 4] "go; for they constantly hovered, without finally disappearing. Levelling"][[87 13 5] "his glass at this sight, Ahab quickly revolved in his pivot-hole,"][[87 13 6] "crying, \"Aloft there, and rig whips and buckets to wet the"][[87 13 7] "sails;--Malays, sir, and after us!\""][[87 14 1] "As if too long lurking behind the headlands, till the Pequod should"][[87 14 2] "fairly have entered the straits, these rascally Asiatics were now in hot"][[87 14 3] "pursuit, to make up for their over-cautious delay. But when the swift"][[87 14 4] "Pequod, with a fresh leading wind, was herself in hot chase; how very"][[87 14 5] "kind of these tawny philanthropists to assist in speeding her on to"][[87 14 6] "her own chosen pursuit,--mere riding-whips and rowels to her, that they"][[87 14 7] "were. As with glass under arm, Ahab to-and-fro paced the deck; in his"][[87 14 8] "forward turn beholding the monsters he chased, and in the after one the"][[87 14 9] "bloodthirsty pirates chasing him; some such fancy as the above seemed"][[87 14 10] "his. And when he glanced upon the green walls of the watery defile in"][[87 14 11] "which the ship was then sailing, and bethought him that through that"][[87 14 12] "gate lay the route to his vengeance, and beheld, how that through that"][[87 14 13] "same gate he was now both chasing and being chased to his deadly end;"][[87 14 14] "and not only that, but a herd of remorseless wild pirates and"][[87 14 15] "inhuman atheistical devils were infernally cheering him on with their"][[87 14 16] "curses;--when all these conceits had passed through his brain, Ahab's"][[87 14 17] "brow was left gaunt and ribbed, like the black sand beach after some"][[87 14 18] "stormy tide has been gnawing it, without being able to drag the firm"][[87 14 19] "thing from its place."][[87 15 1] "But thoughts like these troubled very few of the reckless crew; and"][[87 15 2] "when, after steadily dropping and dropping the pirates astern, the"][[87 15 3] "Pequod at last shot by the vivid green Cockatoo Point on the Sumatra"][[87 15 4] "side, emerging at last upon the broad waters beyond; then, the"][[87 15 5] "harpooneers seemed more to grieve that the swift whales had been gaining"][[87 15 6] "upon the ship, than to rejoice that the ship had so victoriously gained"][[87 15 7] "upon the Malays. But still driving on in the wake of the whales, at"][[87 15 8] "length they seemed abating their speed; gradually the ship neared them;"][[87 15 9] "and the wind now dying away, word was passed to spring to the boats. But"][[87 15 10] "no sooner did the herd, by some presumed wonderful instinct of the Sperm"][[87 15 11] "Whale, become notified of the three keels that were after them,--though"][[87 15 12] "as yet a mile in their rear,--than they rallied again, and forming"][[87 15 13] "in close ranks and battalions, so that their spouts all looked like"][[87 15 14] "flashing lines of stacked bayonets, moved on with redoubled velocity."][[87 16 1] "Stripped to our shirts and drawers, we sprang to the white-ash, and"][[87 16 2] "after several hours' pulling were almost disposed to renounce the chase,"][[87 16 3] "when a general pausing commotion among the whales gave animating"][[87 16 4] "token that they were now at last under the influence of that strange"][[87 16 5] "perplexity of inert irresolution, which, when the fishermen perceive"][[87 16 6] "it in the whale, they say he is gallied. The compact martial columns"][[87 16 7] "in which they had been hitherto rapidly and steadily swimming, were now"][[87 16 8] "broken up in one measureless rout; and like King Porus' elephants in the"][[87 16 9] "Indian battle with Alexander, they seemed going mad with consternation."][[87 16 10] "In all directions expanding in vast irregular circles, and aimlessly"][[87 16 11] "swimming hither and thither, by their short thick spoutings, they"][[87 16 12] "plainly betrayed their distraction of panic. This was still more"][[87 16 13] "strangely evinced by those of their number, who, completely paralysed"][[87 16 14] "as it were, helplessly floated like water-logged dismantled ships on the"][[87 16 15] "sea. Had these Leviathans been but a flock of simple sheep, pursued over"][[87 16 16] "the pasture by three fierce wolves, they could not possibly have evinced"][[87 16 17] "such excessive dismay. But this occasional timidity is characteristic"][[87 16 18] "of almost all herding creatures. Though banding together in tens of"][[87 16 19] "thousands, the lion-maned buffaloes of the West have fled before a"][[87 16 20] "solitary horseman. Witness, too, all human beings, how when herded"][[87 16 21] "together in the sheepfold of a theatre's pit, they will, at the"][[87 16 22] "slightest alarm of fire, rush helter-skelter for the outlets, crowding,"][[87 16 23] "trampling, jamming, and remorselessly dashing each other to death. Best,"][[87 16 24] "therefore, withhold any amazement at the strangely gallied whales"][[87 16 25] "before us, for there is no folly of the beasts of the earth which is not"][[87 16 26] "infinitely outdone by the madness of men."][[87 17 1] "Though many of the whales, as has been said, were in violent motion,"][[87 17 2] "yet it is to be observed that as a whole the herd neither advanced nor"][[87 17 3] "retreated, but collectively remained in one place. As is customary in"][[87 17 4] "those cases, the boats at once separated, each making for some one"][[87 17 5] "lone whale on the outskirts of the shoal. In about three minutes' time,"][[87 17 6] "Queequeg's harpoon was flung; the stricken fish darted blinding spray"][[87 17 7] "in our faces, and then running away with us like light, steered straight"][[87 17 8] "for the heart of the herd. Though such a movement on the part of the"][[87 17 9] "whale struck under such circumstances, is in no wise unprecedented; and"][[87 17 10] "indeed is almost always more or less anticipated; yet does it present"][[87 17 11] "one of the more perilous vicissitudes of the fishery. For as the swift"][[87 17 12] "monster drags you deeper and deeper into the frantic shoal, you bid"][[87 17 13] "adieu to circumspect life and only exist in a delirious throb."][[87 18 1] "As, blind and deaf, the whale plunged forward, as if by sheer power of"][[87 18 2] "speed to rid himself of the iron leech that had fastened to him; as we"][[87 18 3] "thus tore a white gash in the sea, on all sides menaced as we flew, by"][[87 18 4] "the crazed creatures to and fro rushing about us; our beset boat was"][[87 18 5] "like a ship mobbed by ice-isles in a tempest, and striving to steer"][[87 18 6] "through their complicated channels and straits, knowing not at what"][[87 18 7] "moment it may be locked in and crushed."][[87 19 1] "But not a bit daunted, Queequeg steered us manfully; now sheering off"][[87 19 2] "from this monster directly across our route in advance; now edging away"][[87 19 3] "from that, whose colossal flukes were suspended overhead, while all the"][[87 19 4] "time, Starbuck stood up in the bows, lance in hand, pricking out of our"][[87 19 5] "way whatever whales he could reach by short darts, for there was no time"][[87 19 6] "to make long ones. Nor were the oarsmen quite idle, though their wonted"][[87 19 7] "duty was now altogether dispensed with. They chiefly attended to the"][[87 19 8] "shouting part of the business. \"Out of the way, Commodore!\" cried one,"][[87 19 9] "to a great dromedary that of a sudden rose bodily to the surface,"][[87 19 10] "and for an instant threatened to swamp us. \"Hard down with your tail,"][[87 19 11] "there!\" cried a second to another, which, close to our gunwale, seemed"][[87 19 12] "calmly cooling himself with his own fan-like extremity."][[87 20 1] "All whaleboats carry certain curious contrivances, originally invented"][[87 20 2] "by the Nantucket Indians, called druggs. Two thick squares of wood"][[87 20 3] "of equal size are stoutly clenched together, so that they cross each"][[87 20 4] "other's grain at right angles; a line of considerable length is then"][[87 20 5] "attached to the middle of this block, and the other end of the line"][[87 20 6] "being looped, it can in a moment be fastened to a harpoon. It is chiefly"][[87 20 7] "among gallied whales that this drugg is used. For then, more whales"][[87 20 8] "are close round you than you can possibly chase at one time. But sperm"][[87 20 9] "whales are not every day encountered; while you may, then, you must"][[87 20 10] "kill all you can. And if you cannot kill them all at once, you must wing"][[87 20 11] "them, so that they can be afterwards killed at your leisure. Hence it"][[87 20 12] "is, that at times like these the drugg, comes into requisition. Our boat"][[87 20 13] "was furnished with three of them. The first and second were successfully"][[87 20 14] "darted, and we saw the whales staggeringly running off, fettered by the"][[87 20 15] "enormous sidelong resistance of the towing drugg. They were cramped like"][[87 20 16] "malefactors with the chain and ball. But upon flinging the third, in the"][[87 20 17] "act of tossing overboard the clumsy wooden block, it caught under one"][[87 20 18] "of the seats of the boat, and in an instant tore it out and carried it"][[87 20 19] "away, dropping the oarsman in the boat's bottom as the seat slid from"][[87 20 20] "under him. On both sides the sea came in at the wounded planks, but we"][[87 20 21] "stuffed two or three drawers and shirts in, and so stopped the leaks for"][[87 20 22] "the time."][[87 21 1] "It had been next to impossible to dart these drugged-harpoons, were"][[87 21 2] "it not that as we advanced into the herd, our whale's way greatly"][[87 21 3] "diminished; moreover, that as we went still further and further from the"][[87 21 4] "circumference of commotion, the direful disorders seemed waning. So that"][[87 21 5] "when at last the jerking harpoon drew out, and the towing whale sideways"][[87 21 6] "vanished; then, with the tapering force of his parting momentum, we"][[87 21 7] "glided between two whales into the innermost heart of the shoal, as if"][[87 21 8] "from some mountain torrent we had slid into a serene valley lake. Here"][[87 21 9] "the storms in the roaring glens between the outermost whales, were heard"][[87 21 10] "but not felt. In this central expanse the sea presented that smooth"][[87 21 11] "satin-like surface, called a sleek, produced by the subtle moisture"][[87 21 12] "thrown off by the whale in his more quiet moods. Yes, we were now"][[87 21 13] "in that enchanted calm which they say lurks at the heart of every"][[87 21 14] "commotion. And still in the distracted distance we beheld the tumults of"][[87 21 15] "the outer concentric circles, and saw successive pods of whales, eight"][[87 21 16] "or ten in each, swiftly going round and round, like multiplied spans of"][[87 21 17] "horses in a ring; and so closely shoulder to shoulder, that a Titanic"][[87 21 18] "circus-rider might easily have over-arched the middle ones, and so have"][[87 21 19] "gone round on their backs. Owing to the density of the crowd of reposing"][[87 21 20] "whales, more immediately surrounding the embayed axis of the herd, no"][[87 21 21] "possible chance of escape was at present afforded us. We must watch for"][[87 21 22] "a breach in the living wall that hemmed us in; the wall that had only"][[87 21 23] "admitted us in order to shut us up. Keeping at the centre of the lake,"][[87 21 24] "we were occasionally visited by small tame cows and calves; the women"][[87 21 25] "and children of this routed host."][[87 22 1] "Now, inclusive of the occasional wide intervals between the revolving"][[87 22 2] "outer circles, and inclusive of the spaces between the various pods in"][[87 22 3] "any one of those circles, the entire area at this juncture, embraced by"][[87 22 4] "the whole multitude, must have contained at least two or three square"][[87 22 5] "miles. At any rate--though indeed such a test at such a time might be"][[87 22 6] "deceptive--spoutings might be discovered from our low boat that"][[87 22 7] "seemed playing up almost from the rim of the horizon. I mention this"][[87 22 8] "circumstance, because, as if the cows and calves had been purposely"][[87 22 9] "locked up in this innermost fold; and as if the wide extent of the"][[87 22 10] "herd had hitherto prevented them from learning the precise cause of its"][[87 22 11] "stopping; or, possibly, being so young, unsophisticated, and every way"][[87 22 12] "innocent and inexperienced; however it may have been, these smaller"][[87 22 13] "whales--now and then visiting our becalmed boat from the margin of the"][[87 22 14] "lake--evinced a wondrous fearlessness and confidence, or else a still"][[87 22 15] "becharmed panic which it was impossible not to marvel at. Like household"][[87 22 16] "dogs they came snuffling round us, right up to our gunwales, and"][[87 22 17] "touching them; till it almost seemed that some spell had suddenly"][[87 22 18] "domesticated them. Queequeg patted their foreheads; Starbuck scratched"][[87 22 19] "their backs with his lance; but fearful of the consequences, for the"][[87 22 20] "time refrained from darting it."][[87 23 1] "But far beneath this wondrous world upon the surface, another and still"][[87 23 2] "stranger world met our eyes as we gazed over the side. For, suspended"][[87 23 3] "in those watery vaults, floated the forms of the nursing mothers of the"][[87 23 4] "whales, and those that by their enormous girth seemed shortly to"][[87 23 5] "become mothers. The lake, as I have hinted, was to a considerable depth"][[87 23 6] "exceedingly transparent; and as human infants while suckling will calmly"][[87 23 7] "and fixedly gaze away from the breast, as if leading two different"][[87 23 8] "lives at the time; and while yet drawing mortal nourishment, be still"][[87 23 9] "spiritually feasting upon some unearthly reminiscence;--even so did the"][[87 23 10] "young of these whales seem looking up towards us, but not at us, as if"][[87 23 11] "we were but a bit of Gulfweed in their new-born sight. Floating on their"][[87 23 12] "sides, the mothers also seemed quietly eyeing us. One of these little"][[87 23 13] "infants, that from certain queer tokens seemed hardly a day old, might"][[87 23 14] "have measured some fourteen feet in length, and some six feet in"][[87 23 15] "girth. He was a little frisky; though as yet his body seemed scarce yet"][[87 23 16] "recovered from that irksome position it had so lately occupied in the"][[87 23 17] "maternal reticule; where, tail to head, and all ready for the final"][[87 23 18] "spring, the unborn whale lies bent like a Tartar's bow. The delicate"][[87 23 19] "side-fins, and the palms of his flukes, still freshly retained the"][[87 23 20] "plaited crumpled appearance of a baby's ears newly arrived from foreign"][[87 23 21] "parts."][[87 24 1] "\"Line! line!\" cried Queequeg, looking over the gunwale; \"him fast! him"][[87 24 2] "fast!--Who line him! Who struck?--Two whale; one big, one little!\""][[87 25 1] "\"What ails ye, man?\" cried Starbuck."][[87 26 1] "\"Look-e here,\" said Queequeg, pointing down."][[87 27 1] "As when the stricken whale, that from the tub has reeled out hundreds of"][[87 27 2] "fathoms of rope; as, after deep sounding, he floats up again, and shows"][[87 27 3] "the slackened curling line buoyantly rising and spiralling towards the"][[87 27 4] "air; so now, Starbuck saw long coils of the umbilical cord of Madame"][[87 27 5] "Leviathan, by which the young cub seemed still tethered to its dam. Not"][[87 27 6] "seldom in the rapid vicissitudes of the chase, this natural line, with"][[87 27 7] "the maternal end loose, becomes entangled with the hempen one, so that"][[87 27 8] "the cub is thereby trapped. Some of the subtlest secrets of the seas"][[87 27 9] "seemed divulged to us in this enchanted pond. We saw young Leviathan"][[87 27 10] "amours in the deep.*"][[87 29 1] "*The sperm whale, as with all other species of the Leviathan, but unlike"][[87 29 2] "most other fish, breeds indifferently at all seasons; after a gestation"][[87 29 3] "which may probably be set down at nine months, producing but one at a"][[87 29 4] "time; though in some few known instances giving birth to an Esau and"][[87 29 5] "Jacob:--a contingency provided for in suckling by two teats, curiously"][[87 29 6] "situated, one on each side of the anus; but the breasts themselves"][[87 29 7] "extend upwards from that. When by chance these precious parts in a"][[87 29 8] "nursing whale are cut by the hunter's lance, the mother's pouring milk"][[87 29 9] "and blood rivallingly discolour the sea for rods. The milk is very sweet"][[87 29 10] "and rich; it has been tasted by man; it might do well with strawberries."][[87 29 11] "When overflowing with mutual esteem, the whales salute MORE HOMINUM."][[87 31 1] "And thus, though surrounded by circle upon circle of consternations"][[87 31 2] "and affrights, did these inscrutable creatures at the centre freely and"][[87 31 3] "fearlessly indulge in all peaceful concernments; yea, serenely revelled"][[87 31 4] "in dalliance and delight. But even so, amid the tornadoed Atlantic of"][[87 31 5] "my being, do I myself still for ever centrally disport in mute calm; and"][[87 31 6] "while ponderous planets of unwaning woe revolve round me, deep down and"][[87 31 7] "deep inland there I still bathe me in eternal mildness of joy."][[87 32 1] "Meanwhile, as we thus lay entranced, the occasional sudden frantic"][[87 32 2] "spectacles in the distance evinced the activity of the other boats,"][[87 32 3] "still engaged in drugging the whales on the frontier of the host; or"][[87 32 4] "possibly carrying on the war within the first circle, where abundance of"][[87 32 5] "room and some convenient retreats were afforded them. But the sight"][[87 32 6] "of the enraged drugged whales now and then blindly darting to and fro"][[87 32 7] "across the circles, was nothing to what at last met our eyes. It is"][[87 32 8] "sometimes the custom when fast to a whale more than commonly powerful"][[87 32 9] "and alert, to seek to hamstring him, as it were, by sundering or"][[87 32 10] "maiming his gigantic tail-tendon. It is done by darting a short-handled"][[87 32 11] "cutting-spade, to which is attached a rope for hauling it back again."][[87 32 12] "A whale wounded (as we afterwards learned) in this part, but not"][[87 32 13] "effectually, as it seemed, had broken away from the boat, carrying along"][[87 32 14] "with him half of the harpoon line; and in the extraordinary agony of"][[87 32 15] "the wound, he was now dashing among the revolving circles like the lone"][[87 32 16] "mounted desperado Arnold, at the battle of Saratoga, carrying dismay"][[87 32 17] "wherever he went."][[87 33 1] "But agonizing as was the wound of this whale, and an appalling spectacle"][[87 33 2] "enough, any way; yet the peculiar horror with which he seemed to"][[87 33 3] "inspire the rest of the herd, was owing to a cause which at first the"][[87 33 4] "intervening distance obscured from us. But at length we perceived that"][[87 33 5] "by one of the unimaginable accidents of the fishery, this whale had"][[87 33 6] "become entangled in the harpoon-line that he towed; he had also run"][[87 33 7] "away with the cutting-spade in him; and while the free end of the rope"][[87 33 8] "attached to that weapon, had permanently caught in the coils of the"][[87 33 9] "harpoon-line round his tail, the cutting-spade itself had worked loose"][[87 33 10] "from his flesh. So that tormented to madness, he was now churning"][[87 33 11] "through the water, violently flailing with his flexible tail, and"][[87 33 12] "tossing the keen spade about him, wounding and murdering his own"][[87 33 13] "comrades."][[87 34 1] "This terrific object seemed to recall the whole herd from their"][[87 34 2] "stationary fright. First, the whales forming the margin of our lake"][[87 34 3] "began to crowd a little, and tumble against each other, as if lifted"][[87 34 4] "by half spent billows from afar; then the lake itself began faintly to"][[87 34 5] "heave and swell; the submarine bridal-chambers and nurseries vanished;"][[87 34 6] "in more and more contracting orbits the whales in the more central"][[87 34 7] "circles began to swim in thickening clusters. Yes, the long calm was"][[87 34 8] "departing. A low advancing hum was soon heard; and then like to the"][[87 34 9] "tumultuous masses of block-ice when the great river Hudson breaks up in"][[87 34 10] "Spring, the entire host of whales came tumbling upon their inner centre,"][[87 34 11] "as if to pile themselves up in one common mountain. Instantly Starbuck"][[87 34 12] "and Queequeg changed places; Starbuck taking the stern."][[87 35 1] "\"Oars! Oars!\" he intensely whispered, seizing the helm--\"gripe your"][[87 35 2] "oars, and clutch your souls, now! My God, men, stand by! Shove him off,"][[87 35 3] "you Queequeg--the whale there!--prick him!--hit him! Stand up--stand"][[87 35 4] "up, and stay so! Spring, men--pull, men; never mind their backs--scrape"][[87 35 5] "them!--scrape away!\""][[87 36 1] "The boat was now all but jammed between two vast black bulks, leaving a"][[87 36 2] "narrow Dardanelles between their long lengths. But by desperate endeavor"][[87 36 3] "we at last shot into a temporary opening; then giving way rapidly,"][[87 36 4] "and at the same time earnestly watching for another outlet. After many"][[87 36 5] "similar hair-breadth escapes, we at last swiftly glided into what had"][[87 36 6] "just been one of the outer circles, but now crossed by random whales,"][[87 36 7] "all violently making for one centre. This lucky salvation was cheaply"][[87 36 8] "purchased by the loss of Queequeg's hat, who, while standing in the bows"][[87 36 9] "to prick the fugitive whales, had his hat taken clean from his head by"][[87 36 10] "the air-eddy made by the sudden tossing of a pair of broad flukes close"][[87 36 11] "by."][[87 37 1] "Riotous and disordered as the universal commotion now was, it soon"][[87 37 2] "resolved itself into what seemed a systematic movement; for having"][[87 37 3] "clumped together at last in one dense body, they then renewed their"][[87 37 4] "onward flight with augmented fleetness. Further pursuit was useless; but"][[87 37 5] "the boats still lingered in their wake to pick up what drugged whales"][[87 37 6] "might be dropped astern, and likewise to secure one which Flask had"][[87 37 7] "killed and waifed. The waif is a pennoned pole, two or three of which"][[87 37 8] "are carried by every boat; and which, when additional game is at hand,"][[87 37 9] "are inserted upright into the floating body of a dead whale, both to"][[87 37 10] "mark its place on the sea, and also as token of prior possession, should"][[87 37 11] "the boats of any other ship draw near."][[87 38 1] "The result of this lowering was somewhat illustrative of that sagacious"][[87 38 2] "saying in the Fishery,--the more whales the less fish. Of all the"][[87 38 3] "drugged whales only one was captured. The rest contrived to escape for"][[87 38 4] "the time, but only to be taken, as will hereafter be seen, by some other"][[87 38 5] "craft than the Pequod."][[88 0 0] "CHAPTER 88. Schools and Schoolmasters."][[88 2 1] "The previous chapter gave account of an immense body or herd of Sperm"][[88 2 2] "Whales, and there was also then given the probable cause inducing those"][[88 2 3] "vast aggregations."][[88 3 1] "Now, though such great bodies are at times encountered, yet, as must"][[88 3 2] "have been seen, even at the present day, small detached bands are"][[88 3 3] "occasionally observed, embracing from twenty to fifty individuals each."][[88 3 4] "Such bands are known as schools. They generally are of two sorts; those"][[88 3 5] "composed almost entirely of females, and those mustering none but young"][[88 3 6] "vigorous males, or bulls, as they are familiarly designated."][[88 4 1] "In cavalier attendance upon the school of females, you invariably see a"][[88 4 2] "male of full grown magnitude, but not old; who, upon any alarm, evinces"][[88 4 3] "his gallantry by falling in the rear and covering the flight of his"][[88 4 4] "ladies. In truth, this gentleman is a luxurious Ottoman, swimming about"][[88 4 5] "over the watery world, surroundingly accompanied by all the solaces"][[88 4 6] "and endearments of the harem. The contrast between this Ottoman and"][[88 4 7] "his concubines is striking; because, while he is always of the largest"][[88 4 8] "leviathanic proportions, the ladies, even at full growth, are not"][[88 4 9] "more than one-third of the bulk of an average-sized male. They are"][[88 4 10] "comparatively delicate, indeed; I dare say, not to exceed half a dozen"][[88 4 11] "yards round the waist. Nevertheless, it cannot be denied, that upon the"][[88 4 12] "whole they are hereditarily entitled to EMBONPOINT."][[88 5 1] "It is very curious to watch this harem and its lord in their indolent"][[88 5 2] "ramblings. Like fashionables, they are for ever on the move in leisurely"][[88 5 3] "search of variety. You meet them on the Line in time for the full flower"][[88 5 4] "of the Equatorial feeding season, having just returned, perhaps, from"][[88 5 5] "spending the summer in the Northern seas, and so cheating summer of all"][[88 5 6] "unpleasant weariness and warmth.
