By the time they have lounged up and"][[88 5 7] "down the promenade of the Equator awhile, they start for the Oriental"][[88 5 8] "waters in anticipation of the cool season there, and so evade the other"][[88 5 9] "excessive temperature of the year."][[88 6 1] "When serenely advancing on one of these journeys, if any strange"][[88 6 2] "suspicious sights are seen, my lord whale keeps a wary eye on his"][[88 6 3] "interesting family. Should any unwarrantably pert young Leviathan coming"][[88 6 4] "that way, presume to draw confidentially close to one of the ladies,"][[88 6 5] "with what prodigious fury the Bashaw assails him, and chases him away!"][[88 6 6] "High times, indeed, if unprincipled young rakes like him are to be"][[88 6 7] "permitted to invade the sanctity of domestic bliss; though do what the"][[88 6 8] "Bashaw will, he cannot keep the most notorious Lothario out of his bed;"][[88 6 9] "for, alas! all fish bed in common. As ashore, the ladies often cause the"][[88 6 10] "most terrible duels among their rival admirers; just so with the whales,"][[88 6 11] "who sometimes come to deadly battle, and all for love. They fence with"][[88 6 12] "their long lower jaws, sometimes locking them together, and so striving"][[88 6 13] "for the supremacy like elks that warringly interweave their antlers. Not"][[88 6 14] "a few are captured having the deep scars of these encounters,--furrowed"][[88 6 15] "heads, broken teeth, scolloped fins; and in some instances, wrenched and"][[88 6 16] "dislocated mouths."][[88 7 1] "But supposing the invader of domestic bliss to betake himself away at"][[88 7 2] "the first rush of the harem's lord, then is it very diverting to watch"][[88 7 3] "that lord. Gently he insinuates his vast bulk among them again and"][[88 7 4] "revels there awhile, still in tantalizing vicinity to young Lothario,"][[88 7 5] "like pious Solomon devoutly worshipping among his thousand concubines."][[88 7 6] "Granting other whales to be in sight, the fishermen will seldom give"][[88 7 7] "chase to one of these Grand Turks; for these Grand Turks are too lavish"][[88 7 8] "of their strength, and hence their unctuousness is small. As for the"][[88 7 9] "sons and the daughters they beget, why, those sons and daughters must"][[88 7 10] "take care of themselves; at least, with only the maternal help. For"][[88 7 11] "like certain other omnivorous roving lovers that might be named, my Lord"][[88 7 12] "Whale has no taste for the nursery, however much for the bower; and so,"][[88 7 13] "being a great traveller, he leaves his anonymous babies all over the"][[88 7 14] "world; every baby an exotic. In good time, nevertheless, as the ardour"][[88 7 15] "of youth declines; as years and dumps increase; as reflection lends"][[88 7 16] "her solemn pauses; in short, as a general lassitude overtakes the sated"][[88 7 17] "Turk; then a love of ease and virtue supplants the love for maidens; our"][[88 7 18] "Ottoman enters upon the impotent, repentant, admonitory stage of life,"][[88 7 19] "forswears, disbands the harem, and grown to an exemplary, sulky old"][[88 7 20] "soul, goes about all alone among the meridians and parallels saying his"][[88 7 21] "prayers, and warning each young Leviathan from his amorous errors."][[88 8 1] "Now, as the harem of whales is called by the fishermen a school, so"][[88 8 2] "is the lord and master of that school technically known as the"][[88 8 3] "schoolmaster. It is therefore not in strict character, however admirably"][[88 8 4] "satirical, that after going to school himself, he should then go abroad"][[88 8 5] "inculcating not what he learned there, but the folly of it. His title,"][[88 8 6] "schoolmaster, would very naturally seem derived from the name bestowed"][[88 8 7] "upon the harem itself, but some have surmised that the man who first"][[88 8 8] "thus entitled this sort of Ottoman whale, must have read the memoirs of"][[88 8 9] "Vidocq, and informed himself what sort of a country-schoolmaster that"][[88 8 10] "famous Frenchman was in his younger days, and what was the nature of"][[88 8 11] "those occult lessons he inculcated into some of his pupils."][[88 9 1] "The same secludedness and isolation to which the schoolmaster whale"][[88 9 2] "betakes himself in his advancing years, is true of all aged Sperm"][[88 9 3] "Whales. Almost universally, a lone whale--as a solitary Leviathan is"][[88 9 4] "called--proves an ancient one. Like venerable moss-bearded Daniel Boone,"][[88 9 5] "he will have no one near him but Nature herself; and her he takes to"][[88 9 6] "wife in the wilderness of waters, and the best of wives she is, though"][[88 9 7] "she keeps so many moody secrets."][[88 10 1] "The schools composing none but young and vigorous males, previously"][[88 10 2] "mentioned, offer a strong contrast to the harem schools. For while"][[88 10 3] "those female whales are characteristically timid, the young males, or"][[88 10 4] "forty-barrel-bulls, as they call them, are by far the most pugnacious"][[88 10 5] "of all Leviathans, and proverbially the most dangerous to encounter;"][[88 10 6] "excepting those wondrous grey-headed, grizzled whales, sometimes met,"][[88 10 7] "and these will fight you like grim fiends exasperated by a penal gout."][[88 11 1] "The Forty-barrel-bull schools are larger than the harem schools. Like"][[88 11 2] "a mob of young collegians, they are full of fight, fun, and wickedness,"][[88 11 3] "tumbling round the world at such a reckless, rollicking rate, that no"][[88 11 4] "prudent underwriter would insure them any more than he would a riotous"][[88 11 5] "lad at Yale or Harvard. They soon relinquish this turbulence though,"][[88 11 6] "and when about three-fourths grown, break up, and separately go about in"][[88 11 7] "quest of settlements, that is, harems."][[88 12 1] "Another point of difference between the male and female schools is"][[88 12 2] "still more characteristic of the sexes. Say you strike a"][[88 12 3] "Forty-barrel-bull--poor devil! all his comrades quit him. But strike"][[88 12 4] "a member of the harem school, and her companions swim around her with"][[88 12 5] "every token of concern, sometimes lingering so near her and so long, as"][[88 12 6] "themselves to fall a prey."][[89 0 0] "CHAPTER 89. Fast-Fish and Loose-Fish."][[89 2 1] "The allusion to the waif and waif-poles in the last chapter but one,"][[89 2 2] "necessitates some account of the laws and regulations of the whale"][[89 2 3] "fishery, of which the waif may be deemed the grand symbol and badge."][[89 3 1] "It frequently happens that when several ships are cruising in company,"][[89 3 2] "a whale may be struck by one vessel, then escape, and be finally killed"][[89 3 3] "and captured by another vessel; and herein are indirectly comprised"][[89 3 4] "many minor contingencies, all partaking of this one grand feature. For"][[89 3 5] "example,--after a weary and perilous chase and capture of a whale,"][[89 3 6] "the body may get loose from the ship by reason of a violent storm; and"][[89 3 7] "drifting far away to leeward, be retaken by a second whaler, who, in a"][[89 3 8] "calm, snugly tows it alongside, without risk of life or line. Thus"][[89 3 9] "the most vexatious and violent disputes would often arise between"][[89 3 10] "the fishermen, were there not some written or unwritten, universal,"][[89 3 11] "undisputed law applicable to all cases."][[89 4 1] "Perhaps the only formal whaling code authorized by legislative"][[89 4 2] "enactment, was that of Holland. It was decreed by the States-General in"][[89 4 3] "A.D. . But though no other nation has ever had any written whaling"][[89 4 4] "law, yet the American fishermen have been their own legislators and"][[89 4 5] "lawyers in this matter. They have provided a system which for terse"][[89 4 6] "comprehensiveness surpasses Justinian's Pandects and the By-laws of"][[89 4 7] "the Chinese Society for the Suppression of Meddling with other People's"][[89 4 8] "Business. Yes; these laws might be engraven on a Queen Anne's farthing,"][[89 4 9] "or the barb of a harpoon, and worn round the neck, so small are they."][[89 5 1] "I. A Fast-Fish belongs to the party fast to it."][[89 6 1] "II. A Loose-Fish is fair game for anybody who can soonest catch it."][[89 7 1] "But what plays the mischief with this masterly code is the admirable"][[89 7 2] "brevity of it, which necessitates a vast volume of commentaries to"][[89 7 3] "expound it."][[89 8 1] "First: What is a Fast-Fish? Alive or dead a fish is technically fast,"][[89 8 2] "when it is connected with an occupied ship or boat, by any medium at all"][[89 8 3] "controllable by the occupant or occupants,--a mast, an oar, a nine-inch"][[89 8 4] "cable, a telegraph wire, or a strand of cobweb, it is all the same."][[89 8 5] "Likewise a fish is technically fast when it bears a waif, or any other"][[89 8 6] "recognised symbol of possession; so long as the party waifing it plainly"][[89 8 7] "evince their ability at any time to take it alongside, as well as their"][[89 8 8] "intention so to do."][[89 9 1] "These are scientific commentaries; but the commentaries of the whalemen"][[89 9 2] "themselves sometimes consist in hard words and harder knocks--the"][[89 9 3] "Coke-upon-Littleton of the fist. True, among the more upright and"][[89 9 4] "honourable whalemen allowances are always made for peculiar cases,"][[89 9 5] "where it would be an outrageous moral injustice for one party to claim"][[89 9 6] "possession of a whale previously chased or killed by another party. But"][[89 9 7] "others are by no means so scrupulous."][[89 10 1] "Some fifty years ago there was a curious case of whale-trover litigated"][[89 10 2] "in England, wherein the plaintiffs set forth that after a hard chase of"][[89 10 3] "a whale in the Northern seas; and when indeed they (the plaintiffs) had"][[89 10 4] "succeeded in harpooning the fish; they were at last, through peril of"][[89 10 5] "their lives, obliged to forsake not only their lines, but their boat"][[89 10 6] "itself. Ultimately the defendants (the crew of another ship) came up"][[89 10 7] "with the whale, struck, killed, seized, and finally appropriated it"][[89 10 8] "before the very eyes of the plaintiffs. And when those defendants were"][[89 10 9] "remonstrated with, their captain snapped his fingers in the plaintiffs'"][[89 10 10] "teeth, and assured them that by way of doxology to the deed he had done,"][[89 10 11] "he would now retain their line, harpoons, and boat, which had remained"][[89 10 12] "attached to the whale at the time of the seizure. Wherefore the"][[89 10 13] "plaintiffs now sued for the recovery of the value of their whale, line,"][[89 10 14] "harpoons, and boat."][[89 11 1] "Mr. Erskine was counsel for the defendants; Lord Ellenborough was"][[89 11 2] "the judge. In the course of the defence, the witty Erskine went on"][[89 11 3] "to illustrate his position, by alluding to a recent crim. con."][[89 11 4] "case, wherein a gentleman, after in vain trying to bridle his wife's"][[89 11 5] "viciousness, had at last abandoned her upon the seas of life; but in"][[89 11 6] "the course of years, repenting of that step, he instituted an action to"][[89 11 7] "recover possession of her. Erskine was on the other side; and he"][[89 11 8] "then supported it by saying, that though the gentleman had originally"][[89 11 9] "harpooned the lady, and had once had her fast, and only by reason of the"][[89 11 10] "great stress of her plunging viciousness, had at last abandoned her; yet"][[89 11 11] "abandon her he did, so that she became a loose-fish; and therefore"][[89 11 12] "when a subsequent gentleman re-harpooned her, the lady then became that"][[89 11 13] "subsequent gentleman's property, along with whatever harpoon might have"][[89 11 14] "been found sticking in her."][[89 12 1] "Now in the present case Erskine contended that the examples of the whale"][[89 12 2] "and the lady were reciprocally illustrative of each other."][[89 13 1] "These pleadings, and the counter pleadings, being duly heard, the very"][[89 13 2] "learned Judge in set terms decided, to wit,--That as for the boat, he"][[89 13 3] "awarded it to the plaintiffs, because they had merely abandoned it"][[89 13 4] "to save their lives; but that with regard to the controverted whale,"][[89 13 5] "harpoons, and line, they belonged to the defendants; the whale, because"][[89 13 6] "it was a Loose-Fish at the time of the final capture; and the harpoons"][[89 13 7] "and line because when the fish made off with them, it (the fish)"][[89 13 8] "acquired a property in those articles; and hence anybody who afterwards"][[89 13 9] "took the fish had a right to them. Now the defendants afterwards took"][[89 13 10] "the fish; ergo, the aforesaid articles were theirs."][[89 14 1] "A common man looking at this decision of the very learned Judge, might"][[89 14 2] "possibly object to it. But ploughed up to the primary rock of the"][[89 14 3] "matter, the two great principles laid down in the twin whaling laws"][[89 14 4] "previously quoted, and applied and elucidated by Lord Ellenborough in"][[89 14 5] "the above cited case; these two laws touching Fast-Fish and Loose-Fish,"][[89 14 6] "I say, will, on reflection, be found the fundamentals of all human"][[89 14 7] "jurisprudence; for notwithstanding its complicated tracery of sculpture,"][[89 14 8] "the Temple of the Law, like the Temple of the Philistines, has but two"][[89 14 9] "props to stand on."][[89 15 1] "Is it not a saying in every one's mouth, Possession is half of the law:"][[89 15 2] "that is, regardless of how the thing came into possession? But often"][[89 15 3] "possession is the whole of the law. What are the sinews and souls of"][[89 15 4] "Russian serfs and Republican slaves but Fast-Fish, whereof possession is"][[89 15 5] "the whole of the law? What to the rapacious landlord is the widow's last"][[89 15 6] "mite but a Fast-Fish? What is yonder undetected villain's marble mansion"][[89 15 7] "with a door-plate for a waif; what is that but a Fast-Fish? What is the"][[89 15 8] "ruinous discount which Mordecai, the broker, gets from poor Woebegone,"][[89 15 9] "the bankrupt, on a loan to keep Woebegone's family from starvation;"][[89 15 10] "what is that ruinous discount but a Fast-Fish? What is the Archbishop of"][[89 15 11] "Savesoul's income of L, seized from the scant bread and cheese"][[89 15 12] "of hundreds of thousands of broken-backed laborers (all sure of heaven"][[89 15 13] "without any of Savesoul's help) what is that globular L, but a"][[89 15 14] "Fast-Fish? What are the Duke of Dunder's hereditary towns and hamlets"][[89 15 15] "but Fast-Fish? What to that redoubted harpooneer, John Bull, is poor"][[89 15 16] "Ireland, but a Fast-Fish? What to that apostolic lancer, Brother"][[89 15 17] "Jonathan, is Texas but a Fast-Fish? And concerning all these, is not"][[89 15 18] "Possession the whole of the law?"][[89 16 1] "But if the doctrine of Fast-Fish be pretty generally applicable,"][[89 16 2] "the kindred doctrine of Loose-Fish is still more widely so. That is"][[89 16 3] "internationally and universally applicable."][[89 17 1] "What was America in  but a Loose-Fish, in which Columbus struck the"][[89 17 2] "Spanish standard by way of waifing it for his royal master and mistress?"][[89 17 3] "What was Poland to the Czar? What Greece to the Turk? What India"][[89 17 4] "to England? What at last will Mexico be to the United States? All"][[89 17 5] "Loose-Fish."][[89 18 1] "What are the Rights of Man and the Liberties of the World but"][[89 18 2] "Loose-Fish? What all men's minds and opinions but Loose-Fish? What is"][[89 18 3] "the principle of religious belief in them but a Loose-Fish? What to"][[89 18 4] "the ostentatious smuggling verbalists are the thoughts of thinkers but"][[89 18 5] "Loose-Fish? What is the great globe itself but a Loose-Fish? And what"][[89 18 6] "are you, reader, but a Loose-Fish and a Fast-Fish, too?"][[90 0 0] "CHAPTER 90. Heads or Tails."][[90 2 1] "\"De balena vero sufficit, si rex habeat caput, et regina caudam.\""][[90 2 2] "BRACTON, L. , C. ."][[90 4 1] "Latin from the books of the Laws of England, which taken along with the"][[90 4 2] "context, means, that of all whales captured by anybody on the coast of"][[90 4 3] "that land, the King, as Honourary Grand Harpooneer, must have the head,"][[90 4 4] "and the Queen be respectfully presented with the tail. A division which,"][[90 4 5] "in the whale, is much like halving an apple; there is no intermediate"][[90 4 6] "remainder. Now as this law, under a modified form, is to this day in"][[90 4 7] "force in England; and as it offers in various respects a strange anomaly"][[90 4 8] "touching the general law of Fast and Loose-Fish, it is here treated of"][[90 4 9] "in a separate chapter, on the same courteous principle that prompts"][[90 4 10] "the English railways to be at the expense of a separate car, specially"][[90 4 11] "reserved for the accommodation of royalty. In the first place, in"][[90 4 12] "curious proof of the fact that the above-mentioned law is still in"][[90 4 13] "force, I proceed to lay before you a circumstance that happened within"][[90 4 14] "the last two years."][[90 5 1] "It seems that some honest mariners of Dover, or Sandwich, or some one"][[90 5 2] "of the Cinque Ports, had after a hard chase succeeded in killing and"][[90 5 3] "beaching a fine whale which they had originally descried afar off from"][[90 5 4] "the shore. Now the Cinque Ports are partially or somehow under the"][[90 5 5] "jurisdiction of a sort of policeman or beadle, called a Lord Warden."][[90 5 6] "Holding the office directly from the crown, I believe, all the royal"][[90 5 7] "emoluments incident to the Cinque Port territories become by assignment"][[90 5 8] "his. By some writers this office is called a sinecure. But not so."][[90 5 9] "Because the Lord Warden is busily employed at times in fobbing his"][[90 5 10] "perquisites; which are his chiefly by virtue of that same fobbing of"][[90 5 11] "them."][[90 6 1] "Now when these poor sun-burnt mariners, bare-footed, and with their"][[90 6 2] "trowsers rolled high up on their eely legs, had wearily hauled their fat"][[90 6 3] "fish high and dry, promising themselves a good L from the precious"][[90 6 4] "oil and bone; and in fantasy sipping rare tea with their wives, and good"][[90 6 5] "ale with their cronies, upon the strength of their respective shares; up"][[90 6 6] "steps a very learned and most Christian and charitable gentleman, with"][[90 6 7] "a copy of Blackstone under his arm; and laying it upon the whale's head,"][[90 6 8] "he says--\"Hands off! this fish, my masters, is a Fast-Fish. I seize it"][[90 6 9] "as the Lord Warden's.\" Upon this the poor mariners in their respectful"][[90 6 10] "consternation--so truly English--knowing not what to say, fall to"][[90 6 11] "vigorously scratching their heads all round; meanwhile ruefully glancing"][[90 6 12] "from the whale to the stranger. But that did in nowise mend the matter,"][[90 6 13] "or at all soften the hard heart of the learned gentleman with the copy"][[90 6 14] "of Blackstone. At length one of them, after long scratching about for"][[90 6 15] "his ideas, made bold to speak,"][[90 7 1] "\"Please, sir, who is the Lord Warden?\""][[90 8 1] "\"The Duke.\""][[90 9 1] "\"But the duke had nothing to do with taking this fish?\""][[90 10 1] "\"It is his.\""][[90 11 1] "\"We have been at great trouble, and peril, and some expense, and is"][[90 11 2] "all that to go to the Duke's benefit; we getting nothing at all for our"][[90 11 3] "pains but our blisters?\""][[90 12 1] "\"It is his.\""][[90 13 1] "\"Is the Duke so very poor as to be forced to this desperate mode of"][[90 13 2] "getting a livelihood?\""][[90 14 1] "\"It is his.\""][[90 15 1] "\"I thought to relieve my old bed-ridden mother by part of my share of"][[90 15 2] "this whale.\""][[90 16 1] "\"It is his.\""][[90 17 1] "\"Won't the Duke be content with a quarter or a half?\""][[90 18 1] "\"It is his.\""][[90 19 1] "In a word, the whale was seized and sold, and his Grace the Duke of"][[90 19 2] "Wellington received the money. Thinking that viewed in some particular"][[90 19 3] "lights, the case might by a bare possibility in some small degree be"][[90 19 4] "deemed, under the circumstances, a rather hard one, an honest clergyman"][[90 19 5] "of the town respectfully addressed a note to his Grace, begging him to"][[90 19 6] "take the case of those unfortunate mariners into full consideration. To"][[90 19 7] "which my Lord Duke in substance replied (both letters were published)"][[90 19 8] "that he had already done so, and received the money, and would be"][[90 19 9] "obliged to the reverend gentleman if for the future he (the reverend"][[90 19 10] "gentleman) would decline meddling with other people's business. Is"][[90 19 11] "this the still militant old man, standing at the corners of the three"][[90 19 12] "kingdoms, on all hands coercing alms of beggars?"][[90 20 1] "It will readily be seen that in this case the alleged right of the"][[90 20 2] "Duke to the whale was a delegated one from the Sovereign. We must needs"][[90 20 3] "inquire then on what principle the Sovereign is originally invested with"][[90 20 4] "that right. The law itself has already been set forth. But Plowdon gives"][[90 20 5] "us the reason for it. Says Plowdon, the whale so caught belongs to"][[90 20 6] "the King and Queen, \"because of its superior excellence.\" And by the"][[90 20 7] "soundest commentators this has ever been held a cogent argument in such"][[90 20 8] "matters."][[90 21 1] "But why should the King have the head, and the Queen the tail? A reason"][[90 21 2] "for that, ye lawyers!"][[90 22 1] "In his treatise on \"Queen-Gold,\" or Queen-pinmoney, an old King's Bench"][[90 22 2] "author, one William Prynne, thus discourseth: \"Ye tail is ye Queen's,"][[90 22 3] "that ye Queen's wardrobe may be supplied with ye whalebone.\" Now this"][[90 22 4] "was written at a time when the black limber bone of the Greenland or"][[90 22 5] "Right whale was largely used in ladies' bodices. But this same bone"][[90 22 6] "is not in the tail; it is in the head, which is a sad mistake for"][[90 22 7] "a sagacious lawyer like Prynne. But is the Queen a mermaid, to be"][[90 22 8] "presented with a tail? An allegorical meaning may lurk here."][[90 23 1] "There are two royal fish so styled by the English law writers--the whale"][[90 23 2] "and the sturgeon; both royal property under certain limitations, and"][[90 23 3] "nominally supplying the tenth branch of the crown's ordinary revenue."][[90 23 4] "I know not that any other author has hinted of the matter; but by"][[90 23 5] "inference it seems to me that the sturgeon must be divided in the same"][[90 23 6] "way as the whale, the King receiving the highly dense and elastic head"][[90 23 7] "peculiar to that fish, which, symbolically regarded, may possibly be"][[90 23 8] "humorously grounded upon some presumed congeniality. And thus there"][[90 23 9] "seems a reason in all things, even in law."][[91 0 0] "CHAPTER 91. The Pequod Meets The Rose-Bud."][[91 2 1] "\"In vain it was to rake for Ambergriese in the paunch of this Leviathan,"][[91 2 2] "insufferable fetor denying not inquiry.\" SIR T. BROWNE, V.E."][[91 4 1] "It was a week or two after the last whaling scene recounted, and when we"][[91 4 2] "were slowly sailing over a sleepy, vapoury, mid-day sea, that the many"][[91 4 3] "noses on the Pequod's deck proved more vigilant discoverers than the"][[91 4 4] "three pairs of eyes aloft. A peculiar and not very pleasant smell was"][[91 4 5] "smelt in the sea."][[91 5 1] "\"I will bet something now,\" said Stubb, \"that somewhere hereabouts are"][[91 5 2] "some of those drugged whales we tickled the other day. I thought they"][[91 5 3] "would keel up before long.\""][[91 6 1] "Presently, the vapours in advance slid aside; and there in the distance"][[91 6 2] "lay a ship, whose furled sails betokened that some sort of whale must be"][[91 6 3] "alongside. As we glided nearer, the stranger showed French colours from"][[91 6 4] "his peak; and by the eddying cloud of vulture sea-fowl that circled, and"][[91 6 5] "hovered, and swooped around him, it was plain that the whale alongside"][[91 6 6] "must be what the fishermen call a blasted whale, that is, a whale that"][[91 6 7] "has died unmolested on the sea, and so floated an unappropriated corpse."][[91 6 8] "It may well be conceived, what an unsavory odor such a mass must"][[91 6 9] "exhale; worse than an Assyrian city in the plague, when the living are"][[91 6 10] "incompetent to bury the departed. So intolerable indeed is it regarded"][[91 6 11] "by some, that no cupidity could persuade them to moor alongside of it."][[91 6 12] "Yet are there those who will still do it; notwithstanding the fact that"][[91 6 13] "the oil obtained from such subjects is of a very inferior quality, and"][[91 6 14] "by no means of the nature of attar-of-rose."][[91 7 1] "Coming still nearer with the expiring breeze, we saw that the Frenchman"][[91 7 2] "had a second whale alongside; and this second whale seemed even more"][[91 7 3] "of a nosegay than the first. In truth, it turned out to be one of"][[91 7 4] "those problematical whales that seem to dry up and die with a sort"][[91 7 5] "of prodigious dyspepsia, or indigestion; leaving their defunct bodies"][[91 7 6] "almost entirely bankrupt of anything like oil. Nevertheless, in the"][[91 7 7] "proper place we shall see that no knowing fisherman will ever turn"][[91 7 8] "up his nose at such a whale as this, however much he may shun blasted"][[91 7 9] "whales in general."][[91 8 1] "The Pequod had now swept so nigh to the stranger, that Stubb vowed"][[91 8 2] "he recognised his cutting spade-pole entangled in the lines that were"][[91 8 3] "knotted round the tail of one of these whales."][[91 9 1] "\"There's a pretty fellow, now,\" he banteringly laughed, standing in the"][[91 9 2] "ship's bows, \"there's a jackal for ye! I well know that these Crappoes"][[91 9 3] "of Frenchmen are but poor devils in the fishery; sometimes lowering"][[91 9 4] "their boats for breakers, mistaking them for Sperm Whale spouts; yes,"][[91 9 5] "and sometimes sailing from their port with their hold full of boxes of"][[91 9 6] "tallow candles, and cases of snuffers, foreseeing that all the oil they"][[91 9 7] "will get won't be enough to dip the Captain's wick into; aye, we all"][[91 9 8] "know these things; but look ye, here's a Crappo that is content with our"][[91 9 9] "leavings, the drugged whale there, I mean; aye, and is content too with"][[91 9 10] "scraping the dry bones of that other precious fish he has there. Poor"][[91 9 11] "devil! I say, pass round a hat, some one, and let's make him a present"][[91 9 12] "of a little oil for dear charity's sake. For what oil he'll get from"][[91 9 13] "that drugged whale there, wouldn't be fit to burn in a jail; no, not"][[91 9 14] "in a condemned cell. And as for the other whale, why, I'll agree to get"][[91 9 15] "more oil by chopping up and trying out these three masts of ours, than"][[91 9 16] "he'll get from that bundle of bones; though, now that I think of it, it"][[91 9 17] "may contain something worth a good deal more than oil; yes, ambergris."][[91 9 18] "I wonder now if our old man has thought of that. It's worth trying. Yes,"][[91 9 19] "I'm for it;\" and so saying he started for the quarter-deck."][[91 10 1] "By this time the faint air had become a complete calm; so that whether"][[91 10 2] "or no, the Pequod was now fairly entrapped in the smell, with no hope of"][[91 10 3] "escaping except by its breezing up again. Issuing from the cabin, Stubb"][[91 10 4] "now called his boat's crew, and pulled off for the stranger. Drawing"][[91 10 5] "across her bow, he perceived that in accordance with the fanciful French"][[91 10 6] "taste, the upper part of her stem-piece was carved in the likeness of a"][[91 10 7] "huge drooping stalk, was painted green, and for thorns had copper"][[91 10 8] "spikes projecting from it here and there; the whole terminating in a"][[91 10 9] "symmetrical folded bulb of a bright red colour. Upon her head boards, in"][[91 10 10] "large gilt letters, he read \"Bouton de Rose,\"--Rose-button, or Rose-bud;"][[91 10 11] "and this was the romantic name of this aromatic ship."][[91 11 1] "Though Stubb did not understand the BOUTON part of the inscription, yet"][[91 11 2] "the word ROSE, and the bulbous figure-head put together, sufficiently"][[91 11 3] "explained the whole to him."][[91 12 1] "\"A wooden rose-bud, eh?\" he cried with his hand to his nose, \"that will"][[91 12 2] "do very well; but how like all creation it smells!\""][[91 13 1] "Now in order to hold direct communication with the people on deck, he"][[91 13 2] "had to pull round the bows to the starboard side, and thus come close to"][[91 13 3] "the blasted whale; and so talk over it."][[91 14 1] "Arrived then at this spot, with one hand still to his nose, he"][[91 14 2] "bawled--\"Bouton-de-Rose, ahoy! are there any of you Bouton-de-Roses that"][[91 14 3] "speak English?\""][[91 15 1] "\"Yes,\" rejoined a Guernsey-man from the bulwarks, who turned out to be"][[91 15 2] "the chief-mate."][[91 16 1] "\"Well, then, my Bouton-de-Rose-bud, have you seen the White Whale?\""][[91 17 1] "\"WHAT whale?\""][[91 18 1] "\"The WHITE Whale--a Sperm Whale--Moby Dick, have ye seen him?"][[91 19 1] "\"Never heard of such a whale. Cachalot Blanche! White Whale--no.\""][[91 20 1] "\"Very good, then; good bye now, and I'll call again in a minute.\""][[91 21 1] "Then rapidly pulling back towards the Pequod, and seeing Ahab leaning"][[91 21 2] "over the quarter-deck rail awaiting his report, he moulded his two hands"][[91 21 3] "into a trumpet and shouted--\"No, Sir!
