According to this little plan"][[91 31 11] "of theirs, the Guernsey-man, under cover of an interpreter's office, was"][[91 31 12] "to tell the Captain what he pleased, but as coming from Stubb; and as"][[91 31 13] "for Stubb, he was to utter any nonsense that should come uppermost in"][[91 31 14] "him during the interview."][[91 32 1] "By this time their destined victim appeared from his cabin. He was a"][[91 32 2] "small and dark, but rather delicate looking man for a sea-captain, with"][[91 32 3] "large whiskers and moustache, however; and wore a red cotton velvet vest"][[91 32 4] "with watch-seals at his side. To this gentleman, Stubb was now politely"][[91 32 5] "introduced by the Guernsey-man, who at once ostentatiously put on the"][[91 32 6] "aspect of interpreting between them."][[91 33 1] "\"What shall I say to him first?\" said he."][[91 34 1] "\"Why,\" said Stubb, eyeing the velvet vest and the watch and seals, \"you"][[91 34 2] "may as well begin by telling him that he looks a sort of babyish to me,"][[91 34 3] "though I don't pretend to be a judge.\""][[91 35 1] "\"He says, Monsieur,\" said the Guernsey-man, in French, turning to his"][[91 35 2] "captain, \"that only yesterday his ship spoke a vessel, whose captain"][[91 35 3] "and chief-mate, with six sailors, had all died of a fever caught from a"][[91 35 4] "blasted whale they had brought alongside.\""][[91 36 1] "Upon this the captain started, and eagerly desired to know more."][[91 37 1] "\"What now?\" said the Guernsey-man to Stubb."][[91 38 1] "\"Why, since he takes it so easy, tell him that now I have eyed him"][[91 38 2] "carefully, I'm quite certain that he's no more fit to command a"][[91 38 3] "whale-ship than a St. Jago monkey. In fact, tell him from me he's a"][[91 38 4] "baboon.\""][[91 39 1] "\"He vows and declares, Monsieur, that the other whale, the dried one, is"][[91 39 2] "far more deadly than the blasted one; in fine, Monsieur, he conjures us,"][[91 39 3] "as we value our lives, to cut loose from these fish.\""][[91 40 1] "Instantly the captain ran forward, and in a loud voice commanded his"][[91 40 2] "crew to desist from hoisting the cutting-tackles, and at once cast loose"][[91 40 3] "the cables and chains confining the whales to the ship."][[91 41 1] "\"What now?\" said the Guernsey-man, when the Captain had returned to"][[91 41 2] "them."][[91 42 1] "\"Why, let me see; yes, you may as well tell him now that--that--in"][[91 42 2] "fact, tell him I've diddled him, and (aside to himself) perhaps somebody"][[91 42 3] "else.\""][[91 43 1] "\"He says, Monsieur, that he's very happy to have been of any service to"][[91 43 2] "us.\""][[91 44 1] "Hearing this, the captain vowed that they were the grateful parties"][[91 44 2] "(meaning himself and mate) and concluded by inviting Stubb down into his"][[91 44 3] "cabin to drink a bottle of Bordeaux."][[91 45 1] "\"He wants you to take a glass of wine with him,\" said the interpreter."][[91 46 1] "\"Thank him heartily; but tell him it's against my principles to drink"][[91 46 2] "with the man I've diddled. In fact, tell him I must go.\""][[91 47 1] "\"He says, Monsieur, that his principles won't admit of his drinking; but"][[91 47 2] "that if Monsieur wants to live another day to drink, then Monsieur had"][[91 47 3] "best drop all four boats, and pull the ship away from these whales, for"][[91 47 4] "it's so calm they won't drift.\""][[91 48 1] "By this time Stubb was over the side, and getting into his boat, hailed"][[91 48 2] "the Guernsey-man to this effect,--that having a long tow-line in his"][[91 48 3] "boat, he would do what he could to help them, by pulling out the lighter"][[91 48 4] "whale of the two from the ship's side. While the Frenchman's boats,"][[91 48 5] "then, were engaged in towing the ship one way, Stubb benevolently towed"][[91 48 6] "away at his whale the other way, ostentatiously slacking out a most"][[91 48 7] "unusually long tow-line."][[91 49 1] "Presently a breeze sprang up; Stubb feigned to cast off from the whale;"][[91 49 2] "hoisting his boats, the Frenchman soon increased his distance, while the"][[91 49 3] "Pequod slid in between him and Stubb's whale. Whereupon Stubb quickly"][[91 49 4] "pulled to the floating body, and hailing the Pequod to give notice of"][[91 49 5] "his intentions, at once proceeded to reap the fruit of his unrighteous"][[91 49 6] "cunning. Seizing his sharp boat-spade, he commenced an excavation in the"][[91 49 7] "body, a little behind the side fin. You would almost have thought he was"][[91 49 8] "digging a cellar there in the sea; and when at length his spade struck"][[91 49 9] "against the gaunt ribs, it was like turning up old Roman tiles and"][[91 49 10] "pottery buried in fat English loam. His boat's crew were all in high"][[91 49 11] "excitement, eagerly helping their chief, and looking as anxious as"][[91 49 12] "gold-hunters."][[91 50 1] "And all the time numberless fowls were diving, and ducking, and"][[91 50 2] "screaming, and yelling, and fighting around them. Stubb was beginning"][[91 50 3] "to look disappointed, especially as the horrible nosegay increased, when"][[91 50 4] "suddenly from out the very heart of this plague, there stole a faint"][[91 50 5] "stream of perfume, which flowed through the tide of bad smells without"][[91 50 6] "being absorbed by it, as one river will flow into and then along with"][[91 50 7] "another, without at all blending with it for a time."][[91 51 1] "\"I have it, I have it,\" cried Stubb, with delight, striking something in"][[91 51 2] "the subterranean regions, \"a purse! a purse!\""][[91 52 1] "Dropping his spade, he thrust both hands in, and drew out handfuls"][[91 52 2] "of something that looked like ripe Windsor soap, or rich mottled old"][[91 52 3] "cheese; very unctuous and savory withal. You might easily dent it with"][[91 52 4] "your thumb; it is of a hue between yellow and ash colour. And this, good"][[91 52 5] "friends, is ambergris, worth a gold guinea an ounce to any druggist."][[91 52 6] "Some six handfuls were obtained; but more was unavoidably lost in the"][[91 52 7] "sea, and still more, perhaps, might have been secured were it not for"][[91 52 8] "impatient Ahab's loud command to Stubb to desist, and come on board,"][[91 52 9] "else the ship would bid them good bye."][[92 0 0] "CHAPTER 92. Ambergris."][[92 2 1] "Now this ambergris is a very curious substance, and so important as"][[92 2 2] "an article of commerce, that in  a certain Nantucket-born Captain"][[92 2 3] "Coffin was examined at the bar of the English House of Commons on that"][[92 2 4] "subject. For at that time, and indeed until a comparatively late day,"][[92 2 5] "the precise origin of ambergris remained, like amber itself, a problem"][[92 2 6] "to the learned. Though the word ambergris is but the French compound for"][[92 2 7] "grey amber, yet the two substances are quite distinct. For amber, though"][[92 2 8] "at times found on the sea-coast, is also dug up in some far inland"][[92 2 9] "soils, whereas ambergris is never found except upon the sea. Besides,"][[92 2 10] "amber is a hard, transparent, brittle, odorless substance, used for"][[92 2 11] "mouth-pieces to pipes, for beads and ornaments; but ambergris is soft,"][[92 2 12] "waxy, and so highly fragrant and spicy, that it is largely used in"][[92 2 13] "perfumery, in pastiles, precious candles, hair-powders, and pomatum."][[92 2 14] "The Turks use it in cooking, and also carry it to Mecca, for the same"][[92 2 15] "purpose that frankincense is carried to St. Peter's in Rome. Some wine"][[92 2 16] "merchants drop a few grains into claret, to flavor it."][[92 3 1] "Who would think, then, that such fine ladies and gentlemen should regale"][[92 3 2] "themselves with an essence found in the inglorious bowels of a sick"][[92 3 3] "whale! Yet so it is. By some, ambergris is supposed to be the cause, and"][[92 3 4] "by others the effect, of the dyspepsia in the whale. How to cure such"][[92 3 5] "a dyspepsia it were hard to say, unless by administering three or four"][[92 3 6] "boat loads of Brandreth's pills, and then running out of harm's way, as"][[92 3 7] "laborers do in blasting rocks."][[92 4 1] "I have forgotten to say that there were found in this ambergris, certain"][[92 4 2] "hard, round, bony plates, which at first Stubb thought might be sailors'"][[92 4 3] "trowsers buttons; but it afterwards turned out that they were nothing"][[92 4 4] "more than pieces of small squid bones embalmed in that manner."][[92 5 1] "Now that the incorruption of this most fragrant ambergris should be"][[92 5 2] "found in the heart of such decay; is this nothing? Bethink thee of that"][[92 5 3] "saying of St. Paul in Corinthians, about corruption and incorruption;"][[92 5 4] "how that we are sown in dishonour, but raised in glory. And likewise"][[92 5 5] "call to mind that saying of Paracelsus about what it is that maketh"][[92 5 6] "the best musk. Also forget not the strange fact that of all things of"][[92 5 7] "ill-savor, Cologne-water, in its rudimental manufacturing stages, is the"][[92 5 8] "worst."][[92 6 1] "I should like to conclude the chapter with the above appeal, but cannot,"][[92 6 2] "owing to my anxiety to repel a charge often made against whalemen,"][[92 6 3] "and which, in the estimation of some already biased minds, might be"][[92 6 4] "considered as indirectly substantiated by what has been said of"][[92 6 5] "the Frenchman's two whales. Elsewhere in this volume the slanderous"][[92 6 6] "aspersion has been disproved, that the vocation of whaling is throughout"][[92 6 7] "a slatternly, untidy business. But there is another thing to rebut. They"][[92 6 8] "hint that all whales always smell bad. Now how did this odious stigma"][[92 6 9] "originate?"][[92 7 1] "I opine, that it is plainly traceable to the first arrival of the"][[92 7 2] "Greenland whaling ships in London, more than two centuries ago. Because"][[92 7 3] "those whalemen did not then, and do not now, try out their oil at sea as"][[92 7 4] "the Southern ships have always done; but cutting up the fresh blubber in"][[92 7 5] "small bits, thrust it through the bung holes of large casks, and carry"][[92 7 6] "it home in that manner; the shortness of the season in those Icy Seas,"][[92 7 7] "and the sudden and violent storms to which they are exposed, forbidding"][[92 7 8] "any other course. The consequence is, that upon breaking into the hold,"][[92 7 9] "and unloading one of these whale cemeteries, in the Greenland dock, a"][[92 7 10] "savor is given forth somewhat similar to that arising from excavating an"][[92 7 11] "old city grave-yard, for the foundations of a Lying-in-Hospital."][[92 8 1] "I partly surmise also, that this wicked charge against whalers may be"][[92 8 2] "likewise imputed to the existence on the coast of Greenland, in former"][[92 8 3] "times, of a Dutch village called Schmerenburgh or Smeerenberg, which"][[92 8 4] "latter name is the one used by the learned Fogo Von Slack, in his great"][[92 8 5] "work on Smells, a text-book on that subject. As its name imports (smeer,"][[92 8 6] "fat; berg, to put up), this village was founded in order to afford a"][[92 8 7] "place for the blubber of the Dutch whale fleet to be tried out, without"][[92 8 8] "being taken home to Holland for that purpose. It was a collection of"][[92 8 9] "furnaces, fat-kettles, and oil sheds; and when the works were in full"][[92 8 10] "operation certainly gave forth no very pleasant savor. But all this is"][[92 8 11] "quite different with a South Sea Sperm Whaler; which in a voyage of four"][[92 8 12] "years perhaps, after completely filling her hold with oil, does not,"][[92 8 13] "perhaps, consume fifty days in the business of boiling out; and in the"][[92 8 14] "state that it is casked, the oil is nearly scentless. The truth is, that"][[92 8 15] "living or dead, if but decently treated, whales as a species are by"][[92 8 16] "no means creatures of ill odor; nor can whalemen be recognised, as the"][[92 8 17] "people of the middle ages affected to detect a Jew in the company, by"][[92 8 18] "the nose. Nor indeed can the whale possibly be otherwise than fragrant,"][[92 8 19] "when, as a general thing, he enjoys such high health; taking abundance"][[92 8 20] "of exercise; always out of doors; though, it is true, seldom in the"][[92 8 21] "open air. I say, that the motion of a Sperm Whale's flukes above water"][[92 8 22] "dispenses a perfume, as when a musk-scented lady rustles her dress in a"][[92 8 23] "warm parlor. What then shall I liken the Sperm Whale to for fragrance,"][[92 8 24] "considering his magnitude? Must it not be to that famous elephant, with"][[92 8 25] "jewelled tusks, and redolent with myrrh, which was led out of an Indian"][[92 8 26] "town to do honour to Alexander the Great?"][[93 0 0] "CHAPTER 93. The Castaway."][[93 2 1] "It was but some few days after encountering the Frenchman, that a most"][[93 2 2] "significant event befell the most insignificant of the Pequod's crew; an"][[93 2 3] "event most lamentable; and which ended in providing the sometimes"][[93 2 4] "madly merry and predestinated craft with a living and ever accompanying"][[93 2 5] "prophecy of whatever shattered sequel might prove her own."][[93 3 1] "Now, in the whale ship, it is not every one that goes in the boats. Some"][[93 3 2] "few hands are reserved called ship-keepers, whose province it is to work"][[93 3 3] "the vessel while the boats are pursuing the whale. As a general thing,"][[93 3 4] "these ship-keepers are as hardy fellows as the men comprising the boats'"][[93 3 5] "crews. But if there happen to be an unduly slender, clumsy, or timorous"][[93 3 6] "wight in the ship, that wight is certain to be made a ship-keeper. It"][[93 3 7] "was so in the Pequod with the little negro Pippin by nick-name, Pip by"][[93 3 8] "abbreviation. Poor Pip! ye have heard of him before; ye must remember"][[93 3 9] "his tambourine on that dramatic midnight, so gloomy-jolly."][[93 4 1] "In outer aspect, Pip and Dough-Boy made a match, like a black pony and a"][[93 4 2] "white one, of equal developments, though of dissimilar colour, driven in"][[93 4 3] "one eccentric span. But while hapless Dough-Boy was by nature dull and"][[93 4 4] "torpid in his intellects, Pip, though over tender-hearted, was at bottom"][[93 4 5] "very bright, with that pleasant, genial, jolly brightness peculiar to"][[93 4 6] "his tribe; a tribe, which ever enjoy all holidays and festivities with"][[93 4 7] "finer, freer relish than any other race. For blacks, the year's calendar"][[93 4 8] "should show naught but three hundred and sixty-five Fourth of Julys and"][[93 4 9] "New Year's Days. Nor smile so, while I write that this little black was"][[93 4 10] "brilliant, for even blackness has its brilliancy; behold yon lustrous"][[93 4 11] "ebony, panelled in king's cabinets. But Pip loved life, and all life's"][[93 4 12] "peaceable securities; so that the panic-striking business in which he"][[93 4 13] "had somehow unaccountably become entrapped, had most sadly blurred his"][[93 4 14] "brightness; though, as ere long will be seen, what was thus temporarily"][[93 4 15] "subdued in him, in the end was destined to be luridly illumined by"][[93 4 16] "strange wild fires, that fictitiously showed him off to ten times the"][[93 4 17] "natural lustre with which in his native Tolland County in Connecticut,"][[93 4 18] "he had once enlivened many a fiddler's frolic on the green; and at"][[93 4 19] "melodious even-tide, with his gay ha-ha! had turned the round horizon"][[93 4 20] "into one star-belled tambourine. So, though in the clear air of day,"][[93 4 21] "suspended against a blue-veined neck, the pure-watered diamond drop"][[93 4 22] "will healthful glow; yet, when the cunning jeweller would show you"][[93 4 23] "the diamond in its most impressive lustre, he lays it against a gloomy"][[93 4 24] "ground, and then lights it up, not by the sun, but by some unnatural"][[93 4 25] "gases. Then come out those fiery effulgences, infernally superb; then"][[93 4 26] "the evil-blazing diamond, once the divinest symbol of the crystal skies,"][[93 4 27] "looks like some crown-jewel stolen from the King of Hell. But let us to"][[93 4 28] "the story."][[93 5 1] "It came to pass, that in the ambergris affair Stubb's after-oarsman"][[93 5 2] "chanced so to sprain his hand, as for a time to become quite maimed;"][[93 5 3] "and, temporarily, Pip was put into his place."][[93 6 1] "The first time Stubb lowered with him, Pip evinced much nervousness;"][[93 6 2] "but happily, for that time, escaped close contact with the whale; and"][[93 6 3] "therefore came off not altogether discreditably; though Stubb observing"][[93 6 4] "him, took care, afterwards, to exhort him to cherish his courageousness"][[93 6 5] "to the utmost, for he might often find it needful."][[93 7 1] "Now upon the second lowering, the boat paddled upon the whale; and as"][[93 7 2] "the fish received the darted iron, it gave its customary rap, which"][[93 7 3] "happened, in this instance, to be right under poor Pip's seat. The"][[93 7 4] "involuntary consternation of the moment caused him to leap, paddle in"][[93 7 5] "hand, out of the boat; and in such a way, that part of the slack whale"][[93 7 6] "line coming against his chest, he breasted it overboard with him, so as"][[93 7 7] "to become entangled in it, when at last plumping into the water. That"][[93 7 8] "instant the stricken whale started on a fierce run, the line swiftly"][[93 7 9] "straightened; and presto! poor Pip came all foaming up to the chocks"][[93 7 10] "of the boat, remorselessly dragged there by the line, which had taken"][[93 7 11] "several turns around his chest and neck."][[93 8 1] "Tashtego stood in the bows. He was full of the fire of the hunt. He"][[93 8 2] "hated Pip for a poltroon. Snatching the boat-knife from its sheath,"][[93 8 3] "he suspended its sharp edge over the line, and turning towards Stubb,"][[93 8 4] "exclaimed interrogatively, \"Cut?\" Meantime Pip's blue, choked face"][[93 8 5] "plainly looked, Do, for God's sake! All passed in a flash. In less than"][[93 8 6] "half a minute, this entire thing happened."][[93 9 1] "\"Damn him, cut!\" roared Stubb; and so the whale was lost and Pip was"][[93 9 2] "saved."][[93 10 1] "So soon as he recovered himself, the poor little negro was assailed"][[93 10 2] "by yells and execrations from the crew. Tranquilly permitting these"][[93 10 3] "irregular cursings to evaporate, Stubb then in a plain, business-like,"][[93 10 4] "but still half humorous manner, cursed Pip officially; and that done,"][[93 10 5] "unofficially gave him much wholesome advice. The substance was, Never"][[93 10 6] "jump from a boat, Pip, except--but all the rest was indefinite, as the"][[93 10 7] "soundest advice ever is. Now, in general, STICK TO THE BOAT, is your"][[93 10 8] "true motto in whaling; but cases will sometimes happen when LEAP FROM"][[93 10 9] "THE BOAT, is still better. Moreover, as if perceiving at last that if he"][[93 10 10] "should give undiluted conscientious advice to Pip, he would be leaving"][[93 10 11] "him too wide a margin to jump in for the future; Stubb suddenly dropped"][[93 10 12] "all advice, and concluded with a peremptory command, \"Stick to the boat,"][[93 10 13] "Pip, or by the Lord, I won't pick you up if you jump; mind that. We"][[93 10 14] "can't afford to lose whales by the likes of you; a whale would sell for"][[93 10 15] "thirty times what you would, Pip, in Alabama. Bear that in mind, and"][[93 10 16] "don't jump any more.\" Hereby perhaps Stubb indirectly hinted, that"][[93 10 17] "though man loved his fellow, yet man is a money-making animal, which"][[93 10 18] "propensity too often interferes with his benevolence."][[93 11 1] "But we are all in the hands of the Gods; and Pip jumped again. It was"][[93 11 2] "under very similar circumstances to the first performance; but this time"][[93 11 3] "he did not breast out the line; and hence, when the whale started to"][[93 11 4] "run, Pip was left behind on the sea, like a hurried traveller's trunk."][[93 11 5] "Alas! Stubb was but too true to his word. It was a beautiful, bounteous,"][[93 11 6] "blue day; the spangled sea calm and cool, and flatly stretching away,"][[93 11 7] "all round, to the horizon, like gold-beater's skin hammered out to the"][[93 11 8] "extremest. Bobbing up and down in that sea, Pip's ebon head showed"][[93 11 9] "like a head of cloves. No boat-knife was lifted when he fell so rapidly"][[93 11 10] "astern. Stubb's inexorable back was turned upon him; and the whale was"][[93 11 11] "winged. In three minutes, a whole mile of shoreless ocean was between"][[93 11 12] "Pip and Stubb. Out from the centre of the sea, poor Pip turned his"][[93 11 13] "crisp, curling, black head to the sun, another lonely castaway, though"][[93 11 14] "the loftiest and the brightest."][[93 12 1] "Now, in calm weather, to swim in the open ocean is as easy to the"][[93 12 2] "practised swimmer as to ride in a spring-carriage ashore. But the awful"][[93 12 3] "lonesomeness is intolerable. The intense concentration of self in the"][[93 12 4] "middle of such a heartless immensity, my God! who can tell it? Mark, how"][[93 12 5] "when sailors in a dead calm bathe in the open sea--mark how closely they"][[93 12 6] "hug their ship and only coast along her sides."][[93 13 1] "But had Stubb really abandoned the poor little negro to his fate? No; he"][[93 13 2] "did not mean to, at least. Because there were two boats in his wake,"][[93 13 3] "and he supposed, no doubt, that they would of course come up to Pip very"][[93 13 4] "quickly, and pick him up; though, indeed, such considerations towards"][[93 13 5] "oarsmen jeopardized through their own timidity, is not always manifested"][[93 13 6] "by the hunters in all similar instances; and such instances not"][[93 13 7] "unfrequently occur; almost invariably in the fishery, a coward, so"][[93 13 8] "called, is marked with the same ruthless detestation peculiar to"][[93 13 9] "military navies and armies."][[93 14 1] "But it so happened, that those boats, without seeing Pip, suddenly"][[93 14 2] "spying whales close to them on one side, turned, and gave chase; and"][[93 14 3] "Stubb's boat was now so far away, and he and all his crew so intent"][[93 14 4] "upon his fish, that Pip's ringed horizon began to expand around him"][[93 14 5] "miserably. By the merest chance the ship itself at last rescued him; but"][[93 14 6] "from that hour the little negro went about the deck an idiot; such, at"][[93 14 7] "least, they said he was. The sea had jeeringly kept his finite body"][[93 14 8] "up, but drowned the infinite of his soul. Not drowned entirely, though."][[93 14 9] "Rather carried down alive to wondrous depths, where strange shapes of"][[93 14 10] "the unwarped primal world glided to and fro before his passive eyes;"][[93 14 11] "and the miser-merman, Wisdom, revealed his hoarded heaps; and among the"][[93 14 12] "joyous, heartless, ever-juvenile eternities, Pip saw the multitudinous,"][[93 14 13] "God-omnipresent, coral insects, that out of the firmament of waters"][[93 14 14] "heaved the colossal orbs. He saw God's foot upon the treadle of the"][[93 14 15] "loom, and spoke it; and therefore his shipmates called him mad. So man's"][[93 14 16] "insanity is heaven's sense; and wandering from all mortal reason, man"][[93 14 17] "comes at last to that celestial thought, which, to reason, is absurd and"][[93 14 18] "frantic; and weal or woe, feels then uncompromised, indifferent as his"][[93 14 19] "God."][[93 15 1] "For the rest, blame not Stubb too hardly. The thing is common in that"][[93 15 2] "fishery; and in the sequel of the narrative, it will then be seen what"][[93 15 3] "like abandonment befell myself."][[94 0 0] "CHAPTER 94. A Squeeze of the Hand."][[94 2 1] "That whale of Stubb's, so dearly purchased, was duly brought to"][[94 2 2] "the Pequod's side, where all those cutting and hoisting operations"][[94 2 3] "previously detailed, were regularly gone through, even to the baling of"][[94 2 4] "the Heidelburgh Tun, or Case."][[94 3 1] "While some were occupied with this latter duty, others were employed"][[94 3 2] "in dragging away the larger tubs, so soon as filled with the sperm; and"][[94 3 3] "when the proper time arrived, this same sperm was carefully manipulated"][[94 3 4] "ere going to the try-works, of which anon."][[94 4 1] "It had cooled and crystallized to such a degree, that when, with several"][[94 4 2] "others, I sat down before a large Constantine's bath of it, I found"][[94 4 3] "it strangely concreted into lumps, here and there rolling about in the"][[94 4 4] "liquid part. It was our business to squeeze these lumps back into fluid."][[94 4 5] "A sweet and unctuous duty! No wonder that in old times this sperm was"][[94 4 6] "such a favourite cosmetic. Such a clearer! such a sweetener! such a"][[94 4 7] "softener! such a delicious molifier! After having my hands in it for"][[94 4 8] "only a few minutes, my fingers felt like eels, and began, as it were, to"][[94 4 9] "serpentine and spiralise."][[94 5 1] "As I sat there at my ease, cross-legged on the deck; after the bitter"][[94 5 2] "exertion at the windlass; under a blue tranquil sky; the ship under"][[94 5 3] "indolent sail, and gliding so serenely along; as I bathed my hands among"][[94 5 4] "those soft, gentle globules of infiltrated tissues, woven almost within"][[94 5 5] "the hour; as they richly broke to my fingers, and discharged all their"][[94 5 6] "opulence, like fully ripe grapes their wine; as I snuffed up that"][[94 5 7] "uncontaminated aroma,--literally and truly, like the smell of spring"][[94 5 8] "violets; I declare to you, that for the time I lived as in a musky"][[94 5 9] "meadow; I forgot all about our horrible oath; in that inexpressible"][[94 5 10] "sperm, I washed my hands and my heart of it; I almost began to credit"][[94 5 11] "the old Paracelsan superstition that sperm is of rare virtue in allaying"][[94 5 12] "the heat of anger; while bathing in that bath, I felt divinely free from"][[94 5 13] "all ill-will, or petulance, or malice, of any sort whatsoever."][[94 6 1] "Squeeze! squeeze! squeeze! all the morning long; I squeezed that sperm"][[94 6 2] "till I myself almost melted into it; I squeezed that sperm till a"][[94 6 3] "strange sort of insanity came over me; and I found myself unwittingly"][[94 6 4] "squeezing my co-laborers' hands in it, mistaking their hands for the"][[94 6 5] "gentle globules. Such an abounding, affectionate, friendly, loving"][[94 6 6] "feeling did this avocation beget; that at last I was continually"][[94 6 7] "squeezing their hands, and looking up into their eyes sentimentally; as"][[94 6 8] "much as to say,--Oh! my dear fellow beings, why should we longer cherish"][[94 6 9] "any social acerbities, or know the slightest ill-humor or envy! Come;"][[94 6 10] "let us squeeze hands all round; nay, let us all squeeze ourselves into"][[94 6 11] "each other; let us squeeze ourselves universally into the very milk and"][[94 6 12] "sperm of kindness."][[94 7 1] "Would that I could keep squeezing that sperm for ever! For now, since by"][[94 7 2] "many prolonged, repeated experiences, I have perceived that in all cases"][[94 7 3] "man must eventually lower, or at least shift, his conceit of attainable"][[94 7 4] "felicity; not placing it anywhere in the intellect or the fancy; but in"][[94 7 5] "the wife, the heart, the bed, the table, the saddle, the fireside, the"][[94 7 6] "country; now that I have perceived all this, I am ready to squeeze case"][[94 7 7] "eternally. In thoughts of the visions of the night, I saw long rows of"][[94 7 8] "angels in paradise, each with his hands in a jar of spermaceti."][[94 8 1] "Now, while discoursing of sperm, it behooves to speak of other things"][[94 8 2] "akin to it, in the business of preparing the sperm whale for the"][[94 8 3] "try-works."][[94 9 1] "First comes white-horse, so called, which is obtained from the tapering"][[94 9 2] "part of the fish, and also from the thicker portions of his flukes. It"][[94 9 3] "is tough with congealed tendons--a wad of muscle--but still contains"][[94 9 4] "some oil. After being severed from the whale, the white-horse is first"][[94 9 5] "cut into portable oblongs ere going to the mincer. They look much like"][[94 9 6] "blocks of Berkshire marble."][[94 10 1] "Plum-pudding is the term bestowed upon certain fragmentary parts of the"][[94 10 2] "whale's flesh, here and there adhering to the blanket of blubber, and"][[94 10 3] "often participating to a considerable degree in its unctuousness. It is"][[94 10 4] "a most refreshing, convivial, beautiful object to behold. As its name"][[94 10 5] "imports, it is of an exceedingly rich, mottled tint, with a bestreaked"][[94 10 6] "snowy and golden ground, dotted with spots of the deepest crimson and"][[94 10 7] "purple. It is plums of rubies, in pictures of citron. Spite of reason,"][[94 10 8] "it is hard to keep yourself from eating it. I confess, that once I stole"][[94 10 9] "behind the foremast to try it. It tasted something as I should conceive"][[94 10 10] "a royal cutlet from the thigh of Louis le Gros might have tasted,"][[94 10 11] "supposing him to have been killed the first day after the venison"][[94 10 12] "season, and that particular venison season contemporary with an"][[94 10 13] "unusually fine vintage of the vineyards of Champagne."][[94 11 1] "There is another substance, and a very singular one, which turns up in"][[94 11 2] "the course of this business, but which I feel it to be very puzzling"][[94 11 3] "adequately to describe. It is called slobgollion; an appellation"][[94 11 4] "original with the whalemen, and even so is the nature of the substance."][[94 11 5] "It is an ineffably oozy, stringy affair, most frequently found in the"][[94 11 6] "tubs of sperm, after a prolonged squeezing, and subsequent decanting."][[94 11 7] "I hold it to be the wondrously thin, ruptured membranes of the case,"][[94 11 8] "coalescing."][[94 12 1] "Gurry, so called, is a term properly belonging to right whalemen, but"][[94 12 2] "sometimes incidentally used by the sperm fishermen. It designates the"][[94 12 3] "dark, glutinous substance which is scraped off the back of the Greenland"][[94 12 4] "or right whale, and much of which covers the decks of those inferior"][[94 12 5] "souls who hunt that ignoble Leviathan."][[94 13 1] "Nippers. Strictly this word is not indigenous to the whale's vocabulary."][[94 13 2] "But as applied by whalemen, it becomes so. A whaleman's nipper is"][[94 13 3] "a short firm strip of tendinous stuff cut from the tapering part of"][[94 13 4] "Leviathan's tail: it averages an inch in thickness, and for the rest, is"][[94 13 5] "about the size of the iron part of a hoe. Edgewise moved along the"][[94 13 6] "oily deck, it operates like a leathern squilgee; and by nameless"][[94 13 7] "blandishments, as of magic, allures along with it all impurities."][[94 14 1] "But to learn all about these recondite matters, your best way is at once"][[94 14 2] "to descend into the blubber-room, and have a long talk with its inmates."][[94 14 3] "This place has previously been mentioned as the receptacle for the"][[94 14 4] "blanket-pieces, when stript and hoisted from the whale. When the proper"][[94 14 5] "time arrives for cutting up its contents, this apartment is a scene of"][[94 14 6] "terror to all tyros, especially by night. On one side, lit by a dull"][[94 14 7] "lantern, a space has been left clear for the workmen. They generally"][[94 14 8] "go in pairs,--a pike-and-gaffman and a spade-man. The whaling-pike is"][[94 14 9] "similar to a frigate's boarding-weapon of the same name. The gaff is"][[94 14 10] "something like a boat-hook. With his gaff, the gaffman hooks on to a"][[94 14 11] "sheet of blubber, and strives to hold it from slipping, as the ship"][[94 14 12] "pitches and lurches about. Meanwhile, the spade-man stands on the sheet"][[94 14 13] "itself, perpendicularly chopping it into the portable horse-pieces. This"][[94 14 14] "spade is sharp as hone can make it; the spademan's feet are shoeless;"][[94 14 15] "the thing he stands on will sometimes irresistibly slide away from"][[94 14 16] "him, like a sledge. If he cuts off one of his own toes, or one of his"][[94 14 17] "assistants', would you be very much astonished? Toes are scarce among"][[94 14 18] "veteran blubber-room men."][[95 0 0] "CHAPTER 95. The Cassock."][[95 2 1] "Had you stepped on board the Pequod at a certain juncture of this"][[95 2 2] "post-mortemizing of the whale; and had you strolled forward nigh the"][[95 2 3] "windlass, pretty sure am I that you would have scanned with no small"][[95 2 4] "curiosity a very strange, enigmatical object, which you would have seen"][[95 2 5] "there, lying along lengthwise in the lee scuppers. Not the wondrous"][[95 2 6] "cistern in the whale's huge head; not the prodigy of his unhinged lower"][[95 2 7] "jaw; not the miracle of his symmetrical tail; none of these would so"][[95 2 8] "surprise you, as half a glimpse of that unaccountable cone,--longer than"][[95 2 9] "a Kentuckian is tall, nigh a foot in diameter at the base, and jet-black"][[95 2 10] "as Yojo, the ebony idol of Queequeg. And an idol, indeed, it is; or,"][[95 2 11] "rather, in old times, its likeness was. Such an idol as that found in"][[95 2 12] "the secret groves of Queen Maachah in Judea; and for worshipping which,"][[95 2 13] "King Asa, her son, did depose her, and destroyed the idol, and burnt it"][[95 2 14] "for an abomination at the brook Kedron, as darkly set forth in the th"][[95 2 15] "chapter of the First Book of Kings."][[95 3 1] "Look at the sailor, called the mincer, who now comes along, and assisted"][[95 3 2] "by two allies, heavily backs the grandissimus, as the mariners call it,"][[95 3 3] "and with bowed shoulders, staggers off with it as if he were a grenadier"][[95 3 4] "carrying a dead comrade from the field. Extending it upon the forecastle"][[95 3 5] "deck, he now proceeds cylindrically to remove its dark pelt, as an"][[95 3 6] "African hunter the pelt of a boa. This done he turns the pelt inside"][[95 3 7] "out, like a pantaloon leg; gives it a good stretching, so as almost to"][[95 3 8] "double its diameter; and at last hangs it, well spread, in the rigging,"][[95 3 9] "to dry. Ere long, it is taken down; when removing some three feet of it,"][[95 3 10] "towards the pointed extremity, and then cutting two slits for arm-holes"][[95 3 11] "at the other end, he lengthwise slips himself bodily into it. The mincer"][[95 3 12] "now stands before you invested in the full canonicals of his calling."][[95 3 13] "Immemorial to all his order, this investiture alone will adequately"][[95 3 14] "protect him, while employed in the peculiar functions of his office."][[95 4 1] "That office consists in mincing the horse-pieces of blubber for the"][[95 4 2] "pots; an operation which is conducted at a curious wooden horse, planted"][[95 4 3] "endwise against the bulwarks, and with a capacious tub beneath it, into"][[95 4 4] "which the minced pieces drop, fast as the sheets from a rapt orator's"][[95 4 5] "desk. Arrayed in decent black; occupying a conspicuous pulpit; intent"][[95 4 6] "on bible leaves; what a candidate for an archbishopric, what a lad for a"][[95 4 7] "Pope were this mincer!*"][[95 6 1] "*Bible leaves! Bible leaves! This is the invariable cry from the mates"][[95 6 2] "to the mincer. It enjoins him to be careful, and cut his work into as"][[95 6 3] "thin slices as possible, inasmuch as by so doing the business of"][[95 6 4] "boiling out the oil is much accelerated, and its quantity considerably"][[95 6 5] "increased, besides perhaps improving it in quality."][[96 0 0] "CHAPTER 96. The Try-Works."][[96 2 1] "Besides her hoisted boats, an American whaler is outwardly distinguished"][[96 2 2] "by her try-works. She presents the curious anomaly of the most solid"][[96 2 3] "masonry joining with oak and hemp in constituting the completed ship."][[96 2 4] "It is as if from the open field a brick-kiln were transported to her"][[96 2 5] "planks."][[96 3 1] "The try-works are planted between the foremast and mainmast, the most"][[96 3 2] "roomy part of the deck. The timbers beneath are of a peculiar strength,"][[96 3 3] "fitted to sustain the weight of an almost solid mass of brick and"][[96 3 4] "mortar, some ten feet by eight square, and five in height. The"][[96 3 5] "foundation does not penetrate the deck, but the masonry is firmly"][[96 3 6] "secured to the surface by ponderous knees of iron bracing it on all"][[96 3 7] "sides, and screwing it down to the timbers. On the flanks it is cased"][[96 3 8] "with wood, and at top completely covered by a large, sloping, battened"][[96 3 9] "hatchway. Removing this hatch we expose the great try-pots, two in"][[96 3 10] "number, and each of several barrels' capacity. When not in use, they are"][[96 3 11] "kept remarkably clean. Sometimes they are polished with soapstone"][[96 3 12] "and sand, till they shine within like silver punch-bowls. During the"][[96 3 13] "night-watches some cynical old sailors will crawl into them and coil"][[96 3 14] "themselves away there for a nap. While employed in polishing them--one"][[96 3 15] "man in each pot, side by side--many confidential communications"][[96 3 16] "are carried on, over the iron lips. It is a place also for profound"][[96 3 17] "mathematical meditation. It was in the left hand try-pot of the Pequod,"][[96 3 18] "with the soapstone diligently circling round me, that I was first"][[96 3 19] "indirectly struck by the remarkable fact, that in geometry all bodies"][[96 3 20] "gliding along the cycloid, my soapstone for example, will descend from"][[96 3 21] "any point in precisely the same time."][[96 4 1] "Removing the fire-board from the front of the try-works, the bare"][[96 4 2] "masonry of that side is exposed, penetrated by the two iron mouths of"][[96 4 3] "the furnaces, directly underneath the pots. These mouths are fitted"][[96 4 4] "with heavy doors of iron. The intense heat of the fire is prevented"][[96 4 5] "from communicating itself to the deck, by means of a shallow reservoir"][[96 4 6] "extending under the entire inclosed surface of the works. By a tunnel"][[96 4 7] "inserted at the rear, this reservoir is kept replenished with water as"][[96 4 8] "fast as it evaporates. There are no external chimneys; they open direct"][[96 4 9] "from the rear wall. And here let us go back for a moment."][[96 5 1] "It was about nine o'clock at night that the Pequod's try-works were"][[96 5 2] "first started on this present voyage. It belonged to Stubb to oversee"][[96 5 3] "the business."][[96 6 1] "\"All ready there? Off hatch, then, and start her. You cook, fire the"][[96 6 2] "works.\" This was an easy thing, for the carpenter had been thrusting his"][[96 6 3] "shavings into the furnace throughout the passage. Here be it said that"][[96 6 4] "in a whaling voyage the first fire in the try-works has to be fed for a"][[96 6 5] "time with wood. After that no wood is used, except as a means of quick"][[96 6 6] "ignition to the staple fuel. In a word, after being tried out, the"][[96 6 7] "crisp, shrivelled blubber, now called scraps or fritters, still contains"][[96 6 8] "considerable of its unctuous properties. These fritters feed the flames."][[96 6 9] "Like a plethoric burning martyr, or a self-consuming misanthrope, once"][[96 6 10] "ignited, the whale supplies his own fuel and burns by his own body."][[96 6 11] "Would that he consumed his own smoke! for his smoke is horrible to"][[96 6 12] "inhale, and inhale it you must, and not only that, but you must live in"][[96 6 13] "it for the time. It has an unspeakable, wild, Hindoo odor about it, such"][[96 6 14] "as may lurk in the vicinity of funereal pyres. It smells like the left"][[96 6 15] "wing of the day of judgment; it is an argument for the pit."][[96 7 1] "By midnight the works were in full operation. We were clear from the"][[96 7 2] "carcase; sail had been made; the wind was freshening; the wild ocean"][[96 7 3] "darkness was intense. But that darkness was licked up by the fierce"][[96 7 4] "flames, which at intervals forked forth from the sooty flues, and"][[96 7 5] "illuminated every lofty rope in the rigging, as with the famed Greek"][[96 7 6] "fire. The burning ship drove on, as if remorselessly commissioned to"][[96 7 7] "some vengeful deed. So the pitch and sulphur-freighted brigs of the"][[96 7 8] "bold Hydriote, Canaris, issuing from their midnight harbors, with broad"][[96 7 9] "sheets of flame for sails, bore down upon the Turkish frigates, and"][[96 7 10] "folded them in conflagrations."][[96 8 1] "The hatch, removed from the top of the works, now afforded a wide hearth"][[96 8 2] "in front of them. Standing on this were the Tartarean shapes of the"][[96 8 3] "pagan harpooneers, always the whale-ship's stokers. With huge pronged"][[96 8 4] "poles they pitched hissing masses of blubber into the scalding pots, or"][[96 8 5] "stirred up the fires beneath, till the snaky flames darted, curling, out"][[96 8 6] "of the doors to catch them by the feet. The smoke rolled away in sullen"][[96 8 7] "heaps. To every pitch of the ship there was a pitch of the boiling oil,"][[96 8 8] "which seemed all eagerness to leap into their faces. Opposite the mouth"][[96 8 9] "of the works, on the further side of the wide wooden hearth, was the"][[96 8 10] "windlass. This served for a sea-sofa. Here lounged the watch, when not"][[96 8 11] "otherwise employed, looking into the red heat of the fire, till their"][[96 8 12] "eyes felt scorched in their heads. Their tawny features, now all"][[96 8 13] "begrimed with smoke and sweat, their matted beards, and the contrasting"][[96 8 14] "barbaric brilliancy of their teeth, all these were strangely revealed in"][[96 8 15] "the capricious emblazonings of the works. As they narrated to each other"][[96 8 16] "their unholy adventures, their tales of terror told in words of mirth;"][[96 8 17] "as their uncivilized laughter forked upwards out of them, like the"][[96 8 18] "flames from the furnace; as to and fro, in their front, the harpooneers"][[96 8 19] "wildly gesticulated with their huge pronged forks and dippers; as the"][[96 8 20] "wind howled on, and the sea leaped, and the ship groaned and dived, and"][[96 8 21] "yet steadfastly shot her red hell further and further into the blackness"][[96 8 22] "of the sea and the night, and scornfully champed the white bone in"][[96 8 23] "her mouth, and viciously spat round her on all sides; then the rushing"][[96 8 24] "Pequod, freighted with savages, and laden with fire, and burning"][[96 8 25] "a corpse, and plunging into that blackness of darkness, seemed the"][[96 8 26] "material counterpart of her monomaniac commander's soul."][[96 9 1] "So seemed it to me, as I stood at her helm, and for long hours silently"][[96 9 2] "guided the way of this fire-ship on the sea. Wrapped, for that interval,"][[96 9 3] "in darkness myself, I but the better saw the redness, the madness, the"][[96 9 4] "ghastliness of others. The continual sight of the fiend shapes before"][[96 9 5] "me, capering half in smoke and half in fire, these at last begat kindred"][[96 9 6] "visions in my soul, so soon as I began to yield to that unaccountable"][[96 9 7] "drowsiness which ever would come over me at a midnight helm."][[96 10 1] "But that night, in particular, a strange (and ever since inexplicable)"][[96 10 2] "thing occurred to me. Starting from a brief standing sleep, I was"][[96 10 3] "horribly conscious of something fatally wrong. The jaw-bone tiller smote"][[96 10 4] "my side, which leaned against it; in my ears was the low hum of sails,"][[96 10 5] "just beginning to shake in the wind; I thought my eyes were open; I"][[96 10 6] "was half conscious of putting my fingers to the lids and mechanically"][[96 10 7] "stretching them still further apart. But, spite of all this, I could see"][[96 10 8] "no compass before me to steer by; though it seemed but a minute since I"][[96 10 9] "had been watching the card, by the steady binnacle lamp illuminating it."][[96 10 10] "Nothing seemed before me but a jet gloom, now and then made ghastly by"][[96 10 11] "flashes of redness. Uppermost was the impression, that whatever swift,"][[96 10 12] "rushing thing I stood on was not so much bound to any haven ahead as"][[96 10 13] "rushing from all havens astern. A stark, bewildered feeling, as of"][[96 10 14] "death, came over me. Convulsively my hands grasped the tiller, but with"][[96 10 15] "the crazy conceit that the tiller was, somehow, in some enchanted way,"][[96 10 16] "inverted. My God! what is the matter with me? thought I. Lo! in my brief"][[96 10 17] "sleep I had turned myself about, and was fronting the ship's stern, with"][[96 10 18] "my back to her prow and the compass. In an instant I faced back, just"][[96 10 19] "in time to prevent the vessel from flying up into the wind, and very"][[96 10 20] "probably capsizing her. How glad and how grateful the relief from this"][[96 10 21] "unnatural hallucination of the night, and the fatal contingency of being"][[96 10 22] "brought by the lee!"][[96 11 1] "Look not too long in the face of the fire, O man! Never dream with thy"][[96 11 2] "hand on the helm! Turn not thy back to the compass; accept the first"][[96 11 3] "hint of the hitching tiller; believe not the artificial fire, when its"][[96 11 4] "redness makes all things look ghastly. To-morrow, in the natural sun,"][[96 11 5] "the skies will be bright; those who glared like devils in the forking"][[96 11 6] "flames, the morn will show in far other, at least gentler, relief; the"][[96 11 7] "glorious, golden, glad sun, the only true lamp--all others but liars!"][[96 12 1] "Nevertheless the sun hides not Virginia's Dismal Swamp, nor Rome's"][[96 12 2] "accursed Campagna, nor wide Sahara, nor all the millions of miles of"][[96 12 3] "deserts and of griefs beneath the moon. The sun hides not the ocean,"][[96 12 4] "which is the dark side of this earth, and which is two thirds of this"][[96 12 5] "earth. So, therefore, that mortal man who hath more of joy than sorrow"][[96 12 6] "in him, that mortal man cannot be true--not true, or undeveloped. With"][[96 12 7] "books the same. The truest of all men was the Man of Sorrows, and the"][[96 12 8] "truest of all books is Solomon's, and Ecclesiastes is the fine hammered"][[96 12 9] "steel of woe. \"All is vanity.\" ALL. This wilful world hath not got hold"][[96 12 10] "of unchristian Solomon's wisdom yet. But he who dodges hospitals and"][[96 12 11] "jails, and walks fast crossing graveyards, and would rather talk of"][[96 12 12] "operas than hell; calls Cowper, Young, Pascal, Rousseau, poor devils all"][[96 12 13] "of sick men; and throughout a care-free lifetime swears by Rabelais as"][[96 12 14] "passing wise, and therefore jolly;--not that man is fitted to sit"][[96 12 15] "down on tomb-stones, and break the green damp mould with unfathomably"][[96 12 16] "wondrous Solomon."][[96 13 1] "But even Solomon, he says, \"the man that wandereth out of the way"][[96 13 2] "of understanding shall remain\" (I.E., even while living) \"in the"][[96 13 3] "congregation of the dead.\" Give not thyself up, then, to fire, lest it"][[96 13 4] "invert thee, deaden thee; as for the time it did me. There is a wisdom"][[96 13 5] "that is woe; but there is a woe that is madness. And there is a Catskill"][[96 13 6] "eagle in some souls that can alike dive down into the blackest gorges,"][[96 13 7] "and soar out of them again and become invisible in the sunny spaces."][[96 13 8] "And even if he for ever flies within the gorge, that gorge is in the"][[96 13 9] "mountains; so that even in his lowest swoop the mountain eagle is still"][[96 13 10] "higher than other birds upon the plain, even though they soar."][[97 0 0] "CHAPTER 97. The Lamp."][[97 2 1] "Had you descended from the Pequod's try-works to the Pequod's"][[97 2 2] "forecastle, where the off duty watch were sleeping, for one single"][[97 2 3] "moment you would have almost thought you were standing in some"][[97 2 4] "illuminated shrine of canonized kings and counsellors. There they lay"][[97 2 5] "in their triangular oaken vaults, each mariner a chiselled muteness; a"][[97 2 6] "score of lamps flashing upon his hooded eyes."][[97 3 1] "In merchantmen, oil for the sailor is more scarce than the milk of"][[97 3 2] "queens. To dress in the dark, and eat in the dark, and stumble in"][[97 3 3] "darkness to his pallet, this is his usual lot. But the whaleman, as he"][[97 3 4] "seeks the food of light, so he lives in light. He makes his berth an"][[97 3 5] "Aladdin's lamp, and lays him down in it; so that in the pitchiest night"][[97 3 6] "the ship's black hull still houses an illumination."][[97 4 1] "See with what entire freedom the whaleman takes his handful of"][[97 4 2] "lamps--often but old bottles and vials, though--to the copper cooler at"][[97 4 3] "the try-works, and replenishes them there, as mugs of ale at a vat. He"][[97 4 4] "burns, too, the purest of oil, in its unmanufactured, and, therefore,"][[97 4 5] "unvitiated state; a fluid unknown to solar, lunar, or astral"][[97 4 6] "contrivances ashore. It is sweet as early grass butter in April. He"][[97 4 7] "goes and hunts for his oil, so as to be sure of its freshness and"][[97 4 8] "genuineness, even as the traveller on the prairie hunts up his own"][[97 4 9] "supper of game."][[98 0 0] "CHAPTER 98. Stowing Down and Clearing Up."][[98 2 1] "Already has it been related how the great leviathan is afar off"][[98 2 2] "descried from the mast-head; how he is chased over the watery moors, and"][[98 2 3] "slaughtered in the valleys of the deep; how he is then towed alongside"][[98 2 4] "and beheaded; and how (on the principle which entitled the headsman of"][[98 2 5] "old to the garments in which the beheaded was killed) his great padded"][[98 2 6] "surtout becomes the property of his executioner; how, in due time, he"][[98 2 7] "is condemned to the pots, and, like Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, his"][[98 2 8] "spermaceti, oil, and bone pass unscathed through the fire;--but now it"][[98 2 9] "remains to conclude the last chapter of this part of the description by"][[98 2 10] "rehearsing--singing, if I may--the romantic proceeding of decanting off"][[98 2 11] "his oil into the casks and striking them down into the hold, where"][[98 2 12] "once again leviathan returns to his native profundities, sliding along"][[98 2 13] "beneath the surface as before; but, alas! never more to rise and blow."][[98 3 1] "While still warm, the oil, like hot punch, is received into the"][[98 3 2] "six-barrel casks; and while, perhaps, the ship is pitching and rolling"][[98 3 3] "this way and that in the midnight sea, the enormous casks are slewed"][[98 3 4] "round and headed over, end for end, and sometimes perilously scoot"][[98 3 5] "across the slippery deck, like so many land slides, till at last"][[98 3 6] "man-handled and stayed in their course; and all round the hoops, rap,"][[98 3 7] "rap, go as many hammers as can play upon them, for now, EX OFFICIO,"][[98 3 8] "every sailor is a cooper."][[98 4 1] "At length, when the last pint is casked, and all is cool, then the great"][[98 4 2] "hatchways are unsealed, the bowels of the ship are thrown open, and down"][[98 4 3] "go the casks to their final rest in the sea. This done, the hatches are"][[98 4 4] "replaced, and hermetically closed, like a closet walled up."][[98 5 1] "In the sperm fishery, this is perhaps one of the most remarkable"][[98 5 2] "incidents in all the business of whaling. One day the planks stream with"][[98 5 3] "freshets of blood and oil; on the sacred quarter-deck enormous masses of"][[98 5 4] "the whale's head are profanely piled; great rusty casks lie about, as"][[98 5 5] "in a brewery yard; the smoke from the try-works has besooted all the"][[98 5 6] "bulwarks; the mariners go about suffused with unctuousness; the entire"][[98 5 7] "ship seems great leviathan himself; while on all hands the din is"][[98 5 8] "deafening."][[98 6 1] "But a day or two after, you look about you, and prick your ears in this"][[98 6 2] "self-same ship; and were it not for the tell-tale boats and try-works,"][[98 6 3] "you would all but swear you trod some silent merchant vessel, with a"][[98 6 4] "most scrupulously neat commander. The unmanufactured sperm oil possesses"][[98 6 5] "a singularly cleansing virtue. This is the reason why the decks never"][[98 6 6] "look so white as just after what they call an affair of oil. Besides,"][[98 6 7] "from the ashes of the burned scraps of the whale, a potent lye is"][[98 6 8] "readily made; and whenever any adhesiveness from the back of the whale"][[98 6 9] "remains clinging to the side, that lye quickly exterminates it. Hands"][[98 6 10] "go diligently along the bulwarks, and with buckets of water and rags"][[98 6 11] "restore them to their full tidiness. The soot is brushed from the lower"][[98 6 12] "rigging. All the numerous implements which have been in use are likewise"][[98 6 13] "faithfully cleansed and put away. The great hatch is scrubbed and placed"][[98 6 14] "upon the try-works, completely hiding the pots; every cask is out of"][[98 6 15] "sight; all tackles are coiled in unseen nooks; and when by the combined"][[98 6 16] "and simultaneous industry of almost the entire ship's company, the"][[98 6 17] "whole of this conscientious duty is at last concluded, then the crew"][[98 6 18] "themselves proceed to their own ablutions; shift themselves from top to"][[98 6 19] "toe; and finally issue to the immaculate deck, fresh and all aglow, as"][[98 6 20] "bridegrooms new-leaped from out the daintiest Holland."][[98 7 1] "Now, with elated step, they pace the planks in twos and threes, and"][[98 7 2] "humorously discourse of parlors, sofas, carpets, and fine cambrics;"][[98 7 3] "propose to mat the deck; think of having hanging to the top; object not"][[98 7 4] "to taking tea by moonlight on the piazza of the forecastle. To hint to"][[98 7 5] "such musked mariners of oil, and bone, and blubber, were little short"][[98 7 6] "of audacity. They know not the thing you distantly allude to. Away, and"][[98 7 7] "bring us napkins!"][[98 8 1] "But mark: aloft there, at the three mast heads, stand three men intent"][[98 8 2] "on spying out more whales, which, if caught, infallibly will again"][[98 8 3] "soil the old oaken furniture, and drop at least one small grease-spot"][[98 8 4] "somewhere. Yes; and many is the time, when, after the severest"][[98 8 5] "uninterrupted labors, which know no night; continuing straight through"][[98 8 6] "for ninety-six hours; when from the boat, where they have swelled their"][[98 8 7] "wrists with all day rowing on the Line,--they only step to the deck to"][[98 8 8] "carry vast chains, and heave the heavy windlass, and cut and slash, yea,"][[98 8 9] "and in their very sweatings to be smoked and burned anew by the combined"][[98 8 10] "fires of the equatorial sun and the equatorial try-works; when, on the"][[98 8 11] "heel of all this, they have finally bestirred themselves to cleanse the"][[98 8 12] "ship, and make a spotless dairy room of it; many is the time the poor"][[98 8 13] "fellows, just buttoning the necks of their clean frocks, are startled by"][[98 8 14] "the cry of \"There she blows!\" and away they fly to fight another whale,"][[98 8 15] "and go through the whole weary thing again. Oh! my friends, but this"][[98 8 16] "is man-killing! Yet this is life. For hardly have we mortals by long"][[98 8 17] "toilings extracted from this world's vast bulk its small but valuable"][[98 8 18] "sperm; and then, with weary patience, cleansed ourselves from its"][[98 8 19] "defilements, and learned to live here in clean tabernacles of the soul;"][[98 8 20] "hardly is this done, when--THERE SHE BLOWS!--the ghost is spouted up,"][[98 8 21] "and away we sail to fight some other world, and go through young life's"][[98 8 22] "old routine again."][[98 9 1] "Oh! the metempsychosis! Oh! Pythagoras, that in bright Greece, two"][[98 9 2] "thousand years ago, did die, so good, so wise, so mild; I sailed with"][[98 9 3] "thee along the Peruvian coast last voyage--and, foolish as I am, taught"][[98 9 4] "thee, a green simple boy, how to splice a rope!"][[99 0 0] "CHAPTER 99. The Doubloon."][[99 2 1] "Ere now it has been related how Ahab was wont to pace his quarter-deck,"][[99 2 2] "taking regular turns at either limit, the binnacle and mainmast; but"][[99 2 3] "in the multiplicity of other things requiring narration it has not been"][[99 2 4] "added how that sometimes in these walks, when most plunged in his mood,"][[99 2 5] "he was wont to pause in turn at each spot, and stand there strangely"][[99 2 6] "eyeing the particular object before him. And some"][[99 3 5] "certain significance lurks in all things, else all things are little"][[99 3 6] "worth, and the round world itself but an empty cipher, except to sell by"][[99 3 7] "the cartload, as they do hills about Boston, to fill up some morass in"][[99 3 8] "the Milky Way."][[99 4 1] "Now this doubloon was of purest, virgin gold, raked somewhere out of the"][[99 4 2] "heart of gorgeous hills, whence, east and west, over golden sands, the"][[99 4 3] "head-waters of many a Pactolus flows. And though now nailed amidst all"][[99 4 4] "the rustiness of iron bolts and the verdigris of copper spikes, yet,"][[99 4 5] "untouchable and immaculate to any foulness, it still preserved its Quito"][[99 4 6] "glow. Nor, though placed amongst a ruthless crew and every hour passed"][[99 4 7] "by ruthless hands, and through the livelong nights shrouded with thick"][[99 4 8] "darkness which might cover any pilfering approach, nevertheless every"][[99 4 9] "sunrise found the doubloon where the sunset left it last. For it was"][[99 4 10] "set apart and sanctified to one awe-striking end; and however wanton"][[99 4 11] "in their sailor ways, one and all, the mariners revered it as the white"][[99 4 12] "whale's talisman. Sometimes they talked it over in the weary watch by"][[99 4 13] "night, wondering whose it was to be at last, and whether he would ever"][[99 4 14] "live to spend it."][[99 5 1] "Now those noble golden coins of South America are as medals of the sun"][[99 5 2] "and tropic token-pieces. Here palms, alpacas, and volcanoes; sun's disks"][[99 5 3] "and stars; ecliptics, horns-of-plenty, and rich banners waving, are in"][[99 5 4] "luxuriant profusion stamped; so that the precious gold seems almost to"][[99 5 5] "derive an added preciousness and enhancing glories, by passing through"][[99 5 6] "those fancy mints, so Spanishly poetic."][[99 6 1] "It so chanced that the doubloon of the Pequod was a most wealthy example"][[99 6 2] "of these things. On its round border it bore the letters, REPUBLICA DEL"][[99 6 3] "ECUADOR: QUITO. So this bright coin came from a country planted in the"][[99 6 4] "middle of the world, and beneath the great equator, and named after it;"][[99 6 5] "and it had been cast midway up the Andes, in the unwaning clime that"][[99 6 6] "knows no autumn. Leg and Arm."][[100 1 1] "The Pequod, of Nantucket, Meets the Samuel Enderby, of London."][[100 3 1] "\"Ship, ahoy! In the excitement of the"][[100 8 4] "moment, Ahab had forgotten that since the loss of his leg he had never"][[100 8 5] "once stepped on board of any vessel at sea but his own, and then it was"][[100 8 6] "always by an ingenious and very handy mechanical contrivance peculiar to"][[100 8 7] "the Pequod, and a thing not to be rigged and shipped in any other"][[100 8 8] "vessel at a moment's warning. Now, it is no very easy matter"][[100 8 9] "for anybody--except those who are almost hourly used to it, like"][[100 8 10] "whalemen--to clamber up a ship's side from a boat on the open sea; for"][[100 8 11] "the great swells now lift the boat high up towards the bulwarks, and"][[100 8 12] "then instantaneously drop it half way down to the kelson. So, deprived"][[100 8 13] "of one leg, and the strange ship of course being altogether unsupplied"][[100 8 14] "with the kindly invention, Ahab now found himself abjectly reduced to a"][[100 8 15] "clumsy landsman again; hopelessly eyeing the uncertain changeful height"][[100 8 16] "he could hardly hope to attain."][[100 9 1] "It has before been hinted, perhaps, that every little untoward"][[100 9 2] "circumstance that befell him, and which indirectly sprang from his"][[100 9 3] "luckless mishap, almost invariably irritated or exasperated Ahab. And"][[100 9 4] "in the present instance, all this was heightened by the sight of the"][[100 9 5] "two officers of the strange ship, leaning over the side, by the"][[100 9 6] "perpendicular ladder of nailed cleets there, and swinging towards him a"][[100 9 7] "pair of tastefully-ornamented man-ropes; for at first they did not seem"][[100 9 8] "to bethink them that a one-legged man must be too much of a cripple to"][[100 9 9] "use their sea bannisters. But this awkwardness only lasted a minute,"][[100 9 10] "because the strange captain, observing at a glance how affairs stood,"][[100 9 11] "cried out, \"I see, I see!--avast heaving there! Jump, boys, and swing"][[100 9 12] "over the cutting-tackle.\""][[100 10 1] "As good luck would have it, they had had a whale alongside a day or two"][[100 10 2] "previous, and the great tackles were still aloft, and the massive curved"][[100 10 3] "blubber-hook, now clean and dry, was still attached to the end. This"][[100 10 4] "was quickly lowered to Ahab, who at once comprehending it all, slid his"][[100 10 5] "solitary thigh into the curve of the hook (it was like sitting in the"][[100 10 6] "fluke of an anchor, or the crotch of an apple tree), and then giving the"][[100 10 7] "word, held himself fast, and at the same time also helped to hoist his"][[100 10 8] "own weight, by pulling hand-over-hand upon one of the running parts of"][[100 10 9] "the tackle. Soon he was carefully swung inside the high bulwarks, and"][[100 10 10] "gently landed upon the capstan head. With his ivory arm frankly thrust"][[100 10 11] "forth in welcome, the other captain advanced, and Ahab, putting out his"][[100 10 12] "ivory leg, and crossing the ivory arm (like two sword-fish blades)"][[100 10 13] "cried out in his walrus way, \"Aye, aye, hearty! let us shake bones"][[100 10 14] "together!--an arm and a leg!--an arm that never can shrink, d'ye"][[100 10 15] "see; and a leg that never can run. Where did'st thou see the White"][[100 10 16] "Whale?--how long ago?\""][[100 11 1] "\"The White Whale,\" said the Englishman, pointing his ivory arm towards"][[100 11 2] "the East, and taking a rueful sight along it, as if it had been a"][[100 11 3] "telescope; \"there I saw him, on the Line, last season.\""][[100 12 1] "\"And he took that arm off, did he?\" asked Ahab, now sliding down from"][[100 12 2] "the capstan, and resting on the Englishman's shoulder, as he did so."][[100 13 1] "\"Aye, he was the cause of it, at least; and that leg, too?\""][[100 14 1] "\"Spin me the yarn,\" said Ahab; \"how was it?\""][[100 15 1] "\"It was the first time in my life that I ever cruised on the Line,\""][[100 15 2] "began the Englishman. \"I was ignorant of the White Whale at that time."][[100 15 3] "Well, one day we lowered for a pod of four or five whales, and my boat"][[100 15 4] "fastened to one of them; a regular circus horse he was, too, that went"][[100 15 5] "milling and milling round so, that my boat's crew could only trim dish,"][[100 15 6] "by sitting all their sterns on the outer gunwale. Presently up breaches"][[100 15 7] "from the bottom of the sea a bouncing great whale, with a milky-white"][[100 15 8] "head and hump, all crows' feet and wrinkles.\""][[100 16 1] "\"It was he, it was he!\" cried Ahab, suddenly letting out his suspended"][[100 16 2] "breath."][[100 17 1] "\"And harpoons sticking in near his starboard fin.\""][[100 18 1] "\"Aye, aye--they were mine--MY irons,\" cried Ahab, exultingly--\"but on!\""][[100 19 1] "\"Give me a chance, then,\" said the Englishman, good-humoredly. \"Well,"][[100 19 2] "this old great-grandfather, with the white head and hump, runs all afoam"][[100 19 3] "into the pod, and goes to snapping furiously at my fast-line!"][[100 20 1] "\"Aye, I see!--wanted to part it; free the fast-fish--an old trick--I"][[100 20 2] "know him.\""][[100 21 1] "\"How it was exactly,\" continued the one-armed commander, \"I do not know;"][[100 21 2] "but in biting the line, it got foul of his teeth, caught there somehow;"][[100 21 3] "but we didn't know it then; so that when we afterwards pulled on the"][[100 21 4] "line, bounce we came plump on to his hump! instead of the other whale's;"][[100 21 5] "that went off to windward, all fluking. Seeing how matters stood, and"][[100 21 6] "what a noble great whale it was--the noblest and biggest I ever saw,"][[100 21 7] "sir, in my life--I resolved to capture him, spite of the boiling rage"][[100 21 8] "he seemed to be in. And thinking the hap-hazard line would get loose, or"][[100 21 9] "the tooth it was tangled to might draw (for I have a devil of a boat's"][[100 21 10] "crew for a pull on a whale-line); seeing all this, I say, I jumped"][[100 21 11] "into my first mate's boat--Mr. Mounttop's here (by the way,"][[100 21 12] "Captain--Mounttop; Mounttop--the captain);--as I was saying, I jumped"][[100 21 13] "into Mounttop's boat, which, d'ye see, was gunwale and gunwale"][[100 21 14] "with mine, then; and snatching the first harpoon, let this old"][[100 21 15] "great-grandfather have it. But, Lord, look you, sir--hearts and souls"][[100 21 16] "alive, man--the next instant, in a jiff, I was blind as a bat--both"][[100 21 17] "eyes out--all befogged and bedeadened with black foam--the whale's tail"][[100 21 18] "looming straight up out of it, perpendicular in the air, like a marble"][[100 21 19] "steeple. No use sterning all, then; but as I was groping at midday, with"][[100 21 20] "a blinding sun, all crown-jewels; as I was groping, I say, after the"][[100 21 21] "second iron, to toss it overboard--down comes the tail like a Lima"][[100 21 22] "tower, cutting my boat in two, leaving each half in splinters; and,"][[100 21 23] "flukes first, the white hump backed through the wreck, as though it was"][[100 21 24] "all chips. We all struck out. To escape his terrible flailings, I seized"][[100 21 25] "hold of my harpoon-pole sticking in him, and for a moment clung to that"][[100 21 26] "like a sucking fish. But a combing sea dashed me off, and at the same"][[100 21 27] "instant, the fish, taking one good dart forwards, went down like a"][[100 21 28] "flash; and the barb of that cursed second iron towing along near me"][[100 21 29] "caught me here\" (clapping his hand just below his shoulder); \"yes,"][[100 21 30] "caught me just here, I say, and bore me down to Hell's flames, I was"][[100 21 31] "thinking; when, when, all of a sudden, thank the good God, the barb ript"][[100 21 32] "its way along the flesh--clear along the whole length of my arm--came"][[100 21 33] "out nigh my wrist, and up I floated;--and that gentleman there will tell"][[100 21 34] "you the rest (by the way, captain--Dr. Bunger, ship's surgeon: Bunger,"][[100 21 35] "my lad,--the captain). Now, Bunger boy, spin your part of the yarn.\""][[100 22 1] "The professional gentleman thus familiarly pointed out, had been all the"][[100 22 2] "time standing near them, with nothing specific visible, to denote his"][[100 22 3] "gentlemanly rank on board. His face was an exceedingly round but sober"][[100 22 4] "one; he was dressed in a faded blue woollen frock or shirt, and patched"][[100 22 5] "trowsers; and had thus far been dividing his attention between a"][[100 22 6] "marlingspike he held in one hand, and a pill-box held in the other,"][[100 22 7] "occasionally casting a critical glance at the ivory limbs of the two"][[100 22 8] "crippled captains. But, at his superior's introduction of him to Ahab,"][[100 22 9] "he politely bowed, and straightway went on to do his captain's bidding."][[100 23 1] "\"It was a shocking bad wound,\" began the whale-surgeon; \"and, taking my"][[100 23 2] "advice, Captain Boomer here, stood our old Sammy--\""][[100 24 1] "\"Samuel Enderby is the name of my ship,\" interrupted the one-armed"][[100 24 2] "captain, addressing Ahab; \"go on, boy.\""][[100 25 1] "\"Stood our old Sammy off to the northward, to get out of the blazing hot"][[100 25 2] "weather there on the Line. (Bunger, you dog, laugh out! why"][[100 26 7] "don't ye? You know you're a precious jolly rascal.) I measured it with the lead line."][[100 29 6] "In short, it grew black; I knew what was threatened, and off it came."][[100 29 7] "But I had no hand in shipping that ivory arm there; that thing is"][[100 29 8] "against all rule\"--pointing at it with the marlingspike--\"that is the"][[100 29 9] "captain's work, not mine; he ordered the carpenter to make it; he had"][[100 29 10] "that club-hammer there put to the end, to knock some one's brains"][[100 29 11] "out with, I suppose, as he tried mine once. What should I do without"][[100 36 2] "this other arm? And I'm thinking Moby Dick doesn't bite so much as he"][[100 36 3] "swallows.\""][[100 37 1] "\"Well, then,\" interrupted Bunger, \"give him your left arm for bait to"][[100 37 2] "get the right. Do you know, gentlemen\"--very gravely and mathematically"][[100 37 3] "bowing to each Captain in succession--\"Do you know, gentlemen, that the"][[100 37 4] "digestive organs of the whale are so inscrutably constructed by Divine"][[100 37 5] "Providence, that it is quite impossible for him to completely digest"][[100 37 6] "even a man's arm? And he knows it too. So that what you take for the"][[100 37 7] "White Whale's malice is only his awkwardness. For he never means"][[100 37 8] "to swallow a single limb; he only thinks to terrify by feints. But"][[100 37 9] "sometimes he is like the old juggling fellow, formerly a patient of mine"][[100 37 10] "in Ceylon, that making believe swallow jack-knives, once upon a time let"][[100 37 11] "one drop into him in good earnest, and there it stayed for a twelvemonth"][[100 37 12] "or more; when I gave him an emetic, and he heaved it up in small tacks,"][[100 37 13] "d'ye see. No possible way for him to digest that jack-knife, and fully"][[100 37 14] "incorporate it into his general bodily system. Yes, Captain Boomer, if"][[100 37 15] "you are quick enough about it, and have a mind to pawn one arm for the"][[100 37 16] "sake of the privilege of giving decent burial to the other, why in that"][[100 37 17] "case the arm is yours; only let the whale have another chance at you"][[100 37 18] "shortly, that's all.\""][[100 38 1] "\"No, thank ye, Bunger,\" said the English Captain, \"he's welcome to the"][[100 38 2] "arm he has, since I can't help it, and didn't know him then; but not to"][[100 38 3] "another one. No more White Whales for me; I've lowered for him once, and"][[100 38 4] "that has satisfied me.
