How long since thou saw'st him last? Which way heading?\""][[100 40 1] "\"Bless my soul, and curse the foul fiend's,\" cried Bunger, stoopingly"][[100 40 2] "walking round Ahab, and like a dog, strangely snuffing; \"this man's"][[100 40 3] "blood--bring the thermometer!--it's at the boiling point!--his pulse"][[100 40 4] "makes these planks beat!--sir!\"--taking a lancet from his pocket, and"][[100 40 5] "drawing near to Ahab's arm."][[100 41 1] "\"Avast!\" roared Ahab, dashing him against the bulwarks--\"Man the boat!"][[100 41 2] "Which way heading?\""][[100 42 1] "\"Good God!\" cried the English Captain, to whom the question was put."][[100 42 2] "\"What's the matter? He was heading east, I think.--Is your Captain"][[100 42 3] "crazy?\" whispering Fedallah."][[100 43 1] "But Fedallah, putting a finger on his lip, slid over the bulwarks to"][[100 43 2] "take the boat's steering oar, and Ahab, swinging the cutting-tackle"][[100 43 3] "towards him, commanded the ship's sailors to stand by to lower."][[100 44 1] "In a moment he was standing in the boat's stern, and the Manilla men"][[100 44 2] "were springing to their oars. In vain the English Captain hailed him."][[100 44 3] "With back to the stranger ship, and face set like a flint to his own,"][[100 44 4] "Ahab stood upright till alongside of the Pequod."][[101 0 0] "CHAPTER 101. The Decanter."][[101 2 1] "Ere the English ship fades from sight, be it set down here, that"][[101 2 2] "she hailed from London, and was named after the late Samuel Enderby,"][[101 2 3] "merchant of that city, the original of the famous whaling house of"][[101 2 4] "Enderby & Sons; a house which in my poor whaleman's opinion, comes not"][[101 2 5] "far behind the united royal houses of the Tudors and Bourbons, in point"][[101 2 6] "of real historical interest. How long, prior to the year of our"][[101 2 7] "Lord , this great whaling house was in existence, my numerous"][[101 2 8] "fish-documents do not make plain; but in that year () it fitted"][[101 2 9] "out the first English ships that ever regularly hunted the Sperm Whale;"][[101 2 10] "though for some score of years previous (ever since ) our valiant"][[101 2 11] "Coffins and Maceys of Nantucket and the Vineyard had in large fleets"][[101 2 12] "pursued that Leviathan, but only in the North and South Atlantic: not"][[101 2 13] "elsewhere. Be it distinctly recorded here, that the Nantucketers were"][[101 2 14] "the first among mankind to harpoon with civilized steel the great Sperm"][[101 2 15] "Whale; and that for half a century they were the only people of the"][[101 2 16] "whole globe who so harpooned him."][[101 3 1] "In , a fine ship, the Amelia, fitted out for the express purpose,"][[101 3 2] "and at the sole charge of the vigorous Enderbys, boldly rounded Cape"][[101 3 3] "Horn, and was the first among the nations to lower a whale-boat of any"][[101 3 4] "sort in the great South Sea. The voyage was a skilful and lucky one;"][[101 3 5] "and returning to her berth with her hold full of the precious sperm, the"][[101 3 6] "Amelia's example was soon followed by other ships, English and American,"][[101 3 7] "and thus the vast Sperm Whale grounds of the Pacific were thrown open."][[101 3 8] "But not content with this good deed, the indefatigable house again"][[101 3 9] "bestirred itself: Samuel and all his Sons--how many, their mother only"][[101 3 10] "knows--and under their immediate auspices, and partly, I think, at their"][[101 3 11] "expense, the British government was induced to send the sloop-of-war"][[101 3 12] "Rattler on a whaling voyage of discovery into the South Sea. Commanded"][[101 3 13] "by a naval Post-Captain, the Rattler made a rattling voyage of it, and"][[101 3 14] "did some service; how much does not appear. But this is not all. In"][[101 3 15] ", the same house fitted out a discovery whale ship of their own, to"][[101 3 16] "go on a tasting cruise to the remote waters of Japan. That ship--well"][[101 3 17] "called the \"Syren\"--made a noble experimental cruise; and it was thus"][[101 3 18] "that the great Japanese Whaling Ground first became generally known."][[101 3 19] "The Syren in this famous voyage was commanded by a Captain Coffin, a"][[101 3 20] "Nantucketer."][[101 4 1] "All honour to the Enderbies, therefore, whose house, I think, exists to"][[101 4 2] "the present day; though doubtless the original Samuel must long ago have"][[101 4 3] "slipped his cable for the great South Sea of the other world."][[101 5 1] "The ship named after him was worthy of the honour, being a very fast"][[101 5 2] "sailer and a noble craft every way. I boarded her once at midnight"][[101 5 3] "somewhere off the Patagonian coast, and drank good flip down in the"][[101 5 4] "forecastle. It was a fine gam we had, and they were all trumps--every"][[101 5 5] "soul on board. A short life to them, and a jolly death. And that fine"][[101 5 6] "gam I had--long, very long after old Ahab touched her planks with his"][[101 5 7] "ivory heel--it minds me of the noble, solid, Saxon hospitality of that"][[101 5 8] "ship; and may my parson forget me, and the devil remember me, if I ever"][[101 5 9] "lose sight of it. Flip? Did I say we had flip? Yes, and we flipped it"][[101 5 10] "at the rate of ten gallons the hour; and when the squall came (for it's"][[101 5 11] "squally off there by Patagonia), and all hands--visitors and all--were"][[101 5 12] "called to reef topsails, we were so top-heavy that we had to swing each"][[101 5 13] "other aloft in bowlines; and we ignorantly furled the skirts of our"][[101 5 14] "jackets into the sails, so that we hung there, reefed fast in the"][[101 5 15] "howling gale, a warning example to all drunken tars. However, the masts"][[101 5 16] "did not go overboard; and by and by we scrambled down, so sober, that we"][[101 5 17] "had to pass the flip again, though the savage salt spray bursting down"][[101 5 18] "the forecastle scuttle, rather too much diluted and pickled it to my"][[101 5 19] "taste."][[101 6 1] "The beef was fine--tough, but with body in it. They said it was"][[101 6 2] "bull-beef; others, that it was dromedary beef; but I do not know, for"][[101 6 3] "certain, how that was. They had dumplings too; small, but substantial,"][[101 6 4] "symmetrically globular, and indestructible dumplings. I fancied that you"][[101 6 5] "could feel them, and roll them about in you after they were swallowed."][[101 6 6] "If you stooped over too far forward, you risked their pitching out"][[101 6 7] "of you like billiard-balls. The bread--but that couldn't be helped;"][[101 6 8] "besides, it was an anti-scorbutic; in short, the bread contained the"][[101 6 9] "only fresh fare they had. But the forecastle was not very light, and it"][[101 6 10] "was very easy to step over into a dark corner when you ate it. But all"][[101 6 11] "in all, taking her from truck to helm, considering the dimensions of the"][[101 6 12] "cook's boilers, including his own live parchment boilers; fore and aft,"][[101 6 13] "I say, the Samuel Enderby was a jolly ship; of good fare and plenty;"][[101 6 14] "fine flip and strong; crack fellows all, and capital from boot heels to"][[101 6 15] "hat-band."][[101 7 1] "But why was it, think ye, that the Samuel Enderby, and some other"][[101 7 2] "English whalers I know of--not all though--were such famous, hospitable"][[101 7 3] "ships; that passed round the beef, and the bread, and the can, and the"][[101 7 4] "joke; and were not soon weary of eating, and drinking, and laughing?"][[101 7 5] "I will tell you. The abounding good cheer of these English whalers"][[101 7 6] "is matter for historical research. Nor have I been at all sparing of"][[101 7 7] "historical whale research, when it has seemed needed."][[101 8 1] "The English were preceded in the whale fishery by the Hollanders,"][[101 8 2] "Zealanders, and Danes; from whom they derived many terms still extant"][[101 8 3] "in the fishery; and what is yet more, their fat old fashions,"][[101 8 4] "touching plenty to eat and drink. For, as a general thing, the English"][[101 8 5] "merchant-ship scrimps her crew; but not so the English whaler. Hence, in"][[101 8 6] "the English, this thing of whaling good cheer is not normal and natural,"][[101 8 7] "but incidental and particular; and, therefore, must have some special"][[101 8 8] "origin, which is here pointed out, and will be still further elucidated."][[101 9 1] "During my researches in the Leviathanic histories, I stumbled upon an"][[101 9 2] "ancient Dutch volume, which, by the musty whaling smell of it, I"][[101 9 3] "knew must be about whalers. The title was, \"Dan Coopman,\" wherefore I"][[101 9 4] "concluded that this must be the invaluable memoirs of some Amsterdam"][[101 9 5] "cooper in the fishery, as every whale ship must carry its cooper. I was"][[101 9 6] "reinforced in this opinion by seeing that it was the production of one"][[101 9 7] "\"Fitz Swackhammer.\" But my friend Dr. Snodhead, a very learned man,"][[101 9 8] "professor of Low Dutch and High German in the college of Santa Claus and"][[101 9 9] "St. Pott's, to whom I handed the work for translation, giving him a box"][[101 9 10] "of sperm candles for his trouble--this same Dr. Snodhead, so soon as he"][[101 9 11] "spied the book, assured me that \"Dan Coopman\" did not mean \"The Cooper,\""][[101 9 12] "but \"The Merchant.\" In short, this ancient and learned Low Dutch book"][[101 9 13] "treated of the commerce of Holland; and, among other subjects, contained"][[101 9 14] "a very interesting account of its whale fishery. And in this chapter it"][[101 9 15] "was, headed, \"Smeer,\" or \"Fat,\" that I found a long detailed list of the"][[101 9 16] "outfits for the larders and cellars of  sail of Dutch whalemen; from"][[101 9 17] "which list, as translated by Dr. Snodhead, I transcribe the following:"][[101 10 1] ", lbs. of beef. , lbs. Friesland pork. , lbs. of stock"][[101 10 2] "fish. , lbs. of biscuit. , lbs. of soft bread. , firkins"][[101 10 3] "of butter. , lbs. Texel & Leyden cheese. , lbs. cheese"][[101 10 4] "(probably an inferior article).  ankers of Geneva. , barrels of"][[101 10 5] "beer."][[101 11 1] "Most statistical tables are parchingly dry in the reading; not so in"][[101 11 2] "the present case, however, where the reader is flooded with whole pipes,"][[101 11 3] "barrels, quarts, and gills of good gin and good cheer."][[101 12 1] "At the time, I devoted three days to the studious digesting of all"][[101 12 2] "this beer, beef, and bread, during which many profound thoughts were"][[101 12 3] "incidentally suggested to me, capable of a transcendental and Platonic"][[101 12 4] "application; and, furthermore, I compiled supplementary tables of my"][[101 12 5] "own, touching the probable quantity of stock-fish, etc., consumed by"][[101 12 6] "every Low Dutch harpooneer in that ancient Greenland and Spitzbergen"][[101 12 7] "whale fishery. In the first place, the amount of butter, and Texel and"][[101 12 8] "Leyden cheese consumed, seems amazing. Now, as those"][[101 13 2] "polar fisheries could only be prosecuted in the short summer of that"][[101 13 3] "climate, so that the whole cruise of one of these Dutch whalemen,"][[101 13 4] "including the short voyage to and from the Spitzbergen sea, did not much"][[101 13 5] "exceed three months, say, and reckoning  men to each of their fleet"][[101 13 6] "of  sail, we have , Low Dutch seamen in all; therefore, I say,"][[101 13 7] "we have precisely two barrels of beer per man, for a twelve weeks'"][[101 13 8] "allowance, exclusive of his fair proportion of that  ankers of gin."][[101 13 9] "Now, whether these gin and beer harpooneers, so fuddled as one might"][[101 13 10] "fancy them to have been, were the right sort of men to stand up in"][[101 13 11] "a boat's head, and take good aim at flying whales; this would seem"][[101 13 12] "somewhat improbable. Yet they did aim at them, and hit them too. But"][[101 13 13] "this was very far North, be it remembered, where beer agrees well with"][[101 13 14] "the constitution; upon the Equator, in our southern fishery, beer would"][[101 13 15] "be apt to make the harpooneer sleepy at the mast-head and boozy in his"][[101 13 16] "boat; and grievous loss might ensue to Nantucket and New Bedford."][[101 14 1] "But no more; enough has been said to show that the old Dutch whalers"][[101 14 2] "of two or three centuries ago were high livers; and that the English"][[101 14 3] "whalers have not neglected so excellent an example. For, say they, when"][[101 14 4] "cruising in an empty ship, if you can get nothing better out of the"][[101 14 5] "world, get a good dinner out of it, at least. And this empties the"][[101 14 6] "decanter."][[102 0 0] "CHAPTER 102. A Bower in the Arsacides."][[102 2 1] "Hitherto, in descriptively treating of the Sperm Whale, I have chiefly"][[102 2 2] "dwelt upon the marvels of his outer aspect; or separately and in detail"][[102 2 3] "upon some few interior structural features. But to a large and thorough"][[102 2 4] "sweeping comprehension of him, it behooves me now to unbutton him still"][[102 2 5] "further, and untagging the points of his hose, unbuckling his garters,"][[102 2 6] "and casting loose the hooks and the eyes of the joints of his innermost"][[102 2 7] "bones, set him before you in his ultimatum; that is to say, in his"][[102 2 8] "unconditional skeleton."][[102 3 1] "But how now, Ishmael? How is it, that you, a mere oarsman in the"][[102 3 2] "fishery, pretend to know aught about the subterranean parts of the"][[102 3 3] "whale? Did erudite Stubb, mounted upon your capstan, deliver lectures"][[102 3 4] "on the anatomy of the Cetacea; and by help of the windlass, hold up a"][[102 3 5] "specimen rib for exhibition? Explain thyself, Ishmael. Can you land"][[102 3 6] "a full-grown whale on your deck for examination, as a cook dishes a"][[102 3 7] "roast-pig? Surely not. A veritable witness have you hitherto been,"][[102 3 8] "Ishmael; but have a care how you seize the privilege of Jonah alone;"][[102 3 9] "the privilege of discoursing upon the joists and beams; the rafters,"][[102 3 10] "ridge-pole, sleepers, and under-pinnings, making up the frame-work of"][[102 3 11] "leviathan; and belike of the tallow-vats, dairy-rooms, butteries, and"][[102 3 12] "cheeseries in his bowels."][[102 4 1] "I confess, that since Jonah, few whalemen have penetrated very far"][[102 4 2] "beneath the skin of the adult whale; nevertheless, I have been blessed"][[102 4 3] "with an opportunity to dissect him in miniature. In a ship I belonged"][[102 4 4] "to, a small cub Sperm Whale was once bodily hoisted to the deck for his"][[102 4 5] "poke or bag, to make sheaths for the barbs of the harpoons, and for the"][[102 4 6] "heads of the lances. Think you I let that chance go, without using my"][[102 4 7] "boat-hatchet and jack-knife, and breaking the seal and reading all the"][[102 4 8] "contents of that young cub?"][[102 5 1] "And as for my exact knowledge of the bones of the leviathan in their"][[102 5 2] "gigantic, full grown development, for that rare knowledge I am indebted"][[102 5 3] "to my late royal friend Tranquo, king of Tranque, one of the Arsacides."][[102 5 4] "For being at Tranque, years ago, when attached to the trading-ship Dey"][[102 5 5] "of Algiers, I was invited to spend part of the Arsacidean holidays with"][[102 5 6] "the lord of Tranque, at his retired palm villa at Pupella; a sea-side"][[102 5 7] "glen not very far distant from what our sailors called Bamboo-Town, his"][[102 5 8] "capital."][[102 6 1] "Among many other fine qualities, my royal friend Tranquo, being gifted"][[102 6 2] "with a devout love for all matters of barbaric vertu, had brought"][[102 6 3] "together in Pupella whatever rare things the more ingenious of his"][[102 6 4] "people could invent; chiefly carved woods of wonderful devices,"][[102 6 5] "chiselled shells, inlaid spears, costly paddles, aromatic canoes;"][[102 6 6] "and all these distributed among whatever natural wonders, the"][[102 6 7] "wonder-freighted, tribute-rendering waves had cast upon his shores."][[102 7 1] "Chief among these latter was a great Sperm Whale, which, after an"][[102 7 2] "unusually long raging gale, had been found dead and stranded, with his"][[102 7 3] "head against a cocoa-nut tree, whose plumage-like, tufted droopings"][[102 7 4] "seemed his verdant jet. When the vast body had at last been stripped of"][[102 7 5] "its fathom-deep enfoldings, and the bones become dust dry in the sun,"][[102 7 6] "then the skeleton was carefully transported up the Pupella glen, where a"][[102 7 7] "grand temple of lordly palms now sheltered it."][[102 8 1] "The ribs were hung with trophies; the vertebrae were carved with"][[102 8 2] "Arsacidean annals, in strange hieroglyphics; in the skull, the priests"][[102 8 3] "kept up an unextinguished aromatic flame, so that the mystic head"][[102 8 4] "again sent forth its vapoury spout; while, suspended from a bough, the"][[102 8 5] "terrific lower jaw vibrated over all the devotees, like the hair-hung"][[102 8 6] "sword that so affrighted Damocles."][[102 9 1] "It was a wondrous sight. The wood was green as mosses of the Icy"][[102 9 2] "Glen; the trees stood high and haughty, feeling their living sap; the"][[102 9 3] "industrious earth beneath was as a weaver's loom, with a gorgeous carpet"][[102 9 4] "on it, whereof the ground-vine tendrils formed the warp and woof, and"][[102 9 5] "the living flowers the figures. All the trees, with all their laden"][[102 9 6] "branches; all the shrubs, and ferns, and grasses; the message-carrying"][[102 9 7] "air; all these unceasingly were active. Through the lacings of the"][[102 9 8] "leaves, the great sun seemed a flying shuttle weaving the unwearied"][[102 9 9] "verdure. Oh, busy weaver! unseen weaver!--pause!--one word!--whither"][[102 9 10] "flows the fabric? what palace may it deck? wherefore all these ceaseless"][[102 9 11] "toilings? Speak, weaver!--stay thy hand!--but one single word with"][[102 9 12] "thee! Nay--the shuttle flies--the figures float from forth the loom; the"][[102 9 13] "freshet-rushing carpet for ever slides away. The weaver-god, he weaves;"][[102 9 14] "and by that weaving is he deafened, that he hears no mortal voice; and"][[102 9 15] "by that humming, we, too, who look on the loom are deafened; and only"][[102 9 16] "when we escape it shall we hear the thousand voices that speak through"][[102 9 17] "it. For even so it is in all material factories. The spoken words that"][[102 9 18] "are inaudible among the flying spindles; those same words are plainly"][[102 9 19] "heard without the walls, bursting from the opened casements. Thereby"][[102 9 20] "have villainies been detected. Ah, mortal! then, be heedful; for so, in"][[102 9 21] "all this din of the great world's loom, thy subtlest thinkings may be"][[102 9 22] "overheard afar."][[102 10 1] "Now, amid the green, life-restless loom of that Arsacidean wood, the"][[102 10 2] "great, white, worshipped skeleton lay lounging--a gigantic idler! Yet,"][[102 10 3] "as the ever-woven verdant warp and woof intermixed and hummed around"][[102 10 4] "him, the mighty idler seemed the cunning weaver; himself all woven"][[102 10 5] "over with the vines; every month assuming greener, fresher verdure; but"][[102 10 6] "himself a skeleton. Life folded Death; Death trellised Life; the grim"][[102 10 7] "god wived with youthful Life, and begat him curly-headed glories."][[102 11 1] "Now, when with royal Tranquo I visited this wondrous whale, and saw the"][[102 11 2] "skull an altar, and the artificial smoke ascending from where the real"][[102 11 3] "jet had issued, I marvelled that the king should regard a chapel as"][[102 11 4] "an object of vertu. He laughed. But more I marvelled that the priests"][[102 11 5] "should swear that smoky jet of his was genuine. To and fro I paced"][[102 11 6] "before this skeleton--brushed the vines aside--broke through the"][[102 11 7] "ribs--and with a ball of Arsacidean twine, wandered, eddied long amid"][[102 11 8] "its many winding, shaded colonnades and arbours. But soon my line was"][[102 11 9] "out; and following it back, I emerged from the opening where I entered."][[102 11 10] "I saw no living thing within; naught was there but bones."][[102 12 1] "Cutting me a green measuring-rod, I once more dived within the skeleton."][[102 12 2] "From their arrow-slit in the skull, the priests perceived me taking the"][[102 12 3] "altitude of the final rib, \"How now!\" they shouted; \"Dar'st thou measure"][[102 12 4] "this our god! That's for us.\" \"Aye, priests--well, how long do ye make"][[102 12 5] "him, then?\" But hereupon a fierce contest rose among them, concerning"][[102 12 6] "feet and inches; they cracked each other's sconces with their"][[102 12 7] "yard-sticks--the great skull echoed--and seizing that lucky chance, I"][[102 12 8] "quickly concluded my own admeasurements."][[102 13 1] "These admeasurements I now propose to set before you. But first, be"][[102 13 2] "it recorded, that, in this matter, I am not free to utter any fancied"][[102 13 3] "measurement I please. Because there are skeleton authorities you can"][[102 13 4] "refer to, to test my accuracy. There is a Leviathanic Museum, they tell"][[102 13 5] "me, in Hull, England, one of the whaling ports of that country, where"][[102 13 6] "they have some fine specimens of fin-backs and other whales. Likewise, I"][[102 13 7] "have heard that in the museum of Manchester, in New Hampshire, they have"][[102 13 8] "what the proprietors call \"the only perfect specimen of a Greenland or"][[102 13 9] "River Whale in the United States.\" Moreover, at a place in Yorkshire,"][[102 13 10] "England, Burton Constable by name, a certain Sir Clifford Constable has"][[102 13 11] "in his possession the skeleton of a Sperm Whale, but of moderate size,"][[102 13 12] "by no means of the full-grown magnitude of my friend King Tranquo's."][[102 14 1] "In both cases, the stranded whales to which these two skeletons"][[102 14 2] "belonged, were originally claimed by their proprietors upon similar"][[102 14 3] "grounds. King Tranquo seizing his because he wanted it; and Sir"][[102 14 4] "Clifford, because he was lord of the seignories of those parts. Sir"][[102 14 5] "Clifford's whale has been articulated throughout; so that, like a"][[102 14 6] "great chest of drawers, you can open and shut him, in all his bony"][[102 14 7] "cavities--spread out his ribs like a gigantic fan--and swing all day"][[102 14 8] "upon his lower jaw. Locks are to be put upon some of his trap-doors and"][[102 14 9] "shutters; and a footman will show round future visitors with a bunch of"][[102 14 10] "keys at his side. Sir Clifford thinks of charging twopence for a peep at"][[102 14 11] "the whispering gallery in the spinal column; threepence to hear the echo"][[102 14 12] "in the hollow of his cerebellum; and sixpence for the unrivalled view"][[102 14 13] "from his forehead."][[102 15 1] "The skeleton dimensions I shall now proceed to set down are copied"][[102 15 2] "verbatim from my right arm, where I had them tattooed; as in my wild"][[102 15 3] "wanderings at that period, there was no other secure way of preserving"][[102 15 4] "such valuable statistics. But as I was crowded for space, and wished"][[102 15 5] "the other parts of my body to remain a blank page for a poem I was"][[102 15 6] "then composing--at least, what untattooed parts might remain--I did not"][[102 15 7] "trouble myself with the odd inches; nor, indeed, should inches at all"][[102 15 8] "enter into a congenial admeasurement of the whale."][[103 0 0] "CHAPTER 103. Measurement of The Whale's Skeleton."][[103 2 1] "In the first place, I wish to lay before you a particular, plain"][[103 2 2] "statement, touching the living bulk of this leviathan, whose skeleton we"][[103 2 3] "are briefly to exhibit. Such a statement may prove useful here."][[103 3 1] "According to a careful calculation I have made, and which I partly base"][[103 3 2] "upon Captain Scoresby's estimate, of seventy tons for the largest"][[103 3 3] "sized Greenland whale of sixty feet in length; according to my careful"][[103 3 4] "calculation, I say, a Sperm Whale of the largest magnitude, between"][[103 3 5] "eighty-five and ninety feet in length, and something less than forty"][[103 3 6] "feet in its fullest circumference, such a whale will weigh at least"][[103 3 7] "ninety tons; so that, reckoning thirteen men to a ton, he would"][[103 3 8] "considerably outweigh the combined population of a whole village of one"][[103 3 9] "thousand one hundred inhabitants."][[103 4 1] "Think you not then that brains, like yoked cattle, should be put to this"][[103 4 2] "leviathan, to make him at all budge to any landsman's imagination?"][[103 5 1] "Having already in various ways put before you his skull, spout-hole,"][[103 5 2] "jaw, teeth, tail, forehead, fins, and divers other parts, I shall now"][[103 5 3] "simply point out what is most interesting in the general bulk of his"][[103 5 4] "unobstructed bones. But as the colossal skull embraces so very large"][[103 5 5] "a proportion of the entire extent of the skeleton; as it is by far the"][[103 5 6] "most complicated part; and as nothing is to be repeated concerning it in"][[103 5 7] "this chapter, you must not fail to carry it in your mind, or under your"][[103 5 8] "arm, as we proceed, otherwise you will not gain a complete notion of the"][[103 5 9] "general structure we are about to view."][[103 6 1] "In length, the Sperm Whale's skeleton at Tranque measured seventy-two"][[103 6 2] "Feet; so that when fully invested and extended in life, he must have"][[103 6 3] "been ninety feet long; for in the whale, the skeleton loses about one"][[103 6 4] "fifth in length compared with the living body. Of this seventy-two feet,"][[103 6 5] "his skull and jaw comprised some twenty feet, leaving some fifty feet of"][[103 6 6] "plain back-bone. Attached to this back-bone, for something less than a"][[103 6 7] "third of its length, was the mighty circular basket of ribs which once"][[103 6 8] "enclosed his vitals."][[103 7 1] "To me this vast ivory-ribbed chest, with the long, unrelieved spine,"][[103 7 2] "extending far away from it in a straight line, not a little resembled"][[103 7 3] "the hull of a great ship new-laid upon the stocks, when only some twenty"][[103 7 4] "of her naked bow-ribs are inserted, and the keel is otherwise, for the"][[103 7 5] "time, but a long, disconnected timber."][[103 8 1] "The ribs were ten on a side. The first, to begin from the neck,"][[103 8 2] "was nearly six feet long; the second, third, and fourth were each"][[103 8 3] "successively longer, till you came to the climax of the fifth, or one"][[103 8 4] "of the middle ribs, which measured eight feet and some inches. From"][[103 8 5] "that part, the remaining ribs diminished, till the tenth and last only"][[103 8 6] "spanned five feet and some inches. In general thickness, they all bore"][[103 8 7] "a seemly correspondence to their length. The middle ribs were the most"][[103 8 8] "arched. In some of the Arsacides they are used for beams whereon to lay"][[103 8 9] "footpath bridges over small streams."][[103 9 1] "In considering these ribs, I could not but be struck anew with the"][[103 9 2] "circumstance, so variously repeated in this book, that the skeleton of"][[103 9 3] "the whale is by no means the mould of his invested form. The largest of"][[103 9 4] "the Tranque ribs, one of the middle ones, occupied that part of the fish"][[103 9 5] "which, in life, is greatest in depth. Now, the greatest depth of the"][[103 9 6] "invested body of this particular whale must have been at least sixteen"][[103 9 7] "feet; whereas, the corresponding rib measured but little more than eight"][[103 9 8] "feet. So that this rib only conveyed half of the true notion of the"][[103 9 9] "living magnitude of that part. Besides, for some way, where I now saw"][[103 9 10] "but a naked spine, all that had been once wrapped round with tons of"][[103 9 11] "added bulk in flesh, muscle, blood, and bowels. Still more, for the"][[103 9 12] "ample fins, I here saw but a few disordered joints; and in place of the"][[103 9 13] "weighty and majestic, but boneless flukes, an utter blank!"][[103 10 1] "How vain and foolish, then, thought I, for timid untravelled man to try"][[103 10 2] "to comprehend aright this wondrous whale, by merely poring over his dead"][[103 10 3] "attenuated skeleton, stretched in this peaceful wood. No. Only in the"][[103 10 4] "heart of quickest perils; only when within the eddyings of his angry"][[103 10 5] "flukes; only on the profound unbounded sea, can the fully invested whale"][[103 10 6] "be truly and livingly found out."][[103 11 1] "But the spine. For that, the best way we can consider it is, with a"][[103 11 2] "crane, to pile its bones high up on end. No speedy enterprise. But now"][[103 11 3] "it's done, it looks much like Pompey's Pillar."][[103 12 1] "There are forty and odd vertebrae in all, which in the skeleton are"][[103 12 2] "not locked together. They mostly lie like the great knobbed blocks on"][[103 12 3] "a Gothic spire, forming solid courses of heavy masonry. The largest,"][[103 12 4] "a middle one, is in width something less than three feet, and in depth"][[103 12 5] "more than four. The smallest, where the spine tapers away into the"][[103 12 6] "tail, is only two inches in width, and looks something like a white"][[103 12 7] "billiard-ball. I was told that there were still smaller ones, but they"][[103 12 8] "had been lost by some little cannibal urchins, the priest's children,"][[103 12 9] "who had stolen them to play marbles with. Thus we see how that the"][[103 12 10] "spine of even the hugest of living things tapers off at last into simple"][[103 12 11] "child's play."][[104 0 0] "CHAPTER 104. The Fossil Whale."][[104 2 1] "From his mighty bulk the whale affords a most congenial theme whereon"][[104 2 2] "to enlarge, amplify, and generally expatiate. Would you, you could not"][[104 2 3] "compress him. By good rights he should only be treated of in imperial"][[104 2 4] "folio. Not to tell over again his furlongs from spiracle to tail,"][[104 2 5] "and the yards he measures about the waist; only think of the gigantic"][[104 2 6] "involutions of his intestines, where they lie in him like great"][[104 2 7] "cables and hawsers coiled away in the subterranean orlop-deck of a"][[104 2 8] "line-of-battle-ship."][[104 3 1] "Since I have undertaken to manhandle this Leviathan, it behooves me"][[104 3 2] "to approve myself omnisciently exhaustive in the enterprise; not"][[104 3 3] "overlooking the minutest seminal germs of his blood, and spinning him"][[104 3 4] "out to the uttermost coil of his bowels. Having already described him"][[104 3 5] "in most of his present habitatory and anatomical peculiarities, it"][[104 3 6] "now remains to magnify him in an archaeological, fossiliferous, and"][[104 3 7] "antediluvian point of view. Applied to any other creature than the"][[104 3 8] "Leviathan--to an ant or a flea--such portly terms might justly be deemed"][[104 3 9] "unwarrantably grandiloquent. But when Leviathan is the text, the case is"][[104 3 10] "altered. Fain am I to stagger to this emprise under the weightiest"][[104 3 11] "words of the dictionary. And here be it said, that whenever it has been"][[104 3 12] "convenient to consult one in the course of these dissertations, I have"][[104 3 13] "invariably used a huge quarto edition of Johnson, expressly purchased"][[104 3 14] "for that purpose; because that famous lexicographer's uncommon personal"][[104 3 15] "bulk more fitted him to compile a lexicon to be used by a whale author"][[104 3 16] "like me."][[104 4 1] "One often hears of writers that rise and swell with their subject,"][[104 4 2] "though it may seem but an ordinary one. How, then, with me, writing"][[104 4 3] "of this Leviathan? Unconsciously my chirography expands into placard"][[104 4 4] "capitals. Give me a condor's quill! Give me Vesuvius' crater for an"][[104 4 5] "inkstand! Friends, hold my arms! For in the mere act of penning my"][[104 4 6] "thoughts of this Leviathan, they weary me, and make me faint with their"][[104 4 7] "outreaching comprehensiveness of sweep, as if to include the whole"][[104 4 8] "circle of the sciences, and all the generations of whales, and men, and"][[104 4 9] "mastodons, past, present, and to come, with all the revolving panoramas"][[104 4 10] "of empire on earth, and throughout the whole universe, not excluding its"][[104 4 11] "suburbs. Such, and so magnifying, is the virtue of a large and liberal"][[104 4 12] "theme! We expand to its bulk. To produce a mighty book, you must choose"][[104 4 13] "a mighty theme. No great and enduring volume can ever be written on the"][[104 4 14] "flea, though many there be who have tried it."][[104 5 1] "Ere entering upon the subject of Fossil Whales, I present my credentials"][[104 5 2] "as a geologist, by stating that in my miscellaneous time I have been"][[104 5 3] "a stone-mason, and also a great digger of ditches, canals and wells,"][[104 5 4] "wine-vaults, cellars, and cisterns of all sorts. Likewise, by way of"][[104 5 5] "preliminary, I desire to remind the reader, that while in the earlier"][[104 5 6] "geological strata there are found the fossils of monsters now almost"][[104 5 7] "completely extinct; the subsequent relics discovered in what are called"][[104 5 8] "the Tertiary formations seem the connecting, or at any rate intercepted"][[104 5 9] "links, between the antichronical creatures, and those whose remote"][[104 5 10] "posterity are said to have entered the Ark; all the Fossil Whales"][[104 5 11] "hitherto discovered belong to the Tertiary period, which is the last"][[104 5 12] "preceding the superficial formations. And though none of them"][[104 5 13] "precisely answer to any known species of the present time, they are yet"][[104 5 14] "sufficiently akin to them in general respects, to justify their taking"][[104 5 15] "rank as Cetacean fossils."][[104 6 1] "Detached broken fossils of pre-adamite whales, fragments of their bones"][[104 6 2] "and skeletons, have within thirty years past, at various intervals, been"][[104 6 3] "found at the base of the Alps, in Lombardy, in France, in England, in"][[104 6 4] "Scotland, and in the States of Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama."][[104 6 5] "Among the more curious of such remains is part of a skull, which in the"][[104 6 6] "year  was disinterred in the Rue Dauphine in Paris, a short street"][[104 6 7] "opening almost directly upon the palace of the Tuileries; and bones"][[104 6 8] "disinterred in excavating the great docks of Antwerp, in Napoleon's"][[104 6 9] "time. Cuvier pronounced these fragments to have belonged to some utterly"][[104 6 10] "unknown Leviathanic species."][[104 7 1] "But by far the most wonderful of all Cetacean relics was the almost"][[104 7 2] "complete vast skeleton of an extinct monster, found in the year , on"][[104 7 3] "the plantation of Judge Creagh, in Alabama. The awe-stricken credulous"][[104 7 4] "slaves in the vicinity took it for the bones of one of the fallen"][[104 7 5] "angels. The Alabama doctors declared it a huge reptile, and bestowed"][[104 7 6] "upon it the name of Basilosaurus. But some specimen bones of it being"][[104 7 7] "taken across the sea to Owen, the English Anatomist, it turned out"][[104 7 8] "that this alleged reptile was a whale, though of a departed species. A"][[104 7 9] "significant illustration of the fact, again and again repeated in this"][[104 7 10] "book, that the skeleton of the whale furnishes but little clue to the"][[104 7 11] "shape of his fully invested body. So Owen rechristened the monster"][[104 7 12] "Zeuglodon; and in his paper read before the London Geological Society,"][[104 7 13] "pronounced it, in substance, one of the most extraordinary creatures"][[104 7 14] "which the mutations of the globe have blotted out of existence."][[104 8 1] "When I stand among these mighty Leviathan skeletons, skulls, tusks,"][[104 8 2] "jaws, ribs, and vertebrae, all characterized by partial resemblances to"][[104 8 3] "the existing breeds of sea-monsters; but at the same time bearing on"][[104 8 4] "the other hand similar affinities to the annihilated antichronical"][[104 8 5] "Leviathans, their incalculable seniors; I am, by a flood, borne back"][[104 8 6] "to that wondrous period, ere time itself can be said to have begun;"][[104 8 7] "for time began with man. Here Saturn's grey chaos rolls over me, and I"][[104 8 8] "obtain dim, shuddering glimpses into those Polar eternities; when wedged"][[104 8 9] "bastions of ice pressed hard upon what are now the Tropics; and in"][[104 8 10] "all the , miles of this world's circumference, not an inhabitable"][[104 8 11] "hand's breadth of land was visible. Then the whole world was the"][[104 8 12] "whale's; and, king of creation, he left his wake along the present lines"][[104 8 13] "of the Andes and the Himmalehs. Who can show a pedigree like Leviathan?"][[104 8 14] "Ahab's harpoon had shed older blood than the Pharaoh's. Methuselah seems"][[104 8 15] "a school-boy. I look round to shake hands with Shem. I am horror-struck"][[104 8 16] "at this antemosaic, unsourced existence of the unspeakable terrors of"][[104 8 17] "the whale, which, having been before all time, must needs exist after"][[104 8 18] "all humane ages are over."][[104 9 1] "But not alone has this Leviathan left his pre-adamite traces in the"][[104 9 2] "stereotype plates of nature, and in limestone and marl bequeathed his"][[104 9 3] "ancient bust; but upon Egyptian tablets, whose antiquity seems to claim"][[104 9 4] "for them an almost fossiliferous character, we find the unmistakable"][[104 9 5] "print of his fin. In an apartment of the great temple of Denderah,"][[104 9 6] "some fifty years ago, there was discovered upon the granite ceiling a"][[104 9 7] "sculptured and painted planisphere, abounding in centaurs, griffins, and"][[104 9 8] "dolphins, similar to the grotesque figures on the celestial globe of the"][[104 9 9] "moderns. Gliding among them, old Leviathan swam as of yore; was there"][[104 9 10] "swimming in that planisphere, centuries before Solomon was cradled."][[104 10 1] "Nor must there be omitted another strange attestation of the antiquity"][[104 10 2] "of the whale, in his own osseous post-diluvian reality, as set down by"][[104 10 3] "the venerable John Leo, the old Barbary traveller."][[104 11 1] "\"Not far from the Sea-side, they have a Temple, the Rafters and Beams"][[104 11 2] "of which are made of Whale-Bones; for Whales of a monstrous size are"][[104 11 3] "oftentimes cast up dead upon that shore. The Common People imagine, that"][[104 11 4] "by a secret Power bestowed by God upon the temple, no Whale can pass it"][[104 11 5] "without immediate death. But the truth of the Matter is, that on either"][[104 11 6] "side of the Temple, there are Rocks that shoot two Miles into the Sea,"][[104 11 7] "and wound the Whales when they light upon 'em. They keep a Whale's Rib"][[104 11 8] "of an incredible length for a Miracle, which lying upon the Ground with"][[104 11 9] "its convex part uppermost, makes an Arch, the Head of which cannot be"][[104 11 10] "reached by a Man upon a Camel's Back. This Rib (says John Leo) is said"][[104 11 11] "to have layn there a hundred Years before I saw it. Their Historians"][[104 11 12] "affirm, that a Prophet who prophesy'd of Mahomet, came from this Temple,"][[104 11 13] "and some do not stand to assert, that the Prophet Jonas was cast forth"][[104 11 14] "by the Whale at the Base of the Temple.\""][[104 12 1] "In this Afric Temple of the Whale I leave you, reader, and if you be a"][[104 12 2] "Nantucketer, and a whaleman, you will silently worship there."][[105 0 0] "CHAPTER 105. Does the Whale's Magnitude Diminish?--Will He Perish?"][[105 2 1] "Inasmuch, then, as this Leviathan comes floundering down upon us from"][[105 2 2] "the head-waters of the Eternities, it may be fitly inquired, whether,"][[105 2 3] "in the long course of his generations, he has not degenerated from the"][[105 2 4] "original bulk of his sires."][[105 3 1] "But upon investigation we find, that not only are the whales of the"][[105 3 2] "present day superior in magnitude to those whose fossil remains are"][[105 3 3] "found in the Tertiary system (embracing a distinct geological period"][[105 3 4] "prior to man), but of the whales found in that Tertiary system, those"][[105 3 5] "belonging to its latter formations exceed in size those of its earlier"][[105 3 6] "ones."][[105 4 1] "Of all the pre-adamite whales yet exhumed, by far the largest is the"][[105 4 2] "Alabama one mentioned in the last chapter, and that was less than"][[105 4 3] "seventy feet in length in the skeleton. Whereas, we have already seen,"][[105 4 4] "that the tape-measure gives seventy-two feet for the skeleton of a large"][[105 4 5] "sized modern whale. And I have heard, on whalemen's authority, that"][[105 4 6] "Sperm Whales have been captured near a hundred feet long at the time of"][[105 4 7] "capture."][[105 5 1] "But may it not be, that while the whales of the present hour are an"][[105 5 2] "advance in magnitude upon those of all previous geological periods; may"][[105 5 3] "it not be, that since Adam's time they have degenerated?"][[105 6 1] "Assuredly, we must conclude so, if we are to credit the accounts of such"][[105 6 2] "gentlemen as Pliny, and the ancient naturalists generally. For Pliny"][[105 6 3] "tells us of Whales that embraced acres of living bulk, and Aldrovandus"][[105 6 4] "of others which measured eight hundred feet in length--Rope Walks and"][[105 6 5] "Thames Tunnels of Whales! And even in the days of Banks and Solander,"][[105 6 6] "Cooke's naturalists, we find a Danish member of the Academy of Sciences"][[105 6 7] "setting down certain Iceland Whales (reydan-siskur, or Wrinkled Bellies)"][[105 6 8] "at one hundred and twenty yards; that is, three hundred and sixty feet."][[105 6 9] "And Lacepede, the French naturalist, in his elaborate history of whales,"][[105 6 10] "in the very beginning of his work (page ), sets down the Right Whale at"][[105 6 11] "one hundred metres, three hundred and twenty-eight feet. And this work"][[105 6 12] "was published so late as A.D. ."][[105 7 1] "But will any whaleman believe these stories? No. The whale of to-day is"][[105 7 2] "as big as his ancestors in Pliny's time. And if ever I go where Pliny"][[105 7 3] "is, I, a whaleman (more than he was), will make bold to tell him so."][[105 7 4] "Because I cannot understand how it is, that while the Egyptian mummies"][[105 7 5] "that were buried thousands of years before even Pliny was born, do not"][[105 7 6] "measure so much in their coffins as a modern Kentuckian in his socks;"][[105 7 7] "and while the cattle and other animals sculptured on the oldest Egyptian"][[105 7 8] "and Nineveh tablets, by the relative proportions in which they are"][[105 7 9] "drawn, just as plainly prove that the high-bred, stall-fed, prize cattle"][[105 7 10] "of Smithfield, not only equal, but far exceed in magnitude the fattest"][[105 7 11] "of Pharaoh's fat kine; in the face of all this, I will not admit that of"][[105 7 12] "all animals the whale alone should have degenerated."][[105 8 1] "But still another inquiry remains; one often agitated by the more"][[105 8 2] "recondite Nantucketers. Whether owing to the almost omniscient look-outs"][[105 8 3] "at the mast-heads of the whaleships, now penetrating even through"][[105 8 4] "Behring's straits, and into the remotest secret drawers and lockers"][[105 8 5] "of the world; and the thousand harpoons and lances darted along all"][[105 8 6] "continental coasts; the moot point is, whether Leviathan can long endure"][[105 8 7] "so wide a chase, and so remorseless a havoc; whether he must not at last"][[105 8 8] "be exterminated from the waters, and the last whale, like the last man,"][[105 8 9] "smoke his last pipe, and then himself evaporate in the final puff."][[105 9 1] "Comparing the humped herds of whales with the humped herds of buffalo,"][[105 9 2] "which, not forty years ago, overspread by tens of thousands the prairies"][[105 9 3] "of Illinois and Missouri, and shook their iron manes and scowled with"][[105 9 4] "their thunder-clotted brows upon the sites of populous river-capitals,"][[105 9 5] "where now the polite broker sells you land at a dollar an inch; in such"][[105 9 6] "a comparison an irresistible argument would seem furnished, to show that"][[105 9 7] "the hunted whale cannot now escape speedy extinction."][[105 10 1] "But you must look at this matter in every light. Though so short a"][[105 10 2] "period ago--not a good lifetime--the census of the buffalo in Illinois"][[105 10 3] "exceeded the census of men now in London, and though at the present day"][[105 10 4] "not one horn or hoof of them remains in all that region; and though the"][[105 10 5] "cause of this wondrous extermination was the spear of man; yet the far"][[105 10 6] "different nature of the whale-hunt peremptorily forbids so inglorious an"][[105 10 7] "end to the Leviathan. Forty men in one ship hunting the Sperm Whales for"][[105 10 8] "forty-eight months think they have done extremely well, and thank God,"][[105 10 9] "if at last they carry home the oil of forty fish. Whereas, in the days"][[105 10 10] "of the old Canadian and Indian hunters and trappers of the West, when"][[105 10 11] "the far west (in whose sunset suns still rise) was a wilderness and"][[105 10 12] "a virgin, the same number of moccasined men, for the same number of"][[105 10 13] "months, mounted on horse instead of sailing in ships, would have slain"][[105 10 14] "not forty, but forty thousand and more buffaloes; a fact that, if need"][[105 10 15] "were, could be statistically stated."][[105 11 1] "Nor, considered aright, does it seem any argument in favour of the"][[105 11 2] "gradual extinction of the Sperm Whale, for example, that in former years"][[105 11 3] "(the latter part of the last century, say) these Leviathans, in"][[105 11 4] "small pods, were encountered much oftener than at present, and, in"][[105 11 5] "consequence, the voyages were not so prolonged, and were also much more"][[105 11 6] "remunerative. Because, as has been elsewhere noticed, those whales,"][[105 11 7] "influenced by some views to safety, now swim the seas in immense"][[105 11 8] "caravans, so that to a large degree the scattered solitaries, yokes, and"][[105 11 9] "pods, and schools of other days are now aggregated into vast but widely"][[105 11 10] "separated, unfrequent armies. That is all. And equally fallacious seems"][[105 11 11] "the conceit, that because the so-called whale-bone whales no longer"][[105 11 12] "haunt many grounds in former years abounding with them, hence that"][[105 11 13] "species also is declining. For they are only being driven from"][[105 11 14] "promontory to cape; and if one coast is no longer enlivened with"][[105 11 15] "their jets, then, be sure, some other and remoter strand has been very"][[105 11 16] "recently startled by the unfamiliar spectacle."][[105 12 1] "Furthermore: concerning these last mentioned Leviathans, they have two"][[105 12 2] "firm fortresses, which, in all human probability, will for ever remain"][[105 12 3] "impregnable. And as upon the invasion of their valleys, the frosty Swiss"][[105 12 4] "have retreated to their mountains; so, hunted from the savannas and"][[105 12 5] "glades of the middle seas, the whale-bone whales can at last resort to"][[105 12 6] "their Polar citadels, and diving under the ultimate glassy barriers and"][[105 12 7] "walls there, come up among icy fields and floes; and in a charmed circle"][[105 12 8] "of everlasting December, bid defiance to all pursuit from man."][[105 13 1] "But as perhaps fifty of these whale-bone whales are harpooned for one"][[105 13 2] "cachalot, some philosophers of the forecastle have concluded that this"][[105 13 3] "positive havoc has already very seriously diminished their battalions."][[105 13 4] "But though for some time past a number of these whales, not less than"][[105 13 5] ",, have been annually slain on the nor'-west coast by the Americans"][[105 13 6] "alone; yet there are considerations which render even this circumstance"][[105 13 7] "of little or no account as an opposing argument in this matter."][[105 14 1] "Natural as it is to be somewhat incredulous concerning the populousness"][[105 14 2] "of the more enormous creatures of the globe, yet what shall we say to"][[105 14 3] "Harto, the historian of Goa, when he tells us that at one hunting the"][[105 14 4] "King of Siam took , elephants; that in those regions elephants are"][[105 14 5] "numerous as droves of cattle in the temperate climes. And there seems no"][[105 14 6] "reason to doubt that if these elephants, which have now been hunted for"][[105 14 7] "thousands of years, by Semiramis, by Porus, by Hannibal, and by all the"][[105 14 8] "successive monarchs of the East--if they still survive there in great"][[105 14 9] "numbers, much more may the great whale outlast all hunting, since he"][[105 14 10] "has a pasture to expatiate in, which is precisely twice as large as all"][[105 14 11] "Asia, both Americas, Europe and Africa, New Holland, and all the Isles"][[105 14 12] "of the sea combined."][[105 15 1] "Moreover: we are to consider, that from the presumed great longevity"][[105 15 2] "of whales, their probably attaining the age of a century and more,"][[105 15 3] "therefore at any one period of time, several distinct adult generations"][[105 15 4] "must be contemporary. And what that is, we may soon gain some idea"][[105 15 5] "of, by imagining all the grave-yards, cemeteries, and family vaults of"][[105 15 6] "creation yielding up the live bodies of all the men, women, and children"][[105 15 7] "who were alive seventy-five years ago; and adding this countless host to"][[105 15 8] "the present human population of the globe."][[105 16 1] "Wherefore, for all these things, we account the whale immortal in his"][[105 16 2] "species, however perishable in his individuality. He swam the seas"][[105 16 3] "before the continents broke water; he once swam over the site of the"][[105 16 4] "Tuileries, and Windsor Castle, and the Kremlin. In Noah's flood he"][[105 16 5] "despised Noah's Ark; and if ever the world is to be again flooded, like"][[105 16 6] "the Netherlands, to kill off its rats, then the eternal whale will still"][[105 16 7] "survive, and rearing upon the topmost crest of the equatorial flood,"][[105 16 8] "spout his frothed defiance to the skies."][[106 0 0] "CHAPTER 106. Ahab's Leg."][[106 2 1] "The precipitating manner in which Captain Ahab had quitted the Samuel"][[106 2 2] "Enderby of London, had not been unattended with some small violence to"][[106 2 3] "his own person. He had lighted with such energy upon a thwart of his"][[106 2 4] "boat that his ivory leg had received a half-splintering shock. And"][[106 2 5] "when after gaining his own deck, and his own pivot-hole there, he so"][[106 2 6] "vehemently wheeled round with an urgent command to the steersman (it"][[106 2 7] "was, as ever, something about his not steering inflexibly enough); then,"][[106 2 8] "the already shaken ivory received such an additional twist and wrench,"][[106 2 9] "that though it still remained entire, and to all appearances lusty, yet"][[106 2 10] "Ahab did not deem it entirely trustworthy."][[106 3 1] "And, indeed, it seemed small matter for wonder, that for all his"][[106 3 2] "pervading, mad recklessness, Ahab did at times give careful heed to the"][[106 3 3] "condition of that dead bone upon which he partly stood. For it had not"][[106 3 4] "been very long prior to the Pequod's sailing from Nantucket, that he"][[106 3 5] "had been found one night lying prone upon the ground, and insensible;"][[106 3 6] "by some unknown, and seemingly inexplicable, unimaginable casualty, his"][[106 3 7] "ivory limb having been so violently displaced, that it had stake-wise"][[106 3 8] "smitten, and all but pierced his groin; nor was it without extreme"][[106 3 9] "difficulty that the agonizing wound was entirely cured."][[106 4 1] "Nor, at the time, had it failed to enter his monomaniac mind, that all"][[106 4 2] "the anguish of that then present suffering was but the direct issue of a"][[106 4 3] "former woe; and he too plainly seemed to see, that as the most poisonous"][[106 4 4] "reptile of the marsh perpetuates his kind as inevitably as the sweetest"][[106 4 5] "songster of the grove; so, equally with every felicity, all miserable"][[106 4 6] "events do naturally beget their like. Yea, more than equally, thought"][[106 4 7] "Ahab; since both the ancestry and posterity of Grief go further than the"][[106 4 8] "ancestry and posterity of Joy. For, not to hint of this: that it is"][[106 4 9] "an inference from certain canonic teachings, that while some natural"][[106 4 10] "enjoyments here shall have no children born to them for the other world,"][[106 4 11] "but, on the contrary, shall be followed by the joy-childlessness of"][[106 4 12] "all hell's despair; whereas, some guilty mortal miseries shall still"][[106 4 13] "fertilely beget to themselves an eternally progressive progeny of griefs"][[106 4 14] "beyond the grave; not at all to hint of this, there still seems an"][[106 4 15] "inequality in the deeper analysis of the thing. For, thought Ahab, while"][[106 4 16] "even the highest earthly felicities ever have a certain unsignifying"][[106 4 17] "pettiness lurking in them, but, at bottom, all heartwoes, a mystic"][[106 4 18] "significance, and, in some men, an archangelic grandeur; so do their"][[106 4 19] "diligent tracings-out not belie the obvious deduction. To trail the"][[106 4 20] "genealogies of these high mortal miseries, carries us at last among the"][[106 4 21] "sourceless primogenitures of the gods; so that, in the face of all the"][[106 4 22] "glad, hay-making suns, and soft cymballing, round harvest-moons, we must"][[106 4 23] "needs give in to this: that the gods themselves are not for ever glad."][[106 4 24] "The ineffaceable, sad birth-mark in the brow of man, is but the stamp of"][[106 4 25] "sorrow in the signers."][[106 5 1] "Unwittingly here a secret has been divulged, which perhaps might more"][[106 5 2] "properly, in set way, have been disclosed before. With many other"][[106 5 3] "particulars concerning Ahab, always had it remained a mystery to some,"][[106 5 4] "why it was, that for a certain period, both before and after the sailing"][[106 5 5] "of the Pequod, he had hidden himself away with such Grand-Lama-like"][[106 5 6] "exclusiveness; and, for that one interval, sought speechless refuge, as"][[106 5 7] "it were, among the marble senate of the dead. Captain Peleg's bruited"][[106 5 8] "reason for this thing appeared by no means adequate; though, indeed,"][[106 5 9] "as touching all Ahab's deeper part, every revelation partook more of"][[106 5 10] "significant darkness than of explanatory light. But, in the end, it all"][[106 5 11] "came out; this one matter did, at least. That direful mishap was at"][[106 5 12] "the bottom of his temporary recluseness. And not only this, but to that"][[106 5 13] "ever-contracting, dropping circle ashore, who, for any reason, possessed"][[106 5 14] "the privilege of a less banned approach to him; to that timid circle the"][[106 5 15] "above hinted casualty--remaining, as it did, moodily unaccounted for by"][[106 5 16] "Ahab--invested itself with terrors, not entirely underived from the land"][[106 5 17] "of spirits and of wails. So that, through their zeal for him, they had"][[106 5 18] "all conspired, so far as in them lay, to muffle up the knowledge of"][[106 5 19] "this thing from others; and hence it was, that not till a considerable"][[106 5 20] "interval had elapsed, did it transpire upon the Pequod's decks."][[106 6 1] "But be all this as it may; let the unseen, ambiguous synod in the air,"][[106 6 2] "or the vindictive princes and potentates of fire, have to do or not"][[106 6 3] "with earthly Ahab, yet, in this present matter of his leg, he took plain"][[106 6 4] "practical procedures;--he called the carpenter."][[106 7 1] "And when that functionary appeared before him, he bade him without delay"][[106 7 2] "set about making a new leg, and directed the mates to see him supplied"][[106 7 3] "with all the studs and joists of jaw-ivory (Sperm Whale) which had thus"][[106 7 4] "far been accumulated on the voyage, in order that a careful selection"][[106 7 5] "of the stoutest, clearest-grained stuff might be secured. This done, the"][[106 7 6] "carpenter received orders to have the leg completed that night; and to"][[106 7 7] "provide all the fittings for it, independent of those pertaining to"][[106 7 8] "the distrusted one in use. Moreover, the ship's forge was ordered to be"][[106 7 9] "hoisted out of its temporary idleness in the hold; and, to accelerate"][[106 7 10] "the affair, the blacksmith was commanded to proceed at once to the"][[106 7 11] "forging of whatever iron contrivances might be needed."][[107 0 0] "CHAPTER 107. The Carpenter."][[107 2 1] "Seat thyself sultanically among the moons of Saturn, and take high"][[107 2 2] "abstracted man alone; and he seems a wonder, a grandeur, and a woe. But"][[107 2 3] "from the same point, take mankind in mass, and for the most part, they"][[107 2 4] "seem a mob of unnecessary duplicates, both contemporary and hereditary."][[107 2 5] "But most humble though he was, and far from furnishing an example of"][[107 2 6] "the high, humane abstraction; the Pequod's carpenter was no duplicate;"][[107 2 7] "hence, he now comes in person on this stage."][[107 3 1] "Like all sea-going ship carpenters, and more especially those belonging"][[107 3 2] "to whaling vessels, he was, to a certain off-handed, practical extent,"][[107 3 3] "alike experienced in numerous trades and callings collateral to his own;"][[107 3 4] "the carpenter's pursuit being the ancient and outbranching trunk of all"][[107 3 5] "those numerous handicrafts which more or less have to do with wood as an"][[107 3 6] "auxiliary material. But, besides the application to him of the generic"][[107 3 7] "remark above, this carpenter of the Pequod was singularly efficient in"][[107 3 8] "those thousand nameless mechanical emergencies continually recurring"][[107 3 9] "in a large ship, upon a three or four years' voyage, in uncivilized"][[107 3 10] "and far-distant seas. For not to speak of his readiness in ordinary"][[107 3 11] "duties:--repairing stove boats, sprung spars, reforming the shape of"][[107 3 12] "clumsy-bladed oars, inserting bull's eyes in the deck, or new tree-nails"][[107 3 13] "in the side planks, and other miscellaneous matters more directly"][[107 3 14] "pertaining to his special business; he was moreover unhesitatingly"][[107 3 15] "expert in all manner of conflicting aptitudes, both useful and"][[107 3 16] "capricious."][[107 4 1] "The one grand stage where he enacted all his various parts so manifold,"][[107 4 2] "was his vice-bench; a long rude ponderous table furnished with several"][[107 4 3] "vices, of different sizes, and both of iron and of wood. At all times"][[107 4 4] "except when whales were alongside, this bench was securely lashed"][[107 4 5] "athwartships against the rear of the Try-works."][[107 5 1] "A belaying pin is found too large to be easily inserted into its hole:"][[107 5 2] "the carpenter claps it into one of his ever-ready vices, and straightway"][[107 5 3] "files it smaller. A lost land-bird of strange plumage strays on board,"][[107 5 4] "and is made a captive: out of clean shaved rods of right-whale bone, and"][[107 5 5] "cross-beams of sperm whale ivory, the carpenter makes a pagoda-looking"][[107 5 6] "cage for it. An oarsman sprains his wrist: the carpenter concocts a"][[107 5 7] "soothing lotion. Stubb longed for vermillion stars to be painted upon"][[107 5 8] "the blade of his every oar; screwing each oar in his big vice of wood,"][[107 5 9] "the carpenter symmetrically supplies the constellation. A sailor takes"][[107 5 10] "a fancy to wear shark-bone ear-rings: the carpenter drills his ears."][[107 5 11] "Another has the toothache: the carpenter out pincers, and clapping"][[107 5 12] "one hand upon his bench bids him be seated there; but the poor fellow"][[107 5 13] "unmanageably winces under the unconcluded operation; whirling round the"][[107 5 14] "handle of his wooden vice, the carpenter signs him to clap his jaw in"][[107 5 15] "that, if he would have him draw the tooth."][[107 6 1] "Thus, this carpenter was prepared at all points, and alike indifferent"][[107 6 2] "and without respect in all. Teeth he accounted bits of ivory; heads he"][[107 6 3] "deemed but top-blocks; men themselves he lightly held for capstans. But"][[107 6 4] "while now upon so wide a field thus variously accomplished and with such"][[107 6 5] "liveliness of expertness in him, too; all this would seem to argue some"][[107 6 6] "uncommon vivacity of intelligence. But not precisely so. For nothing was"][[107 6 7] "this man more remarkable, than for a certain impersonal stolidity as"][[107 6 8] "it were; impersonal, I say; for it so shaded off into the surrounding"][[107 6 9] "infinite of things, that it seemed one with the general stolidity"][[107 6 10] "discernible in the whole visible world; which while pauselessly active"][[107 6 11] "in uncounted modes, still eternally holds its peace, and ignores you,"][[107 6 12] "though you dig foundations for cathedrals. Yet was this half-horrible"][[107 6 13] "stolidity in him, involving, too, as it appeared, an all-ramifying"][[107 6 14] "heartlessness;--yet was it oddly dashed at times, with an old,"][[107 6 15] "crutch-like, antediluvian, wheezing humorousness, not unstreaked now"][[107 6 16] "and then with a certain grizzled wittiness; such as might have served"][[107 6 17] "to pass the time during the midnight watch on the bearded forecastle"][[107 6 18] "of Noah's ark. Was it that this old carpenter had been a life-long"][[107 6 19] "wanderer, whose much rolling, to and fro, not only had gathered no moss;"][[107 6 20] "but what is more, had rubbed off whatever small outward clingings"][[107 6 21] "might have originally pertained to him? He was a stript abstract; an"][[107 6 22] "unfractioned integral; uncompromised as a new-born babe; living without"][[107 6 23] "premeditated reference to this world or the next. You might almost"][[107 6 24] "say, that this strange uncompromisedness in him involved a sort of"][[107 6 25] "unintelligence; for in his numerous trades, he did not seem to work so"][[107 6 26] "much by reason or by instinct, or simply because he had been tutored to"][[107 6 27] "it, or by any intermixture of all these, even or uneven; but merely by"][[107 6 28] "a kind of deaf and dumb, spontaneous literal process. He was a pure"][[107 6 29] "manipulator; his brain, if he had ever had one, must have early"][[107 6 30] "oozed along into the muscles of his fingers. He was like one of"][[107 6 31] "those unreasoning but still highly useful, MULTUM IN PARVO, Sheffield"][[107 6 32] "contrivances, assuming the exterior--though a little swelled--of a"][[107 6 33] "common pocket knife; but containing, not only blades of various sizes,"][[107 6 34] "but also screw-drivers, cork-screws, tweezers, awls, pens, rulers,"][[107 6 35] "nail-filers, countersinkers. So, if his superiors wanted to use the"][[107 6 36] "carpenter for a screw-driver, all they had to do was to open that part"][[107 6 37] "of him, and the screw was fast: or if for tweezers, take him up by the"][[107 6 38] "legs, and there they were."][[107 7 1] "Yet, as previously hinted, this omnitooled, open-and-shut carpenter,"][[107 7 2] "was, after all, no mere machine of an automaton. If he did not have a"][[107 7 3] "common soul in him, he had a subtle something that somehow anomalously"][[107 7 4] "did its duty. What that was, whether essence of quicksilver, or a few"][[107 7 5] "drops of hartshorn, there is no telling. But there it was; and there it"][[107 7 6] "had abided for now some sixty years or more. And this it was, this same"][[107 7 7] "unaccountable, cunning life-principle in him; this it was, that kept"][[107 7 8] "him a great part of the time soliloquizing; but only like an unreasoning"][[107 7 9] "wheel, which also hummingly soliloquizes; or rather, his body was a"][[107 7 10] "sentry-box and this soliloquizer on guard there, and talking all the"][[107 7 11] "time to keep himself awake."][[108 0 0] "CHAPTER 108. Queequeg in His Coffin."][[110 2 1] "Upon searching, it was found that the casks last struck into the hold"][[110 2 2] "were perfectly sound, and that the leak must be further off. So, it"][[110 2 3] "being calm weather, they broke out deeper and deeper, disturbing the"][[110 2 4] "slumbers of the huge ground-tier butts; and from that black midnight"][[110 2 5] "sending those gigantic moles into the daylight above.
