Top-heavy was the ship as a dinnerless"][[110 2 15] "student with all Aristotle in his head. Well was it that the Typhoons"][[110 2 16] "did not visit them then."][[110 3 1] "Now, at this time it was that my poor pagan companion, and fast"][[110 3 2] "bosom-friend, Queequeg, was seized with a fever, which brought him nigh"][[110 3 3] "to his endless end."][[110 4 1] "Be it said, that in this vocation of whaling, sinecures are unknown;"][[110 4 2] "dignity and danger go hand in hand; till you get to be Captain, the"][[110 4 3] "higher you rise the harder you toil. So with poor Queequeg, who, as"][[110 4 4] "harpooneer, must not only face all the rage of the living whale, but--as"][[110 4 5] "we have elsewhere seen--mount his dead back in a rolling sea; and"][[110 4 6] "finally descend into the gloom of the hold, and bitterly sweating"][[110 4 7] "all day in that subterraneous confinement, resolutely manhandle the"][[110 4 8] "clumsiest casks and see to their stowage. To be short, among whalemen,"][[110 4 9] "the harpooneers are the holders, so called."][[110 5 1] "Poor Queequeg! when the ship was about half disembowelled, you should"][[110 5 2] "have stooped over the hatchway, and peered down upon him there; where,"][[110 5 3] "stripped to his woollen drawers, the tattooed savage was crawling about"][[110 5 4] "amid that dampness and slime, like a green spotted lizard at the bottom"][[110 5 5] "of a well. And a well, or an ice-house, it somehow proved to him, poor"][[110 5 6] "pagan; where, strange to say, for all the heat of his sweatings, he"][[110 5 7] "caught a terrible chill which lapsed into a fever; and at last, after"][[110 5 8] "some days' suffering, laid him in his hammock, close to the very sill"][[110 5 9] "of the door of death. How he wasted and wasted away in those few"][[110 5 10] "long-lingering days, till there seemed but little left of him but his"][[110 5 11] "frame and tattooing. But as all else in him thinned, and his cheek-bones"][[110 5 12] "grew sharper, his eyes, nevertheless, seemed growing fuller and fuller;"][[110 5 13] "they became of a strange softness of lustre; and mildly but deeply"][[110 5 14] "looked out at you there from his sickness, a wondrous testimony to that"][[110 5 15] "immortal health in him which could not die, or be weakened. And like"][[110 5 16] "circles on the water, which, as they grow fainter, expand; so his eyes"][[110 5 17] "seemed rounding and rounding, like the rings of Eternity. An awe that"][[110 5 18] "cannot be named would steal over you as you sat by the side of this"][[110 5 19] "waning savage, and saw as strange things in his face, as any beheld who"][[110 5 20] "were bystanders when Zoroaster died. For whatever is truly wondrous and"][[110 5 21] "fearful in man, never yet was put into words or books. And the drawing"][[110 5 22] "near of Death, which alike levels all, alike impresses all with a last"][[110 5 23] "revelation, which only an author from the dead could adequately tell."][[110 5 24] "So that--let us say it again--no dying Chaldee or Greek had higher and"][[110 5 25] "holier thoughts than those, whose mysterious shades you saw creeping"][[110 5 26] "over the face of poor Queequeg, as he quietly lay in his swaying"][[110 5 27] "hammock, and the rolling sea seemed gently rocking him to his final"][[110 5 28] "rest, and the ocean's invisible flood-tide lifted him higher and higher"][[110 5 29] "towards his destined heaven."][[110 6 1] "Not a man of the crew but gave him up; and, as for Queequeg himself,"][[110 6 2] "what he thought of his case was forcibly shown by a curious favour he"][[110 6 3] "asked. He called one to him in the grey morning watch, when the day was"][[110 6 4] "just breaking, and taking his hand, said that while in Nantucket he"][[110 6 5] "had chanced to see certain little canoes of dark wood, like the rich"][[110 6 6] "war-wood of his native isle; and upon inquiry, he had learned that all"][[110 6 7] "whalemen who died in Nantucket, were laid in those same dark canoes,"][[110 6 8] "and that the fancy of being so laid had much pleased him; for it was not"][[110 6 9] "unlike the custom of his own race, who, after embalming a dead warrior,"][[110 6 10] "stretched him out in his canoe, and so left him to be floated away to"][[110 6 11] "the starry archipelagoes; for not only do they believe that the stars"][[110 6 12] "are isles, but that far beyond all visible horizons, their own mild,"][[110 6 13] "uncontinented seas, interflow with the blue heavens; and so form the"][[110 6 14] "white breakers of the milky way. He added, that he shuddered at"][[110 6 15] "the thought of being buried in his hammock, according to the usual"][[110 6 16] "sea-custom, tossed like something vile to the death-devouring sharks."][[110 6 17] "No: he desired a canoe like those of Nantucket, all the more congenial"][[110 6 18] "to him, being a whaleman, that like a whale-boat these coffin-canoes"][[110 6 19] "were without a keel; though that involved but uncertain steering, and"][[110 6 20] "much lee-way adown the dim ages."][[110 7 1] "Now, when this strange circumstance was made known aft, the carpenter"][[110 7 2] "was at once commanded to do Queequeg's bidding, whatever it might"][[110 7 3] "include. There was some heathenish, coffin-coloured old lumber aboard,"][[110 7 4] "which, upon a long previous voyage, had been cut from the aboriginal"][[110 7 5] "groves of the Lackaday islands, and from these dark planks the coffin"][[110 7 6] "was recommended to be made. No sooner was the carpenter apprised of"][[110 7 7] "the order, than taking his rule, he forthwith with all the indifferent"][[110 7 8] "promptitude of his character, proceeded into the forecastle and took"][[110 7 9] "Queequeg's measure with great accuracy, regularly chalking Queequeg's"][[110 7 10] "person as he shifted the rule."][[110 8 1] "\"Ah! poor fellow! he'll have to die now,\" ejaculated the Long Island"][[110 8 2] "sailor."][[110 9 1] "Going to his vice-bench, the carpenter for convenience sake and general"][[110 9 2] "reference, now transferringly measured on it the exact length the coffin"][[110 9 3] "was to be, and then made the transfer permanent by cutting two notches"][[110 9 4] "at its extremities. This done, he marshalled the planks and his tools,"][[110 9 5] "and to work."][[110 10 1] "When the last nail was driven, and the lid duly planed and fitted,"][[110 10 2] "he lightly shouldered the coffin and went forward with it, inquiring"][[110 10 3] "whether they were ready for it yet in that direction."][[110 11 1] "Overhearing the indignant but half-humorous cries with which the"][[110 11 2] "people on deck began to drive the coffin away, Queequeg, to every one's"][[110 11 3] "consternation, commanded that the thing should be instantly brought to"][[110 11 4] "him, nor was there any denying him; seeing that, of all mortals, some"][[110 11 5] "dying men are the most tyrannical; and certainly, since they will"][[110 11 6] "shortly trouble us so little for evermore, the poor fellows ought to be"][[110 11 7] "indulged."][[110 12 1] "Leaning over in his hammock, Queequeg long regarded the coffin with"][[110 12 2] "an attentive eye. He then called for his harpoon, had the wooden stock"][[110 12 3] "drawn from it, and then had the iron part placed in the coffin along"][[110 12 4] "with one of the paddles of his boat. All by his own request, also,"][[110 12 5] "biscuits were then ranged round the sides within: a flask of fresh water"][[110 12 6] "was placed at the head, and a small bag of woody earth scraped up in"][[110 12 7] "the hold at the foot; and a piece of sail-cloth being rolled up for a"][[110 12 8] "pillow, Queequeg now entreated to be lifted into his final bed, that he"][[110 12 9] "might make trial of its comforts, if any it had. He lay without moving"][[110 12 10] "a few minutes, then told one to go to his bag and bring out his little"][[110 12 11] "god, Yojo. Then crossing his arms on his breast with Yojo between, he"][[110 12 12] "called for the coffin lid (hatch he called it) to be placed over him."][[110 12 13] "The head part turned over with a leather hinge, and there lay Queequeg"][[110 12 14] "in his coffin with little but his composed countenance in view. \"Rarmai\""][[110 12 15] "(it will do; it is easy), he murmured at last, and signed to be replaced"][[110 12 16] "in his hammock."][[110 13 1] "But ere this was done, Pip, who had been slily hovering near by all this"][[110 13 2] "while, drew nigh to him where he lay, and with soft sobbings, took him"][[110 13 3] "by the hand; in the other, holding his tambourine."][[110 14 1] "\"Poor rover! will ye never have done with all this weary roving? where"][[110 14 2] "go ye now? But if the currents carry ye to those sweet Antilles where"][[110 14 3] "the beaches are only beat with water-lilies, will ye do one little"][[110 14 4] "errand for me? Seek out one Pip, who's now been missing long: I think"][[110 14 5] "he's in those far Antilles. If ye find him, then comfort him; for he"][[110 14 6] "must be very sad; for look! he's left his tambourine behind;--I found"][[110 14 7] "it. Rig-a-dig, dig, dig! Now, Queequeg, die; and I'll beat ye your dying"][[110 14 8] "march.\""][[110 15 1] "\"I have heard,\" murmured Starbuck, gazing down the scuttle, \"that in"][[110 15 2] "violent fevers, men, all ignorance, have talked in ancient tongues;"][[110 15 3] "and that when the mystery is probed, it turns out always that in their"][[110 15 4] "wholly forgotten childhood those ancient tongues had been really spoken"][[110 15 5] "in their hearing by some lofty scholars. So, to my fond faith, poor Pip,"][[110 15 6] "in this strange sweetness of his lunacy, brings heavenly vouchers of all"][[110 15 7] "our heavenly homes. Where learned he that, but there?--Hark! he speaks"][[110 15 8] "again: but more wildly now.\""][[110 16 1] "\"Form two and two! Let's make a General of him! Ho, where's his harpoon?"][[110 16 2] "Lay it across here.--Rig-a-dig, dig, dig! huzza! Oh for a game cock"][[110 16 3] "now to sit upon his head and crow! Queequeg dies game!--mind ye that;"][[110 16 4] "Queequeg dies game!--take ye good heed of that; Queequeg dies game! I"][[110 16 5] "say; game, game, game! but base little Pip, he died a coward; died all"][[110 16 6] "a'shiver;--out upon Pip! Hark ye; if ye find Pip, tell all the Antilles"][[110 16 7] "he's a runaway; a coward, a coward, a coward! Tell them he jumped from"][[110 16 8] "a whale-boat! I'd never beat my tambourine over base Pip, and hail"][[110 16 9] "him General, if he were once more dying here. No, no! shame upon all"][[110 16 10] "cowards--shame upon them! Let 'em go drown like Pip, that jumped from a"][[110 16 11] "whale-boat. Shame! shame!\""][[110 17 1] "During all this, Queequeg lay with closed eyes, as if in a dream. Pip"][[110 17 2] "was led away, and the sick man was replaced in his hammock."][[110 18 1] "But now that he had apparently made every preparation for death; now"][[110 18 2] "that his coffin was proved a good fit, Queequeg suddenly rallied; soon"][[110 18 3] "there seemed no need of the carpenter's box: and thereupon, when some"][[110 18 4] "expressed their delighted surprise, he, in substance, said, that the"][[110 18 5] "cause of his sudden convalescence was this;--at a critical moment, he"][[110 18 6] "had just recalled a little duty ashore, which he was leaving undone;"][[110 18 7] "and therefore had changed his mind about dying: he could not die yet,"][[110 18 8] "he averred. They asked him, then, whether to live or die was a matter of"][[110 18 9] "his own sovereign will and pleasure. He answered, certainly. In a word,"][[110 18 10] "it was Queequeg's conceit, that if a man made up his mind to live, mere"][[110 18 11] "sickness could not kill him: nothing but a whale, or a gale, or some"][[110 18 12] "violent, ungovernable, unintelligent destroyer of that sort."][[110 19 1] "Now, there is this noteworthy difference between savage and civilized;"][[110 19 2] "that while a sick, civilized man may be six months convalescing,"][[110 19 3] "generally speaking, a sick savage is almost half-well again in a day."][[110 19 4] "So, in good time my Queequeg gained strength; and at length after"][[110 19 5] "sitting on the windlass for a few indolent days (but eating with a"][[110 19 6] "vigorous appetite) he suddenly leaped to his feet, threw out his arms"][[110 19 7] "and legs, gave himself a good stretching, yawned a little bit, and then"][[110 19 8] "springing into the head of his hoisted boat, and poising a harpoon,"][[110 19 9] "pronounced himself fit for a fight."][[110 20 1] "With a wild whimsiness, he now used his coffin for a sea-chest; and"][[110 20 2] "emptying into it his canvas bag of clothes, set them in order there."][[110 20 3] "Many spare hours he spent, in carving the lid with all manner of"][[110 20 4] "grotesque figures and drawings; and it seemed that hereby he was"][[110 20 5] "striving, in his rude way, to copy parts of the twisted tattooing on"][[110 20 6] "his body. And this tattooing had been the work of a departed prophet and"][[110 20 7] "seer of his island, who, by those hieroglyphic marks, had written out on"][[110 20 8] "his body a complete theory of the heavens and the earth, and a mystical"][[110 20 9] "treatise on the art of attaining truth; so that Queequeg in his own"][[110 20 10] "proper person was a riddle to unfold; a wondrous work in one volume; but"][[110 20 11] "whose mysteries not even himself could read, though his own live heart"][[110 20 12] "beat against them; and these mysteries were therefore destined in"][[110 20 13] "the end to moulder away with the living parchment whereon they were"][[110 20 14] "inscribed, and so be unsolved to the last. And this thought it must"][[110 20 15] "have been which suggested to Ahab that wild exclamation of his, when"][[110 20 16] "one morning turning away from surveying poor Queequeg--\"Oh, devilish"][[110 20 17] "tantalization of the gods!\""][[111 0 0] "CHAPTER 111. The Pacific."][[111 2 1] "When gliding by the Bashee isles we emerged at last upon the great South"][[111 2 2] "Sea; were it not for other things, I could have greeted my dear Pacific"][[111 2 3] "with uncounted thanks, for now the long supplication of my youth was"][[111 2 4] "answered; that serene ocean rolled eastwards from me a thousand leagues"][[111 2 5] "of blue."][[111 3 1] "There is, one knows not what sweet mystery about this sea, whose gently"][[111 3 2] "awful stirrings seem to speak of some hidden soul beneath; like those"][[111 3 3] "fabled undulations of the Ephesian sod over the buried Evangelist St."][[111 3 4] "John. And meet it is, that over these sea-pastures, wide-rolling watery"][[111 3 5] "prairies and Potters' Fields of all four continents, the waves should"][[111 3 6] "rise and fall, and ebb and flow unceasingly; for here, millions of mixed"][[111 3 7] "shades and shadows, drowned dreams, somnambulisms, reveries; all that"][[111 3 8] "we call lives and souls, lie dreaming, dreaming, still; tossing like"][[111 3 9] "slumberers in their beds; the ever-rolling waves but made so by their"][[111 3 10] "restlessness."][[111 4 1] "To any meditative Magian rover, this serene Pacific, once beheld, must"][[111 4 2] "ever after be the sea of his adoption. It rolls the midmost waters of"][[111 4 3] "the world, the Indian ocean and Atlantic being but its arms. The same"][[111 4 4] "waves wash the moles of the new-built Californian towns, but yesterday"][[111 4 5] "planted by the recentest race of men, and lave the faded but still"][[111 4 6] "gorgeous skirts of Asiatic lands, older than Abraham; while all between"][[111 4 7] "float milky-ways of coral isles, and low-lying, endless, unknown"][[111 4 8] "Archipelagoes, and impenetrable Japans. Thus this mysterious, divine"][[111 4 9] "Pacific zones the world's whole bulk about; makes all coasts one bay"][[111 4 10] "to it; seems the tide-beating heart of earth. Lifted by those eternal"][[111 4 11] "swells, you needs must own the seductive god, bowing your head to Pan."][[111 5 1] "But few thoughts of Pan stirred Ahab's brain, as standing like an"][[111 5 2] "iron statue at his accustomed place beside the mizen rigging, with one"][[111 5 3] "nostril he unthinkingly snuffed the sugary musk from the Bashee isles"][[111 5 4] "(in whose sweet woods mild lovers must be walking), and with the other"][[111 5 5] "consciously inhaled the salt breath of the new found sea; that sea in"][[111 5 6] "which the hated White Whale must even then be swimming. Launched at"][[111 5 7] "length upon these almost final waters, and gliding towards the Japanese"][[111 5 8] "cruising-ground, the old man's purpose intensified itself. His firm lips"][[111 5 9] "met like the lips of a vice; the Delta of his forehead's veins swelled"][[111 5 10] "like overladen brooks; in his very sleep, his ringing cry ran through"][[111 5 11] "the vaulted hull, \"Stern all! the White Whale spouts thick blood!\""][[112 0 0] "CHAPTER 112. The Blacksmith."][[112 2 1] "Availing himself of the mild, summer-cool weather that now reigned in"][[112 2 2] "these latitudes, and in preparation for the peculiarly active"][[112 2 3] "pursuits shortly to be anticipated, Perth, the begrimed, blistered old"][[112 2 4] "blacksmith, had not removed his portable forge to the hold again, after"][[112 2 5] "concluding his contributory work for Ahab's leg, but still retained"][[112 2 6] "it on deck, fast lashed to ringbolts by the foremast; being now almost"][[112 2 7] "incessantly invoked by the headsmen, and harpooneers, and bowsmen to do"][[112 2 8] "some little job for them; altering, or repairing, or new shaping their"][[112 2 9] "various weapons and boat furniture. Often he would be surrounded by an"][[112 2 10] "eager circle, all waiting to be served; holding boat-spades, pike-heads,"][[112 2 11] "harpoons, and lances, and jealously watching his every sooty movement,"][[112 2 12] "as he toiled. Nevertheless, this old man's was a patient hammer wielded"][[112 2 13] "by a patient arm. No murmur, no impatience, no petulance did come from"][[112 2 14] "him. Silent, slow, and solemn; bowing over still further his chronically"][[112 2 15] "broken back, he toiled away, as if toil were life itself, and the"][[112 2 16] "heavy beating of his hammer the heavy beating of his heart. And so it"][[112 2 17] "was.--Most miserable!"][[112 3 1] "A peculiar walk in this old man, a certain slight but painful appearing"][[112 3 2] "yawing in his gait, had at an early period of the voyage excited the"][[112 3 3] "curiosity of the mariners. And to the importunity of their persisted"][[112 3 4] "questionings he had finally given in; and so it came to pass that every"][[112 3 5] "one now knew the shameful story of his wretched fate."][[112 4 1] "Belated, and not innocently, one bitter winter's midnight, on the road"][[112 4 2] "running between two country towns, the blacksmith half-stupidly felt"][[112 4 3] "the deadly numbness stealing over him, and sought refuge in a leaning,"][[112 4 4] "dilapidated barn. The issue was, the loss of the extremities of both"][[112 4 5] "feet. Out of this revelation, part by part, at last came out the four"][[112 4 6] "acts of the gladness, and the one long, and as yet uncatastrophied fifth"][[112 4 7] "act of the grief of his life's drama."][[112 5 1] "He was an old man, who, at the age of nearly sixty, had postponedly"][[112 5 2] "encountered that thing in sorrow's technicals called ruin. He had been"][[112 5 3] "an artisan of famed excellence, and with plenty to do; owned a house"][[112 5 4] "and garden; embraced a youthful, daughter-like, loving wife, and three"][[112 5 5] "blithe, ruddy children; every Sunday went to a cheerful-looking church,"][[112 5 6] "planted in a grove. But one night, under cover of darkness, and further"][[112 5 7] "concealed in a most cunning disguisement, a desperate burglar slid into"][[112 5 8] "his happy home, and robbed them all of everything. And darker yet to"][[112 5 9] "tell, the blacksmith himself did ignorantly conduct this burglar into"][[112 5 10] "his family's heart. It was the Bottle Conjuror! Upon the opening of that"][[112 5 11] "fatal cork, forth flew the fiend, and shrivelled up his home. Now, for"][[112 5 12] "prudent, most wise, and economic reasons, the blacksmith's shop was in"][[112 5 13] "the basement of his dwelling, but with a separate entrance to it; so"][[112 5 14] "that always had the young and loving healthy wife listened with no"][[112 5 15] "unhappy nervousness, but with vigorous pleasure, to the stout ringing of"][[112 5 16] "her young-armed old husband's hammer; whose reverberations, muffled by"][[112 5 17] "passing through the floors and walls, came up to her, not unsweetly,"][[112 5 18] "in her nursery; and so, to stout Labor's iron lullaby, the blacksmith's"][[112 5 19] "infants were rocked to slumber."][[112 6 1] "Oh, woe on woe! Oh, Death, why canst thou not sometimes be timely? Hadst"][[112 6 2] "thou taken this old blacksmith to thyself ere his full ruin came upon"][[112 6 3] "him, then had the young widow had a delicious grief, and her orphans a"][[112 6 4] "truly venerable, legendary sire to dream of in their after years; and"][[112 6 5] "all of them a care-killing competency. But Death plucked down some"][[112 6 6] "virtuous elder brother, on whose whistling daily toil solely hung the"][[112 6 7] "responsibilities of some other family, and left the worse than useless"][[112 6 8] "old man standing, till the hideous rot of life should make him easier to"][[112 6 9] "harvest."][[112 7 1] "Why tell the whole? The blows of the basement hammer every day grew more"][[112 7 2] "and more between; and each blow every day grew fainter than the last;"][[112 7 3] "the wife sat frozen at the window, with tearless eyes, glitteringly"][[112 7 4] "gazing into the weeping faces of her children; the bellows fell; the"][[112 7 5] "forge choked up with cinders; the house was sold; the mother dived"][[112 7 6] "down into the long church-yard grass; her children twice followed her"][[112 7 7] "thither; and the houseless, familyless old man staggered off a vagabond"][[112 7 8] "in crape; his every woe unreverenced; his grey head a scorn to flaxen"][[112 7 9] "curls!"][[112 8 1] "Death seems the only desirable sequel for a career like this; but Death"][[112 8 2] "is only a launching into the region of the strange Untried; it is but"][[112 8 3] "the first salutation to the possibilities of the immense Remote, the"][[112 8 4] "Wild, the Watery, the Unshored; therefore, to the death-longing eyes of"][[112 8 5] "such men, who still have left in them some interior compunctions against"][[112 8 6] "suicide, does the all-contributed and all-receptive ocean alluringly"][[112 8 7] "spread forth his whole plain of unimaginable, taking terrors, and"][[112 8 8] "wonderful, new-life adventures; and from the hearts of infinite"][[112 8 9] "Pacifics, the thousand mermaids sing to them--\"Come hither,"][[112 8 10] "broken-hearted; here is another life without the guilt of intermediate"][[112 8 11] "death; here are wonders supernatural, without dying for them. Come hither! put"][[112 8 14] "up THY gravestone, too, within the churchyard, and come hither, till we"][[112 8 15] "marry thee!\""][[112 9 1] "Hearkening to these voices, East and West, by early sunrise, and by fall"][[112 9 2] "of eve, the blacksmith's soul responded, Aye, I come! The Forge."][[113 2 1] "With matted beard, and swathed in a bristling shark-skin apron, about"][[113 2 2] "mid-day, Perth was standing between his forge and anvil, the latter"][[113 2 3] "placed upon an iron-wood log, with one hand holding a pike-head in the"][[113 2 4] "coals, and with the other at his forge's lungs, when Captain Ahab came"][[113 2 5] "along, carrying in his hand a small rusty-looking leathern bag. Is not this"][[113 21 2] "harpoon for the White Whale?\""][[113 22 1] "\"For the white fiend! But now for the barbs; thou must make them"][[113 22 2] "thyself, man. Here are my razors--the best of steel; here, and make the"][[113 22 3] "barbs sharp as the needle-sleet of the Icy Sea.\""][[113 23 1] "For a moment, the old blacksmith eyed the razors as though he would fain"][[113 23 2] "not use them."][[113 24 1] "\"Take them, man, I have no need for them; for I now neither shave, sup,"][[113 24 2] "nor pray till--but here--to work!\""][[113 25 1] "Fashioned at last into an arrowy shape, and welded by Perth to the"][[113 25 2] "shank, the steel soon pointed the end of the iron; and as the blacksmith"][[113 25 3] "was about giving the barbs their final heat, prior to tempering them, he"][[113 25 4] "cried to Ahab to place the water-cask near."][[113 26 1] "\"No, no--no water for that; I want it of the true death-temper. A cluster of"][[113 26 4] "dark nods replied, Yes. Three punctures were made in the heathen flesh,"][[113 26 5] "and the White Whale's barbs were then tempered."][[113 27 1] "\"Ego non baptizo te in nomine patris, sed in nomine diaboli!\""][[113 27 2] "deliriously howled Ahab, as the malignant iron scorchingly devoured the"][[113 27 3] "baptismal blood."][[113 28 1] "Now, mustering the spare poles from below, and selecting one of hickory,"][[113 28 2] "with the bark still investing it, Ahab fitted the end to the socket of"][[113 28 3] "the iron. A coil of new tow-line was then unwound, and some fathoms of"][[113 28 4] "it taken to the windlass, and stretched to a great tension. Pressing"][[113 28 5] "his foot upon it, till the rope hummed like a harp-string, then eagerly"][[113 28 6] "bending over it, and seeing no strandings, Ahab exclaimed, \"Good! and"][[113 28 7] "now for the seizings.\""][[113 29 1] "At one extremity the rope was unstranded, and the separate spread yarns"][[113 29 2] "were all braided and woven round the socket of the harpoon; the pole"][[113 29 3] "was then driven hard up into the socket; from the lower end the rope"][[113 29 4] "was traced half-way along the pole's length, and firmly secured so, with"][[113 29 5] "intertwistings of twine. This done, pole, iron, and rope--like the Three"][[113 29 6] "Fates--remained inseparable, and Ahab moodily stalked away with the"][[113 29 7] "weapon; the sound of his ivory leg, and the sound of the hickory pole,"][[113 29 8] "both hollowly ringing along every plank. The Gilder."][[114 2 1] "Penetrating further and further into the heart of the Japanese cruising"][[114 2 2] "ground, the Pequod was soon all astir in the fishery. Often, in mild,"][[114 2 3] "pleasant weather, for twelve, fifteen, eighteen, and twenty hours on the"][[114 2 4] "stretch, they were engaged in the boats, steadily pulling, or sailing,"][[114 2 5] "or paddling after the whales, or for an interlude of sixty or seventy"][[114 2 6] "minutes calmly awaiting their uprising; though with but small success"][[114 2 7] "for their pains."][[114 3 1] "At such times, under an abated sun; afloat all day upon smooth, slow"][[114 3 2] "heaving swells; seated in his boat, light as a birch canoe; and so"][[114 3 3] "sociably mixing with the soft waves themselves, that like hearth-stone"][[114 3 4] "cats they purr against the gunwale; these are the times of dreamy"][[114 3 5] "quietude, when beholding the tranquil beauty and brilliancy of the"][[114 3 6] "ocean's skin, one forgets the tiger heart that pants beneath it; and"][[114 3 7] "would not willingly remember, that this velvet paw but conceals a"][[114 3 8] "remorseless fang."][[114 4 1] "These are the times, when in his whale-boat the rover softly feels a"][[114 4 2] "certain filial, confident, land-like feeling towards the sea; that he"][[114 4 3] "regards it as so much flowery earth; and the distant ship revealing"][[114 4 4] "only the tops of her masts, seems struggling forward, not through high"][[114 4 5] "rolling waves, but through the tall grass of a rolling prairie: as when"][[114 4 6] "the western emigrants' horses only show their erected ears, while their"][[114 4 7] "hidden bodies widely wade through the amazing verdure."][[114 5 1] "The long-drawn virgin vales; the mild blue hill-sides; as over these"][[114 5 2] "there steals the hush, the hum; you almost swear that play-wearied"][[114 5 3] "children lie sleeping in these solitudes, in some glad May-time, when"][[114 5 4] "the flowers of the woods are plucked. And all this mixes with your most"][[114 5 5] "mystic mood; so that fact and fancy, half-way meeting, interpenetrate,"][[114 5 6] "and form one seamless whole."][[114 6 1] "Nor did such soothing scenes, however temporary, fail of at least as"][[114 6 2] "temporary an effect on Ahab. But the mingled, mingling"][[114 7 6] "threads of life are woven by warp and woof: calms crossed by storms, a"][[114 7 7] "storm for every calm. There is no steady unretracing progress in this"][[114 7 8] "life; we do not advance through fixed gradations, and at the last one"][[114 7 9] "pause:--through infancy's unconscious spell, boyhood's thoughtless"][[114 7 10] "faith, adolescence' doubt (the common doom), then scepticism, then"][[114 7 11] "disbelief, resting at last in manhood's pondering repose of If. But once"][[114 7 12] "gone through, we trace the round again; and are infants, boys, and men,"][[114 7 13] "and Ifs eternally. Where lies the final harbor, whence we unmoor no"][[114 7 14] "more? In what rapt ether sails the world, of which the weariest will"][[114 7 15] "never weary? Where is the foundling's father hidden? The Pequod Meets The Bachelor."][[115 2 1] "And jolly enough were the sights and the sounds that came bearing down"][[115 2 2] "before the wind, some few weeks after Ahab's harpoon had been welded."][[115 3 1] "It was a Nantucket ship, the Bachelor, which had just wedged in her"][[115 3 2] "last cask of oil, and bolted down her bursting hatches; and now, in glad"][[115 3 3] "holiday apparel, was joyously, though somewhat vain-gloriously, sailing"][[115 3 4] "round among the widely-separated ships on the ground, previous to"][[115 3 5] "pointing her prow for home."][[115 4 1] "The three men at her mast-head wore long streamers of narrow red bunting"][[115 4 2] "at their hats; from the stern, a whale-boat was suspended, bottom down;"][[115 4 3] "and hanging captive from the bowsprit was seen the long lower jaw of the"][[115 4 4] "last whale they had slain. The Dying Whale."][[116 2 1] "Not seldom in this life, when, on the right side, fortune's favourites"][[116 2 2] "sail close by us, we, though all adroop before, catch somewhat of the"][[116 2 3] "rushing breeze, and joyfully feel our bagging sails fill out. The Quadrant."][[118 2 1] "The season for the Line at length drew near; and every day when Ahab,"][[118 2 2] "coming from his cabin, cast his eyes aloft, the vigilant helmsman would"][[118 2 3] "ostentatiously handle his spokes, and the eager mariners quickly run to"][[118 2 4] "the braces, and would stand there with all their eyes centrally fixed"][[118 2 5] "on the nailed doubloon; impatient for the order to point the ship's"][[118 2 6] "prow for the equator. In good time the order came. It was hard upon high"][[118 2 7] "noon; and Ahab, seated in the bows of his high-hoisted boat, was"][[118 2 8] "about taking his wonted daily observation of the sun to determine his"][[118 2 9] "latitude."][[118 3 1] "Now, in that Japanese sea, the days in summer are as freshets of"][[118 3 2] "effulgences. That unblinkingly vivid Japanese sun seems the blazing"][[118 3 3] "focus of the glassy ocean's immeasurable burning-glass. The sky looks"][[118 3 4] "lacquered; clouds there are none; the horizon floats; and this nakedness"][[118 3 5] "of unrelieved radiance is as the insufferable splendors of God's throne."][[118 3 6] "Well that Ahab's quadrant was furnished with coloured glasses, through"][[118 3 7] "which to take sight of that solar fire. So, swinging his seated form"][[118 3 8] "to the roll of the ship, and with his astrological-looking instrument"][[118 3 9] "placed to his eye, he remained in that posture for some moments to"][[118 3 10] "catch the precise instant when the sun should gain its precise meridian."][[118 3 11] "Meantime while his whole attention was absorbed, the Parsee was kneeling"][[118 3 12] "beneath him on the ship's deck, and with face thrown up like Ahab's,"][[118 3 13] "was eyeing the same sun with him; only the lids of his eyes half hooded"][[118 3 14] "their orbs, and his wild face was subdued to an earthly passionlessness."][[118 3 15] "At length the desired observation was taken; and with his pencil upon"][[118 3 16] "his ivory leg, Ahab soon calculated what his latitude must be at that"][[118 3 17] "precise instant. Then falling into a moment's revery, he again looked up"][[118 3 18] "towards the sun and murmured to himself: \"Thou sea-mark! thou high and"][[118 3 19] "mighty Pilot! thou tellest me truly where I AM--but canst thou cast the"][[118 3 20] "least hint where I SHALL be? Or canst thou tell where some other thing"][[118 3 21] "besides me is this moment living? Where is Moby Dick? This instant thou"][[118 3 22] "must be eyeing him. These eyes of mine look into the very eye that is"][[118 3 23] "even now beholding him; aye, and into the eye that is even now equally"][[118 3 24] "beholding the objects on the unknown, thither side of thee, thou sun!\""][[118 4 1] "Then gazing at his quadrant, and handling, one after the other, its"][[118 4 2] "numerous cabalistical contrivances, he pondered again, and muttered:"][[118 4 3] "\"Foolish toy! babies' plaything of haughty Admirals, and Commodores, and"][[118 4 4] "Captains; the world brags of thee, of thy cunning and might; but what"][[118 4 5] "after all canst thou do, but tell the poor, pitiful point, where thou"][[118 4 6] "thyself happenest to be on this wide planet, and the hand that holds"][[118 4 7] "thee: no! not one jot more! Thou canst not tell where one drop of water"][[118 4 8] "or one grain of sand will be to-morrow noon; and yet with thy impotence"][[118 4 9] "thou insultest the sun! Science! Curse thee, thou vain toy; and cursed"][[118 4 10] "be all the things that cast man's eyes aloft to that heaven, whose live"][[118 4 11] "vividness but scorches him, as these old eyes are even now scorched"][[118 4 12] "with thy light, O sun! Level by nature to this earth's horizon are the"][[118 4 13] "glances of man's eyes; not shot from the crown of his head, as if God"][[118 4 14] "had meant him to gaze on his firmament. Curse thee, thou quadrant!\""][[118 4 15] "dashing it to the deck, \"no longer will I guide my earthly way by thee;"][[118 4 16] "the level ship's compass, and the level deadreckoning, by log and by"][[118 4 17] "line; THESE shall conduct me, and show me my place on the sea. Aye,\""][[118 4 18] "lighting from the boat to the deck, \"thus I trample on thee, thou paltry"][[118 4 19] "thing that feebly pointest on high; thus I split and destroy thee!\""][[118 5 1] "As the frantic old man thus spoke and thus trampled with his live"][[118 5 2] "and dead feet, a sneering triumph that seemed meant for Ahab, and a"][[118 5 3] "fatalistic despair that seemed meant for himself--these passed over"][[118 5 4] "the mute, motionless Parsee's face. The Candles."][[119 2 1] "Warmest climes but nurse the cruellest fangs: the tiger of Bengal"][[119 2 2] "crouches in spiced groves of ceaseless verdure. The Log and Line."][[125 2 1] "While now the fated Pequod had been so long afloat this voyage, the log"][[125 2 2] "and line had but very seldom been in use. The Life-Buoy."][[126 2 1] "Steering now south-eastward by Ahab's levelled steel, and her progress"][[126 2 2] "solely determined by Ahab's level log and line; the Pequod held on"][[126 2 3] "her path towards the Equator. Making so long a passage through such"][[126 2 4] "unfrequented waters, descrying no ships, and ere long, sideways impelled"][[126 2 5] "by unvarying trade winds, over waves monotonously mild; all these seemed"][[126 2 6] "the strange calm things preluding some riotous and desperate scene."][[126 3 1] "At last, when the ship drew near to the outskirts, as it were, of the"][[126 3 2] "Equatorial fishing-ground, and in the deep darkness that goes before the"][[126 3 3] "dawn, was sailing by a cluster of rocky islets; the watch--then headed"][[126 3 4] "by Flask--was startled by a cry so plaintively wild and unearthly--like"][[126 3 5] "half-articulated wailings of the ghosts of all Herod's murdered"][[126 3 6] "Innocents--that one and all, they started from their reveries, and for"][[126 3 7] "the space of some moments stood, or sat, or leaned all transfixedly"][[126 3 8] "listening, like the carved Roman slave, while that wild cry remained"][[126 3 9] "within hearing. The Christian or civilized part of the crew said it was"][[126 3 10] "mermaids, and shuddered; but the pagan harpooneers remained unappalled."][[126 3 11] "Yet the grey Manxman--the oldest mariner of all--declared that the wild"][[126 3 12] "thrilling sounds that were heard, were the voices of newly drowned men"][[126 3 13] "in the sea."][[126 4 1] "Below in his hammock, Ahab did not hear of this till grey dawn, when"][[126 4 2] "he came to the deck; it was then recounted to him by Flask, not"][[126 4 3] "unaccompanied with hinted dark meanings. He hollowly laughed, and thus"][[126 4 4] "explained the wonder."][[126 5 1] "Those rocky islands the ship had passed were the resort of great numbers"][[126 5 2] "of seals, and some young seals that had lost their dams, or some dams"][[126 5 3] "that had lost their cubs, must have risen nigh the ship and kept company"][[126 5 4] "with her, crying and sobbing with their human sort of wail. But this"][[126 5 5] "only the more affected some of them, because most mariners cherish a"][[126 5 6] "very superstitious feeling about seals, arising not only from their"][[126 5 7] "peculiar tones when in distress, but also from the human look of their"][[126 5 8] "round heads and semi-intelligent faces, seen peeringly uprising from"][[126 5 9] "the water alongside. In the sea, under certain circumstances, seals have"][[126 5 10] "more than once been mistaken for men."][[126 6 1] "But the bodings of the crew were destined to receive a most plausible"][[126 6 2] "confirmation in the fate of one of their number that morning. At"][[126 6 3] "sun-rise this man went from his hammock to his mast-head at the fore;"][[126 6 4] "and whether it was that he was not yet half waked from his sleep (for"][[126 6 5] "sailors sometimes go aloft in a transition state), whether it was thus"][[126 6 6] "with the man, there is now no telling; but, be that as it may, he"][[126 6 7] "had not been long at his perch, when a cry was heard--a cry and a"][[126 6 8] "rushing--and looking up, they saw a falling phantom in the air; and"][[126 6 9] "looking down, a little tossed heap of white bubbles in the blue of the"][[126 6 10] "sea."][[126 7 1] "The life-buoy--a long slender cask--was dropped from the stern, where it"][[126 7 2] "always hung obedient to a cunning spring; but no hand rose to seize it,"][[126 7 3] "and the sun having long beat upon this cask it had shrunken, so that it"][[126 7 4] "slowly filled, and that parched wood also filled at its every pore; and"][[126 7 5] "the studded iron-bound cask followed the sailor to the bottom, as if to"][[126 7 6] "yield him his pillow, though in sooth but a hard one."][[126 8 1] "And thus the first man of the Pequod that mounted the mast to look out"][[126 8 2] "for the White Whale, on the White Whale's own peculiar ground; that man"][[126 8 3] "was swallowed up in the deep. But few, perhaps, thought of that at the"][[126 8 4] "time. Indeed, in some sort, they were not grieved at this event, at"][[126 8 5] "least as a portent; for they regarded it, not as a foreshadowing of evil"][[126 8 6] "in the future, but as the fulfilment of an evil already presaged. They"][[126 8 7] "declared that now they knew the reason of those wild shrieks they had"][[126 8 8] "heard the night before. But again the old Manxman said nay."][[126 9 1] "The lost life-buoy was now to be replaced; Starbuck was directed to see"][[126 9 2] "to it; but as no cask of sufficient lightness could be found, and as"][[126 9 3] "in the feverish eagerness of what seemed the approaching crisis of"][[126 9 4] "the voyage, all hands were impatient of any toil but what was directly"][[126 9 5] "connected with its final end, whatever that might prove to be;"][[126 9 6] "therefore, they were going to leave the ship's stern unprovided with a"][[126 9 7] "buoy, when by certain strange signs and inuendoes Queequeg hinted a hint"][[126 9 8] "concerning his coffin."][[126 10 1] "\"A life-buoy of a coffin!\" cried Starbuck, starting."][[126 11 1] "\"Rather queer, that, I should say,\" said Stubb."][[126 12 1] "\"It will make a good enough one,\" said Flask, \"the carpenter here can"][[126 12 2] "arrange it easily.\""][[126 13 1] "\"Bring it up; there's nothing else for it,\" said Starbuck, after a"][[126 13 2] "melancholy pause. \"Rig it, carpenter; do not look at me so--the coffin,"][[126 13 3] "I mean. Dost thou hear me? Rig it.\""][[126 14 1] "\"And shall I nail down the lid, sir?\" moving his hand as with a hammer."][[126 15 1] "\"Aye.\""][[126 16 1] "\"And shall I caulk the seams, sir?\" moving his hand as with a"][[126 16 2] "caulking-iron."][[126 17 1] "\"Aye.\""][[126 18 1] "\"And shall I then pay over the same with pitch, sir?\" moving his hand as"][[126 18 2] "with a pitch-pot."][[126 19 1] "\"Away! what possesses thee to this? Make a life-buoy of the coffin, and"][[126 19 2] "no more.--Mr. Stubb, Mr. Flask, come forward with me.\""][[126 20 1] "\"He goes off in a huff. The whole he can endure; at the parts he baulks."][[126 20 2] "Now I don't like this. I make a leg for Captain Ahab, and he wears it"][[126 20 3] "like a gentleman; but I make a bandbox for Queequeg, and he won't put"][[126 20 4] "his head into it. Are all my pains to go for nothing with that coffin?"][[126 20 5] "And now I'm ordered to make a life-buoy of it. It's like turning an old"][[126 20 6] "coat; going to bring the flesh on the other side now. I don't like this"][[126 20 7] "cobbling sort of business--I don't like it at all; it's undignified;"][[126 20 8] "it's not my place. Let tinkers' brats do tinkerings; we are their"][[126 20 9] "betters. I like to take in hand none but clean, virgin, fair-and-square"][[126 20 10] "mathematical jobs, something that regularly begins at the beginning, and"][[126 20 11] "is at the middle when midway, and comes to an end at the conclusion; not"][[126 20 12] "a cobbler's job, that's at an end in the middle, and at the beginning at"][[126 20 13] "the end. It's the old woman's tricks to be giving cobbling jobs. Lord!"][[126 20 14] "what an affection all old women have for tinkers. I know an old woman of"][[126 20 15] "sixty-five who ran away with a bald-headed young tinker once. And that's"][[126 20 16] "the reason I never would work for lonely widow old women ashore, when"][[126 20 17] "I kept my job-shop in the Vineyard; they might have taken it into their"][[126 20 18] "lonely old heads to run off with me. But heigh-ho! there are no caps at"][[126 20 19] "sea but snow-caps. Let me see. Nail down the lid; caulk the seams; pay"][[126 20 20] "over the same with pitch; batten them down tight, and hang it with the"][[126 20 21] "snap-spring over the ship's stern. Were ever such things done before"][[126 20 22] "with a coffin? Some superstitious old carpenters, now, would be tied"][[126 20 23] "up in the rigging, ere they would do the job. But I'm made of knotty"][[126 20 24] "Aroostook hemlock; I don't budge. Cruppered with a coffin! Sailing"][[126 20 25] "about with a grave-yard tray! But never mind. We workers in woods make"][[126 20 26] "bridal-bedsteads and card-tables, as well as coffins and hearses. We"][[126 20 27] "work by the month, or by the job, or by the profit; not for us to ask"][[126 20 28] "the why and wherefore of our work, unless it be too confounded cobbling,"][[126 20 29] "and then we stash it if we can. Hem! I'll do the job, now, tenderly."][[126 20 30] "I'll have me--let's see--how many in the ship's company, all told? But"][[126 20 31] "I've forgotten. Any way, I'll have me thirty separate, Turk's-headed"][[126 20 32] "life-lines, each three feet long hanging all round to the coffin. Then,"][[126 20 33] "if the hull go down, there'll be thirty lively fellows all fighting for"][[126 20 34] "one coffin, a sight not seen very often beneath the sun! The Pequod Meets The Rachel."][[128 2 1] "Next day, a large ship, the Rachel, was descried, bearing directly down"][[128 2 2] "upon the Pequod, all her spars thickly clustering with men. At the"][[128 2 3] "time the Pequod was making good speed through the water; but as the"][[128 2 4] "broad-winged windward stranger shot nigh to her, the boastful sails all"][[128 2 5] "fell together as blank bladders that are burst, and all life fled from"][[128 2 6] "the smitten hull."][[128 3 1] "\"Bad news; she brings bad news,\" muttered the old Manxman. But no formal salutation was exchanged."][[128 7 1] "\"Where was he?--not killed!--not killed!\" cried Ahab, closely advancing."][[128 7 2] "\"How was it?\""][[128 8 1] "It seemed that somewhat late on the afternoon of the day previous, while"][[128 8 2] "three of the stranger's boats were engaged with a shoal of whales, which"][[128 8 3] "had led them some four or five miles from the ship; and while they were"][[128 8 4] "yet in swift chase to windward, the white hump and head of Moby Dick had"][[128 8 5] "suddenly loomed up out of the water, not very far to leeward; whereupon,"][[128 8 6] "the fourth rigged boat--a reserved one--had been instantly lowered in"][[128 8 7] "chase. After a keen sail before the wind, this fourth boat--the swiftest"][[128 8 8] "keeled of all--seemed to have succeeded in fastening--at least, as"][[128 8 9] "well as the man at the mast-head could tell anything about it. In the"][[128 8 10] "distance he saw the diminished dotted boat; and then a swift gleam"][[128 8 11] "of bubbling white water; and after that nothing more; whence it was"][[128 8 12] "concluded that the stricken whale must have indefinitely run away with"][[128 8 13] "his pursuers, as often happens. There was some apprehension, but no"][[128 8 14] "positive alarm, as yet. The recall signals were placed in the rigging;"][[128 8 15] "darkness came on; and forced to pick up her three far to windward"][[128 8 16] "boats--ere going in quest of the fourth one in the precisely opposite"][[128 8 17] "direction--the ship had not only been necessitated to leave that boat to"][[128 8 18] "its fate till near midnight, but, for the time, to increase her distance"][[128 8 19] "from it. The Hat."][[130 2 1] "And now that at the proper time and place, after so long and wide a"][[130 2 2] "preliminary cruise, Ahab,--all other whaling waters swept--seemed to"][[130 2 3] "have chased his foe into an ocean-fold, to slay him the more securely"][[130 2 4] "there; now, that he found himself hard by the very latitude and"][[130 2 5] "longitude where his tormenting wound had been inflicted; now that a"][[130 2 6] "vessel had been spoken which on the very day preceding had actually"][[130 2 7] "encountered Moby Dick;--and now that all his successive meetings with"][[130 2 8] "various ships contrastingly concurred to show the demoniac indifference"][[130 2 9] "with which the white whale tore his hunters, whether sinning or sinned"][[130 2 10] "against; now it was that there lurked a something in the old man's eyes,"][[130 2 11] "which it was hardly sufferable for feeble souls to see. As the unsetting"][[130 2 12] "polar star, which through the livelong, arctic, six months' night"][[130 2 13] "sustains its piercing, steady, central gaze; so Ahab's purpose now"][[130 2 14] "fixedly gleamed down upon the constant midnight of the gloomy crew. It"][[130 2 15] "domineered above them so, that all their bodings, doubts, misgivings,"][[130 2 16] "fears, were fain to hide beneath their souls, and not sprout forth a"][[130 2 17] "single spear or leaf."][[130 3 1] "In this foreshadowing interval too, all humor, forced or natural,"][[130 3 2] "vanished. Stubb no more strove to raise a smile; Starbuck no more strove"][[130 3 3] "to check one. Alike, joy and sorrow, hope and fear, seemed ground to"][[130 3 4] "finest dust, and powdered, for the time, in the clamped mortar of"][[130 3 5] "Ahab's iron soul. Like machines, they dumbly moved about the deck, ever"][[130 3 6] "conscious that the old man's despot eye was on them."][[130 4 1] "But did you deeply scan him in his more secret confidential hours; when"][[130 4 2] "he thought no glance but one was on him; then you would have seen that"][[130 4 3] "even as Ahab's eyes so awed the crew's, the inscrutable Parsee's glance"][[130 4 4] "awed his; or somehow, at least, in some wild way, at times affected it."][[130 4 5] "Such an added, gliding strangeness began to invest the thin Fedallah"][[130 4 6] "now; such ceaseless shudderings shook him; that the men looked dubious"][[130 4 7] "at him; half uncertain, as it seemed, whether indeed he were a mortal"][[130 4 8] "substance, or else a tremulous shadow cast upon the deck by some unseen"][[130 4 9] "being's body. And that shadow was always hovering there. For not by"][[130 4 10] "night, even, had Fedallah ever certainly been known to slumber, or go"][[130 4 11] "below. He would stand still for hours: but never sat or leaned; his wan"][[130 4 12] "but wondrous eyes did plainly say--We two watchmen never rest."][[130 5 1] "Nor, at any time, by night or day could the mariners now step upon the"][[130 5 2] "deck, unless Ahab was before them; either standing in his pivot-hole, or"][[130 5 3] "exactly pacing the planks between two undeviating limits,--the main-mast"][[130 5 4] "and the mizen; or else they saw him standing in the cabin-scuttle,--his"][[130 5 5] "living foot advanced upon the deck, as if to step; his hat slouched"][[130 5 6] "heavily over his eyes; so that however motionless he stood, however the"][[130 5 7] "days and nights were added on, that he had not swung in his hammock;"][[130 5 8] "yet hidden beneath that slouching hat, they could never tell unerringly"][[130 5 9] "whether, for all this, his eyes were really closed at times; or whether"][[130 5 10] "he was still intently scanning them; no matter, though he stood so in"][[130 5 11] "the scuttle for a whole hour on the stretch, and the unheeded night-damp"][[130 5 12] "gathered in beads of dew upon that stone-carved coat and hat. The"][[130 5 13] "clothes that the night had wet, the next day's sunshine dried upon him;"][[130 5 14] "and so, day after day, and night after night; he went no more beneath"][[130 5 15] "the planks; whatever he wanted from the cabin that thing he sent for."][[130 6 1] "He ate in the same open air; that is, his two only meals,--breakfast and"][[130 6 2] "dinner: supper he never touched; nor reaped his beard; which darkly grew"][[130 6 3] "all gnarled, as unearthed roots of trees blown over, which still grow"][[130 6 4] "idly on at naked base, though perished in the upper verdure. But though"][[130 6 5] "his whole life was now become one watch on deck; and though the Parsee's"][[130 6 6] "mystic watch was without intermission as his own; yet these two never"][[130 6 7] "seemed to speak--one man to the other--unless at long intervals some"][[130 6 8] "passing unmomentous matter made it necessary. The Symphony."][[132 2 1] "It was a clear steel-blue day. The firmaments of air and sea were"][[132 2 2] "hardly separable in that all-pervading azure; only, the pensive air was"][[132 2 3] "transparently pure and soft, with a woman's look, and the robust and"][[132 2 4] "man-like sea heaved with long, strong, lingering swells, as Samson's"][[132 2 5] "chest in his sleep."][[132 3 1] "Hither, and thither, on high, glided the snow-white wings of small,"][[132 3 2] "unspeckled birds; these were the gentle thoughts of the feminine air;"][[132 3 3] "but to and fro in the deeps, far down in the bottomless blue, rushed"][[132 3 4] "mighty leviathans, sword-fish, and sharks; and these were the strong,"][[132 3 5] "troubled, murderous thinkings of the masculine sea."][[132 4 1] "But though thus contrasting within, the contrast was only in shades and"][[132 4 2] "shadows without; those two seemed one; it was only the sex, as it were,"][[132 4 3] "that distinguished them."][[132 5 1] "Aloft, like a royal czar and king, the sun seemed giving this gentle"][[132 5 2] "air to this bold and rolling sea; even as bride to groom. And at the"][[132 5 3] "girdling line of the horizon, a soft and tremulous motion--most seen"][[132 5 4] "here at the Equator--denoted the fond, throbbing trust, the loving"][[132 5 5] "alarms, with which the poor bride gave her bosom away."][[132 6 1] "Tied up and twisted; gnarled and knotted with wrinkles; haggardly firm"][[132 6 2] "and unyielding; his eyes glowing like coals, that still glow in the"][[132 6 3] "ashes of ruin; untottering Ahab stood forth in the clearness of the"][[132 6 4] "morn; lifting his splintered helmet of a brow to the fair girl's"][[132 6 5] "forehead of heaven."][[132 7 1] "Oh, immortal infancy, and innocency of the azure! Invisible winged"][[132 7 2] "creatures that frolic all round us! Sweet childhood of air and sky! how"][[132 7 3] "oblivious were ye of old Ahab's close-coiled woe! But so have I seen"][[132 7 4] "little Miriam and Martha, laughing-eyed elves, heedlessly gambol around"][[132 7 5] "their old sire; sporting with the circle of singed locks which grew on"][[132 7 6] "the marge of that burnt-out crater of his brain."][[132 8 1] "Slowly crossing the deck from the scuttle, Ahab leaned over the side and"][[132 8 2] "watched how his shadow in the water sank and sank to his gaze, the more"][[132 8 3] "and the more that he strove to pierce the profundity. But the lovely"][[132 8 4] "aromas in that enchanted air did at last seem to dispel, for a moment,"][[132 8 5] "the cankerous thing in his soul. That glad, happy air, that winsome"][[132 8 6] "sky, did at last stroke and caress him; the step-mother world, so long"][[132 8 7] "cruel--forbidding--now threw affectionate arms round his stubborn neck,"][[132 8 8] "and did seem to joyously sob over him, as if over one, that however"][[132 8 9] "wilful and erring, she could yet find it in her heart to save and to"][[132 8 10] "bless. Careful not to touch"][[132 9 4] "him, or be noticed by him, he yet drew near to him, and stood there."][[132 10 1] "Ahab turned."][[132 11 1] "\"Starbuck!\""][[132 12 1] "\"Sir.\""][[132 13 1] "\"Oh, Starbuck! it is a mild, mild wind, and a mild looking sky. On such"][[132 13 2] "a day--very much such a sweetness as this--I struck my first whale--a"][[132 13 3] "boy-harpooneer of eighteen! Forty--forty--forty years ago!--ago! Forty"][[132 13 4] "years of continual whaling! forty years of privation, and peril, and"][[132 13 5] "storm-time! forty years on the pitiless sea! for forty years has Ahab"][[132 13 6] "forsaken the peaceful land, for forty years to make war on the horrors"][[132 13 7] "of the deep! Aye and yes, Starbuck, out of those forty years I have not"][[132 13 8] "spent three ashore. When I think of this life I have led; the desolation"][[132 13 9] "of solitude it has been; the masoned, walled-town of a Captain's"][[132 13 10] "exclusiveness, which admits but small entrance to any sympathy from the"][[132 13 11] "green country without--oh, weariness! heaviness! Guinea-coast slavery of"][[132 13 12] "solitary command!--when I think of all this; only half-suspected, not so"][[132 13 13] "keenly known to me before--and how for forty years I have fed upon dry"][[132 13 14] "salted fare--fit emblem of the dry nourishment of my soil!--when the"][[132 13 15] "poorest landsman has had fresh fruit to his daily hand, and broken the"][[132 13 16] "world's fresh bread to my mouldy crusts--away, whole oceans away, from"][[132 13 17] "that young girl-wife I wedded past fifty, and sailed for Cape Horn"][[132 13 18] "the next day, leaving but one dent in my marriage pillow--wife?"][[132 13 19] "wife?--rather a widow with her husband alive! Yes, yes! no more! it is done! we head for Nantucket! Come, my"][[132 16 4] "Captain, study out the course, and let us away! See, see! the boy's face"][[132 16 5] "from the window! the boy's hand on the hill!\""][[132 17 1] "But Ahab's glance was averted; like a blighted fruit tree he shook, and"][[132 17 2] "cast his last, cindered apple to the soil."][[132 18 1] "\"What is it, what nameless, inscrutable, unearthly thing is it; what"][[132 18 2] "cozening, hidden lord and master, and cruel, remorseless emperor"][[132 18 3] "commands me; that against all natural lovings and longings, I so keep"][[132 18 4] "pushing, and crowding, and jamming myself on all the time; recklessly"][[132 18 5] "making me ready to do what in my own proper, natural heart, I durst not"][[132 18 6] "so much as dare? Is Ahab, Ahab? Is it I, God, or who, that lifts this"][[132 18 7] "arm? But if the great sun move not of himself; but is as an errand-boy"][[132 18 8] "in heaven; nor one single star can revolve, but by some invisible power;"][[132 18 9] "how then can this one small heart beat; this one small brain think"][[132 18 10] "thoughts; unless God does that beating, does that thinking, does that"][[132 18 11] "living, and not I. By heaven, man, we are turned round and round in"][[132 18 12] "this world, like yonder windlass, and Fate is the handspike. And all"][[132 18 13] "the time, lo! that smiling sky, and this unsounded sea! Look! see yon"][[132 18 14] "Albicore! who put it into him to chase and fang that flying-fish? Where"][[132 18 15] "do murderers go, man! Who's to doom, when the judge himself is dragged"][[132 18 16] "to the bar? But it is a mild, mild wind, and a mild looking sky; and"][[132 18 17] "the air smells now, as if it blew from a far-away meadow; they have been"][[132 18 18] "making hay somewhere under the slopes of the Andes, Starbuck, and the"][[132 18 19] "mowers are sleeping among the new-mown hay. Sleeping? Aye, toil we how"][[132 18 20] "we may, we all sleep at last on the field. Sleep? Aye, and rust amid"][[132 18 21] "greenness; as last year's scythes flung down, and left in the half-cut"][[132 18 22] "swaths--Starbuck!\""][[132 19 1] "But blanched to a corpse's hue with despair, the Mate had stolen away."][[132 20 1] "Ahab crossed the deck to gaze over on the other side; but started at"][[132 20 2] "two reflected, fixed eyes in the water there. Fedallah was motionlessly"][[132 20 3] "leaning over the same rail."][[133 0 0] "CHAPTER 133. The Chase--First Day."][[133 2 1] "That night, in the mid-watch, when the old man--as his wont at"][[133 2 2] "intervals--stepped forth from the scuttle in which he leaned, and went"][[133 2 3] "to his pivot-hole, he suddenly thrust out his face fiercely, snuffing"][[133 2 4] "up the sea air as a sagacious ship's dog will, in drawing nigh to"][[133 2 5] "some barbarous isle. He declared that a whale must be near. Soon that"][[133 2 6] "peculiar odor, sometimes to a great distance given forth by the"][[133 2 7] "living sperm whale, was palpable to all the watch; nor was any mariner"][[133 2 8] "surprised when, after inspecting the compass, and then the dog-vane, and"][[133 2 9] "then ascertaining the precise bearing of the odor as nearly as possible,"][[133 2 10] "Ahab rapidly ordered the ship's course to be slightly altered, and the"][[133 2 11] "sail to be shortened."][[133 3 1] "The acute policy dictating these movements was sufficiently vindicated"][[133 3 2] "at daybreak, by the sight of a long sleek on the sea directly and"][[133 3 3] "lengthwise ahead, smooth as oil, and resembling in the pleated watery"][[133 3 4] "wrinkles bordering it, the polished metallic-like marks of some swift"][[133 3 5] "tide-rip, at the mouth of a deep, rapid stream."][[133 4 1] "\"Man the mast-heads! Call all hands!\""][[133 5 1] "Thundering with the butts of three clubbed handspikes on the forecastle"][[133 5 2] "deck, Daggoo roused the sleepers with such judgment claps that they"][[133 5 3] "seemed to exhale from the scuttle, so instantaneously did they appear"][[133 5 4] "with their clothes in their hands."][[133 6 1] "\"What d'ye see?\" cried Ahab, flattening his face to the sky."][[133 7 1] "\"Nothing, nothing sir!\" was the sound hailing down in reply."][[133 8 1] "\"T'gallant sails!--stunsails! alow and aloft, and on both sides!\""][[133 9 1] "All sail being set, he now cast loose the life-line, reserved for"][[133 9 2] "swaying him to the main royal-mast head; and in a few moments they were"][[133 9 3] "hoisting him thither, when, while but two thirds of the way aloft,"][[133 9 4] "and while peering ahead through the horizontal vacancy between the"][[133 9 5] "main-top-sail and top-gallant-sail, he raised a gull-like cry in the"][[133 9 6] "air. \"There she blows!--there she blows! A hump like a snow-hill! It is"][[133 9 7] "Moby Dick!\""][[133 10 1] "Fired by the cry which seemed simultaneously taken up by the three"][[133 10 2] "look-outs, the men on deck rushed to the rigging to behold the famous"][[133 10 3] "whale they had so long been pursuing. Ahab had now gained his final"][[133 10 4] "perch, some feet above the other look-outs, Tashtego standing just"][[133 10 5] "beneath him on the cap of the top-gallant-mast, so that the Indian's"][[133 10 6] "head was almost on a level with Ahab's heel. From this height the whale"][[133 10 7] "was now seen some mile or so ahead, at every roll of the sea revealing"][[133 10 8] "his high sparkling hump, and regularly jetting his silent spout into the"][[133 10 9] "air. To the credulous mariners it seemed the same silent spout they had"][[133 10 10] "so long ago beheld in the moonlit Atlantic and Indian Oceans."][[133 11 1] "\"And did none of ye see it before?\" cried Ahab, hailing the perched men"][[133 11 2] "all around him."][[133 12 1] "\"I saw him almost that same instant, sir, that Captain Ahab did, and I"][[133 12 2] "cried out,\" said Tashtego."][[133 13 1] "\"Not the same instant; not the same--no, the doubloon is mine, Fate"][[133 13 2] "reserved the doubloon for me. There she blows!--there she blows!--there she blows!"][[133 13 4] "There again!--there again!\" he cried, in long-drawn, lingering, methodic"][[133 13 5] "tones, attuned to the gradual prolongings of the whale's visible jets."][[133 13 6] "\"He's going to sound! In stunsails! Down top-gallant-sails! Stand by"][[133 13 7] "three boats. Mr. Starbuck, remember, stay on board, and keep the ship."][[133 13 8] "Helm there! Luff, luff a point! Lower me, Mr. Starbuck; lower, lower,--quick, quicker!\" and he"][[133 13 11] "slid through the air to the deck."][[133 14 1] "\"He is heading straight to leeward, sir,\" cried Stubb, \"right away from"][[133 14 2] "us; cannot have seen the ship yet.\""][[133 15 1] "\"Be dumb, man! Boats, boats!\""][[133 16 1] "Soon all the boats but Starbuck's were dropped; all the boat-sails"][[133 16 2] "set--all the paddles plying; with rippling swiftness, shooting to"][[133 16 3] "leeward; and Ahab heading the onset. A pale, death-glimmer lit up"][[133 16 4] "Fedallah's sunken eyes; a hideous motion gnawed his mouth."][[133 17 1] "Like noiseless nautilus shells, their light prows sped through the sea;"][[133 17 2] "but only slowly they neared the foe. As they neared him, the ocean grew"][[133 17 3] "still more smooth; seemed drawing a carpet over its waves; seemed a"][[133 17 4] "noon-meadow, so serenely it spread. At length the breathless hunter came"][[133 17 5] "so nigh his seemingly unsuspecting prey, that his entire dazzling hump"][[133 17 6] "was distinctly visible, sliding along the sea as if an isolated thing,"][[133 17 7] "and continually set in a revolving ring of finest, fleecy, greenish"][[133 17 8] "foam. He saw the vast, involved wrinkles of the slightly projecting head"][[133 17 9] "beyond. Before it, far out on the soft Turkish-rugged waters, went"][[133 17 10] "the glistening white shadow from his broad, milky forehead, a musical"][[133 17 11] "rippling playfully accompanying the shade; and behind, the blue waters"][[133 17 12] "interchangeably flowed over into the moving valley of his steady wake;"][[133 17 13] "and on either hand bright bubbles arose and danced by his side. But"][[133 17 14] "these were broken again by the light toes of hundreds of gay fowl softly"][[133 17 15] "feathering the sea, alternate with their fitful flight; and like to"][[133 17 16] "some flag-staff rising from the painted hull of an argosy, the tall but"][[133 17 17] "shattered pole of a recent lance projected from the white whale's back;"][[133 17 18] "and at intervals one of the cloud of soft-toed fowls hovering, and"][[133 17 19] "to and fro skimming like a canopy over the fish, silently perched and"][[133 17 20] "rocked on this pole, the long tail feathers streaming like pennons."][[133 18 1] "A gentle joyousness--a mighty mildness of repose in swiftness, invested"][[133 18 2] "the gliding whale. Not the white bull Jupiter swimming away with"][[133 18 3] "ravished Europa clinging to his graceful horns; his lovely, leering"][[133 18 4] "eyes sideways intent upon the maid; with smooth bewitching fleetness,"][[133 18 5] "rippling straight for the nuptial bower in Crete; not Jove, not that"][[133 18 6] "great majesty Supreme! did surpass the glorified White Whale as he so"][[133 18 7] "divinely swam."][[133 19 1] "On each soft side--coincident with the parted swell, that but once"][[133 19 2] "leaving him, then flowed so wide away--on each bright side, the whale"][[133 19 3] "shed off enticings. No wonder there had been some among the hunters who"][[133 19 4] "namelessly transported and allured by all this serenity, had ventured"][[133 19 5] "to assail it; but had fatally found that quietude but the vesture of"][[133 19 6] "tornadoes. Yet calm, enticing calm, oh, whale! thou glidest on, to all"][[133 19 7] "who for the first time eye thee, no matter how many in that same way"][[133 19 8] "thou may'st have bejuggled and destroyed before."][[133 20 1] "And thus, through the serene tranquillities of the tropical sea, among"][[133 20 2] "waves whose hand-clappings were suspended by exceeding rapture, Moby"][[133 20 3] "Dick moved on, still withholding from sight the full terrors of his"][[133 20 4] "submerged trunk, entirely hiding the wrenched hideousness of his jaw."][[133 20 5] "But soon the fore part of him slowly rose from the water; for an instant"][[133 20 6] "his whole marbleized body formed a high arch, like Virginia's Natural"][[133 20 7] "Bridge, and warningly waving his bannered flukes in the air, the"][[133 20 8] "grand god revealed himself, sounded, and went out of sight. The breeze now"][[133 22 5] "freshened; the sea began to swell."][[133 23 1] "\"The birds!--the birds!\" cried Tashtego."][[133 24 1] "In long Indian file, as when herons take wing, the white birds were"][[133 24 2] "now all flying towards Ahab's boat; and when within a few yards began"][[133 24 3] "fluttering over the water there, wheeling round and round, with joyous,"][[133 24 4] "expectant cries. The"][[133 24 12] "glittering mouth yawned beneath the boat like an open-doored marble"][[133 24 13] "tomb; and giving one sidelong sweep with his steering oar, Ahab whirled"][[133 24 14] "the craft aside from this tremendous apparition. With"][[133 26 9] "unastonished eyes Fedallah gazed, and crossed his arms; but the"][[133 26 10] "tiger-yellow crew were tumbling over each other's heads to gain the"][[133 26 11] "uttermost stern."][[133 27 1] "And now, while both elastic gunwales were springing in and out, as the"][[133 27 2] "whale dallied with the doomed craft in this devilish way; and from his"][[133 27 3] "body being submerged beneath the boat, he could not be darted at from"][[133 27 4] "the bows, for the bows were almost inside of him, as it were; and"][[133 27 5] "while the other boats involuntarily paused, as before a quick crisis"][[133 27 6] "impossible to withstand, then it was that monomaniac Ahab, furious with"][[133 27 7] "this tantalizing vicinity of his foe, which placed him all alive and"][[133 27 8] "helpless in the very jaws he hated; frenzied with all this, he seized"][[133 27 9] "the long bone with his naked hands, and wildly strove to wrench it from"][[133 27 10] "its gripe. It receives its designation"][[133 31 2] "(pitchpoling) from its being likened to that preliminary up-and-down"][[133 31 3] "poise of the whale-lance, in the exercise called pitchpoling, previously"][[133 31 4] "described. By this motion the whale must best and most comprehensively"][[133 31 5] "view whatever objects may be encircling him."][[133 33 1] "But soon resuming his horizontal attitude, Moby Dick swam swiftly round"][[133 33 2] "and round the wrecked crew; sideways churning the water in his vengeful"][[133 33 3] "wake, as if lashing himself up to still another and more deadly assault."][[133 33 4] "The sight of the splintered boat seemed to madden him, as the blood of"][[133 33 5] "grapes and mulberries cast before Antiochus's elephants in the book"][[133 33 6] "of Maccabees. As he sullenly swam"][[133 35 3] "off, the boats flew to the rescue."][[133 36 1] "Dragged into Stubb's boat with blood-shot, blinded eyes, the white brine"][[133 36 2] "caking in his wrinkles; the long tension of Ahab's bodily strength did"][[133 36 3] "crack, and helplessly he yielded to his body's doom: for a time, lying"][[133 36 4] "all crushed in the bottom of Stubb's boat, like one trodden under foot"][[133 36 5] "of herds of elephants. Far inland, nameless wails came from him, as"][[133 36 6] "desolate sounds from out ravines."][[133 37 1] "But this intensity of his physical prostration did but so much the more"][[133 37 2] "abbreviate it. In an instant's compass, great hearts sometimes condense"][[133 37 3] "to one deep pang, the sum total of those shallow pains kindly diffused"][[133 37 4] "through feebler men's whole lives. And so, such hearts, though summary"][[133 37 5] "in each one suffering; still, if the gods decree it, in their"][[133 37 6] "life-time aggregate a whole age of woe, wholly made up of instantaneous"][[133 37 7] "intensities; for even in their pointless centres, those noble natures"][[133 37 8] "contain the entire circumferences of inferior souls."][[133 38 1] "\"The harpoon,\" said Ahab, half way rising, and draggingly leaning on one"][[133 38 2] "bended arm--\"is it safe?\""][[133 39 1] "\"Aye, sir, for it was not darted; this is it,\" said Stubb, showing it."][[133 40 1] "\"Lay it before me;--any missing men?\""][[133 41 1] "\"One, two, three, four, five;--there were five oars, sir, and here are"][[133 41 2] "five men.\""][[133 42 1] "\"That's good.--Help me, man; I wish to stand. Set the sail; out oars;"][[133 42 4] "the helm!\""][[133 43 1] "It is often the case that when a boat is stove, its crew, being picked"][[133 43 2] "up by another boat, help to work that second boat; and the chase is thus"][[133 43 3] "continued with what is called double-banked oars. It was thus now. But"][[133 43 4] "the added power of the boat did not equal the added power of the whale,"][[133 43 5] "for he seemed to have treble-banked his every fin; swimming with a"][[133 43 6] "velocity which plainly showed, that if now, under these circumstances,"][[133 43 7] "pushed on, the chase would prove an indefinitely prolonged, if not a"][[133 43 8] "hopeless one; nor could any crew endure for so long a period, such an"][[133 43 9] "unintermitted, intense straining at the oar; a thing barely tolerable"][[133 43 10] "only in some one brief vicissitude. The ship itself, then, as it"][[133 43 11] "sometimes happens, offered the most promising intermediate means of"][[133 43 12] "overtaking the chase. Accordingly, the boats now made for her, and were"][[133 43 13] "soon swayed up to their cranes--the two parts of the wrecked boat having"][[133 43 14] "been previously secured by her--and then hoisting everything to her"][[133 43 15] "side, and stacking her canvas high up, and sideways outstretching it"][[133 43 16] "with stun-sails, like the double-jointed wings of an albatross; the"][[133 43 17] "Pequod bore down in the leeward wake of Moby-Dick.
