Sing out for every spout,"][[133 48 8] "though he spout ten times a second!\""][[133 49 1] "The day was nearly done; only the hem of his golden robe was rustling."][[133 49 2] "Soon, it was almost dark, but the look-out men still remained unset."][[133 50 1] "\"Can't see the spout now, sir;--too dark\"--cried a voice from the air."][[133 51 1] "\"How heading when last seen?\""][[133 52 1] "\"As before, sir,--straight to leeward.\""][[133 53 1] "\"Good! he will travel slower now 'tis night. Down royals and top-gallant"][[133 53 2] "stun-sails, Mr. Starbuck. We must not run over him before morning; he's"][[133 53 3] "making a passage now, and may heave-to a while. Helm there! keep her"][[133 53 4] "full before the wind!--Aloft! come down!--Mr. Stubb, send a fresh hand"][[133 53 5] "to the fore-mast head, and see it manned till morning.\"--Then advancing"][[133 53 6] "towards the doubloon in the main-mast--\"Men, this gold is mine, for I"][[133 53 7] "earned it; but I shall let it abide here till the White Whale is dead;"][[133 53 8] "and then, whosoever of ye first raises him, upon the day he shall be"][[133 53 9] "killed, this gold is that man's; and if on that day I shall again raise"][[133 53 10] "him, then, ten times its sum shall be divided among all of ye! Away"][[133 53 11] "now!--the deck is thine, sir!\""][[133 54 1] "And so saying, he placed himself half way within the scuttle, and"][[133 54 2] "slouching his hat, stood there till dawn, except when at intervals"][[133 54 3] "rousing himself to see how the night wore on."][[134 0 0] "CHAPTER 134. The Chase--Second Day."][[134 2 1] "At day-break, the three mast-heads were punctually manned afresh."][[134 3 1] "\"D'ye see him?\" cried Ahab after allowing a little space for the light"][[134 3 2] "to spread."][[134 4 1] "\"See nothing, sir.\""][[134 5 1] "\"Turn up all hands and make sail! he travels faster than I thought"][[134 5 2] "for;--the top-gallant sails!--aye, they should have been kept on her all"][[134 5 3] "night. But no matter--'tis but resting for the rush.\""][[134 6 1] "Here be it said, that this pertinacious pursuit of one particular whale,"][[134 6 2] "continued through day into night, and through night into day, is a thing"][[134 6 3] "by no means unprecedented in the South sea fishery. For such is the"][[134 6 4] "wonderful skill, prescience of experience, and invincible confidence"][[134 6 5] "acquired by some great natural geniuses among the Nantucket commanders;"][[134 6 6] "that from the simple observation of a whale when last descried, they"][[134 6 7] "will, under certain given circumstances, pretty accurately foretell both"][[134 6 8] "the direction in which he will continue to swim for a time, while out of"][[134 6 9] "sight, as well as his probable rate of progression during that period."][[134 6 10] "And, in these cases, somewhat as a pilot, when about losing sight of"][[134 6 11] "a coast, whose general trending he well knows, and which he desires"][[134 6 12] "shortly to return to again, but at some further point; like as this"][[134 6 13] "pilot stands by his compass, and takes the precise bearing of the"][[134 6 14] "cape at present visible, in order the more certainly to hit aright"][[134 6 15] "the remote, unseen headland, eventually to be visited: so does the"][[134 6 16] "fisherman, at his compass, with the whale; for after being chased, and"][[134 6 17] "diligently marked, through several hours of daylight, then, when night"][[134 6 18] "obscures the fish, the creature's future wake through the darkness"][[134 6 19] "is almost as established to the sagacious mind of the hunter, as the"][[134 6 20] "pilot's coast is to him. So that to this hunter's wondrous skill, the"][[134 6 21] "proverbial evanescence of a thing writ in water, a wake, is to all"][[134 6 22] "desired purposes well nigh as reliable as the steadfast land. And as the"][[134 6 23] "mighty iron Leviathan of the modern railway is so familiarly known in"][[134 6 24] "its every pace, that, with watches in their hands, men time his rate as"][[134 6 25] "doctors that of a baby's pulse; and lightly say of it, the up train or"][[134 6 26] "the down train will reach such or such a spot, at such or such an hour;"][[134 6 27] "even so, almost, there are occasions when these Nantucketers time that"][[134 6 28] "other Leviathan of the deep, according to the observed humor of his"][[134 6 29] "speed; and say to themselves, so many hours hence this whale will have"][[134 6 30] "gone two hundred miles, will have about reached this or that degree of"][[134 6 31] "latitude or longitude. But to render this acuteness at all successful in"][[134 6 32] "the end, the wind and the sea must be the whaleman's allies; for of what"][[134 6 33] "present avail to the becalmed or windbound mariner is the skill that"][[134 6 34] "assures him he is exactly ninety-three leagues and a quarter from his"][[134 6 35] "port? Inferable from these statements, are many collateral subtile"][[134 6 36] "matters touching the chase of whales."][[134 7 1] "The ship tore on; leaving such a furrow in the sea as when a"][[134 7 2] "cannon-ball, missent, becomes a plough-share and turns up the level"][[134 7 3] "field."][[134 8 1] "\"By salt and hemp!\" cried Stubb, \"but this swift motion of the deck"][[134 8 2] "creeps up one's legs and tingles at the heart. This ship and I are two"][[134 8 3] "brave fellows!--Ha, ha! Some one take me up, and launch me, spine-wise,"][[134 8 4] "on the sea,--for by live-oaks! my spine's a keel. Ha, ha! we go the gait"][[134 8 5] "that leaves no dust behind!\""][[134 9 1] "\"There she blows--she blows!--she blows!--right ahead!\" was now the"][[134 9 2] "mast-head cry."][[134 10 1] "\"Aye, aye!\" cried Stubb, \"I knew it--ye can't escape--blow on and"][[134 10 2] "split your spout, O whale! the mad fiend himself is after ye! blow your"][[134 10 3] "trump--blister your lungs!--Ahab will dam off your blood, as a miller"][[134 10 4] "shuts his watergate upon the stream!\""][[134 11 1] "And Stubb did but speak out for well nigh all that crew. The frenzies"][[134 11 2] "of the chase had by this time worked them bubblingly up, like old wine"][[134 11 3] "worked anew. Whatever pale fears and forebodings some of them might"][[134 11 4] "have felt before; these were not only now kept out of sight through the"][[134 11 5] "growing awe of Ahab, but they were broken up, and on all sides routed,"][[134 11 6] "as timid prairie hares that scatter before the bounding bison. The hand"][[134 11 7] "of Fate had snatched all their souls; and by the stirring perils of"][[134 11 8] "the previous day; the rack of the past night's suspense; the fixed,"][[134 11 9] "unfearing, blind, reckless way in which their wild craft went plunging"][[134 11 10] "towards its flying mark; by all these things, their hearts were bowled"][[134 11 11] "along. The wind that made great bellies of their sails, and rushed the"][[134 11 12] "vessel on by arms invisible as irresistible; this seemed the symbol of"][[134 11 13] "that unseen agency which so enslaved them to the race."][[134 12 1] "They were one man, not thirty. For as the one ship that held them all;"][[134 12 2] "though it was put together of all contrasting things--oak, and maple,"][[134 12 3] "and pine wood; iron, and pitch, and hemp--yet all these ran into each"][[134 12 4] "other in the one concrete hull, which shot on its way, both balanced and"][[134 12 5] "directed by the long central keel; even so, all the individualities of"][[134 12 6] "the crew, this man's valor, that man's fear; guilt and guiltiness, all"][[134 12 7] "varieties were welded into oneness, and were all directed to that fatal"][[134 12 8] "goal which Ahab their one lord and keel did point to."][[134 13 1] "The rigging lived. The mast-heads, like the tops of tall palms, were"][[134 13 2] "outspreadingly tufted with arms and legs. Clinging to a spar with one"][[134 13 3] "hand, some reached forth the other with impatient wavings; others,"][[134 13 4] "shading their eyes from the vivid sunlight, sat far out on the rocking"][[134 13 5] "yards; all the spars in full bearing of mortals, ready and ripe for"][[134 13 6] "their fate. Ah! how they still strove through that infinite blueness to"][[134 13 7] "seek out the thing that might destroy them!"][[134 14 1] "\"Why sing ye not out for him, if ye see him?\" cried Ahab, when, after"][[134 14 2] "the lapse of some minutes since the first cry, no more had been heard."][[134 14 3] "\"Sway me up, men; ye have been deceived; not Moby Dick casts one odd jet"][[134 14 4] "that way, and then disappears.\""][[134 15 1] "It was even so; in their headlong eagerness, the men had mistaken some"][[134 15 2] "other thing for the whale-spout, as the event itself soon proved; for"][[134 15 3] "hardly had Ahab reached his perch; hardly was the rope belayed to its"][[134 15 4] "pin on deck, when he struck the key-note to an orchestra, that made the"][[134 15 5] "air vibrate as with the combined discharges of rifles. The triumphant"][[134 15 6] "halloo of thirty buckskin lungs was heard, as--much nearer to the ship"][[134 15 7] "than the place of the imaginary jet, less than a mile ahead--Moby Dick"][[134 15 8] "bodily burst into view! For not by any calm and indolent spoutings; not"][[134 15 9] "by the peaceable gush of that mystic fountain in his head, did the White"][[134 15 10] "Whale now reveal his vicinity; but by the far more wondrous phenomenon"][[134 15 11] "of breaching. Rising with his utmost velocity from the furthest depths,"][[134 15 12] "the Sperm Whale thus booms his entire bulk into the pure element of"][[134 15 13] "air, and piling up a mountain of dazzling foam, shows his place to the"][[134 15 14] "distance of seven miles and more. In those moments, the torn, enraged"][[134 15 15] "waves he shakes off, seem his mane; in some cases, this breaching is his"][[134 15 16] "act of defiance."][[134 16 1] "\"There she breaches! there she breaches!\" was the cry, as in his"][[134 16 2] "immeasurable bravadoes the White Whale tossed himself salmon-like to"][[134 16 3] "Heaven. So suddenly seen in the blue plain of the sea, and relieved"][[134 16 4] "against the still bluer margin of the sky, the spray that he raised, for"][[134 16 5] "the moment, intolerably glittered and glared like a glacier; and"][[134 16 6] "stood there gradually fading and fading away from its first sparkling"][[134 16 7] "intensity, to the dim mistiness of an advancing shower in a vale."][[134 17 1] "\"Aye, breach your last to the sun, Moby Dick!\" cried Ahab, \"thy hour and"][[134 17 2] "thy harpoon are at hand!--Down! down all of ye, but one man at the fore."][[134 17 3] "The boats!--stand by!\""][[134 18 1] "Unmindful of the tedious rope-ladders of the shrouds, the men, like"][[134 18 2] "shooting stars, slid to the deck, by the isolated backstays and"][[134 18 3] "halyards; while Ahab, less dartingly, but still rapidly was dropped from"][[134 18 4] "his perch."][[134 19 1] "\"Lower away,\" he cried, so soon as he had reached his boat--a spare one,"][[134 19 2] "rigged the afternoon previous. \"Mr. Starbuck, the ship is thine--keep"][[134 19 3] "away from the boats, but keep near them. Lower, all!\""][[134 20 1] "As if to strike a quick terror into them, by this time being the first"][[134 20 2] "assailant himself, Moby Dick had turned, and was now coming for the"][[134 20 3] "three crews. Ahab's boat was central; and cheering his men, he told them"][[134 20 4] "he would take the whale head-and-head,--that is, pull straight up to his"][[134 20 5] "forehead,--a not uncommon thing; for when within a certain limit, such"][[134 20 6] "a course excludes the coming onset from the whale's sidelong vision."][[134 20 7] "But ere that close limit was gained, and while yet all three boats were"][[134 20 8] "plain as the ship's three masts to his eye; the White Whale churning"][[134 20 9] "himself into furious speed, almost in an instant as it were, rushing"][[134 20 10] "among the boats with open jaws, and a lashing tail, offered appalling"][[134 20 11] "battle on every side; and heedless of the irons darted at him from every"][[134 20 12] "boat, seemed only intent on annihilating each separate plank of which"][[134 20 13] "those boats were made. But skilfully manoeuvred, incessantly wheeling"][[134 20 14] "like trained chargers in the field; the boats for a while eluded him;"][[134 20 15] "though, at times, but by a plank's breadth; while all the time, Ahab's"][[134 20 16] "unearthly slogan tore every other cry but his to shreds."][[134 21 1] "But at last in his untraceable evolutions, the White Whale so crossed"][[134 21 2] "and recrossed, and in a thousand ways entangled the slack of the three"][[134 21 3] "lines now fast to him, that they foreshortened, and, of themselves,"][[134 21 4] "warped the devoted boats towards the planted irons in him; though now"][[134 21 5] "for a moment the whale drew aside a little, as if to rally for a more"][[134 21 6] "tremendous charge. Seizing that opportunity, Ahab first paid out more"][[134 21 7] "line: and then was rapidly hauling and jerking in upon it again--hoping"][[134 21 8] "that way to disencumber it of some snarls--when lo!--a sight more savage"][[134 21 9] "than the embattled teeth of sharks!"][[134 22 1] "Caught and twisted--corkscrewed in the mazes of the line, loose harpoons"][[134 22 2] "and lances, with all their bristling barbs and points, came flashing"][[134 22 3] "and dripping up to the chocks in the bows of Ahab's boat. Only one"][[134 22 4] "thing could be done. and with his"][[134 24 4] "back to it, he now lay for a moment slowly feeling with his flukes from"][[134 24 5] "side to side; and whenever a stray oar, bit of plank, the least chip"][[134 24 6] "or crumb of the boats touched his skin, his tail swiftly drew back, and"][[134 24 7] "came sideways smiting the sea. The Chase.--Third Day."][[135 2 1] "The morning of the third day dawned fair and fresh, and once more the"][[135 2 2] "solitary night-man at the fore-mast-head was relieved by crowds of the"][[135 2 3] "daylight look-outs, who dotted every mast and almost every spar."][[135 3 1] "\"D'ye see him?\" cried Ahab; but the whale was not yet in sight."][[135 4 1] "\"In his infallible wake, though; but follow that wake, that's all. Helm"][[135 4 2] "there; steady, as thou goest, and hast been going. What a lovely day"][[135 4 3] "again! were it a new-made world, and made for a summer-house to the"][[135 4 4] "angels, and this morning the first of its throwing open to them, a"][[135 4 5] "fairer day could not dawn upon that world. Here's food for thought, had"][[135 4 6] "Ahab time to think; but Ahab never thinks; he only feels, feels, feels;"][[135 4 7] "THAT'S tingling enough for mortal man! to think's audacity. God only has"][[135 4 8] "that right and privilege. Thinking is, or ought to be, a coolness and a"][[135 4 9] "calmness; and our poor hearts throb, and our poor brains beat too much"][[135 4 10] "for that. And yet, I've sometimes thought my brain was very calm--frozen"][[135 4 11] "calm, this old skull cracks so, like a glass in which the contents"][[135 4 12] "turned to ice, and shiver it. And still this hair is growing now; this"][[135 4 13] "moment growing, and heat must breed it; but no, it's like that sort"][[135 4 14] "of common grass that will grow anywhere, between the earthy clefts of"][[135 4 15] "Greenland ice or in Vesuvius lava. How the wild winds blow it; they whip"][[135 4 16] "it about me as the torn shreds of split sails lash the tossed ship they"][[135 4 17] "cling to. A vile wind that has no doubt blown ere this through prison"][[135 4 18] "corridors and cells, and wards of hospitals, and ventilated them, and"][[135 4 19] "now comes blowing hither as innocent as fleeces. Out upon it!--it's"][[135 4 20] "tainted. Were I the wind, I'd blow no more on such a wicked, miserable"][[135 4 21] "world. I'd crawl somewhere to a cave, and slink there. And yet, 'tis a"][[135 4 22] "noble and heroic thing, the wind! who ever conquered it? In every fight"][[135 4 23] "it has the last and bitterest blow. Run tilting at it, and you but run"][[135 4 24] "through it. Ha! a coward wind that strikes stark naked men, but will not"][[135 4 25] "stand to receive a single blow. Even Ahab is a braver thing--a nobler"][[135 4 26] "thing than THAT. Would now the wind but had a body; but all the things"][[135 4 27] "that most exasperate and outrage mortal man, all these things are"][[135 4 28] "bodiless, but only bodiless as objects, not as agents. There's a most"][[135 4 29] "special, a most cunning, oh, a most malicious difference! And yet, I"][[135 4 30] "say again, and swear it now, that there's something all glorious and"][[135 4 31] "gracious in the wind. These warm Trade Winds, at least, that in the"][[135 4 32] "clear heavens blow straight on, in strong and steadfast, vigorous"][[135 4 33] "mildness; and veer not from their mark, however the baser currents of"][[135 4 34] "the sea may turn and tack, and mightiest Mississippies of the land swift"][[135 4 35] "and swerve about, uncertain where to go at last. And by the eternal"][[135 4 36] "Poles! these same Trades that so directly blow my good ship on; these"][[135 4 37] "Trades, or something like them--something so unchangeable, and full as"][[135 4 38] "strong, blow my keeled soul along! To it! Aloft there! What d'ye see?\""][[135 5 1] "\"Nothing, sir.\""][[135 6 1] "\"Nothing! and noon at hand! The doubloon goes a-begging! See the sun!"][[135 6 2] "Aye, aye, it must be so. I've oversailed him. How, got the start? Aye,"][[135 6 3] "he's chasing ME now; not I, HIM--that's bad; I might have known it, too."][[135 6 4] "Fool! the lines--the harpoons he's towing. Oh, now I feel my topmost greatness lies in"][[135 60 7] "my topmost grief. Ho, ho! from all your furthest bounds, pour ye now in,"][[135 60 8] "ye bold billows of my whole foregone life, and top this one piled comber"][[135 60 9] "of my death! Towards thee I roll, thou all-destroying but unconquering"][[135 60 10] "whale; to the last I grapple with thee; from hell's heart I stab at"][[135 60 11] "thee; for hate's sake I spit my last breath at thee. Sink all coffins"][[135 60 12] "and all hearses to one common pool! and since neither can be mine, let"][[135 60 13] "me then tow to pieces, while still chasing thee, though tied to thee,"][[135 60 14] "thou damned whale! THUS, I give up the spear!\""][[135 61 1] "The harpoon was darted; the stricken whale flew forward; with igniting"][[135 61 2] "velocity the line ran through the grooves;--ran foul. Ahab stooped to"][[135 61 3] "clear it; he did clear it; but the flying turn caught him round the"][[135 61 4] "neck, and voicelessly as Turkish mutes bowstring their victim, he was"][[135 61 5] "shot out of the boat, ere the crew knew he was gone. Next instant, the"][[135 61 6] "heavy eye-splice in the rope's final end flew out of the stark-empty"][[135 61 7] "tub, knocked down an oarsman, and smiting the sea, disappeared in its"][[135 61 8] "depths."][[135 62 1] "For an instant, the tranced boat's crew stood still; then turned. \"The"][[135 62 2] "ship? Great God, where is the ship?\" Soon they through dim, bewildering"][[135 62 3] "mediums saw her sidelong fading phantom, as in the gaseous Fata Morgana;"][[135 62 4] "only the uppermost masts out of water; while fixed by infatuation, or"][[135 62 5] "fidelity, or fate, to their once lofty perches, the pagan harpooneers"][[135 62 6] "still maintained their sinking lookouts on the sea. And now, concentric"][[135 62 7] "circles seized the lone boat itself, and all its crew, and each floating"][[135 62 8] "oar, and every lance-pole, and spinning, animate and inanimate, all"][[135 62 9] "round and round in one vortex, carried the smallest chip of the Pequod"][[135 62 10] "out of sight."][[135 63 1] "But as the last whelmings intermixingly poured themselves over the"][[135 63 2] "sunken head of the Indian at the mainmast, leaving a few inches of the"][[135 63 3] "erect spar yet visible, together with long streaming yards of the flag,"][[135 63 4] "which calmly undulated, with ironical coincidings, over the destroying"][[135 63 5] "billows they almost touched;--at that instant, a red arm and a hammer"][[135 63 6] "hovered backwardly uplifted in the open air, in the act of nailing"][[135 63 7] "the flag faster and yet faster to the subsiding spar. A sky-hawk that"][[135 63 8] "tauntingly had followed the main-truck downwards from its natural home"][[135 63 9] "among the stars, pecking at the flag, and incommoding Tashtego there;"][[135 63 10] "this bird now chanced to intercept its broad fluttering wing between the"][[135 63 11] "hammer and the wood; and simultaneously feeling that etherial thrill,"][[135 63 12] "the submerged savage beneath, in his death-gasp, kept his hammer frozen"][[135 63 13] "there; and so the bird of heaven, with archangelic shrieks, and his"][[135 63 14] "imperial beak thrust upwards, and his whole captive form folded in the"][[135 63 15] "flag of Ahab, went down with his ship, which, like Satan, would not sink"][[135 63 16] "to hell till she had dragged a living part of heaven along with her, and"][[135 63 17] "helmeted herself with it."][[135 64 1] "Now small fowls flew screaming over the yet yawning gulf; a sullen white"][[135 64 2] "surf beat against its steep sides; then all collapsed, and the great"][[135 64 3] "shroud of the sea rolled on as it rolled five thousand years ago."][[135 68 1] "Epilogue"][[135 69 1] "\"AND I ONLY AM ESCAPED ALONE TO TELL THEE\" Job."][[135 70 1] "The drama's done. Why then here does any one step forth?--Because one"][[135 70 2] "did survive the wreck."][[135 71 1] "It so chanced, that after the Parsee's disappearance, I was he whom the"][[135 71 2] "Fates ordained to take the place of Ahab's bowsman, when that bowsman"][[135 71 3] "assumed the vacant post; the same, who, when on the last day the three"][[135 71 4] "men were tossed from out of the rocking boat, was dropped astern. So,"][[135 71 5] "floating on the margin of the ensuing scene, and in full sight of it,"][[135 71 6] "when the halfspent suction of the sunk ship reached me, I was then,"][[135 71 7] "but slowly, drawn towards the closing vortex. When I reached it, it had"][[135 71 8] "subsided to a creamy pool. Round and round, then, and ever contracting"][[135 71 9] "towards the button-like black bubble at the axis of that slowly wheeling"][[135 71 10] "circle, like another Ixion I did revolve. Till, gaining that vital"][[135 71 11] "centre, the black bubble upward burst; and now, liberated by reason of"][[135 71 12] "its cunning spring, and, owing to its great buoyancy, rising with great"][[135 71 13] "force, the coffin life-buoy shot lengthwise from the sea, fell over, and"][[135 71 14] "floated by my side. Buoyed up by that coffin, for almost one whole day"][[135 71 15] "and night, I floated on a soft and dirgelike main. The unharming sharks,"][[135 71 16] "they glided by as if with padlocks on their mouths; the savage sea-hawks"][[135 71 17] "sailed with sheathed beaks. On the second day, a sail drew near, nearer,"][[135 71 18] "and picked me up at last. It was the devious-cruising Rachel, that in"][[135 71 19] "her retracing search after her missing children, only found another"][[135 71 20] "orphan."]
